review_content: lol oh this hotel.  I second a lot of what the other reviewers said.  But I have to comment on the check in experience.  They gave me the wrong room number.  When I walked into the room, it was definitely someone else's room.  I went back downstairs and they were like oh, THIS is your room (the one next door)So okay, that would be ok.  I get mixups happen.  But for the fact that my friend was also staying at the same hotel.  He goes to check in and they did the same thing to him!  He went back downstairs and was like "you gave me someone else's room"I mean come on.  What if we walked in on ugly people having sex.  I would have been scarred for life.  (Not if they were hot people, maybe they need a third) Okay, this review is taking a turn for the worst.Anyway.  They need to get that straightened out.Upon check out, they said they needed my room key back.  I literally could not find it anywhere.  I had a ton of bags.  I may have even left it in the room.  I didn't even find it when I unpacked when I got home.  The guy at the front desk said "We need it for security reasons" at which point I kind of snarkily said "How secure could it be if you give people the wrong room numbers" but he did not find this amusing.This is a horrible hotel. The neighborhood is not safe. The bed was pretty bad, and the sheets seemed old. The towels had holes in them. The bathroom etc is also substandard. Outside the hotel, the area seems really sketch.Envy Hotel couldn't produce a clean LOOKING sheet - much less an actually clean bed linen - to save its life. When I checked in, my bed was riddled with black curly hairs. Honestly, if it had been one I would've brushed it away and moved on. There were 4 or 5 hairs in BOTH beds in my room. I was grossed out.I called the front desk, asked for clean sheets, and was informed all the housekeeping staff had gone home for the night. I would have to wait a couple hours until the night laundry person came in. Fine. More than 2 hours after this call its 9:30 and I still have hairy sheets. I call again and am told if I want the sheets I have to put them on myself. Ridiculous, but okay, I guess.The guy at the front desk brings a stack of sheets with MORE HAIR AND STAINS THAN THE ONES I ALREADY HAVE.Out of a bargain hotel, the absolute minimum requirement for me is a bed I can sleep in without my skin crawling. Minimum requirement not met.If you can avoid it at any cost, don't stay here. I know why it's called Envy Hotel now...I'm envious of the people in every other hotel in Baltimore.I have worked in the hospitality business my whole life and what I experienced at The Envy during my stay on Saturday, August 2nd 2015 was embarrassing to the entire hotel industry. I made reservations at your hotel as a social event brought us to the area for the evening. My wife and I checked in, walked into our room, 711, and upon entering the bathroom I was mortified to see a cockroach on the bathroom floor, big and dead.  After flushing it down the toilet I walked out to explore the rest of the room.  What we found was upsetting. There were stains on the bed sheets, the chair and both (two) towels we were given looked like they had black make-up on them. The thermostat was not working. Most hotels have fan coil units as an HVAC system but I was surprised to see window PTAC units in this property.  The PTAC unit itself would have been acceptable, however the design of the installation caused an airflow problem so we had to keep the blinds open or the cold air wouldn't circulate.  The room was filthy and disgusting; there were dust balls on the carpet, water ring marks on the nightstand and the public areas were just poorly maintained from a cleanliness perspective -- I think I know where they cockroaches came from.  The elevator floors were very dirty and sticky and the ice machine area was so nasty I almost threw up.  I took quite a few pictures, like the one attached of the ice machine area representative of the level of filth we endured. I even attempted to charge my phone and none of the electric outlets in the room worked.  I went down to the front desk to inform the associate of status of the room, especially the cockroach, and he said, "Oh, we haven't had a complaint about roaches in a long time."  He then continued to offer his apologies and an insulting 10% discount, which I accepted at the time but the more I think if it the more infuriated I get over the condition of this hotel that I paid over $200 for. I have reached out to management and have not yet received any communication back -- a month later.  This place is bad -- B-A-D.I didn't pay much for this hotel room because I booked it in conjunction with my flight.  I wasn't expecting much.  I had stayed in the area before so I knew it was probably best to stay vigilant.  I was only staying there for one night.  It was January and the room was ice cold.  I turned up the thermostat, showered, and left for the night.  When I returned, my room still didn't feel warm, so I played with the thermostat some more and went to bed.  The room never warmed.  It was an awful uncomfortable night.  They don't even have comforters on the bed, so it was me, my body heat, and a blanket.  I probably would have faired better sleeping over a steam grate.I booked on Hotwire (first time trying that out) and I paid a mere $51 per night for a great location. What could go wrong? And what does someone expect for $51? A clean room, right? Not much else.I stayed in room 216 for future reference. The staff were pleasant and the breakfast area was well-stocked with sausage patties and scrambled eggs (from a powder stock.) There were also pastries and cereals, and some fresh fruit. Not so bad for the money. Now for the bad news. My room was in great disrepairs. The bed frame itself was broken (if I had brought my spouse I would have had it fixed or changed rooms.) With one person, it rocked only when I was getting in/out of bed.The bathroom was gross. They installed a type of wood flooring that's very difficult to properly clean -- it had fairly wide cracks. The inside of the shower had a lot of mould along the inside rim that would flake off and run down the drain. The shower door barely worked. Whole thing was weird; it was likely supposed to be trendy. The walls and ceilings in the bathroom were fairly extensively water damaged (photo.)And there was *a chicken bone* on the floor when I came in (photo.) Welcome, here are some animal parts! I actually went out and bought some cleaning supplies, and gave the room a once over before turning in. I thought the room had a weird smell, but I also smelled it outside the room. So the ventilation system had a bad smell, apparently.Would not stay again.you get what you pay for.  My room was clean.  The elevators didnt work though so that sucked being on the 4th floor.  Breakfast was fine.Its not the hilton or marriott but its centrally located and it was safe.  For 90 bucks you couldnt beat it.Ugh... This place...- Window AC, cardboard and duct tape used to "close" opening around it!- Toilet seat falling off, took a coin and 10 seconds to maintain for them!- Shower spraying all over.- Elevator skips floors.- Breakfast is half empty with space for things never put out.- Bathroom has very odd smell.- All vending machines empty 3 days.- Shady area out front, harassed for change every time I walked in or out.  If you live in an urban area, it's the usual.- Laundry in hall for days.- Closet storing luggage left wide open in lobby.I've stayed in worse, but this one is pretty close to the bottom.I should have known when I checked in and the guy at the front desk was wearing a skully (winter hat) 70 degrees outside. When we took the elevator up it was making noises and was about 90 degrees same with the hallways. Our room looked ok at first glance. Then we looked around...... Stains on the curtains hair in the beds. (Both of them) sink was dirty, the tub dirty.  Weird metal plate over the threshold of the bathroom every time you walk over it seems like it will cave in and makes a load crunching sound. Water pressure very low, no hot water. Then to make matters worse when we came back to the hotel at 2am after going to power plant live (very fun) we got stuck in the elevator for 40 minutes before the fire department came to save us because the employees there could not.  The phone in the elevator kept ringing the front desk but you couldn't understand what the employee was saying to you. I now have a fear of small places. Never did before... Not once did any of the employees, manager contact me to say sorry you where stuck in the elevator. I wouldn't recommend this hotel to anyone. They did offer free breakfast I was told it was in the basement after walking up and down 6 flights of stairs several times I was not interested in try that.  Then when checking out I wanted to voice my troubles to someone I was told by the front desk employee she was the only one working and couldn't make any decisions she was pretty shaken from being yelled at from the people In front of me and wrote down My complaints on the same paper with theirs. The elevator was down still from me and my friend getting stuck In it 5 hours earlier even though I wouldn't have taken it In the morning people where all I the hallways complaining. The stairs are dirty and steep and scary.... Ill stop with this I was told I'd get a call back either sat or Sunday and still haven't heard from management.....I suppose I could be spoiled with staying at great places but the quality of this hotel is shameful. Every area including the breakfast room is 80 degrees, even with the air conditioner on (it's not even that hot outside yet today) the receptionist was VERY nice but she told me to walk down the block in the middle of the night for toothpaste and she had to use her own wallet to give me change for a $5 bill so I could get a bottle water (which they don't provide u a comp one in the room and I had to visit 3 floors to find a vending machine that wasn't soldOut) the threshold to the bathroom was metal that popped in and out EVERYTIME I stepped on it which made a loud noise and would make me jump bc I got scared EVERYTIME bc it's so loud. Hahaha.  The parking garage is also not attached to the hotel and I had to walk a block with my suitcase in the middle of the night to get to the hotel. Kinda scary. The breakfast bar is shameful. Not one healthy thing to eat, they didn't even have peanut butter. Tjere were empty trays saying eggs and sausage which they never filled and weren't in the middle of making another batch bc there was only one other person in there eating. Worst comp breakfast at a hotel I've ever seen. The only positive is the beds are more comfortable than most other hotels. In fact I canceled my second night stay here bc it is not very accommodating.Place is horrible. It's cheap and we're only here for one night so thank God for that. The elevators are disgusting. Sticky mess. Our room is small and there wasn't any toiletries. I went down to the front desk to ask for some and he didn't even look for any. He said "don't got none." Later I go to the soda machine and my $5 bill isn't accepted so I go downstairs and ask the guy for change (he was laying down on the sofa and watching television) every time I go to the front desk he huffs and puffs like I'm bothering him to the point where I feel uncomfortable. I ask him for change "we don't got none" is his popular answer of the night. I was like "are you kidding me? I wanna get a soda outta the machine." "Don't got none" he says again like he was happy to inconvenience me. Bottom line is -this place is horrible. I'd actually rather spend time at one of those flea bag hotels on route 40 than this place again. The location is in a good spot. My girlfriend and I waked to fells point and back and it was 4 miles in total. Nice leisurely exercise. As far as this place -spend an extra $40 and stay at the Sheraton hotel. I will never come back to this place again. You shouldn't either. It's disgusting and the hospitality (if you can call it that) is absolutely dreadful.If you're used to staying in suburbs, this place may make you uncomfortable.  It's an old building redone in an edgy, modern way.  It's in the middle of downtown giving you great access lots of interesting restaurants, clubs, and attractions.  Yes, being downtown means the people along the sidewalk will ask you for change and parking is probably an issue (we took a cab).The rooms are small with small windows.  Ventilation in the hallways is lacking a bit, but it wasn't an issue in our room.  Breakfast is in a small room in the basement, but includes all the standards hot free help-yourself hotel breakfast favorites.  This is a good downtown option to the expensive glass towers. The shortcomings are made up for with character.My wife and I stayed here in September 2013 for a long weekend. If you're looking for an inexpensive hotel within walking distance of major Baltimore attractions and/or public transportation, this hotel is a fine value.  We relied upon the area light rail system to get from BWI airport to the hotel. We also walked to Baltimore's harbor area and then used water taxis to visit the Fells Point area and Fort McHenry.Two items I would mention to anyone considering staying here: The rooms are clean, but small. This hotel is also located near the border of downtown and a not-so-great surrounding area.WE WERE LOCKED IN THE ROOM AND THEY HAD TO DRILL OPEN THE DOOR TO GET US OUT!My boyfriend and I booked this hotel online and got an amazing price, since he's from Baltimore I thought we scored a deal. Now I have a lot of patience when it comes to service because I deal with people every day however after the first night I could no longer be patient. I arrived in Baltimore at noon and asked about early check in and they said no without even checking if a room was open, we had to wait in the cold for hours before being able to check in. I didn't complain, I understand things happen, when we were finally able to check in we had no blanket and only one towel. We called down to get a blanket and towel and no one answered, we went downstairs and they said they would send someone up and no one came. We had to call again for them to actually send someone up, while waiting we found underwear in the dressers next to our beds ... We were utterly disgusted. Finally room service came up and the deadbolt on the door got stuck, we were not able to open the door from either side. The man at the desk began to yell at us like it was our fault ... After an hour and a half, a lock smith and a general manager, we finally were able to get out. The next day we went down for breakfast they told us it was from 6:30 to 10am we went down at 9 and there was no more food left and the lady said they weren't going to put out anymore. When I stayed at the marriott they put in fresh food every half hour and continued to put food out until the last half hour. The service here is crappy, the area isn't that great, the hotel is right in font of a local bus stop and there are people standing in front of the hotel constantly, dirty sheets in front of the vending machines, broken elevators, and bathrooms  smell of mold... I will conclude with this ... if you can get a room for 50 bucks that's great, you get what you pay for but don't pay anything more then that when you can stay at another hotel for the same price .... You will be disappointed.Not only was this place gross and sleazy, but they charged several hundred dollars to my card for a "smoking fee" fraudulently! While they are close to downtown, I would not think of them as conveniently located unless you consider proximity to boarded up strip clubs "convenient." The staff were blatantly rude and unhelpful while I was staying there. I've tried, repeatedly, to get back the money they charged me for "smoking" (I did no such thing, btw), but not surprisingly they refuse to return my calls or e-mails. I called Best Western headquarters, who told me that this place is no longer part of their chain so they couldn't help me. Stay away unless you are looking to pick up bed bugs!Abysmal customer service. Upon checking in, the hotel discovered they had overbooked double rooms and the two double rooms we had booked 10 months prior were now NOT available to us. They provided us with 2 single rooms and promised a 10% discount and a lower room rate upon checking out.The room my boyfriend and I stayed in was okay. Typical mediocre hotel room. A/C worked and that was good enough for me. However, our friend's room (and whole floor) lacked A/C which is unacceptable for Baltimore in August. Luckily for him, the weekend's weather was mild but it was still incredibly humid and uncomfortable in his room during the day.Check out day was by far the worst experience I've ever had in a hotel. My boyfriend handed the woman (an employee I hadn't seen the entire stay) our key. She responded with, "Ok, you're checked out." We requested a receipt as it had never been clear what we were going to be paying after the initial mess-up. To our INCREDIBLE DISAPPOINTMENT AND ANGER, we were given a receipt totaling our stay around $1100 which is $200 more than what we were expecting to pay with 2 DOUBLE hotel rooms!!!! No discount was applied and no lower room rates were given. We immediately asked what was wrong and the (now frustrated with us) employee got her manager.Who we assume was the manager (he did not introduce himself) came down and a confusing dialogue ensued. He didn't know what the hotel's rates were, made my boyfriend bring up his original reservation e-mail so he could figure out the rates himself on a calculator and provided us with little to no solution. He took around $140 off of our bill, still higher than our original double room reservation and offered no more help. He told us he couldn't take any discounts off (the 10% or the AAA discount my boyfriend has for participating hotels) and sent us on our way.Along with the other small problems that piled up (no A/C on a floor, out of stock soda machine all weekend, elevator doors that slam into you with no motion sensor, room service who walks into your room unprompted, sewage pipe smell in bathrooms) none of us will ever be staying at a Best Western ever again, and especially not this location.I advise anyone who likes a quick, easy check in/out and fair rates to go somewhere else. I come to Baltimore once a year, every year, for Otakon and while that won't be changing anytime soon, my hotel location next year will.this place sucks!!! we booked a room here 6 weeks ago we have a con # and everything. good thing we called to check because they had not record of us booking with them. They said they had room available but wanted to charge us 2x what we had been confirmed for. when i asked to speak to a manager there was not one on staff and is 2:00 pm in the afternoon!!! dont book unless you want to worry about not having somewhere to stay on vacation!!!Nice room in an OK location in Baltimore. It was really difficult to find at first. If your driving down the street there are no signs that scream this is a hotel. I had to park my car and walk up and down the street until i saw a little sign that said Best Western. Check in was easy, rooms were clean, and the bed was comfortable. One big downfall was there was no parking but fortunatley on the weekends there is parking around the courthouse for free. Great location right near the harbor and only a mile walk to federal hill and a short cab ride to fells point. All in all i would stay here again.The location is alright. I had a difficult time finding the hotel and had to drive around it twice to eventually find some decent parking. The entrance is right next to a bus stop so it's really crowded in front of the hotel. I tried calling the front desk as I was driving around to ask for parking, but the line was busy. When I eventually walked into the lobby, I found the front desk guy on a personal call. Figures.The rooms are clean and look recently renovated. No complaints there. One thing that irked me was when I went to the lobby for some toothpaste, they told me they ran out and I had to walk three blocks to the 7-11 at night. I guess you could argue it was my fault for not having any toothpaste on me or for checking in so late. But you have to wonder...what kind of hotel doesn't carry any extra toothpaste on them? What else are they missing in their inventory?My experience overall was okay. I may or may not use their services again. I haven't made up my mind yet.Was charged for 2 additional nights after I checked out.  When I called about the overcharge - absolutely rude customer service - no apology & still have not recieved the credit.  Decent hotel, very old with what seems to have had a very small cosmetic update, and the staff is terrible.  When I checked out, the front desk person was dressed like he was going out to a club, was sitting on the lobby couch, got up and took 10 minutes to print me a receipt.  Which he ultimately could not do.  All in all - I DO NOT RECOMMEND!

Wonderful hotel. Great location and priced rooms. The front desk staff were very welcoming. Briana and her co-worker, I didn't get her name :(, we very attentive. We they asked our reason for travel, we said it was our anniversary. They congratulated us and said they wanted to do something special for us.We went to lunch and came back to a bottle of Prosecco on ice. That was so thoughtful. The rooms are nice and the bed is super comfy. We will definitely be back.Hotel Indigo was a surprising gem in Mt. Vernon. The decor was pleasing but the showstoppers are the wonderful staff which make your experience friendly and lighthearted.I enjoyed Kim and Briana as soon as we walked in they took care of all our concerns quickly and efficiently. 4/5 stars because while the hotel is pet friendly it's guests are not pet considerate. I walked back up to our room with a "present" in the hallway from one of the floors dogs.Also arriving would be a little less stressful IF the hotel provided Valet services. Tone on such a busy street I would think a service like Valet would be a no brainier. It is cumbersome to circle the block for parking. Although the garage is right across the street, sadly it is on the opposite corner and Franklin is a one way. overall I had a great stay and would definitely go back or recommend !Such a wonderful hotel!!! I stayed here for a month.This was my second time coming to Baltimore for work and I thought that the previous hotel I stayed at was amazing but this place shits on them. When we first arrived at the hotel, we walked in and everyone that worked there looked like they actually enjoyed their jobs. A really nice change for once! The check in process was really fast and we actually got to check in about 6 hours before check in time which was greatly appreciated after a long flight from San Francisco.ROOMS:- clean- good size- Aveda shampoo & conditioner (which had a great scent!)- hair dryer- iron- mini fridge (tiny freezer)- complimentary Keurig coffee & tea- cable TV- fast and free wifi- pets allowed - comfortable beds- powerful shower head - room service with delicious food! Try the bean burger.HOTEL/NEIGHBORHOOD: - not too expensive based on the service and rooms you're paying for- fruit water in the lobby which is delicious!- good sized gym with pretty much everything you need (yoga mats, weights, elliptical, etc)-restaurant downstairs with great food and drinks!-lounge type area with plenty of seats - safe neighborhood with a supermarket up the street (mt vernon supermarket) if you need anything such as wine, snacks, etc. 5 minute walk. Or a 7 eleven around the corner.- plenty of great restaurants nearby. (try doobys for something different!)- 5 minute uber ride to inner harbor (about $4) Highly recommend this hotel! Definitely staying here next time I'm in Baltimore for work.This is a newly renovated property. Stayed in an upgraded room on the 8th floor with lovely city views. Nice decor. Two flat screens, sitting area, large comfy bed, modern wardrobe, hidden fridge. Tv near sitting area is poorly placed as the only place to actually see it would be if you sat on edge of couch. Bathroom was nice, however, the porous shower floor was not cleaned well (there was visible dirt)Everything else was so nice it did not ruin my night. We did report the issue to front desk and received comp breakfast. Restaurant had major issues (separate review) so we didn't actually receive breakfast. I would recommend this hotel and am likely to return for a staycation.This hotel is very nice and modern! The lobby is spacious and you will also find the restaurant/bar (Poets) to your right. The front desk agent was very nice when we arrived and provided us with a free upgrade that was available which was beautiful! We found a great price on ihg.com and I was excited to book here! We only stayed one night. We brought our dogs ($25 fee-less than many) and there were some small nearby parks about a block or two away which was nice to walk the dogs. It was also nice to see dog bowls filled with some small dog treats and water outside of the facility. I enjoyed seeing the hard wood floors in the room as well which is not common. I absolutely loved the pillows in the room too, I want to buy them! One thing I didn't care for was the parking. It was across the street in a parking garage and I was told it was $5 for my stay. However, I parked and then left (within 30 minutes), and then came back by 11pm and left by 9am the next day and was charged another $10 ($5 per day). The garage is paid by using the machines and when I asked a worker about the price, it was clear he did not understand me. So the only way out was to pay. I know the hotel said they can charge you instead on your room bill and provide you a way to get in and out of the garage, which I would do next time if I stayed here to avoid any extra fees. Personally, the area this hotel is in (Mt. Vernon) is not where I preferably be as I felt it was sort of far from places I may want to see (stadium area, bars and inner harbor). However, it is very pretty and many cathedrals and churches are nearby. They also have a historic map you can view around the block. In the morning, we got cappuccinos to go at Poets which took longer than they should have but it felt like the employee forgot about our order until someone must have mentioned we were still waiting. He did apologize for the delay too. Overall, we had a fantastic stay and truly enjoyed this hotel and would come back again!What a surprise!! Only got to stay for one night, but this place made me feel right at home* with its quirky, hipster-esque decor (see pics!). Staff was friendly, hotel was quiet on a Tuesday night.Minus one star for no in-room fridge, which I guess it was supposed to have but we looked everywhere for it so it was hidden far too well, or missing. Room 413 was otherwise a delight, comfy sofa, two flat screens, great bed with quality linens, and a roll-in shower.Highly recommend, and will be where I stay if I ever make it back to Baltimore!*Portland, OR. Portlandia is fairly accurate.Quick 12 minute walk to Brewer's Art and fast drive to the inner harbor. Love the downstairs bar area and lobby! The room was comfortable and the decor was amazing! Love the splash of orange throughout. Parking was only $5 a day in the garage across from the hotel. Looking forward to coming back!Great hotel with friendly service, unique decor, and wonderful Aveda products in the room. The location is close enough to walk to many sights, though if you're going out at night it's probably best to take a cab for safety's sake. Many interesting bars and restaurants within walking distance or a $10 cab ride away.Love this downtown hotel!! Great staff, great location... Brianna and Kim at the front desk are wonderful with customer care and Tom makes a great cocktail!This place is great! We stay here every time we are in the Baltimore area. It's been awhile and when we came back this time we were quite surprised. The whole place has been remodeled and upgraded. The decor is beautiful, the beds and pillows are fabulous, the shower is great, and the staff continues to be super friendly. Also, free wifi. There are two public parking garages within a block (one almost across the street) and the prices are great (we paid $6 for 24 hours). Definitely recommend staying here on your visit.I was suuuuper skeptical to book this hotel based on the number of reviews and the newness of the hotel. We arrived and it was very chic! The front desk staff was very nice and accommodating. When we go to our room we were very pleased with the modern and sleek layout. Everything in the room is brand new and they even have a Keurig machine for complimentary coffee. There was a cute boutique where I found an amazing dress. On top of everything, the parking across the street is only $11. I was going stay at a hotel that was much expensive and I'm so glad I kept some $$ in my pocket.Booked a room two weeks ago through Expedia at a very affordable price. I wouldn't call it a five star hotel, but certainly great for what you pay for. Showed up five hours before checkin, and was allowed to check in early at no additional cost. Amenities were clean and well kept. Room offered everything you could want - a spacious, clean bathroom, a large, comfortable bed, a decent sized television(which I actually never got a chance to use), plenty of lights and outlets, and a USB charging port on the desk.Wish my stay was longer to utilize the room longer. The staff held my bags free of cost the next day as I watched the Oriole's game. Will be my first choice depending on room availability when I go back.Just left an industry meeting at Hotel Indigo. The food was amazing and the staff was so on point. I love the orange infused water in the lobby, the decor is so chic. The food I couldn't get enough. Many different items to try tonight and I loved them all. Oh the management team answered all my questions perfectly. From the time I walked in and left Robert at the door was great as well. One minor issue we had a small shortage of forks ..,But overall 5 stars and let's bring Hotel Indigo more businessNot quite 4 stars, more like 3 and 3/4..I must say, when I drove up to this place I was not too thrilled. It is in an ok neighborhoodbut far from the type of area one would want to go out and take a stroll.. The hotel is a newlyrenovated old YMCA.. Self parking is available across the street and it was cheap. The interior of the hotel was much nicer then you would expect from the looks on the outside. Check in was smooth and the lobby/ bar area was active and had a good vibe. The elevators were fast which is always a plus in my book. My room while not huge was new and fresh. The bathroom was really nice, and the room was spotless. I booked the room on hotwire, and for the price I paidI was happy.The hotel was really nice. The rooms and bathroom were very clean. It's a neat converted historic building. Would definitely stay here again. The rooms are small, but everything is new and nice. Check in was great and the lady who served breakfast was awesome! Only downside, was that whatever they cleaned the bathroom with had a very strong perfume smell.It's taken me a while to think about how I'd like to phrase my review, or for that matter how I'd even write it because it's a doosey. I think the easiest way will be to copy and paste an email I sent the general manager after my rather horrific stay. I will also include the response of the general manager. As of today 8/13/15 the matter has not been settled and the account has yet to be credited.Dear Jason, First allow me to say that I send this email without looking for any kind of compensation. To be completely honest with you even a comped hotel stay wouldn't do me any good as I only come to Baltimore once a year. I also feel compelled to tell you that I'm going to leave my review with both positives (few that there where) and negatives online. Now allow me to start with the positives. Check in was handled and quickly and smoothly as any I've ever experienced. Our bellhop, who I must admit I didn't get the name of, was the model of efficiency. Tiffany was friendly and helpful. That was about all the good that came from Thursday. We were told that we'd be the first ones to stay in our room, looking back on it now it was almost a warning.Problem #1 Thursday (5 minutes after check in)- Key cards don't work - time #1Problems #2 -4 Thursday (7 minutes after check in)- No glasses or coffee cups for the room. This one could've easily NOT happened with just a little attention to detail.- No room service menu. Annoying but not the end of the world.- Phone line was full of static and didn't work (hence me having to go back downstairs AGAIN). That's THREE trips in less than ten minutes to the front desk.Problem #5 (20 minutes after check-in) This was dangerous and potentially lethal.- The shower isn't properly sealed. My girlfriend stepped out of the shower to find an absolute lake of water all over the bathroom floor. Problem #6 (Yes, we're STILL on the first night of our stay at the hotel) Key cards don't work again (that's twice)Problem #7 Friday morning 7:20 am- Room service debacle. Where to start on this one? Breakfast was 50 minutes late, the order was wrong, it arrived without bacon or our bread options being toasted, and after three attempts we just gave up on getting ketchup. Now for the quality of the meal. The eggs were inedible due in large part to the repugnant cheese used in the omelette. The hashbrowns tasted like they were coated in salt, they definitely would've been better with some ketchup but well....we see how that request wentProblem #8 Friday evening- Came back to a "serviced" room. Still no glasses and this time ONE coffee cup for two people. Improvement??? I mean really how difficult was this one detail to get right? At least the keycards worked right? Well they did up until midnight when I stepped out to grab something from 7-11. Please don't tell me about demagnetizing the cards because it worked when we came in, and when I went out later that night I didn't even take me wallet only a $20 (So that makes FOUR, count em four times our cards stopped working.Problem #9 Saturday evening. - This one could've ended in criminal charges or someone getting seriously hurt. This is the one bit of single incompetence that not only made me furious but had me calling the police. 6 guests,COUNT THEM 6, were locked out of the hotel at 2 am for approximately twenty minutes!!!! The front door just refused to open for ALL of our keycards, and there was NO ONE on duty at the front desk or answering the phones (I have the call logs to prove it) for TWENTY MINUTES!!!! That's inexcusable and borderline criminal. What would've happened if someone needed to get inside for medical reason or if the homeless guy bothering us outside would've turned violent? What if it were my girlfriend that was trapped outside and not me??? Oh and who finally let us in? The person from the front desk? No, it was another guest who'd come downstairs to buy something but couldn't because THERE WAS NO ONE AT THE FRONT DESK FOR TWENTY MINUTES! So when I finally get upstairs I have to come right back down again because you guessed it my keycard doesn't work again. After looking around I FINALLY find someone who tells me "Oh that door doesn't work at night." If that's the case maybe, just maybe you mention it to your guests or I don't know make sure someone is staffing the door. Inexcusable, unforgivable negligence. Problem #10 Sunday morning around 2:30 am- Room hadn't been serviced. Trash hadn't been taken out, we're back to ZERO clean coffee cups as we used one that morning, still no glasses for water. At this point I'm still furious from being trapped outside and then I walk into this. Seriously how hard is it to pay attention to the details? Oh and before you ask, no we didn't put a do not disturb sign on our door because we didn't have one, I guess it went the same place as our glasses and room service menu!Problem #11 Sunday eveningI'm at my character limit, I will try to continueBrand new hotel still having teething problems. Breakfast on a Sunday took over an hour with 15-minute waits between visits from the one waiter on duty. Other tables gave up and left. No room cleaning service for first 48 hours there. Rooms are fine though.What an amazing hotel! The space recently was renovated and every part of it is impeccable. The rooms are spacious with cathedral ceilings and the windows are huge with incredible views of the city. It's also in the most ideal location to conveniently explore downtown Baltimore. The staff is extremely friendly and the food is great! Try the Lexington Market Salad...it's delicious!Fabulous restaurant and bar! Very stylish decor, original cocktails and tasty food. Quite the local hotspot! Reminiscent of the days when hotel bars were chicest watering holes in town.Stayed for a few nights at the Indigo in September 2015. If not for a terrible "service" experience in the dining area, I would've said its a great place to stay.The Good:- beautifully renovated lobby- nice rooms- reasonably pricedThe Bad- I called the hotel ahead of my stay inquiring how late can I park my car in the garage across the street. The girl on the phone responded it's 24/7. When I tried parking my car at 12:30am, I was annoyed to find the garage closed. I expect the hotel to provide accurate info here, last thing I want to do is search for parking at 1am...- While getting breakfast in the hotel restaurant I came across perhaps the worst waitress in my memory. She never said a word to me or my girlfriend, and simply handed us the menus. When she couldn't make out my girlfriend's order, she simply said "Huh?", and gave her a dirty look. Half way through our meal, I was getting the waitress's attention that she never got us our napkins. My "excuse me" was met with "whatchaneed?" response. If I wanted to get ghetto service, I'd stay at a motel 6, but I certainly expected more from Indigo. I work close to the hotel, but would not be staying there again. It's a shame, since people like that waitress give Baltimore a bad name.
review_content_20: Absolutely amazing! So amazing in fact I considered writing a bad review so no one else would come here to keep the rates down lol. I lived in Baltimore for 30 years I know this city like the back of my hand. I now live in Florida but this will be my go to hotel when I come back to visit! Perfectly located, and honestly hands down the best staff I've ever encountered. I can't say enough about this place. I vote for a sixth star.This hotel is great. Everything top notch, first class. The interior designer and team did an outstanding job. Management should be recognised for a great job and forward thinking vision. Go for a larger room its worth it.What a complete overhaul!!!!! The place looks awsome and very upscale. Went to a private party in the Library space. Appatizers were good and the crab dip was delicious. Will visit  again for cocktails.Absolutely beautiful! Staff is super friendly and I have never stayed in a cleaner hotel! my husband and I stay in hotels frequently and this is by far the #1. We will be sure to recommend and return. Thank you to much everyone at hotel indigo for making this such an enjoyable experience for us.My husband and I were very skeptical about booking a room at Hotel Indigo based on old reviews on various websites. Having lived in the Baltimore area for over 2 years, I knew the hotel was in a great area of the city (historic Mount Vernon). So going off more recent pictures and reviews, we decided to book. And we are so glad we did! I'm assuming they are now under new ownership, based on the updates and previous reviews. The design of the hotel is modern beautiful and we could not be happier with our stay. We were even able to bring our pup along with us. I would definitely recommend this hotel!Excellent! Newly opened, clean, nice amenities, friendly staff, great location. Parking across the street was $11. Overall, I was extremely happy with this hotel and will definitely stay again.

review_content: Kinda embarassing because I'm better then this. No offense. But I honestly just needed somewhere to put makeup on really fast and take a fast shower and I didn't wanna book a expensive room downtown Baltimore. So I went here. They say "non smoking" in the rooms but it's smells like hella smoke. I paid 40$ for an hour just to get ready. Grosssss. Maybe I'm overreacting idkA cheap motel in downtown Baltimore with a friendly staff. Not far from the Harbor and about a 10 min drive from the nightlife area. If you have a vehicle, you'll need to park it street side but be aware of the time limit. The staff was friendly enough to give us their business parking spot to park longer than the time allotted.This motel is a good place just to crash if you need something last minute. The bed was uncomfortable, but overall an alright place.I got a great deal on a 3 night stay at this hotel via a popular mystery hotel discount site two months in advance. Called a few days before check-in to confirm my reservation, and was told that for the dates I'd be staying, the hotel was overbooked by 5 reservations. Good thing I called ahead; would have been awful to travel 200+ miles, check in, & be told that there's no vacancy. Managed to get my reservation cancelled, and found a much nicer hotel for my trip.There are countless reviews on several sites regarding how awful this place is, and it's obvious the owners aren't taking any of them into consideration. The biggest red flags- lots of reviews state that there's no air conditioning, and that the water pressure in the showers is very, very low. Those two things are inexcusable during the summer. Stay here at your own risk."You get what you pay for" is a fair assessment of this place. It's the cheapest in the city, but also incredibly run down and exudes an incredible "we don't care" atmosphere. The check-in and reservation went surprisingly smoothly. No problems here. Our room was on the first floor, and wasn't as small as other reviewers have reported. Pretty clean actually, no signs of bugs or rodents. But the general look/decor looked like something from a 70s porno. We both took a shower together on the first night but didn't receive replacement towels or have the stall cleaned until several days later. Admittedly, the two of us don't shower that often so it didn't bother us, but hey that'd be a BIG deal to other people.The shower itself actually was a pleasant surprise. Good pressure and hot water. The bathroom in general sucked though on account of how loud the vent fan was. Like, loud as in if you were in the bathroom and someone yelled to you from the room, you couldn't hear them.The wifi network 'Rodeway 1' listed in their welcome brochure doesn't exist. We had to ask them later on about it, and they revealed that we should use 'Rodeway 2' if 1 wasn't appearing, despite it needing a password. Fortunately they told us the password, and internet worked fine rest of the trip.Originally we only had four channels available, all staticky. Randomly on the second night, a satellite box appeared in our room while we were out, so that's cool. Unfortunately, it was DISH Network, trollolol. After this, most things went pretty smoothly.The biggest specific complaint we had was the lack of water/drinkable fluids. We drink a lot of water. Yet there were no water fountains, and just the one ice machine. They had a small pitcher of ice water in the semi-kitchen breakfast area at the front, but it was left out all day and we felt bad drinking all of it. I mean theoretically we could've tried drinking the tap water from the bathroom, but Iiiiiii doubt anyone would trust that stuff. There was only one fridge in the entire hotel, a mini-fridge in the aforementioned breakfast area, though it was communal and anyone can go in there. So basically, unless you brought a ton of your own drinks, you're gonna die of thirst. (Especially considering their heat was forced-air, and thus the entire building was dry as hell, wreaking havoc on your skin/chapped lips)Lastly, the bed wasn't terrible, but the comforter was made of some odd, semi-fabric semi-plasticky material that made you feel like you were being asphyxiated while under it. We've no idea what it was, could've contained frigging asbestos for all we know.In conclusion: If you're poor and want to spend as little as possible on a trip to Baltimore, this place  DOES get the job done and will save you a lot of money. But absolutely expect the worst hotel imaginable when you do so.BONUS: The 'continental breakfast' was cereal and some wonderbread. Bravo.This was the worst hotel stay I have ever experienced. It's located in a great part of town and looks good from the pictures online. Lessons were learned on this stay.It was cheap at 69.00 per night. We stayed for two nights visiting Baltimore with my family who came in from Michigan. Upon arrival we were greeted with very hospitable staff. When we got to the rooms, everything went downhill. My husband and I walked into our room and got smacked with a stale odor. The carpet looked dirty enough that I was not going barefoot. Ceiling light had one light bulb. The bathroom smelled of mold. The shower head was broken with the sprinkler head on the floor. The water shot out like a laser jet the size of a pencil. It made for an unsatisfying shower after the 95+ degree days sight seeing . The towels were thin torn rags.Next to the only chair in the room was a mouse trap and extension cord with too many plugs for the ref rig that rattled, the TV on DISH with 3 channels, and room space heater. The breakfast was an added let down. Cereal and bagels were available, but stale. And the milk was outdated by 4 days. The coffee was the only thing worth pouring.Look for someplace else to stay. The mantra of "you buy cheap, you get cheap" clearly fits here.worst hotel experience of my life. DO NOT STAY HERE!!!i booked a room here 2 years ago with a friend. the booking was pretty vague so we didn't know what the bed setup was going to be. turns out it was just one bed. my friend opted to stay on the floor all weekend. they gave us a room on the top floor and we had to go up some weird narrow stairways to get up to it and it was really hot up there. we called the front desk and they said they had central air so we asked them to turn the temperature down in our room but it never happened (we called 2 or 3 times). they claim they have sattelite tv but only maybe one channel came in. also, the shower was a joke, it was just a trickle of water coming out of the showerhead, seems pretty unsanitary, i don't know how they are allowed to operate like this, it should be fixed or this place should be shut down. i had another set of friends get a room there the same weekend. well i should say a few rooms because they had issues and kept requesting to be moved. the first room had the same shower issue as ours and then they got moved to the basement and had a working shower but there were a few other issues with the room that i can't remember. oh, and i should mention that we were placed on the top floor and then my friends who got there a day later were placed on the first floor before moving to the basement. the area this place is located is pretty nice, right next to the washington monument (and yes, i'm talking about baltimore, not DC!) but the owners just don't seem to care about this place. i know it's cheap but it's worth it to spend more and stay somewhere else.Horrible!  That's what you get when you try to save money. If you have a car...good luck finding decent parking to stay at this hotel.  Given that they don't have their own parking lot, you would think that the guys at the front desk would know a little bit about local parking lots.  Information like distance from hotel, (cost..which is BS..how about some parking validation???) and addresses of nearby parking lots.   The people at the front desk don't really seem to care to help make your stay more hospitable.  Some people have had a long day traveling and the last thing we want to do is to figure out where and how much we need to pay to park. I was so frustrated that I didn't even stay there.  It was not worth it.  Horrible service and hospitality, I completely concur with the low ratings that this hotel has.This place is simply awful, my room was hot and had a window that looked into a hallway.  I knew that I was going to be in for a bad time when I had to sign something that said that you couldn't get a refund after checking in (clearly enough people were trying to do that that that became necessary) I get that this place is cheap, but spring for a little more and get towels that don't have huge holes in them.Excellent location in an historic neighborhood, close to monuments and shops. Absolutely horrible room. I paid $40 (Priceline), and got a room (after a four-floor walkup) that measured approximately 8' x 12' (see photo). There was no window in the room. I could barely squeeze inside with my luggage because the door hit the bed. The sheets and towels were worn threadbare, every electrical appliance (fire alarm, light, shower fan) was missing its cover, there were holes in the ceiling, the shower took a small eternity to heat up and never got above a trickle. And I'm pretty sure it hadn't been cleaned in a week, if not a month.I would never, ever stay here again, but if you are absolutely destitute, it beats a bench in the park.I guess you get what u pay for for $80 bucks a night you get semi clean,luke warm water, heat if you know where the magic switch is in the middle of the wall ..one REALLY thin blanket. the freezer turns your ice cream into soup i forgot a bottle of wine in the fridge came back and hour later it was gone. lets not forget the 3 grainy channels on the t.v! the electrical outlets were so dangerous i thought we were going to burst into flames rodeway to hellAttention to anyone reading this review, this property isn't even worth one star. By far the worst hospitality property I've ever stayed in. Wifi Internet is slow. Their "continental" free breakfast is pathetic. For instance, they offer bagel, but with no cream cheese in sight. Oh, lets not forget the cold showers I had everyday of the week. I even tried for a hot shower late at night, and still cold. Bath towels look dirtier than the towels I use to wipe my car after a wash. Housekeeping forgot to give me new towels after I personally asked the front desk three times in one day. Hardly any basic or cable tv channels available -  5 channels in total!If you do plan to bring a car, then you better be prepared to wake up at 7 am to move your vehicle. Baltimore has horrible street parking, but this location has one of the worst parking situations. Also, their telephones don't work, and neither do their elevators. Luckily, I keep myself in decent shape so I could go up and down their stairs with ease. Although, it is four stories of stairs. So if you have any large bags like I did, it won't be a pleasant experience. I took a six hour flight and thought it would be nice to get some sleep as soon as I arrived for a 2 pm check in. Their reservation and computer system was down and I couldn't get a room until 5 pm. The one and only bright spot of this establishment is their front desk person Keith. But, even as great of a person he may be, it still doesn't give this place a one star rating. I sincerely hopes he is able to find another job and leave this dump.All in all, if I could stay at this place for free, i still would considered it to be over priced. I try not to write harsh reviews; but if I can save a person from staying at an establishment like this, then this review was worth the time and effort put in.It's a cheap hotel in a part of town that may or may not be shady (I had no problems walking around late at night). It's definitely cheaper than some of the Inner Harbor hotels and the Charm City Circulator (free when I went) is right across the street. Basically, when I travel, my hotel/motel is basically where I sleep and shower, one of the main reasons why I mostly look for a cheap hotel/motel which is close to the attractions I want to see. I don't really care about anything more than that, unlike others who need to be in absolute luxury when they travel. Here, though, you get what you pay for, in my case, a place to sleep and a shower. Surprisingly enough, I was able to sleep, I was afraid that the street noise and noise from the neighboring rooms would keep me up but that was not the case.Onto the breakfast- it sucks in a nutshell. Go elsewhere and pay for the breakfast, trust me, your stomach will thank you later.I do want to commend the front desk person when I checked out. He was extremely helpful in telling me how to get to where I wanted to go, (Fort McHenry) but ultimately, I ended up not going. Would I stay here again if I went to Baltimore? Um, I'm not sure yet. But if you're like me, you only need a place to crash and shower, then this place gets the job done.Cheapest hotel in Mt. Vernon (and probably any of the nicer neighborhoods in Baltimore).The front desk staff could not possibly be nicer, they really try hard. I had a last-minute late-night emergency and needed a room, and I got one for under $100 (in advance, it's more like $80 and that includes taxes). Positives: it is cheap! nice staff. clean rooms. spacious rooms. free hi-speed wifi.Negatives: those cheap and awful motel towelsPossible negatives: two words here: Bare Bones. This place doesn't have much that isn't necessary. Examples: Shampoo is provided, but not conditioner; there was no closet in my room, just a clothes rack (and luggage rack) without a door or anything. You won't find an iron or hair dryer in your room (though I didn't ask at the desk if one could be provided, maybe so).  Everything is basic basic basic, although there is the wifi, and my room had a very comfy chair, along with the desk, bed, and TV.If you're picky at all, or like luxury, forget this place. But if you're like me, and you want a clean, cheap place to stay in the heart of the cultural district: give this place a try!The free breakfast is a nice idea, but the cereal tends to the stale side. They did have a waffle machine, though! And having coffee or OJ in the morning is always nice.I'll stay here again for sure. But it's not for everybody.I only paid 25/night because of choice employee rewards but Jesus, it was terrible. There was gum on our walls painted over, toilets don't flush all the way , terrible showers. It comes out like a weak hose an takes FOREVER for it to warm up to acceptable heats... Our room (106) was in a basement. We had two terrible neighbors in 3 days the first of which was evicted. There's little to no parking unless you wanna pay or park on the street. Would not stay here again.Cheap but still not worth the cost savings. Don't stay here. No heat, unclean sheets and shower. Good location, bad hotel.I think this is probably the best cheap hotel in the area, especially for business travelers. It's walking distance to both Penn Station and the Inner Harbor/downtown area, i.e. your transit and your convention/meeting site, and close to a number of excellent restaurants. I don't know Baltimore that well, but as an outsider, I felt really safe in this part of town, which is a definite plus.I think they've managed to make their prices so low by drastically paring down on non-essential services, so if you're heading to Baltimore for a decadent getaway, this is not your hotel. The hotel looks like it saw better days, and then much worse days, and then better days again. So it's an odd mixture of fancy and tumbledown, but exquisitely clean.Case in point - the wireless here is amazing. Strong signal and blazingly fast, much better than what I have at home. There's a huge, wide desk - perfect for work, and a great chair. They serve free "breakfast", but it's basically your choice of carbs (muffin, cereal, or toast), and plenty of hot, strong, coffee. Again - exactly what I needed, maybe not what you need.The hot water is plenty hot, though the water pressure is low. The bed is extremely firm. There are a number of channels on the television, if you're in to that sort of thing. I found the desk staff to be very friendly and helpful. There are a number of weird stern warnings - you will be charged if you steal the towels! you will be charged $300 if a pet is found in your room! hotel is for registered guests only! - but if you're just looking for a place to get some work done and get a little rest, you should be fine.I did not have a good experience at the Rodeway Inn.  In fact, I did not even get to stay at the Rodeway Inn.  My friends and I planned on staying there because it seemed affordable and it was close proximity to the wedding we were attending.  After booking twp rooms two months in advance, we arrived to find out there was a "plumbing/flooding problem" that occurred the night before and they did not have rooms for us.  They offered to put us in rooms in another hotel 4 miles away and "I have a friend that can drive you there."  We asked them why they did not tell us this last night when we called to check our reservation or even the morning we were to arrive and they could not answer.  When we asked if the rooms in the other hotel would be the same price, they would not answer.  We ended up canceling the room, and I must say we were better off.  Our friends that had arrived there three days ahead had nothing but complaints of no air-conditioning and no water pressure (possibly to do with their plumbing problem).  When they complained, they were moved to another room and charged more for the bigger room.  Ridiculous.I would not recommend the Rodeway Inn.  It looks very rundown both inside and out.  Their one perk seems to be that they have free and fast internet, which came in handy when searching for another hotel closer than 4 miles away.A dump.  Barely adequate.  No elevator so had to walk up four flights.  Had to change rooms because a window was broken, and there are no screens.  Rooms are small cramped and hot.  Lights flickers.  Yeah, has wi fi but plugged computer in and it got really hot and wouldn't work.  TV fuzzy.  Bed uncomfortable.  Coke machine didn't have an option for diet.  Free breakfast consists of your choice of two generic cereals that you'd have to take back to your room if you want to sit down.  Chairs too big for room and/or desk they put them with.  Wasn't dirty but dingy.  And I could have dealt with all that for one night, but the bathroom door didn't lock and/or stay closed all the way.  Spend a little extra and be comfortable.FAIR WARNING TO EVERYONE: avoid both Rodeway Inns on St. Paul Street and Pulaski Highway in Baltimore, Maryland. They have the same local owner, whose only concern is cash, not customers. They have absolutely no qualms at all about overbooking you in advance, lying to you about it on the day you arrive, and trying to pawn you off on their other dive across town, thereby forcing you to scramble to book another hotel at the last minute (if you can find one). If you value honesty, integrity, and your time, DO NOT BOOK HERE!!!!!I booked at Rodeway Inn on St. Paul about a week prior to my visit to Baltimore by calling the hotel directly. I got a great rate at $99 per room per night. I got a room for myself and another room for my business colleague. I chose this hotel because of semi-decent reviews elsewhere online and decent location close to the train station & where we were conducting a business seminar. I received 2 confirmation numbers over the phone at the time of the booking. The hotel desk clerk refused to email me a receipt, but assured me that I had 2 rooms booked (should have been my first warning sign).The day I was to arrive in Baltimore to check into the Rodeway on St. Paul, I checked my reservations online and they were good. However, I received a phone call at about 1:00 PM from the hotel's desk clerk, explaining that there was a problem with the internet in the rooms I had booked. He asked if I would mind staying at the Rodeway Inn on Pulaski Highway, about 6 1/2 miles away. I said I really didn't care about the internet being down, and that I'd prefer to stay at the on St. Paul location because that was exactly where I needed to be. He ignored my comments and instead offered to shuttle me to and from the Pulaski Hwy location for free. I asked him to call the other hotel to confirm whether a free shuttle would actually be possible, but made it clear that I was not committing to his offer. He said he'd check and promised to call me back.About 3 or 4 hours passed with no phone call from the clerk, so I called the hotel back to find out what was going on. The clerk said he had no problem making arrangements to shuttle me to the other Rodeway on Pulaski Hwy. I again explained that I didn't care about the internet problems and would just rather stay at the Rodeway on St. Paul. Then, he changed his story on me and told me that actually, they were having problems with the toilets in both of the rooms and that it would not be possible for us to stay in them. Obviously, he was a liar. I told him I'd look into some other options and get back to him with my decision. He again offered the rooms at Pulaski Hwy, with free shuttle across town or to refund me for the rooms at on St. Paul with no penalty.I had a few hours left in Philadelphia before I had to leave for Baltimore, so I checked hotels online. There was NOTHING available anywhere near Rodeway Inn on St. Paul that was under $200 a night, except for, strangely, the Rodeway St. Paul itself. I called Rodeway corporate (Choice Hotels: reservations dept.) just to see if the St. Paul location actually had any availabilities, and they confirmed that it didn't. I called Rodeway St. Paul back anyway to make it clear that I didn't care what the situation was with the rooms...that I just wanted to stay in the rooms that I had paid for. He again told me that I couldn't stay there because of the toilets, but that I could stay at the Pulaski Hwy. location. I told him that I didn't want to stay at the Pulaski Highway location (by that point, a friend in town had warned me against staying in that area) and that I'd call back with my decision.I called Rodeway corporate again (Choice Hotels: customer service) to complain. The first support person I spoke to was absolutely useless, claiming that each hotel is independently managed and that they couldn't interfere. Thankfully, my cell phone cut out before I could finish with her. I called back and got a different woman, who actually listened to me and cared about my problem. She promised to call Rodeway St. Paul to find out what was going on. She did call me back promptly and confirmed that Rodeway St. Paul had overbooked me, and that the guy who owned Rodeway St. Paul also owned Rodeway Pulaski Hwy (shocker, right?), and that I was welcome to file a complaint with corporate.So avoid any Rodeway Inns in Baltimore, my friends! By the way, I ended up booking rooms at the Country Inn & Suites out by the BWI airport in Linthicum, MD (closest decent place I could find that day). It was fantastic. Huge, clean suites. Free shuttle. Free cookies. Free newspapers. Free huge breakfast. And an absolutely awesome, friendly, and honest staff. GOOD RIDDANCE, RODEWAY INN! NEVER AGAIN!!!Let me make a few qualifications beforehand: I don't come to Baltimore often and I have nothing to compare to. But having said that...the place is seriously undermaintained  at every turn and overall it's pretty dirty . The first room they gave had its bathroom light out so they cheerfully offered to move us. The next room had its smoke detector removed and what looked like spattered puke on the bathroom door.. The third room was okay. And yes, the elevator is broken. The continental "breakfast"  is extremely meager.  I get the sense the owners are extremely cheap and refuse to pay for anything resembling qualified work. Doors that don't shut right...light switches installed upside down...showers that gurgle when the toilet is flushed...extension cords all over the place...this place needs an inspection in the worst of ways. My advice : spend a few more bucks and get something nicer, or at least safer.
review_content_20: I booked a hotel room at the Rodeway Inn months in advance. When I got to the hotel, the person in charge told me that they didn't have my room available due to plumbing issues, and they wanted to transfer me to a different hotel 3 miles away. I needed to be walking distance from an event, so I told them I had to have a room at this hotel. When I went to the room, the bannister of the stairway was loose and I almost fell over. The stairs were also uneven and shaky. When I looked at the room, there were toenail clippings on the window sill, and the room had a funny smell. Also, on the way up to check into the room, a friend was helping me, and the person in charge started harassing me about how many people were staying there. When I saw the state of the room, I wanted to cancel my stay. I was charged for one night stay, even though I didn't stay there for more than one minute. At the same time I was having problems, a few other people were complaing about the room as well. I don't think this hotel is sanitary, or up to code.

review_content: I honestly can't remember the last time I rated a business five stars.  Black Olive deserves every star of this review. The service, atmosphere, living quarters, owner and staff were all exceptional! I felt at peace when I stayed here and I am truly looking forward to going back. I loved it so much that I'm often recommending it to folks ! If you want an earthy, boutique and peaceful setting this is your place! Oh, and yeh hot tub is pretty dope too.Staying here this evening and it just keeps getting worse. The guy at the front desk is very nice, but without a manager here he can't solve any problems. It's Valentine weekend and we booked a corner spa suite. Well, the jacuzzi tub doesn't work, but even if it did all of the hot water is murky brown. The thermostat also does not work either and to make matters worse the phone in the room doesn't work, so we have to go down to the desk to let them know our concerns. The hotel seems poorly taken care of as well. The walls are dirty and have patches all over them and the room is very strange, we have an open utility closet in room and a curtain in the bathroom that leads to an empty space with water hook ups on the wall. It could be a decent hotel if it were cleaned and/or painted and everything worked. We were told to wait for the manager to get in in the morning and see what she could do about it, so review pending outcome of a discussion with the manager. It's a shame because the hotel is in a great location and the amenities are great on paper. Update: Manager, Tiffany, was never in as promised and we never got a resolution. 0 stars.Decided to take a spontaneous trip to Baltimore last week, and a deal on this hotel so decided to go for it after seeing positive reviews.  Overall, I had a mixed experience. When I arrived to the hotel, we were unable to properly check-in because the system was down.  This wasn't a huge deal because we were able to complete the process the next day.When I walked into the actual room we were staying in, I was a little surprised at first.  The room was very sparse and it really looked like an unfinished apartment with paint peeling on the walls and cold concrete floors. Not necessarily bad, if you're into that style, but just very different from the style of a typical hotel.The good: There was a very convenient and fairly priced parking garage right next door.  There was also a cool area with different bars/restaurants within walking distance.  The bed was super comfortable, and there was a HUGE jacuzzi tub which was pretty fun. We also got a good price on the room, so I can't really complain.The bad: The room was HOT.  I admit, I like to sleep in very cold temperatures; but the room was consistently set at 75 degrees.  I adjusted it down to 65 before leaving to go to dinner, and after returning, the thermostat was still showing 75.  There was a note saying to call down to the desk if you were having trouble adjusting the temperature (which leads me to believe you're unable to actually adjust it) but the person at the front desk said we should be able to adjust it ourselves.  Needless to say, we left the balcony door open to cool down the room.There is also A LOT of outside noise that gets in to the room through the balcony.  Even after the room cooled down and I closed the balcony, I was still woken up multiple times by noise from trucks driving by.  There is also construction going on across the street (I know this is unavoidable) but it is just unfortunate getting woken up to the sound of jackhammers on a getaway.The bottom line is, for one night this hotel was fine.  However, I probably wouldn't choose this it again over some of the other hotels in the area.Came to Baltimore to see a concert and decided not to stay at a big name, branded hotel. Wanted something a bit more "boutique." I must say, I couldn't ask for more. The GM, Tiffany, has made us feel so unbelievably welcome that I feel like I'm staying at a friend's home. The room is gorgeous and SPOTLESSLY clean. The service has been top-notch, from the reservation, to the reschedule due to a blizzard, to the check-in. The staff is polite, and the accommodations are beautiful. Also, the rooms are very unique - stained concrete floors, area rugs, beautiful furniture - feels like an artsy, well decorated apartment, not a hotel. And the price was unbeatable! Thank you Tiffany and Staff for a pleasant experience that my wife and I could never have received from one of the big guys. I'd recommend this hotel to anyone!Horrible experience! The was one of the worst stays we have ever had anywhere in the world. We had paid a good amount of money ($300+) for what we expected to be a romantic stay for our anniversary. The staff member at arrival really did not seem to want to be there and was very unhelpful while checking in. When we found our room, our first thought was that it had not been cleaned from the prior stay, but soon found out that this is how they thought a room should be presented. The mirror in the bathroom, that should have been on the wall behind the vanity, was lying propped against a wall next to an exposed plumbing pipe. The couch had stains and remnants of food and other items all over it. There was coffee and no coffee machine. Cups but no spoons. Plates but no knives. Dead plants and a general state of disrepair. The towels and carpets were so worn they looked like they should have been trashed. When we spoke another staff member at reception (who had not been told our concerns by his colleague even though we where told he would have) he explained that he knew nothing about the free bottle of wine that was advertised when we booked. Having traveled the world I would have expected more from a $20 a night hostel. Do yourself a favor and stay way clear!I stayed here on new years day for one night. The hotel is very nice and as soon as you  check  in the aroma from the organic establishment inside beside the desk is extraordinary!! Omg it's like wow I just ate but all of a sudden I'm hungry :)..our room was spacious and very cozy. They have a nice size jacuzzi in the bathroom area and they also give you a complimentary bottle of wine.  Be sure to ask for it as we did when we checked in. The only reason i can't give this hotel  5 stars is because i could not get with the fact that they didn't have a microwave in the room. They had a frig but that was it. Maybe it's just me but if i had to stay there more than one night i would have preferred to have one. The organic very very healthy breakfast was super delicious. I enjoyed every bite.. also kudos to the comfortable bed.  Overall it was a great stay :) And definitely nicer for couples..Love it here! Relaxing. Peaceful. Calming. I've stayed several times. I even stayed here during the riots and, not to take anything away from that unfortunate situation, you would have never known that you were even in the same state! Want to disconnect, relax, get away from the "everydays"....you're here!!I wanted to love this hotel, but after staying here I can only say that I like it.The good: The rooms here are *huge*.  The hotel's website says that its smallest rooms are 800 square feet, and my room definitely looked that big.  For reference's sake, my room was about the same size as the apartment my now-wife was living in when I met her.  The location's also great -- the hotel's in the trendy Fells Point neighborhood, and just a short walk away from Inner Harbor.  The I'm-not-so-sure: The hotel's done in a style reminiscent of a Mediterranean villa, complete with plaster walls and bare concrete floors.  I guess the look works, but it doesn't really feel luxurious in the way you'd expect in a hotel where the rooms start at close to $300 per night.  I only ordered food once, but the "Baltimore Benedict" (eggs Benedict, except with crab instead of ham) I got was disappointingly flavorless.  The WiFi is slow but usable.The bad: All of the room lights are controlled by motion sensors, but at least in my room the sensor couldn't see the shower, so halfway through each shower the windowless bathroom would be plunged into complete darkness.  It's not the hotel's fault, but right now there's a million square foot office building being built across the street, which means that at seven o'clock in the morning every weekday, you're awakened by the sound of big trucks rumbling by and beeping as they back up.  This is extra non-awesome if you're still on Mountain Time as I was.  Also, there were some pretty gnarly stains on the walls of the bathroom and living room.  (?!?)The hotel's location is perfect for what I'm looking for, so I may be back, but I have to say that the place isn't awesome for the price.Let me start by saying that I've never met nicer hotel/inn staff than those at the Inn at The Black Olive. Without exception, quality individuals.Having worked in Fells Point for years, and having interacted with the owner of the restaurant and inn, I was excited to finally have an opportunity to stay at the inn. (We were holding a function in the area and needed a place to get dressed after the hard work was done -- and sleep after the even harder work was done.)Not the fault of the inn, but that area of Caroline St. stinks -- like rotten eggs or sewage. I gagged several times while walking back and forth to our event venue.A wall in the living area that should have contained a piece of art was bare -- except for four screws. Also, it appears that there were several areas on the ceiling that had been spackled but not painted -- not very attractive.Unlike another review noted, there was no television in the bedroom.Loved the whirlpool bathtub.I wanted to love my stay there but I was a bit disappointed.Didn't stay here but visited the restaurant upstairs. We had a dinner party of 6 and were well taken care of the entire night. We went on a Saturday night for a birthday dinner and enjoyed our entire meal. Our meal began with a cucumber topped with some avocado cream puree. For our main course we ordered a bunch of family style plates that we passed around the table and shared. Everything was delicious and cooked perfectly. My steak was so tender and juicy I couldn't help but go for seconds. It is a bit expensive here but the food is worth it. Another great thing was the amazing view of the balcony. You could see all the beautiful city lights of Baltimore.Beautiful inn, spacious, clean, friendly staff. My one complaint is that parking was not included. The parking lot next door was full so we had to park at a different lot further away that cost $30 for less than 24 hrs and was not all that convenient :(Wonderful setting w views of the Harbor only exceeded by the quality of the food. Our server Kevin Calhoun was awesome.The hotel allowed a rooftop party on a Sunday night. Not only is it so loud I can't hear anything but the rap blasting...I've heard the "N" word and "F" bombs more then my entire life combined! I called the front desk multiple times but it's no better. Horrific experience. Seriously horrific. My kids are here!!!!!!!The staff was extremely friendly. Carrying our bags to or room and delivering ice was just the start. They were kind enough to scatter rose petals around the room, made a heart on the bed, and around the bath tub. They also gave us a supply of bath salts to use in the two person hydro therapy hot tub. The stand in shower is one of the largest iv ever been in. OrderUp delivered breakfast from a local bagel shop in the morning.  A fantastic start to our honeymoon.The staff here is great. Not many places where you can meet and interact with the owner. Dimitri is very friendly and down to earth. The rooms are great, spacious and cozy!My fabulous bridesmaids found the Inn and reserved a suite for my bachelorette party.  There were two king beds and a whole separate bedroom.  The bathroom was massive and gorgeous.  We slept 6 people very comfortably (including an air mattress).  The service of the staff is amazing .... they were so attentive.  PLUS, you get a free bottle of wine with yelp check in!!  Small Mediterranean cafe downstairs open M-Sat.A fantastic place for a weekend retreat! Great customer service in all phases of the place; market, hotel, and restaurant.   The food is exceptional; it's all organic and for the most part Greek.   We will be back the next time we're in Bmore.Lovely hotel. Huge rooms and fantastic food. We were here for a special event (a reception for the hugely talented writer of 'Ghana must Go,' Taiye Selasi) and they treated us beautifully. The space was a teeny bit cramped but that's probs cos most of the guests were larger than life personalities ;)  I was bowled over by the polenta and the pie. The quality of everything was top notch. Would thoroughly recommend!Just lovely place. Situated in a nice area- with a short walk to the Aquarium. The cafe is nice, and delectable. I enjoyed my breakfast sandwich-it was very delicious. The room was a suite, and it was very relaxing and clean. I loved it. The bed was super comfortable and I loved how much space there was for the price.Would def. visit again.Greek Mediterranean seafood.   Amazing selections of wine.  Great service great atmosphere and even better food. The squid salad....omg.  Incredible. This is for a special occasion.  Do not miss it!
review_content_20: We were looking for a place to host a VERY special dinner for 8 complete with atmosphere, location, ambiance and amazing food and we found it all at restaurant at The Black Olive Inn.  We met with Dimitri and Layce to tell them what we were looking for and they went above and beyond our expectations.  They helped us find a little boat for a harbor tour, brought delicious appetizers on the boat for us and then laid a special table for us on the rooftop of the Inn including a personalized menu!  Our guests were thrilled, as were we.
