Thank you to all at the Inn, it was a magical evening.There are several up market choices for the waterfront, but this one is just a 5 minute walk from that cluster of 4 Seasons, Marriott, surrounding retail, restaurants, and a Whole Foods.  It's a smart alternative and the stroll along the dock is exceedingly relaxing.  Fell's point is just another 5 minute walk in the opposite direction.The hotel staff is extremely accommodating, the rooms have an industrial, loft conversion feel, and the amenities are modern and truly eco, down to the toiletries.  Each even has its own flat screen google tv, so no need to leave your room for a business center.  There's a mini kitchen, and a washer dryer combo unit for small loads (I repeat, small). Unlike those other places, this place is so clean I had to walk barefoot on the concrete floor, and I didn't hear a thing all week, not even a neighbor.If you're around during the day, sneak up to the rooftop restaurant deck and enjoy the views, the sun, and the complete luxury of it being all to yourself.  Open the doors to both of your balconies and let the fresh breeze in.Don't be fooled by the plain exterior, as usual it's the inside that counts.Awful service. Waited 30 minutes to be seated even though we had reservations. Took the staff two hours to serve us out main course despite us putting in the order at same time as appetizer. Had the braised lamb (just ok), catch of the day (just ok), crab cakes (no flavor), and lamb chops (just ok). The lamb chops came out raw and had to be sent back to finish cooking. Had 3 cocktails off their menu- all of them awful. Usually if I have a bad dining experience I won't take the time to yelp it. This time the restaurant earned the bad review in a big way.Great hotel!  The rooms are suites with lots of natural light and very modern.  I enjoyed  the rooftop restaurant and bar.  It's a short walk to all the great locations and parking in the adjacent garage was only $13 for 24 hours.  A big plus is that the hotel is NON-Smoking so you don't get slapped in the face with the smell like you do in the big chains down the street.Great rooms, eco-friendly design.   I stayed here recently and I really like it. they are the most eco-friendly hotel I've ever been to. TP is from a brand that uses recycled paper, whirlpool tubs, and many other things.  There is also an organic market/cafe next to the lobby that has some great food.  I would definitely stay here again.  My only reason for giving 4 stars instead of 5 is that they are still using CFLs in their lighting fixtures instead of the much better LED lights.I'm a bit of a hotel brat, and have stayed in some of the finest hotels around the world. With two kids in college, the hotel budget is smaller, but the bratty expectations are still there, so I am challenged to find high standards at good prices. The Inn at the Black Olive made this hotel brat a very happy person.Upon arrival, I was intrigued by the small check-in area, with the small cafe next to the area, and wasn't entirely sure what to think. My check in was a breeze, and AJ took me to my suite on the fourth floor. The rooms were enormous! I was impressed by the rugs made with vegetable dyes, the hypoallergenic furnishings, the thoughtful (and free!) bottle of Mountain Vally water (my favorite) and a bottle of Greek wine chilling in the small refrigerator, the spacious bedroom and the colorful artwork. AJ gave an interesting explanation of the attributes of the mineral coloring in the walls, the art, and the other characteristics of the rooms. And the bathroom! A huge air jet tub, large enough for two, and the air jets made the spa bubbles ensuring no nasty recycled jacuzzi water was in this tub. And there was a separate shower that was also enormous. Great water pressure, organic bath products including a fabulous bubble bath, and separate WC for privacy. The towels were plentiful and thick.Other pluses:Valet parking is just $25 for the LENGTH OF YOUR STAY! Not per night. And your car is brought around very quickly.No carpet! I loved the oasis of the rugs, and no carpets meant cleaner floors, less allergens, and no stuff that gets trapped in carpets.Comfortable platform beds with lovely but firm mattresses. Great pillows, too.Large closet and plenty of nice wooden hangers.Delicious coffee and a coffee maker that actually worked.First class service! The staff, including AJ, Ahmed, Al, Chris, and Joseph were amazing! If I needed something, they were right there. One night I had to make a CVS run about 11:15 pm. Rather than send me out at night, one of the staff took me in their car and waited for me to make my purchase. You just don't find service like this anymore!One afternoon, the owner, Dimitris was in the lobby, and he inquired about my stay. I was telling him how pleased I was, then I figured out to whom I was speaking. Dimitris was so gracious, asking if I needed anything, and thanking me for selecting his hotel for my stay. You can tell the guests are appreciated at the Inn at the Black Olive.Overall, this is the place I will stay in Baltimore. I already have reservations for move-in weekend and Parents' Weekend at the university. The uniqueness, cleanliness, attention to detail, friendliness of staff and top-notch service have sold me on the Inn at the Black Olive. I used to wrinkle my nose at small boutique hotels, but not this one. When I return to the Inn at the Black Olive, which I am eager to do, I know the staff will make me feel welcome and I'll have another wonderfully comfortable stayWonderful service!  Staff was very attentive and welcoming! The location is great for bumming around the harbor and was right next to our dinner destination.  The views from the restaurant on the roof were spectacular.  As were the cocktails we enjoyed there.  Also loved at the eco-friendly touches.  My only complaint would be wanting better lighting in the bathroom- for make up application.  We will definitely come back.  Thank you for a wonderful weekend.What a great find. We vacationed in town for the weekend and the hotel is right at the juncture of Harbor East and Fells Point - lots of restaurants, shops, etc to walk to. A very Eco-friendly hotel - huge rooms , big bathrooms with a jacuzzi, incredible beds. Beautiful oriental carpets on the floors and very colorful walls and artwork. Met the owner, Dimitri, who is obviously very proud of his inn and was extremely gracious. Very nice bar on the top floor with a great view. A market on the ground floor too for coffee, sandwiches, etc. A very nice change from your standard hotel and such a nice personal feel to the place - would definitely come back. My only suggestion would be some more seating in the living area and perhaps a TV in the bedroom.We came with big expectations to the IatBO due to favorable review on TA. It is well located and the staff really go out of their way to accommodate you. The rooms (at least ours) was HUGE, probably almost 1000 sqft, with a large BR, LR, kitchenette, and bath,There are problems, however. The highly touted geothermal heating, really didn't work that well, with blowing cold air, and the hot water never was that hot or plentiful. The fancy net-based house phone didn't work either, nor did the coffee maker. Although located on a quiet street, it is opposite a construction site that it quite noisy, and the street does get a surprising amount of traffic. The staff, though helpful, are a bit too "laid back" for my taste, just seem like some "slouchers" hanging around the front desk more than service professionals.For my money, I'll stay next time at a big chain and leave the autoclaved gypsum walls, hypoallergenic concrete floors, organically grown linens, and geothermal heating for someone else to enjoy.Very accommodating! Everyone that works here is at your service and will provide you with whatever you want! Had an amazing experience and will definitely stay again if ever in the area!Stayed one night with my daughter while looking at colleges. First time here and was very impressed. Staff couldn't have been any more friendly and helpful. Room was a suite and very large. Though the property is relatively new it was made to look old which was great. We had dinner outside on the roof and the food and service was great. Couldn't have been any more relaxing. Fells Point area is unique and worth exploring. Highly recommend and look forward to returning.Low key, relaxed, quiet and comfortable.  Plus, it's a great deal!  The two bedroom suite is huge, spare and modern.  The beds are amazingly comfortable, with organic bedding.  There is a large whirlpool bath as well.  The staff is friendly and helpful.  The cafe has nice choices and the nearby Greek restaurant associated with the hotel has terrific food.  The hotel is in Fell's Point, close enough to be very convenient to restaurants and the waterfront, but far enough from the center to avoid the noise of the bar scene.Very clean-- welcoming-- original artwork in walls--a great location in Fells Point--a real presence of a family run business-- I felt that we were their first priority! I recommend the Inn highly.

review_content: Not sure why this hotel has such low reviews. I thought they did a great job managing all of us from area TV stations during the blizzard. The food at their restaurant was great and for me the service was wonderful. The only bad thing was the room I was in smelled like cigarette smoke -- but I was too exhausted to care enough to tell someone. Sandra at the front desk is amazing! She saw I was super exhausted and even though they didn't have rooms ready she got me into one ASAP. Also they are dog-friendly. Didn't bring my pup this time, but next time I will!Oh dear. While this hotel seems to be so proud of their renovations, it appears as of Summer 2015 that they neglected quite a few aspects in the reno process. My fiance and I were looking at a wedding venue in the area and this would have been the primary hotel for our guests. After our stay, it was blatantly clear that should we have our wedding nearby the Radisson fell way below our standards and we need to look elsewhere. PROS: The only pros of the place are the staff and newly renovated rooms. The Sleep Number bed is a great touch. Overall the room was very nice aside from the comments below. Parking is great with both outdoors or covered options. That is if you can find it as their driveway isn't exactly the easiest to find. They have a mini convenience store area next to the front desk which is always a plus should you need any amenities or food/drink. CONS: First off the elevators are terrible. Half of the lights don't light up and several times we had to push the "open" button for the doors to even open. Room wise, our door wouldn't close (obviously doors aren't their forte) unless physically pushed very firmly...of course by my fiance. So not good for those people who assume the door closes right behind them. Shortly after checking in we got some ice so we could pour some water into the glasses as it was super hot outside and we wanted some nice cold ice water. That idea was quickly ruined as there was ALREADY WATER in one of the glasses. Ewwww! Not the first thing you want to see when you walk into your hotel room. We were also missing the do not disturb sign. Typically we wouldn't care but we wanted to sleep in, especially on the Sleep Number bed! Luckily we got one from the front desk as the hotel staff was a bit noisy outside early the following morning. The fitness room leaves much to be desired while the pool had caution tape along the edges. Definitely not something I'd want my future wedding guests from out of town to see! The trek to the pool was confusing. Once we figured out how to get to the pool the exterior spaces that take you to the pool are incredibly outdated. I felt like I was in a 70's movie! Gross. Wi-Fi might be free but it was on and off. Totally not reliable so don't bet on that.OVERALL: I applaud the Radisson for the upgrades and updates to the rooms. Mad props there as the rooms trump several of the major hotels I routinely stay at in downtown Baltimore. Still, you seriously need to fix literally everything else. My fiance gives you a C- while I'd give a C. More specifically the pool area, common areas, gym, and elevators need major help. I have no idea why you were sold out for 3 weddings the weekend we stayed here. I'd be beyond embarrassed to have my friends and family stay here for my wedding. No offense to the fabulous staff but seriously if you're going to fix something fix the whole package if you're going to charge over $200!We visited this hotel for the first time this past weekend while down for Hopkins Family weekend.  I have to say I was less than impressed.  For perspective, I'm not a super high-end traveller (not that I wouldn't LOVE that) -- but our norm for family trips are Hampton Inn, Hyatt Place  -- clean, comfortable, budget friendly.  I chose this location over the Hampton Inner Harbor -- next time I'll try the Hampton.  From the photos and description of this "recently renovated" hotel, I thought it would be in that league, but it fell short:CONS:1.  Housekeeping:  The white duvet/comforter covers that you would think they replaced with each visitor were NOT clean.  On arrival, I checked and saw immediately that both were stained, clearly by previous visitors.  With one call to the front desk it was taken care of -- but still -- this should not happen with those white duvets covers.  Toothpaste splash stains on the wallpaper (from previous guests) also should have been wiped off.2. Beds were not good.  This hotel website advertises "sleep number" beds.  I know what that is because we have one, and I love it.  Our room did NOT have a sleep number bed, and the old mattress was not very comfortable.  When I asked about the sleep number beds, the front desk clerk was very honest and said that only SOME rooms have the sleep number beds - their website does NOT say this.  Honestly, the sleep number bed is not why I booked this room -- but I did have an expectation that the beds would be of a certain higher quality comfort --- and they were definitely not.  3. Location of this hotel is off the B'more beaten path, and slightly hard to find b/c signage is poor, in an upscale-ish shopping center (Williams Sonoma, Talbots, Donna's).  The building itself is older, with longggg hallways that make some rooms quite a haul from the elevators.  Despite the renovations (new carpets, wallpaper furnishings), our room -especially the bathroom- had a slightly grungy feel.PLUS: 1. Free parking.I was pretty bummed out by my latest experiences here.1) Touting that they are oriented toward business travelers, this hotel has very poor, spotty wi-fi. They were not able to fix it after multiple complaints.2) Their "handicap" rooms range in actual accommodations. I've been in multiple rooms they call "handicap," and they all have a range in door width, accessibility to the shower, etc.3) Their faulty refrigerators (2) not only did not work but ruined expensive prescription medicine. There was not even an apology.4) Management has been overwhelmingly rude lately about changing dates for reservations despite my being a regular customer here and being a Club Carlson member.Ordered a King, got two Queens. The place looks rough, and well lived in, not what I expected from a Radisson. The staff was ok. Didn't ask much and regretted the choice once I walked in the elevator. Rooms were spotless.Worst guest service ever. Rate confirmation of $50/night from company reservation confirmation email was categorically denied by this location.  Several other people in our group had same experience.  Managers said they could not comp a room, which would have brought the quoted rate to the wedding rate we had asked to book under. Some people who complained got half off one night. Orhers got free drink tickets.  No one got the rate quoted in their confirmation letter.Don't ever go to a Radisson unless you are willing to pay more than what they quote.I was surprised to see all the negative reviews of this hotel. The lobby area is beautiful, and the room is spacious and modern. It's also incredibly clean. There's a nice flat screen TV. I am not 100% sure about the Sleep Number bed yet, but I think it will be comfortable and there are lots of pillows on the bed. We would definitely stay here again.EDIT: After sleeping, I'm editing my review. The Sleep Number bed did not seem to work with the remote, and it wasn't comfortable. Kind of like sleeping on a futon. The sheets didn't fit the bed well and were pulled off the mattress by morning. Radisson: ditch the Sleep Number beds!Don't stay here!! I only stayed here one night and didn't have a great experience....First off, five minutes after I walked into my room housekeeping walked right in with a master key to add more towels to the two I already had!! Ummmm excuse me?? Thank God I wasn't getting busy yet....smh Then they charged both my debit card and my credit card for my one night stay!! When I first called to inquire about it, I was told that I wouldn't be charged twice!! Then a week later when I checked both my accounts they were indeed charged!!!! Uhhhhh so annoying!!This hotel is fine--there is really nothing wrong with it. And I have to say, that their sleep number beds created some of the better nights of sleep I have had in a long time! Great advertisement for those beds :-)Were the rooms the most updated? No, but everything was definitely fine. I would have liked an overhead light rather than having to turn on all of the little lamps and such, but really the room was fine overall--decent size, comfy bed, what else do you really need? They have happy hour in their bar downstairs which I found myself hanging out at which was fun, but that was mainly because other than the little boutique shops here, if you don't have a car, staying here means you are pretty much stuck at the hotel, since there isn't really anything within a mile from the hotel. So make sure you have your laptop or ipad to use their free wifi! And definitely eat at the village square cafe next door to this place--you won't regret it!Highly recommended place to stay and dine.  The atmosphere was pleasant, food was outstanding, and the mixologist was a true professional.  There was also a shuttle service that we took advantage of.   The new Horseshoe casino was 15 minutes away and we plan on retuning in May for the preakness Horserace, which, by the way is only 10 minutes away.  The rooms are newly renovated and had a modern sleek look.  Room service was exceptional.Great room! Very spacious, with a comfy bed, nice lounge chair, clean bathroom, stylish desk/chair and plenty of power outlets :)The location is kind of strange, inside a small mall/office complex, but it was easy to find and had available underground parking.  I was staying here for an interview at Sinai Hospital, and had been told there was a free shuttle service, but it turns out the shuttle only ran once early in the morning...  The service was nice and they had available late check-out for no extra charge :)Overall, it was a comfy room.  No minifridge/microwave combo, but there was a hair dryer available.  Currently undergoing some renovations on the 4th floor, so some paint smell.I enjoyed my stay here.  I stayed in the junior suite for about $140/night which is very reasonable considering the other hotels more intown in Baltimore.  The decor was updated and there  was a mini fridge and microwave.  Also there were a couple of water bottles waiting for me in the room which was a nice touch. The older African American lady in the front desk was very nice with a calming demeanor.  Only thing I did not like was being disturbed twice within 2 hours of entering my room.  The first time, the lady knocked, did not wait for me to answer door and just walked in. I was very annoyed and she did not even apologize and instead told me I should have used the door stop. Also, the restaurant is very pricey but the food was good.  I liked their bar and lobby sitting area as well.  Parking is also easy.  The hotel is a little hard to find when you fist arrive as it is in a complex.If I ever had to chance to stay here again... I WOULDN'T & wouldn't recommend it to anyone.  The beds were uncomfortable even though they were advertised as sleep number beds, the bathroom was so tiny that it barely fits 2 people to get ready, and the remote for the bed was disgusting. The interior in the lobby isn't bad, but that's about it. The checkin guy was ok, but kept having conversations with the other worker and it wasn't professional. After leaving, a few days later we noticed a $100+ charge on our credit card statement. When we called to inquire about this  mysterious charge, as we booked and payed in advance through Expedia, they had no record of us checking us and couldn't even find our credit card on file to look up this charge.  They had no idea what we were talking about cause they were INCOMPETENT. I'll never stay at any Radisson again.My husband and I stayed here for a quick night during travel. The staff is very pleasant, and they have definitely done some work here and there to modernize the place. I also enjoyed the shops at Cross Keys. All in all, a decent hotel in a nice location. Everything was clean, nothing special, but very clean.My main complaint would be the bed in our room. It was so firm that it was uncomfortable. The bedding itself was fine, but the mattress was hard as a rock. A pillow top or more cushioned mattress pad would help a lot.One of the nicest features of this hotel is the restaurant, Scoozi. We stopped in for a quick dinner, and I went again for breakfast while my husband was at a work meeting. Both meals were very good, and I would definitely go back.Came to this hotel for a one-day seminar.  The hotel was undergoing some much needed renovation (looks very dated).  The room that my seminar was held in was on the mezzanine level, which only had one restroom for men and women to share.  The room was okay, nothing fancy, but the tablecloths that were provided to us had rips / holes in them.  I ate at the restaurant downstairs.  Ordered the grilled chicken casesar salad, where the chicken was extremely dry and tasteless and drenched in dressing, but the rest of the salad was okay.  Also ordered a french onion soup, which I think they forgot about because I had to ask for it after they took my salad away.  It was extremely hot and I burned my tongue :(  Taste-wise it was good though.The room was beautiful and huge-somehow, we got a suite. We stayed for one night, we got in late. It's pretty confusing to find the front desk-maybe we were just super tired. The room was comfortable, and most importantly really clean. We were there for graduation weekend-so we didn't spend very much time in the hotel.By pet "friendly", this hotel means your pet can stay here. If anyone complains or if there is audible noise/barking etc. you will be harassed by staff multiple times a day until you check out, adding a lot of stress to your trip.  On the flip side, if you require silence and don't like dogs...you can be guaranteed your complaints will be heard. The housekeeping staff is stellar creating a clean environment but the beds were uncomfortable and the pet friendly status is in name only.Needs updating. The sleep number beds are nice, but some of them don't function properly or fully. The bathrooms definitely need renovated. The TV gets something like 18 channels, and everything else is pay-per-view. Wi-fi is not free.It wasn't a luxury resort, but it was far from a dump. The little "village" it is located in is nice for out-of-towners. We ate lunch at the cafe next door, and there were a number of shops surrounding a little quad area. The housekeeping staff were incredibly nice, and the front desk was helpful in providing us with directions to an event we were attending.I would probably try somewhere else if I was in the area again, but it wasn't an unpleasant stay.I check-in Mothers Day and while it wasn't the nicest looking place it was in a quiet setting.  The inside smelled a little musty, but looked clean.  My room was large and late that night I went to shower only to discover a dirty washcloth in my shower.  I continued on!Off to work the next day to return and find a note stating we apologize but we had a water pipe failure and are working to repair it, we will keep you informed.  I went out to eat, returned and around 9 pm that evening called to see what the status was with the water.The front desk said it would be on at NOON the following day, I said excuse me did you say tomorrow.  Yes NOON tomorrow, so I asked what I should do about showering.  He said that they could give me a couple of gallons of water for my room.  (Not sure how that helps)  I said that would not be acceptable, he said well you can go to a hotel where we made arrangements.I asked when they decided to let me know and he said we left a message on your room phone, I stated I had no message and he said we left one for all guest.  Now is he saying I lied?  I guess he thought I would sit around until 9:30 just to give him a hard time.  I said I was going to the other hotel and would be down.The other hotel was Best Western an $89 dollar a night hotel and my room was costing $179, not a fair trade.  Plus the hotel was miles away from where I needed to be.  What I couldn't figure out is how the water goes out before noon Monday and it takes until NOON Tuesday to fix. Baltimore has plumbers.  Just doesn't seem the customer is that important to them.  So today I checked out a day early and moved to another hotel.  The funny thing is no one asked way I was leaving early.I stayed here for a business tip.  The location was pretty strange, it was part of what looked like a gated mall.  The staff were extremely friendly.  The room itself was big, but the furniture was all pretty old, it looked like it had not been updated in a long time.  I was not impressed by the sleep number bed, it felt like there was a board running down the middle of it.For business purposes, it seemed like the shuttle ran somewhat randomly, the setup seemed to be to accommodate people who were in town to visit the hospitals.  I was told they could not make it available for one of my trips, I shared a cab with another person and after the cab ride saw the shuttle roll up behind me at the destination.But hey, cab fare wasn't much, staff was great on the check in and check out, would have liked a bit more modern comfort for getting my work done.  I would probably stay there again if I needed to be in this particular area of the city.
review_content_20: Just like their logoSad and dated and real old.Sleep number's a joke.I'm going with only two stars for this hotel and there's several reasons for it. First of all the location is weird and not easy to find. The entrance to the hotel is located inside a shopping plaza within a gated complex. Looking for it at night you're most likely to drive by the first time then turn around and look for it again. Once you're past the gate it's not over yet. Good luck finding the signs for the actual hotel entrance. Someone made sure they are vague and few! My tip: look for it where you would least expect it, inside a parking garage! My second gripe: this hotel must have the thinnest walls ever. I was able to hear every single word and every action of guests staying in two adjacent rooms. This can be irrelevant if you're a loud person yourself or very annoying if you're trying to catch some sleep and your neighbors are not...Third issue: room service hours are odd. They start at 11:30am and end at 10:30pm. I don't get it. Aren't these exactly the hours most people wouldn't be in their hotel room?!? What good is a room service if you never get to use it? I have to say their menu looked quite inviting, which was even more annoying because I didn't get to try anything! ;)Not end the review with just complaints the cleanness of the room was impeccable. Beautifully maintained, fully equipped bathroom, good beds (although i can see how the firmness control feature will be seen as more of a nuisance than a good feature by some).I stayed here on a trip for work.  It was okay, not the best but by no means the worst.  It was situated in a sort of outdoor mall setting.  From the outside the hotel kind of looked like a retirement community.  It smelled like on on the inside.  The staff was quite friendly.  Although, they weren't overwhelmingly concerned with running the shuttles on time.  However, they were exceedingly sweet and stopped by a drug store so I could pick up a few things that got left behind.The room was nice and clean, the bed was perfect.The location is weird and the restaurant is limited and has very poor service. This hotel is basically in a mall, and the area is pretty dead. There is only one other restaurant in the mall, and it's hard to find if you don't know what you're doing. The hotel had no gift shop, and we didn't have a car, so getting the mile down the road to a drug store was not easy.I would stay here again, if I had a car, and needed to be in the area. Otherwise, I would recommend staying downtown instead. The hotels by the inner harbor are more expensive, and there's a good reason why -- they're by a lot more neat stuff, in a more fun area.I visited this Radisson from our east coast office - our offices are based right next door to the hotel.  We had several colleagues from our west coast come to the hotel where we had a conference room and all the amenities for 3 days. I called in room service on 12/15/10 at 645pm.  After ringing several times, I was transferred to the front desk, where they just continued transferring me back to room service. Sheniqua was the person who kept transferring me.  I went through literally 25 minutes of this.  Never did she take ownership to find out why no one was picking up.  She just continued transferring me back, never inquiring or never doing anything really.  Finally, I called the restaurant myself and was told someone would come to my room to take my order.  No one.  35 minutes later I walked down to the restaurant where I waited another 10 minutes for someone to even talk to me.  Finally I was able to give my order 45 minutes after I placed my initial call.During this time I was expected to work to get out work assignments that evening - what business travelers do and why I wanted room service in the first place (and now I am taking time to write a complaint when I should be working).Rest assured, I nor anyone at my company will ever stay at any Raddison hotel anywhere and anytime.  Not only have they lost a major corporate client in the area, but also a very young professional who has a lifetime of stays ahead of him.Simple as that - one employee's negligence coupled with a system wide failure of hotel staff and management (are you guys understaffed?).  How absurd it is that someone can call room service for 25 minutes and not only have anyone pickup, but then employees refuse to take ownership and figure out what's going on (and follow up to make sure the issue was resolved).  The entire hotel staff and management should be wiped out - surely if I was in charge of this operation, the failure to deliver such an elementary service as room service would warrant such a drastic change.I chose to stay at the Radisson Hotel at Cross Keys because it is just a few minutes away from my friend's home. I wasn't overly impressed with the hotel, but it's your typical Radisson at an average price ($139/night). The rooms aren't anything spectacular, but they are pretty large. The people who work at the hotel are nice and friendly, but they don't go out of their way for you like they do at some nicer hotels. I did notice that it's next to some nice restaurants and the red door spa, which I would have checked out if I was staying in the area longer.  My stay at this hotel was very convenient, but if I was staying in Baltimore for a longer period of time I would probably choose another hotel.

hotel_name: Holiday Inn Express Baltimore At The Stadiums
review_content: Better than I expected. The complimentary breakfast included hot food. Not great quality, but OK. Location is an easy walk to the stadium. The rooms were OK. Air conditioning was effective, but a bit loud. Everything was clean.I stayed at the Holiday Inn express in Baltimore for the weekend of 10/16-10/19. I booked 2 rooms with 2 month advance notice. on 10/15, I called to change one of the rooms to be a 3 night stay instead of 4. When I arrived, things went smoothly, until Friday when the check in for the second room took place. Holiday Inn originally quoted me $1192.00 for the entire stay of both rooms and suddenly I had a total of 2600 charges pending on my card. Concerned, I asked multiple times to speak to a manager and the staff said they would have someone call me. I called after not hearing back and the front desk lady hung up on me. I called again and no results. I went to the front desk multiple times throughout the day and no manager was on site. I was told Sunday, the manager Jim would be there by 8AM. I waited till 8:30AM and then was told Erica, the other manager would come at 11AM. No one showed up. The staff had no idea what was going on and they were just incompetent and rude. I called your corporate office on Sunday 10/18 and again I was told a manager would call me back.. I didn't hold my breath. I am yet to hear back. This organization needs serious training on customer service.Good Riddance!I have chosen Holiday Inn Expresses as my go to (go to sleep too tired to drive).  Upon arrival with reservation, clerk needed my reservation number to find me, odd.  I have road warrior written all over me, glazed eyes, coffee stains, disheveled, exhausted.  She look annoyed to have to put down her phone.  I gave her everything she needed and she started rattling everything pertinent to rush me off. I was EXTREMELY incensed that it's $20 a night to park!  She said my hotel key will open the gate to the lot.  So I drive around to lot in back of hotel- the "gate" is a bar that even if down could be ducked under/over.  Didn't matter, it was UP, WTH?  This is the middle of crap town, junkie, hookers, get the picture?  I'm told to display the card they give you in window.  I notice there are tons of cars w/o one.  This lot is really false security, no cameras and dark, with a short fence keeping "the hood" out.  I'd feel safer parking at the lighted gas station and pay the clerk $20 to watch it.There are no valet carts in sight, I had to schlep everything in one trip.  Awful, because the hotel is relatively empty off season, mid week.  Pass hotel clerk, doesn't look up from her phone.  This level of service can certainly be automated.The room itself is nice enough, but totally NOT worth the $$$ ($145 with parking for one night).  No restaurants around unless you go in the casino- which wasn't interested or Subway.This hotel did everything we wanted for our stay. Good location where we could walk to the stadium and Inner Harbor. And it was a clean and decent hotel for us to sleep.  Some of the reviews on here are negative and I can understand that. There were some sketchy characters hanging around outside during our stay. We didn't pay them any mind and they didn't bother us. You are going to get that at most hotels around this area. But it is a short walk to the stadiums from here.This hotel has some things going for it and some very frustrating things about it.     If you are going to be spending a considerable amount of your stay at the casino as my friend and I were for poker, then it is the closest option. Although I wouldn't recommend it for almost anything else as it is sort of hood down here and not much of a discount to reflect that reality, likely due to the increase demand coming from casino.  Also, the walls in this hotel must be made of paper mache' or something.    I am currently in my room writing this review because the front desk called our room threatening to have us removed by police because of a noise complaint by our "neighbor"    My friend and I were having a normal conversation at very normal levels of speaking. Nothing that one would even consider possible to be getting a call from the front desk. Not only that but they tell us that they called us the previous night due to a noise complaint from same said neighbor.First off, no one called our room the previous evening. period. end of story. Either the person who spoke to us is making it up or the person who reported to them that we were called was making it up. . So either we are staying next to the crankiest old man who happens to also be the lightest sleeper ever, these are the thinnest walls ever, or some combination of both, which I believe to be the case.    Either way it is extremely frustrating being someone that tends to be awake "non-traditional" hours, that any form of normal conversation or standard volume television options are eliminated because of the lack of the walls ability to keep even the smallest of sounds out.      The other thing that has been frustrating about the room is the heat/cooling system. It basically will make it in the room so that you will wake up 1-3 times a night guaranteed just to adjust the settings because it is either a sauna or an igloo. Very tough to maintain any sort of normal an acceptable temperatures.   Also, it is $20 a night to park. And yes I am sure buried in their fine print it says this somewhere but the fact is most people assume when booking a rate of $100+ per night that this might be all inclusive enough as to let your park there without a 20% increase in payment.   The staff has actually been very polite for the most part it is just annoying having to be called and threatened with removal over something that should be a total non issue. I should never have to remain silent in the room I am paying three figures to stay in, but with these walls apparently that has what it has come to. So instead I got on here and am trying to silently type and reflect the absurdity of this situation to my fellow yelpers before they send Baltimore's finest in to bust us for having a normal human conversation in a room absent of drugs, alcohol, outsiders, or anything of the sort.So overall, just make the drive from some nicer area like hanover 15 minutes away  or stay closer to the actual harbor/downtown. This location wouldnt be worth it to almost anyone who has other options.Was having a dr visit at the University of Maryland medical center and needed a place to stay. We have always used HIE in the past and were very pleased with our stay. We arrived a lot earlier than we had planned and our room was ready and we were allowed to check in. The hotel staff was very friendly and had all the amenities we love about HIE. We will be back in may when my husband  has surgery. Close to the hospital and in a nice part of town. Room was clean beds were comfy. Thanks for a great night! See you soon!Ps... Will the shuttle be able to take me to and from the University of Maryland medical center?This was one of the worst hotel stays I have had in years.  I wrote a review on Holiday Inn's website and it was rejected due to being inappropriate.  I did not mention anything that wasn't true.  I feel they just don't want to accept poor reviews and that is why it looks good on their site.  Poor service from front desk and cleanliness of hotel where my main reasons for my review.Stayed here on a weekend for an O's game and to check out the casino next door to the hotel. First time in Baltimore, so I wasn't too sure what to expect, but I had a pretty good time overall at the hotel. Front desk held our bags so we could explore the city a little bit. Parking is $20 a day, but I didn't find that to be outrageous or anything. The room was nice, definitely in line with what we paid for our stay. They offered free pancakes from 8pm to midnight, which was a nice touch. Free hot breakfast in the morning as well. Our room faced the casino so it could get kinda loud, but again, nothing we couldn't sleep through. If you're planning on going to an Orioles or Ravens game, you really can't beat staying here as you can walk to both relatively easily.The water took forever to warm up, I literally stood in the shower for 5min waiting for the water to warm up. It is also right next to a major road, so it is really loud and noisy around that area (barely got any sleep). Only good side is that it is right next to the city so it is somewhat of a walking distance to everything, and the horseshoe casino is literally right next door so for the gamblers that's good.One of the worst hotels we've stayed at. $220 per night for a run down, worn out room! Stay Away'I picked this hotel due to proximity to Carroll Park but the price was high for what they gave you.  I stayed two nights and they did not replenish my in room coffee.  I don't like being tentatively charged for parking when I said at check in I did not have a car.  The system should be able to handle it.  The room was clean so that was a plus!  If you are attending something at M&T or Camden Yards  the location is great.At least those that wish to stay at this hotel will know they have to pay for "their" room and the "parking-room" for their vehicle. Bring a pillow! I still will not be staying at this or any other hotel in that area if they charge for vehicle parking. I realize it's a "tourist" area and probably why the hotels want to suck more money from the person on their short vacation stay. :)I found a much better choice at another HIE on Rt 40 with access to everything I needed,  including my trips downtown.Had a wionderful experience at this hotel.  WO\ould recommend it especially for cruise parking.Look, if you're coming to Baltimore and don't realize in advance that some of the city isn't up to par with your white picket fence, Disney World standards.....then this hotel or even the city for that matter, aren't for you.  The hotel itself has gone through some significant upgrades over the years, including a fenced in, key only parking area.  The slightly shady Greyhound bus station is right behind the hotel and yes, there are abandoned lots surrounding the HIE, but it's not the fault of the hotel for this.....blame the taxpayers and local officials for having an eyesore so close to the city itself.  I've been staying here the past two weeks for business and it has certainly grown on me.  My rates have ranged from $108 to $124 a night. The staff is one of the friendliest I have ever encountered and it takes awhile for a Northerner to grow accustomed to the "how are you doing?" from random strangers who pass by.  My rooms have been very nice in general and what makes me the most happy is that they not only have 40" flatscreens in the rooms, they ALSO come with actual HD channels.  So many times I've been in hotels where this was wasted on the good screen, here they have DirectTV to ensure that this doesn't happen, +1 star right there. :)  Oh and as a techie, this is the time to mention how fast and reliable the completely free wi-fi is.....I've been impressed having to do work late into the night and it never dropping the signal or timing out on a page.  Criticisms are few.  Keep the pool open beyond Labor Day when it's still in the 90's!  I don't know why that's a closure time for anything below the Mason-Dixon line, somewhat annoying.  Also, the workout area is in need of an upgrade, free weights would be nice.  HIE's are all over the place when it comes to the fitness centers, some extremely nicer than others....this one needs an overhaul.  The shuttle to and from town is a nice feature, it stops at the convention center, Inner Harbor and Johns Hopkins hospital.....this is nice for those that don't want to pay for parking downtown or came in on a bus themselves.  A walk to the city would be quite a pain since it doesn't look all that pedestrian friendly.  There is a reason it's also called "At the Stadiums", this is likely the best hotel for NFL fans attending a game against the Ravens.  In fact, I'm lucky I got a room on a Thursday night prior to their home opener because they are for sure booked solid this upcoming weekend.  Go because it's cheap and has FREE transportation to the city, not for the viewsDO NOT stay at Holiday Inn Express Baltimore at the Stadiums.  Why?  Two reasons:1) This hotel makes false claims  (on its website) about its location that it is located in Inner Harbor, Baltimore. Do not be fooled. The hotel is definitely NOT in the Inner Harbor area. It is almost two miles to the Inner Harbor. It is at the Stadiums; the Stadiums are NOT in Inner Harbor. Unless you want to be at the Stadiums, DO NOT stay at this Holiday Inn Express.2) Hotel charges for parking and then denies hotel guests parking. This hotel charged $15 per night for parking. We stayed at the hotel for two nights and paid for parking for two nights, June 6 and 7, 2014. On June 7, the hotel parking lot was full and we were forced to park at a Shell station across the street. When you paid hotel for parking, you expect to park at the hotel parking lot. While the hotel clerk was not rude, she did not even apologize for the inconvenience nor offered to refund our parking fee. It appeared to her to be quite normal - to deny guests parking after they have paid for parking.Then, when we tried to park at the Shell station, the Shell employee knew NOTHING about this arrangement. He tried to call his boss but his phone ran out of power. He had to use my husband's phone to call his boss who then gave him the OK to let us park. It took 15 minutes to sort all this out. This was 11:30 pm and this is NOT something any hotel guest should have to deal with late at night.Unlike the hotel parking lot, the Shell station is not a secured area. So we paid $15 to park at an unsecured space. We might as well be parking on the street.For these two reasons I will NEVER stay at the Holiday Inn Express at the Stadiums again. If you need parking, DO NOT stay at this hotel because you may find yourself denied parking even after you paid for it and sent to god only knows which gas station in the area.  If you want to be in Inner Harbor, Baltimore, DO NOT stay at this hotel because it is NOT in Inner Harbor despite its claims on its website. PLUS, the traffic at the Stadiums is horrendous especially on game nights.  The area this hotel is in, is generally quite shabby and not a specially nice area to be sent off to park at some gas station late at night.   Oh, the  wifi is pretty much useless even though free.Is this really a Holiday Inn?  Paid $$$ online.  Then we were solicited by two homeless people for handouts during our check-in process (and the new casino is not even open yet!)  We were assigned the room closest to construction of new casino -- was it the only room left???.  Room smelled bad, burnt out light bulbs, missing shower curtain (WTH!?!).  Trash found on floor of room.  Ear plugs were provided in the room, apparently to reduce the noise in the morning.  The only positive was the maintenance man (72 yrs) showed up right away with lightbulb and shower curtain, was friendly and nice.  Maybe the new casino will hire him and he can retire shortly thereafter.Stayed at this hotel one night as we were catching a cruise ship out of the Port of Baltimore the next day.  This is a pretty bare bones, no frills hotel, but they did provide a small breakfast the next morning.  Our stay happened to coincide with the July 4 holiday, and the hotel faces a busy street as well.  I will liken the experience to trying to sleep in the middle of the Gettysburg Battlefield (fireworks) and  the Indy 500 speedway (loud traffic noise throughout the night) at the same time. It is also located in what appeared to be a rather sketchy part of town. The best part of our stay was the fact that they provide a "park and cruise" option which allows you to leave your car at the hotel for the week for a small charge while they take you  by shuttle to the cruise port and transport you back to your car upon your return. We took advantage of this offer because it is much less expensive than parking at the port for a week, and there were no problems.  In addition, there are no real options for food located nearby.  The casino is next door to the hotel, and we were told by hotel staff that this is where most of the closest food options are located.  However, we have two children under 18 who weren't even allowed to go into the casino building even though we only planned to eat. In retrospect, many hotels in that area make available the "park and cruise" service, so in all likelihood, the next time I would choose another hotel on a quieter street with restaurants and other amenities located nearby.If it weren't for the manager Michael's assistance, this would be a 1-star. We had a lot of trouble with our reservation, but the service we received from the manager was good enough to overcome what could have potentially been a drastic situation. Holiday Inn needs to empower their managers to be able to assist guests easier. It was difficult for Michael to honor our reservation without having to displace others. In the end we got what we needed, which was a room.When I arrived at this Holiday Inn they couldn't fulfill the booking I requested weeks ago. I reserved a two-bed, non-smoking room. When I arrived all they had was a room with a king bed and another with two beds but it was a smoking room. We checked the smoking room out but it smelled horrible therefore we decided to go with the room with the king bed. The manager told us he would give us a roll away bed since there was two of us.Once we got into the room with the king bed we noticed it was much smaller. The roll away bed soon arrived and it barely fit in the room. The roll away was also unmade and the mattress was broken (I attached a picture of it). They also gave us possibly the worse room in the hotel. It was right above the lobby so we heard people talking below, and cars on the busy road. It is also advertised that they have free WiFi in the rooms but the signal wasn't strong enough for our room apparently. Due to these circumstances we decided to check out at 10 PM and go elsewhere.Also I'm a Priories Club member and I booked this reservation weeks in advance so this shouldn't of happened. I also noticed that this hotel has had previous car brake-ins. They have a fence and gate so I'm not sure if this is still a problem. Just make sure you don't leave anything in plain view of the window. It is a shady area.I will give the hotel itself 4.5 stars but the area 1 star.We stayed at the hotel for 3 nights. The first night we ventured out to get food and went the wrong way apparently cause we ened up in the ghetto. We were scared for our lives. We got the gps to take us back and decided to order room service for the night. The hotel is nice and new and updated just dont go outside.
review_content_20: I guess the bottom line is you get what you pay for. We booked based on the transportation to and from the port but you can't sleep because of all of the noise from the other guests and anything that's plugged into a wall that constantly runs. Complimentary breakfast should have been called "instant breakfast". It was horrible. We waited for two hours after coming back from our trip in the freezing cold. We all ended arguing over who gets the seats. The attitudes from the drivers were unheard of. It was very unorganized. We will never stay at a holiday inn ever again because of the very poor service that we received. One night was one too many nights for us. I never thought that I would end up writing a bad review.Well...I would have given this place 2 stars if my vehicle was not broken into during my stay.  It is a subpar Holiday Inn Express, but what do you expect for a name brand hotel that is cheap and close to town?  It is completely surrounded by abandoned buildings, the Greyhound station, and shady-looking dudes everywhere.  Don't even think about walking anywhere, cause nothing is nearby except gas stations (they don't sell alcohol).  But the hotel does have free shuttles to the happening stuff at Inner Harbor.If you can get over the hotel being in a not-so-pleasant part of town, I think you'll enjoy your stay here. The shuttle service is great, and it's free so you don't have to worry about walking around here. The rooms are great too -- I got a good night's sleep on the big comfy bed.The only thing I didn't like was during the free breakfast -- they have the toaster right in the middle of the line, so if you just want to grab a cinnamon roll, you have to wait for everyone else toasting their bread. The line can get very long just for that. Otherwise, I liked the selection offered and my coffee was tasty and hot.Booked a hotel room here 3 weeks in advance for a convention. 2 days before the convention, hotel staff called to inform me that they had to transfer the booking to Extended Stay, a cheaper hotel which is 5 miles away, and for the same rate! This is the last thing you need when you're about to attend a big convention! They're so inconsiderate!It has all of the looks of an old hotel that was renovated.  The area is kinda scary and they have hotel security inside the building.  But that is nothing compared to the HUGE rat baits in the parking lot. The breakfast was even lower than the typical they didn't have the cinnamon rolls, eggs... This is the LOWEST cost option for hotels in the area.  I stayed there because we were in desperate need of a hotel.  We used the coupon from the Highway Travel magazine (pick them up in the rest areas) one night for $99 including parking, which is normally $10.

hotel_name: Fairfield Inn & Suites Baltimore Downtown/Inner Harbor
review_content: Top notch service!  Allowed me to use the laundry prior to check in and than check in early!  When I'm usually leaving between midnight and 2 in the morning every night this really is a nice treat.Stayed here for 2 nights in November. Very affordable, very clean, and in a great location. Just a couple mins walk to the inner harbor and restaurants. Only complaint we had was maid service skipped our room, and we had complain several times before they finally clean our room.Kevin Brown was my Check In person & was very professional & engaging. The hotel has two towers so be specific if you have a room view preference. The smaller hotel divisions of the big hotel chains always gives an extra effort of extending good customer service. Such as opening my bottle of Malbec & giving me a nice red wine glass for my suite. Plus the location was outstanding as my walk to Whole Foods, CVS & the Harbor was a brisk 5-10 minute walk. This hotel & awesome staff were right on the mark.Great hotel in downtown Baltimore. Customer service was outstanding from Janet at the front desk to JP in the bar, who was exceptional!! They went out of their way toAccommodate me, will definitely be back.I recently stayed at this find hotel while I was in town at a show at pier six pavilion. The hotel is a comfortable five minute walk to our destination. The entire staff that my girlfriend and I encountered were extremely friendly, polite,and hospitable.The rooms were clean spacious and very fordable. If possible, pay the small extra premium for valet parking. It's well worth it and you have 24 access to your vehicle!We reserved the room using points from my girlfriends employer-unfortunately there was a small hick up and my credit card was accidentally charged. Ellen the sales manager and Kevin who works at the front desk were very attentive in fixing situation and the entire problem was solved all before check out. We are both very grateful to their dedication and they made us feel we were their number one priority. I highly recommend this hotel to anyone that will be in the inner Harbor area and you better believe I will be back.Thanks for a great nights stay-you all were great!I called and attempted to make a Marriott rewards reservation at this hotel for a Saturday night.This hotel has a 2-night minimum stay requirement, which they enforce even for rewards travel. The Saturday night I wanted had vacancy, but they would not accept my one night rewards voucher unless I paid for Friday night.I've always been a loyal Marriott customer, but it seems very disingenuous to offer incentives to customers and then black out days where the hotel clearly has vacancy.I've maintained Gold Status for several years, but perhaps it's time that I look at other hotel chains.Not acceptable.Boy, did our floor stink! I don't even know how to describe it, but it was bad. Thankfully, the smell didn't linger into the room.The complementary breakfast wasn't bad. What you'd expect for any other Marriott.Considering I was there for the Ravens' SuperBowl victory parade, I was hoping the front desk would have more information about it, but they were totally clueless.The valet parking was $30/day, but most garages will charge you $20 plus overnight anyway so it's worth it.This place cost me 20,000 points. In hindsight, I wish I had stayed at the harbor location for an extra 10,000.I had a very good experience here.  The location is great, walking distance to restaurants and a short drive to lots more.  My room was very clean, as was my bathroom, and everything worked. Beyond those basic requirements, I found the check-in process to be very quick and efficient, due to a high level of staffing at the front desk.  The in-house restaurant was interesting looking, but my group only had a pre-dinner drink, so I don't know about their food offerings.Shavon Staten has been a dream! I am the maid of honor in my sisters wedding (Paige) and the planning has been so great because of Shavon! The weekend is coming up and we just met with her to finalize and things we weren't even thinking about she has made easier on us.... Truly an amazing experience! All of our stressors (especially my mom) were alleviated because she has been so generous and caring throughout this whole process. She is a breath of fresh air always!IA thought this hotel would be great since it was green certified and had good decor, however, it was the worst hotel experience I have ever had.The stay here was by far the worst experience in my life. I left the hotel feeling violated, frustrated, and dumbfounded that a hotel would treat a guest so badly. I checked in late at the Fairfield Inn in Baltimore.  I was not greeted that pleasantly by the night staff. I was a bit embarrassed as I was checking in with a coworker who I had recently converted to Marriott hotels. She is a preferred Starwoods member. Her comment about the staff was they were a bit "ghetto" and would our car be safe in valet. The front desk clerk checked me into a first floor room and told me there were no other options, but I overheard my friend check in and they asked her if she wanted 2 or 3rd floor. After checking in I walked to my first floor room which was just around the corner from the  front desk. When getting to my room I realized I only had my credit card and room key in my hand and was missing my Drivers License. I immediately walked back to the front desk and informed them, I thought they might have forgotten to give me back my ID. Without even looking up from her phone the front desk clerk said, "No I gave it back to you, check the floor you must have dropped it" I informed her I looked on my way back and since I was on the first floor and only gone less than a minute I would have seen it on the way back to the counter. She still said "Nope not up here" NOT EVEN LOOKING AT HER DESK, surrounding floor or putting forth any effort to find it. As you can tell I was quite upset but returned to my room thinking maybe I put it a pocket of my jacket etc. After searching all of my belongings I still did not find it.  I called the front desk and was told that if housekeeping finds it they would let me know. The next morning, I went down to the front desk where a new set of crew members were. I asked them about the ID and told them my story. They reported that the night clerk did not mention anything to them about it. I said, "Well maybe there is a safe or drawer that you put things in, maybe you could check it just in case?" Again I was met with "if she would have done that she would have told us" No one even went to look for it. By this point I was very upset as I had to fly HOME and needed the ID to get on my flight. I was met with no concern and they said they had my info and if it turned up they would call me. I continued to call all day and no one said they had seen it. I asked one more time when checking out and again the staff did not check any safe, drawer or anywhere and simply said nothing had been turned in. As you can imagine, it was very difficult to get on my flight with no ID.Upon my return home I received a call that my ID was found. The housekeeping manager found it at the FRONT DESK. I was livid. I asked the manager to mail me my ID. My story should end here HOWEVER it has been a week now and I still am without my ID. When calling to check on the status, no one can answer my questions: When was it  mailed, how it was mailed, they have no tracking number, and i am just getting general run around. At this point I have to fly AGAIN this week for both business and the Thanksgiving holidays and AGAIN do not have an ID. I will be forced to take Monday off from work and sit at the DMV to get a new one as I DO NOT know if it will be here on Tuesday or not due to their incompetence. If an ID is mailed to a customer it should have been done so with a tracking number that is given to the customer. I honestly do not even believe they found the ID. I am currently monitoring my credit as I believe the front desk clerk STOLE it.***This Fairfield is in a great location in Baltimore (right next to the nice Inner Harbor waterfront area and professional sports stadiums); it is a new hotel and it is very modern and comfortable as well as LEED-certified***This Fairfield Inn is a new location and it has a unique and different look when compared to most Fairfield Inns (or Marriott brand hotels for that matter).  It has a great brick exterior, which is consistent with a lot of the older brick buildings in Baltimore.  This look extends to the lobby, which also features the brick look as well as a nice classical wood front desk.While this Fairfield Inn feels like a classic throwback in many ways, it is very modern.  This is noticeable in its environmentally friendly nature--it is LEED-certified.  The rooms are very nicely appointed and comfortable.  The bed felt more comfortable than the beds at other Fairfield Inns I've stayed at and the digital temperature unit was much nicer than what you will find at other Fairfield Inns (it was also much cooler than the hot Fairfield Inns I have stayed at in Cleveland and Pittsburgh).The room was spacious and the bathroom was nice.  I do wish Fairfield Inns had soap dishes on their washroom counters though (it gets messy and the bars of soap slide everywhere).A stay at Fairfield Inn includes complimentary breakfast and the one here was pretty good.  There were a few hot options like scrambled eggs and sausage patties.  The scrambled eggs were fine though they did look like powdered eggs.  The sausage patties were similar to the kind that McDonald's serves; they were probably not healthy, but they were tasty.There was also a great variety of cereals and the fruit dispenser produced orange juice that was not watered down like you get at a lot of hotel complimentary breakfasts.I did not visit the fitness center, but I believe it is 24 hours.  Wi-Fi internet access is also complimentary.Service was very good.  The hotel manager seemed to be really on top of things.  He was polite, professional and very efficient.  He also seemed to managed issues effectively.  A non-guest tried to take advantage of the complimentary breakfast and the manager handled the issue without creating a scene; he also managed it in a way that was professional and respectful to both the hotel guests and the non-guest.This Fairfield Inn is in a great location; it is right next to the bustling Inner Harbor--a great waterfront area that is a must visit if you are in Baltimore even if the area is quite touristy.  Oriole Park at Camden Yards and the stadium where the Ravens play are within walking distance though it would be a long walk from this hotel.Because of its great location, the room rates at this hotel are pricey for a Fairfield Inn.  Still, it is significantly less expensive than the Baltimore Marriott Inner Harbor at Camden Yards and this hotel does offer advance purchase discounts.Fairfield Inn Baltimore Inner Harbor is a pretty nice hotel and my stay was much better than my stays at other Fairfield Inn locations.  Given its great location, I recommend it if you are spending the weekend in Baltimore and are loyal to the Marriott brand.  I actually prefer it to the Baltimore Marriott Inner Harbor at Camden Yards.  That Marriott does have a great advantage of being within two blocks of Oriole Park, but this Fairfield Inn is less expensive and provides a significantly more modern and fresher room.Parking at the non-full service Marriott brand hotels (Courtyards, SpringHill Suites and Fairfield Inns) tend to be complimentary, but since this hotel is located in Downtown Baltimore, parking requires a fee; parking is available via valet ($30).  The valets are very nice.Our first time staying at this hotel after staying at many other places in Baltimore. I would say it was a great experience and would recommend it to others. We will definitely be using them again in the future. And they have the best breakfast there too..not too many hotels that I have experienced have that great or fresh of continental breakfast waiting the next morning, everything there was so fresh and tasted great! This is a very clean and friendly hotel!Stayed here on a Saturday night after a great day at the aquarium and night out on the town. No complaints here, loved our stay. It was the cheapest rate in the area and very close to everything on the harbor. Great customer service, nice rooms. Only complaint was the continental breakfast, and that was only because there was about 40 people eating there at one time so the food was going faster than it could be replaced. Also, on top of all that, it is a green-certified hotel! Pretty cool!Honestly, this place smells like wet laundry. The staff was nice but unfortunately I wouldn't come back here. Too bad you can't open the window to air out, the plus side is that they have multiple washers and dryers!Do not stay here. The front desk employees are incompetent. I am a pretty laid back person, and I don't generally complain, but my stay was one headache after another. First, they did not have the room we reserved. My work college and I had booked a double, and they tried to put us in the "honeymoon suite" -- with one bed! Changing rooms was a nightmare. We finally got the room we had reserved, but only after one night in the other room. Our room keys also stopped working several times. We kept having to get them replaced. And the sheets were horribly scratchy. But the worst, by far, was the disaster of checkout. My colleague was leaving at 4 am, and I was leaving at 8am, and we were splitting the bill. We wanted to make sure it was split properly, so we tried to do it the night before. The man working the desk told us he could not settle the bill unless he checked us out, and that we had to do it at 4am! Now, I travel a fair amount for work, so I KNOW that it is fairly common practice to settle the bill the night before for easy morning checkout. This employee was either incompetent or lazy, or the hotel has a TERRIBLE policy. So, fine. We agree to check out in the morning. But when my colleague goes down to check out at 4am, the employee working the desk says that the computer is being backed up and she cannot check her out! Then, the employee gets mad at my friend for trying to check out at such an unreasonable hour. After my friend explains to her the details of early morning flights, the computer finally finishes backing up, and the employee proceeds to totally mess up the math of dividing the room charge. My friend does the math for her. When I go to check out a few hours later and settle my portion of the bill, a different front desk employee attempts to tell me that the room was paid in advance and the bill cannot be separated. I tell him he is wrong, that it was not paid in advance, and can he print me a copy of the itemized charges (because if I didn't sort it out, the whole thing was going to end up on my friend's credit card, making our respective work reimbursements a total nightmare). He prints the bill. I look at it and say, "Hmm, this is interesting. It says here there is a credit of $XXX and a remaining charge of $XXX. So, how is that paid in full?" He reads the bill (I assume actually looking at it for the first time) and says, "Oh, I guess it wasn't paid in advance." One mistake I can handle. Mistake after mistake after mistake is a sign of gross incompetence. No one working the desk seemed to understand what they were doing, and no one ever wanted to take responsibility. A total failure of hospitality, with no sense that guests are a priority. If the place were cheap, fine, but the charge is far too high for service this poor and sheets this uncomfortable!Very friendly staff. Room was very nice. Breakfast was good and really liked the to go bags. I stayed here for the weekend of the Baltimore running festival and really enjoyed my stay. Very reasonably priced and 5 min walk to inner harbor. I will stay there again next year.I am a Marriott Rewards Member and Travel all the time for work. I am overall highly disappointed with this hotel and its accommodations.The bed was messily made, 4 out of 5 pillows had a stain on them and the room had a musty smell..No room service menu in the room. I finally found a small version of the menu online and called down to request room service. Sunday night at 8 o clock with no one in the restaurant they told me it would be at least an hour. Also, very costly valet parking is your only option here. If coming to Baltimore, stay somewhere else.The room was musty, the decor was odd, the room service was completely disorganized and OUT OF FRENCH FRIES. How does a tavern run out of french fries?!? Also, no on demand so I hope you like watching whatever is on HGTV. The service was nice enough, but I wouldn't pay what they ask to stay here.Although the hotel is quirky inside with dark wood, brick, a light shade made from packing peanuts, and a garage door panel hanging from the ceiling it all works. Homey and warm. I was on the second floor overlooking a side street that was very close to President's.  Pretty darn loud during rush hour and later at night when police sirens are blaring. Nothing can be done about that but I would warn you from staying in room 204. The air conditioner has a ridiculous  loud vibration noise. I finally had to just turn it off to get some sleep. Hotel was sold out so I did not complain. Room was fine otherwise...clean with 2 queen beds, nice decor, and roomy bathroom.Beware if you need a cab - two of us were going to the airport the next morning and we were told it is standard procedure to charge each person a full fare because we were going on two different airlines. Really?? To save on the fare the hotel driver would take us to the airport for $38 each. The airport is 12 miles from the hotel and it is going to cost $76...call a cab yourself - it was $30 flat rate to BWI...total, not each.Beware!!Do not use valet. The hotel cannot accommodate for this service as there is a wait of about 30 minutes for your vehicle.
review_content_20: I travel to Baltimore a minimum of 2 weeks a month for a client. I have stayed at the Hyatt, the Renaissance, the Residence Inn and the Fairfield.The Fairfield is the closest hotel to my office, so I'm already a big fan of that. The Fairfield is really clean and my room (King Suite - this has the separate living area) is very spacious. The room I currently have is on the first floor and it has really high ceilings, which makes spending a lot of time in your room less cluster phobic.There are some weird things I've noticed. For instance, this hotel prides itself on being a very eco-friendly hotel. It's the biggest thing this hotel advertises, yet, the only cups in my room are disposable ones for my coffee machine. There aren't any glass ones to reuse. It also makes wanting a cup of water weird.Also, I don't know if this is because I'm on the first floor, but I don't have an ice machine in sight. I've walked the entire section of my floor looking for one to no avail. I have an ice bucket in my room, but have no idea where to get ice. Needless to say I've been drinking warm tap water out of disposable cups made for coffee.Ps, there were 3 packages of coffee in my room. All decaf. Not sure if that's part of the eco-movement, but I don't do decaf. I tried Tavern 101 and got the BBQ burger. The patty actually was really good. The bun had obviously been frozen because the center of it was cold and hard. The fries I got on the side were delicious. The prices seemed rather fair for the location and the increase for the hotel.The free breakfast is fairly plentiful. I wouldn't recommend the eggs or other hot dish, but it's really great to have breads, fruits, cereals, yogurts, etc. to choose from and snag in the AM before making your way out. The staff does an excellent job of keeping it stocked too, so you never have to worry. The coffee is quite dreadful, but that's not their fault. I suggest a different roaster.Finally, all the staff is incredibly kind and friendly. When you travel often, it's nice to be greeted warmly and made to feel comfortable.All in all, it's a pretty great stay.My 3 girlfriends and I stayed at Fairfield Inn this past weekend, for a bachelorette weekend. We came in not really expecting much, but were blown away at how great this hotel was! The staff is very friendly, and willing to go to great lengths to make your stay as comfortable as possible. The hotel itself is beautiful. Exposed bricks in the lobby, green, and has a cute little courtyard right in the middle of the building. At one point, we were very tempted to just stay at the hotel for the night, instead of going out! (We, of course, didn't. You don't drive 3hrs from Richmond just to hole up in a hotel).Pros: Hotel is very clean, modern. The room was perfect for four women (the counterspace in the bathroom proved sufficient all our night-on-the-town equipment :). Staff is great and made sure these four female out-of-towners were safe and knew where to go and who to call in case of a bind. Great location; walking distance to Inner Harbor and Power Plant. Complimentary breakfast wasn't the best, but it was actually far better than most hotel breakfasts I've had!Cons: Slow elevator. Room was a bit stuffy no matter how much we fiddled with the thermostat. $30/night valet parking (although the valet guys were thoroughly entertaining and quick to retrieve our car). This may be a little vain, but there was no power outlet next to the full length mirror, which meant we had to fight over mirror space in the bathroom to do our hair... But that was just us ;)I would DEFINITELY stay here again. In fact, we are planning to make this little getaway a tradition!Pulled up fast service from the bell man grabbed the bags and it was only complemented by the fast service at the desk, The room is neat and clean close to the restaurants and the inner harbor. When in the area i would stay again. GOOD JOBVery good location, free breakfast in the morning, free wifi, & a business center. The hotel had a gym but didn't check it out. The only two things I had a problem with were the elevator. The elevator took FOREVER!!! It seemed like it just ran really slow and basically stopped on every floor and didn't matter what time of day it was. Annoying! Also we had to pay for valet parking of $30 a night. I hate valet parking and probably could of parked down the street for a little bit cheaper.The rooms are very nice, beds are comfy. I would give this place five stars (good value! great location!) but the service I received was seriously subpar. I was in town for a conference and stayed three nights and four days. My card key stopped working at least once a day. The second night, I called for an extra towel and a blanket around 10:30 p.m., as soon as I got back from conference events. They said they'd call me back. 45 minutes later, after I had gotten all ready for bed, they called back and said I had to come down to the front desk to get the extra towel and blanket. When I got there, what they actually had for me was two handtowels and a comforter cover, essentially a thin seersucker sheet. Housekeeping was closed and it was all they had, they said. Finally, on the morning of checkout I waited for 20 minutes while the front desk helped one man who was apparently staying in the hotel long term settle some of his tab. Essentially, every time I needed something from the desk, the customer service person was all alone and I had to wait an unreasonable time for it. But, all that aside, it was a good hotel stay. The rooms were clean, stylish, and felt nice for the price. The breakfast was very good (cold and hot options) and there was free wifi.Great location, friendly staff, and comfortable beds, but our key stopped working about 7 times during our 3-day stay. Other than that, a decently good hotel.The hotel was attractive and clean, in a great location, all the amenities I needed, the room was spotless and comfy, and the free wifi actually worked really well...but the star of the show was the excellent staff. I arrived at 5:30 am to valet my car for a later check in. The guy at the valet couldn't have been nicer or more helpful. After my marathon, I could barely walk (!), the valet staff retrieved my luggage while I checked in.  The front desk staff were also very friendly and helpful, answered questions and called me a taxi when I mentioned I was just going to hail one. When the taxi didn't show, they made sure to get me another one. I just can't say enough about how impressed I was with the staff. Every. Single. One.  It definitely made my stay and I shall be back next year, or any time I need to stay overnight in Bmore again. Thank you!!!!While it's not 'technically' a 5-star hotel, it gets a 5-star review from me as a top-notch hotel.Not entirely familiar with the Baltimore area, this location was chosen for a wedding in the area. Everything we needed was either (safe) walking distance, or a $3-$5 cab ride away.The design, look-and-feel of the hotel is warm and comforting. The staff is friendly, the rooms were inviting, and all the perks -- good Continental breakfast bar, free 24-hour WiFi when needed, convenient store, on-the-go business center desk -- all made it a worthwhile experience. All at a very reasonable rate.I look forward to my next stay at this hotel, as this will definitely be the location I recommended when wanting to experience Baltimore.The hotel is pretty nice and very close to the harbor. The breakfast is not bad, but the Holiday Inn generally has more to choose from and cheaper base prices.
