So we kept the curtains closed the entire time. I wouldn't be frustrated about it if I hadn't asked for a view. I would highly recommend staying here. If you don't like eating out for every meal, and having a homier feeling hotel room, then stay here! The free dinner was awesome, especially that it was with free drinks. Lots of shopping and restaurants and water is right next to hotel and a walking path along the water. Parking at $23 a night, $32 for valet, pretty comparable to all hotels in area. Starbucks next door which was good. If you have free time, definitely just take a nice walk by the water. I'll be back here at this hotel in 6 months!Nothing bad to say about this place. Rooms, the service, location and MAC being next door make it one of my favorite stops in Baltimore.Good choice in the Baltimore area.  The room was laid out like a mini-apartment in a high rise.  People were friendly and the place was spotless.  Lot's of shops around and places to sight see.  Have fun!

review_content: My wife and I live just a few doors down from this LOVELY place.   We love walking by and seeing the quaint detailed TLC on the outside.    I look forward to taking my wife here for a weekend getaway.    It is lovely.I can't imagine that there would be a better place to stay in Baltimore than Rachael's Dowry Bed and Breakfast.  I stayed for one evening and it was definitely the right choice for picking a place to stay.  It is located right outside Oriole Park and a short walk from the light rail.  They do an unbelievable job of making you feel at home and do everything they can do make your stay very comfortable.  The room was very nice, the bed was very cozy.  Breakfast served the next morning was very good.  I can't stress enough the very comfortable and secure feeling you have while you are a guest in the house.  I would absolutely stay here again when I visit Baltimore.Lovely and unique place to stay in Baltimore. The bed was very comfortable and the room and building full of small touches like many wonderful books, orange brandy and homemade treats out every night, and well chosen antiques that never felt fussy. The neighborhood is quaint with a few good restaurants and a coffee shop. Its walkable to the conference center and harbor, though a bit of a hike to the buzzier local neighborhoods. The one bummer is the limited availability of breakfast from 8-9am. I understand that many people stay here for conferences, but its very difficult for those visiting from more western timezones to drag ourselves out of bed on time. Maybe extend the hours a bit if only on the weekends? (admittedly- I did not ask, as I was planning to get up and slept right through my alarm instead, oops).I stayed at Rachael's from Sunday-Thursday because I have accepted a research position with the University of Maryland-Baltimore and I needed to come up to fill out paperwork and do some training with my new lab.  This was a very short walk away from the medical building where the office is so I was very happy with that.  There are so many reviews that I thought I might take some time to hi-light some of the details that don't often come up in the reviews I read.Breakfast: The breakfast is excellent.  The typical breakfast hour is between 8 and 9.  My HR orientation started at 8:15 and they were flexible with me and had breakfast available starting at 7:30.  I was very appreciative.  For breakfast expect to come down every morning to a table set just for you with a dish of fruit tossed with yogurt (I'm guessing vanilla) and topped with home made granola.  The fruits I had included things like fresh pears, bananas, cherries, oranges.  You wouldn't think that oranges would be right with yogurt, but it was nice.  There is also a small glass of juice at the table waiting for you (e.g. cranberry apple) and a cup ready for self-service coffee.  The coffee is a very strong roast (I would guess a french roast) and is apparently local.  I love that the coffee was self service because sometimes I want one cup and sometimes a want 3 cups, and I would rather get my own rather than wait.  Just as a tip, I did see that he has to go cup lids available if you're a take-away coffee kind of person then you should just ask.  Then the entree comes, I'm just going to list what I had on each day so you can get the feel of what to expect.  I like everything I ate:Monday: Something like an egg frittata with pineapple in it (I know, strange, but very good, the pineapple became caramelized and was excellent, 2 link sausages, and some sweet breakfast breadTuesday: Another baked egg dish with some hot peppers in it, bacon, and little heavy breakfast muffins with butterWednesday: Poached eggs on butter english muffins and sausagesThursday: Buckwheat pancakes with toasted almonds and warm maple syrup along with sausages and orange slicesThere were also a small fresh batch of cookies every afternoon.  I think that I personally ate almost all of the peanut butter cookies on Wednesday afternoon by myself (ops).  There is also honey cognac available.  I will often drink a bit of honey whiskey at home/make a hot toddy with it.  I started to feel like I was getting a cold and I poured some into a cup of hot tea, it was a good substitute.  I stayed in the Carrie Frank suite the first day and the Randolph room the other 3 days.  The bath products have a lovely floral scent.  The rooms are very clean.  The sheets are very soft.  The bed in the Randolph room was comfortably soft, the bed in the Carrie Frank suite was impossibly hard, I would strongly suggest a new mattress.The neighborhood is great.  There is a sort of general convenience store next to the house which would be great to get a snack or something.  There is a coffee place next to that called Sidewalk Espresso Bar, and the lovely Corner Bistro and Wine Bar is very close too.  Don't get turned off by all of the market prices listed on the menu.  They are really nice there, and I almost got the impression that they were even nicer to me because I was staying here.  I had a great stay.  I did not regret the choice to stay in a B&B rather than picking a big chain hotel.A bed and breakfast gem nestled in a delightful neighborhood with plenty to see, do, eat, and drink within walking distance.  This is my second year in a row staying here and I will be back again.  If you are staying here please try the Sidewalk Cafe, only a few blocks away, also The Corner Bistro and Wine Bar.Excellent in everything they do. I stayed Thursday thru Sunday while attending a conference at the nearby Hilton, and I'm so happy I selected this charm-filled B&B rather than the host hotel. A month later I still remember the delicious breakfasts, served at a time that suited my unfortunately early starts - spicy eggs, dairy-free muffins made especially to suit my dietary restrictions and fresh fruits. The bedroom was enormous with a spacious, comfortable four-poster bed giving excellent nights of sleep. Of course, it goes without saying that the service was incredibly friendly and personable. Has my highest recommendation.Really enjoyed my stay here.  The House is beautifully decorated with period antiques, books and clocks.  The host made a great breakfast, wish I hadn't had so many early breakfast meetings as part of the conference!  I definitely recommend staying here.This was my first bed and breakfast and I was very impressed.  The home was very comfortable and welcoming.  Tish was very friendly and accommodating.  We were also impressed with the homemade breakfast!  The home and neighborhood were quiet, despite it being a block away from the ballpark.  The location is also very conveniently located to the harbor and Camden Yards.  We will definitely be staying here again and highly recommend it to others looking for comfortable, homey accommodations in Baltimore.Great place to stay.  Tish was very accommodating.   The location, room, food and hospitality are as good as it gets.    Walking distance to the inner harbor.   Highly recommended.DaveAs a native "Baltimoran," it was a pleasure to have an opportunity to be a guest in my former hometown! This B&B is a treasure!  Staying at this well-located Inn helped turn a weekend of family duty into a lovely weekend of exploration and comfort! The Inn is beautiful and so well-maintained!  There is simply nothing that could have been better: the sleeping accommodations, the bathroom, the breakfast, added amenities and of course, the warm but not intrusive hospitality.I encourage you to stay at Rachael's Dowry, but hope there will be room at the Inn for us when we want to return.My husband and I stayed at Rachael's Dowry which is located in the heart of Baltimore, walking distance to the inner harbor.  Tish was an excellent hostess and made our stay very comfortable.  Our room was outstanding, the breakfast was yummy terrific, the location was convenient and the experience sold my husband on future B&B visits.  We had a fabulous Bicycle Tour with Penny, the owner at Light Street Cycles.  She rode her bike and met us at Rachael's Dowry and we took off from there for a leisurely 15 mile tour of the inner harbor and surrounding area.  How awesome to spend a couple of days in a quaint residential area, blocks from Camden Yard and a perfect location to enjoy neighborhood restaurants.Close to the harbor, sporting arenas and great food!  One of the most comfortable beds I've every slept in. And most importantly wonderful hosts!My husband and I stayed here when attending an event at the Hippodrome. We were able to walk there and to an excellent restaurant recommended by Tish: Forno. Our room was absolutely lovely and comfortable. Norman, our host, was wonderfully attentive, offering history of the area and the house. Each room in the house is beautifully appointed and individually unique. Elegant, including charming antiques. The house is quiet, the fire delightful for early morning reading and late evening cosy comfort in rooms with a fireplace--gas but well done. We are staying there again--in another room--this weekend and look forward to staying each time we visit Baltimore! Breakfast was simple (and varies): delicous coffee, juice, eggs, bacon, english muffin, fruit with lovely yogurt topping. Charming dining room. Good romantic getaway. Easy walk to the Harbor area.What a great stay! We were only there for one night but it was wonderful. Norman was so pleasant and welcoming. The inn is warm and inviting. Very romantic. Everything was extremely clean and updated. I would highly recommend this bed and breakfast. I definitely plan to return when it's warmer out and I can explore more of Baltimore. Breakfast was delicious! Thank you Norman!Wonderful hospitality and great charm. Tish was very considerate to the needs of our family and made us feel quite welcome. We will stay here again if we are back in Baltimore again!Aaaaafrigginmazing!  stayed for two nights with my boyfriend. We were on a Baltimore food tour. I researched many restaurants Glad I did!The weather was crappy- so we drove everywhere (all the awesome places were close)Back to B&B gorgeous - breakfast was deelish The host was awesome & sweet! The room was quiet and relaxing. I def took advantage of bathtub.Can't wait to go back this summer (hopefully make a Yankee game down there)The location is excellent. We were able to walk to the inner harbor and the stadiums. Breakfast was wonderful. The rooms are clean and comfortable. The owner, Norman, is kind and friendly. We will certainly stay if we are in the area again.What an amazing find!  My husband and I stayed here for our mini-moon.  We scoured the internet looking for a nice play to stay in Baltimore, and were excited to book Rachael's Dowry based on the excellent customer reviews.  This place did not disappoint in the least!Titia, one of the proprietors, contacted us shortly after we made our reservation with helpful information and directions to their private parking lot (no extra charge).  We parked our car and never moved it because the B&B's location was super convenient...a short walk to Camden Yards and all of the attractions at the inner harbor.  Our room (which we selected from the several available) was tastefully and comfortably decorated, with modern amenities that didn't take away from the historic/period touches.  The rest of the B&B was wonderfully restored, and we were invited to walk around and enjoy it as if it were our own home.  We felt so welcome!The breakfasts were incredible.  I looked forward to seeing/smelling/tasting the delicious meal we'd be surprised with each morning.  Everything was locally grown or made, and prepared fresh each morning by Norm, the main proprietor (I need to get his recipes).  We'd usually move to the cozy shaded garden in back and let breakfast settle before heading out for the day.We had such a great overall experience, we intend to return to Rachael's Dowry at least once a year for a romantic get-away.  This place was top notch.This bed and breakfast is fantastic. The owners did a great job of renovating a historical building to create a comfortable and tasteful abode with modern conveniences while retaining the charm and details of the building's background. The balance and touches of history and modernity are just the right mix, not overwhelming or stuffy (nor flowery).The large room we stayed in had tall windows that looked out on to their beautiful garden and the street. Even the bathroom was large and beautifully outfitted.Located within a quiet charming (i know, i said charming already...) little network of old little buildings and streets. Perhaps a bit like a miniature NYC West Village? There is a large front garden, so it' set back from the street. It's also walking distance to the stadium, convention center, waterfront, and med school.Parking, WiFi, TV, library, great big breakfast, cookies, water, cognac, thick sheets and towels, host is helpful and non-intrusive.I travel once every 6 weeks and find corporate hotels rather boring and uninteresting, so asked my wife to find me a nice place in Baltimore. Rachael's Dowry B&B place is fantastic, great hosts, great room, very quiet and clean and a delicious breakfast. The rooms are beautifully restored with modern conveniences such as wireless internet (great for me as a business traveler). Breakfast was lovely with great attention to detail and beautifully cooked food, I have never been this relaxed on a business trip before. I'll be back......
review_content_20: Stayed over Memorial Day weekend and had an incredible time. We stayed in the Ella Virginia suite and it couldn't have been more cozy and comfortable. We had plans to go out and see the city but it was a struggle to leave the room at times. The rest of the house could not be more charming, as well. Tish was an unbelievable host, and the breakfast each morning was divine.I cannot recommend this place highly enough!Coming from a first time B&Ber... we absolutely loved our stay! The owner, Tish, is welcoming and helpful, but not overwhelming. The home is charming, beautiful and very clean. The breakfast was different each morning and was a real treat. My girlfriend and I recently stayed a weekend in January and will definitely go back.My wife and I extremely enjoyed our one night stay at Rachael's Dowry. We stayed in the Randoph Room and it was very accommodating. We could not ask for a better location in Baltimore, as we attended the Orioles game at Camden and we enjoyed walking to the Inner Harbor. We will not stay anywhere else but here when we return to Baltimore.I stayed here for 10 days, and i couldn't have been happier with the room, the food, and the hospitality. Tish and Norman are both great cooks, and they are super nice, too.My husband and 13 year old vegetarian daughter joined me a few days after i arrived. They were just as impressed as i was. My daughter was served her own special breakfasts, and she was very comfortable staying there.I really could not recommend Rachael's Dowry enough to anyone wanting to stay in Baltimore. Be sure to check out Corner Bistro and Peace and a Cup of Joe just a few blocks away, too.Our B&B experience at Rachael's Dowry was perfect. We came for a one night stay in Baltimore to explore the inner-harbor and particularly the aquarium and science museum. The B&B is within easy walking distance (5-6 blocks) and would be a good place to stay if you were planning to go to the convention center as well!The B&B itself is really well put together and is run in a fun, no-nonsense, kind of way that lets you get past any logistics and lets you relax. The bedroom was great with a a cute electric fireplace and lovely antique furniture that made it all very cozy. My wife and I stayed int he Ella Virginia Bath Suite which was fantastic. The bed was very soft and having the bath for us to relax with some (provided) bubble bath was great.I would recommend this to anyone visiting Baltimore and the inner-harbor area.(Thanks Tish!)Wonderful find in an incredibly convenient location. We came down for a long weekend for a convention/mini vacation and really wanted to find a more palatable price tag than the hotels near the Inner Harbor. Looked all over the web and found this B&B, which was much more reasonable per night AND included free parking and breakfast. Our walk to the convention center was 15 minutes at most, basically just on the other side of the baseball stadium. And by the way, there were games both nights of our stay but you wouldn't know since you could barely hear it, even being so close.Tish (innkeeper) couldn't have been any friendlier. She gave us very helpful recommendations for local eateries, remembered the activities we'd mentioned and gave us directions to and from our destinations. Her breakfasts were awesome, and she was very thoughtful. She asked about vegetarian preferences, and made me a separate quiche without meat.We stayed in the Ella Virginia Suite and the room and furniture were gorgeous. Everything was clean and well maintained. All in all, this was far better than getting ripped off for a generic stay in a chain hotel. We will definitely recommend to friends and family and book for future visits to town!A wonderful option near the convention center. I had a large, comfortable and clean room with sumptuous colonial furnishings, delicious fresh-baked cookies, custom-made breakfast, and all for less than the Hilton a block away was charging. Highly recommend.Rachel's Dowry: a Bit of Shangri-la in Ridgley's DelightRachel's Dowry, though it has been in business for only a few years, might have been conceived as a bed and breakfast. It is so ideally suited to that purpose that it can hardly be imagined as anything else. Its excellent accommodations, antique-filled rooms, and aura of comfort are as quintessentially "B & B" as its historical lineage and walkable locale.The house is Ridgley's Delight's most imposing and has outlasted innumerable dust-ups and reconfigurations, not only to the City of Baltimore, but to a politically complicated country that has been invaded once and attempted to tear itself apart fifty years later. Orioles Park/Camden Yards looms above its chimneys and cornices to the east while two-lane roads that are lined with two and three-story houses meander along, away from, and catty-corner to, its spacious front yard. Rachel's Dowry was built in 1798 and has bones to match. And while its facade is Victorian, its interior hearkens back to the days when George Washington was said to have slept in every home and wayfarers from New York and Philadelphia found a comfortable place to land while they were in Baltimore City on business.Modern-day guests may well gawk at its well-appointed interior, which has been restored to such a fare-thee-well that its many nuances go, paradoxically, unnoticed. Yet all of its amenities blend to create an experience that is tinged with the brandy one can sip in its library and suffused with the light that is filtered by a "heritage" magnolia in the courtyard, from which a guest may enter after parking in its private lot.One may choose from six rooms, which can be found in the main house as well as an annex that had very likely housed slaves and servants. The one my fiance and I stayed in was appointed with a fine four-poster bed, a fireplace whose flames could be remotely controlled, and a basin-style "water fountain". Its bathroom, while small, was well-designed, with a walk-in shower and "green"/single-flush toilet. The room's color-scheme was as calming as its view of the courtyard, whose brick-inlaid charm was as potent as any of the house's interior features.Though we didn't utilize them, complimentary internet, satellite TV, as well as iPod/iPhone docking stations, were available to us. (We are luddites whose techno-savvy extends to opening car doors.) Solar panels contribute to an energy-efficient heating and air-conditioning system. And should business-folk want to catch up on emails, work stations provide for that. Our host, Norman Finnance - who, along with his sister, Letitia Finnance Bohner, renovated the house in 2010 - could not have been more generously unobtrusive, though he was always accessible and never less than gracious. He and his sister are obviously in love with the place. No B & B in my experience has been given such lavish care and attention. Mr. Finnance (et al) is so intimately acquainted with the restoration process - which was necessary to get the house "in gear" - that his subtle decision-making is embedded in every little thing. His thoughtful questions regarding our nutritional preferences bore fruit (as it were) in our breakfast, which suited our vegan propensities to a T. Kudos should not be spared on the dining-room, whose marble fireplaces and random-width floorboards evoked the past as unassumingly as the parlor into which it flowed. Because of a security system that was easy to operate and understand, our comings and goings were drama-free. Though I don't claim to have much savvy in this regard, I have stood outside of hotel rooms pleading with the gods to let me in. Eventually a three-dimensional person comes, to our mutual embarrassment, and rescues me. At Rachel's Dowry, there was, thankfully, no need to worry about being stranded outside. What was wrong with Rachel's Dowry? If I could think of something, I'd love to share it with you. But when perfection comes into one's life, it's best to enjoy it and hope that it won't be the last time. Rachel's Dowry is at 637 Washington Boulevard, Baltimore, MD 21230.It can be reached by phone at (410) 752-0805 or through its website, whose address is: rachaelsdowrybedandbreak...Rachel's Dowry accepts Visa, Master Card, American Express, and Discover cards. Cancellations must be received twelve days before check-in in order to avert a deposit forfeiture. Many attractions, including the Inner Harbor area, are within walking distance. Consult the website for the comprehensive choices that will be available to you.Rachael's Dowry is a gem! Located near the heart of downtown Baltimore this Inn is fewer than 10-minutes' walk from the Convention center and the Piers (Aquarium, Museums, Entertainment, etc). The rooms are lovingly restored, spacious and thoughtfully decorated. We stayed in the room with the large soaking tub on the top floor. The bed was so comfortable.Rachael's Dowry includes special treats (but they're a surprise!) that make you, the guest, really feel like the innkeepers are happy to have you there. Parking is included in a lot with video surveillance just around the corner. Free Wi-Fi is available and the innkeepers are incredibly knowledgeable about the area. They give good recommendations for entertainment and dining venues.The breakfast was delicious and included fresh-squeezed orange juice--yum!I highly recommend this place; we will be back!MgOur stay in this lovely old house (1798) was enhanced by the friendliness and culinary talents of our hostess and the historical information shared by her co-host. We were too busy to take advantage of the lovely patio and library but enjoyed passing through them. Though the house was an easy walk from the Inner Harbor, it was very quiet and peaceful. Looking forward to a return visit.As one of the first guests ever to stay at Rachel's Dowry B&B, I can't say enough good things about it! Such a GORGEOUS house with a fabulous restoration. The attention to detail is impressive and I could definitely see George Washington staying there (which he really did!).The rooms are beautiful and the hosts are SUPER friendly! Not to mention the location being PERFECT for baseball games (only 1.5 blocks to the stadium) and about a 10 minute walk to the inner harbor. We stayed in the Ella Virginia room which was very cozy. My favorite part might have been the bathtub though! We will definitely be coming back again soon! Can't wait to see the huge magnolia tree in bloom!

hotel_name: Inn at the Colonnade - A DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel
review_content: You get as many warm cookies as you want. I think that sold it for me. I must have consumed about 12 cookies during my 2 night stay there. The staff was very professional and nice.Cookies aside. I think the location near Med Star Union Memorial Hospital and John's Hopkins University makes it ideal of any trips that involve those two sites. In addition for Med Star Union Memorial there is a set rate for 109 dollars a night.The room I got was enormous. I had a view of the JHU campus. All the furnishings were good. There are a few areas were you can see the age of the building, but those are minor issues. Overall didn't see any reason not to give them a full 5 stars.This is a real black mark on the Hilton brandThey get 2 stars, but only because their staff is very helpful.Unfortunately you have to call on them all too often. Foolishly we've stayed there twice because of its proximity to Union Memorial Hospital, but never again. The rooms aren't maintained. TVs aren't connected, outlets too loose to hold a plug, Jacuzzis that don't work (but are advertized), a WiFi that is substandard, showers and mattresses that are spotty....I speak from experience with 4 rooms as we needed changes made both times.Beware of the pricing. They are way high for the Baltimore market. Parking is expensive at $25 a day. Deals that purportedly get 20% off don't. (But they will get you stuck into a room that's a bit bigger than a closet.) Restaurant is also pricey, and while the free breakfast is OK, the dinners are to be avoided.Hilton would be well advised to jettison this franchise and find another one for the staff to work at. It's just two floors of rooms that seem to have low occupancy judging by the traffic in the restaurant and lobby. (For example, the breakfast at the resturant is free, but diners seem to easily outnumber staff) Seems it's just a tag-on to a much larger condo association. The franchise operators are clearly gouging the hotel market and squeezing as much out of the building as they can.I booked this venue based on the beautiful Atrium and the friendliness of the staff- in particular Rebecca. I had no issues until the day of. I was informed that my wedding scheduled to take place in an hour and a half was not able to take place in the Atrium. It was made out to be a freak accident. I found out later by hotel staff that this is a reoccurring issue at the hotel. I made a complaint after I returned from my honey moon. My once friendly Rebecca was now combative and extremely unhelpful. She claimed to talk to the Catering Manager and they offered me $500 back after spending almost $15,000. I told Rebecca that was unacceptable because I spent at least $500 on decorations for that room alone. I asked that the Hotel Manager give me a call back and was never contacted. I have been following some hotel events, and since my wedding 5 events (that I know of) have been moved due to the rain. Also, included in our price was a honeymoon room. The hot tub in the room did not work nor did the shower. No bubbles despite the apparent button to turn on the hot tub and the special shower (with bluetooth/steam/etc) did not work at all. Was a regular shower. I have now contacted a lawyer to try to get some of my funds back.Rooms are good sized and clean, and the staff are incredibly friendly. I think that the showers and tubs are a little dated and could use and upgrade and some improved water pressure, but the staff is so incredibly pleasant I'd ignore that little problem.Great location if you are visiting Johns Hopkins University.My wife and I stayed here last week. The staff here is very friendly and helpful. The rooms are a great size and clean. It's nice to get away even though we live outside of Baltimore. We usually go out and have a night on town... so it's nice to have a place to stay where everyone is so friendly. Definitely check this place out it you are out and about. I've seen some of the bad reviews, but this place really is a great place to stay.I have to be honest and acknowledge how wonderful and amazing this hotel and staff were to me and my friend during our girls trip. I enjoyed our room immensely however that was second to the SERVICE. from the valet, concierge, front desk (Warren especially) and house keeping, my friend and I did not want to leave. Food...the restaurant Alizee is amazing, wonderful and not a disappointment. I loved everything from the risotto, shrimp cocktails, crab cake and soup of the day etc. Just to name a few....words can't express how I enjoyed my stay. This us the hotel to stay. It's 15 min from the harbor which was ok by cab for 14 bucks. This will be my go to place. Rating this first doubletree stay was a pleasure. I highly recommend.Had a two day reservation and last minute the day before wanted to make it a one day. Hotel refused saying there was a two night minimum. Nowhere on the websitie was this ever stated and they refused. Have stayed here before so close to Johns Hopkins but never again. I guess they would rather have an empty room. Will post this on Hopkins parents page as well telling people not to stay here. So Unaccommodating. The room is available we r talking one day in advance. The hotel would rather have an empty room.Don't understand the three star rating; this hotel is very, very nice, and considering the surrounding neighborhood (around jhu) I'd say this hotel is EXCELLENT. I had a great experience with the helpful staff and the clean, spacious rooms. I did encounter some annoyance when the person on the other end of the room service call had NO idea what their menu was all about (made me feel rather silly asking for an item that was listed as BEING INCLUDED with the meal I ordered).... but then again it was early in the morning, so being not a morning person at all I was commiseratingly forgivable. (Still, learn your freaking menu, Staff. You're lucky your gratuity is automatic because the combo of my tired, crankiness and your rude, ineptness would yield NO tips whatsoever). jAnyway. Room service aside, wonderful place to stay.And you get a freakin' warm cookie when you check in! You can't get mad at that!Update : the vending machine in floor 2 doesn't work and steals money. Room service adds automatically 20% tips + 6 dollars to the room account, which is a shame ! Don't give extra tip. The restaurant looks elegant and the free cookies at the reception are really good. But the room is dusty, we got allergies all night. The walls are so thin, you hear what your neighbors say. When the A/C decides to work, it's very noisy and it gives dust.Pretty classy looking place. I came for a health and wellness expo. I have to say that even though the event itself was pretty nice- the area it was held in was strange. It was just not set up well. I would like to try the restaurant inside one day. I will have to come back to get the real feel of this place.Staff were cheerful and warm. Loved the bedding and plentiful towels. And...the "guess what else you have to pay for" speech at check-in was really annoying. I travel quite frequently and haven't seen such a time-consuming nickel-and-dime vibe in a while. $20 per day for parking in a neighborhood with limited transit is just ick. The walls were thin and the hallways were noisy, especially during the day. Gym was about average for the type of hotel- adequate, as long as there's only one person there. This place is clearly cut out as an event space and not a place to relax, at all. There was pretty much constant activity- they even curtained off the ice machine! Maybe that's nice for whoever booked the event, but I didn't appreciate it.Definitely not worth what we paid for. "Whirlpool jet tub" was disgusting. King size bed was low end. Pull out bed in sofa was absolutely horrific. And bathroom fan may as we'll have not existed the bathroom felt like a swamp after a shower. HHonors member very disappointed. Pool is nonexistent and "fitness room" includes 2 treadmills and a bench press. Very disappointed in you DoubleTree Hilton.$20 a night to have a refrigerator in your room??? This place could use more traffic but nickel and diming customers is not the way to go.The good: Friendly, good food, good bar, clean lobby, clean hallways.The bad: Hilton should be ashamed to list this as their hotel. So lets run down the list of issues since entering my room: The first thing I noticed was that the sofa cushions were flipped around, so the zipper was facing outwards. I thought this was odd and spun it around so the zipper wasn't exposed to find that the correct facing side was sliced open with a knife (I assume the staff will just flip it around again when I leave). The vertical moulding strip along a corner that goes from floor to ceiling is only attached at the bottom two feet of the wall, so the top of the moulding is pulled away from the wall and dangling. About an hour prior to going to sleep I found a fairly large 1" spider on the bed waiting for me, that made for a nice sleep. The shower heated quickly, but the sink took over a minute before the water was tepid...I didn't stick around for hot. The shower tub was a faux-jacuzzi, meaning it was a jacuzzi tub, but the knobs were replaced with blanks, and presumably any water that went into the tubs jets (which are present) would just sit there after the shower. I have no idea how old soap scum and water is cleared out from the jets. The thermostat is digital, and I guess uses a battery that needs to be replaced as you can barely read the dim display unless at an extreme angle. The clock radio had a broken bezel that fell off when I moved it. I don't know what's wrong with the toilet, but it's an insanely weak flush. As others have noted, there is a lot of dust, looking around the ceiling, almost every edge between the wall and popcorn ceiling has a line of dust and cobwebs. But it's all okay, because free cookie, right?I stayed at this hotel for one night and the service was excellent. I arrived at 1:30 AM and the night staff was courteous, warm, and professional, unlike at some hotels where I have arrived very late at night. The valet handed me a chilled bottle of water when I gave him my car key and the front desk staff handed me a warm chocolate chip cookie when I checked in. Even minor mishaps, such as my room key not working, were handled smoothly and efficiently. My request for a very late checkout (3:00 PM) was also accommodated, which I find to be unusual these days.I ordered the crab and artichoke ravioli from room service for lunch and it was excellent. It was also probably the fastest room service delivery I've ever experienced (just under 20 minutes.)I stayed in a standard king room and it was clean and very spacious. The decor in the interior of my room was very slightly shabby, but the (apparently) newly renovated bathroom with whirlpool tub and Crabtree & Evelyn bath products made up for it. My room had a not-so-lovely view of the parking lot, but it did have a large balcony with patio furniture.For the price, I think this hotel is an excellent value. IMHO, it deserves more than the 3 stars it is currently averaging on Yelp.It was clean and the staff were really nice but it was expensive. Parking and breakfast are not included. My boyfriend and I went there for only one night to experience the night life of inner harbor and check out a game. We're not familiar with Baltimore so if you want places that you can easily walk to from the hotel at a reasonable price, don't stay here. Taking a cab to inner harbor is about $2-15 each way.It was expensive, for one night it was just over $170, even with my AAA discount. yikes.This a nice budget-friendly hotel option. I came to Baltimore on a work trip and this place was recommended to me because it's location is convenient to everywhere I was going. I was pleasantly surprised that it was part of the DoubleTree/Hilton chain - they're my go-to, and the warm cookie at check-in is always an awesome surprise. The hotel was easy to find, the parking garage is clearly marked and connected to the hotel, the lobby was clean and pretty and spacious. The room was nice - again, everything seemed clean. The bathroom was a little small and the vanity area has absolutely wretched lighting, but that wasn't too bothersome. My only real annoyance was the heating system - it never seemed to reach the temp that I set it to so it was a little chilly the first night. The housekeeping staff must have fiddled with the settings when they came in during the day because when I returned that night it had been reset to a different temp. Also for some reason there's this faction of hotel heating systems that suck all the moisture out of my skin overnight, and this was one of them. But overall, that really isn't a big deal. The hotel was super safe, clean, the staff was friendly, and it was only $70/night. I'd definitely stay here again.There aren't that many hotels north of downtown to stay in. We found this one last minute. It's expensive, but we asked if we could have a discount and got $30 dollars off and the guy slid two chocolate chip cookies across the counter. The beds were super comfortable. You do have to pay for parking, but there is also free street parking across te street between 6pm and 10 am. We were charged for te garage parking, but when we said we parked in the street, they removed the charge. Staff is nice.* Very nice hotel to stay at, but be forewarned, you have to pay extra for parking in their garage & it is expensive! The front desk staff people were fine, businesslike, but not friendly (no smiles).The room was great ~ clean, comfortable and nicely decorated. The mattress was very comfortable & the room temperature was fine. The bathroom is modern & has a real cast iron tub & marble walls. The shower had good water pressure and temperature. No complaints.I found this hotel in marylandhotels.com. The room rate was good (I called at 9:30pm for a room for that night); was quoted $56., which was in the price range I was willing to pay. After taxes, it was $61. There is valet parking, but I decided to park the car myself after checking in. Why? As I said in the beginning, if I used the parking garage, it would have been very expensive, so I parked on the street, knowing that I would be out early the next morning. No problems with that.I would recommend this hotel & would stay there again if I need to return to Baltimore.* I wrote this review for a friend (a 38 yr old single male) who stayed at the Inn At The Colonnade after attending a convention in Baltimore; however, he isn't "into writing reviews". It's pretty much verbatim.if I could rate just the VALET portion of this, that's what i'm doing. This Valet department is a joke! The staff is rude, arrogant, unwilling to help, and CANT DRIVE! They parked my car, okay, they pulled it out, and took it against a pole! The guy gets out of the car denying he did anything, after I watched him do it claiming he thought it was the windshield wipers! WHATTTTT! Now here we are, two months later and this joke of a hotel is jerking me around of my money for the damage there guy did! I sent in a review to the corporate of the hotel and they are now jerking me around, stating they will send me a $75 gift card! WHAT?! How is that going to fix my car. They issued me a small portion of the money, but still owe me $350. The "valet manager" is now denying there was damage to my wheel. When the original paperwork report and night of incident, he took pictures of the wheel as well as documented damage on my wheel. I AM FURIOUS! What a joke! I went to the hotel for an event, not to stay. and I will never step foot in this hotel again! So, word of advice, if you come here to stay DONT VALET YOUR VEHICLE!
review_content_20: Of all the hotels my husband and I have stayed at over 26 years, we agreed that this hotel was the worst by far.  We were simply shocked at how small and outdated the room was. Overall SF of the room was perhaps 120FT?The bathroom had no vanity space. I had to put my makeup bag on top of the toilet.The bathroom had no towel rack.The entire bathroom, including the shower, was about 5'x7'?The shower curtain was ripped.There was 1 bath towel, 2 hand towels, 2 tip towels--I've never been to a Hilton where only 1 bath towel was provided. I saw other guests asking for additional towels at the Reception. I didn't know why until I got to the room.The closet was half the size of average hotel room closets.The telephone was from the 80's.There was only 1 free outlet in the entire room. I had to plug in my phone there and the IPad in the bathroom.The AC/Heater was so loud that we turned it off to get some peace and quiet.The hallways on the 2nd floor *HHonors floors was hideous and smelled "old."Instead of flowers, there was a sad looking unhealthy house plant on display near the elevator.The elevator was outdated and slow, subpar to what is available on the market.The flowers near the tour desk was literally dead and the water in the vase was completely depleted.They're  very lucky that the hotel is the closest chain hotel to Hopkins. Otherwise, I'm not sure how much business they'd get. I took pictures of the room and plan to post on Hopkins parents Facebook page, Expedia and other websites to never go to that facility unless they would like to experience a 1 or 2 star hotel room where they can see what claustrophobia feels like.  I was so disgusted that I really wanted to leave immediately. The only consolation was the friendly staff.  Sorry, but the  facility needs to be reevaluated by the Hilton Group.  It's time for an upgrade or set appropriate expectations with future guests. The Colonnade is a 1.5 or 2 star facility.Rooms are so so. The heating system is completely messed up, so the rooms are always cold. The only heat output in my room is in the bathroom, facing inwards (towards the shower).  In my experience the rooms are poorly lit too.Last night the smell of cigarette smoke started wafting into my room through the ventilation system, at one point it was quite strong. Probably some idiot smoking in their room, so not the hotel's fault, but it's a risk you take with shared HVAC.The biggest problem is lack of attention to detail. Instructions for how to use the business center printer were incorrect and incomplete. The front desk failed to properly validate my parking. In general the place is just really disorganized.Location is convenient to JHU, which is why people stay here.I probably won't stay here again next time I am in Baltimore even though it means a less convenient location to get to JHU.I would like to say this is a 3.5 rating by my standards. We were fortune to get a special using our AAA discount so the rate wasn't horrible. Parking was extra and pricey at that. Hotel is pretty big but our room was located near the elevator so it wasn't too inconvenient. Our room was fine, nothing super fancy but served our purposes well enough. I do remember the water jet features were broken and it was annoying since I wanted to take a bath. Oh well.The wi-fi is free provided you get the access code from concierge.   For our stay, the hotel was conveniently located enough since we had a rental car and were hitting different areas of the city. There is a coffee shop in the hotel for standard coffee and snacks. Another local coffee shop is outside the hotel about a 3 minute walk away. Would I stay here again? Well, if the rate was cheap- I might.The staff are friendly and helpful, giving me good first impression.The room is spatial but the decoration is a little old.The WiFi is the SLOWEST I've ever seen.  Never got a single email downloaded, not to speak streaming video.We came to Baltimore for a short vacation.  Choose this inn because it states there is a gym and pool.  I give it ONE STAR because the pool & gym failed miserably.  I can't swim in the pool as first it was extremely dirty  (you basically can't see what's ahead).  Second, the depth of pool is so shallow that one basically can't swim in it.  I was utterly disappointed with the pool as well as how uninviting and weird the gym lay out is!I do like the spaciousness of the room but hated the air con system which automatically came off and on according to certain temp.  I felt warm and cold at times as the air came off through a small vent and as a result cause the loud sound. The hot water from the vanity sink is only working on the last day prior to our checking out.  Hated that it does not come with a fridge!  It is on rental though and will charge on daily basis.  What kind of hotel is that.  although on paper, it says car park cost $20 for hotel parking.   it automated deducted $24 when we drove out of the garage.  You are better off with off street parking which is free from 6pm till 10am.Use this hotel only for transit or if you are here for the meeting @ the John Hopkins university.The hotel was beautiful.  My room was great.  The staff at the hotel was hit and miss on if they were  friendly, or helpful or not.  The most helpful was darked skinned male that was very nice in greeting people and asking what they needed and was helpful in giving restaurant advice. Everyone else seemed like they didn't want to communicate.  There were several of us there for a conference and none of us got the cookie at check in, The double tree I stay at in California leaves the cookie or cookies in your room.  This one, I guess you are supposed to get it at the front desk.  When we asked about it, the woman, said "we must have been out" and didn't offer anything more.  Another unfriendly.The breakfast was very over priced, but it was onsite.  There was no diet coke in the soda machines or any available to buy in the hotel, which was sad.  Hotel entry = 5 starsHotel room = 4 starsHotel reception = 2 starsDiet coke availability = 1 starBreakfast = 2 starsOverall =  2.8DO NOT USE FOR EVENTS - They completely botched our wedding planning.  We pulled out and found another venue with 3 weeks before wedding.  Horrible management.  You have been warned!Overpriced!The rooms were comfortable however, the parking was expensive and there weren't very many options nearby as far as food goes.  The downtown area is about a 10 minute drive.My LSAT class used to meet here twice a week... Never went into the ractual hotel rooms but the conference rooms were either too hot or too cold... Also not the greatest experience to practice an LSAT test because the dividers are flimsy and you could hear EVERYTHING on the other side... Small bar/restaurant seemed pretty overpriced... ((shrugs shoulders))Spent five days at this hotel on a business trip. Good points: room was clean and bed quite comfortable, staff were helpful and friendly (except for the very snippy day guy at front desk, seemed annoyed to be asked anything tearing him away from gossip with his friends), and a nice location near Johns Hopkins. Negatives were the heating/AC which were extremely loud, too warm or too cool, had to shut it off and open the window, which was fine in the nice weather. The room was a bit narrow, and more importantly the shower is dangerous--not even a corrugated surface or bathmat on the slippery tub floor. The lobby is large and nicely appointed, but the rooms and HVAC system could certainly use a bit of remodeling.After trying to find a hotel around Baltimore for a few hours (conventions and college graduations made this very difficult) my road trip buddie and I ended up here after sharing our sob story with the Hampton Inn in Glenn Burnie (which was also sold out). While this was the only open room in the city on a Saturday night - it was also pretty expensive. Like $31 valet expensive - but what can you do when there's no street parking? I must say that the customer service was impeccable. From the valet, to check-in and check-out, each interaction with staff was pleasant. I especially enjoyed the trademark Double Tree cookie at check-in; it helped subside my grumpiness. The room was spacious, clean, and equipped with a very comfy bed. The bathroom was "water-closet style" - not ideal if you have a roomate. Brushing your teeth, washing your face, etc. happens in the room. While out of my usual price range, I would stay here again to be near John Hopkins and tour the university area when its not under construction.A disappointing property. The location is good, and the basic features are nice, but it's not well managed. The front desk staff is uniformly unfriendly.  The housekeeping staff, on the other hand, is very VERY friendly.   Some light fixtures in the room don't work & tub barely drains, plus some lights out in hallways. Pool is cold and very limited hours; whirlpool is only lukewarm (broken temp sensor according to staff, so why don't they fix?). In-room thermostat is locked - seriously, WTF?I've stayed here 4-5 times in the last 10 years. Convenient to Hopkins and walking distance to a couple of decent restaurants. Rooms are okay, though last time we had a double bed instead of a booked queen/king (even though the hotel claimed it was a "queen" -- it was NOT!). The Alizee restaurant at the hotel was not bad; not great, but pretty decent. Less stuffy than the Polo that preceded it in the same location.We had a very nice and helpful waitress.The gym is small but nice: clean and functional. One problem was that the room wasn't cleaned one of the days. The front desk said it was because the do-not-disturb button was pressed. (This could've been the case). However, when we called at 5pm toask for the room to be made up, it took 2 more calls and 3 hours.In fact, no one came to make up the room but they just brought ussome toiletries and towels. (After 2 hours of waiting we had to sneaksome fresh towels out of the maids' closet).Excellent service!   Nice, clean, comfortable room.Great place to stay.  Only a few minutes from the downtown district.  Very nice place and free wifi.  The new Alizee restaurant is very posh as well.  Highly recommended.  We got just a regular room and it had a 37" flat screen in it.  Only problem is parking.  Cost per day or get valet for $20.I  picked the Inn as it is conveniently located next to a a conference venue that I was going to attend in Baltimore in early June. I had a positive experience with the housekeeping staff and a very poor and unfriendly with the management.  Bottom line: the customer is not always right here.  The hotel is clearly geared for corporate business and large groups,  where the rate per nite is the most important thing. Do not expect  the attention to detail or the willingness to help you when things go wrong  that one can expect from other hotels in the area.  Google will point you to a few alternatives in the same areas of the Colonnade!The details: I had previously booked a room with the conference rate. I then calledasking the front desk if I could use a 'Livingsocial' coupon that for the same rate would add one free  breakfast and dinner. I was told that yes, it was possible. I then proceeded with the purchase.At the check in the financial manager refused to accept the coupon. I asked to talk with the Hotel manager, who the day after confirmed me that the coupon was subject to 'black out dates'. The Livingsocial contract said 'subject to availability' and the room was obviously available as I was in it! For fairness: the contract  also mentioned in the fine print to call an Hotel  number, but without saying that it was a direct line to the financial manager, NOT the normal boooking number that I instead used. That is a pretty fine print, I think. I was disappointed and  as  compromise I said I 'd not  take advantage of the free dinner option, and stressed that their staff had told me that that I could use the coupon instead of the conference rate.  The Hotel manager  said he could not help me in any way and refused to acknowledge any responsibility.Bottom line to save a few dollars, the hotel managers  were quite willing to have a customer (who acted in good faith) lose $300. Thankfully, Living Social was gracious and promptly refunded me the coupon. they are awesome, so at least I did not lose money on this misadventure.Details on the Hotel: - The room was advertised as smoke free, but it definitely smelled like somebody had smoked there before (yes, I could have asked to change room, but after the  cold  shoulder treatment received regarding the LivingSocial coupon, I could not be bothered). - The electric socket on the desk lamp where unsafe and sparked when I plugged in my laptop. Not cool. I called the  housekeeping manager and they fixed the problem pronto. Still, not something I expect from an expensive hotel.-The threadmill at the gym was broken and the safety  clips were not functional on several machines  (a maintenance crew was working on the threadmill  the second day of my stay though).Pleasant exterior and common rooms, but for the price this leaves a lot to be desired, e.g.   (1) The staff is not knowledgeable about anything in the area; (2) the airconditioning is set so that you cannot make it cool in the room to sleep--the unit actually cuts off if you set it below 69 degrees!This place has a good exterior, but the insides aren't quite as nice.  Nothing wrong with the place, but sometimes the window dressing isn't quite representative.  Nevertheless, it's the best thing I've found near Hopkins.

review_content: If you've ever stayed at holiday inn express you know the quality of breakfast that you get. It's the same coast to coast and I love it. Biscuits and gravy, oatmeal, fruit, chiobani or activia yogurt, sausage, special k cereal or other kinds, bagels, cheese omelets, hot chocolate and the list goes on.  However this hotel has a great touch of history because it is an old bank. The lobby has tall marble columns and the vault is an office where they bake cookies haha. Check in/ out was easy. Only self parking available for $15/night and is very limited and on a first come first serve basis. The 4 star rating isn't for anything they can control its just a noisy area. Since you want a good night sleep when paying for a hotel I feel the 4 stars reflects that. There is a large homeless population on the block. Like tents and everything. Police sirens are constantly going off. The parking is charged at checkout. Staff is great and if you forget shaving cream or something they offer it for free. There is a 7-11 attached to the building which is great for late night munchies!I changed my review from a 4 star to 5 star after the front desk went above and beyond for me regarding a rental car issue.  (tire was flat and they brought the keys back inside the hotel after it had been repaired by roadside assist).This is a really unique and cool place as it used to be a bank and has a high atrium interior that is really pretty and the rooms are newly remodeled.  There is a little noise but that's to be expected because it's downtown.It is in the urban area of Baltimore, opposed to the more expensive rooms on the Harbor.  Some people may not be comfortable walking in the neighborhood at night. I didn't have any problems even at night and frequently walked around downtown and the area.  I was able to jog from the hotel to the harbor in about 10-15 minutes along the concrete trail by the river, it was pretty fun to see Little Italy along the way and some other cool places.The front desk was helpful and professional and I felt the price was very reasonable, about half the price of the harbor side hotels.  Parking was convenient and was able to find a spot each night although the lot was almost full.We got lucky on this one.  Apparently their hotel flooded on the floor we were to be on.  They were going to put us in a smaller room (for 5 people) and we asked about cots - which they have none, what hotel doesn't have cots?  I guess it was a good thing anyway.  We ended up getting a suite with a room connected and had a stairway shared with one other room.  The hotel was gorgeous inside.  The area though seemed kind of shady.  It felt so unsafe to keep our car in the lot.  I wouldn't walk out there alone at night!  10 minute walk to the Harbor if I may add.Our bathroom had a HUGE window as well as FOUR long windows in the room, with perfect black out curtains.  Two windows on one side of the room, and the other two windows looking INSIDE the hotel.Lighting I will say was HORRIBLE (in the night I mean) cause we obviously didn't need any during the day.Fridge was completely empty with tons of room in it to store food!Breakfast was great.  I thought it was continental it included pancakes, eggs, buiscuts, and more.The one thing that did disturb me was Church service on Sunday's.  It's in a room off the main lobby.  You can easily hear the bass from the microphone.  I'm not sure why they have service there but it should go.  It's unnesssary, and for people traveling, and late sleepers - I would not want to be woken up by that.After a long day of working, I finally checked into this hotel and went to sleep.  At about 3 or 4 in the morning I woke up and noticed roaches crawling on me.  And that is roaches. . . plural.  After screaming and changing my clothes, I went to the front desk to explain the problem.  The front desk person was kind and helpful and saw the still live roaches crawling around.  He offered me another room.  I transferred rooms and lo and behold the other room's bathroom had shaved off hair in the sink.  I called the front desk person again.  By this time, I was not willing to stay at this hotel any longer.  Word to the wise- if you have a problem in the middle of the night at an IHG hotel, it is very difficult to get in touch with customer service.  When I did, the representative started speaking to me about pricing for other hotels.  I feel that at that point, there should have only been offers to upgrade me to the best hotel room available in the city given that the two previous rooms I used at this current hotel were substandard.  The Holiday Inn I transferred to by the casino in Baltimore had a dirty mattress and dirty mattress pads but at 5 am, I couldn't fight with anyone anymore.  In addition,I was never compensated for the items I needed to leave behind in the room where I encountered the roaches.  The likelihood of me staying at a Holiday Inn every again . . . you can take a guess. Please note that waking up with roaches has never occurred prior to this hotel stay, nor subsequently nor do I have any infestation in my home.Recommended by Johns Hopkins as an affordable hotel while my dad was there  for surgery.  The hotel is a little run down and not in the best section of town.  But the staff was very accommodating, they had a good pet policy and the rooms, while not fancy, were comfortable.Parking is $12/day and the lot was always full on Sat and Sun.  There is free breakfast in the morning:  pancakes, eggs, bacon, cinnamon rolls, muffins, yogurt, etc.  The lobby is interesting and Art Deco.  There is a complimentary shuttle van that takes you to Johns Hopkins, Inner Harbor and other areas of town.  There is no dining in the hotel (besides breakfast) but the front desk staff gave me menus to nearby places that deliver.On the con side:  The area is sketchy (as most of the area near Johns Hopkins) and I was a bit nervous to dog walk late night.  Wifi was excruciatingly slow.  I probably wouldn't stay here for leisure travel (I like the Hilton in Inner Harbor much better)  but it was an affordable alternative for a longer term stay.The location of this facility is quite frankly not good. It's down the street from a rather seedy part of Baltimore and it is in a bit of a food desert - not much safely accessible restaurants nearby unfortunately. The building itself in situated in an old bank and has a great art deco theme to it. My first room they gave me appeared okay...until I opened the closet door and saw a cockroach skitter for cover. I immediately asked for another room. The front desk attendant at the time didn't really apologize or say anything to acknowledge the incident and seemed to not believe me. My next room looked okay on my cursory inspection but either that means I couldn't find the roaches or there were none there. The room was a nice king with a desk and large LCD TV. After that start, the rest was very good. The breakfast isn't gourmet but is diverse and filling with plenty of coffee to get your day started. Free newspapers in the lobby was a nice touch too. The hotel shuttle provides great door-to-door service to JHU; do note that for pick-ups you may have to wait up to 40 minutes (like me during traffic). Most of the front desk staff (other than the 1 guy above) are very nice and helpful.Clean and spacious single bed rooms. Friendly front desk people. Nice variety for breakfast the following morning. Very reasonable week day pricing considering the location although the Orioles weren't in town so that may have something to do with it. Location could be better but too late now. Definitely would stay again!Tiny rooms. I had a suite but it was smaller than most regular rooms. The king size bed was almost a foot less tgan a real King bed and staff kept on insisting that is what the hotels call a king. Crmaped, outdated. Too bad, since its in an old bank and lobby could be so nice.Oh yeah, almost forgot to mention the unsecure parking lot and the homeless people who hang outside the place. Lovely combo, but you are near the highway....well literally right beside/underneath the highway.You know those HIX commercials, yeah, well, its not based on this place!The hotel lobby is architecturally beautiful and the rooms are updated and comfortable.  Housekeeping needs to be told what you need or you may run out of important little things like toilet paper but the hotel itself is clean and comfortable.The staff was friendly and helpful and went out of their way to be accommodating. The hotel only gets 2 stars because despite the above it feels fundamentally unsafe.  The poorly lit parking lot had homeless people in it every time we walked through.  The immediate neighborhood for 3-4 blocks in all directions is filled with homeless beggars and derelicts.  It is a short walk from the inner harbour and we did the walk during the day but we were harassed for money during the walk as we got close to the hotel.  The hotel has a shuttle service and if you stay there and use it you will likely have a lovely time.  The holiday inn on Lombard street was less expensive and a better location.I recommend this hotel for people who need an affordable place to stay with first class service and comfort. I'm giving the Holiday Inn Express 4 stars for many reasons. 1) They are good neighbors and welcoming to all. Online, people had complained about the "homeless" they saw near the hotel. I was pleased to read the hotel's response, which was detailed and defended their neighborhood. They noted that being "misfortunate" doesn't mean dangerous. The response sounded like they were a neighborhood business, rather than a chain. I was so impressed with that. Kudos!2) Front desk service is exceptionally sharp and helpful. I thought the staff was amazing and made me excited to be visiting Baltimore. 3) Free Continental breakfast and newspapers in lobby. That's becoming a rarity nowadays.I had a few problems in that they tested the sprinkler system for what seemed an interminable time. But I had been warned in advance about that. How can I complain about safety tests. That's better than dying in a fire.Very good service and extremely polite. Our room was spotless and the free breakfast in the morning was very nice. Great for my girlfriend and I to just have a place to rest after a concert out in Baltimore one night. Not the best area but overall we were satisfied!Got stuck here in Baltimore seeing doctors so they recommended that we stay here at the Holiday Inn Express. If I were driving and not taking their shuttle, I really could have easily missed this place. I was really quite stunned (in a good way and not in a I got tasered way) when I walked in. The lobby looks like a fancy hotel lobby. The person was quite nice at the text to help us check in and such. I found it to be very clean and welcoming. They have a free shuttle service that takes you to where you want to go at the top of the hour and picks you up from a reasonable distance at every half hour. You will have to call the front desk to let them know you intend on using the shuttle. The rooms are actually quite cozy. The 2 we were in were awkwardly designed with a small hallway that you had to walk down inside the room before you got to the actual beds. Not very spacious but enough to be comfortable. If you plan on staying, order from Mo's Seafood. They deliver and they are a great seafood restaurant!For Johns Hopkins affiliates, they have a $89.99 special so make sure to mention that.Having never been to Baltimore and wanting a place near Inner Harbor...I enlisted Hotwire to find a hotel, and I actually got a great deal!  Pulling into the parking lot, I was a bit skeptical.  The property backs to kind of a shady neighborhood...but hey, at least they have parking on-site ($12 per day).  We entered through the side entrance (which appears to double as a bus stop).  Walking through the door, you're immediately slapped in the face with the smell of lemon.  The lobby (an old bank)  is absolutely gorgeous!  The front desk was accommodating as we checked in early.  The room was super clean, quiet, modern, and came equipped with a fridge.The hotel was just a short walk away from Inner Harbor.  During the evening, we opted for the free hotel shuttle service which dropped us off in Midtown.  Although the conversation (keep your eye out for my upcoming memoir, "10 Things You Hope No Person Ever Says To You") was a tad on the creepy side...it beats paying $10 in cab fare.I can't comment on the breakfast buffet because the trip was cut unexpectedly short.  What I can say is that Hotwire has a HORRIBLE cancellation policy!A suitable hotel in a poor part of town.  There are three times as many rooms as there are parking spaces so arrive early!.  Parking is $12 per night and if you miss out one of the 20-odd spots, you're on the street.  The view out our window was of the lovely Juvenile Justice Center which provided some good people watching (in conjunction with the "takeout" shop across the street.)  The hotel itself is in an old bank, leading to an impressive lobby area.  The staff was friendly and helpful and the room was spacious and clean.  The pillows were really nice as well, a mix of firm and soft, which is hard to find in this type hotel.  So all in all, its a good hotel, affordable, less than 10 minutes from Johns Hopkins, with a shuttle that runs to and from, but I wouldn't stay here again unless I were visiting the hospital again (which hopefully doesn't happen.)Wonderful clean rooms, few issues tho. The staff for the most part are friendly and helpful. The incidentals are RIDICULOUS. $100 is a bit steep, I'm not responsible for what other people have done so the story of people breaking rules has 0 to do with me. Beware parking is $12 per day. You won't find anywhere free so don't waste your time, unless it's between 6PM - 8AM. It's not the best area but it is nice, and the price is decent besides that incidental mess.Stayed at this boutique hotel for over a MONTH while my husband was at Johns Hopkins for a very serious condition. Let me say, you get to know people very well in that extended time frame & the staff was consistently incredible! Erica, James, Tina, Letitia, Kevin, Justin, Mark & all those whose names I'm forgetting -- you guys rock!On to the assorted travel-type details --  lobby's architecture of this converted bank is gorgeous & adds interesting character. Rooms are comfortable with well appointed amenities like micro, fridge, coffee maker, blow dryer, lotions/potions, etc. I had no trouble with the free Wi Fi on access or speed. Bedding includes both soft & firm pillows. The free breakfast offered is more than just the usual continental selection. There are restaurants which deliver or you can dine out near the harbor. Free shuttle to JH Hospital & other areas within a mile of the hotel. Didn't use their parking, but parking is scarce so it's nice they offer it & $12 is reasonable. Surrounding area is a typical downtown -- some blocks are upscale, others not. But if your circumstance puts you in DT Baltimore for Johns Hopkins you will be well taken care of by that hospital AND by the kind, caring & professional staff at this Holiday Inn Express!I can understand Alpa V.'s frustrations; I wouldn't want to be caught with extra charges for nights I didn't stay. I hope everything works out and I hope it's a once off error with this hotel.My stay at this hotel has been pleasant so far. I am staying here for 2 weeks for Hopkins Winter Institute. The place is certainly a step or two up from Motel 6 and others like it. There is a modern feel to the room. The rooms have microwaves and a small refrigerator if you need to store anything. The hotel serves basic but reasonable warm breakfast including eggs, sausage, toast, biscuits, french toast and danishes. I certainly think they are better than many I've stayed at. There is a gym at the basement which is accessed by the room key. The hotel is new and the staff is pleasant.I think it's definitely worth looking at if you want to stay in the St Paul, Charles Street area. It is about 15 minutes walk to Hopkins if you want  to go it on foot. Pretty decent for the price.Eh...not sure what to say here, it's okay. Being located in a less than desirable portion of town was the first thing I noticed. Being from NH and frequenting Boston, I guess I was expecting something a bit different from the area. There's plenty of food in close proximity to the hotel, but I for one would not be comfortable walking anywhere from this hotel. I'm not saying it's not safe, but I just didn't get that vibe from what I'm typically used to.The hotel itself is clean, modern and nice. It has free Wi-Fi which seemed spotty and I opted to hardwire to get better speeds. The view out my window of the Baltimore Juvenile Justice Center is a cute twist since there wasn 't much of a view of the downtown area. The staff here was friendly and easy to work/deal with. The temperature controls worked well and actually kept the room comfortable, not too hot or cold which seems to be my luck in hotels.The bedding was comfortable although I wasn't a huge fan of the pillows...they just weren't the right height for my head and had a hard time manipulating them so they were.All in all, I like the hotel, but the location would have made a massive difference if I could have walked to a pub for a couple drinks.I stayed here in March for one night after I got a great deal through Hotwire.  It isn't in the best area, and I would not suggest young ladies walk around there alone, but it is maybe a 10-minute walk to the downtown harbor area, and maybe 5 of those minutes are in a shady part of town.The hotel staff were friendly, the breakfast was tasty, the room was clean and comfortable.  For night before a cruise, it was perfect, though I would not suggest staying there for longer than a night or two, just because the location isn't ideal.We stayed two nights in early July, and it's a pretty standard Holiday Inn Express with the standard amenities.  Something that I found odd, the staff that maintains the breakfast bar walks around and talks to the guests for prolonged periods of time while they're eating.  Overall I'm satisfied with my stay and wouldn't hesitate to stay there again.
review_content_20: Boy was this area ghetto! Despite the unsatisfactory location, the hotel was pretty nice. Everything was clean and in great shape, and housekeeping was very friendly and amiable (even more so than the front desk!). The fitness room is a joke with only 3 machines, all of which are "Hotel Fitness" brand and pretty much falling apart. The rooms are equipped with a microwave and fridge which is great, and the complimentary breakfast definitely saved me a lot of money on having to eat out. It's nothing special though, with the same old microwave eggs and fake bacon.I would avoid for two reasons:1. It is not in a very good location (only to get to the stadiums, but not the city)2. The staff is not helpful at all (they neglected to properly check me out when I left so my credit card kept getting charged- even though I booked for 1 night only with hotwire. They refused to fix the problem and I am currently having to deal with credit card disputes.Stay away. Much better options are available and you'll be happy you spent the extra $10-20!

review_content: - Great staff and comfy room.- Having no fridge or microwave was a downside but I could go down in the kitchen & use it there. - Spiral staircase is beautiful and enjoyed quirky art works displayed in the hall way. I liked wooden floors & high ceilings.- Was a little disappointed bc there was no bathtub but shower box.- Close to light rail and Charm City shuttle- Free breakfastThis is a very nice and dainty hotel! It was built in 1810, but remodeled in 2010 from the interior. My husband and I loved the look of it, although the restroom is too damn cold to shower in this time of year lol! It seems like there is cold air going into the restroom area instead of warm. We loved the convenience of the location. About two miles from the harbor ($5-8 lyft cost) and another two miles to own stationThe bed was also tiny! It did not look like a queen size, more like a full size mattress. My husband is 6'1" and I am 5'6", so we were quite uncomfortable, but we made it work. If we were to come back to Baltimore, we would definitely stay at the hotel again, but request a king size bed. Staff was amazing and extremely nice! Also, complimentary continental breakfast :)The entire hotel is gorgeous. Beautiful big windows, very comfortable beds, and lovely details. Furthermore, the staff is helpful and very professional. You won't find much better for this price in any urban area. The location is about 10 minutes from Fell's Point nightlife by car, and very close to the new restaurants and bars popping up on Charles St. And free parking!My husband and I stayed here for our mini-moon. Spent almost $900 dollars for our two night stay and the room was in horrible condition. I stepped on a beer bottle cap, there was no fridge (it looked like it was removed), stuff was broken in the bathroom, and there were stains on the bed. Not to mention they gave us two double beds instead of a king like I requested. The manager said they would give me a free two night stay, but I have yet to receive my voucher. I wouldn't stay here again.My boyfriend and I stayed here for our one night visit, and had a great time. We absolutely loved the big open windows! Granted there was not much of a view besides the gay bar across the street, but it gave us plenty of natural light during the day. Front desk is friendly and offers sound advice on where to explore. The location is sort of away from all the chaos of inner harbor which wasn't bad for us either. It is only a mile away. You can access the free trolley from here to take you down to inner harbor too. That is only a couple of blocks away for you to hop on if you choose not to drive. Hotel Brexton has only 29 rooms. I don't know if you would really consider this a boutique hotel even though it is not part of a chain. I would think it has its own little identity. It is not super upscale, but it is not low quality by any means. It is a simple place. The rooms are designed with a modern touch in a restored historical building. I think my biggest complaint was the noise level. You can't here anyone in the building itself, but conversation outside can be heard clear as day. I think it was primarily because of where our window was situation as previously mentioned and being on the 3rd floor. Though I should point out that noise we did here was only brief and it didn't last long. Otherwise, it was very quiet and relaxing.Price is reasonable. You can get some deals if you look on some the exterior hotel booking websites versus booking direct. Just be warned though if you do book from a third party, you won't be able to refund your money like you could if you did book directly with the hotel. Rates may be different though with one compared to the other per usual.Breakfast consists of bagels, select cereals, and fruit served from 7am-10am daily, respectively. Nothing hot. Breakfast is found on the bottom floor with a small kitchen area.You win some you lose some. Here is a total win if you like something unique and different.We booked a block of rooms here for our wedding. OMG EVERYONE IS SO NICE AND EVERYTHING IS SO CLEAN. It rained during our wedding and the general manager (Bob) drove folks around for us. I couldn't have asked for a better place. They allow dogs for cheap so our little guy chihuahua could be at the ceremony. I just love this place. I only have one wish, that there was free wifi, but other than that, this is just a perfect place with wonderful people. Terrell, the other manager #gem. Pat, another person who worked at the front desk #lovely. Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful.Pros- Nice-looking historic building.- Helpful staff, made good local dining and transportation recommendations.- clean lobby and room.Cons- less than desirable location- slow, small, stuffy elevator- noisy room - mostly from the AC unit and neighboring rooms.- tiny shower.- charged us $20 for 3 days of Wifi when they had a price listed of $10 for 48 hours, which is what we requested. We stayed 3 nights but only wanted 2 days of wifi, but they wouldn't allow that.- the breakfast is a joke - lousy toaster, mushy bananas, and warm milk for the cereal.I stayed overnight.  It was ok  I gave it 3 stars because the staff provided excellent customer service.Very disappointing Hotel. No night lighting to help you find the hotel. Very limited on street parking. watermarked furniture and peeling walls leave much to be desired. The architecture itself is very intriguing but the hotel is a disappointment. The breakfast bar was mini cupcakes and cereal and bagels.  a loose runner in the hall nearly caused a fall. The smallest elevator ever. Musty smell in the room. Steep stairs to the front door that you have to be buzzed in to day or night.My husband and I stayed here for one night only and really enjoyed it.
