Hotel Brexton is a beautiful and historical on the outside and modern on the inside. It's a really small hotel with only 29 rooms. We were in a king room. Room is spacious and so is the bathroom. There is a coffee maker, but no fridge or microwave (there is a microwave in the basement). Everything was clean, we felt really comfortable. We paid 91$ for a king room in January, breakfast included. They put a 50$ hold on the credit card. We got it back in a week, but didn't like that. I read that some people paid for the wifi, but they gave us the password with no extra charge. There is a free parking in front of the hotel, but it's limited. The breakfast is served in the basement area. Bagels, cereals, yogurt, some fruits, basic stuff. There is a coffee machine available at all times. Cappuccino, espresso, french vanilla, hot chocolate...    A lot of options, all the good stuff. Overall, we were happy with our stay in Hotel Brexton, would definitely recommend.It's a historic hotel and it looks lovely on the outside.  However, it is too small for me to be able to like it.  The elevator could barely fit two people.  The halls are narrow. The bathroom is so small you cannot turn around in it.  A person with disabilities or an older person with mobility problems would hate this place.  I don't think a wheelchair can fit into the elevator and there are lots of stairs everywhere.  I think the limit of space made the updating of the inside challenging.  The room had a noisy A/C unit located above the door to the hallway.  Closets are not in the wall but cabinets that take up space in the room that I would have appreciated having.  The bed was comfortable and my room was quiet.Parking is a challenge.  Another resident was complaining bitterly to me.  I paid $25 for one of two slots on the side street, which was very odd and very cramped.  The street is tough to find at night.  Lots of hidden fees and nothing is given away for free.Stayed here this past weekend.  Got a great deal through Hotwire.  The hotel itself is beautiful and nicely designed on the outside.  The renovated rooms are nice, a solid 3 stars.  I find our room on the 2nd floor to be spacious and comfortable, bathroom is simple and nice, but I did wish the shower was bigger, or may be a tub.  Parking is a challenge if you choose to do street parking, but I opted for the reserved parking which guaranteed me a spot, that was nice.   The area itself is quiet, but like a lot of parts in Baltimore, there are some questionable characters roaming around especially late at night.  There is a Rite Aid and a 7-11 that you could walk to (within a block or two), so that was very convenient.  The hotel is about 3 miles from inner harbor so it's rather nice to be away from all of that.  I checked out the continental breakfast, but chose to go to The Bun Shop down the street instead as they had some great coffee and tea, as well as pastries, and they're open 7am-3am.AC didn't work.  Poor assistance at front desk.  Despite the cute setting, I Would not stay here again.  I did not feel cared for at allTechnically this is a 4 1/2 star review, but I'm rounding up because my stay was so thoroughly delightful.Pros: LOCATION LOCATION LOCATION! everything (and I mean everything) you could want or need is near -- drug store to  7-11 to fancy brunch to dive bar to bespoke sex toys to free Inner Harbor bus. Also steps from Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and a quick cabride from the Amtrak Station. Latenight munchies are are within (drunk) walking distance. Easy parking right out front.  Keurig Machine in the room.  SUPER CHEAP BARGAIN.The room itself was light and roomy. no funny smells. Bathroom was modern and shiny w/ fluffy towels. Bedding was a solid B+ and the lighting was better than average. Super nice staff, free quicky breakfast.Cons: Some of the furniture was unfortunate. no restaurant.  The TV required an MIT degree to understand. Thankfully, my traveling companion fit the bill.We stayed at the Hotel Brexton for one night while visiting family in the area. To decide whether this is a good hotel for you, you should understand what the Brexton is and what it is not. If you are looking for a clean, spacious, decently priced room in a convenient, but less touristy area, the Brexton is a good choice. If you are looking for a luxury hotel experience with plenty of amenities, or need a hotel with large public areas or want to be in the center of the city's activity, you will probably be disappointed.We paid for the internet and parking package. The hotel has 4 spaces in front that are first-come-first-served, and 4 in an adjacent courtyard that are reserved for those choosing the parking package. We found it worth the extra $30 for the peace of mind of having a space waiting for us at night (plus included internet, which is otherwise $10). The building is old, but quirky and charming. It has been nicely renovated and is clean and well kept. Our room on the 5th floor was oddly shaped in an interesting way, but spacious and spotless. The large bathroom was updated. The bed was extremely comfortable. There was a well placed flat screen tv hanging from the ceiling. Service was friendly. We skipped the provided continental breakfast and the staff at the front desk recommended a nearby restaurant where we could get a full breakfast. When we returned, she seemed genuinely interested in whether we had enjoyed our meal. All in all, we had a fine stay, and found the Hotel Brexton to be a good base for enjoying Baltimore.I have never had worse customer service at a hotel.  I called to reschedule my reservation and the person on the other end of the phone refused to be of assistance. He stated that my card had already been charged and that there was nothing else he could do. With this, we wanted to cancel the reservation and again we were told that there was nothing that could be done. All told, I was billed for a single nights stay that I didnt even use. I wasnt even in the same state to be able to use it. When I told the customer service rep that I did not approve of the charges he informed me that I would need to take the issue up with my credit card company...can you believe that? I asked him if I could speak with his manager and he said that I would have to call back the next day.  If you want to be treated like dirt then ripped off then be my guest and try to stay here.When planning my trip to Baltimore, I was torn between staying at a big name chain hotel, or Hotel Brexton.  I'm so glad I made the right choice by staying in this unique and adorable hotel, in a beautiful and historic building.  The neighborhood is quiet but charming, and there is plenty to do within walking distance or picking up the free bus that takes you right to Inner Harbor.  The staff were extremely helpful and friendly throughout our stay, and we had no complaints about our room (seriously, who cares if the furniture is "cheap").  If you are looking for something with a little more charm and character than the big name hotels that are the same in every city, I recommend staying at Hotel Brexton!Awesome place. Rooms are immaculate and it's in a great area of town. First time staying in Baltimore and so glad I picked this place. Staff are very friendly. Don't be put off by outside it's an historic building. Once inside you can see that the owners have put an lot of money into this place. If you are glbt the this is an perfect location for the nightlife.Staying in the hotel Brexton tonight. Unfortunately I think I had a guest below me that was unreasonable. I ordered a pizza for my wife and I. When the front desk called me they let me know my food was here,and we had a noise complaint for a lot of noise from the room below. The only thing I can think of is when I moved my suitcase from the bed to floor(which I admit banged loudly) that was all,one bang. I really can't believe I got a complaint. If anyone had came up to listen they would have maybe heard our TV on,that was all. The hotel is nice,and the girl at the desk was nice but that was all, one noise. The front desk should really check out these claims of noise to see if it's happening,before they confront a guest.  I read bad reviews of the hotel that seemed ridiculous(but checked it out for myself) guess I'll just believe what everyone says from now on without seeing for myself.thats what the front desk does.Our stay here was fine. There are some nice things about this place and some not-so-nice things. The neighborhood doesn't seem great. It's also not close to a lot of the attractions we wanted to see, such as the Walters museum and the National Aquarium. The hotel is a historic landmark, and it is still beautiful and looks historic on the outside, but when they restored the inside, they really didn't maintain any of the hotel's former historic charm. The furniture looks like any other generic hotel furniture - they could have at least tried to keep the place in character. On the plus side, the room was very clean and the bed was comfortable. As another reviewer mentioned, they have Keurig machines in the rooms, and there's 24-hour access to the breakfast room in the basement, where there's a fancy coffee machine that makes all kinds of espresso drinks and hot chocolate. Breakfast was complimentary and was fine. They had bagels, some fruit, cereal, OJ, and some pastries. The woman working at the concierge desk was friendly and helpful. Some people on here have said they had to pay for WiFi, but it was free when we were there. You just had to call the front desk and ask for the code. Maybe that's new? Anyway, like I said, the stay was fine, but it wasn't as special as we were hoping it would be, given the history of the building. On past visits to Baltimore, we've stayed at the historic Admiral Fell Inn in Fell's Point, and I think we'll go back to staying there next time.
review_content_20: I paid $125.99/night for a Wed-Sat in late October.Pros: The room was clean and the bed and bedding was comfortable. There was very little noise from outside or from other guests. The building has been beautifully restored.Cons: cheap Ikea furniture -- the lamp was falling apart, the veneer surface on the nightstands was blistered and peeling, etc. Room smelled of bleach because of the 'bleach bomb' in the toilet. Why does a toilet cleaned everyday need a tank bomb? There are towels for two, but only one coffee cup and one drinking glass. The property is handicap accessible, but to get to the ramp, you go through the dining area on the lower level, not the lobby. For my disabled father, it felt like going through a service entrance. I'm finding that poor handicap access is the norm all over, though. They advertise 'Wine and Cheese Receptions', but it turns out only on Wednesday. The confirmation email said there was free bottled water, but the bottles had big price tags on them. No newspaper (website says there is). Not that I care that much, its just that they mislead on these little details. The breakfast was fine, but not as fancy as their menu makes it sound; basic fruit and store-brand breads and cereal.Street parking is scarce, so you will probably have to pay $25 extra for one of their reserved spots around the corner. They charge $20 for internet. The really annoying thing is the $50 per night 'block' they put on your credit card when you check in. Not for incidentals, and not a new $50 block a day either; a full $400 block on my card. I hear this is common practice in Las Vegas, but at a boutique hotel in Baltimore? Am I wrong? Do many hotels do this (i.e. via taking your cc number for incidentals) and I just never noticed? In any case, the message it sends is, "Although you (pre) paid for your stay through hotels.com, we still think you might trash the room." When I registered my displeasure, the hotel clerk was condescending, and told me is was standard procedure. It was insulting. Summary: good for a decent night's sleep, but it is run more like a chain budget motel than like the first-class boutique hotel they claim to be.LivingSocial customers are not the only ones Hotel Brexton refuses to accommodate. Having purchased tickets to see Louis C.K. at nearby Meyerhoff Symphony Hall on New Year's Eve, I booked a room for two via hotels.com six months in advance. I received an e-mail confirmation immediately after, and another on Thursday, December 27 (this one saying explicitly, "You don't need to call to reconfirm.")When we showed up on what was supposed to be the night of our stay, we were told that they'd had some "unexpected overstays," and that they'd instead booked me a place at a Doubletree hotel two miles away, and relatively removed from any bars, restaurants, stores, or anything else of note. I should note here that we were lied to about how far away the Doubletree was, and also about the circumstances of our relocation: the hotel manager tried to get in touch with us repeatedly, it was claimed; our phone and e-mail records tell a different story.The whole point of our reserving a room at Hotel Brexton was that it was within walking distance of the show we'd already paid to see. Instead, we had to waste money (not to mention compete fiercely with hordes of other fares -- it was New Year's) to take cabs from place to place. A minor inconvenience, certainly -- but that's not the point. If a reservation made so far in advance is treated with the same disdain as LivingSocial customers apparently are, then whose reservations are secure, exactly? Unacceptable. Avoid.Great night in a historic building in a convenient spot, the staff was pleasant, the room clean, the breakfast was small but sufficient, building was quiet. The furniture was worn, but clean and usable. All in all a nice place for a decent price, I would go again.I stayed there with my girlfriend on a last minute decision because everything was booked. Wow a great surprise to see this beautiful hotel. Service was excellent, rooms where very well kept . The staff takes great pride in there establishment . Close to all activities , dining, clubs etc.......... I would definitely stay there againThe CEILINGS of hotel rooms at Hotel Brexton, apparently, are PAPER THIN because you can HEAR EVERY SOUND, step, thump, bounce, drop, laugh and tip-toe of guests upstairs. No kidding: if nightly PEACE and QUIET is a priority for your hotel experience, then DO NOT STAY HERE. I am a really, really tolerant and experienced traveler and, despite my tendency never to voice a complaint, surprisingly I had to call downstairs TWO NIGHTS IN A ROW to notify hotel staff about this problem. The first night, the thundering noise continued until 4 am, even after the front desk informed me that the upstairs guests had been asked to stop making noise. The second night I assumed the same noisy guests must be stomping around upstairs but, surprisingly, I was informed by the front desk that ANOTHER GUEST had checked in. The only conclusion I can reach, then, is that THE INCESSANT ECHOING NOISE FROM UPSTAIRS isn't the result of inconsiderate guests but, rather, the hotel must have REALLY LOUSY SOUNDPROOFING, REALLY LOUSY ACOUSTICS. On top of that, while I regret to pile on, the hotel only has parking for maybe 4-6 vehicles. Plan on not being able to park in front of this hotel. I had to circle numerous blocks around the hotel both nights in order to find public street parking -- giving me little confidence that I wouldn't find my rental car towed (or worse) when I searched to find it the next morning. Location is great but "Meh" is right. Unless you have relatively moderate lodging standards, this hotel has unfulfilled potential at almost every level.Tried for three months to book with our LivingSocial and even said we would pay more for their "premium" room and not only did it end with a null response but we returned our LivingSocial deal which involved them calling the hotel and confirming that they would not let us book. We read up and there was a complaint about the same thing. The owner even told us he was tired of dealing with the LivingSocial people of which whom he signed up with in the first place. I was very frustrated even after offering to pay extra. The owner said it would be %50 a night more and we agreed and when we tried to book with that he wouldn't let us book even then after we agreed to the extra money for the "premium" room. Not a well run business and I can't imagine it being nice to even go too. With such rude owner/clientele I would never suggest this place nor go there.Charming boutique hotel in the heart of Mount Vernon. As a Baltimorean looking for a place to stay for a few days while a condo was being renovating, I stumbled upon the Hotel Brexton doing a quick internet search. The hotel is in a historic building, in a great location and reasonably priced. I paid $119 for a weekend and $125 for the weekend, including breakfast. The price included on-street parking in front of the building. Our room, on the fourth floor was quite large, with a spacious bathroom (in the turrett section of the building which provided great angles). It's walking distance to the City Cafe and neighborhood bars - with a Starbucks a few blocks away. Would absolutely reccomend to any out-of-town guests - or even for a hometown stay-cation.My stay at the Hotel Brexton was pleasant. My bf and I arrived late, around 2am, and check-in was no problem. The meters out front are free on the weekends, so no need to worry about searching for parking or if the lot is full. The complimentary coffee and continental breakfast in the morning was definitely appreciated. Two things to note though. We were staying on the 1st floor and since the hotel is an old townhouse, the noise abatement between the walls and the floors above has something to be desired. We could hear guests moving around as early as 6:30am. Also, there is no central air and the air conditioner in our room was not very powerful. The room was a little stuffy. Overall, these were minor inconveniences in a overall very nice stay. I would definitely visit again.the pros---walking distance from the Amtrak station and Joseph Meyerhoff Hall (we took the train from VA to see Louis CK on New Years eve). so the location was perfect.-we arrived 2 hours before check-in and they had a room ready for us for no extra charge. awesome!-K-Cup coffee maker in the room, can't go wrong.-very friendly desk staff.-Beautiful historical building.-they let us check out late (our train wasn't until 3pm) for a fee.the cons---WIFI COSTS $10!!!! (for 48 hours) you're kidding me? even motel 6 and super 8 have free wifi. the amtrak train i took to baltimore had free wifi. i paid $120 a night and i have to pay for wifi? that is insane beyond words for 2013. seriously. c'mon now.-not a very lively neighborhood. maybe because it was new years, but the area was dead. no restaurants were really open or seemed to exist without walking several blocks.-cheap furniture was bubbled and worn because of the coffee maker. there is no pitcher to put water in it, so water dribbles on the counter, since it's particle board, it just dissolves. cheap! i would expect a hotel that costs from 120-150 a night to have nicer furniture and showers/sinks.-their TV is hooked up to DirecTV box which was literally falling off the wall, just dangling by wires. the tv had been set to another input, so i had to fiddle with the input to get the tv signal, also the remote didn't control the tv (input or volume). hell, i don't even let my home tv get this disorganized. it's a simple thing that the customers shouldn't have to reconfigure the tv to get it to work.-buffet in the morning is just like super 8 motel. cold cereal, bagels and pastry from the grocery store. they have a big, fake espresso machine thingy, but honestly the coffee in our room was better. food quality could be stepped up just a little bit to make a big difference. felt like a youth hostel.overall it was a medium experience for what is supposed to be a higher end hotel. glad it was so close to the train and performance but i've had better experiences at cheaper places.The Hotel Brexton is a major ripoff. I bought a 2 night stay with the only restrictions being no holidays, but when I tried to book it 5 months before it expired I found out that it is impossible to make a reservation on a weekend. The only nights available were Sunday - Thursday. The Hotel Brexton oversold the deal, limited the number or rooms available and was unwilling to accommodate people who bought their vouchers. When I contacted Living Social they said there is nothing they can do and they are "aware that many people were not able to book rooms at the Hotel Brexton before the expiration date". Yet, they continue to do business with the Hotel Brexton by continuing to sell getaway deals for them even though Living Social knows that Hotel Brexton doesn't honor the deals that are sold. This is a major ripoff and there are many more reputable hotels in Baltimore that would not steal money from unsuspecting people and give them nothing in return. Stay away! Find another hotel.

hotel_name: The Inn at Henderson's Wharf, an Ascend Hotel Collection Member
review_content: My boyfriend and I came down to Baltimore for a spontaneous weekend trip and a friend had recommended to stay in the Fells Point area. So glad we found this place, as it helped to make our weekend wonderful. Some of the highlights included:1. front desk/staff: kind, helpful, and even let us check in a few hours earl2. parking: easy, across the street, and only $10 for the day3. location: on the water; our room was garden view which was wonderful because it was private, quiet, and still had a beautiful view4. room: decor was perfect for a cozy bed and breakfast feel; bed was so comfortable it was hard to convince ourselves to get out of bed the next morning; the only downside was the hot water situation- you have to wait awhile after one person takes a shower to have hot water again5. extras: did not check out the gym, but the breakfast was wonderful, the wine down was a wonderful addition (as was the night cap), and the free starbucks coffee was a nice touch as wellOverall, fabulous stay and cannot wait to come backThis is an intimate hotel in one of the oldest neighborhoods in Baltimore. The rooms are spacious and beautiful with wood plantation shutters and exposed brick. Some rooms face the water. The view is pretty. Be aware if you have a water view, you may hear people (early morning joggers, late night dog walkers, etc). Some rooms face an interior court yard which is very tranquil.I found the bed very comfortable although my companion would have liked it more firm. And I think that is the only negative thing either of us would say about our stay. The staff is amazing. They are nice and attentive. There is a night cap station for drinks and roasting marshmallows for smores.The Inn at Henderson's Wharf is touted as Baltimore's best hostelry.  This title is ridiculous and I don't know what folks are talking about.Located in Fell's Point, directly on the water, Henderson's admittedly has a fantastic location.  All the rooms are on the first floor, and while privacy can be an issue, the views are fab.  Alas, we had a courtyard room, but took advantage of the lovely boardwalk running along the hotel.  This is where the good ends.  While the rooms are large, they are dated, and not everything works well.  Our bathroom sink backed up, the bed was lumpy, and the TV was missing a bunch of channels.Storage in the bathroom was non-existent as the cabinetry didn't open, a ludicrous design flaw.  Walls are thin, and noise carries.  We heard every voice in the hallway and every door close.  The room was not cleaned well, and debris discovered on the bathroom floor the first day remained through the third day.  The gym in the hotel has dated and worn equipment and is not the cleanest.Service is supposed to be a hallmark of this hotel and you are charged nine dollars and change daily for the honor.  I didn't get the big deal.  Butler service consisted of a couple of cups of coffee in the morning and shoe shines.  However, if you don't explicitly ask for it, you get nothing.  Free ($9 and change daily) breakfast is okay, consisting of beverages, pastries, fruit and yogurt, but no hot items.  There is a coffee maker in the room.  Nightcap service consists of a few bottles of Grand Mariner left out on a table. The folks working the check-in desk were not overly warm or helpful.  Their affect was competent. Fells Point has tons of good bars and mediocre restaurants.  You are a 15 to 20 minute walk from the Inner Harbor neighborhood where the better restaurants are located.  If you have meetings at the convention center, it's a 8 to 10 dollar Uber or taxi ride away.  I walked it in about 30 minutes.  Downtown Baltimore is not salubrious, and you are better off staying in one of the close by neighborhoods of Little Italy, Inner Harbor, Fells Point, or Federal Hill.  Baltimore comes alive in these neighborhoods and takes on a charm reminiscent of Georgetown, Annapolis, and Old Town Philadelphia.  The Inn at Henderson's Wharf has a wonderful setting, but it is not Baltimore's best hotel and it is not worth the outlay of cash required.I was there with a group of Friends this past December. We had a wonderful time. The hotel is beautiful. The staff (Winsome, William, Nija and Joan) were the best. So friendly, helpful and fun.  I would recommend a stay there when visiting Baltimore.I have known of the Inn at Henderson's Wharf for years. It has a reputation as the best (and priciest) hotel in Baltimore. While recent additions in Harbor East may have knocked it off that perch, it certainly is not by far. It is tucked into the end of a pier in Fells Point, just far enough from the action to stay peaceful but close enough for an easy walk. It is in a gorgeous brick building that blends into the condo units surrounding it. (Fans of a long-running satirical show will be amused to see that you can live at the Penthouses in the Lofts at the Residences in the Inn at Henderson's Wharf in Fell's Point.) When we wanted to splurge on a hotel room for Halloween in Fells Point, I knew just where to go.Everything about the hotel is beautiful, from the stately lobby to the open garden atrium to the rooms themselves. There are not many amenities on site, but they seem to have partnerships with many places nearby if you desire a workout or other standard options. There is a wine reception in the lobby on most days, which seems to run for exactly one hour. The times are posted in the material in the room (but if you ask me, if you're checking in within an hour of the start time the desk clerk could mention it.) They apparently also offer Grand Marnier at the complimentary coffee stations as a nightcap in the evening, but I don't think I would have availed myself of any even if I noticed it after returning from a fun evening in Fells Point. We did receive a text from the hotel shortly after we left for dinner asking us to contact them if we needed anything, which was nice if we needed a cab I guess.Aside from the coffee stations, they do have a lovely and varied continental breakfast laid out in the morning. It made for a pleasant morning after a pleasant night.Definitely my favorite hotel in Baltimore.  Located at the edge of Fell's Point, this is a really nice and charming hotel.  Large rooms with great views of the harbor.  Everything is clean and modern.  Great continental breakfast with fresh fruit, pastries and some hot items from time to time.  They also do a manager's wine happy hour at night from time to time.  Free wine, why not?Price wise it is a bit on the higher end, but I don't mind paying for it given the location and lack of hotels in this area.  They also have a parking lot for those of you driving in.I managed to get a good rate here for a business trip and I could not have been more pleased. The staff were professional and friendly at every interaction. I snapped a photo of the room when I arrived and it really is exactly as the brochures and web site make it out to be.  Located right in the old neighborhood of Fells Point, stumbling distance to incredible taverns along historic cobblestone roads and beautiful townhouses, this inn lies at the marina along the water.  The insides are built to impress.  Rich wood trim and furniture, plush carpets, and tasteful decor greet you.  The usual amenities are all there with nothing wasted on frivolous things, attention is spent on what matters: comfort, lighting, bedding, rich pillows, and the little extras like fresh eggs, berries, and melons at the breakfast bar.  Only two things could have made this hotel better: an on-site pool and an on-site hot tub. I would definitely recommend this place to others, even at their full price.Beautiful in every way!  Loved the location, the views, the ambience, the Grand Marnier/Chocolate night cap hour, the furnishings, the staff, the breakfast, etc., etc. One of the nicest and friendliest hotels ever.  As good as it gets!My partner and I were in Baltimore for an overnight (Sunday into Monday) and this boutique hotel had come highly recommended to us. When we arrived, we were immediately pleased with the hotel and its location - in addition to being on the water, the hotel is right around the corner from a ton of trendy restaurants and local shops. It's also only about a mile from the busy and beautiful Inner Harbor, which we were able to walk to in no time. The hotel itself is lovely. It has an old-fashioned charm with all the amenities you could possibly want or need. Our room was much larger than expected, with windows that looked out onto to the water and, most importantly, it was spotless. From start to finish, the hotel employees were excellent - polite, professional, etc. There were, however, a few things that struck us. First - we were told parking was valet and there would be a wine reception at check-in (5 p.m.). Turns out parking isn't valet; instead, you park in a (very) nearby lot. And the wine reception? It's only Monday through Saturday. Neither of these were a problem - parking was easy and super-secure. Also, it's included in the room rate, which is a great value in that part of the city. And while we would've loved complimentary wine, there were plenty of fabulous restaurants to more than makeup for the miscommunication. Next? Check-in isn't until 4 p.m., but we were told the hotel would hold on to our bags and call when the room was ready. They accepted our luggage and tagged everything accordingly, but we never did receive the call regarding our room. To err on the side of caution, we headed back to the hotel around 4:30 p.m. and the woman who checked us in apologized for not calling - she said she hadn't realized we were waiting for our room. As it turned out, the woman waiting to check in behind us had the same problem.Finally, upon check-out we were charged an additional $9.95 "Guest Service Fee" for a list of services we didn't utilize. Harbor Magic Hotels, which owns The Inn at Henderson's Wharf, among other properties, explained on a brochure that it's "excited to now offer all of our most popular services in one convenient Guest Service Fee of $9.95" ... PER NIGHT. Among the services? A "complimentary" bottle of water; free Wi-Fi (Is charging for that still a thing?); unlimited calling; a daily newspaper, etc.In an effort to fight back, my partner and I ate $10.95 worth of berries at the "complimentary" breakfast buffet, read our "complimentary" newspaper - twice, and pocketed some Earl Grey tea bags.Honestly? The hotel was terrific and we would absolutely stay again, but we were disappointed to find the kitschy brochure and hidden fee - just increase the cost of the rooms by $10 night. It's still a great value and much less offensive to travelers when they wake up in the morning and find the bill underneath the door.I'm a local so I've never stayed here but I've known a couple of folks who have and by all accounts this is a fantastic hotel. Prices aren't cheap but you get what you pay for. The rooms are gorgeous and very tastefully decorated and the location along the water is fantastic. Hotel staff come off as very professional and apparently there's a free breakfast that's far better than the usual junk that most hotels feed you in the morning. The only real reservation I have about Henderson's Wharf is the price. Unless you get a great deal it seems silly to drop the kind of money a room here usually costs if you're only using it to sleep. For romantic or special occasions though you'd be hard-pressed to do better.What a beautiful hotel! I stayed here for a night over the summer with a bachelorette party in a stunning room right on the pier in Fells. Although there were 7 or 8 of us, we all fit just fine in the room with two queen beds. I was lucky enough to snag a spot on the heavenly pillow-top for the night!I'm sure the front desk staff had a laugh as we ran back and forth asking for tape to hang decorations and ice for the drinks. But they were very helpful and even though we had to wait before checking into our room, they were apologetic yet friendly.There was a fantastic garden/courtyard area right off of the lobby where we took pictures and probably got laughed at (again) in our matching shirts.Possibly the highlight was in the morning when the lady cleaning up the complimentary breakfast stopped to make sure we could all grab as much as we wanted before she had to toss it! Such great service, beautiful location, and fantastic rooms. I don't know about the price (not sure I want to) but I think it would be worth it!A very delightful surprise.Staff/Check-InThe staff was extremely courteous and welcoming. The gentleman who staffed the happy hour and nightcap event was phenomenal. I would hire him to run my business. The company that runs this hotel really has their stuff together. After check-in I even received a welcome text on my cell phone and I was free to text back if I needed anything.LocationExcellent location on the wharf. Walking distance to Fell's Point, Inner Harbor, and Little Italy, and Canton.RoomsAll rooms in the hotel are located on the ground floor, so views are limited. The hotel is fairly small, only ~32 rooms I believe. The hallways are adorned with original handmade brick and really didn't feel like a normal hotel. Things looked new, well-kept, good-sized rooms with a real flower in the bathroom vase. Our room window opened up into the courtyard, where there were people seated (it was a little awkward so we kept the shutters closed). The courtyard was lushly landscaped. The rooms feature an iHome system (iphone 5 or newer) which was great.$10 Amenity FeeThere is a $10 fee for amenities/events which include: WiFi, continental breakfast (no hot foods), happy hour cheese and wine event, evening nightcap, a Starbucks coffee machine, and parking. The morning paper is delivered in a nice cloth bag.Overall, I highly recommend the Inn at Henderson's Wharf, and would look into staying at their 2 other sister properties in the area.I recently spent my first weekend at this place and I plan on coming back in the future. I have been coming to fells point for 3 years and have stayed at Admiral Fell inn ( which wasn't bad either) , but I found this place on yelp and I'm glad I found it. The customer service at this place was outstanding , anything at all you need is handled by the guest service butlers, free wine and cheese, and Gran Marnier & chocolate at night. The staff were all very friendly and all had great recommendations on where to find  local events . I will be booking my next stay in Fells Point at the Inn at Henderson's Wharf !!Great Hotel, great location, great staff. The facility is beautiful with a premium location right on the harbor, easy walking to all the Fells Point attractions and frankly not a bad walk to the Inner Harbor also.There is secure parking right next door and if walking is not your thing there is a shuttle that will take you around.The staff are exactly the people you want in the hospitality business, friendly, efficient and always willing to go above and beyond for the clients. Shout out to Katie and Marvin in particular, they could not be nicer or more helpful.Based on the Yelp reviews, we booked here this past weekend when we came to Baltimore for a concert at Pier Six.  This is the CUTEST little hote!  Clean, the rooms are cute, and the location is fantastic.  Wine Hour was great - complimentary wine and cheese in the afternoons, and the free breakfast was really great (much better than most hotels).  It is a great value for the price.  We had a room on street level and there was no issue at all with noise.  I would stay here again anytime!Always great.  We booked 5 rooms.  All wonderful.  The hospitality of this remarkable staff is unbelievable.  Chrissy at the front desk not only took care of our reservations and rooms, she reconfigured my iPhone with great apps for the area.  Marvin made our family feel so welcome, he was so kind we feel like he is now part of our family.  All five siblings and our spouses were there for Mother's Day weekend to celebrate our wonderful Mom who passed away at Christmas.  We all live in different cities, so it was great to get together in this lovely spot to spend time together.  Katie at the front desk took care of us as well, letting us know what was happening in the area and arranging a shuttle to take us to dinner on Saturday.  Raymond was our driver and he did a great job of getting us all to the restaurant on time.  Brett you do a great job and your staff is amazing.  We are thinking of doing this every Mother's Day weekend.  Thanks so much.  We really needed that and we appreciate your kindness.I'll try this again, apparently my reviews of Hendersons Wharf are "too gushing" and the Yelp filter throws them into the hidden category.  Stayed here again, April 2014, for 2 more days and are planning another visit in June.  Favorite hotel on the planet and we cannot say enough good things about it!  Our goal is to stay in every room, which is doable since there are only 38, all quiet and peaceful and just a few blocks from the bars and shops.   Once more to the staff:  Thank You All AGAIN!!stayed here during our last-minute trip to baltimore on a tuesday night.  pros: in fell's point and right on the water -- a really cool part of town, walking distance to great bars & restaurants.  the rate was reasonable, considering that the place was right on the water.  the complimentary wine at check-in is a nice touch.  the breakfast is good -- lots & lots of fresh fruit, cheese, breads, lucky charms. cons: the parking lot is somewhat questionable at best.  the decor is a little meh -- suited for an older crowd, i guess.  the "garden view" room...well, someone got a view at breakfast.  oops.I adore this place.  Most importantly, I love - I miss! - the breakfast.I can't explain exactly why it's so great ... the food is good (overflowing bowls of blackberries!) and the staff is adorable.  Somehow, all together, it makes for the most relaxing experience.You can eat properly at a table, outside in the courtyard, or curled up in an armchair in the lobby.  You can even bring a wooden tray filled with food back to your room.Maybe I love the breakfasts here so much because they epitomize the spirit of this place - not at all pretentious, but luxurious.  Warm and comfortable, yet elegant.I want to go back.The room I stayed in was spacious, clean, and inviting.  The bathroom was equally spacious and renovated. I stayed in room 111, which has a very nice view of the harbor.  I was also pleased with the breakfast- hard boiled eggs, fresh fruits, bagels, pastries, and fresh juices.  They have hot tea and coffee in the lobby whenever you like and their friendly service tops off with a complimentary wine in the room.  Now, that's service!!
review_content_20: We had an AMAZING experience at Henderson's Wharf Inn.  We stayed at the hotel on a last minute trip to Baltimore.  The location is absolutely amazing.. The setting is right on the water of the harbor. Each morning we woke up to a beautiful scene of serene water and the boats across the harbor.  From the moment we stepped into the inn's lobby and were greeted by the amazing staff.  The front desk receptionist (Shelby) was super friendly and assisted us with every request during our stay.  The lobby is beautifully appointed with plush, luxurious furnishings and the rooms are super comfortable.  The beds are amazing, the furnishings and bathrooms are wonderful..The atmosphere and location was exceptional.  One nice thing about the location is that it's located in the residential area off of the main Fell's Point area so it is super quiet as opposed to being located in the heart of Fells, but is in close walking distance.  There is a driver and plush Mercedes Van that can take you to and from the Inn to locations around the harbor up until 10pm.  The overall experience was definitely a 5 star experience,  the  breakfast each morning is awesome and Shelby the front desk agent is amazing and friendly.This place is a sure-bet if you are looking for a very nice place, close to the Fells Point action.  The location is fantastic, and even though the rooms are all on the street level, noise was never an issue.  Complimentary bottle of wine, the best TV channel selection I've ever seen (the entire DISH package), wonderful complimentary breakfast.The only thing preventing a 5-star rating is that our room and the lobby bathroom were a tad worn.  The tub in our room has some cracks around the drain.  The lobby bathroom was a little ragged.  Also the online reservation system is a bit odd and could use an upgrade.  Other than that, very very nice place.It would be hard to stay anywhere else when visiting Baltimore.I came here for a party in one of the penthouses (yes, some people actually do live here) so I didn't actually stay in the inn so I can't vouch for the hotel rooms but based on what I did see, I'm sure they're incredibly nice.  The location is pretty great, right in Fells Point.  The view is gorgeous, you can see for miles down the harbor.  The staff was sooo nice and helpful.  Living 15 minutes away, I have no real reason to ever stay here, but it is very tempting.This is the second time that my wife and I have stayed in the Inn at Hendersons Whart and both times we loved it. The place is beautiful, the staff is friendly and top notch and the rooms are extremely nice. We find the Inn very romantic and it is located right near all of the Fell Point activities and only a short water taxi ride to the Inner Harbor. They provide you with a comlpimentary bottle of wine and have a very nice continental breakfast. We always book a room overlooking the marina although the garden is very beautiful and a great place to enjoy breakfast. We find it a very relaxing and comfortable place to stay while we are in the Baltimore area.Oh my gosh-- this place is SO nice!!  The people who work there are extremely helpful and very sweet.  The toiletries are orange-scented and will tempt you to bathe when you don't need to (I'm serious about this-- I totally jumped in the shower when I didn't have time or need just because I wanted to use the soap and shampoo again).The bed is heavenly, although the pillows are a little fluffier than my liking.  I like my pillows pretty close to flat.  You'll get an amazing breakfast with tons of choices including fresh berries.  The rooms have a view of either the water or the gorgeous courtyard.I hear they have a 24-hour workout room, although I didn't use it.There are cool little bars nearby and a live-music venue, but I didn't visit them either.  It was a work trip and unfortunately, I saw the office and the hotel.  Good thing I loved the hotel.  :-)My boyfriend surprised me with a night here last weekend and it was incredibly romantic.  The complimentary bottle of wine facilitated a beautiful sunset over the harbor right from the window of our spacious room.  The location at Fells Point is ideal and the generous continental breakfast with fresh fruit and all the fixin's sealed the deal - we will be back!So , If you are in a quandrey over what special gift to give someone--- why not consider a night or two in Baltimore--- and stay at the most delightful Inn in all of Baltimore the Inn at Henderson's Wharf. Recently, my husband and I celebrated our 30th wedding anniversary-we wanted to go to Italy - but that was out of the question--- however, we stayed at the Inn at Hendersons Wharf for the weekend and enjoyed all the wonderful offerings of downtown Fells Point- great food, eclectic choices  and more musical venues than you can imagine in one little area....just a marvelous time...The Inn at Henderson's Wharf really made our weekend special--upon arrival everyone receives a complimentary  bottle of wine for the room ( of age visitors)- what a great way to start!The rooms are  refreshing and stylish and with the Inn's  spectucular location, right on the water...provided great views.The staff were friendly and accommodating, and the morning complimentary breakfast was  outstanding.So, If you want a great getaway without the hassle of trains, planes, and body scanners--- enjoy a stay at The Inn at Henderson's wharf.TerriWe ended up finally getting in for an incredibly reasonable rate last year, I think because they had a day of cancellation. On top of the hotel just being really cool and on the water, it's located in a great part of town. Soooo much is within walking distance. To start, they have a private gated parking lot, I guess because as someone mentioned the top floors are actually condos that people own. The lobby area is very nicely decorated. Guest get a complementary bottle of wine, a small cheese plate, and two chocolates, which were a nice touch. Our wine was red, I only drink white, and they allowed us to trade at the front desk. The room was above and beyond; I will add pics later, with exposed brick and antique wood furniture. I don't know what the full rate would be, but I'm assuming I wouldn't be able to afford it. The stay included a continental breakfast which was good, pastries, fresh fruit, and the usual. The staff was great, they assisted us with suggestions of places to dine, and other parts of the city we might enjoy. There was a flower festival on the opposite side of town, which they directed us to. Overall a great stay, I would definitely go back.

hotel_name: Home2 Suites by Hilton Baltimore Downtown
review_content: We stayed here for 3 nights while visiting family. The hotel was clean and inviting. The staff was very friendly and accommodating to any/all of our needs. Each time we came into the lobby, we were greeted right away with a very friendly voice!  We used the valet service for our car and they were very quick each time we called for service. The rooms were very clean and straightened up each day that we were there.   They even changed the towels each day, even if we left them hung up to dry, which was a nice surprise!The only thing that might need improvement is the breakfast service, if you got there within 20 minutes of closing there wasn't much of a selection as far as breakfast sandwiches or oatmeal...but the early bird gets the worm, do we need to make sure we are there earlier next time we stay. The hotel is easy to get to and close to a lot of the main Baltimore attractions.It's not a great hotel, but's a good one and it was perfect for my recent Christmas visit to see family in Baltimore. Edward L. redeemed his HHonors points and picked well for us.The room itself is large and well appointed. I get the feeling this building was converted to a hotel from studio apartments or a medical building. If so, great reuse of the space. We didn't need or use the kitchen during our trip, but the appliances were new and even included a dishwasher. I guess that's why they call it Home2 because it's sorta like your home, too.I like the fact that the building is a narrow highrise because there aren't many rooms on each floor and the elevator is pretty fast. Parking isn't ideal and I'd prefer an attached parking deck, but they do a good job running valet service 24/7 and there's a lot of metered street parking available, which was surprising because in most cases like that you're fighting for limited spaces, high rates, and inconvenient time limits. This neighborhood doesn't seem to have those problems. We didn't try it, but I'd encourage hotel guests to consider street parking because I think it's a really good alternative.Location is always important when traveling from out of town. We were 20 minutes to family gatherings and about 5 minutes from Horseshoe Casino. I'm glad that was there because there were torrential rains every day, all day during our trip and being able to escape inside to the adult arcade was fun. Plus, Oriole Park at Camden Yards, M&T Stadium, are all within walking distance.Our 10th floor room had a great view toward the monument that was decorated with Christmas lights from top to bottom. You can also see out toward the Inner Harbor area. Oh, and free wifi! Just connect to "attwifi" or "HHonors" and you're set.I stayed here one night on a business trip last week. It is a downtown hotel. Parking options are street parking which is free overnight but your car must be moved by 7 am; valet parking which is $36? / night or there is a garage 2 blocks away that charges $15 for 24 hours (it's next to the Embassy Suites). I chose the garage. The hotel is of European design. There is a breakfast offered in the morning which is minimal but sufficient. My room was spacious.  I arrived at 11:00 pm due to a delayed flight and when I walked in the room the thermostat was set to 81 and this was in late June. It took me about an hour to cool the room down.My stay was ok. I would return only is the price was attractive. The parking options were not appealing to me. Front desk staff were nice and the property was clean.Inexpensive and clean rooms but on the top floor the street noise was still a problem and heard the neighboring room's alarm clock.I teetered on the 3 star bubble, but would average this hotel at 2.5.We were in town for a wedding and this was the cheaper of the 2 options we were given. We called for an early check in and they said a room would be ready by 1. We arrived at around 1:15. When we got to the front, Latina I think he name was, we told her our name and she mumbled basically "not ready". Um. ok? Well do you have a time frame? Can we put our luggage somewhere? We were told 1pm, and no we got told another hour at least because everyone was at lunch.  We had to ask a million questions like they had never checked someone in before. No one seemed to know where we parked or the valet situation. It was just a bit of a mess. When we finally check in, we got our "queen" room, which was in fact a full sized bed in a giant room that could accommodate 2 kings if it had to. I took off my flops to get unpacked and the floor was soaking wet. I mean, like walking on a sponge wet. It was gross. When we told the front desk, their response was "ok". Not I'm sorry, or anything, we had to ask if it had been cleaned that way, could they do anything? Again, we had to do all the problem solving. Their response was "yeah we have something to dry it, we just have to find it." They obviously didn't, because the floor was still wet when we returned. It finally dried by the next morning. The bed wasn't comfortable at all and squeaked quite a bit every time we moved.You have to valet your car, there is no on site parking. And give yourself 30 minutes to get your car ready. We had to twice and each time they told us 15-20 minutes and one time it took closer to 45 minutes. So be ready for a wait. The breakfast was ok, basically a waffle maker and some microwavable sandwiches. I will say the one man stocking and taking care of breakfast was extremely helpful and friendly.Overall, this wouldn't be my first choice in Baltimore.I had stayed at one of these properties when I was in San Antonio for business. I had many choices of hotels to choose from at even lower rates but decided on this one because they provided transportation to my events. Next time I will stay further out and just rent a car.I was able to catch the van out without incident a couple times but had problems getting rides in. I called and was told someone was coming. Called 30 mins later and was told they had already been out. I was in the same spot watching and no one had come through. They sent the driver back. He said he was picking up me and another person and he had "waited 15 mins". I had been outside all the time and the van is easy to spot. I even told them where I was when I called in. I asked him "So you just left me?" He apologized.The next time I was told someone was on the way. Another guest recognized me from staying at the same hotel. We were out there about 20 mins. They called and were told no one was coming due to traffic and to just call a cab. (1)Why wasn't I told the same thing? They had my room # with my contact#. Why didn't anyone bother to contact me as a courtesy?Another time I called, I was told the van was out and to call a cab. The van was at the site when I got there. My visit was mediocre at best. The staff seemed to have attitudes at time too. This by far was one of the least pleasant visits I have had at a Hilton property in all my years of traveling.Will definitely stay elsewhere next time. Very disappointed with my stay and will not recommend it to my friends and family. I do think the Home2 Suites is a great concept but feel some of this staff at this location could benefit from some customer service training. Some of them give off nasty vibes. Some of the conversations with customers were less than appealing.Terrific bargain for the price paid. We got a full kitchenette, the bathroom was amazing, and had so many unexpected surprises. We had a full refrigerator, toaster, dishwasher, cutlery, pull-out sofa and a beautiful bathroom. If this room had a range cooking area, we would move in as a condo or a renter! Will definitely be looking to book at this hotel in the future!Pros: this was a very clean hotel. The suites are of good size and the amenities are nice. I liked the tv setup and the comfort of the bed.Cons: The location is odd. It's tough to get in and out of. I opted for the valet at $16/day which made it much easier. Overall a good place that I would enjoy visiting again.Excellent! Wonderful staff. Great room with kitchen - modern and clean. Nice fitness room with laundry. Delicious breakfast. One complaint - the iron was chincy. Otherwise a wonderful home away from home!The cleanest hotel by hilton we ever stayed in ! Jason at the front desk is very nice and helpful, walls are not paper thin like other hotels, everything in the room was new, and the staff are all friendly. The only thing is that the breakfast selection is very poor, so don't count on it.My husband and I, my sister in law and her SO and three friends all stayed at this hotel from 4/25-4/27 for my daughter's wedding. The cost is reasonable, the hotel is clean and well managed. The breakfast is not skimpy like some free breakfasts are. The rooms were very comfortable and the addition of a kitchenette made it convenient too. Will definitely stay here on subsequent trips to Baltimore.Great deal for your money. Stayed 1 night in July and was very happy with the eco friendly options. Breakfast was good and staff were great! Clean hotel and nice outdoor eating space.I'm running the Baltimore half marathon on October 18, 2014 and booked my hotel room back in July. I'm a Hilton rewards member and booked this hotel specifically because it was a Hilton and for the in room kitchen. Then, a few days ago (October 8) the Hilton Home2Suites on E. Pleasant St. in Baltimore bumped 30 runners competing in the Baltimore Running Festival because they could get a higher rate for the rooms due to the Orioles making the playoffs. It's been a while since I've seen such greed and terrible business practices. Apparently being a reward member doesn't mean a damn thing.We stayed at the Baltimore Home2 for one night, and it was a wonderful experience. They did everything they could to make it a good stay, even helping us find a good place to park. Great breakfast, wonderful beds.I absolutely love this hotel!!! Have stayed here on two separate occasions with the bf and I can say I always love my stays here. The service is top-notch... free breakfast!!!! and smoking rooms that have ipod/ipad docking stations!!! rooms are spacious, full kitchenette with dishes, silverware and cups/mugs.FREE WI-FI!!!!!!This place is soooo convenient that you will not miss being right on top of the inner harbor. The hotel is about 6 short blocks away from the inner harbor, but there's a super market and food court a block away.There are bars that and restaurants that line Charles st which is one of the cross streets that the hotel sits on. There are strip clubs a few blocks away including hustler, and a few clubs on east Baltimore. Being from NYC and in love with New Orleans Baltimore is more 3rd favorite place and I will always stay at this hotel if possible.I love this place so will you!!!!Hands down the best hotel stay from the West coast to the East coast!  The rooms are very, very clean...not even dust!!! Customer service is wonderful..delightful even!  The rooms are fully equipped with everything you could possibly need to feel at home away from home.  Yes, the valet is a bit expensive, but it's downtown Baltimore. Some garages charge $5 for 20 minutes.  Get over it, El Cheapos. Other positives:  rooms are very quite. Miminal street noise, can't hear anyone in the other rooms.  Huge TV, amazing bathroom, lovely housekeeping staff, AMAZING IN-ROOM COFFEE!!! The only issue we had during our stay was the water temperature control.  It was never an option to get cold tap water from the sink, but the showers can get super hot, so proceed with caution!  I love this place.  Great location! Try Maisy's just around the corner on N. Charles St. for some tasty comfort food and hard drinks!  If we ever need another hotel here in Baltimore, we already know where we're staying, folks!  LKLove Love Love this hotel! I have stayed in this hotel about 3 times. Very unique from other hotels I have stayed in. All rooms come with a kitchenette! Bathroom has a sliding door...Yes...A SLIDING DOOR!!! Service was great. Prices are not bad. You can find specials online for this hotel as well. Not far from the inner harbor at all. Don't take my word for it.... Try it on your next visit to Baltimore City or to just get away! :)Hotel is centrally located in Baltimore.  The stadium, the Poe grave site, the aquarium, and the Baltimore waterfront are all within a mile.  Walking distance if you are up for it!  Plenty of places to eat around the hotel.  The rooms were clean and spacious.  The staff was incredibly accommodating.  They offered us plenty of recommendations and assistance if needed.  They always asked how we were doing when we walked in the door.  Darnell, the breakfast attendant, is amazing.  The only downside I can mention is that the parking is valet and is an additional change, but this seems common for hotel in Baltimore.  Overall, highly recommended.A very nice property in the heart of Downtown  Baltimore. Great location and very accommodating staff. The rooms are spacious and clean. Views are nothing spectacular due to the location around larger buildings. The #1 negative however is the parking. Valet is available, but at a cost of course. Other than that, there is on street parking if you can find it. Still, a nicely priced property.I like this hotel.  I actually stayed here last year for my birthday.  It just seemed right.  The hotel is between the Charm City Circulator Purple Route,  how perfect is that.  I booked online and stayed on a low floor which was fine, it was very quiet so I had alot of peace and quiet.  I love the free wifi and the lovely flat screen t.v. There is also an alarm clock with an Ipod dock in the room.  The room was clean and comfortable I had enough room to lay about.  There is also a supermarket about 2-3 blocks over that has already prepared foods and goodies that you would need if you didn't feel the need to go to the restaurants that line Charles Street.  The only issue is that is on a steep hill which for some may be a real problem for some namely the elderly or a person in a wheelchair but I am from The Bronx, NY, my borough is consists of steep angled hills so it wasn't much of a problem.  The free breakfast was so-so, I preferred to walk over to a Dunkin' Donuts about 3-4 blocks away to grab some breakfast.
review_content_20: I spent two weeks at this location and could not have been more pleased. Entire staff was exceptional.  Rooms clean and comfortable.  Would strongly recommend to anyone.I recently stayed here to have a place to crash before and after the Baltimore Half Marathon.  It's in the perfect location-right in the heart of Mt. Vernon, half way between Penn Station and the Inner Harbor.  At $150 for a Hilton hotel, you can't beat it.  Plus, it has a kitchenette, so my gf and I were able to eat take out on real plates and silverware and drink wine out of glass like we were at home in our living room.Let us just say that we stay exclusively at Hilton Brand Hotels.  We phoned in to the front dest to ask a question prior to booking our 2 room 5 night stay on line.  The girl, and I use that word intentionally...the GIRL who finally answered the phone after picking it up and talking to her peers for about 20 seconds answered my question with an, "um...NO.  Is that it?"  Before she shuffled me off the phone.  So, needless to say, we booked our rooms elsewhere.The accommodations were clean, and neat. However, the front desk is a bit disorganized - they failed to warn me of an "incidentals" charge of $50 against my debit card. Of course, this will come off after a few days, but I was upset that I was not forewarned about e charge. The other thing is that the A/C was not working, and I didn't get a chance to tell them until the next morning. Marlon (manager) there was very helpful, and made up for the up fact that it didn't work by removing my parking charge of $25.00 after I spoke with the front desk about the problem.Would I stay there again? Probably. But the front desk needs to be extremely clear about there charges up front.This hotel is wonderful!  The staff is incredible!  The guests are all happy!  The rooms are clean and have absolutely everything (except a bath tub). Even the housekeeper Shyneice is terrific! Be sure you remember to leave her tips. That girl works hard and has the best attitude and smile! I would give the staff 10 stars and thank whoever hires here. They all seem happy and take pride in their work. I would give the overall stay a 5 if they had shuttle service (but the staff will happily call a cab for you and it will be prompt...thanks Cameron!). And a big thanks to Mike for being so thoughtful at 3am and making sure my water for my hot tea was hot enough and prepping the great breakfast at 6am...he is just so thoughtful and attentive. Other than no tub or shuttle it's just a great great place to stay!For the money, it's a great deal.  Really, really nice rooms with new amenities and firm beds.  Exceptional service.  The lounge downstairs was nice and comfy and the hotel was generally pretty quiet.  Being that we would have had the same rate at the Mount Vernon Hotel a couple of blocks away, I'm glad we stayed here.Great deal , extremely friendly and helpful staff, good room, and great location... To disagree with others reviews about parking i thought the valet service was great, 25$ a day unlimited in and out, and knowing my car was save I'm a garage and not on the street is enough for me. Coming from A place like Philly where your car is not safe on any street any time from being dinged and side swiped, having valet for 25 a day is amazing. We plan on looking for more home 2 suites if we travel again, and definitely would come back to this one.PROsGreat price and brand new :)AAA members get 10% off and they don't check your member card, if you know what I'm sayin'There was a super amazing helpful employee named Lakia who always went above and beyond. Everyone else resonated around sub par. Breakfast is offered from 7-9. Selection is just carbs and coffee (coffee is around through the afternoon though yay). Yogurt. All rooms have a full size fridge,large microwave, dishwasher, toaster, coffee maker and a hotplate/skillet upon request. There is also a pull out couch and a curtain to separate the bed from the couch bed. wifi and printing are free. Remote printing is not available. There is a decent fitness center, "game room" (just an xbox), and laundry room.No bed bugs yayyyyyy There are lots of bars/restaurants within walking distance. Neutrogena shampoo and body wash are stocked in dispensers in the shower (which is only a shower... and the dispensers sometimes leak..)CONsParking is kinda shitty but as long as you read the signs you're good. They have valet for $25/day, but we just did parking lots/street parking and ended up spending less than $30 for Fri/Sat/Sun combined. Bed was pretty uncomfortable.Some of the dishes weren't *ready*to*use* clean.We stayed from Friday until Monday morning during St. Patty's Day. The sign in the bathroom explained the cleaning services are only provided M-F, and on the weekends as requested. They also offered a "full cleaning" every 5th day. However a cleaning person came on Saturday. The bathroom is had a sliding door, and the cleaning person moved it in such a way that it was stuck :( When we came back to the room later on Saturday we had to call the front desk several times (thank god Lakia was working!!). The staff persons -- janitorial engineers or something ridiculous who had the tools to fix said door wouldn't be back until Monday and Lakia offered to move us to another room. We magically figured it out with a screw driver, because all our toiletries were in the bathroom... and I would not have survived the weekend.We ended up here because the Brookshire Hotel had given away our room, even though we had informed them we would be late when we booked.  We were very happy with the suite.  Plenty of room and clean.  People at the desk were friendly and helpful. Breakfast was more varied and tastier than other places we've been.  I'd stay again.Very pleased with this property for the price and location. It is off a side street in a great location for restaurants and easy access to the interstate. I really loved the rooms for the class of hotel it is. Comfortable bed, nice kitchen area and very modern looking. Will try to stay here again. I personally think about the same as a new Hampton Inn.Meh...It served its purpose. The location was not easy to find and the noise from outside was loud. I travel frequently for business and this isn't a place that I would choose on purpose again.

review_content: Stayed one night so we didn't have to drive after a concert at the Royal Farms Arena.  On the plus side - very pleasant staff at desk and valet, the room was clean, bed & pillows very comfortable and the location was perfect. We did have a microwave and mini fridge, but didn't need it.  On the not as good side - we booked a Queen room, but the bed was clearly only a full size. The room was on the small side, but in the city that is what you get.  Breakfast buffet was disappointing.  You do have to pay extra for parking. I would stay here again.If I could give the Baltimore Harbor Hotel zero stars I would. The hotel was over priced for the room. The room was no bigger than any regular hotel room. The nicest part of this hotel was the lobby. There is a bar by the lobby area that does not serve food, aside from the continental breakfast, which consisted of cereal and a waffle maker. The rooms were outdated and small and it looked as though the mirror hadn't been cleaned in months. The bathroom mirror wasn't any better. Speaking of the bathroom,not the water pressure was terrible and the water itself was cold. The hotel staff are rude. Every last one of them. Granted, there was a blizzard outside and they were stuck at work, so I would not be the happiest person either, but all of them were flat out rude. The valet got my car stuck in the snow so myself, along with other guests had to dig my car out for over an hour. Had I not said anything to the valet personnel, they would have left. Thanks to the plow truck driver (who was also stuck) who gave my party a bucket of salt to help us move my car, otherwise my car would have been stuck in the valet's driveway for even longer. After getting my car stuck and inconveniencing my friends, other hotel guests and myself, the hotel still tried to charge me $38/night for the valet, when at the end of the day I drove my own car into the parking lot. If you do decide to stay here, just know that you have to utilize the valet because there is no other parking available, other than another parking garage down the road that is $20/night without in and out services. So make sure you include the parking price along with the cost of your room.In all of my years of traveling, I've never encountered such terrible customer service, and that is coming from a New Yorker. I love downtown Baltimore but I will never give the Baltimore Harbor Hotel another penny.Booked a last minute room here for my friends mini bachelorette party. The hotel was actually really nice, I was impressed. Checking in the staff was nice and the lobby is very well decorated. Our room was just as I expected. Two double beds. The room was nice, a little warm but nothing the AC can't fix. The only downfall was that they do not have refrigerators in the regular rooms. We were constantly filling out ice bucket and thank goodness we brought a cooler too to keep our drinks cold. The hotel is just a 5 min cab ride to the inner harbor or fed hill which is what we wanted. I'd definitely stay here again.Terrible customer service. Bathroom was dirty and I didn't stay. My gf and I took one look at room and left. Hotel charged me 50 dollars stil... Terrible customer service in a bad area. Don't stay here there are plenty better around in better safer areasPictures can be deceiving. Main lobby looks great. You get up to the rooms and they're worn down. Stuff is falling apart in the rooms. Dirt on the walls. Just not the best hotel experience especially since this was fairly expensive.This review is from August 2014 and was posted on what was the other Yelp entry for the Baltimore Harbor Hotel that has changed names to a non-existing hotel at this address.For many years the group I travel with has stayed here during Otakon with pleasant experiences. On the Sheraton Baltimore City Center Yelp page I gave this hotel a four star rating. The situation has greatly changed with the hotel no longer being a Sheraton.From the outside it looks slightly different with changed signage and a coat of paint. Valet parking staff are still excellent and were nothing but helpful. The South Tower is now closed and it was the first time we roomed in the North Tower. The North Tower was a world of difference in the wrong direction. Starting off, the room for a double was smaller than the ones in the South Tower were.What we found in our room:1. Capped electrical wires had fallen out of the bottom of the rooms cooling unit.2. Graffiti/Vandalism was written on the inside of the closet wall.  3. The center divider on the top of the table in our room had broken loose.4. The electrical socket closest to our bed was loose and falling out of the wall.The room remained functional but we reported many of these problems to hotel staff immediately. Checkout was even more of a disaster then Otakon Sunday tradition. Of the three elevators, one broke, leaving two functional units for 20+ floors. Another surprise we received, when calling for a baggage cart is the bellhop position at the hotel has been terminated. You have to get your own carts from the lobby and transport your own luggage. My friend and I carried our luggage down seven floors to the lobby via the stairs, consequently reducing my rating from three stars to two.The only reason we are giving two stars to this hotel is because the staff were excellent and helpful, that has not changed. Our group has made the decision to look into other options in the harbor area after this year as the hotel has visibly gone backwards. I can't recommend this hotel right now.So...things that were good: staff, location, valet parking.That's it.  Bad things: water pressure (a complete joke), upkeep of the hotel property, and sheets were torn up. *UPDATE: I forgot the worst part. I went to get a cup of coffee and fruit from the breakfast bar.  The banana was warm.  I don't mean room temp....I mean HEATED!   For what we paid for it, it was just fine (priceline discount).  For the money they wanted to charge - absolutely not.  We stayed one night for the ballgame - and it did what we needed.Stayed here overnight last month. Checked in really late so everything was pretty quiet when we arrived. Until we got up to our room that is--the walls were paper thin. Like paper paper, we could hear the moans of the woman across the hall (corner rooms) gettin' her whole world rocked. It was pretty surreal.Add this to a lumpy mattress, dim lighting, and my own 1am check-in and I just felt cheap the whole time I was there lol.They also charged us inaccurately for a movie rental-still need to resolve that!We picked the wrong weekend to come. Apparently there was a football tournament nearby so there were 150+ youth football players and their families. It was complete craziness. The breakfast was held in the bar restaurant in the hotel. There was not enough seating for everyone. There were only two people working. One making the waffles and one supposedly cleaning, but the tables were a mess and there were cups everywhere because apparently the guest don't know how to clean up after themselves. The mirror in the men's bathroom was broken and the only thing anyone did was put paper towels on top of the broken glass. They didn't clean up the glass on the floor. I would not recommend the place to anyone.I have had to have my key re-magnetized every single time I enter my room. Over five days I have been waiting in line at the front desk at least twice a day to fix the key issue. Also, the AC unit is dirty and aggravated my sinuses. They seem understaffed and I am underwhelmed.Their only morning tea choice was Lipton.We rented the deluxe corner room, room was nice and clean but we expected the room to be bigger. Bathroom was clean but very small. If I come back to Baltimore City I will most likely choose another hotel.Booked through Hotwire two rooms for the weekend. Location close to convention center, and the breakfast was ok. Room was small but clean, and we had no issues with our stay. Recommended.We booked three rooms here for my friend's bachelorette party. After looking at the website we thought we would be staying at a really nice hotel for the weekend. When we arrived we saw a cockroach in the lobby. After arriving in our rooms we found ripped curtains, stained bed spreads and wallpaper peeling off of what looked like a moldy walls. We did have a refrigerator in our room, that was the only perk. We felt extremely Mislead comparing the rooms we were staying in to the pictures on the website.Enjoyed the stay. The room (King size bed) was not that spacious. Its just enough room for one person, but if you have a guest be prepared to tango while getting dressed. We found out as we attempted to grab a bite to eat they do not have a kitchen. They have a grab and go section, which has wraps, sandwiches, and salads. The deal for $10 (sandwich, fruit cup, and beverage) was surprisingly good. I grabbed the pastrami. Back to the room, the bathroom stylish, but also small. The heat, however worked great. Imagine so, since it has but so much space to heat. For some a small room would be just fine, but if you're looking for something to stretch out in this is not the spot.Expected Stay:12/23/14-12/31/14Actual Stay: 12/23/14-12/24/14Room:1201We booked this hotel for the holidays while visiting family. The reason we decided on this hotel because it was pet friendly and located near many different things.1. First issues we encountered was parking. The hotel valet parking is $32.00 per day. We were advised that our only other parking options were a public lot that charged $15.00 each time a person drives in or out. We asked about street parking and they said "good luck". We were also advised even if we did find street parking that we could not park on the street overnight. So we were basically forced into the valet parking. Another issue with the valet is trying to get your car. There was several times that I called to get the car and no one answered it would bounce back to the front desk. 2. There is no bell person at all. The valet will help you unload and load. However you are on your own getting things to your room. We were on the 12th floor by the way. Two people, two dogs and lots of bags and no one to assist us. I found this really weird since there were several people just standing around the front desk area. Why the need for so many front desk staff but no bell person? 3. We picked this hotel because it was pet friendly. This is really not a pet friendly hotel. There are no area's at all to take your pet to use the bathroom. The front desk front told us that we could use a grass area across the street that people took dogs. As soon as we went over to the grass area we could see many different signs saying "no dogs on lawn." We were very confused why the desk person would send us to an area that didn't allow dogs. Pet friendly and no pet areas at all. However if your pets have an accidents you will be charged $100.00 cleaning fee.4. The Traditional King room was the size of a closet and no way sufficient for two people. The room was booked for two people. The bathroom was not even big enough for one person. The heating didn't work properly so the room was cold most of the night. There were huge brown stains of the curtains. White stains on the floor and the blankets on the bed smelled of old newspapers. The hotel is in downtown so it is very noisy and loud at night. A hospital is very close so lots of sirens constantly.5. Breakfast was the bare minimum. Toast, cereal, hard boiled eggs, yogurt, waffles and juice. The boiled eggs tasted very old and gross. I opened the yogurt and as soon as it went into my mouth I spit it out. It tasted really funny. I looked at the date and it said 12/02/14. So the yogurt I was given by this hotel was over 24 days old. So now I know that the boiled eggs were definitely old. The yogurt was given to the front desk we when checked out so they would know about the issue. We planned to stay 8 night but after the first night decided to check out and go to Best Western Plus BWI. There was no way we could put ourselves or our dogs through this disaster of a hotel. There was really no good points about our stay at all. Just a big disappointment and a headache finding a new hotel last minute on a holiday.Decent downtown hotel but it still has the same problems that the Sheraton had when this was the Sheraton.
