The place is dated and the AC often doesn't work properly and you'll wake up sweating. I was sort of pissed off when I call down to the valet and they tell me the car is available for for pickup in 1 hour they estimate. I thought I misheard them so I said excuse me and they told me everyone is checking out now so it will be a while. (palm to head). The place does have its positives though. Great downtown location where you can walk to the sports stadiums and it is dog friendly. It has a nice pool and gym and the price is reasonable. Would I stay here again? Sure. Would I seek it out? No.Our room wasn't ready even though it was 5PM when we arrived. They double booked our room. Loud concert playing outside our room which was loud until 11PM even on 22nd floor. Room was dusty. Someone tried to enter the adjoining room door in the middle of the night which made me nervous. Loud neighbors even though we were in a corner room with only one other adjacent room. Luckily it was only one night. Oh and bar where happy hour took place had no dewars. What!??!!My family and I recently spent 5 nights at the hotel while my daughter underwent major surgery at Johns Hopkins hospital. From reception to the valet parking, people could not have been more friendly or accommodating.  Rooms are clean, breakfast is included, though limited.  I would recommend to anyone, especially if your visit involves the hospital.I just have to say that after reading the awful reviews for this hotel, I was pretty darn scared to come here.  But, I didn't experience ANY of the problems that everyone has complained about - the air conditioning in the whole building was really quite chilly - I was here for a conference and the meeting rooms were pretty darn cold, and my room was perfect.  All the employees were very nice too - maybe because there were a hundred or so people there for a conference, they were on their best behavior?  I don't know.  But I didn't have any problems at all.  Oh - one of my favorite things about the place was the pillows in my room - four huge down pillows on each bed - I quite literally just wanted to lounge in my room all day snuggling with those pillows!  I guess the only downfall would be that there wasn't a mini fridge in the room, or a microwave.  Most rooms have those these days.  Anyway, I would definitely stay here again.The room was small however very clean and neat. The biggest problem was that everything was unplugged. Bedside lights and clock unplugged  and required us to move the bed in order to plug in. We thought the TV was broken until we realized that too was unplugged. For $200 a night I shouldn't have to move furniture and plug in the lights.
review_content_20: The hotel staff is very discourteous and slow. It took us an hour to check in and when we wanted to check out there was no one available to check us out for a half an hour. A and when we did finally get someone to check us out, she acted like we were bothering her.  Plus the rooms are small. I would never stay here again.Hotel itself is old appearing. Parking is expensive $30 for valet $18 for self park across the street. Free WiFi. Nice swimming pool. There is a continental breakfast that has basics yogurt hard boiled eggs waffles pancakes and other carbs. Also cereal and milk. The shower did not have great water pressure. Beds were comfortable enough. The hotel bar had a decent selection of taps and a happy hour from 4-8pm. Not sure if I would stay here again. For being called Baltimore harbor hotel would think it would be closer to the harbor. A good 12-15 minute walk. Front desk and housekeeping were very nice.Nice hotel. Room was clean & this hotel had decent amenities. Good service & the continental breakfast was plentiful. Security guards were very friendly and the gym was well equipped for a good workout. Overnight parking was overpriced though. Overall I would say that this hotel was a good place to say.It was fine-but nothing to rave about. It is clearly an old building, but they have tried to keep it up to date and it seemed clean. My standard room had a fridge and microwave which was nice. The beds and pillows weren't particularly comfortable, but could have been worse. Fine for one night on a work trip, but probably wouldn't stay for longer.The room was perfect. The bell staff was great they went above and out of their way. Gerald extra kudos to him he helped mw load jn both to the conference and to my room...he also periodically passed and asked if I was ok. He made the stay feel extra special with hia attentiveness.The bar was a nightmare. The Bartender was very slow,  rude and unprofessional. A middle aged guy on Friday night with no clue how to properly service a bar and many left the bar upset and frustrated. The hotel has no food except a small cooler of very expensive sandwiches - really $3 for a Gatorade?! It was never properly stocked and price gouging.Good experience. In/out parking included. Hotel rooms are nice and the staff are attentive. We had an issue with the air in our room and they were very responsive. This hotel is not neat the harbor though so there aren't many views of this is what you're looking for. And the free breakfast is more like continental style not deluxe as advertised... That's my only hang up. Overall I would probably stay here againNope just nope, standard room means STANDARD room BUT that was not the issue , the heater didn't work , the fan worked (it blew air) but not hot air just air even cranked up to 80 , so we went down to the front and asked and they said they'd send someone up , an hour later still nothing, went down again , an hour after that still nothing , SO we fell asleep then low and behold in the middle of night the heat was on and fine , dunno if they did anything but it behind below 30 outside and no heat was not funDon't be fooled, this is NOT on the harbor. It should really be considered as being downtown.  The renovation helped a little on the inside but it is still an old building in a location that is not very convenient for most tourist attractions. It's a bit of a walk to the water front, passing through an area that is a somewhat unsavory.Where to start, beds and pillows are awesome, customer service are ok. It is clean but my big thing is the room was hot we couldn't cool it off. The maintenance guy had to come and unlock the window. The water pressure in the shower sucked. The continental breakfast was average. I would stay here again if i needed too.Service is very so-so!  Key didn't work 2 times and they tried to blame me...   Upon checkout, I did not get a receipt and was asked for an email address so they could transfer the profile and charge the account without my viewing of charges...  Bad service in my opinion!!!!!!The first receptionist was very accommodating, however the night shift was NOT. I checked in around 10:30pm and when I finally entered my room, it smelled like an astray. I called to complain, no response. I turned on the heat because it was chilly and it never came on. I think my room was colder than outside. Called downstairs, waited 20mins, no response. I finally went down to the front desk and the receptionist was rude. I decided I was not going to stay there at 12:34am and she had the never to say she would charge me half. YEAH RIGHT..... The hotel should invest in renovating the rooms, as they did the lobby.The staff were very nice to me, but that's about the only good thing I can say about this hotel.  Our room was extremely drafty and cold the entire time. In fact we went to look at the window to see if it was left open and it turned out the window had no seal on it--so we could basically feel it in our room every time the wind picked up outside.We also had 3 people in our room, all sleeping in separate beds, and they refused to give us a rollaway bed to sleep on. They insisted it was due to some fire code restriction. All I know is that there appeared to be plenty of room for another double bed in there and they couldn't even give us a measly twin to sleep on. We had to use a makeshift mattress of pillows and blankets to sleep on every night, and it was incredibly uncomfortable and cold. At one point they finally agreed to allow us to have a rollaway and promised to send it up to us. Several hours later after no one showed up I went back down and asked them where the bed was and they told me once again that they were going back on their word and would no longer give us a bed.The lobby is ok, the rooms are tiny with even tinier bathrooms.  The bathroom sink is pedestal style with very little space for anything. There was no space to put clothing if changing in the bathroom...just some very narrow glass shelves that were dusty.   The carpet in the room was old, dingy and dirty feeling and buckled in places.  The hotel offers very few amenities.  There was no safe in the room for keeping valuables.  There is no room service in this hotel and the "tavern" offers very few options.   The day we checked out, I noticed a problem with the bill that had been slipped under the door.  It looked like I had been charged for three days of valet parking when we had only been there two days.  I stopped at the front desk to deal with this issue while my traveling companions took all the luggage, including my bag, out to wait for the valet to bring around her car.  It turned out that they had charged two days of valet parking to a random Discover card that didn't belong to anyone in my party, and one day to my credit card.  While they were trying to figure out who's Discover card they had used, I asked if they could just please correct the charges on my card and deal with that later...which they did.  When I walked outside, my friends were waiting in the vehicle and we left.  Only when we got home (5 hours away), did I realize that my bag never made it into the car.  I called the hotel and they had it there behind the front desk.  I asked if they could ship it to me and they said that I would have to make arrangements to have it picked up and shipped.  I spoke to my friend who had been outside when the car was loaded. She said that when the valet (Bob) brought the car around she and the girls had started to put our bags in the back of the car and Bob told her that one of his guys would take care of that.  All of our bags were together on the curb.  My friend and the girls got into the vehicle while Bob's "guy" loaded everything in.  He asked if that was it and my friend looked at the curb where our bags had been and there was nothing there, so she said yes, that was it.  Somehow, my bag was left out.  There were several vehicles being loaded at the same time so the only thing we can guess is that my bag inadvertently got picked up by another of Bob's "guys" and put into another car...and then when those people said it wasn't theirs, was taken into the hotel lobby.  When I explained this to Aaron (at the front desk) on the phone that night, he told me that the valet service was not connected to the hotel and I needed to call their manager (Mr. Emerson I think he said) if I wanted my bag shipped back to me at their expense.  I asked to speak to a hotel manager and he said there was not one on duty.  I felt that since the hotel charged me for the valet service, that it was indeed an agent of the hotel and a service they provided.  Plus, the hotel had possession of my bag.  I called again at 8 am the next morning and was told by Sarah that there was no manager there, but that the staff had discussed my bag and that it was guests responsibility to keep track of their own bags.  I asked to have a manager call me and she assured me that would happen.  When I asked her how they normally handled these situations, she said that it had never happened before. (I find it hard to believe that nobody has ever left anything at the hotel before).  I waited over two hours and no manager called, so I called again. After being put on hold for over ten minutes...twice (I hung up each time after ten minutes and called again), I got Sarah again.  She told me that the manager was in a meeting and would call me when done.  I told her that I had contacted UPS to arrange for pick up and they required a weight for my bag and that it be placed in a shipping box.  She again told me that it is the guest's responsibility to keep track of their own bag.  She said that she wasn't sure what they would be able to do but she would have manager call me.  No manager ever called me.  Luckily, a co-worker of my husband who lives in Maryland agreed to drive over an hour to the hotel to pick up my bag for me and bring it the next time he comes to town for a meeting.  When I called the hotel to let them know, I was placed on hold again for over ten minutes. I hung up and called back and immediately said to please not put me on hold...that I just wanted to give them the name of the person who was going to pick up the bag.  She took the name and said she would put it on the bag.  Needless to say, this is the worst customer service I have ever experienced.  I still have never heard from a manager.  Do yourselves a favor...when you go to Baltimore do not stay at The Baltimore Harbor Hotel.We booked thru groupon looking at the nice pics ..First they said they had no booking in our name and then they gave us a card for the room with which the room wouldn't openWe went down to tell them, they got the card changed and gave it to us. We went back to the room and opened it only to find out it is occupied. Someone's Victoria secret bag n boots were lying there... They again gave us another room and this time it was a smoking room though it is supposed to be a non smoking facility. And yaaa... They charged us for parking.. Ridiculous!! Rooms arnt so great too.This was just a weekend getaway trip and a chance to see Orioles Park at Camden Yards. The Hotel was in a convenient location in regards to walking distance-- the Inner Harbor and The Baseball Stadium. A few restaurants around its locations (The Sushi restaurant around the corner was amazing). They only offered Valet Parking for a price otherwise there was pay for parking across the street for a price up to 24 hours. The Hotel itself was nice, very visually appealing but you can tell it's an older building as with most hotels. When you walk into the lobby, theres so much space. One downside would be the chandeliers, for a hotel this nice, the chandeliers are quite ugly (they were just round glass casing with bulbs in them). We got to the hotel at night and a couple was ahead of us on line, it seemed odd to me that it would take two people to check in one couple. Finally, after what seemed like forever, we checked in and it didn't take that long. We got to the room and couldn't find the switch, when we got the lights on we were able to look around the room, which wasn't as advertised. For the room itself I was disappointed, not so much in the room itself, which was nice with a huge (comfortable) King bed, typical TV channels, clean and all the comforts we needed for a weekend stay. We were more so disappointed that it was nothing like what the pictured showed when we booked it online (the size for one). We were expecting a LARGE Deluxe King and it was just a typical sized corner room with a king bed. Didn't matter too much as we weren't going to be staying there for an extended period of time but it's always better to get what you are expecting. The bathroom didn't have any amenities (razor, toothbrush, etc) as i've had in other hotels (just hand soap, shampoo, conditioner, body wash- all tiny size). The view was great. I loved having so many windows and being able to open all the blinds and have sunlight come in. We were on the 20th floor which I was excited about because I'm a fan of high floors. The hotel had a pool, which we didn't get a chance to use but the view of it from our room looked nice. The hotel offered complementary breakfast and that was GREAT. They had many options from cereal (6 types), muffins, waffles that you make yourself, coffee, tea, juice, bread, boiled eggs, etc. There was a wait staff always there restocking if they ran out of something. One specific thing that I appreciate from this hotel is having breakfast until 11am!!!!!! When you're on vacation, no one wants to wake up at 6am to catch breakfast before it stops at like 8/9am! Most hotels stop serving free breakfast early so I really really like this. At times it seem like there wasnt enough seating because everyone came to breakfast. There was a bar on the premises which is always an added bonus. Overall though this was a very pleasant experience with great proximity of where we wanted to spend our time in Baltimore and would stay again upon a return visit.nice clean rooms don't make up for the lack of decent parking and the rudeness of Aaron, our desk attendant. our room has a nice view of the buildings across the street and the people below which was pretty entertainingYuck and Yikes! The hotel should not contain "Harbor" in its name. It's too far from it. Priceline gave it 3 1/2 stars. Shame on you Priceline. Check in was slow but when finally greeted by Justin, it got a little better. As indicated, I used Priceline. I was given a room that was dated, small, smelled of old cigarettes and had a very loud hvac unit. The bathroom sink had dried up toothpaste on it and the toilet bowl was not clean. In fact, I saw spots that clearly reflected recently use. Basically, it was just dirty and does not warrant a property that Priceline should be reflecting as 3 1/2 stars. Even the elevator smelled of old cigarettes. I won't be using Priceline to book another last minute hotel in Baltimore.DonnellWell, where do I begin? Let's see ... The room was surprisingly small, considering it cost me $245 for the night. I've paid less for a suite. Believe me, this was no suite! The bathroom is ... well, small is an understatement. It's really tiny. There's no hotel restaurant here. You'll have to walk at least two or three blocks to find anything that remotely resembles a restaurant. There's a bar, but it doesn't open until 4 pm ... Wait a second... It's after 4 now, and the bar still ain't open... Okay, Tony the bartender finally got here and opened the joint!  Hey, we're here to see the Eagles concert! So, the hotel is the least of my concerns! Well, maybe not the least. As a matter of fact, all those other reviews that mentioned the lousy air conditioning -- they're true. This hotel has one of those penny-pinching energy-saving systems that keeps the a/c pretty much in a state of non-operating limbo unless it detects movement in the room. So, if you're going to spend the night here and you like your room to be cool, you'll have to wake yourself every 10 minutes or so and wave your arms around over your head so the a/c motion detector knows you're still alive and in the room. Otherwise, enjoy your warm surroundings. Oh yeah... I almost forgot; if you want a cold soda, you'll have to go down to the main lobby and walk next door to the bar to get it. Did I mention that the bar doesn't open until 4 pm?I am staying at the Baltimore Harbor Hotel to attend the Stevie Wonder Concert. The concert was spectacular however the hotel was subpar. Let's start with the valet parking cost 35.00 for guest however on their website it said free. The Queen size beds rooms are in a corner on and get this up to the six floor. My room was facing an office building and construction site. I guess 160.00 a night gets you this in Baltimore Inner Harbor. There is no direct line to the front desk noted on the rooms phones. When you call the telephone will ring for a very long time which by then you could have walked out of your room taken the elevator to the lobby and stood at the front desk and by then no one would have answered. I left my room at 7:15 placed the heat on 90 degrees and when I returned the room was still cold. So I go through the calling of the front desk process three times when what to my wondering ears there appears an answer. I explain that I had no heat and had left the heat on 90 for about 4 hours the response was I will send maintenance at first I said ok then I thought what for me to be attacked in my room. No thank you. There was no offer to move me to another room. The lamps need replacing some work and some the leather is peeling off. No restaurant and I was referred to another hotel Monoco for a sit down restaurant. Really? If you are in a pinch and don't have time to look for a more decent hotel then stay here however I will never stay here again.I had a great weekend the hotel staff was friendly the room was clean. I am not sure of the reason for all of these bad reviews. Complimentary breakfast free WiFi. Great bargain for the price. I only wish they had free parking. Location is great you can walk to everything.
review_content_40: This place is an excuse for a hotel. They will charge you full price for half the necessities. The first room we went to had a bed not made and clearly not cleaned up. The second one was VERY hot. After calling the electrician and waiting till 3am twice he told us that they did not have AC in the hotel and refused to help. The bathrooms are nasty and the room is cramped. There were drunk people downstairs causing chaos and people fighting in the room right next to us. I would definitely never recommend anyone to stay here. One of the worst experiences I've ever had at a hotel. DO NOT GO HERE.I just can't say enough good things about my stay at BHH, I booked on priceline. I checked the reviews of the hotel after it was booked and I was pretty worried about the quality of my lodging. Well the place is a little oldish. But I don't think of that as a bad thing. In the reviews there was all kinds of info about how cold and drafty the place is- well in February of 2015 at -2 outside, walking through weather that froze my eyebrows- I can report that my room on the 17th floor was so toasty!!! The heater pumped out the warm vibes and with the tiniest of prompting produced balmy almost too warm temps. The sheets and towels smelled good and were nice and soft. the comforters and ample pillows were like heaven after a long day of business at an annual trade show. i would be happy to stay here again. Oh and the wifi was free and FAST!!This hotel is so so. We got a good deal. The towels were old and nasty but you get what you pay for. The room was clean and the staff was friendly.  I would stay here again, only if, I was trying to save $, otherwise I would pay more for a better hotel.The only reason I didn't give it zero stars was because I liked my room. That has nothing to do with Baltimore Harbor though, because Sheraton built this building and sold it. Whoever bought this hotel clearly has very little experience with the hotel business. The customer service is HORRENDOUS here, there is shit everywhere. It looks pretty at first, but then you find all this random shit everywhere. The night staff couldn't care less about the guests and I've had multiple employees talk back to me. I would NEVER suggest anyone stay here. It'll be gone within a few years anyway. Should be an Omni.The room was hot and the thermostat will not set lower than 73.  Facilities are clean, but no water pressure.  Staff is friendly.  Could hear people in adjoining rooms all hours during the night. Jackhammer going outside all day long... Construction!  No coffee in the bar in the evening.   We will not be back!Loved the stay. Convenient to many parts of Baltimore. Safe. Quiet. While a few websites are still advertising much larger rooms that are no longer available, the rooms are still spacious. Housekeeping was always pleasant, on time, and efficient. The front desk staff are very pleasant at all times. The attached bar could be better. Some easy events to help entertain guests would be an excellent idea. It was always a ghost town which made it feel awkward to hang around. A vicious cycle I suppose. The breakfast is advertised as a 'Deluxe Breakfast' but I would have to disagree with that. Regular coffee with no flavored creamers. Waffles, boiled eggs, cereal, and some yogurt. That's not a deluxe breakfast in my opinion. Starbucks is two blocks away. AleWife is a local pub with excellent food and drinks. A few other local spots makeup for the hotels lack in food/drinks. Overall, excellent experience and I will be staying again

review_content: We stayed here on 6/21/14. It wasn't bad. The decor was dated and getting a bit shabby,  but the room was clean. The bed was extremely comfortable, the AC worked GREAT, and our room was enormous, as was the bathroom. There is very limited parking under the hotel (get there early if you want a spot) or there is reasonably priced parking across the street.The staff was friendly and polite. I can't speak for the free breakfast quality as we generally sleep too late and miss it most places. The area is decent and only about a mile from the harbor, very short cab ride away.This hotel wasn't anything fancy or particularly special, aside from the lobby, which is rather pretty,  but I'd certainly stay again for the value/price.You can't check in until shift change. Hilarious, and awful. The woman working today until 3pm just gazed past everyone in line until her relief came in.The room honestly isn't that bad. Sure, bed bugs might be lurking, but I can't see any yet!The lamp near my bed had no light bulb. Was somewhat hard to use without it.Our room had an ironing board, but no iron.There's three of us in the room and on the reservation, but only two sets of towels. We requested more, and when housekeeping cleaned the room the next day, they left us with only two sets again.No bible. But we did find a phone book from 2008.In one of the nightstands, we found a Disney character t-shirt with the tags still on!  Bonus!  There's a safe in the room and they're nice enough to charge you for using it, even if you don't!  We put the shirt in there for safe keeping.The breakfast is good for the price (free). The staff in the cafe are the only friendly people in the entire hotel. Especially the guy with the cool chef hat. On our second day here, someone discharged a fire extinguisher in the hall outside our room. The sprayed down two hallways. Powder everywhere. It took over 15 hours for the hotel crew to even take a vacuum to it. I'm sure that stuff is safe to breathe, so no biggie.If I could summarize the Mount Vernon Hotel in one sentence it would be, "Transitional housing unit masquerading as a "hotel." Sure, it's walking distance from the Harbor. Whoop-de-do, so are certain locations seen in The Wire.  This old YMCA is located near a soup kitchen and given the look and smell of some customers I think Family Services uses this hotel when it needs immediate shelter for clients.  My room was dark and old, with an outdated tube TV (didn't know those were still around), a nylon-like comforter, old light fixtures, sad little pillows ( see photo comparing its height to that of my IPad).  MOST importantly! when I found a BED BUG, the morning after my first night's stay, I was told by the very nice woman at the front desk that they had a "problem" but sprayed two weeks ago. NO NO NO!!!! That isn't how it works.  I checked out early and booked a room at the Hyatt.  I know this hotel might seem like a deal b/c you can get a room for $70 or less in the city, but it isn't worth the risk.  Someone else wrote "if you are not a snob and need a room" book this place.  I would disagree and say "if you don't mind a skin disease and need a room, book this place."  Seriously. Spend the extra $30 a night at stay at the Days Inn if you are on a budget.My husband and I went to a Ravens game for our one-year anniversary.  We picked Mt. Vernon because of its location, price, and the pictures online made the hotel look very charming and historic.  If we ever visit Baltimore again, we'll probably go to the Days Inn that is nearby.When we walked into our room, we noticed that our towels had fallen into the toilet.  No big deal, these things happen, and the desk clerk was quick to provide us with new towels.  Unfortunately, we didn't know at the time that our towel situation was going to get worse during our stay.  The hotel was very busy, and probably was fully booked for the weekend.  This hotel apparently does not have enough towels for each room.  We were given two towels, one for each of us.  When we requested a third towel, we were told they didn't have any more. We spent a day out in Baltimore and got caught in the rain-big time.  When we walked into the lobby (soaking wet) and asked if there were any towels available yet, the desk clerk said no.  We had a three-night stay and never had the opportunity to get any fresh towels.As we were on vacation, we slept in on most days and only got to enjoy a free breakfast once, as the cafe closes at nine o'clock.  The breakfast is served cafeteria-style and wasn't much to brag about, McDonald's makes a better breakfast, and they serve it until 10:30.  Apart from the towel situation, it still really wasn't much to brag about.It didn't feel super clean. Room was spacious. Internet worked.My second stay at the mount Vernon was horrible. The hotel smelt like mildew and bleach. One of the girls at the front desk lied to me when I was checking into the hotel and asked how much parking cost per night and she told me it was free. I end up paying almost $200 dollars in parking fees because of that girls stupidity. When I called to speak to the manager, he didn't believe my story and basically said I was a liar. The morning breakfast food is the quality of high school cafeteria food. Never staying here again.Hotel Vernon's website is deceiving, be careful of that. Yes, the rooms are cheap. Yes, the Hotel is only a stroll away from the Downtown area and a little farther from the Harbor. Yes, there is a free continental breakfast in the morning. Here's where the negatives are. Our room's AC was broken and it was pretty hot when we walked in there. Alas, it wasn't "I'm going to die" hot - but it was pretty uncomfortable. We had to kick off our pants and chill in our boxers, considering that you cannot open the windows. There was still trash in the bathroom garbage can too, but it just looked like paper. The bathroom and beds were clean for the most part, but in comparison to the pictures on the website it obviously did not live up to what they had made the hotel out to be. For a one night stay, I'd say not too shabby.Didn't even make it to the room. Had a late arrival and was scared for my life as I drove up to the hotel. Spend the extra money and get a hotel out of this area. Mount Vernon is in the hood.Good  Breakfast, rest  horrible.  Upon arriving, our room was hot and since  we can  not sleep in a hot room, we cranked up the air conditioning and walked down to the port.  When we came back the room was still hot and I called down to the desk who informed me that turning on the air conditioning would make the room hotter and that they had no fans.There was no toilet paper in our room but luckily we found some in the maids closet which we discovered from our room map (it was supposed to be the ice room)Our tv was  mostly snow and no remote.  Got another remote from the desk and it did not work.Breakfast was better than avge thoughMy parents have stayed here a few times while visiting my sister in Baltimore and I joined them this past visit. Hotel is decently priced and not expensive, have a buffet continental breakfast and is close to the inner harbor.On the down side, the Internet is spotty, sometimes you can pick it up, other times you can't. It can get loud, even 6 floors up, with street noise, and our room smelled musty. Our bathroom in general could have used some work to. It's a hotel and does the jobParking under the hotel in the garage is horrible. It's so tight to get anything down there and you can see where people have hit the corners. I'd opt for the parking aross the streetWe booked the hotel through Priceline. We had an emergency so had to cancel our trip last minute tonight. I called the hotel and was expecting that they would not give us a refund, but the lady "Betsy" was so sweet and understanding, really going above and beyond. She assured us it was going to be no problem and said they would be happy to cancel the reservation, just call priceline. :)Very painless. First class customer service!!ABSOLUTELY HORRIBLE !!!! Do not stay !!!! We found a bug I'm our room !!! Pretty sure they have people living In the hotel !!! Front desk is horrible management is no where to be seen. They told myself and the people I'm staying with that they have no towels for us and one desk clerk went on to bitch about his coworkers that they did nothing for him during the day shift didn't even fold anything for him (FYI not my problem ) in other words do not ever stay here you will regret it !!!Where to start.. An absolute nightmare. I usually don't write reviews, nor do I lie or write things online if they aren't true. This was a complete mess. I drove from VA to go to an orioles game and wanted tins to be a nice night, but the only nice thing was the game. We arrived and it was 90 degrees in our room. Turning it on only made it blow hot air. We ran into a couple in the elevator who was sweating from having no AC. We called to complain about it and they said there is nothing they could do because they don't have air this time of year. Would have been nice to know that. That's not all! We walked in to stains on our blankets, sheets, and all. Right out in the open for God and everyone to see. We asked twice for new linens and they Never arrived. When calling the front desk they say that THEY don't have linens but house keeping might and they will TRY to find them. Nice service huh?  Well aside from burning up and not being able to sleep in our bed, we figure a cold shower may help so we come to find out there is no complementary soap or shampoo in the shower. We once again call and the front desk says THEY don't have any at the front desk and they believe they are all out!!! What!!!? Did someone forget to go to the dollar store before running a hotel in downtown Baltimore!? We asked for them to comp us since by the time we got back from the game it was midnight, and we walked into a sauna of a room with no sheets or shampoo and they said if they helped us with the price, we would have to leave.. That there is nothing they can do. So for 100 dollars, I sweat, slept on extra clothes that I laid down on the bed, and took a soapless, shampooless shower, and am now about to pull out of my bike sized parking spot.. PLEASE listen to me when I say don't stay here. Pay the extra 10-20 bucks to stay somewhere with clean air conditioned rooms with some kind of service!!!A really outdated hotel with very little amenities. Exterior is blah, interior is straight from the 50's movies, room is fairly clean, no gym, no parking, staff are ok, ice machine is only only the 2nd floor. Stayed here for 3 nights, wished I stayed somewhere else.I really want to give it 2.5 stars.  Its not the greatest, but its probably the best you can get for the price in downtown Baltimore.The bad:  The pics from the website are a bit deceiving, its a lot more dilapidated than the pics show.  A lot of stuff is quite visibly worn and looks a little bit dirty.  Slightly smelly room (expected for cheep downtown hotel). Free breakfast was supposed to be at 6:30.  I left at 7:10 and it still hadn't been set out, but at least there was coffee.  The good:  Of course location, the staff was very helpful and deodorized the room (not quite so successful, but I appreciated the effort.Would I stay there again - probablyStayed here for one night recently and had an afwul experience. Quickly to cover the good: affordable prices, location is near the inner harbor, free breakfast. Now for the bad- there is no parking available so you must pay for your own parking. The rooms are some of the dirtiest rooms I have ever stayed in. There were bugs in the coffee cups left in the rooms and the beds smelled awful. Honestly if these were the only things wrong with it I would only have been a little upset but that was just the beginning. I bought my ticket using hotwire but they told me they needed to run my credit card just as a confirmation and that no charges would be added. I checked my bank account after check out and saw they had charged me 90 dollars. I called the hotel and after being told to call hotwire even though i explained the 90 dollar charge had nothing to do with them I was told I could not be helped because she did not know how to pull up my account. She told me to call back the next day because that was when the manager was on duty. I called back 4 seperate times the next day leaving voicemails everytime with no response from the manager. I still have not gotten my money back from these charges and had a pretty awful stay. I would not recomend this place to anyoneI stayed here for one night, a Friday.  We arrived at the hotel around 8pm and had no wait to check-in, they even had our keys ready.  There was a huge coach (52 passenger) bus parked in the hotel lading zone when we arrived, and it stayed there overnight, so there was no where to park while you checked in.  Luckily I was travelling with another person who could wait in the car with the flashers on, otherwise I would have had to find street parking just to check-in.  Our room was on the 2nd floor, but I was pleasantly surprised at the lack of street noise.  It was very quiet. The room was quite spacious, plenty of space around both queen beds (I hate it when you get a 2-bed room and you have to squeeze between the beds b/c they are jammed so close in a tiny room!).  They could have even fit in a little loveseat & coffee table with the open space in the room.While the furniture and carpet was a bit dated and slightly worn, everything was clean.  The wallpaper in the bathroom had a few spots where it was peeling, but the tub and toilet looked to be pretty new, and the sink had a nice granite counter-top.  The free breakfast was very extensive.  On the Saturday morning we were there, they offered scrambled eggs, bacon, home fries, and biscuits & gravy.  They also had a selection of bread and bagels you could toast yourself.  Yogurt and fresh fruit were also available, though we missed out on the fruit as all but one piece had been taken by the time we got down there at 9:30am (breakfast is served from 7am- 10am). Coffee and juices were on offer too. I did try to park in the garage, but after parking and coming up to pay at the front desk, was told the garage was sold out and I would have to move my car. That was annoying. The garage is a tight squeeze, but easily manageable if you know how to maneuver your vehicle and don't drive an enormous SUV.This is not a top of the line hotel, but it is affordable and clean.  As for the quality of the neighborhood, it's Baltimore, so just keep in mind that's the type of city you're in and be smart about it. I felt perfectly safe inside the hotel, but wouldn't go wandering the streets at midnight.Very nice hotel.  The rooms were clean, the staff friendly.  Breakfast is good.  They have an underground parking lot, but if you're driving a full size suv or larger, it's tight.Neighborhood is pretty good too.  We wound up staying there a second time we went to Baltimore.Not the fanciest hotel, but well worth the price.If you're looking for a place to crash for a night, it's not that bad. The room was clean - there was some washed-in stains on the sheets but as the saying goes, you get what you pay for. Park in the 15 West Franklin Street garage - $4 for 24-hour parking on weekends and located right across the street.The website will lead you to believe you'll be staying in luxury but I assure you this won't be the case. The price is decent for Baltimore. It's a bit further from the harbor than I'd like and it's a pretty hilly walk but it's an okay choice. The free breakfast was run of the mill. The egg's were slimy though. I couldn't even finish them. The AC/heater only blew out hot air, so luckily it wasn't a super hot weekend, being that it was early April. There was also garbage in the bathroom's garbage can, which is gross. When you're paying a low price relative to the area, your expectations should be relatively lowered as well. With that in mind, this place is alright for a night or two.
review_content_20: For the price - less than $70 per night - how could you possibly beat the Mount Vernon Hotel? The location allows you to enjoy all the best of what Baltimore has to offer - venture south for the harbor, take a stroll in the neighborhood for some intimate restaurants and an art museum, or drive a little further north for Hampden. The room decor leaves something to be desired, but no chain hotel in the Inner Harbor is going to offer you groundbreaking interior design. If it's clean, who cares? You can return home to your feng shui in just a few short days. The hotel has an underground parking garage with an elevator that will take you directly to your room, and you get free breakfast vouchers to use during your stay. When we arrived for breakfast before 11AM on a Sunday  morning, we may have seen spaghetti and meatballs, but that didn't stop us from stealing a cup full of Raisin Bran for our ride home.In short: if you're not a snob, and you need a place to stay, book a room here.PROS: Cheap price for the location ($60/night in downtown Baltimore), front desk staff was attentive and helpful, within walking distance of lots of little shops and boutiques.  Not a bad view from the clean room, either.CONS: Bed was uncomfortable... extremely firm, but not in a good way like in the commerical where they have a wine glass on the bed and are jumping on it yet it doesn't spill.  Staff didn't mention the air conditioning was broken, but they brought us a fan after we called to ask why the AC didn't seem to be cooling the room at all. It was noisy so we turned the fan off.  Oh well.P.S. I would recommend Maisy's restaurant a few streets over, which we discovered browsing aroundThis is a case of you get exactly what you pay for. Clean hotel in a good location, but bare bones. Parking is $15 extra, and the lot is the smallest, worst designed underground lot I have seen! I ended up scratching my brand new car trying to gingerly come around the corner. Breakfast is until 10 am, and if you do what I did and sleep till 9:55 by accident you can't even get coffee. What is so hard about having coffee available? The bed was fine, but the pillows were....flat doesn't really describe it fully. Like a pancake. You get exactly what you pay for here...is it worth it? I don't think so.You know how you see an older person who dresses well and looks good even at their advanced age? Well that's kinda how I felt about this place. Nice enough place that is still holding it all together after all these years.Located in downtown Baltimore, a decent walk from the Inner Harbor is this hotel. A former YMCA it looks quite distinguished from the outside (and from it's website and brochures). Going in though you see that it has seen better days. Things look older or worn down. The feel is like of a place that was once greater than it is now. That's OK because for the very reasonable price, it's not bad when you think about it. I stayed overnight for a conference and settled into the room before going to the events. My room was sizable with an indirect path into the spacious bedroom space. The furniture looked colonial and a bit dated. Like something your grandparents might have in their home. There was one window, a king-sized bed that was comfortable enough, a desk with side drawers from which you could write from, a TV cabinet that was probably used for clothes at one time with a basic TV with basic cable. Two nightstands held classical-looking lamps. The alarm clock was like a travel clock but was plugged in with the accurate time listed. The carpet felt worn with no padding but wasnt an issue. The bathroom door was small but the bathroom had a nice countertop, ornate mirror and a suitable shower that produced a nice flow of hot water. The control to the shower had "Pull" written on it and there was a well-worn drain stopper chained on the side. Despite the unusual look, it was adequate for me ( A woman might feel differently). The place offers a nice enough breakfast with eggs, bacon, hash browns and grits as well as chilled cranberry and orange juice. I didnt have the cereal or french toast but everything was modestly provided by the very sweet chef ( you should tip her). I saw a few Europeans who no doubt probably felt this place was more like it appears in it's lietrature and online. It is a bit deceiving. The place has a piano in the lounge and underground parking. The surrounding area is urban, reflecting what Baltimore once was and how this part of town has been gentrified. Kinda reminded me of Boston, Mass. Overall though, I liked the place. The price was right. I noticed from the outside that my room had windows that were effectively built over. The sheets and some of the towels were on the thin-side (Some discount, high thread-count sheets are in order) but I was downtown and felt relaxed in the space. For what I was paying for, it was alright with me. I would go back if I was looking for a decent place to stay without wanting to pay a whole lot for it all.Check in at the hotel begins at 3pm.  So when we arrived at 320pm to check-in, I was disappointed to see that my room was not yet ready.  I was not the only one that had this problem.  Approximately 2 dozen people had to wait as their rooms were cleaned and ready for them to check in.  The hotel manager was nowhere to be found when we asked to speak with him/her.  The reason for the manager being unavailable was that they were busy cleaning rooms to get everyone checked in.  The scene in the lobby was a mess.  It didn't help that the lobby had no air conditioning.  We did not get into our room until approximately 5pm.  Furthermore, only one of the two elevators were working.  Once we got into our room, our telephone didn't work.  The only reason this place gets two stars from me was that the rooms were clean, and the hotel was reasonably priced compared to other hotels close to the harbor.  The parking garage is across the street, and it charges $4/day during the weekends.I travel to Baltimore often and to be honest, I'd rather pay money for a hotel then drive back to Virginia drunk than not drink.Anyway, I first stayed here after purchasing a LivingSocial deal. Ironically enough, to pay full price on the govt rate is the same as the LS price except you only get parking if you have the LivingSocial voucher which sucks. I guess normally they have parking here that's included but until the deal expires, you're shit out of luck and have to park across the street and pay $10/night weekdays and $4/night weekends. It's definitely not so much a cost thing but more of a "fuck, we're in Baltimore lets not get out car stolen" type of thing.In regards to the hotel, it's ok. It's old (or as they say "historic") so don't expect to walk into a glamorous place. For the most part the hotel is well maintained but the rooms are pretty gross. We did a complete bed bug inspection and while it passed, we did find stray hairs and random cracker crumbs under the mattress. Take from that what you will. Aside from sleeping and monkey business, we spend more time outside the hotel enjoying Baltimore stuff. What really won us over to come back was the price and location. While you are not walking distance (unless you really wanna WALK) to the inner harbor, you are a $5 can ride away. Literally, $5 for two people. There is also a few nice places within walking distance (nice Spanish place).  WiFi is included. Staff generally nice. No fridge but they will send one up if you ask.GOOD: Decent rooms (stayed in a queen double), nice staff, cheap. you don't necessarily need a car since it's very close to bus lines (including the free Charm City Circulator), walking distance from a variety of restaurants + bars on Charles Street, more of a haul but still easily doable to walk to the Inner Harbor, and I saw some Zipcar spaces in the neighborhood.OKAY: I eat mostly vegetarian and I can't have eggs, so the free breakfast was more like a free bagel - though they may have had more variety if I had went to breakfast earlier. Some other people have said it's in a bad area or whatever - I (a twenty-something suburban girl) would not wander around by myself at night but I felt fine with another twenty-something suburban girl. Wi-fi was a little spotty for a day but I think they put in a new network while I was there (some rooms can probably pick up a good signal from the Enoch Pratt Library).BAD: Housekeeping could have been better. The room wasn't dirty, per se, but under the bed etc hadn't been swept in awhile.My boyfriend and I stayed there for two nights because we were at a wedding and the entire wedding party was staying there with the exception of bride and groom. it was probably one of the worst experiences ever. I got $60 stolen out of my wallet when the cleaning lady was there. the room is dirty and just moldy. our friends room had hand prints everywhere on the bed frame. it was disgusting. the bath tub still had hair and stain in in. Not sure how people still stayed in this hotel. oh and the hotel never resolved the issue of the thief that stole my moneyThe hotel was decent. It's not the best but it is clean. Like I told my cousin who accompanied me on my trip, " it has character".  Pros:  Located in a decent area, we walked A few blocks during the day when we got here to see the area. Free breakfast (may not be the best but it's free).Cheapest hotel around the area.Maids/cleaners folded my blanket and pillow on the bed. (sweet gesture seeing as other places I have stayed they have just left it waded up.Cons: 15$ a night parking in the garage under the building which was very oddly set up (park across the street for 4$ a night unless you plan on leaving a lot) Kinda werid smell in the hall and when you first walk in. Request not to be near the elevator! We are tucked back in a corner but the elevator makes buzzing noises as it goes up and down to each floor. It would be annoying with a room right across from it.I stayed here for three nights last week, and I feel like this place is being slagged a little. Then again, I'm not someone who gets bothered by mismatched carpet or elevator problems (that's why there's the stairs, in my opinion). Here's my take:GOOD:- As affordable as the area gets.- Very close to Charm City Circulator- in the middle of a great neighborhood, Mount Vernon. I loved hearing the bells at the top of the hour from the nearby Basilica, and one of my prime destinations (the Walters Art Museum) was less than a 5-minute walk. I wasn't out after 9pm but comments that this neighborhood was unsafe don't make much sense to me.- breakfast was better than I expected. Hot line varied daily, with French toast, pancakes, various meats, scrambled eggs, and potatoes seen. Aside from that, a couple of cereals (corn flakes and...something else), yogurt, and a variety of bagel types (and they weren't the cheap packaged bagels).- of the 4 hotels I tried to take an actual bath in on our road trip, this was the only one that had an actual stopper.- no problems with wifi- cheap, convenient parking deck across the street ($10 per 24 hrs), though I arrived at 8pm Saturday evening and took advantage of unregulated meter parking outside the hotel until moving on Sunday night.- the city had a water main break during our stay, and even though the hotel was not at fault they comped my night's stay and offered free bottled waterUNGOOD:- you can hear what's going on in the next room at times. Couldn't tell how elevated the volume had to get to bleed through, but we heard our neighbors in the evening enough to comprehend some of their conversation.- would have been nice to have a fridge- yes, the elevators were acting up for most of our stay in one way or another, but one was usually working and the stairs were fine for anything otherwise In any case the pros far outweigh the con. A great base for seeing a great city!This hotel is good if you're not planning on spending too much time in your room and you don't want to pay that much money. The rooms aren't anything to brag about but what is good is their free breakfast is pretty on point. Another plus about this place is their location, it's walkable to the inner habor and it's also about a block away from the free shuttle stop. I'll probably only come back here for the free breakast--everything else is sub par.Ok- this isn't hotel Monaco or the ritz but its super cheap. I have stayed here twice and will again for the price and location. The furnishings are old and everything is dated but it's fine for a place to crash when visiting Baltimore. I've had only positive experience with the staff. The free breakfast is excellent. Grits, eggs, biscuits and gravy, potatoes, fruit, yogurt. It's a definite perk. Affordable parking across the street.The hotel was pretty nice, affordable and basic, no frills. The full service breakfast was also really impressive (eggs, bacon, potatoes, biscuits, juices, coffee, etc.). This definitely helped since everything else in Baltimore is so expensive. There is a $15/day charge for parking in their "hidden" garage. We drove around the block a few times before we finally found it. You have to physically get out of the car to open the garage door (with your room key). We chose this hotel because it was "just blocks from the Harbor". Well, it's about 10 blocks away, which isn't awful for walking, but the neighborhood is super sketchy, and didn't seem that safe. After a couple of days, we ended up driving over to the Harbor instead, but then couldn't find parking for under $20. No knock to this hotel, because it was overall pretty descent, but in the future, I would spend the extra money to stay closer to the Harbor.I lived in the Mount Vernon Hotel for 5 weeks while teaching at Baltimore International College.  The experience was just like being at home.The prospect of living in a hotel for 5 weeks was not exciting to me, but this place has a very homey feel and the staff is outstanding.  At the front desk, Andy and Ben were always accommodating, regardless of the request.  The room I had was like many of the historic Bed and Breakfast Inns I've stayed in.  It was a loft with huge living room area and upstairs bedroom.  The 20 foot antique windows looked out over the street and gave me a sense of being right in the middle of it all.  Something the Holiday Inn can never duplicate.If your expectations are a sterile, brand new Marriott-type hotel, this is not the place to come.  However, if you like interesting architecture, unique rooms in an historic atmosphere, just like an excellent B&B experience, you should stay here.The rates are considerably less than Inner Harbor locations and I feel you get A LOT more for the money.  Plus, the location is absolutely perfect if you want a Baltimore experience other than the strictly tourist areas.The hotel is within 5 minutes walk of just about every theater, museum and restaurant you could ever want, and a 1/2 block off the central Charles Street Corridor, including the Washington Monument.If you really need the Inner Harbor tourist spots, it's just a 10 minute walk down Charles Street.  Another 10 minutes walk and you're in Federal Hill or Little Italy.They have on-site parking which is incredibly convenient in a city with crowded parking problems.For the reviewers that say it's near a "ghetto" (using that word shows the paranoia), it's not true.  The hotel is in the middle of a busy city where people may not look like you do.  I think that's the beauty of it.  I needed no "burly man" to walk around any time of day or night.  If you're scared by an urban environment, the neighborhood is not your problem, you should visit Kansas or something instead.I was introduced to the Mount Vernon area by this hotel and was so impressed that I wound up relocating within a few blocks.  Too bad I'll be living near by, because I'd love to stay here again.  I'll be sure to send all my friends and relatives that come to visit Baltimore.Thank you Mount Vernon Hotel and Staff for a fantastic re-introduction to Baltimore.Thought the location was pretty decent, especially for the price we paid for a room. It also has very cheap parking in a garage across the street. Room was clean. Walls are a bit thin but not too bad. Complimentary breakfast which was just okay -- had fruit, yogurt, oatmeal, unappetizing eggs and sausage though... I agree that the reviews which state it's near the "ghetto" are not true and I'm assuming these reviewers have never even lived or stayed near an area that would be considered a ghetto... Overall if you are looking for a decent place to spend a night in Baltimore, don't count out Mount Vernon Hotel. Pretty good bang for your buck.This place is a total dive. The one thing it has going for it is the price, and you certainly get what you pay for. For the sake of expediency, I'll just list my complaints:It was dirty, the room smelled dingy, was missing shampoo, a do not disturb tag and a light bulb, the internet was functionally useless, the "business room" was the size of a closet, the air conditioning was poor, and there was neither vending nor ice machine on our floor.Wtf man.  For a hotel downtown I was disappointed.  I just finished running the Baltimore marathon at 12pm. Finished four beers at the beer garden and all I could think about was taking a nice shower and taking a nap on a nice bed. So I BS'ed around until 3pm.  But NO...........  I get here and my room is not ready for the 3pm check in.  So I wait an hour to check in because non of the king rooms are ready.  Im tired and need a shower while I'm sitting here watching other people check in to their queen and double rooms.  So I finally get my room an hour later and I admit the room was decent.  The sheets on the bed sucked though. Kinda harsh.   Im sorry, all hotels should be prepared for check in or at least offer another comparable room.Great place to stay if you like roaches and bad smells...would have been better off sleeping in the car.WARNING: An outsider targets guests by pretending to be hotel staff.  The front desk transferred a guy to my room at 1:30 am and he pretended to be from the front desk.  He said there was a freakish meltdown with the hotel computer system and that they needed to manually enter guest information.  He said it was an issue that needed to be dealt with immediately because of hotel liability and guests that could slip by without paying (because all of their information was gone).  He told me I could come downstairs or give him my info over the phone.  The worst part about  this is that when I told staff and management, no one so much as apologized.  Moreover, they didn't appear to document it or take the issue seriously at all.  They did not appear to be concerned in the slightest that outside individuals are targeting their guests for credit card fraud.Other problems I had with the hotel:room smells bad and bedding appears to be from the 80s.  I didn't complain about this or change hotels.  I adjusted by buying and spraying a lot of febreeze and purchasing pillows.  housekeeping was sub par.  There was a tampon wrapper floating in the toilet when I arrived and no conditioner stocked with the toiletries.  I left a note for housekeeping to leave it the next day.  They wrote on the note that they would bring it back.  They never did.  I found out at check out that the hotel doesn't even carry conditioner.wake up call didn't happen.  I asked the front desk for a wake up call and I watched her write my request on what I can only assume was the wake up call sheet.  That wake up call never occurred (PS I was staying there because I was taking the Maryland bar.  Punctuality was very important.  So was uninterrupted sleep.)manager response.  I received no apology, condolences, or anything positive at all, despite the fact that I was calmly explaining my situation and not even demanding anything at that point.  The manager's response was his hotel is always booked, he doesn't receive complaints from guests, and his staff are exceptional.  So, his response was more of a rebuttal to my complaint than anything.I stayed here for a trip to a conference at the Baltimore Convention Center.  It didn't look too far away on MapQuest.  In reality, it's right on the cusp of the decent Inner Harbor area and the somewhat frightening ghetto.Walking to the Inner Harbor took about 15 minutes and was fine during the day time.  The streets were also easy to navigate.  It's right across the street from a big, beautiful library.  However, I wouldn't suggest walking at night unless you are in a big group or have a big burly man with you (or I suppose if you are a big burly man yourself).The rooms in the hotel were not great-- they were decent.  The air was stale and the elevators were borderline creepy.  Nowhere on their website or in any reviews did anyone mention the fact that the hotel houses college-age dormitories on their top floors, so there are often young people in their pajamas hanging out in the lobby area.The reception desk people were very friendly and helpful.  They offer free breakfast for every morning that you are there and the architecture in the area is very nice.All in all, the hotel was a nice experience and you get what you pay for (it's relatively cheap), but if I would have known how close to the ghetto it was, I would have looked for something closer to the Inner Harbor, even at a higher price.
review_content_40: If your looking for fancy, look somewhere else..if your looking for a hotel with a bed, bathroom and electric than this is your place. Our room was alittle dirty when we checked in, garbage behind the nightstands and the garbage pail still had garbage in it. If you stay here, bring your own pillow cause the ones supplied were absolutely horrible. Decent breakfast considering, parking was a parking lot across the street which was very cheap and convenient($8 for the weekend). 10 minute walk to the inner harbor, which is fine during the day, sketchy at night, take a cab but be careful of cabbies trying to get one over on tourists, shouldn't cost more than $5. Staff was friendly.I got a good groupon deal for this spot so it was great price. Im pretty sure there are better hotels around this one but i have to admit that i like the location a lot. as for the stay, things like newer tv with better programming, newer heating, and some newer furniture would bump this stay up to four star in no time. Its an old hotel in a very busy area so i can see why its still there. Me and my girl liked the stay so given another shot with a good deal id go again.Pros:Clean, hot breakfast included, close proximity to inner harbor, easy check in and check out, accommodatingCons:Staff is not that knowledgeable about tourist information.Based on the mediocre reviews, I was nervous to give this hotel a try. But I had a definite budget and was only going to Baltimore to take the LSAT, so I thought I'd risk it. However, the hotel was a completely pleasant surprise. This has got to be the best value hotel near the harbor. The rate is extremely low on the weekend ($60 when I booked through Priceline) and it's in a nice location near the harbor and a couple museums. There are also a number of restaurants fairly nearby, as well as places that will deliver to the hotel. The service is also extremely helpful and accommodating. Throw in the free breakfast (which is not bad) and this is honestly the best deal in Baltimore - I know, I researched A LOT. The parking garage was probably the only aspect that needed improvement (my boyfriend literally did an 11-point turn to get out of our spot in the morning), but that's my only complaint. It was definitely very secure. While I wasn't impressed by Baltimore as a city, I was extremely impressed by this hotel.I went to Baltimore in May and needed a hotel for one night.  The cheapest hotel looked like it might not be too clean.  This was the second-cheapest hotel I could find, and it was a great deal for the price.The room was basically clean. There were little things I wish they'd change, but they weren't too distracting overall. For example, some of the furniture was nicked and showed slight signs of wear, they hadn't swept behind the nightstand in quite a while, there was no luggage rack to put my luggage on, the TV had some basic cable channels but didn't have the ABC,CBS, NBC or Fox networks, and the coffee maker was on the counter in the bathroom because there was no counter space in the sleeping area. But none of those things really bothered me, so I don't count them as negatives.On the plus side, the king-size bed was huge and comfortable, the shower was clean and had great water pressure, and the complimentary breakfast buffet was very impressive (if you have no dietary restrictions).  French toast, sausages, scrambled eggs, hash browns, instant oatmeal, yogurt, very fresh apples and oranges, and lots of cereal. I had eggs and potatoes, which were fresh and hot. The french toast and the sausages also looked really good if you like those items. Unfortunately, I didn't notice any juice. All they had to drink was coffee, Lipton tea, and sugary fountain drinks.The dining room is large and the decor overall is lovely. It's a converted old building and they've retained all the charm and architecture. Even the pictures in the rooms are interesting. It was centrally located and I could walk where I needed to go.This isn't a 4-star hotel, but for the price, it's perfectly serviceable in a convenient location and well worth the cost.As another reviewer said, Mount Vernon Hotel offers great value for the money.   The pros: Rooms are clean and large.  Parking is a relative value at $15/night.  Staff is extremely helpful and friendly.The cons: Dated decor, both in the rooms and the lobby.  The parking garage is SUPER tight--good thing I have a compact sedan!  Not necessarily the BEST neighborhood, particularly at night.I stayed overnight at the Mt. Vernon, and everything was clean and serviceable. The place could use some updating and there were some quirks (every door seemed to have a different trick to open it - lift this handle up, turn that one a little to the left), but all in all, this was a fine, inexpensive place to lay our heads. I appreciated the laid-back, friendly staff. If you get a chance, ask for Room 102, which is bigger than my apartment and has a loft!Great value for the money. Cheap, but still in a nice neighborhood and within an easy mile walk of the Inner Harbor. The staff was pleasant and efficient. Our room was much nicer than I expected it to be given the dated appearance of the exterior and public areas of the hotel. Our room was very clean, with nice furniture and a good view of the surrounding neighborhood. Our cable was a little weird--we only got some random channels--but I don't go to other cities to watch TV so I didn't really care.I read a lot of reviews before staying in this hotel and most were right. It is clean and comfortable but its decor is outdated. There were no bed bugs, thank God! I really appreciate good customer service so this 2 1/2 -3 star hotel gets an additional star because they were extremely friendly and helpful when we needed it. They also upgraded us to king sized beds which was great and we really appreciated it. Its location is okay. Mount Vernon is not exactly an exciting place to stay but Inner Harbor is pretty close, about a 15-20 minute walk away.The negatives about this hotel -some hotel guests seem to think it's okay to go to the complimentary breakfast in their pajamas. I wish the hotel would have mandated that guests be dressed when they come down to the lobby and cafeteria- the breakfast was edible but nothing I would go to a restaurant and pay for -there were some people loitering in front of the hotel when we got back on Sunday night. They didn't look like hotel guests so that took away from the hotel's image

hotel_name: Pier 5, an Ascend Hotel Collection Member
review_content: We loved this place. We came for my birthday weekend. The staff were super friendly and professional. They remembered our names. On Saturday, they host the "Chocolate Event" and it was wonderful. We also had the National Aquarium package.It was an amazing weekend and highly recommend you stay here. In the famous words of Arnold, "We'll be back".Call them. Ask for a room and work with the front desk. I tried Expedia, Priceline, and hotels.com and just kept getting higher prices for rooms. Calling them directly, I was greeted with friendly service - but ontop of that... they saved me money for the room!Now I will say, the view was "A-OK"... hence the 3 star rating. There were more expensive rooms with the patio.... though those were booked, so I asked for the next best thing - and it wasn't a bad view but it wasn't breath taking either. Overall, I had a fine stay here although the annoying thing as check-out was at 12pm the next morning... room service came at 9am in the morning knocking on our door, asking us when we were going to leave.... that to me was a little rude. Other than that, everyone else was ridiculously friendly and the place was overall clean. Does feel about 6-7 years old though (building/materials).We loved this place. I booked it the first time via Groupon but will absolutely book again with or without! I must say, however, that the $40.00 a day for valet parking threw me for a loop but I was informed that the parking lots are privately owned by the city. You'd think that a resort this big would have it's own lot.So ok, $40.00 parking aside, we checked in. I was under the impression that I'd purchased the package with breakfast and a bottle of wine included. Well, I didn't. No problem said Brett at the desk. He appeared with a cold bottle of chardonnay and 2 tickets for a beautiful breakfast buffet that is served in the lobby every morning. Nice. And about the lobby, lets not forget about "Crabby Hour". Every night is a different theme with the chef teaching how to make everything crab. So just so you understand, everything crab and matched cocktails, free and just part of the awesomeness that is Pier 5.I would be remiss not to mention that adjoined to the hotel on either side is a Ruth's Chris that has spoiled me for oysters and carpaccio forever more, and a McCormick and Schmik's.If you go, remember that you have to request a refrigerator for your room. Enjoy!Just returned from my second stay at Pier V Hotel in the inner harbor in Baltimore. First time was a couple trip and I loved that I was allowed to bring my Lab and how nice they were to him. This second time was a work trip and I had convinced my boss and colleagues to stay here rather than at the Hyatt where our convention was. Brett made it an extremely fun stay with all of his happy hour activities- wine and crepe night. We missed whiskey Wednesday and paint night. The hotel staff was wonderful especially Brett., who made us laugh and joked with us making it memorable. Could not recommend higher. Location is convenient and a more unique corner of the harbor, lovely balconies, convenient to little italy, Ruth Chris, McCormack and Schmidt, national aquarium, etc. this was a much nicer experience than we would have had in a bigger chain. tripadvisor.com/ShowUser...Dated, Dirty, and Disappointing....the only saving grace is that it's located on the water. They need to do a soft goods (furniture, curtains, and carpet) renovation at the very least to bring it up to par with the other hotels in the area.Stayed there with my gf this past week. It is on the Inner Harbor, with the aquarium a 5 min walk. They are *very* dog friendly, with no restrictions on dog size, type, etc. - no pet deposit either, and, your dog can stay in the room by itself. Also, every day during the week they have a different "crabby hour" which they call happy hour. Tuesday is sushi, wine, and beer - all free.The hotel was very clean - the room was very spacious and modern.Only downside is that it's $40/day to valet park and the wifi wasn't working very well (it was included in a mandatory hotel fee).This place continues to go down hill... stayed here for business on 11/17 and the experience was pretty bad. Rooms are very dated, dirty, and falling apart. Water stains, peeling wallpaper, NASTY bathroom!! I wish I had taken some pictures to post. They even charged an additional 9.95/day for "Guest Services" which was not explained to me when I checked in. When I questioned the charge on checkout I was told "you initialed to accept this charge sir" when I challenged the woman she basically gave me the oh well response... can sum it up in a single word, DUMP!!I really like this hotel for it's funky cool design and location. Second time I've stayed here. The rooms are spacious and well appointed for a very comfortable stay. The staff is very friendly and helpful as well. Pier 5 feels more like a boutique hotel, not like the big chain hotels. They have "Crabby Hour" M-F featuring a chef who teaches you how to make fabulous crab dip. Then you get to enjoy it with drinks. I recommend requesting a harbor view room to enjoy the beauty of the Inner Harbor. Located just steps away from restaurants and everything the Inner Harbor offers, the location can't be beat. Compared to the price of other waterfront, and not waterfront, hotels in the area, Pier 5 is priced significantly below similar hotels. They offer valet parking for $38 or you can park in the public lot next door for $22 a day, so parking is easy.I'm looking forward to my next stay here.Ritz Carlton and Four Season level service! Best stay for New Years! Checkin with Donita was outstanding. Front desk provided coupons for free and reduced prices for places having celebrations within walking distance of the hotel. Complimentary champagne, noise blower, hat, happy hour with crepes and fantastic crab dip. What more could you want? Chris made the best omelets I have ever had at the fantastic buffet bar. Chris has a phenomenal personality that starts your day. Loved the lobby. Price was reasonable and you are right on the water. Ruth Chris is also in the building so I did not have to go outside. Love the tree in the lobby. Walking distance to great shopping, convenience stores. Loved this place. I will return.I'm hard pressed to understand why some give this hotel poor marks. I was here for two days for a staff meeting and everything was great. The meeting room for 24 was adequate and the food was terrific. My guest room in the second floor was nice. No complaints. The lobby area was welcoming and a group of us watched a presidential debate over a few bottles of wine. I will definitely stay here again. Location was the best. Next to the aquarium and three block walk to little Italy where we went for dinner.This is one of those places that was the coolest thing in the world when I discovered it but now it's just meh. The primary reason is the decor. When I first stayed here it was 2000 and the decor looked incredibly hip and contemporary. 15 years later, it looks like it was furnished by Ikea. In 2000. The staff is nice enough but not really engaged so you just kinda feel like you're on your own. And the cavernous lobby adds to that feeling. I'll go back because the location is great and the prices are reasonable. But it no longer holds the allure it once had.I had my wedding here in February 2014. When I booked the venue, I lived half a world away in Hawaii, so let me tell you, I was NERVOUS about this whole thing. I saw that the Yelp reviews weren't that hot, but I decided to go with them because out of all the establishments I talked to in the venue selection process, Pier 5 had the most top notch customer service. They were the most straightforward about price and what to expect and I appreciated that so much. My wedding planner from the hotel was Chris Sikora and he was just phenomenal throughout the whole years' worth of planning. He stayed in close contact with me throughout the process and I wasn't nervous about any of it. Pier 5 handles everything, from the food (which was so good my guests can't stop talking about it a year later) to the cake, the liquor, and the decorations, they have it all. It was effortless for my friends and family to book rooms, and they got a pretty steep discount for being a part of my wedding. Everyone really enjoyed their stay, and the extra perks (like the bridal room and the groom's room) were excellent.On the day of my wedding, I didn't have to stress at all. Chris and his team took care of everything beautifully. The servers were so awesome! My bridal assistant was just phenomenal as well.Basically, I could keep going about how wonderful the whole experience was, but I think you get the point. I will never forget my wedding at Pier 5 and I would never hesitate to recommend it to any bride-to-be.Great location but you're stuck paying at least $24 for parking in an outdoor lot. Super loud AC unit in room. Light in bathroom didn't work. It's pet friendly, so that is cool...Look guys, you can't generate goodwill and the likelihood of return visits when you stiff people $20 for valet parking. Your neighbor Ruths Chris steakhouse offers the very same service for $8 and the classy Cinghiale in nearby Harbor East offers it for $0. My point is this: you miss a great opportunity for future business when people are onsite to attend an event and exit with a bad taste in their mouths.Very noisy room bc the walls r so thin. The resort fee of $10 and a $22 self parking fee per day didnt help. even with a $22 parking fee, there is no guarantee one will find a parking spot since anyone can park in the lot if willing to pay. the hotel is located right behind the aquarium, so that is a good thing. This hotel allows pets so if one has pet allergy, might want to think twice before booking.Not really sure why this hotel is not rated higher! I would hands down stay here next time I am in town. The location of this hotel is right on the harbor close to everything! Look no further if you are looking to stay in Baltimore. Stayed here Friday/Saturday night. Super cute boutique hotel. Staff is top notch/super friendly and helpful! You can find the GM socializing with the guests and this is something I have not seen at any other hotel. Everyone was always smiling and saying hello to the guests. This hotel offers a "crabby hour" during the weekdays with complementary beer/wine and delicious crepes in the lobby and "chocolate hour" on weekends with complimentary champagne and chocolate/carmel fondue. Not really sure where else you would get something like this at any other hotel. The room was spotless and everything was updated in the room. Thanks to everyone who made our trip as great as it was! To anyone who complained about paying for parking.. what do you expect? Its a city I am pretty sure that every city hotel I have ever been to makes you pay for parking one way or an other whether its included in the daily rate or charged separately..1st thing I must say is we stayed here for very cheap, almost 70% off their regular price.
