So, that makes a BIG difference for a review..... You don't seem to expect or demand as much when you get a great deal. Anyway, nice place, spacious rooms with high ceilings, great location that allows you easy walking to the entire inner harbor and Little Italy. It's also very beautiful at night due to it's location on the water. The staff was extremely friendly and accommodating.Stayed for a couple of nights for a wedding. Very nice hotel. Staff went out of their way to make us feel comfortable. Pet friendly, so we had our 75 pound puppies. Would definitely stay here againHad to stay the night in Baltimore because of a concert (I didn't feel like driving back to DC after rocking out and possibly drinking) but my options were limited since I have a dog. Lucky for me the pier 5 hotel is in the prime location of Baltimore's inner harbor, my room even faced the Baltimore aquarium and harbor. The staff was friendly and welcoming and treated my dog like the princess she is. The room, was fun (bright bold colors) and inviting. They even were nice enough to make recommendations on restaurants that were dog friendly. The hotel was within walking distance of the concert venue which made it ideal for the evening as I was able to stumble back (drunk, with the help of a friend) to my room. My dog was happy here too, I feel like I got my money's worth and I would definitely stay here again.Stayed here 3 nights. We couldn't have asked for a better stay. The staff was great. The rooms were clean. We attended "crabby hour" twice. Fun and free wine. How can you go wrong? Would definitely stay here again.
review_content_20: I read past reviews on Yelp and was not really sure what to think. It almost seemed like things were suspiciously bad.Anyway, I am sitting in their ridiculously chic lobby to set the record straight because I love this hotel too much to not share!Think W hotels but slightly more laid back and better customer service.Seriously.This is a independent, non-chain, cute little boutique hotel that has funky decor and art all over the place. They have Ruth Chris (yes, that ridiculous steak restaurant) and McCormick's & Schmicks (seafood!) attached to their lobby and spilling out onto the street with waterside tabels. No bland full-service hotel restaurant here! Only the good stuff. For breakfast they had eggs, waffels, paninis, bagels, yogurt, coffee, etc. right there in the lobby- more than enough to start the day.The aquarium is literally next door, and power plant will fulfill any bar/club craving you have. The gallery has some nice shops, though this area is probably better known for restaurants, not shopping.The rooms were cute. Again, the whole art theme. They are not your bland, beige decor. You can tell that this hotel is not brand spanking new, but whatever- you're not paying an arm and a leg for it. And it's completely unique and independent. It's really nice to stay somewhere different that is not a cookie cutter place you would pay the same- actually probably more- for.Oh yeah, and free craft beer during their happy hour/crab dip making class. And free wine with their chocolate fountains (food is free as well!). Seriously, what hotel does that?! At the Pier 5. That's where.Okay enough rambling! Check it out :)This review us for a stay in August of this year. Thank you for making the first REAL vacation my husband and I have had since Sandy memorable! The view from our room was fantastic, your staff were extremely helpful! My only complaint was about the bottle service function...the music was very loud! For a romantic weekend we will definitely be back!This review is not a pleasant one to write.  First off I must say thank you to the manager for helping to try and fix what was wrong with this stay but even he couldn't overcome what was a bad stay.When we checked in everything looked ok until we discovered two flies had somehow gotten into our room, this without even having the patio door open.  The bathroom light had a short which the engineer was sent up to fix, the towel rack on the back of the door was inadequately screwed on and then to top things off, there was only one wash cloth in the bathroom.  I addressed that with the night manager who asked in front of me that housekeeping provide more but they didn't until the next day.  It's not that this is a bad hotel but if your staff doesn't help you, as a manager and owner you will continue to look bad.  The price you pay for this doesn't even add up for the service not provided here.  The free passes to the gym is nice but that is really included in the 9.95 a day along with the Internet you get which you have to pay for no matter what.  Maybe the next time we have a chance to stay here it will be better but this stay in particular was not on par with what we were expecting for a weekend getaway.Hotel is a great spot and the staff is super friendly. However, valet is woefully slow and inefficient.  My guess is it is an isolated incident, but the self park lot next door would have saved twenty minutes.Update:   The staff from the hotel emailed after seeing the review to apologize.  Very cool.  They offered to send something to make up for the trouble.  Very cool.  They either forgot it, or just never planned to do it because it never came (months later).  Not cool.   I could have cared less about what they were "sending"; however if you say you're going to do something, you should do it.  Perhaps the crappy valet service wasn't too isolated after all.Location, Location, Location.This place is in a great location.  Moderately priced.  I picked up a nightly rate which included breakfast and happy hour online at one of the discount websites.  It was a great deal.  We stayed here because it's on the inner harbor Baltimore.  It's a gang plank away from the National Aquarium.  We were tourists without a car, so it was an easy taxi ride from the train station to the Pier 5 hotel.  They're also on the free bus line which interconnects to the other free Baltimore Charm City bus lines.From here, we walked the gang plank to the National Aquarium.  For lunch, we had crab cakes at Phillips  between the National Aquarium and this hotel.  The hotel has a couple restaurants, Ruth Chris, etc. in  the lobby, but we were tourists and so the crab cakes and pickled watermelon were on our list for lunch.Our rate included a free bottle of wine.  I was thinking it was going to be some small split, but it turned out to be a dry malbec. For ice, they turn off the ice machine during the day -- probably because just about anybody can walk into the lobby and help themselves.  So, you have to ask the counter staff to get you ice from the kitchen.  At night, when you have to use your key for access, the main ice machine is working and available. From here, we walked to Camden Yards for an Orioles game.  It was about a 20 minute, safe, scenic walk.  Our hotel room had all that we needed.  The carpet was a little dingy.  The soaps reminded me of my stays at places like the PGA National.  Its a nice boutique hotel with friendly staff.Great hotel in a great location!This hotel has a very friendly staff, a trendy vibe, and great food options. The breakfast is really good, and a Ruth's Chris on site is perfect.  The surrounding area has tons of options for things to do.The room is top notch.  Comfy bed, good shower and TV.We just had our wedding there and had an amazing experience! The staff was wonderful, helpful, and able to meet any need we had. All of our family and friends only had glowing things to say about the experience. The Harbor Club for the reception had an amazing view of Baltimore's Harbor and it was great that people could pop out there for fresh air or to hear the concert across the way. I was most impressed that now a week after the wedding they have emailed us that we overpaid and want to send us a refund. So many places would just keep that money for themselves, but they have the integrity to refund it. The food was also wonderful, and as someone with difficult food allergies they were able to prepare foods to meet my specific needs!The location is fantastic. The Aquarium is your neighbor and all the shopping and sites are within walking distance. Little Italy is minutes away. At first glance, the property looks good, but there were some service missteps and structural problems that made our stay just ok.The Good: The rooms are spacious. They include a coffeemaker and the usual bath amenities. There's a bar of massage soap in the bathroom that I liked. The hotel offers a free shuttle service between its three properties in the area, so you can easily get to Fell's Point.The Bad:We had a problem with our bathtub. The stopper wouldn't come up so the water drained ever... so... slowly...Bf had ordered champagne and chocolates to celebrate our anniversary, but the chocolates were missing upon our arrival. We had to ask the concierge twice about them before they were finally delivered to our room on our second night.The room doors SLAM shut even if you're being careful. At all hours of the night, I heard people shutting their doors up and down the hall. Also, if you have a connecting door and your neighbors are loud, you can forget about a restful night. The family next to our room had immature kids slamming the doors again and again and again very early in the morning.We got a special breakfast package with our reservation. We had to inquire about the breakfast vouchers. Then, we found out that the advertised restaurant for the breakfast had been out of business since last year. Fail!Our room faced the harbor so we were thinking it would be pretty peaceful. Nope. We could hear tourists and guests talking and laughing outside from our room. There was also a conference in the lobby of the hotel on one of the days we stayed. It was so annoying and awkward to pass by all the vendors several times throughout the day.Over all, I liked the location, but so many things were wrong.This is a nice, tourist friendly hotel. Rooms are nice, but will agree with other reviews that the carpeting is visibly stained. I selected the hotel for the following reasons...1. Location: once you park you do not need you vehicle again to experience the harbor. 2. Convenience: perfect for a quick overnight trip. I was able to check in early, they accommodated my last minute request for an adjoining room. If you valet with them, although you check out at 12, they will grant you access to your car until 5:00 pm.I got exactly what I expected.This hotel has a great location. However, the plaster was dripping from the ceiling due to roof leaks, there were buckets in the hallway to catch the drips, and nobody on the hotel staff seemed at concerned about the appearance or shape of the hallways or rooms. It was very expensive for what it was and there simply must be better options nearby.The staff was polite and professional.Nice lobby and close to Little Italy. Horribly big A/C units right outside my balcony. There is a great view of the harbor ruined by 10 A/C units. Loud at night. Would have loved to sleep with window open or sit on patio with my morning coffee. Can't tho. There are only like 5 rooms like this tho.  The service and staff were great.  Lovely little food and beer/wine in the evening.  I would stay there again bc of the staff and request a different rooomGreat location. GREAT location. It is a little bit funky with the whole art deco thing going on, but I also go out of my way to find hotels that do not look like they hopped right out of a cookie cutter mold.Unfortunately, that normally means you have to spend a little bit more, but I was able to get a room for $160. Super cheap. Definitely would come back.We got married in this hotel on 11/12/11 and my wedding was AMAZING! Everyone was great and all my guests and family still to this day say that the wedding was the most fun hey had ever had. The whole process was so easy- there were no hidden fees like you always hear about with wedding venues. The food was all great and definitely not typical "wedding food". The harbor club room over looks the water and you feel like your on a boat almost. We went back last year for our anniversary, Valentines Day and are going again this year for the weekend. It has become a little escape away from home for us and takes us back to all our wedding memories. Donna - who helped me the day of my wedding has become a friend when I go by there. She went above and beyond on my wedding day and was with me every mintue whether i needed a drink or to say something nice to relax me. She knew exactly what needed to be done  2 minutes before and was on point! WE LOVE DONNA!!!  I am looking forward to going back this weekend- every time we have been there everyone is so accomodating and friendly. Great location and close to everything.Great hotel!!  Pier 5 is located in a great location if you're visiting the Inner Harbor.  It is super convenient if you're going to the Aquarium or any of the other local attractions.  The staff could not have been nicer or more accommodating to our needs.  I stress that a lot!!  The staff really made the stay so great.  Sure, the decor is a bit outdated, but really.  Who cares?  The rates are great, the hotel was really clean, and our room had several nice amenities.  All in all, we loved it and would stay there again in a heartbeat.  And thanks to the staff- you were wonderful!!!the best part of this hotel is the convenience. otherwise it just seemed run down. the lock on my balcony door didn't lock luckily the security bar was there. the  wall paper is falling off has bubbles or is torn.  the repairs around the room seem like quick fixes and poorly done. I can still see the pencil mark of where the measured the  room mirror. (it's a pretty big mark).. the front door has a mark where it's obvious they had to break in the room. for the price I expected more. $20 parking for hotel gets on top of it all!my wife called it the "Just Ask" hotel when we left today.....  you want it "just ask"  they'll get it for you.... nice folks, nice room and close to everything..... l  I love Baltimore's free charm city buses!!!!     will return next time we are visiting Baltimore ocation location and location....Yeah this place blows. There were some nice people who served breakfast , but my god this place is dirty and tacky. Also fun is the rock concerts going on out on the pier !! Sleep isn't an option. Avoid this place like the plague.Well, Pier proved to be hard to work with. After my husband and I went to contract, we were in for a bumpy road! But Pier 5 worked hard to restore our faith and we had a gorgeous wedding and reception! Our guests were so amazed and ecstatic about our wedding! Our guests enjoyed the delectable cocktail reception and plated dinner. The drinks were also mixed well and not watered down! And the Cake was absolutely delicious!!! I mean, there was no cake left except for the top layer! Our family and friends were especially happy for us and our parents couldn't have been more proud. The Pier 5 Staff did an outstanding job of hosting our family and friends throughout the weekend and the staff was very kind to my husband and me. The music was good and they were very accommodating to our elderly guests with special needs and dietary restrictions. Also, the location was perfect for my husband's family and friends who traveled from New York to be with us.  In the end, the wedding was venue was gorge, the food was amazing and the ambience was sexy! And remember Brides, no matter what happens, it all works out in the end!The main bragging point for this hotel is it's location: it is RIGHT on the harbor, with nice views from most rooms, and is directly next door to the National Aquarium and all the harborfront restaurants and shops.Besides those perks, there isn't a whole lot else going on here. I hear that they have 2 very nice suites, but the rest of the rooms (I stayed in a "Premier Harborview King") are not particularly impressive.The room service is extremely limited. There is no mini-bar, nor even an empty fridge to utilize. The bathrooms are boring and standard. My sheets had (blood?) stains on them. There is no pool or spa, and the only ice machine is on the second floor.All in all, if they hadn't charged me $260.00 a night for what is really a motel with a great location, I wouldn't have been so disappointed by my experience.I haven't been back in Baltimore for very long, but this is by far the weirdest place I have visited since I have been here.  I don't know if this is supposed to be a hotel or just an elaborate event venue.  Every time we walked through the lobby there was a rowdy group of people occupying the space.  We were only there one night and we bumped into participants in a young lady's bat mitzvah, a software convention, a wedding celebration, a doggie club meeting, and an anniversary party.  In fact, the hotel seemed so comfortable with having the lobby be a social scene that they had a chocolate tasting party for the hotel guests midday on Saturday.  Apparently, it is something they do every Saturday during the fall and winter, a lovely gesture.  I will certainly say that all of it gave the hotel an extremely lively/upbeat atmosphere and provided me and my friends with hours of comedic people watching.  However, it did make me feel like the hotel was a little too open to the public...in the sense that, usually hotels in big cities make a big deal about security in order to protect their guests.  I really didn't get that here.  If that's a concern to you, you may want to find a different hotel. As for the rooms, again, I was amused and confused.  At first glance, the rooms are spacious and artfully decorated with a flair for the colorful and contemporary.  Plus, I was overjoyed to find that most rooms have a small or shared balcony that provides a breath-taking view of the harbor.   But, upon further inspection, the carpets and the balcony curtains were heavily soiled.  I joked to my companions that my room may have once been a crime scene because the stains on the floors, walls, and curtains were reminiscent of either hot chocolate or dried blood.  Hey, this is the city that inspired the show "Homicide."  However, don't let that scare you.  I assume the reason the rooms are dingy upon close inspection is, the hotel is dog friendly (which I support so bonus points to Pier 5) and pets are a bit harder to clean up after than humans.   One additional note about the rooms, my companions had a bit of trouble during check in.  They were initially given a room that was occupied and walked in on a set of hotel guests.  When they returned to the front desk, they did not receive much of an apology, but were quickly given another room.  Unfortunately, the second room must have also been reserved for another party because a mere hour after my friends' arrival, a bunch of strangers walked into their room using a card that had recently been issued by the front desk.  While the front desk never apologized for this scenario to my friends' satisfaction (my buddies wanted a free night), the staff was ultimately courteous and helpful. Despite the unevenness of this establishment, there are a few great things to keep in mind about this hotel.  First, it is within one mile's walking distance of Fell's Point (the younger more eclectic side of Baltimore).  And, of course, it is in the heart of all the things that make the Inner Harbor great:  shopping, H&M/Best Buy/Barnes & Noble; restaurants, Cheesecake Factory/Ruth's Chris Steakhouse/McCormick & Scmick's; and the Aquarium.2.5
review_content_40: Upon arrival, I was very excited about my stay at Pier 5. All that quickly disintegrated when I arrived at my room, which 1) wasn't the harbor view room I had booked and 2) had such a strong smell of cheap, flowery carpet deodorizer I could barely breathe.  When I tried to change rooms, they gave me some lame excuse about how I had booked through a third party and they hadn't even been paid for my stay yet.  I finally called negotiated a new price for a new, smaller but less offensive, room.  Then the real fun begins....from midnight until about 3:00 am a large party across the hall kept us awake.... Music, yelling, profanity....  It took a few calls to the front desk and a visit from the police to get the thing under control. I am currently seeking a refund.My husband and I came to the Inner Harbor for our 6th wedding anniversary.  We chose this hotel based on its location to the aquarium.  If I rated this hotel solely on its location, it would be 5 stars.  Here is the short and sweet:Pros:  They allowed us an early check in (2:30 pm) and the rooms were clean.Cons:  For the price, the hotel is not decorated well, nor does it offer many amenities.  My husband and I had left overs that we were forced to throw away because they did not have a small refrigerator.  These may seem like small gripes, but for 300+ a night, the hotel should have included more.  My husband and I opted for the extra package that came with the hotel which included wine and breakfast.  The breakfast was the standard toast and boxed cereal (not worth the extra money).  There was an omelet station in the middle of the carb feast, but it was not included.   We were only informed of this by the very rude staff that came over to "police" the food.  Bottom line:  I would not return to this hotel.  There are many other hotels in VERY close walking distance that offer rooms at a similar or lesser price that would have been much better to stay at.  If your goal is to stay as close to the aquarium as possible, this would be the hotel; otherwise, take the 5 minute walk and look into other hotels.Sorry, but I really can't recommend this place. I'm sure there are a few fabulous suits here, but they certainly don't take care of the business clients very well. Issues?-coffee or dark stains on carpet-cracks in tiles-rust in tub-missing handle on draws -room service not available 24 hrs a day (out of luck if you get in late or get a hunger pang)-blood stain beneath sheets! Ewww...Anyway, I've stayed at a lot of hotels and I would not recommend this for the biz traveler.Baltimore isn't the best city in the world, nor in the country, in the east coast, heck matter of fact, not the best city in the state of Maryland. Yet somehow people continuously flock to the city, go figure! Take it from someone who worked across the harbor from the city and had to endure the funk in the air day after day. So where do I go when I need a break from it all? Where else? Baltimore! This hotel sits right on the pier (I think it sits on pier 5... just a guess... =p) by the water (surprisingly not stinky). Once you walk in, your senses will be overwhelmed by color purple. The decorator dude had to be a serious Prince admirer. There are funky symbols everywhere and plush purple velvet couch in the lobby. Now the rooms. Well, THE room in particular actually. It's called the "Tradewind Suite." It is located on the second floor and it used to be a cigar lounge that they turned into a bedroom suite. As you walk through the double door, you will say, OH MY GOD (period). Through all my travels in diff countries, this room by far is the most memorable. The bed was phenomenal! High sleigh bed and oh so comfortable. They still have all the boxes on the wall for cigars (no cigars though, I checked). In one corner of the room, there is a bar area completed with all the glassware and supplies (mixers, shakers, etc) and next to it is... wait for it... in-room jacuzzi!!! I turned them bad boys on and it was simply heaven. Something about taking a bath in a bedroom totally rocks! Oh, yeah let's talk about the bathroom. It had a shower and the faucets that are flushed into the ceiling so water fell from the ceiling. It was like taking a shower in the rain. LOVE IT!!! The hotel has only ONE Tradewind Suite and they get booked WAY in advance. Jan and Feb booked solid on weekends already. I wouldn't book this room if you are interested in looking outside the window (e.g. New Year's Eve). The room has ABSOLUTELY no view. It literally sits above the air conditioner units (and there's alot). I would love to spend every weekend I can at this suite but the room costs anywhere from $500 to $800 per night (pending season). They also have "Experience Specialist" who arranges bubble baths, rose petals on bed, champagnes, chocolate covered strawberries (do not get this), etc etc. Go! And experience Baltimore like you've never had before!Jada Pinkett & Will Smith got married here....now why did they do that???Went as a wedding date with a friend to her cousin's wedding. The place is located in Harbor, so I was thinking this is gonna be super romantic...what a dream wedding.Well visually...everything was great...only problem is theres an outdoor stage next door blaring Pat Benetar's Love is a Battlefield as the lovebirds are reciting their vows on the grassy knoll outside the hotel...WTF???Well the reception hall is smaller and definitely for a intimate sized wedding. Food took FOREVER to come out....and the desserts (mango peach gelato) and appetizers (duck quesadilla, beef bruschetta, coconut shrimp) were better than the main course (filet, crab cake and vegetables). -__- FAIL!The acoustics were OK, we could barely hear or see whoever was on the microphone. Parking is ridiculous...cars are back to back in this tiny lot next to the hotel. I wouldn't have my wedding here, but i'm sure it could be someone's else's dream come true. :)Good thing is we had an open bar right next to the "party table" and I was with a bunch of chingus who could handle their drink. party on!

hotel_name: Residence Inn Baltimore Downtown/ Inner Harbor
review_content: I love this hotel.  Perfect location... walkable to many great restaurants, waterfront and Federal Hill (lots of great bars in this area).  Great views from the room I was in.  Amazing staff who is willing to go the extra mile to ensure you feel like a guest in their own home.  And most importantly, it was CLEAN!!!  Wouldn't stay anywhere else if I ever make it back to Baltimore.The Residence Inn is a perfectly decent hotel: small and clean lobby, decent sized suites, competent room service and efficient bell boys.It's a cookie cutter Marriott, but with a vey filling breakfast buffet. Gotta love Americans and their hearty appetites. I spent three nights here while attending a conference, and I definitely appreciated the proximity to the convention centre, inner harbour, fells point etc. Baltimore can be super sketchy so I am especially thankful for the safe location.My stay here was unremarkable except for their good coffee in the lobby which my friends commented favourably on.My stay here was brief, but they made a good impression.  Points for having a very friendly, accommodating, and helpful staff, that made sure everything was set up as needed.  Points for a nice view outside as well.  Minus points for the area in Baltimore... which isn't their fault, but hey, it's Baltimore.  Shortly after I was there the city was on fire.  Some pretty sketchy alleyways were taken from the airport shuttle driver to the hotel.  The room was very nice but had some wear and tear.  Overall a solid stay.Dark and dingy. I was a little disappointed with this property in terms of comfort and ambience. There is a pungent smell that will hit you as soon as you enter the hotel. The best part of the hotel was its location. Just a few blocks from inner harbor making it a good cheaper alternate to the harbor side hotels. Breakfast was just ok.Stayed here a few months back and have nothing except for nice things to say about The Residence Inn Baltimore Downtown / Inner Harbor.The location is ideal for anyone wanting to explore the Inner Harbor or even get to the stadiums. Our room was beautiful and spacious. The staff was accommodating and friendly. Breakfast was good with a lot of different options. I liked the little market area because it allowed me to sneak down late at night for some ice cream!I would recommend this hotel to anyone and if I am ever in Baltimore again, this will be my first choice for a hotel.I came to the hotel for Otakon 2015 at the Convention Center a few blocks away. My group stayed in one of the corner suites. It was very spacious, organized, soundproof and it even came with Paul Mitchell shampoo and conditioner!Our group needed items at odd hours and the hotel staff always delivered extra towels, blankets, etc. within 5 minutes. We were in the 11th floor.The free breakfast had a HUGE variety of food! As a vegetarian I really appreciated the  large selection of fresh fruits. My favorite part of this place? The staff. They were genuinely friendly, not just professionally polite. Everyone I met - from the bellhop to the manager - would offer a smile and keep up a happy conversation.I had the pleasure of staying late for breakfast and watching the manager brief the maids for the day. He treated all his employees with respect, friendliness and dignity and called them all by first name. The cleaning staff seemed very comfortable with him. I found out that he started this hotel 10 years ago and has a passion for his business.The front desk woman went out if her way to help me with some laundry issues. She even sent a runner to the laundry room with some soap when I forgot mine downstairs. Rarely have I experienced such great customer service and staff in a hotel. This place has a very homey feel to it because of the people. For that alone the experience is worth it. My roommates and I all agree and we choose this hotel every year.Absolutely recommend to anyone.My parents receive medical services from Johns Hopkins, but they live just outside Washington, DC. Whenever they're going in for medical services, they get a room at the Residence Inn because it's so close in proximity to the hospital campus. Not only that, they have a small dog that they're very attached to and the Residence Inn is pet-friendly (for a $100 fee). The rooms are always clean and well-appointed. They are equipped with kitchenettes and flat-screen TVs that have three HBO channels, which is wonderful. Not only that, a buffet breakfast is included in the room price. It includes scrambled eggs, breakfast meat, potatoes, fruit, cereal, bread/pastries, Belgian waffles, and delicious coffee with International Delight flavored creamer (which is always available throughout the day at a station in the lobby). There's also valet parking, a lounge area, and a 24-hour limited selection convenience bar that features things like beer, wine, snacks, frozen entrees, sundries/toiletries, and Ben & Jerry's ice cream (!!). The lobby also features a restaurant (17 Light) that has a full bar, and delicious food -- most of it is seafood, so if you don't eat that you won't be too impressed with the menu. The hotel is also right next door to a Dunkin Donuts and a CVS, plus there's a 7-11 across the street and a Royal Farms, which sells the best fried chicken (in case you weren't aware). It's also in walking distance of the Inner Harbor (shops and restaurants and museums), and is only a 7-10 min drive to Baltimore Penn Station where you can catch Amtrak. Recently my dad had an extended hospital stay at Hopkins and my mother and I stayed at the hotel with our dog. Our stay was wonderful as usual. The staff of the hotel is really nice and accommodating. In particular, there's a woman named Chasity who works there who is simply amazing. She has taken such good care of my parents over the years, is always in such a great mood, and is just all-around a pleasure to work with. There's never anything we've asked of her that she hasn't done (within reason!). Several other members of the staff from housekeepers to valets are just a delight. They work hard to anticipate your needs and deliver before you even have to ask. But then they're just super-accommodating to ensure your stay is a good one. My parents will probably never go to another hotel in Baltimore ever again and now that I've spent a significant amount of time there, I don't blame them! As long as Chasity is there, I know for sure we'll keep coming back. Thanks for making us feel so comfortable in the midst of a difficult time.The biggest problem with this hotel is the ridiculous price for a Residence Inn... but the free breakfast was quite good the location is downtown and the rooms were entice and clean.  I would stay here again but would like to stay for less then $300 a night.  After the over priced food and the exorbitant pet fee it turned into a $500 stay.I stayed here for an extremely stressful couple of nights and was very comfortable. The hotel staff was nothing short of wonderful, even with all their stressed out customers. The room was beautiful, huge, and clean. I got two queen beds with a kitchenette and oh Lordy was that lovely. There was a full sized fridge, a half sized stovetop, a dishwasher, sink, and cabinets full of everything you could need to cook up dinner and eat it. When I checked in, I asked for a wake up call. Although she said no problem, I think she may not have heard me fully: you have to set up the wake up calls through the phone in your room, so they're fully automatic. It worked out fine because I brought several other alarms to be safe. The bed and pillows were comfortable but I did call and ask for another blanket. The blanket was brought up in less than five minutes. I didn't watch the television but I did use the wifi, which worked fine for Facetime calls. Cell reception was likewise acceptable. It is VALET PARKING ONLY. I parked out of the city and took the light rail in so I wouldn't have to pay for the parking. If you can do that, it's totally worth it. When I checked out, I was able to leave my luggage in a locked room behind the front desk to pick up after the day was complete, which worked beautifully.  I am absolutely staying here again the next time I have something going on in the Inner Harbor.Me & my boo boo stayed here for 2 nights. Or stay in BMore was okay. The only bright spots was the restaurant & this hotel. Before coming the front staff was very knowledgeable & friendly. One person in particular Steve. I believe he is not here full time. But he knows his stuff. Very helpful we are from Philly. The room was clean only knock I'll say is the when I turned off the heat to cool the room it took along time. Other then that Perfect. If we come to Baltimore this place will be it!FYI Pick the high floor!I stayed at this hotel for one night. When I checked, the process was quick since I reserve a room by using the Marriott app. The overall room was great. The room was pretty big. The room was very clean. I was happy to see that they offer 3 HBO channels along with other major channels such as ESPN or CNN. I am very glad it was a smoke free hotel. The breakfast buffet was delicious!!! The room looked very clean. I was completely suprised when one of the employee took my empty plate without me asking. I absolutely appreciate it.This was our 3rd time at the this hotel, and we still like it. The staff is very friendly and the place is clean and welcoming. Their suites fits our family of five perfectly, and the kids have a blast at the breakfast buffet. As a side note they allow pets to stay. However, the interior is getting a little worn and could use an update, and the madras in our beds were too soft for our liking.This is for the staff at the Residence Inn. I arrived right before the riot on 4/27. I was unaware of the situation until I checked in and turned on the news on TV. After getting a call from my company to reschedule the meeting and leave the city, I approached the front desk expecting to pay for the day stay. To my surprise and delight the front desk staff said we understand and there will be no charge for the stay. Kudos to the staff and management for this act. Really good to know that there are times when businesses and people recognize a special situation and act accordingly. I have a whole different view of the staff at this particular establishment and of Residence Inn in general.Really well done. I will look forward to coming back.The first thought of this hotel - perfect location. It's a close walk to EVERYTHING.Our room was beautiful! We had the two bedroom, two bath suite. It was HUGE! Although the sight out our window wasn't so beautiful. You pay almost $40 to park your car. A little ridiculous if I may add. I didn't know that's how you treat guests who already pay enough.Paul Mitchell's shampoo and conditioner, SWEET! And a free breakfast! - I'm only assuming we pay for this when we park our car for $40.00, right?Looks at this fancy room with a kitchen and everything!  Ok it's not really that fancy.  But it was nice enough, and probably more than we really needed.  We only stayed one night whereas these kind of rooms are built for people staying longer periods.  This would totally be a great place to stay for someone staying a week in Baltimore.  Also they are pet friendly!The breakfast was so horrible.  Don't even bother.  Especially if there is a line.  Dunkin Donuts coffee is right next door.Also I had flashbacks to college days waiting for an elevator for like 10 minutes.For the price of a regular hotel, you can get a kitchen (apartment style) and some meals at no additional cost (breakfast and two dinners).  The food provided is low quality food, but one can pick around for whole foods.  The staff is less than stellar, but everything seems to run smooth enough, as expected.The gym has dumbbells, two benches, and cardio machines only.My favorite hotel in Baltimore - good rate, close to convention center, convenient stores nearby, friendly staff, free full breakfast and bar restaurant if you don't feel Ike headin out - And if you're lucky - get the 2 room suiteVery rude front desk clerk named Bill HOWEVER the hotel overall isn't bad.  Valet can be a bit too busy since they only have room for about 4 cars coming in and out. The location is great for getting around the Inner Harbor area too.As for the room though... it was very clean and large. Unfortunately it's a bit outdated and features a good amount of tacky furniture and art.Since the price is phenominal though I'd definitely return.Such a good experience.  I think that was a newer renovation, and they did a great job with it... it does not have the older Residence Inn vibe that I have experienced elsewhere.  Light 17 in the building was a cute and yummy restaurant with great service.  Everyone at the hotel had great customer service skills as well.  Great location, easy to walk anywhere in the Inner Harbor.  Highly recommended.  We will be back!Baltimore Running Festival - Perfect Race Location for Half-Marathon.Spent two nights here for the 2013 Baltimore Running Festival - ran the half-marathon. For the race, the Half Marathon, the hotel location is PERFECT (the start line is less than a 2 minute walk). For the full marathon and from the finish line area, it is about a .75 mile walk (took about 12min to walk back to the hotel. I cannot speak high enough of this hotel (as described below):STAFF: The front desk staff on Friday the 11th unfortunately was not wearing name tags, otherwise I would have mentioned her by name - but, she was very customer service oriented, check-in was quick and I was offered my room, early, without even a hesitation. HOUSEKEEPING: Again, perfect. I asked for extra towels - and got them immediately. Room upkeep was perfect and timely. The only shortfall was a 11:51pm wake-up with a knock at the door with a night housekeeper with 2 rolls of TP----I was dead asleep....but, the knocking persisted.....got a good laugh out of it in the morning.....just worth mentioning that the night staff needs to triple-check room numbers before knocking on doors that late (plus, after the 2nd knock, if I was expecting TP, I would have answered after the 1st knock...lol).BREAKFAST: Hotel was sold-out for both days I was in the property (marathon, convention and Green Bay vs. Raven game) and they easily kept up with the morning demand. And, as a plus, there is soda available in the morning (wish more hotels did that). Plentiful hot items available.PARKING: OK - see my picture below - and I hate to ruin the $32/day fee the hotel charges, BUT, park across the street (directly south of the 7-Eleven) at the 25 Charles St garage (yes, the entrance is off of Light St) - - - the weekend (Fri, Sat, Sun) fee is only $10/day (yes---only $10 day). My picture has the parking fees. Even during the work-week, the fee is only $20/day - so, still a substantial savings. The valets are extremely friendly (all of them I engaged during my visit) - while not Marriott employees, they definately extended a customer service level that most valets do not. So, for my entire weekend - I spent $30 for parking - - no in-n-out, but, it didn't matter....you don't need a car in downtown Baltimore....you can walk everywhere.ROOM: I was in Room 1503, with a nice north view. 2 Queen studio and as the pictures reveal, the room was huge. Room is well maintained, everything worked, plenty of space (with the exception of the bathroom----but, still do-able). HVAC worked perfectly - plenty of AC. Kitchen was well appointed and we utilized the appliances on several occasions. Beds were extremely comfortable.INTERNET: It's free! Not that fast - but, fast enough.ELEVATORS: OK - it's an older building - and only has -2- elevators - but, we never really ever had to wait for a ride. 17 Light St Bar: Very friendly bar on the ground floor - resonable "hotel" prices.MARKETPLACE: OK, again, I hate to ruin the "money-making-marketplace" - but, there is a 7-Eleven literally directly across the street - and the 7-Eleven prices are a bargin, compared to the hotel prices (yes, I said that 7-eleven was a bargin....bet you never heard that before). There is also a CVS and a Royal Farms less than a 1 minute walk from the hotel. Also, McDonalds is 1 min away as well (but, that McDonalds is over-run with transients).We were extremely happy with our stay, and this will be my home-away-from-home on all trips to Baltimore. Room rates are extremely competitive (and a value) for such a central Downtown location. Throw in the 2 free newspapers (USA Today and WSJ), free breakfast and free wi-fi and the roomy suites - and you just cannot beat this property
review_content_20: For Baltimore, prices are good, rooms are decent. The problem: The hotel is in a shady area. Lots of homeless begging for money. Last night, there was a shooting a few blocks away which caused lots of issues next to the hotel. MAJOR PROBLEM: Hotel charges $32 a night to park your car in an unguarded lot next door, where I witnessed someone taking a piss right next to mine. This is also where a ton of police activity happened last night. Not the hotel's fault per se, but security would be nice outside!GM couldn't really care, making up lame excuse after lame excuse. He eventually refunded our parking fees after lots of arguing. Also, don't put "garage parking" on my bill when it wasn't. Shady shady shady.Stayed here for 5 weeks while working in Baltimore. A satisfactory - if not great - experience. Really a 3.5 Good location; Friendly staff. The room that I had was small for the price, and the couch/sleeper sofa was really uncomfortable - like sitting on a cardboard box. The towels were old, thin, and scratchy, and the bed was less than luxurious.Breakfast was okay, but only okay. I often found myself eating breakfast  at  the Cheapside Wharf (just around the corner on Water St.) instead of eating the same tired food at the hotel - even though it was "free."  [And speaking of Water St. - the Water Street Tavern (also *very close*) is AWESOME! Great drinks, and good food served late! (read my review for more info)]Still; the staff was good about bringing mail and packages to my room; greeting me by name every day; and really taking care of things when Hurricane Sandy threatened to make things rough. Housekeeping also did a great job of keeping things tidy and comfortable.Why do I keep using the word "things"? I don't know.Things.The biggest pro/con about this place is not their fault - but I'll mention it just as a caveat for fellow travelers:  Baltimore has wonderful history, beautiful scenery and architecture, and fabulous food. It also has a very very high homeless population, lots of crime, and can be a generally rough place.This hotel is right in the middle of ALL of that.  So, just know that you can walk or take the free "circulator" to just about anywhere in town during the day - but be very careful when you're out for the evening.Friendly staff, clean & comfy rooms, modern decor, good location, safe, decent price, D&D/7-11 across the street. All in all a great hotel. MY only gripe is the gym; the elliptical & treadmills are all pieces of...... yeah, not so hot.The hotel was very nice and close to the inner harbor. The rooms were decorated in modern decor and had a kitchenett with granite countertops. I was shocked when I opened the door to see how nice the room actually was. The first room we had was a large corner king room, standard. It was huge and very nice. Unfortunately, we asked to move because of the screaming child next to us. Customer Service was great. They were up to our room within a couple of minute s to take us to a new room. It was not on the corner, rather the side of the building but still a nice room. We definetely had a nicer room the first time. I woke up by teenagers hollering on the street below at 2:00 in the morning. I got up to look out of the window to see what looked like a club down below. So, the location is great for inner harbor, but not good for sleeping. The free breakfast buffet was good. It was very crowded around 10:00, so we had to share a table with others. The hotel was nice, but I am not sure I would pay the price again because of the noise compliants. The parking deck is right accross the street, but very expensive. Pay attention to what you will pay if you leave and return. We ended up paying $20 for one night stay.While the parking is over-priced, it is efficient and cheerfulLight level in our room was insufficient for reading.The "turkey Canadian bacon" served at breakfast was a curious pressed Spam-like meat, sliced paper thin.I was very happy with this hotel. Although I was only here one night, I was very impressed with the quality and cleanliness of our room, especially considering the fairly large size and the kitchen. Very clean sheets, floors, bathroom, everything! I will certainly stay here again next time I'm in Baltimore. Wonderful value for the quality!I recently had a house fire, and was relocated here while some repairs were going on. We were staying with our dog (white German Sheppard) and our toddler (15 months old). We stayed here for about 5 weeks, and it was a very positive experience. The staff was EXCELLENT! The folks working the front desk were always friendly and accommodating. The valet staff was always prompt and smiling (even in the rain). The breakfast in the morning (when I was able to wake up before 9am) was delicious, and always changing from day to day. The room itself was fairly spacious, and had it's own little kitchen (minus a stove), which was fantastic! We like to cook our own food, and are not too keen on getting takeout or dining out. This little kitchen definitely suited our needs. The amenities were clean and easily accessible, although we didn't really use them much ourselves. The entire place was fresh and clean. The Aquarium (as well as the rest of the harbor) was within close walking distance. It wasn't home, but it was close!Really nice hotel that is so convinent to the inner harbor. Very friendly staff, pretty good continental breakfast buffet, and clean rooms. My family and I were always greeted when we left and entered the hotel. The front desk also gave us great walking directions to near by shopping and restaurants. I would definitely stay here again.The hotel is great. Great location. The staff is super helpful. Not excited about 33/day valet - but I can deal with that. The rooms don't have great views. The rooms are clean and spacious. I have been to many residence inns and this is a good one.A great location for the price we have paid...its only a 5-10 min walk from the inner harbor.  The valet is a bit expensive, $32 per night, but the attendents were very attentive and efficient.  I requested a higher floor and corner room, and I got what I wanted.  Daily breakfast is included, and it is a great breakfast.  Coffee, tea, and hot chocolate are provided throughout the day.  The only down side is there is no swimming pool.  I will definitely come back to stay here again if I am visiting Baltimore again.Great location! Great staff! Adequate rooms.. Reasonable parking rates... I'm a fan..We had a great experience at this hotel on a recent weekend getaway from the DC area.  The staff was some of the friendliest, most helpful that I have ever experience at a Marriott property.  From the time we pulled up until the time we loaded up to leave we couldn't have asked for more from the staff.  We enjoyed our time there and will be coming back.The hotel appears to have been renovated, and provides free breakfast (full breakfast, not just continental) in the mornings. It's in a great location for those wanting to go to the National Harbor. They have a business center that offers 3 computers with free internet access and a restaurant by the main lobby. I'm not sure if they requested the local police to patrol the front, but they are regularly there. The only down side is you must pay $30 per day for parking.Great location a couple blocks up the hill from Inner Harbor.  Good security (front door requires key to access after-hours, and you can't even use the elevator most of the day without a door key!), nice front desk staff.    Rooms were spare but clean, though the pull-out bed that was advertised as comfy was really not.  We probably should've seen through this selling point.  Nice kitchenette in the suite with a clean fridge and dishware.Valet parking was $29/day, compared to $21/day at the garage next door (at Light & Lombard St.).  Walk one block and you can park it yourself, maybe save a few bucks.Like most/all Residence Inns, this place is pet friendly... for a steep fee.  My brother brought his dog along at a cost of $100 for two nights.  You have to walk a little ways to find grass where the dogs can do their business, but Tigger liked walking around with all the excitement of the harbor.  Beats being left at home!  He also loved the front desk, which was generous in its distribution of dog treats.My only real complaint is in regards to the breakfast room, which was a complete zoo throughout Labor Day weekend.  The staff did their best to keep the food stocked and the coffee pouring, but it was pretty insane.  Kinda reminded me of a feeding frenzy at a fish farm.I stayed here during the busy Otakon 2010 convention weekend.  The staff were very friendly and check-in was a breeze.  Parking was around $23.00 a night.  The room was $219.00 a night, which is a bit exorbitant.  The room was nice and big.  One large bed, a sofa bed, two desks and chairs, and a coffee table.  There was a television, stove, dishwasher, fridge, plates, bowls, cups, etc.The shower was nice.  They served breakfast every morning, although I did not go down for it.  Checking out was quick, I just had to drop off my room keys at the front desk.I stayed here recently and we paid $99 the first night and $119 the second night. They have recently remodeled and we were pleasantly surprised when we got to our room. It was so nice that we called the front desk when we got up there to make sure they hadn't given us a suite by mistake. We had 2 queen beds, a pullout sofa, desk, dining table and a fully stocked kitchen. The customer service was above and beyond. They consistently went one step further to anticipate our needs. I was so impressed and I will only stay there if and when I return to the Inner Harbor!I almost gave this hotel two stars, but they  made up the one star in location,  convenience, and size of the room. I really liked what I saw when I checked in, it looked clean, and staff was really nice. But the next day when I went to take a shower, there was no water. When I called the front desk, they mentioned that they had "cleaned out the water lines" despite the fact that everyone else I was with had plenty of water...Anyway, they got the water on, and it was RUSTY!! I let it run for a good 15 minutes and it seemed ok, until I dried off with a white towel and discovered that the water was still rusty. :-( I figured that I would see what would happen when I returned in the evening, it seemed ok. Then when I took a shower the next morning, and dried off, it was still a little rusty, but a lot better than the previous day. It eventually got better, but I shouldn't have had to go through that, when I told the front desk all she could say was sorry.The breakfast was pretty much non-existant, some runny scrambled eggs, and coffee (which I don't drink).On a brighter note, the room was clean, and decent.DISGUSTING. EWWWWWWWWW. Cheap and dirty. You can cook your own food which is nice, but make sure you do the dishes yourself, the maids will just put them back in the drawers when you aren't looking without cleaning them, I watched her do it. The sheets never get cleaned unless you tell them to, I was there for 4 weeks. When I first got to the room the sheets were dirty, so gross!  Free internet, eh ok.  other trainees like myself staying at the place said there were bed bugs, I didn't see any, but I was in the 15th floor.  The neighborhood is scarey lots of homeless asking for money, so be prepared for that gem of an experience too.$105/night for a king size bed.  Not bad at all considering the location.  Room was clean... a lot better than I thought it would end up being.  The parking on the other hand, cost $29.  The complimentary breakfast was decent!  biscuits, sausage, eggs, fruits, granola & other cereals, yogurts, juices, seasoned potatoes, and... I think that was about it.  The ONLY thing I did have a problem with the hotel was that the housemaid came about 3 TIMES in the morning time on our check-out date... 8am, 10am, 12:15pm.  We were granted for a late check-out @ 1PM.  She almost walked into our room at 8am... the boyfriend and I were passed out and didn't hear her until she opened the door.  I was asked, "who is it??!!" and she just simply replied, "oh I'm so sorry".  I don't blame the housemaid, I blame the front desk staff who obviously failed to communicate something as simple as a late check-out for my room.I reserved two large rooms for a group of girls. When we arrived (past check in time), both rooms weren't ready. They were not helpful, kind or a bit apologetic. Only upside- Large rooms. In a city full of unique and beautiful hotels, I do not recommend this hotel.
review_content_40: Great place to stay in the Inner Harbor. Clean, spacious rooms, a quick jaunt to the Inner Harbor, pots of Marriott coffee always brewing, and the nicest, most helpful staff, from the manager right down to the valets. The price seemed just right for the accommodation. I would've loved a few more good restaurants close by, but all in all more than pleased with this place!Close to the stadium for the game and free breakfastVery nice and clean hotel right next to the Inner Harbor (the shops are within walking distance). My parents always stay here when they're visiting me at college. The rooms are spacious and well-appointed, and the hallways are brightly lit. The bed are comfy and the staff is friendly and helpful. When they make a mistake, they try to make up for it. They might bake you fresh cookies.The only thing that kind of irks me when we stay there is the valet service. They can be quite slow sometimes, even when calling ahead. But I've found that this isn't limited to just this hotel, so we'll cut them some slack.Rooms are decent, parking is over-priced and the Inner Harbor is a good 5 block walk, which can be shaky after dark. No decent eatery close by, including on site. This place will usually save you a couple of bucks when compared to hotels closer to the harbor, but it comes with some drawbacks. If you don't mind hoofin' it in the dark, this place is a decent choice.super friendly staff, clean, free breakfastWe celebrated out son's destination wedding at this location.  The corporate office was FABULOUS for booking our wedding block and the hotel itself accommodate our every need.  We had so many rooms booked for friends  who traveled from many different states and they all received excellent service and accommodations.  We loved the buffet breakfast it was a wonderful treat to all our guests and the front desk was very helpful!  Since the state is a dry alcohol state it was very convenient that they sell alcohol at the front desk.  Thank you again to all who helped make our son's wedding a treasured memory in MD.I stayed here when I was taking the bar exam which was a really stressful time. However, this hotel was wonderful. The staff goes out of their way to help you and the service is great. The people are friendly and the rooms are quite comfortable and spacious.  Also, the breakfasts in the morning were really good. To top it off, I left my phone charger in the room and when I called and asked if the hotel could mail it to me, they overnighted it and didn't charge me a penny! I would stay at this hotel anytime I'm in Baltimore.

review_content: Great hotel for an unbeatable price. Robin and Charles are hands down the best staff I have encountered at a hotel and I have been traveling for years. I would stay here again in a heart beat. My traveling partner and I took pics with them because they are fun and we love memories!Breakfast is much better than your standard continental breakfast and it changes daily, variety is the spice of life.THE BEDS, I was tempted to stay in bed all day and skip a day of playing tourist!!! I want to order one of these beds and have it shipped back home. I will be back!Great Hotel.Robin and Shanee were excellent and helped us in any way.Cant beat free cookies and free breakfast (if you wake up in time).A great location for the ballpark and having pickles pub next door is kind of coolThis hotel was very expensive - $100+ and 20,000 points per night of the Gold Cup semi-final. We were given a corner room on the eighth floor, and it was great! I think it's the biggest Hampton suite I've ever had (though whirpool suites are the best). We had views of Camden Yards and M&T Bank Stadium; we could see the mound inside the ballpark. Breakfast was mediocre. It's your standard, typical Hampton breakfast of lightly baked scrambled eggs, watery sausage patties, etc. There's a waffle maker, oatmeal, cereal, pastries, applies/banans, yogurt, juices, and coffees. Frankly, Hamptons have my least favorite breakfasts on the Hilton totem pole because the quality isn't the best.The manager at least let us have a bottled water, bottled coke, chocolate bar, and Utz crab-flavored chips as a welcome gift. You're really supposed to only get one beverage and one snack. During the stay, the front desk and valet were very accomodating, including getting an airport cab for me at 6AM. I would've given the hotel two stars, which is typical of my Hampton ratings, but I added a star for service!I "downgraded" to this hotel from the Marriott because the rate was $100 less per night.  But it wasn't a downgrade at all.  The amenities at this place are ridiculous:- valet parking- they give you a snack anddrink when you check in- free wifi- amazing beds- warm walk in shower- THE THERMOSTAT IS DIRECTLY ABOVE THE BED SO YOU DONT HAVE TO GET UP IN THE MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT TO CHANGE IT- free awesome breakfast in the morning and if you aint got time for dat they have pre packed brown bags you can take with you that have muffin apple water etcThis place is the bees kneesThe staff hands down is the reason this place gets a five star from me....hotel is very clean...appears to be fairly new...good location for those wanting a hotel downtown but away from a lot of traffic. Frank and Keon were very helpful with bags and anything else you needed during your initial arrival and making sure your car is parked and well taken care of. I was leaving right back out for dinner so they were sure to keep it close to ensure I made my dinner reservations. Tim at the front desk made sure my hotel room met my needs....had an issue with one of the rooms but he changed it out with no questions added. Would certainly stay again...keep up the good work Hampton Inn...I had a great experience at this hotel. The valet parking men were so friendly and professional. They made us feel welcome from the get go. The hotel itself was very clean, attractive, and the perfect size. Free breakfast every morning from 6-10am. Check out is at noon which is nice because some other hotels in the area have early check out times. The pool and hot tub areas are nice, along with a nice size gym. My only complaint was the water temperature in the shower took a while to get hot and when it did, it was scorching. My only minor complaint. Great hotel!Can't say enough great stuff!  Staff is great. Location is perfect. Sitting in my comfy king bed right now. Update tomorrow   MaybeI've stayed in a few different hotels in the Baltimore area and this one is definitely one of the better ones I've stayed at. Before arriving there was a slight booking snafu but it was fixed by the staff and they were so friendly about everything when I checked in. The rooms are spacious (especially the bathroom which is always a plus) and they were clean and comfortable. I also really liked how close the hotel was to the Inner Harbor and you have access to major roads which makes it great and easy for getting around and for catching a taxi. It is also right across the street from Camden Yards and a few blocks away from M&T Stadium if you are looking for a place to stay while catching either baseball or football games. The free breakfast was is pretty much a deluxe continental breakfast. They have eggs, make your own waffles, fruit, cereal, yogurt, etc. The overall dining space is really clean and if there isn't any room to sit, you can easily take your food up to your room. Another thing that is helpful here is the parking. It's a little pricey at $29/night but you can take it in and out as often as you can and when you check out, even though you have to leave the hotel at noon, your car can stay in the lot until 3PM if you wanted to leave your car and explore a bit before leaving. I would probably look into staying here again since I had a great experience and it's recommended if you are looking for a place to stay in Baltimore!What a nice surprise this hotel was.  The rooms were very comfortable, quiet and updated.  We had a lovely view of Camden Yards.  The location was walkable to nearly everything that we wanted to see.  There was free continental breakfast which was perfect for getting up and out to see the city with children.  The kids loved the free popcorn, cookies and beverages in the lobby in the evenings. The pool area seemed a little bit worn/dated, but there was a super-attentive employee who handed my children fresh towels as they got out of the pool!  What service!The best part, though, was the price!  An unbelievable value for an East Coast US city!Best place you could stay if you're attending an Orioles game or Raven's game. The hotel is about five or six blocks (half a mile) from Inner Harbor, but only one block from the Convention Center and literally 70 feet from Camden Yards and a block from M&T football stadium. Costs will run 139 per room plus about another 30 for parking nearby.After staying at this hotel the furniture was in bad condition. Both rooms that we had were in poor shape. One of the rooms that we first saw had AC that was not working properly.  Other issues with the other rooms were sheets were dirty. The beds were in bad condition. Also one of the rooms had stains on the chair.  General Manager Mustaha Agourram called us and threatened us. The General Manager Mustaha Agourram was very defensive and did not was to resolve the issues. We are providing no stars. Due to poor management and lack of taking ownership of the situation. In addition told us never to comeback.  We reported to Hilton about the situation and provided comments that the general manager said. We would not recommend going to this hotel.Finally came back to Baltimore for a Vacation to show my lady the places I have lived and experienced. I was able to E-checkin to the best room the hotel has to offer, the King Suite Top Corner Room with the Panoramic view. I arrived to the Hotel to have my first set of keys not working...and when i got the second set to work and went in, the room was still under construction...which i was very disappointed thus we would not be able to stay in this particular room that i wanted us to be in, i told the front desk person that the room does not look ready since it seems to be under construction...he provided me with another room in a different floor but not the room style that i booked, which i let him know from the room. He was able to book us to another room which was the panoramic view king suite that i wanted but 3 floors down :(. He did the best he could and was able to comp us on 1 night of valet parking and something i wanted from the condiments, since it was in the evening time we wanted to rest up and check out the area to go eat as well. The next day i was able to give my honest feedback on my experience of the first of the 3 nights as a Diamond member and from the front desk lady i spoke to, she told me the parking and the whole stay was comped.....to find out the check out day that they had only comped the 1 more night parking, and we would have to pay the whole stay...I was NOT HAPPY when i heard it was only for parking..i have talked to the manager and she comped just one night, but in the end i am Very Dissatisfied!!!!.....The Hampton Inn had everything we needed. It was right across from the ballpark and we were there to watch the Yankees play. We got two rooms because we had 3 adults and 4 kids. So the king size bed with sleeper sofa was perfect. Our room was on the 7th floor and at the end of the hallway so it was nice and quiet. The room was spotless and clean. With fresh smelling linens. Including the ones in the closet for the sofa bed. The continental breakfast was everything the kids needed and the staff was friendly and accommodating. I would definitely stay here again.My wife and I stayed here one night with our 3 year old daughter. This was a very good experience. The hotel is very clean and the staff is very friendly and very good at what they do.The indoor pool is a little small, but the fitness center was very nice. The hotel is also right across the street from Oriole Park which was the biggest plus for us since we took in a game.We will defiantly be staying here in the future.I've been sitting on this review for a while but finally decided to post it:DO NOT BOOK A ROOM AFTER THEIR NORMAL CHECKIN TIME, DESPITE IT BEING AN OPTION VIA THEIR WEBSITE.I had book two rooms for my colleague and I to stay in. We are from Hawaii, and our travel time to the east coast is typically 10- 12+ hours. Our flight would arrive by midnight, and we were due to check in at around 2am on July 5. I had made this note when I booked the reservation online (as indicated on the website, if you plan to check in after their normal business hours). After making the reservation I gave them a call to confirm that it would be possible to check in at 2 am. I booked these rooms more than a month in advance and called three separate times leading up to our arrival date to confirm that we could check in at 2am. Each time I received a, "Yes, not a problem," confirmation. I even called the day before and got the okay. Well, when we arrived we were told we could not check in because all the rooms were booked as their files "still say we were in July 4." If that's the case, I wanted to know why we weren't told that each time I had called to confirm. The person insisted it is their policy and I pointed out that their instructions on the website say otherwise. Ultimately, they called and sent us to their more expensive sister hotel, the Hilton,  a block and a half away. At 3am. After we checked in there, and weren't even given a discount (off our Hampton reservation or our new Hilton stay) for their mistake. Before we left the front desk attendant at Hampton told us if we wanted a room on July 5, it would be first come first serve for people who arrive early to catch one of the rooms that a occupant was leaving early. So, essentially, even though we booked our rooms way in advance, they made a mistake and didn't have enough rooms and sent us away without a discount, they had the audacity to ask us to come early to get a room that wasn't guaranteed -- for one we had reserved in advance. Seriously. Regarding our actual stay: the Hampton rooms were cozy enough. Nothing blatantly wrong or unclean. However, regarding the breakfast option: my colleague and I pulled out bagels and cream cheese with mold in them. Both of us. It was a shame because the complimentary breakfast was part of why we chose the Hampton. We ended up getting breakfast elsewhere.The hotel was great. Every employee from the bellman to the receptionist to the ladies that cleared my room were so friendly. I was greeted every time I walked past an employee. The hotel was clean, my room was ready for me. They even granted me a late checkout due to my flight schedule. Also the breakfast was great. Lots of options and the counters were always clean and tidy. I don't know if I'll ever be in Baltimore again. But if I am, I'll stay here.It's tough for me to give a great review for anything in Baltimore because it is the single most screwed up and scariest city I've ever been to. OK, except maybe Newark.But the Hampton Inn was decent and conveniently located near the harbor and Camden Yards. The rooms were clean and very nice, despite their lack of mini fridges to keep drinks cold or tubs in the bathroom. Hampton Inns always have the most comfortable beds, even more so than pricier chains.However, the climate control in the room was set up very strangely, and despite being on the sixth floor, the alley our room overlooked was pretty noisy on and off throughout the night. Additionally, there was a large group there for some kind of convention, so the breakfast the next morning was just a wreck with really nowhere to sit and people fighting in and out of the buffet. We were eventually herded away from the large group into a meeting room. The breakfast options were only so-so anyway but provided enough sustenance until a seafood lunch could be obtained.The big kicker is that this hotel has NO parking lot and NO parking garage underneath it or nearby. Unless you're getting dropped off by a taxi, I would recommend you don't fall for the good prices that this Hampton Inn puts out there on Expedia and similar sites. They make it up with a whopping $29 overnight valet parking fee -- and unless you want to leave your car stranded out front on the street (in the middle of it, because there's no street parking), you have no choice but to pay for the valet parking.I really don't want to go back to Baltimore anytime soon. The place was just entirely too run-down with way too many rough characters hanging out on every street corner. There's no 'good' side of town, it seems. But if I do go back and need to stay overnight, I'll probably try somewhere else that at least has a parking garage and that's perhaps closer to the aquarium.Friendly staff, decent breakfast, pool and hotel gym were adequate. The room was clean. The only negative is that my room smelled like stale smoke, like the previous guests had smoked in the room.Definitely a fan of this hotel in this particular area of Baltimore.  I stayed here for a couple nights since I was in town for the AOTA conference.  The customer service here is spot on.  I had such a horrible and dreaded train ride coming (blame Amtrak, stuck in station for 3 hours with no updates or anything) and finally arriving at the hotel was such a sigh of relief.  Although I missed the opening ceremony and a few lectures I had planned to attend at the conference, I was somewhat happier at hearing that my room was ready for me and I was able to help myself to free popcorn and coffee/tea! Score!!-Room: The room I got wasn't too shabby or fancy.  The view itself was quite boring and somewhat of a downer; the windows faced some electrical plant which was not quite appealing.  I had thought I would get the view of the baseball stadium, Camden Yards, or at least something more scenic than a graffiti wall but nope.  However, the room itself was quite cozy and clean. No complaints about the upkeep. And best of all -- Who can say no to free wifi!!? -But the best part of my stay was the FREE BREAKFAST!! My oh my, everything tasted so good.  I had steak and eggs with home fries the first morning, eggs and kielbasa sausage on the second, and regular sausage and egg omelets with cheese on the third morning.  These are the "special" dishes they put out each morning.  But, you'll get your fresh oatmeal and add-on's, a diverse assortment of pastries (their banana nut muffins and banana scones were AH-MAZING and a MUST-TRY!!!), and fresh fruit that the morning staff keep replenishing.  But to top it off, the waffles..were the best!! Their waffle mix somehow produces some of the best tasting and soft, fluttery waffles I've ever had.  I've even looked up the mix and they sell it online!! All in all, I had a terrific stay at this hotel and would love to stay at other Hilton-associated hotels, especially the Hampton Inn.  The breakfast is something to look forward to, and of course, hopefully the view will be better next time (that's why I gave 4, not 5, stars). And, you'll definitely feel safe here since they lock the front doors at 9pm.  No entry unless you present/have your room card.  Throughout the day, they have fresh coffee/tea waiting for guests and also warm cookies for snacking. Considering this was my first time at the Hampton Inn, I must say I had a wonderful stay.Seriously very happy with our stay this weekend. The room was immaculate and had a beautiful view of Camden Yards. Front Desk was extremely helpful and friendly. We had an issue with the mini fridge, was replaced by a very nice maintenance man immediately. We our Hilton Honors members and this was our first time staying at a Hampton Inn, highly recommend staying here , you will not be disappointed. On side note if you our staying during the weekend you can park on S. PACA street for free instead of paying the $29 to valet.
review_content_20: I'll never understand why people complain about a hotel like this! This Hampton Inn is a very nice, clean, pretty hotel for an EXCELLENT price. Wifi is free, breakfast is free, and I stayed for a weekend for under $200 which was remarkable in the area. Think about it, just across the street there's a Hilton, where you're paying more money for the room, and you have to pay extra for wifi and breakfast!I had an extremely satisfying stay here at the Hampton Inn.One complaint I do has is regarding the staff. Mainly, those who work at the front desk. They are obviously very (too) comfortable at their jobs, and all weekend we saw them with their family members and friends leaning against the counter having conversations and not giving their full attention to the customers. It also seemed like they sort of had an attitude problem and like they were annoyed with the customers whenever anyone "interrupted" the conversation they were having with their loitering friends. That is my only complaint though. Great room, great price, great breakfast, great location. Would recommend in a heartbeat.Great hotel, incredible location, and fantastic value.  Clean and friendly service and extremely nice lobby and overall location to everything you want to do in downtown Baltimore.  Would definitely recommend it to others and would stay here again myself.I came hear with my friend Pete last week on our baseball tour trip. I am a real fan of this hotel. It is right across the street from the ballpark. As soon as we got there they welcomed us with a warm smile. The room was comfortable. The pool was great with a lifeguard that is a big plus for families with kids. The breakfast was outstanding and it came with the room. I recommend this hotel to anyone coming to Baltimore.We had a fabulous stay! From the moment we pulled up we were met with a gracious welcome... It was very easy to be there. They accommodated all of our needs, even our unusual ones. The staff was not just gracious but personable and engaging. The proximity to the orioles game was unbelievable. Shuttled to a fabulous dinner at Moes. The room was perfect. Highly recommend staying here!Stayed here on 9/21 with my friend. We were in town to see an Orioles game and I loved how close it was to the stadium, could even see it from the room window! Very convenient.  I did overnight parking at the Hilton across the street (not sure if I was allowed since I wasn't a guest, but I did anyway...oops?) So that was convenient too. Everyone was kind, no loud people, and all very clean. Concierge guy out front ran across the street to hail me a cab which was nice. Good experience.This hotel was really very nice. The location across from the ballpark was very nice. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was because of the amount of chlorine in the hot tub and the pool. Our eyes stung just being in the room. But overall the staff was great and the hotel was new and clean.I recently stayed at the Hampton Inn, Convention Center for about two weeks.  The room was spacious and clean but what really stood out was the friendly staff.  My husband had major cancer surgery at UMd Medical Center so this was no vacation.  The staff was so kind, always  smiling faces. One woman in particular who worked at the desk and always seemed to be there,  would ask how the day went and ask how my husband was. I really appreciated this.  I think I remember her name is Pearla. We hugged the day I left.My wedding reception was at M&T Bank Stadium so my newly married husband and I stayed at this hotel after all the partying was done. We had stayed here once before a couple of years ago when a friend of ours had their reception at Camden Yards. Both stays were nice, the rooms were clean and the staff was courteous. Checkout is at noon, which is wonderful. I see people complaining about the FREE continental breakfast, but we thought it was great both times. You can make your own waffle and there is plenty of coffee, juice, fresh fruit, bagels and muffins, cereal, danishes and yogurt. They also had western omelets and hash browns that were served hot. I don't know what people are complaining about, it was delicious! It's not a 5 star hotel room, but you also aren't paying 5 star prices.
