We ordered something, ate and sat there where it was warm. Not too long after security came down asking were we staying in the hotel. We told them "yes we checked out this morning". They said "Okay" and then left. 3 minutes later...a security lady came back telling us that we can not sit there any longer unless we buy something else because we were occupying that table ( MIND YOU THERE WERENT MANY PEOPLE IN THERE ). I just felt uncomfortable. For the price I paid for one night I should be able to sit wherever I wish especially if I'm not offending anybody. Was it offensive that my boyfriend and I were black and my boyfriend had dreads! Is that why we looked suspicious? Idk. But that will be my last experience staying at that hotel!Stayed here while dad was recovering from Pancreatic cancer surgery. This place was suggested to us by the accommodation line at John Hopkins. We were told over and over again that parking was covered. Come time to check out and were were charged 375 for parking. To make matters worse, the GM found it funny that the hotel is privately owned and the buck stopped with him. If you want to deal with rude managers and HORRIBLE customer service than stay here.Very nice, classic hotel that shows way above her listed star rating. I was not expecting the grand lobby or the excellent dining room in this reasonably priced hotel.Friendly staff that remembers your name, five star food, and a short walk to everything you want to see in Baltimore. Highly recommend!The Lord Baltimore hotel has old-timey charm and history (including a historical marker out front)--It seemed like a very appropriate place to stay for exploring a historic U.S. city. The room was smallish with contemporary decor and had obviously been freshly renovated--including the bathroom. The hotel has REAL, old-fashioned windows that actually OPEN. (I can't wait for the day when they begin building all hotels this way again. Sealed hotel rooms are an American phenomenon, I think, and an awful one.) The staff were very pleasant and welcoming and the bakery downstairs had excellent pastries.I'd definitely stay here again.The paneled ceiling, brass stairs, and other Lobby features give the initial feel of a higher rated hotel. The rooms are just ok but a little small. The beds are comfortable. No fan in the bathroom. Although ok Overall the rooms just don't live up to the promise of the lobby so I was a little disappointed.I recently stayed at the Lord Baltimore, and had actually stayed there a few years ago in it's previous incarnation as a Radisson. This is a standard, middle of the road hotel room- a few steps up from something like Days Inn, but not anything luxurious like the grand lobby may suggest- but honestly, I don't think you could get a better bed for this price in this part of Baltimore. It was so, so comfortable, and I'm assuming pretty new since the hotel was recently renovated. Between the bed and large flat screen tv, I was pretty happy with my small room. The neighborhood of downtown Baltimore doesn't have a whole lot to offer, but you are geographically poised to easily access the fun places in Baltimore by car, taxi, even by foot or the metro station across the street. But, if you want to hang out close to "home", the hotel has a nice bar, restaurant, and bakery. If you need a nice place to rest your head at a reasonable rate, I'd definitely suggest giving Lord Baltimore a look.I had a wonderful stay at the Lord Baltimore. My first room wasn't exactly what I wanted and the issue was very quickly dealt with the issue. Elise Wilson was so incredibly helpful and even called to make sure that I enjoyed my experience. This will always be the hotel I use in Baltimore.We went to Baltimore for a very last minute, quick 4th of July getaway. We were looking for a hotel that was close enough for a walk to the inner harbor and was decently priced. Lord Baltimore Hotel met both of those. The pictures of the recently renovated rooms helped as well. Overall, I was very pleased with this hotel. The staff i encountered were all kind and pleasant and very accommodating, specifically to my early check-in and late check-out requests. The hotel lobby was beautifully decorated and inviting. We stayed in a Deluxe King room where the over-sized bed was comfortable and the white linens looked clean and fresh. The newly painted gray walls, blackout curtains, and dark furniture were all wonderful touches to the fairly spacious room.One interesting thing I learned about this hotel AFTER we booked it was that it was believed to be haunted. I'm not sure I would have decided to stay here had I known this beforehand, but considering none of the reviews I read online were of terrified, screaming guests, I figured maybe it wouldn't quite be that scary. And overall, it wasn't. While I will admit to leaving every single one of the lights on and to sleeping no more than 30 minutes the entire night, this was all due to my overactive imagination. At no point in our stay did I see anything resembling a little girl in a cream colored dress bouncing a red ball nor did I see a well-dressed couple roaming the halls. I did, however, ask to stay in a room far away from the 19th floor where the sightings supposedly happen just in case. I will say that every time we waited for an elevator, we noticed that at least one was paused for an abnormally long time on the 19th floor. Strangely, upon checkout we learned that the entire 19th floor has been turned into meeting rooms and there were no meetings scheduled that entire weekend. I choose to not think about that too much..Is the hotel haunted? Probably. Did I see anything scary during my stay? No. Yes, I would recommend this hotel to others and yes, I actually would stay here again.Really nice lobby. Really boring room. This place looks like someone tried to put some nice finishes on a mid 2000s Marriott renovation. Not a bad deal, just not a "knock me out" hotel experience. Front desk lady was bizarre, as well.We booked a room at the Lord Baltimore for when we came into town for a wedding. The location of the hotel is quite good, you are close to the Inner Harbor if that's your thing, you are also close to Camden Yards and a quick car or preferably Uber ride to Federal Hill or Fell's Point/Canton. The staff was very friendly and helpful and the rooms were very nice, the bathrooms are very bright even if they are a little dated. The maids are on top of you about whether you are leaving that day or not, they knock pretty much once a hour which is somewhat annoying and why this review isn't 5 stars. We will probably stay here again in the fall when we have another wedding that is in Baltimore.
review_content_20: Booked a king room through Hotels. comWe checked into a queen room with a leaky toilet. Called the front desk and they would do nothing.Had to call Hotels. com to get a new room. The front desk moved us to a king room with no AC. The rheostat would only blast hot air. We spent all night opening and closing the window.We will NEVER stay at the hotel again!We stayed at the Lord Baltimore Sept. 13th-17th and I give it a pretty solid thumbs up. We booked before reading many reviews and after reading some, I got a little nervous about our non-refundable stay. My fears were unfounded and we wound up being totally happy with our stay.The valet staff are very friendly, quick and really just seemed like good guys. They gave directions, made suggestions and were very personable.  You enter the hotel and there is a nicely designed, albeit dark lobby. The furniture is all nice, nice decor, all that good stuff. Artwork throughout is meh but who really gives a crap? My only real complaint about the place would be about the front desk staff. They were by no means rude or dismissive but they weren't exactly warm and inviting. As we traveled around Baltimore, that seemed to be the norm for service industry workers so I think maybe it's a fairly regional thing (I'm used to a certain Midwest politeness, I guess). Just sort of matter of fact about what they were doing and that was that. Considering that was about the extant of my interaction with them, who really cares? So I felt a little bit like a nuisance for 5 minutes instead of like a welcome guest.  Our hotel room was located on the corner of the 17th floor. It was a very nice room and very comfortable. We walked in and there is a certain posh feeling you get thanks to the nice monogrammed comforter on the bed. The room was again fairly dark (in decor) but the windows and spacious nature of the room kept it from feeling uninviting. The room had a small fridge, safe, ironing board, hair dryer, clothes line in the shower for drying things... All nice, handy touches. The bed and pillows were super comfortable. I mean, I love getting home to my bed after a trip but this time not so much. I slept great in the room.  You can hear some street noise through the windows during the day but I never really noticed it at night and it didn't keep me awake at all (the heavy curtains being drawn probably helped with that). The room also had a desk & chair for working, a side chair & table and bench at the end of the bed.  Everything was in very nice condition. The bathroom was nice enough.  The bathtub area was the only part of the room that felt a touch dated, but not like 70s-80s dated but more nostalgic of the age of the hotel. The shower head is a little low for a 6' tall guy but this is also a 100 year old building. Most modern hotels have the same problem without the excuse of age.The room had free wifi or you could pay to upgrade to faster connection. We went with the free and it was just fine. It got a little spotty a couple times but that seemed to coincide with when they were filming a TV show downstairs (Oh yeah, they were filming House of Cards on various floors while we were there which was kind of cool and interesting and thankfully not a nuisance) and there were a bunch of people working and presumably all on wireless devices at once. Generally I just disconnected and reconnected and that took care of the problem.The elevators... Everyone bitches about the elevators. I won't be one of them.  there are 5 elevators. the 2 on the right have clearly been renovated. The middle one I never once rode in 5 days so I think it might be out of commission (possibly being renovated?). The second from the left was not an updated cab and the door moves a bit slow but otherwise it was just fine. Interior a touch dated but I assume that will be renovated like the 2 updated ones. The 1 elevator that did prove a little tricky is the one on the far left. We dubbed it the Magical Mystery Elevator. Yes, it is a bit of an adventure with that elevator, but at no point was I put out or freaked out by it. Going down to the lobby, it tended to take you to the Lower Lobby (home of the gym and a meeting room) instead. The first time it did that might be a little startling cause you don't know where you are. But there is a stair around the corner that leads to the street and into the lobby. So worst case scenario, you just lost 10 seconds of your life. Big deal. Going up, the 17th floor where our room was, wasn't available for whatever reason. So we'd have to go to the 18th floor (which had an open stair to the 17th floor right outside the elevator) so again, 10 seconds extra to get where we were going. On 1 occasion instead of stopping at 18, it went to 19 which is meeting rooms (and supposedly haunted) but then took us to 18 when we pushed it again.  Honestly if the elevators were a big problem for you, you need to relax and enjoy life a little.We got food from the bar (truffle fries, burger, chicken) and it was excellent. The bakery is convenient and good.  Sideshow (gift shop) is awesome and you should go there, for real!!If I'm back in Baltimore someday, I'd absolutely stay here again.I don't usually come on the internet to complain, but I was severely disappointed in this hotel. It looked quaint and lovely online, and had some good reviews. I usually enjoy staying in Historic Hotels in the DMV area.However, while the lobby is lovely, our room was...no other way to put this, crappy. They stuck us in a handicapped room directly in front of the elevators, so we got to hear everyone coming and going. No bathtub, just a large shower--and if we wanted to shower, we would have had to use the handheld sprayer. The bathroom's cleanliness was questionable at best--obviously has not been updated in a long time, and some moldy-looking areas. Needless to say, as we stayed there only one night, we didn't bother using the shower.The beds and pillows were very soft, but almost too soft. Clearly the beds have been used a LOT.I didn't bother to go back down to the front desk to complain; it was my husband's birthday and I didn't want to waste time being persnickety and changing rooms. We were only there one night, so we dealt with it. We certainly had a lovely view...of the air conditioning unit and another building. Basically, what a letdown. Not to mention adding insult to injury when they mistakenly charged my card for one night's stay after I had prepaid.Only big plus for me--self-parking is only $15, cheaper than or comparable to most city parking garages. However, it is about 5 minutes away so you have to schlep your bags. Just...I was really disappointed and I won't bother coming back next time I'm in Baltimore.My husband and I were in town and in need of a place to stay last minute and found Lord Baltimore Hotel. The hotel is beautiful and very clean. Love the room and modern look they have. We stayed on the 14th floor and had a great view of the city. All thanks to Vawn who was an amazing employee that helped us. If you want quality in your customer service then ask for him. The down side is that parking is a bit difficult to find if you don't mind parking on the street. They have valet parking but they charge 20%....needless to say we parked at the meters across the hotel which is $1 every hour Monday-Friday from our understanding. We only needed to park for a few hrs so it wasn't a burden for us.Our stay here was super comfortable. This was a very modern, elegant hotel. Didn't have any glitches throughout our stay and got a more than reasonable late checkout. We checked in a little late but still ended up with our king sized bed, score! The front desk was very pleasant and peppy, qualities that should be standard but are hard to find these days. The room itself was very clean and spacious. I docked half a star because the bathroom was a little on the small, cramped side as well as the vanity table area was crowded with the coffee maker. I also docked another half star because breakfast should come standard with a hotel of this stature. I really like that it was right across from the Charleston Metro Station. I would come back here again. Cheers!Three years ago, Maryland Deathfest. Saturday night. I split from the group I'm rooming with and hang out with my friend around 3 AM. He meets up with his friend who is staying here. Said friend informs us that the door to the rooftop is unlocked. We steal said friends' roommate's beer and have a few until we run out. I state that my group has plenty of beer at the hotel I was staying at. Instead of coming back to a room of slumbering metalheads, the whole fucking room is awake and ready to rage. We lug a cooler full of beer a couple of blocks to this place, and party on the rooftop until sunrise. A very hammered Guy decides to seize the day and piss off the roof of a 20+ story hotel. Looking back, it's one of the most frightening things I've ever done. This hotel gets 4 stars for facilitating this crucial life experience.Beautiful hotel, friendly staff all the way around, awesome gift shop with lots of unique things, great food in the deli/bakery. The rooms were nice. Loved the old school charm of the bathrooms and showers. All though the hotel was renovated, it's kept it charm of being an older hotel. I'd definitely stay here again if I'm ever in Baltimore.Comfortable, king size bed!  Fridge!  Nice big flat screen TV, free water in my room.  And a Haunted ghost story to go with it!  Great location!  Walking distance to Little Italy and the Harbor.  Love this hotel!  Always happy to stay here!  Great, friendly staff, too!We were coming into town to meet up with friends for dinner and hit the casino and chose to stay here based on location and price.  I wasn't worried about having a ton of amenities since we weren't going to be in the room much and really just needed a bed and a place to shower.  The lobby was quite pretty, the room was clean but the bathroom was clearly not included in any of the renovations that have been done. The bed was comfortable so that requirement was met, but when we woke in the morning and attempted to shower we found there was no cold water.  Literally, the cold water wouldn't turn on making it impossible to shower with the added bonus of not being able to flush the toilet.  When we checked out shortly after this discovery we told the person at the front desk of our difficulty to which he replied "Oh really?  Well I'm glad that I was able to get your check out taken care of for you".  We couldn't even get a feigned "I'm sorry for your incredible inconvenience"?  The customer service response stunk as much as we did...We decided to stay there because we had a family member going to John Hopkins Hospital and it was the same week that the riots and National Guard took over baltimore.  Easy to get back and forth since the hotel provides a taxi (Arrow Taxi). The problem is with the hotel itself. It "looks" like they did remake, but a closer look,  they did a cheaply and unsafe makeover...The ice machine wasnt on every floor and the area that used to have it was old and nasty. The eleavator signal area above one of them had a hole and just left there. The first night we got there, the TV and the mini fridge didnt work, so we called the front desk that told us they'll call maintance which never showed up. I took a look and found that they had 4 plugs into 1 wall outlet and you had to "play" with it to get anything to work. Huge fire hazard if you ask me! The next day, my wife takes a shower and the soap dish falls off the wall, almost falling on her foot! It hit the tub and peices went everywhere. We went downstairs and told the front desk about it and we got the "sorry, we'll call maintance" and we left to go to the hospital.  We got back later that night, tired and went to bed till we got a knock on the door at 11:35 PM and they tried to come in. Lucky, I put the hook on the door before going to be and found out it was the maintance guy, come to fix the soap dish! He wasnt told that someone was staying in the room nor was told to fix it during the day! We left the next day and glad we did! Oh and we ate at the hotel bar. Over priced and the cooking was all over the place. I wouldnt eat there again nor stay there no matter what the cost!Price was not bad bad. Toilet overflowed came to fix and left dirty towels on the ground. The restaurant for breakfast they tuned us away Bc they said they were backed up. She was rude about it too.Standard hotel quality, clean, simple and with some french accents. The food was not particularly spectacular that was catered for an event at the hotel nor the French Kitchen. It was just ok, and not as exquisite as the interior looks. The service was efficient and courteous, I'd be more than happy to stay at this hotel again--but most likely not for dining.Stayed here for a wedding. Was put in a newly renovated corner room. Pretty nice - the decor reminded me of Scandanavia hotel room - sparely and simply furnished. No frills but a good room. Location good - easy 10 minute walk to the harbor area.Wedding reception was held here. Very nice - seemed like they allowed outside caters which generally means you'll get better food (and we did have good food).If I was to stay in downtown Baltimore again, if the price was good, I would stay here.i stayed at the Lord Baltimore after attending the Gold Cup quarterfinals. It was a great stay.  To begin, the check in was swift and very pleasant (and I checked out by phone so there was no wait)  Also, the hotel is very close to downtown.  We were able to walk to the stadium in about 10 minutes. The Deluxe King room is great,  It is very spacious and the bed was incredible-so comfortable.  Also, our room was on the  10th floor and  was exceptionally quiet.  It is a little pricey, but I felt like I got my money's worth.  There are many other hotels in that area and many are less expensive, but I doubt they are as comfortable and quiet.I stayed here one night for the Baltimore Improv Festival.  This hotel has a lot of old charm.  Keep in mind this isn't a modern hotel, so hedge your expectations. With that said, our rooms were clean and we had plenty of hot water.  The front desk was extremely helpful with our reservations and assisting us with finding where we needed to go.   The valet service was also very speedy.The free wifi can be spotty.   Don't expect to stream movies but it's good enough.  I wish I had more time to hang out in the lobby.  They had a piano player there an relaxing there in the evening with a drink watching people move in and out would have been fun.**all the positives***The staff was WONDERFUL. From the valet, to the concierge, to the people working at the cafe downstairs. Every single person I interacted with was warm and friendly and seemed to have my best interests in mind. I am a customer service oriented person so this is the first thing I look for. The place was very clean. I have no complaints at all. A lot of older buildings can smell musty, but not here. The room smelled good, the bathroom was clean as a whistle and the bed linens were in excellent condition. It had a ton of historic charm, so much better than I would have gotten at some huge chain hotel. And also the location was perfect and made most of the city walkable. *what I would correct*Nothing here is a true complaint. I also noticed that other reviewers mentioned renovations. It was not evident that the Reno is still going on, but if it is, then the below comments may not matter. 1-bathtub surround needed new tile and grout. The rest of the room appeared up to date, so the inside of the shower sort of stood out as outdated. 2-the exhaust in the bathroom was not operable. If the work done to date in the bathroom is to last awhile, this needs to be corrected. 3-the heat and a/c kept fighting. We did not touch any of the controls in the room, but it seemed to waffle between overly warm and too chilly. We could hear the heater kick on and then the a/c a little while later. Temperature control needs to be worked out. Overall, however I cannot speak well enough of this place. THANK YOU to all of the staff for a wonderful experience. I would stay again if I get down the Baltimore way.We stayed here 3 nights at the beginning of August for a convention.Area:  The hotel has no direct control of these but are important to know.  These aren't included in the rating.PROS:  It's a very short walk to the convention center and harbor.CONS:  I didn't feel completely safe walking around outside the hotel especially during the evening.  I stayed on the 15th floor and could hear the traffic below at all times of the day.  This was annoying with trying to sleep.Hotel:  Relating directly to the staff, restaurants, building, etc.PROS:  The renovation does make the hotel feel nicer.  I liked the proximity locks on the doors as opposed to traditional sliding method.  I put the staff as both a pro and con.  One guy was nice, the other was dismissive.  Free standard WiFi was one of the selling points for me.CONS:  By far my biggest complaint is related to the dining options.  Specifically, I was looking for any sort of food - bar food would have been sufficient - at 10:30pm.  I asked the front desk what was open and I received a couple of delivery menus (this is the dismissive employee).  Upon further inquiry, I was instructed that there was nothing open near by and the hotel had no dining options this late.  Let me reiterate that it was only 10:30pm.  This alone will cause me to choose a different hotel next year.  Despite the renovation, there was a stain on the carpet in our room and our faucet wasn't secured completely.  It appears as if the windows were not included in the renovation which is likely why so much noise made it into the room.  I thought maybe the website didn't list a pool as an amenity but there was actually one.  Sadly, no pool here.Stayed here for a night a few days ago.  Love the historical charm this has!  Room was clean, updated and comfortable. Bathroom could use some updating, but other than that, it was great!Stayed at Lord Baltimore hotel for 2 nights during end of April and was very disappointed. Pictures of room that I've seen on website are EXTREMELY deceiving. Our "king superior" room was very small, door opened and you stumble right into the bed. Bathroom was tiny and outdated, shower was stained. The only thing I loved about this hotel was it is walking distance to absolutely everything in the city (Camden Yards, Inner Harbor, etc) great location but for the price I expected more.This hotel is so beautiful, and the staff was superb. It is close to the inner harbor and perfect for other sight seeing. The decor was beautiful and tasteful, and the rooms were super clean and the beds were very comfortable. I will come back again and stay here for every Baltimore trip!
review_content_40: Just stayed 1 night here.Despite some of the previous review this place is pretty nice.I needed a place close to Baltimore Arena. Everything in the area for the day was super expensive. I found this place on one of those last minute places for a reasonable price. No room choice was available on the last minute website. Upon checking in I asked if I could have a room with 2 beds. Request granted without issue.Lobby was nice, room was very nice. Elevators could use some fixing up.I did not eat at the restaurants.Location is very close to Baltimore Arena and not far from Inner Harbor.My room was on the 11th floor. Despite being on the 11th floor there was a bit of noise from the road below. Specifically there was a manhole cover in the middle of Baltimore Ave that was loose, so when cars would drive over them it would make a sound like a cymbal on a drum set. So all night long it was klank klank from the road.Also I was not a big fan of their garage, it's $15 per night there, but when you pull into the garage they want to park your car for you. I guess watching that Ferris Bueller movie makes me a little suspicious of people that park your car for you. I was able to park on Baltimore Ave directly across from the arena for the same price of $15.So all in all I would not mind coming back here I would just request a room facing the other way because of the manhole cover. I would hope they could get the city to fix the loose one.Not at all impressed with this hotel for the money. Rooms were OK but, very drafty. Old windows in the room. You could feel the cold air rolling in from outside. The shower, from the time we got there was acting up. You would get burnt and then froze from the hot and cold water cutting on and off. Then the next morning the cold water cut off all together. No working toilets and only a shower w hot water. I had to drag my things to another room just to shower. What did we get for the inconvenience, 15% off our bill of $150. Not to mention, if you don't pay $37 for the valet parking, your lugging all your bags over a city block to get back to the hotel as parking is the next block and half over and not on site. WOULD NOT RECOMMEND!!Time for a gut renovation. This hotel is old as sin. Priced right for what what it is.The staff at the front desk and valet were great. Extremely nice and helpful. The bellhop was good but he recommended a terrible place to eat. I'm literally writing this review from the toilet. I probably would not stay here again until a renovation is completed.Faded glory, a short walk from the Inner Harbor.I recently stayed here on a business trip.  The hotel is very grand, and the valet & check-in staff were friendly and efficient.  However, the elevators took you on a mystery trip (ala Roald Dahl) stopping at random floors!  The rooms were a little dated, but wifi reception was good.Worn and weary, but undergoing a renovation.Stayed here last weekend as we were in town for the Jets v Ravens game.The room we had was big and clean, The bed frame was a little suspect though. If you sat at the foot of the bed on the right side, the bed would tilt up. Pretty hilarious after a couple of cocktails.  The fitness center was closed for renovation and the business center consisted of one computer.The hotel bar poured a stiff drink.You can see this once was a pretty nice hotel (built in the 1920's), with all the accents of that era. Now it's worn and weary, with black electrical tape holding down the carpeting by the elevator bank on our floor.If they do the renovations right, this will be a nice spot to stay. They were filming an episode of HBO's VEEP while we were here. You might see me checking in in the background. I had my Jets jersey on.Not a bad experience, but not amazing. The room was clean and spacious, and the bed was comfortable! However, the temperature regulation in the room wasn't great, we felt suffocated at night even with the thermostat set low. The decor of the room was nice but there was no view, and the color of the room was kind of dreary. The service wasn't great, always felt like I was bothering someone to help me. Overall, the hotel was nice and I would recommended for cleanliness and location.Horrible customer service from the night staff (not the valet - but front desk), especially the females. Also the breakfast staff will not wait on you if you don't "wear your money" on your sleeve, so to speak. I was in scrubs and i never got waited on like the older, richer-looking couples did. And no matter how much you eat, it's a 10.55 charge regards of their lack of customer service and to-go boxes. The night staff will also not answer the phone for a number of rings with the hopes that the customer will hang up. They also lack room service or courteous to help you with your bags once you've checked out (or to be nice to you). Randomly they will also have their "Monday and Tuesday" rate go up about 30$ for no reason. DO NOT RECOMMEND.Went here tonight for Charm City Countdown. The worst NYE party ever!!! The layout did not work for the amount of people that were in attendance. They ran out of beer at multiple bars.The end of the night was the worst. We knew that there would be a long line for coat check, so we tried to hang back and chill until things calmed down. Unfortunately, they forces everybody out at 1:45. We finally got our coats at 3:30 after almost getting into multiple fights. The hotel and the promoters should have known of the problems that could of happened since they have held this party in past years. Do not come here!!!A group of us from my company stayed here to prepare for an important sales presentation. We chose it because its location was only a block away from where we had to do the presentation. I would NOT stay here again under any circumstances.First: the few positives:1. The staff were very friendly and helpful, except for one bartender (a man) who ignored us for 30 minutes to help new arrivals when all I wanted was to pay my check. The front desk clerk was cheerful and friendly, and the people who worked on our meeting room were professional and courteous. The doormen were very helpful and polite.2. Most of the food  was good in the bar and meeting room (catered from meeting services). The only thing that was mediocre was the hamburger I had in the bar.3. The bed was comfortable.4. The lobby is historic and attractive, except for the unpolished brass (see negative #8 below).Now the negatives:1. No room service. I can't remember the last time I was in a supposedly full-service urban hotel that didn't have room service.2. The elevators from hell. They got stuck or went to wrong floors. There are five (which they don't need) and the one on the extreme left should be removed. My colleagues got stuck at least three times, and it would stop about a foot or two away from the floor so you had to climb up or hop down. The one on the extreme right worked fine.3. Rooms that are TINY. No desk!! Who ever heard of a modern business hotel with no desk?4. Bathroom so small that you can't open the door without going on the side of the toilet. And, with a bathroom so small, they chose to use a sink that has no surface area. I'm a man and I only had a few things to lay out, but there was no room. I can't imagine how a woman would deal with it with makeup, cosmetics, hair dryer, etc.5. No place to charge electronics. There was a single socket on the bedside lamp, but the shape of the lamp blocked the socket for  iPhone or iPad chargers, or my computer charger. The only socket was behind the heavy dresser.6. My window was so dirty on the outside I literally could not see through it. The view was terrible anyway.7. When I checked in, there were dirty towels on the floor behind the bathroom door, apparently from the previous resident.8. The old hotel had a lot of brass doors and walls ... coming in from the street, the revolving doors were brass and glass, and all the elevator doors were brass as were part of the elevator wall. It appeared that the brass hadn't been polished in months, maybe years. It was literally disgusting.9. The carpets in the three old elevators were filthy and grimy. When the elevator doors were open, you could see major crud and grime in the slots where the doors open and close.10. The temperature controls were faulty. My room, and our meeting room, never got to the temperature set on the thermostat.11. Check out time is 11 am. I cannot remember the last time I stayed in a hotel with a checkout before noon, especially in a big city. I think the last time was 1977.I will never stay at the Lord Baltimore again, and I highly recommend others avoid it.Don't waste your money. We came here using the Valentines Day package and I should've stayed home. The valet was horrible. It took 10 minutes to get someone to even acknowledge we were waiting. We ate at the LB Tavern... Took two hours. Most of that was slow wait service as they were behind the bar chatting. We were able to bond with our fellow diners over the horrible time. To top off the trip, when we went to leave, Valet told us it would take 45 minutes to get my car... Turns out it was right up the road and they were using it as a runner car because it's 4wheel drive and it had snowed that night. Terrible staff and overall experience and many others felt the same way.Surprised by the review regarding customer service. When I showed up at 2 a.m., I was warmly greeted by the night watchman who was more than eager to show me around the hotel and give me a history lesson. This is a historic hotel, which means you might encounter lingering elevators and amenities that aren't as readily accessible as the Hyatt or Hilton, but isn't that the point of staying here? Character. The Lord Baltimore has plenty. I had heard ghost stories, but this is not the Chelsea. The hotel was inviting and comfortable. The bed was fabulously soft and the floor quiet. I had a great night's rest. My only disappointment was that visiting on a Monday meant that the French Kitchen was not open. If you happen to arrive on a Sunday or Monday, make your way to Sotto Sopra. It is a great little Italian place around the corner.Booked a room a lil last minute for a night in town for a wedding. All the main necessities of a hotel we're covered and we were overall satisfied with our stay. The rooms, beds, linens and decor was nice and well done. Everything was clean and in great shape. The thermostat was easy to use, which helped as the summer humidity had arrived just in time for our visit.The little inconveniences that made our stay less than stellar include: 1) unavailable room key at check in due to a technical glitch2) inadequate staff at the front desk, which left us a long wait at check in, further waits when checking on the status of our keys, and unanswered phone calls to the front desk. 3) lack of hair dryer for the lady (likely important to some lords as well)4) it's a little inconvenient to have the parking garage down the street but understandable for a downtown area. Would help If the location and process could be better described on the website and when asked on the phone.For me, this hotel rates Higher for facilities, presentation and comfort. Average to Low for amenities (e.g. lack of hair dryer, budget coffee maker and grind)Low for services and staff. Everyone was nice and courteous, but just not up to game, and not delivering top quality hotel service.I booked a stay at this hotel and paid in full in advance thru Priceline.  I was asked for my credit card for "incidentals" which is a normal practice; HOWEVER, the hotel instead charged my card for the entire stay and has refused to return the money.We stayed here for a night while we were in town to go to the Do Or Die Mystery Dinner Theater at the Grand Historic Venue, because their "go-to" hotel next door (Embassy Suites) was booked up. Very short walk to the GHV (like barely 2 blocks) and also a reasonable walk (or quick cab ride/drive) to all the stadiums, centers and the harbor.This hotel is very beautiful and they have done a good job with the restoration. The room we had was just renovated, with nice decor and a comfortable bed. It was nice that our room come with complimentary wi-fi and "reduced rate" parking at a nearby garage (213 W. Fayette St). BTW - The Lord Baltimore does not have a garage, so plan accordingly if you are driving. Extremely friendly and helpful staff - The next time we visit Baltimore, this place will be on our list.We enjoyed our stay. Everyone was super friendly and helpful, the place was clean, the bed was comfortable, and the location was convenient. The biggest downside was that we booked a king and got a double (way different, and while the two of us can sleep in a double just fine, not every couple can).But this was kind of evened out by the fact that they let us check in super early (around 11am). I chose the hotel because it was close to UMD Law, which I was visiting, AND not far from the aquarium (which is awesome by the way). So the location was perfect for that.We're from DC and we're used to the city: I had to laugh at everyone that complained about the neighborhood. This is downtown Baltimore guys, not the suburbs. The neighborhood was just fine for walking through, and a couple blocks from the sanitized tourist area where the aquarium and all the suburban shopping is. Also, a longer walk to Fells Point, but doable (although we took a cab back).Okay experience... The staff was friendly and the bakery had delicious soup and sandwiches. Unfortunately, the bathroom was dirty and the bed sheets had hair all over them... Got the room at a low rate so can't complain... But it was gross seeing that hair...So... I decided to book a last minute trip to Baltimore and used hotel tonight to find a location.The reviews are on point for this hotel and they deserve a three star rating... Definitely nothing more.The gentleman at the front door were extremely helpful and exceptionally nice... A+ for customer service!The lobby is nice... dark but cozy! They have a TV, nice decor, fireplace and bar. I can't give my opinion on the restaurant because I didn't eat here. The elevators... Oh my goodness... Where do I begin! They are old... Skip floors and should be renovated. Actually they do have ONE that has been upgraded but the other ones are questionable! Truly... They need to put at least three of them out of service and use the space for something else! Do not.. I repeat use the one to the far left!The bed was nice... Comfortable but there are NO extras! My room had no lotion.. But did have shampoo and conditioner. You can clearly hear ALL that goes on outside through the windows but then again... It is in the middle of the city! The internet is clearly questionable... Intermittent... Not suggested if you have important deadlines to meet for work ....the thermoset did not work properly. We set it on 64 degrees and it was still not comfortable... Slept without covers! So if you are looking for the bare minimum...  This place will work. Take the stairs... Bring your own lotion... Wear light clothes to bed in the summer months... Bring earplugs and you will be just fine.I say all that to say... It was an an experience  and I will not stay here again! Not even worth the hotel tonight price!So...are you like me and have joined the 21st century?  By that I mean do you like technology and all the things it's meant to give you?  Well I do.  This hotel doesn't do any of those things. My employer has opted to put me and many of my coworkers up here for 6 weeks.  I'm on week 5.  I checked in the end of June 2014.  I was ready to be done with this travesty of a hotel by 4th of July weekend.  Hot running water?  Well...in the shower I can have hot running water once I figure out what time it's hot...because it apparently can't keep up with the number of guests it can support.  Like hot water in the sink to shave with?  I do.  Sadly most days it takes 10 minutes for that water to actually get hot.  Oh...but it doesn't stay hot in my sink long enough for me to shave...so I decided to get that done at the barber shop....because finishing a shave with cold water is enough to piss a person off.  Elevators that work?  Nah...that's no good either.  They stop on random floors, they don't stop on the floors you want to get to, and heaven forbid you need to get somewhere when they're busy.  I've seen people wait more than 20 minutes to get an elevator.   So I bet you'd opt to take the stairs.  Well as far as I can tell, beyond the 3rd floor the only stairs I can find are the fire exit stairs.  Well...on the 4th of July weekend, my wife came out to spend the weekend with me, and we were getting up and getting ready to go out.  Suddenly the fire alarm goes off.  Now I don't blame them because some random idiot pulled the fire alarm.  However, my wife and I opted to take the fire stairs down (because we didn't know it was a false alarm).  Imagine our surprise when we get to the fire exit going outside only to find out that the door was locked.  Had it been a real fire, we'd have died here.  So we go back up looking for a door to get out.  The one we found was in the kitchen...it was open.  Sadly that might've been one of the most likely places for a fire to start.  Needless to say the kitchen staff was quite surprised to see us.  Why you ask?  Because the fire alarm only went off on a couple of floors...so they had no idea why we were there.  As we walk out of the kitchen we got to walk through the restaurant, full of guests, also blissfully unaware of the fire alarm.  Hazardous much?  I would already have left here if I had an option.  I wish I'd thought to call the fire marshal that day.  Alas I didn't.  Oh...and to top it all off, the manager working was not only unapologetic, but downright insulting to my wife.  We complained later to another manager, but we got platitudes, but no offer of any sort to attempt to make it up to us.  They could've offered to buy us a drink.  They could have offered to buy us breakfast, lunch, dinner...nothing.Let me get back to the 21st century for a bit.  If you've joined me in the modern era, I bet you'd like WIFI.  Well, as it happens they have wifi.  I guess.  AT&T's 4g whatever is better than their WIFI most times.  They have free wifi.  I averaged about .25gb down, and 8gb up.  The heck do I need so much up and no down for?  So they also have wifi to pay for.  it's like $10 a day or some such.  Since I'll have been here for 40 days or so once I'm done, I thought this was exorbitant.  So naturally I asked if their was anything they could do.  They gave me a code for their pay for WIFI.  Yay I thought.  Sadly it ranges between .5gb down and 1.5gb down with a rare spike of 2-3gb down (presumably when no one else is on.).  If I had paid for their wireless, I'd be livid.  Instead I'm merely disgusted.I won't even get into how when I called to check on my reservation, I was in a king room, and when I got here to check in (and I was almost certainly the first out of more than 100 or so coworkers...perhaps more...by several hours) I got stuck in a queen room, even though some of us are in queens and some kings, because of the large number of rooms given.  On the first day, I wanted to lock up my laptops.  Alas, I had to get someone to come fix the safe as it wasn't working.  My alarm clock?  well...it keeps time I guess, but the alarm doesn't work. Thankfully I use my own cell phone for that.  Aside from all those problems, the majority of the staff was friendly enough.  The place seems clean.  I just wouldn't want to stay here again.  I'd rate it lower, because I'm still pissed about the fire alarm and the fire stairs.  If they actually ever have a fire here, I expect that plenty of people will die.  Hopefully it won't happen until after I leave.I got the skinny on this place.They have been purchased by some folks with an amazing vision for what will be.So disregard everything you may have read/seen.The facelift will be done by next Spring.This place will be transformed into a modern art mecca.Oh, BTW, there are legit ghosts here (in case you want to have some extra fun).This hotel feels like it *used* to be 4-5 star back in the good old days... but has not seen renovation in a while.  Its got a nice lobby with paintings, marble floors / staircases, and beautiful light fixtures, but everything just feels old and outdated (for example the CRT TVs in the rooms).  With a small cosmetic face-lift, this hotel could easily return to its glory days, but I understand why its not worth the investment to the owners - there are a lot of large newer hotels neighboring it, and Baltimore is not the most popular destination... so the general mood around here is that of a sleepy fly (not much business).In any case, I came here for a meeting, and the hotel is just two blocks (less than 5 minute walk) from the Conference Center where the meeting was taking place.  Considering the alternatives (double the price, but one block away instead of two), I went with this one. And, in retrospect, I believe I had made the right choice!The room was fine, everything clean, nobody bothered me, had plenty of clean towels, soaps and shampoos, iron and board, etc.  Downstairs there is a bar and a gift shop, and I believe the hotel has some kind of free shuttle service.  The only bad thing I can think of is the wifi.  Sometimes it would kick you off, or would be slow... but I found that there are other hotel's wifis in range that you could get on to, when this happened, lol.
review_content_60: Spent the night at The Lord Baltimore for an Os game. Clean and friendly. We thought the beds were very comfortable. Yes, the elevators are a little wonky. But, it's an old hotel. Part of the charm!Stayed at the Lord Baltimore Hotel over the weekend.Pros: Nice lobby, especially compared to some in the area.Friendly and helpful front desk staff.Free wifi worked good enough (a bit slow). Location is convenient to stadiums.Cons:There was a massive hairball in the room upon arrival. Other evidence of shoddy cleaning existed as well.The TVs are from the 80s. We don't really watch TV but they gave the room an antique roadshow vibe that wasn't pleasant.Phone in our room didn't work. Beds are very uncomfortable, the rolling bed we requested was much more comfortable.Overall if you plan on going to Baltimore, don't go. But if you have to go, and you find a deal for the Lord Baltimore hotel it isn't a completely unpleasant choice.Take a bullet proof vest.Worst management ever! 1) I arrived late and they overbooked. so I slept in a "room" that had a pull out couch.2) I came down in the morning as instructed to get a new room and the front desk guy who looked about 12 years old rudely told me I had to wait till 11 when people had checked out. 3)when I finally got my room the key maker was not functioning so I had to stay in my room once they let me in. instead of delivering my key I had to wait in line again to get the key. 4) my room was not cleaned today. housekeeping came by but I was still in the room. They did not speak English I told them to come back and they did not. 5) The elevators broke today and when I took the stairs the end on the first floor was in the kitchen of the bakery! when I got to the lobby I walked by the elevator a staff member bit my head off as I looked at the elevator telling me It was broken.My stay is not over...what will happen next. Go to the Hilton don't stay here!!!!Prrrrt Prrrrt Prrrrrrt!! (royal horn sounds) Welcome to The Lord Baltimore! Hotel is old and the architecture of the lobby is beautiful,this is actually the 2nd time I have stayed there & the rooms were updated since my last visit a few years back, but the elevators weren't....straight wacky...one wouldn't stop on our floor 5,another that would jus pass us right by...missing floor indicators & wires hanging (see picture)...really a shame because it's a nice old building! Staff was freindly & coffee shop in lobby was great & had fresh pastry & coffee! Parking...there's another star gone,they have a valet but I don't like people parking my car...I jus don't trust strangers with my car....sorry,but I don't...front desk directed me to a wayyyy diffrent lot then my last visit & we pull up & sit there...and sit there....the mindless attendant has no green tickets,I guess they are magical and needed to park my car...after 5 good minutes I had to get out & go to the window where mr.mindless had a giant ass stack of magical green tickets BUT told me that the desk doesn't tell people but there isn't any self parking & he has to park my car for me...ok then WHY did they make me drive 2 block away when I could have had my car valet at the lobby....what a bunch of crap & scam....I left & found the old garage from my last visit & $15 a day too...wayyyy cheaper then the magical green ticket lot....only gripe is walking back to the car they expect you to go all the way around the block to enter the garage because the staircase coming out from the garage locks behind you....hint: pull the glass door hard & it opens,just watch out for the massive pile of bum feces infront of the door that was there when we left....I love Baltimore but the vagrants need to be delt with....hey stay at the hotel,grab some joe & a scone but watch the poo poo on your shoe shoe!Not great .The best staff were the valetTo be fair they in Baltimore which is kinda dirty ( check CDC data)they say they are about to remodel, but dicey hotels always say thatits a messStaying at this hotel was not a positive experience. I realize they are planning to modernize, but it can't happen soon enough!  The beds are hard as wooden planks. There is no room service. The carpeting is worn and filthy. The ceilings are buckled and creepy. The elevator takes you to the lower level which is off limits. Oh and the elevators are not clean, just gross and scary. The only positives were most of the people, specifically housekeeping and wait staff. We also met the chef. She was lovely and the food she prepared was delicious.Beautiful renovation. The dining area reminds me of Louisiana more than Paris, but this place was really restored with love and an appreciation of its history in mind.So, I have booked a club room. I am in it right now. Turns out, the club room really isn't a club room as the "club" isn't in service right now. Some sort of "Autocon" or something like that conference is here now. When I checked in with valet parking, the guy had no idea what to do. Check in was a disaster...I was not told that the "club room" was not in operation due to the convention in town, but after I walked away, I asked what time the club breakfast was, and they said, "Oh" and handed me an envelope. I read the letter in the elevator that said it was not open this weekend and to accept gift CARDS (note the S) worth 10$ to use at the bakery or French Kitchen. I called downstairs (I had paid for the club which advertised club privileges, wine and cheese, breakfast for two, and valet parking. Reception told me they would give me 2 more cards, as they inadvertently only gave me one and to come down. Went down, they said one card was enough - I asked, for two? After much debate, they gave me one more card...after further debate and for the manager who said, "This isn't my section" and a trip to the bar to confirm, I was given two more cards. Went back upstairs to look for info about the restaurants...none...no book, no info, no nothing. Went down and asked and they said they don't give information out about the hotel or the restaurants in the hotel. I went to the restaurant --- instead of the advertised special that the reception pointed out to me was available that night (turns out, it was only lunch, not dinner), I was told by the lovely restaurant manager that he would give me the lunch special, and would make sure breakfast fit within their limit (it otherwise would not -- the 10$ cards would not cover the breakfast, let alone the drinks promised). After dinner, sure enough, the bill was not as it was promised. The dinner itself -- apparently the first night they offered the menu -- head's up, you need to test out the food! -- the French Onion Soup was cold -- cheese not melted, and just cold. Sent it back to get warm, it was warmed, but no cheese apparent... I was told the cheese must have made the soup cold?! My daughter's crab cake was good. The beef bourguignon was cold as well. I gave up. I guess tomorrow the eggs will be cold too. Bagged the rest of the dinner, brought up to the bedroom, decided to watch a movie and eat the cold soup...and well, no movie channels. A fail all around.  So, if you are going to close the club level, then you really need to advertise that BEFORE people buy the club package. Your staff needs to know what is going on, and for goodness sake, why don't you have a book in your room that has the menus, operating hours and hotel information in it? Can you not have movies available? I should have gone with the cheaper hotel...I thought that by including breakfast, the club mark up would make it worthwhile. Never again.The Lord Baltimore is located strategically between the more uptown (north) areas of Mt. Vernon and Mt. Washington, where there are wonderful Industry-Age landmark buildings, and The Inner Harbor area.  It was definitely to our taste as we appreciate older-style beauty and good value, but some may quibble as there is no room service (not an issue for us), and some quirks with the rooms (at least our room)--poor lighting-- we are a couple and there was only a nightstand on ONE side of the bed and no lighting or nightstand on the other--and the lighting in general was odd (no lights anywhere near a full-length mirror?).  The elevators can also be problematic during high-traffic hours--we were there for a convention and it sometimes took a while and by the time it got to the 4th floor where we were the elevators were already full, and there was no way I could see to walk downstairs.  Wi-fi is free which is a great pleasure to still find although I can't say it was the fastest I have ever encountered.  Fine for us though.  I really enjoyed the location--I am a big walker and it was easy to get anywhere--and the staff was very helpful.  Bonus points for the great LB Bakery/coffee place in the lower level; the pastries were fabulous and they had homemade gelato in great flavors.  And it was open late!  There's also a very quirky, fun gift shop that echoes the Visionary Museum in FedHill (a must-see).Here we go:First room was facing a building that was no more 40 feet away or so. The lights were on  that building all night and shining through the windows. This was probably west facing. There are curtain sheers but they are translucent, there are decorative end curtains but they don't actually extend across the windows so you won't be getting any darkness to sleep in. The water comes out of the sink brown right away.The tv is super old and does not fit the picture.The tv remote was missing it's backing and had duct tape holding the batteries in place. The door would not close on its own you had to use the key.The elevator often takes you to the lower lobby which is currently under construction. This has happened to me on at least 5 occasions. You have to ride the elevator to the lower lobby then go back up to the main lobby.Changed rooms which solved the window and the tv remote. Now the bed.Climb in and all the stuffing slides away. One side of the bed is massively firm and sits about 3" higher than the right side of the bed. I pulled the sheets aside and there is a queen mattress with a giant foam cutout fitted around it to make it queen size. On further review it doesn't even look like a mattress just a bunch of pads foams and egg crates...I am stuck here because of a conference reservation. Do not make the same most ask as me. Go elsewhere. I am getting worse sleep than I have ever had.Internet not workingFront desk not answering the phoneElevators not workingand NOW A PULL OUT COUCH BED......NO WAY       REALLYI would give it 2 and 3/4 but not quite 3 stars. Place is ok but not great. While I did not have a problem with the elevators like everyone else who reviewed seem to have, they were slow in the morning around checkout time.. Bed was pretty good, tv was nice. Where it fell short was, there was no view and the window was dirty on outside .. The shower head was way too low so anyone over 5'6" will struggle washing their hair.. We were on the 11th floor and I was woken up by sirens outside at 2:30 am.. Valet was expensive, but car was there when I called 10 minutes ahead like they said it would.Honestly, if you need a hotel within walking distance to the convention center or stadium then this is a good choice. The staff was extremely friendly and accommodating but that doesn't override the bad quality of the hotel. The elevators do not work well (takes you to the wrong floor and the outside door closes before the inside door) my bed was slanted in the middle and I had to sleep on one side, my coworkers bed broke in the middle of the night, and no hot water in the morning since everyone showers around the same time. The restaurant food was eh. But the staff at the coffee bar are so nice and the doormen were very sweet. Like I said, not terrible but not worth more than a hundred a night.I really enjoyed my stay at The Lord Baltimore Hotel. They are doing an amazing renovation and have done a great job keeping the integrity of the history, with the a modern/ boutique touch. The staff is wonderful at helping you feel welcome and attending to your needs. The owner is an amazing woman. I was very impressed with the restaurant and good quality and ingenuity. The fitness room is also quite nice.I imagine that after the renovations are complete, this will be one of the most spectacular hotels/ restaurant to be at.Nice folks who were helpful and kind. They are renovating it which will make is a snazzy place to stay. It's central and easy to move around. The bed was super comfortable and the shower was strong. I was very glad to stay in this hotel my whole family has stayed in. FREE WIFI!!!! See you next year.Went here last night for an event but got to see the hotel after the renovation. I was thoroughly impressed with the new decor, it was clean, classic, the customer service was top notch. I also toured the new rooms and they looked great. I strongly recommend this hotel. Best kept secret in Baltimore and I will def be staying here in the future!!!!Haven't seen a recent review and I'm really bored so I'll give my 2 cents.  I HATE hotels a lot...like maybe even more then the average person, but I kinda like it here.  The rooms are freshly renovated.  You can tell the place is old, but carpets, walls etc look really fresh.  I'm a ghost hunters fan so the appeal of the haunted 19th floor kinda got me interested as well.  Just a quick update the 19th floor is office space now and has no hotel rooms.  Bummer.  The only thing stopping me from giving 4 stars is the lack of vending machines and parking.  $30 to valet...ehhh.  Other then that it's pretty nice, I'd come back here.There is nothing good about this place. A black eye for the name Radisson for sure. Don't stay here, don't eat here, and enter the elevators at your own risk.Nice rooms and friendly staff but under renovation.  Some rooms no water, no workout room (they give a pass to a nearby gym but inconvenient in bad weather. Small bar. Wait for them to finish and could be ok.Booked a room for my daughter, who was there to check out a college and an inexperienced traveler. She arrived to find that the coffee bar closed for renovation and the restaurant closing before 9 pm! Oh, and there's no snack bar either although there was one advertised. She had to beg the restaurant to feed her and when the fish came (fish and chips) it was full of bones, so she ate the fries and went to find a vending machine. No machines anywhere in the building!! No other food available. The front desk told her to walk to 7-11 (really?!) She'd already seen a street fight break out below her window -- cops were called -- and rightly decided not to walk around Baltimore at night. The desk was unhelpful and huffy. Apparently, there was no clock in the room, no wash cloths or hand towels. The next morning, since there was no coffee bar, she had to go to the restaurant to order breakfast even  though she was pressed for time. It took the staff more than 10 minutes to get her a simple yogurt parfait. NOT a good experience!

review_content: Rooms were clean and comfortable. The staff were friendly and helpful. I booked with Groupon and had no problems at all with the reservation. The location was the best part. This hotel is within a short walk of many great restaurants and plenty of things to do. The light rail station is close by as are many bus stops. We only drove out car one time during our entire stay. The only negative things were the price of parking ($25 per day is outrageous for self parking) and no free breakfast. Every Holiday Inn Express I have ever stayed in had a free breakfast.  I also wish there had been a microwave in the rooms. We often had dinner leftovers that would have made good midnight snacks had we been able to reheat them.The location is perfect and so is the customer service but that is as good as it gets.  It was our first trip to Baltimore so we wanted to be close to everything because we had no idea what the layout would actually be like.  The room furnishings were nice and updated. I appreciated the desk with the mirror at it that I used as a vanity and the couch and table came in handy to eat at. The little single up coffee maker with to-go cups and actual mugs was a nice touch. The hotel is so old! It says it was renovated so I cringe to think of what it was like before. Every elevator literally shook as you went up and down, I have never experienced this before! Our room had a really funky smell to it when you walk in, I have no idea what it was. At first I thought the room might just need to air out. And honestly, after a 5 hr drive, I was not interested in having to change rooms.  The bed was very firm and high off the ground, not a big fan of either. The thermostat was off, it would get really hot or cold in the room. The fridge never got cold. The ceilings are very low, especially in the bathroom. The wifi was awful. I actually turned it off and used my data because it was so slow and spotty.  I would not stay here again because there are so many other hotels to stay at in the area that would have better accommodations.I was in town for a conference taking place at a hotel down the block.  This hotel was in the perfect location and proximity the conference and a few places to eat.  The staff are extremely helpful and professional from check-in, to room service, to the cafe.  The west tower room I stayed in appeared to be recently remodeled, but the quality of the remodel was lacking quality.  The bed and pillows were comfortable and the heating/air work great!  The Wifi is free; however, I had access issues several times over the course of my stay that eventually led to my postponed usage.While staying at this location I ate at the Eden West, the restaurant within the hotel, one evening.  I found the place to be average in food quality but over-priced.  I ordered room service one evening and the call line was not familiar with the items listed in the menu.  Once I ordered, it took more than and hour and a half to receive my plate.  They were gracious to give me my room service order for free and to comp my breakfast the next morning (great customer service idea).I would stay here again if I was in the Inner Harbor area.Neither good or bad really..... Mediocre Hotel, not typical of what I have experienced at other Holiday Inn's though. Room was pretty dated, Beds were wayyyy too soft, the mini-fridge didn't keep anything cold at all, west tower only had soda machines on every other floor so I was stuck going one floor down anytime I wanted a drink. The bathroom was SO Small! Practically had to stand in the bathtub to close the door. Friday was $180 dollars, Saturday was $315. What a HUGE difference 1 day makes. They sold microwave stuff in the dotties coffee place, but we had no microwave. The Wings were good that we had at the bar that evening at Eden West, but the Crabcake sandwich was too much bread. I ate none of the pretzel roll, just the crabcake, which was okay. The breakfast buffet next morning was cold, the sausage looked as if it had been sitting all morning, the bacon was swimming in a sea of grease, the scrambled eggs were cold, the french toast was cold and only had some kind of strawberry sauce to put on top, had to get ketchup and syrup from another table as we were not offered any. As we sat and ate, a server, not the one who seated us, not the one who took our order, and not the one who took our drink order, came over and promptly handed us 2 coffee to go cups and our bill even before we were done eating.... we figured it was probably best to just leave. The front desk employees were helpful, and called us a cab when we needed one. $10 including tip is about all a cab ride down to the power station costed so not that bad. The hotel was clean, but for a holiday inn, I have stayed at better ones.I was in town for a meeting taking place at another hotel but wanted to collect the points.  I was able to get a better price than the meeting hotel by contacting the HI management, so thanks to them for working with me. And the meeting was only a few blocks away and not a challenge to walk to.Overall a decent hotel for an older downtown location.  I was on the 11th floor and so used the elevators more than normal - I like to take the stairs, but eleven flights with a heavy computer bag is a bit much.  However, there was never a long wait for an elevator because there are three of them. Much better than some hotels where the lone elevator is overwhelmed.You have to pay $25 per day to use the parking garage.  That gives you in and out privileges, but you most likely will leave the car and walk.  The Inner Harbor area is only a few blocks away.  You are better off walking than dealing with the traffic and then having to pay again to park elsewhere.  The convention center is also close.One point about urban hotels is that you can go from a good neighborhood to a sketchy one very quickly. As long as you stay by the hotel and the area toward and including the Inner Harbor, you should be fine.  There are a lot of people in those areas.  However, I headed north to Baltimore Street to grab some snacks from a 7-11 and found the area to be a bit challenging.  I bought more stuff and got out of there, and I later found another convenience store on Lombard Street near the hotel.Overall a decent place to stay.The one thing that almost saves this hotel is the friendly staff, but even they aren't enough.  It is a shabby, stuffy and smelly place that has no ventilation in the bathrooms nor windows that open. The indoor restaurant, Eden West, served a great shrimp salad that was prepared for takeout. We had just arrived after a long flight and just wanted to sleep. The next day however we went down to dine in, and found that its about 40 feet away from the lobby front doors, but since the hotel allows people to smoke outside, it just blows all through the lobby and the restaurant. The restaurant's bar/lounge is upholstered in a brown, dull fabric that hasn't been aired out in decades. The odor was so offensive we just turned around and left. The elevators are nearly deathtraps, and the rooms would have been comfortable were it not for the musty odor. I turned on the AC to clear it out, but it began to smell like body odor more than anything else. The beds are large enough, and there is a frig and microwave included, but the frig's cooling system was iffy. The bath tub was dingy and lack of a fan in the bathroom was puzzling. The rooms have flat screen tvs, but no DVR/TiVO and only a few channels are HD. We stayed in February, but  I couldn't recommend this place. Certainly wouldn't come here in the summer.This should be a quaint, historic hotel. It wants to be that. Instead, it's just a bit shabby, a bit uncomfortable, and seriously overpriced. Any character it once had has been overwritten by modern upgrades that didn't add to the charm - in fact, they erased the charm in search of the modern. The only reason to recommend this hotel is the location. Even that isn't enough to warrant $175 a night.Stayed here April 4-5 for a conference held at the convention center (located 1 block away)Fantastic location for the convention center. Inner harbor is a 15 minute walk away, Power Plant (bar/club scene) is a $10 taxi ride away. Parking at the hotel is $25 per night. Restaurant and bar located inside, but did not have a chance to experience either. Convenience/gift store/bakery located in the lobby -- baked goods are divine and the lattes aren't so bad. Skip the bagels--they were cold and hard (and $4!). They also have a good selection of souvenirs (mugs, plush toys, magnets, and even old bay seasoned pickles!)Room was great. Newly updated faucets and showers. Pillows and beds were a bit small but comfortable nonetheless. No in-room safe or hairdryer, but the room did have an iron and coffee maker. Bath and Body works toiletries were a nice touch. Special shout out: Hubert was amazing-- he was friendly and quick to check us in, sent maintenance (who was also very courteous) to our room within 5 minutes of our call (our bathroom light was out) and even helped us with our overpacked, oversized bags when we checked out. He has a genuine warmth about him that's hard to find in the service industry. Overall a great hotel, would definitely recommend.We encountered quite a few house keeping problems during our week-long stay. After several complaints and my initial very negative review, the housekeeping manager and hotel managers both made efforts to apologize and fix the problems. The staff at the hotel was very friendly and helpful, good location, decent price, etc. I'd give it 4 stars if house keeping had it together before the numerous complaints.Stayed here for five days and picked it based on the location. I will never stay in this hotel again until they fix their wifi. It was the most frustrating experience trying to get some light work done which normally would have taken an hour, but ended up taking several hours! If you are going to serve people that attend conventions, then you should have better wifi service?Overall, it's a mediocre hotel and not memorable, and the close proximity to the Convention Center is the only plus.Nice hotel close to government buildings. Room was clean. Pillows were soft. The curtains blacked out the sun to help me adjust to the time zone difference. Server Bryant was excellent. Morning buffet is ok (eggs, fruit, yogurt, potatoes). The bar/restaurant servers don't seem very motivated to help people seated at tables. The menu could do with some variety.Great location, super convenient, but definitely not holiday inn standard. The rooms are clean but old. The receptionist people are friendly but not very professional. I asked the receptionist if she can send a plumber in an hour to fix our leaky shower head and she asked me call the front desk again in an hour so she "doesn't forget". The bathroom smells moldy and the wall papers are peeling off very badly. The housekeeping staff is not very good at replenishing our supplies such as toilet paper, tissue, and toiletries, and they seem to be incredibly unhappy when we call to ask for these to be brought up. We have four people listed for our room but somehow we keep on getting only 3 sets of clean towels. And here is what I don't understand, when they give us toilet paper or facial tissue, it's never a full roll or box! It's always half!! WHERE IS THE FIRST HALF?!?!So bottom line, it's a good place if you want convenience. It's one block away from the convention center. The light rail stops one block away from the hotel. And there are plenty of restaurant, shopping, convenient stores within one mile radius (or easily reachable with the downtown free orange route bus). But if you want comfort, you should try somewhere else. At the end of our 7-day stay, I couldn't wait to get out of here.Stayed here as part of a convention that spanned 7-8 hotels around the convention center.  In previous reviews, there is a real swing of positive and negative, and I can tell you that that is largely driven by which "tower" you stay in.  The rooms in the main tower are quite a bit larger than the West Tower.  And the West Tower guests have to use a key to get from the West Tower to the lobby, restaurant, and meeting rooms.  I was actually in the main tower - so my room was one of the better ones; however, there were still a number of issues - none so major as to warrant a pow-wow with the manager, but taken as a whole it was not a great hotel.The bathroom was laughably small--- almost had to stand in the tub to close the door and use the toilet.  nice.The maid service was bizarre to me.  They knocked on the door at 8am - and we said we'd be out in about 10 minutes. Even waved to them when we left.  But when we returned at 4pm the room had not been serviced.  The front desk said service was usually 6pm -- huh?  So there's something about their schedule I don't get. But more importantly, there was a huge swing in the quality of the service - one day great, the next no wash clothes, two bath towels short, only a quarter roll of toilet paper, etc.  Even MORE bizarre was the restaurant.  7 of us went there for breakfast-- the bored hostess said she could not put us at one table. We said no problem, we can be at two tables. She said all tables were dirty and they had no bus boy -- "give me a minute" -- and she NEVER came back.  neat. we found other places to eat.  In fact, in an 8 day stay, I never ate there, nor did my friends.  I can't believe how much business they lost by not being ready for our group.Also want to warn you that the little convenient store in the lobby has crazy prizes.  My friend bought 2 purse packs of Kleenex -- $4.50!!?!?  excuse me?  I wanted a latte and the clerk had no idea how to make one. "I could out some flavor in plain coffee." (yeah, that's how they do it at Starbucks).  My friend asked for hot chocolate -- plain water and a pack of Swiss Miss for $2.80  Try the nearby CVS if you need to buy something.Bottom-line, not horrible, not even memorably bad....but not good enough to return or recommend.PLUSES: Free wifi, fridge and microwave in roomOkay I understand why you don't have certain rooms available.  But putting someone that stays 50+ nights with your brand on the 3rd floor, next to the ice machine and across from a fire station is beyond belief.  IHG is a loyalty program- I don't care I am paying whatever a night, but if I am a loyal guest then put me in a better room.  Told there were no other rooms available- but coworker with no status got high floor and bay facing (no fire station).Franchise as all HI, so it makes me question one of my loyalties.I was a bit disappointed in this Holiday Inn.  The rooms were ok, but a little dated. There was only one person at the desk at a time, so check-in took quite a bit. And breakfast in the hotel's restaurant was slow and cold. The manager should work on improving customer service and the hotel restaurant.I can not speak to the price of this lovely establishment because I was there for a trade show and on someone else's dime. That being said, I really enjoyed my stay at this location.  It was close (translation: walking distance) to everything that we needed to be close to -- Convention Center, Camden yards (and the Red Sox were playing to boot!), all the inner harbor fun. I had an issue with printing my boarding pass the night before my departure and a polite young man helped me get it printed. He did not leave my side until it was done correctly.I would totally recommend this location to anyone needing to be in this part of town.I really enjoyed my stay here.Pros:-Location, location, location. It's close to the hospital and within a 10-min or so walk to Harborplace Mall.  -My room (king size bed) was quite spacious.  I love that it had a little sitting area - small sofa, easy chair, desk - and microwave and mini-fridge.-As a "Priority Reward" member, I got a little welcome gift bag.  It contained 2 bottles of water, a bag of chips, and two pieces of chocolate.  I love utility in gifts, so I definitely appreciated the free water and I popped a piece of chocolate right away.  You can also save 2 bucks from the steep parking cost as a Priority Reward member.-My room was on the 11th floor right across from the elevators and next to the soda and ice machine.  I was afraid it would be noisy but I didn't hear a peep and slept like a rock.Cons:-$25/night for parking.  I know this is due to the hotel's great location but it's still a bit much to swallow.  TIP: Sign up to be a Priority Rewards on the hotel website.  It's free to sign up -- akin to signing up for a CVS card, there are no fees, just perks -- and parking is $23/night.  But regardless, at least you can drive in and out and you do have access to the garage until 3 PM the day of your check-out.-Breakfast is NOT included, though there's a restaurant within the Holiday Inn and a store where you can buy food. However, thanks to there being a mini-fridge and microwave in the room, I bought a chicken sandwich elsewhere for under  3 bucks and stashed it in the mini-fridge and had that for breakfast.Neither pro/con: When I first checked out the bathroom/sink area, it looked like someone had urinated in the toilet.  Maybe the housekeeper?  I didn't think too much of it, but later I got a letter under my door that there were piping problems throughout the city, so the water may be tinted brown.
