That explained things, and I was glad to know the reason for the urine-tinted water.All in all, I had a good visit here. The location and room were great. The only downside is the steep price of parking, but I guess that's to be expected in this part of town.Noise level at 3am is horrible. I was woke up at 3am still up now till 5am with loud people next to me. In the morning I will be requesting a refund or a free night at a different property. I have never seen an IHG property so nutty. Microwave is trashy. Washer and dryer is 1.75 per wash or dry. Quarters or Credit card required. Have your own quarters or they may have them at front desk but they do not have a change machine in laundry room. Gym is unattended and has clean towels. The ONLY reason they have 2 stars from me is the gym and the fact they have washers. Other than that, this place is a dump.Clean room.  Super friendly staff.  Amenities are about two star though.  Bad lighting.  No makeup mirror for her.  Oh boy.Not the best but far from the worst hotel I've stayed at. The good:  Clean, good service, price wasn't too crazy for downtown Baltimore and it's in a good location.The bad: I know check out and check in times have being changing but this place has to be the worst. Check in at 4pm and Check out at 11am.  I'm paying a good amount of money to stay less than a day already with the normal check out times not this just shortens my stay even more and cause more agrvation as far as preparations for my travels. Another big con about this place is the parking situation. $25 for parking $2 off if you are a Holiday Inn member. Again this just seems a little steep esp. when you can go around the block and find cheaper garages. I'm just glad I'm not a tourist and don't live that far that I knew where the free parking was in the city.
review_content_20: Stayed Mon - Thurs...Pros: Staff was very friendly & helpful, location was near to points in the inner harbor area, good access to highways to go south out of the city Cons: $25 per day for parking, bathtub in the room wouldn't drain & by day 3 it was as if you were taking a shower but in a full bathtub...Stayed at this Holiday Inn for a business trip a few weeks back. It was a prime spot in regards to the Baltimore Convention Center except that there was construction going on at the hotel (no notice of it while booking...) so the front entryway was closed off and guests had to walk around to the other exit....The hotel is walking distance to touristy inner harbor and Oriole park which was convenient since we did attend a game and passed by the tailgaters leading up to the stadium. There's also a good amount of restaurants, pubs and coffee shops nearby. Front desk personnel were personable which made up for them taking forever to check us in, i hate waiting!!I travel about 10 months of the year for work, and all of that time is spent in hotels. Recently I spent two weeks in Baltimore at this Holiday Inn. Comparatively to others of the same chain I would call this one middle of the road. It has a great location, close to the harbor/convention  center/ stadium/ theatre district. But there wasn't anything specifically to make this place stand above the rest to give a hotel that "WOW factor." This property is actually two budding a the main one with the lobby and all other accommodations.   And the "west tower" while separated by a covered outdoor walkway, is only guest rooms.  And as a warning the house keeping staff have different hours or just don't check your room. Lobby/ public spaces:Clean, spacious, the pool was nice, located in the basement but plenty of windows. And the adjacent fitness center was fairly well equipped. It did seam fairly evident that the West tower was not as well maintained/cleaned as the main building. Room:Was well laid out, and spacious. They have plenty of outlets near the bed located in the lamps both night stands. The mattress was nice and pillows were full, not over used.  My single king room was also furnished with a couch/lounger thing, as well as a fridge and microwave (a small piece of Heaven when doing extended hotel stays). The bathroom as a bit small, having to step out of the way to close the door past the front of the stool. But for me staying alone, needing to close the bathroom door was a mute point.  Bar/restaurant:I did not eat on property, I do know there was a restaurant and what looked like a bar past the lobby both of which I never saw people in (staff OR guests). As well there is also a small coffee shop. I was never able to figure out when it was open. But heard rumor it dose open daily with VERY odd hoursInternet speeds:SLOW!  Summery:Was a decent place, would stay here again. The only real downside I would have to say is the few days I actually wanted my room freshened up by the cleaning staff they skipped over my room.True 3-star hotel. Don't expect luxury or wide spaces, bathroom is really small. This HI is a 3-star done right. Good bed, nice pillows, real cold A/C, and great, Great, GREAT location. We recommend to include breakfast in your rate. Breakfast buffet has good offerings for the rate differential. Besides, there are no restaurants around hotel. Must walk couple blocks and more to get to restaurants and convenience stores. One plus: this hotel does have a pool and fitness center. Some others don't in this area.The room was very clean but there were some issues regarding a worn out chair and chipped paint, which made the room look undesirable.  I sent a comment to the staff and it was all taken care of the same day.  I was very pleased with their prompt response.  The hotel is in a great location.  Highly recommended. They have a good pool and gym sauna, and the wifi is free. Breakfast ins not include. Great staff.Worst experience I have ever had at a Holiday Inn. Was paying an exorbitant amount of money for a room that had dirty furniture and bed bugs. Left a day early and when I went to the front desk to check out and I told him of my experience with the bedbugs, they indicated to me "sorry".  Didn't offer a discount or have the manager come over to apologize. I will never stay at another holiday and ever again.The room was on the 8th floor and facing the fire station. The road noise even at this height was too loud all night. The room charge does not include breakfast. For a few dollars more and hot breakfast included there are much better other choices. I do not much care for the self parking at 25 dollars per day either.Stayed 1 night for an o's game.  Just over a block from Camden Yards and a lot cheaper than the hotels closer. We had the king room that ended up being upgraded to a suit which was really really nice. Everything was super clean and everyone on the staff was super nice. The room was surprisingly quiet as well. The only reason not giving 5 stars is no hot water for a shower in the morning. It was 10:30 am so I'm sure it was just from the heavy morning use.Definitely a fan of this hotel. Solid 3.5 stars. Again, the price really can't be beat for the location. I know the parking is pricey - but honestly, it's the best city-hotel-parking I've had to deal with. I've never had trouble finding a spot. I like that I take the little pass inside to the front desk and they just charge my room and I keep the same pass until I'm leaving. No valet, no paying every time I need to leave, and I'm not required to park in a creepy garage. Was put on the other side of the building this time - definitely quieter. Will be back!Great Service!  Justin at the front desk was extremely helpful.  Everyone at this hotel has been extremely polite and helpful. Very different experience from my last hotel in Baltimore.  I would stay here again.Update: hotel staff promptly corrected most items i brought up, upgrading them to 3 stars.Checked in after a long day of travel. Justin was amazing. He was professional, friendly, and has excellent customer service skills. Great room, great customer service! Thank you Justin!I stayed at this Holiday Inn during Otakon 2012 for 3 nights with 4 other friends in a 2-queen bed room. The prices were really reasonable for us, and the location is attractive, with it being literally minutes (walking distance) from all the major attractions of the Inner Harbor area. The staff stayed very strong under the pressure/insanity that coordinating hundreds of guests in costumes / with crazy luggage for Otakon entails, and even were supportive of the festivities, by providing free drinks, accurate directions, and taking photos of con-goers.The room was standard, and got the job done. We were provided with enough towels/blankets for all of us, and our room came with a convenient mini-fridge and microwave. It was typical Holiday Inn-quality.The only major downside was the lack of air conditioning in the lobby / other public areas of the hotel. The weekend was averaging temperatures of over 100 degrees Farenheit, and that coupled with hundreds of people in costumes made for an unpleasant experience when waiting to check in / lounging in the lobby. Other than that, though, I was content with my experience here.This was my first time attending the Firehouse Expo. I arrived early to attend the morning conferences and wanted to check in early so that I could get settled in before going to the conference and then so I could head out to the Inner Harbor after. This was not the case. I was told that I had to wait until 4pm and that if I was lucky, I may be able to check in by 3pm. I was alright with this, brought by baggage back to my car and got ready for the conference in my car. However, just an hour or so later while I just sat down in the conference, the other people in my group arrived and were able to check in early and got their room. Why was this? What special exception was made for them?When I was finally able to check in, we were given a room in the main building facing the firehouse. When we got to our room, we noticed that the cot we had requested and paid for was not in the room. Surprisingly, the manager who had checked us in called us within an hour of checking in to make sure everything in our room was alright. I advised him of the cot situation and one was immediately sent up. This was great service, but then I was also informed by my other group that the cot we had paid for their room was also not given to them. So thus far, I have not figured out why when I booked the room a few months in advance that I requested a cot and early check in for each room because those requests were not granted as I thought they would.The room was actually not bad overall. It was pretty spacious and modern. However, our refrigerator and blow dryer did not operate at all. When we attempted to take a nap after classes, we noticed that the shades in the room did not close all the way, allowing light to enter the room creating an uncomfortable environment to sleep in. These were some minor things, but they were definitely noted. As for the housekeeping, they were extremely slow. They were by far the slowest I have ever experienced at any stay I have had in any hotel. We came back for a nap after classes and were awoken at 4pm by housekeeping staff asking if they could come clean our room. 4pm?! A little ridiculous if you ask me. Yet the next morning, they were banging on our door at 9am trying to clean our room when we were not even awake yet. They did not even give us time to get up out of bed and answer the door because she attempted to key into our room. It would have been nice if this hotel offered the "Do Not Disturb" signs that every other hotel offers. I was never advised by the staff about the noise from the firehouse just across the street. Although I was quite fine with it, I still would have liked to be warned or maybe given the option to be away from that if needed. I was also never given the courtesy to pardon their appearance while they were renovating. I had to read signs and ask staff why they were giving out free chips, popcorn, water, and even beer to be given this memo. I did not know what noise or inconveniences there would be with this construction. Overall, there was not much inconvenience made by the construction nor noise made except for having to walk through the parking lot to get to the entrance in the breezeway (the main entrance was under construction), and it was nice to see the staff actually try to compensate for any inconveniences faced. To conclude this experience, my biggest disappointment came from the parking and breakfast amenities offered. First, this is not a Holiday Inn Express, so there is no free continental breakfast. This is understandable, but their "restaurant" is not very welcoming to Holiday Inn patrons. They did not offer their menu to us and served us right to the breakfast "buffet" that consisted of eggs, french toast, bacon, and potatoes (All of which took forever to be replenished fresh) and also included a limited amount of fruit and cereal. Figuring that this restaurant was apart of the Holiday Inn that they would offer some sort of discount, but they did not. $15 for this lousy breakfast buffet. $15! That is insane for what was offered.Second, you have to park in a parking deck in between the two hotel towers. You have to hold on to your parking ticket for the duration of your stay. When I checked in, I asked for my card to be validated, figuring that parking was free for valued customers of Holiday Inn. Wrong. I was charged on my hotel bill at my surprise at a "discounted" rate of $23 a night, $2 cheaper than the normal rate. To add a few bucks to that, since I arrived earlier than expected, I was charged an additional $6 because I came too early and then an additional $9 when I left cause I stayed 2 hours after 3pm while attending the Orioles game. Thus, a total of $84 was spent solely on parking in 3 nights. This to me is insane. Never have I had to pay for parking at a hotel I was staying at. I am not sure how other hotels operate in the immediate area, but I know I will at be taking my business elsewhere to see if I am treated as poorly.The hotel was clean and close to the stadium.  Those were the priorities for us!  Everything was in walking distance and the hotel staff was extremely helpful.  We will be back to Baltimore and we wouldn't stay anywhere besides the Holiday Inn in the Baltimore Inner Harbor.I will definitely choose the Holiday Inn Express-Inner Harbor in the future.  The front desk staff were friendly and accommodating, as well as the other staff, including the restaurant and Dottie's workers.  A huge bottled water, popcorn, oat & honey granola bar, chocolate chip cookies, and crackers with nutella were waiting on me in my room. The room also has a microwave and refrigerator which is just great. The hotel has a restaurant and coffee shop/convenience store on the lobby level.  It also has a nice-sized workout room, pool, and sauna.  The doorman was also helpful in explaining various parts of the city. The Holiday-Inn Express is walking distance to the Baltimore Convention Center and Harbor West where there is plenty of music, shopping, and food.  I received my wake-up call on time and never had to request cleaning service like some hotels who inadvertently forget to stop by your room.The only reason I did not give this place five stars is because when I made the reservation the reservationists assured me there would be complimentary continental breakfast, the hot water in the shower took a few minutes to kick in, and the bed wasn't up to my standards - I like pillow top and thick comfortable blankets.Horrifying, however the front desk was smiling and friendly through the whole experience.Eutaw street is a half block away from the hotel. Avoid it at all costs...especially if you're a woman traveling alone. I was yelled at on the street by locals who made it quiet clear that we stood out and weren't really welcome. The hotel was under construction in the main lobby when I arrived. I stayed 3 nights for business. I was given a Priority Rewards welcome bag with a bag of BBQ chips and water...gee thanks.Night one there was a domestic disturbance in the room next to mine. Think lots of screaming about who hurt my baby's daddy...Morning two we found baby roaches in a folder we had left on the floor next to the bed. WTF?And finally our last morning there, a fire alarm went off at 9am. No indications that it was a false alarm until we clammered down 11 flights of stairs only to see the front desk at ease like nothing was happening. No note under the door to warn us? It was just a scheduled test? Thanks...I stayed here with 3 friends during the WFTDA Eastern Regionals. The hotel was conveniently located (walking distance to the harbor and to many restaurants). We were staying in part of the hotel that is in a different tower from the main lobby. It seemed like the hotel had been remodeled in the somewhat recent past so we didn't mind. We investigated the pool but were sad to discover that there wasn't a hot tub, so we didn't spend any time there. Our room was clean and seemingly bedbug-free (being paranoid New Yorkers, we just had to check).Parking is not included in the price of your room and neither is the continental breakfast. I didn't think the dry goods at the continental breakfast were worth the price so I would suggest going elsewhere to eat in the mornings. Overall, I would stay here again the next time I'm in Baltimore.Stayed here for 4 nights. The staff were always welcoming, and quick to address any request we had. The hotel is clean, easy to navigate, and a great price. Great location, close to the convention center, the inner harbor shops & restaurants, airport, etc. The food in the restaurant and room service was great tasting and did not cost you an arm and a leg. I would definitely stay here again!nice, clean, friendly staff, and the best price in the inner harbor.I recommend it! - See and O's game and the National Aquarium, Great restaurants close by. SOunds great to me  (and it was!!!)
review_content_40: Great location and a very clean hotel.It is just a few blocks from Camden Yards, M&T Bank Stadium and the Inner Harbor in a very safe area.The staff is very friendly even late at night and the pool is nice.I recently stayed here with a group of friends for the Otakon convention. The only thing keeping this from being a 2-star review is the incredible staff. The front desk staff were phenomenal. They were very friendly and helpful and made us feel very welcomed even though it was crazy busy in there with all of the guests for the convention checking in. The onsite parking was expensive but convenient. I just wish they wouldn't have tried cramming more cars into the tiny surface lot during the baseball games. My car was blocked in several times throughout the weekend and when I left on Sunday I was blocked in again (luckily the person blocking me in was leaving at the same time as me, but if he hadn't been I would not have been able to leave). People were just making up their own parking spaces with zero regard for anyone else.The rooms were sized right for the price, not very big, but big enough to comfortably fit the three of us for the weekend. The AC worked fine and the beds were hard, but not too uncomfortable. However, the rooms did have a certain "old" feel. You could tell they had redone them at some point, but there were still giant old, loud AC units in the room, lazily painted trim, and no vents or fans in the bathroom. We stayed in the west tower and the elevators were hot, stuffy, and uncomfortable. Not to mention with only two of them to service all the rooms in that tower, they were crowded and we ended up just taking the stairs (also hot and stuffy) because there was no room for us in the elevator. Now the worst part: the NOISE level. The walls seemed to be paper thin. And we had a non-functional connecting door between our room and the one next to us and we could hear EVERYTHING our neighbors were saying even though they weren't even talking loudly. It was awful. We didn't want to knock on their door and ask them to be quiet because even though it was 3 am, they really were talking at a normal level. If this had been any other hotel I've stayed at, we wouldn't have been able to hear them. We tried stuffing towels and blankets under the crack of that stupid fake door thing, but it didn't work. It was like a group of people were sitting right there in our room talking and laughing. We barely got any sleep that night and it made our convention experience the next day a tired, unpleasant one. If I am paying $160/night, I expect to actually be able to rest and sleep in my room at night.I've stayed in many hotels and this was a delight. The price was extremely reasonable, $99, and it was attractive, clean, friendly, and unbelievably convenient to downtown and the inner harbor. There was also a microwave, a mini fridge, a large, well equipped workout room, a restaurant (I didn't get to try it), and a little convenience store in the lobby---not to mention an indoor pool! I will be looking for an event in order to have a reason to stay here.We arrived late from the West Coast so I was already kind of agitated, but upon checking in I was given 2 goodie bags with bottled water, chips and a couple mints. I thought that was a pretty nice touch. Oh, and their fitness center is pretty top notch as far as hotel fitness centers go.. they also had a nice dry sauna. I like to swing through those when I'm on vacation and get some of the booze and bullshit.. Downstairs they had a little coffee shop, bakery that seems to get the job done. I never had any issues with the business center either.. the only small complaint I have was the tub got clogged after only the 2nd day. The housekeeping staff should be a little more on top of that, but other than that, this place was serviceable.Nice enough old hotel. Was quiet with good firm beds. Wished the windows opened because room was musty from lots of air conditioning and inadequate air flow. Also, hot water availability was an issue 2 out of 4 mornings. So early birds get the hot water, others -- maybe not. Very convenient location.The rooms here weren't horrible; however, I asked on two separate occasions for a toothbrush and some toothpaste and they never came. There was a sign in the bathroom that stated that they would supply these items upon request. Both times I was told "Sure, Ma'am." . And nobody ever came. I ended up purchasing these items instead. The bar was a little entertaining - as there was a lady who fell off her bar stool onto the floor...TWICE...and yet they continued to serve her. There was a free happy hour offered one of the nights we were there..but it left a lot to be desired. We walked out...even though there was a free open bar. The food was horrible and the crowd was shady.Had to come to Baltimore for a Facilities Conference and when my boss booked us at the Holiday Inn I cringed. I try to stay at a Hyatt or Marriott when I travel and just the thought of switching up made me hella nervous. So I arrived at the hotel and the staff was exceptionally courteous. Was told that we would be in the upgraded side so I was hyped. Well....the upgraded side looked decrepit. I really would have hated to see what the non-upgraded side looked like. Small rooms, dingy looking hallways, creaky elevator. Soooo not a top notch establishment. Continental breakfast was kinda crappy as well; id have been better off eating leftovers. Only saving grace for me again was the customer service. Definitely much better places to stay at in the area.I recently stayed here and had a good time. This hotel is perfect if your visiting the Inner Harbor or going to an Orioles game. Both are within walking distance. A lot of the previous reviews mentioned the fire station across the road. It was never an issue. It did not go off every hour as some of the reviews have said and the one time it did go off it really wasn't that loud. There are ice machines and soda machines on every floor. The room was clean and the service was fine. My only complaint was the coffee in the coffee shop was kinda crappy/watery/weak, but I'm a bit of a coffee snob. I also wish the pool was open later because it would have been nice to relax in the pool after the baseball games at night. I understand its their policy but it still would have been nice. Be prepared to pay $25 a day to park but otherwise I'd stay here again.I would never stay here again, check in was at 4pm ok I arrive at 245pm and was told no rooms available so I was told I would be notified when it was ready I waited and hour and half and decided to ask if they had a room ready they said yes, the front desk couldn't care less that peopleStayed here for a fun filled night in charm city! The check in was a quick process and the desk staff was friendly. The room was ready as soon as I got there which was at least an hour before check in. I wasn't the largest room I have ever been in but it was clean and the bed was comfortable. The window actually opened and the room had a mini fridge, which in my book is a HUGE plus! I love the bath and body products they provide in the bathroom. The only con was the paid parking, I know it's the city and you pretty much have to pay for parking everywhere I just think it should be assumed that if you are staying in a hotel you will also need parking for your stay. But all and all it was a pleasant expereience and I will be back!I stayed here for 3 weeks as part of military/hospital training. The neighborhood is not the safest, but is IS Maryland. The staff was always nice and helpful. My calls to the front desk for clean up, food, or supplies were always answered in a timely manner. It was always clean. I cannot speak about the price compared to the room because I did noto pay for it (military provided the room). The food at the restaurant was ok. I never had a problem with the service from the restaurant. The bar is a nice little addition when you don't want to walk elsewhere for a drink.Stayed here for our Family Reunion and I was really impressed with the facility and our accomodations. The Holiday Inn Inner Harbor was about 9 blocks from the Inner Harbor and within walking distance to pretty much everything. Check in took us a total of 6 minutes and I was pleased with the 2 bed guest room we had for just 1 night. The room smelled a bit like cigarette smoke but, after turning on the a/c and spraying some Febreeze, all was well. This hotel was a great location to hold an event....the staff was very accomodating to our needs and very friendly. The only issue I had was with parking. We had to pay $23 to park our car in the "city" parking garage and the garage was always full. The garage was like a damn maze too! I hate that....Otherwise, I had a great time...the staff was awesome...and the hotel is even awesomeer :)Yes you'll be attracted by the cheap price and convenient location to the convention center and Camden Yards but what distinguishes the Baltimore Holiday Inn is the aroma of nicotine wafts through the halls.The place has a cheap feel to it, thin walls and being located on the first floor make for a recipe for a long night.I stayed at this Holiday Inn for one night. The walls are thin and you can easily hear through them, kind of annoying but not a big deal if you are able to sleep easily.The room I stayed in had a bathroom that was separated into two different parts. The toilet and shower were in an inclosed area while the sink was visible to anyone in the room. Make sure you request a room with a private bathroom if your looking for privacy. I'm a Priority Club member and I saved $2 on parking, not that big of a deal. The parking is orginally $23 but $21 for us Priority Club members. I also want to point out that they do not give free breakfast coupons away to the Priority Club. Breakfast is around $16.99 per person, not including the tip.horrific. Unorganized staff, rude as hell manager. I checked out early because I didn't like the way the manager treated me. They are really shady about telling you the entire price of your stay. I booked a room for Friday night till Sunday morning, I was told it would cost about 160$ that was fine. HOWEVER none ever told me that was per night. I'm not stupid, I practically lived in dozens of hotels all over the country. And everytime you get the room they ask how long you will be staying, then give you the price....FOR YOUR ENTIRE STAY. Not a misleading nightly quote, and then wake up to a 480$ pending charge on my debit card. It's bad business, and the manager is obviously a bad manager, letting it continue in the fashion it is. Place was clean. Ghetto ass people everywhere, but it's downtown in a big city..you'll have that, just typically not in the parking lot bumming cigarettes and chatting with the "security". So that stuff, and make sure you bring a bucket to put the pieces of your skull in after they bash it in with their insane parking rates. It's clean, convenient, fairly quiet...if you enjoy being rushed by the rude incompetent staff this is the place for you.No Attitude of Gratitude here!We spent two nights at this hotel getting poor service, bad attitude and definitely NOT 3-star-hotel sharp accommodations. We checked in but had to wait 4 hours for a room to become available...because we had been assigned a handicapped-accessible room. Neither of us is handicapped; we didn't reserve a handicapped accessible room; we didn't want a handicapped accessible room; and we sure didn't want to wait 4 hours because that's what Holiday Inn assigned us! There was absolutely no persuading the steely faced young woman at the counter to help us out in any way. Not a smile or apology in sight. Not a soothing word was spoken to alleviate our unhappiness, and absolutely no explanations about why we had been assigned a "special needs" room.When the (caucasian) man next to us checked right in, we started to wonder if the problem was that we're an interracial couple. Now...I'm not sayin'...just tellin' the question that ran through our minds.The dining room food was awful; the lounge doesn't open 'til 5:00 p.m.; the snack shop is outrageously overpriced for simple fare & has disgusting coffee; the carpeting throughout is dirty and old and, of course, worst of all was the bad attitude of the check-in staff.Hi. A few years ago, I spent one night at this fascinating hotel in the heart of downtown Baltimore's Inner Harbor district. Boy is this one lucky find! Not only is this hotel as close to the major harbor attractions but it is also right directly across from Camden Yards, and from some rooms in the one tower you can see the outer parts of Camden Yards clearly from your room's window.But the picture that marks this hotel here on Yelp, isn't the only portion of this hotel that is part of this Holiday Inn's property. They also have another tower(of a slightly smaller size in width, not height) that they use daily in the summer. A better picture of this portion can be found at: yelp.com/biz_photos/QXmD...The hotel is also next to/across the street from Baltimore's light rail system. The tracks lay right outside the hotel directly across from the check-in area, car overpass and in front of the entrance to the parking garage.Be very careful near this hotel, although the streets that mark the corners of this hotel aren't marked as such, all the streets nearby are all unmarked One-Way Streets.I was stunned when I used their free wifi at this hotel from my room-fast and effective, and, even when I had become a Priority Rewards card member, I received a free pack of 3 baseball cards with my purchase of a night of one of their rooms-a valuable plus in my book-all for free. But be prepared to buy your room on cyber Monday, as the rooms in the one tower are pricey and the other one not quite/but close to pricey. But for the amount of stuff I got in this hotel, it was well worth it, as I got to walk several times back and forth to do some sightseeing in the city without needing a car-you need to walk about 10 blocks to get to the Inner Harbor district-where the temps are comparatively cooler. A few problems exist with this hotel:1.)I couldn't find the parking garage system right next door. 2.)I had another problem with this place, upon checkout from the parking lot: the parking attendant is required to take your ticket and KEEP your ticket(unlike all other hotel chains) and the attendant is the only one that is allowed to scan your ticket to exit the lot.3.)Be prepared to veer to the left is want underground-inside parking. Spots on upper level tend to become very hot on the asphalt.4.) Parking isn't free for the guest, but you can pay for parking upon check-in at this hotel at the front desk.Although he front desk line moves slowly at the time when I checked in, the issues people were having were respectable, and the employees value your time as you are their paying customer.(contact me for details).If I was ever in Baltimore again, I'd choose this hotel over all the others for both price and quality/quantity of services they offer.I travel to Baltimore every year to watch the Yankees play the O's, and this is where I always stay. It's not fancy and the rooms aren't big..BUT...it's clean, cheap and only two blocks away from the stadium and four blocks away from the inner harbor. Its in a perfect spot. If you require more, try the Hilton or Marriott which are right next door. But prepare to pay for it. For me the holiday inn is exactly what I need.This is a great place to stay when visiting Inner Harbor. Walking distance to EVERYTHING. If you don't want to get a car when in baltimore, its really no problem when staying here. The ball park is literally two blocks away. And the inner harbor is probably half a mile away. They have a heated pool, a coffee shop, free parking, a gym, restaurants, a really nice staff, and the coldest air conditioners. Stay here, its great.Great location ~ stones throw to the convention center, the stadium and 4 blocks to the Inner Harbor. Hotel was very accommodating to our soccer team. The rooms were clean and certainly large enough. Great pillows ~ towels need to be thrown out! Too old to recover. Other than that, loved the hotel. Better than average gym and very nice pool.
review_content_60: One of the better Holiday Inns that I have stayed at, and I have been to many over the years. With that beign said, my three days and two nights spent here o nthe 4 th of July holiady weekend went very well. A very friendly staff, accompanied by a spacious/clean room, for a great value. The hotel is located at the Westren end of the Inner Harbor, but a block and a half from the water front areas. Room service was fast and efficent, the hotel food was very good, above par on my filet mijon. There is a nice indoor pool, located  on the first level. Parking is a bit pricey at the hotel, but after all, this is the Inner Harbor district, everything comes for a price, particuarly convience.    The down side is if you are tall, their showers are too damn low if you are over six feet. The hallway noise with the maid service starts by 7 or 8 AM, not fun after arrivign at your hotel room in the wee hours of the morning. The cleanign staff was nice, and again, the room was very clean and modern. Their flat screen HD TVs really had awful reception for some unkown reason, but I could make out enough viisuals to get the jist of things. The rooms offer an ipod dock, which was nice...Queen size beds, no smoking policies, just a decent spot while in Baltimore on buisness or pleasure, or both. Nearby is the Poe grave site, besides the standard aquarium, et al..The hotel offers a very nice breakfast buffet, in a above average resturant. There is also a small convience store within the hotel, with fresh baked goodies. If you stay here, tell them I sent ya.I stayed here in August.  It was 100 degrees in Baltimore so that goodness they had air conditioning.I, too, ended up in the west wing.  Not my favorite walk but I just avoided the rest of the hotel the entire time.The rooms are a bit tired.  I looked out the window at the Marriott and wondered if I had made the right choice.  Hmmm.It was close to Camdem yards and the Convention Center so that was great.It was also a short walk to Inner Harbor and such.  I think if I go back I'd try the Marriott.I did try the room service and that was fine but my dishes sat outside my room for about 3 or 4 days.Not the best. There was a stain on the bed sheets & when we walked in our room barefoot we noticed the bottom of our feet were BLACK.Very disappointed in their customer service.Otherwise known as the  Holiday Inn Inner Harbor, or the Holiday Inn Downtown - this is a short distance from the inner harbor (5 blocks) and maybe four to Camden Yard. Rooms are clean and well appointed although the maintenance could be kicked up another notch (wallpaper just starting to peel in the bathroom) - but it does look like they are trying to improve that. Staff is friendly and helpful. We were in a room on  firehouse side (opposite Camden yard side) - but fortunately they never got called last night. Highly recommend a higher floor for that reason and to get away from the street noise. Penthouse dining area does have great views of Baltimore, and the conference rooms are well appointed. Also, the breakfast is good in the hotel restaurant. Make sure to have your "Holiday Inn" priority card with you, you'll save money and get a better room for the same rate.Bottom Line: Good for convention goers to the convention center. Some better hotels closer to the inner harbor exist, but if they are all booked - this is an a-ok alternative.The hotel stay was fine, except for the noise from semis crossing over the train tracks outside.  My problem with this hotel is the extra $525 in charges that showed up on my debit card with no explanation.  Long story short, my company credit card was declined, so I had to use my debit card to check in (last resort) and my boss faxed her card info over the next day.  The staff assured me that the charges for the room would not show up on my debit card.  When I checked out, I got a receipt for the total amount showing it was charged to my boss's card, as promised.  After I flew home, I found out that $525 in pending charges was being held against my checking account from the Holiday Inn (this was on top of the amount charged to my boss's card).  When I finally got to talk to someone about it, there was no apology or explanation.  They just "took care of it."  There was absolutely no warning at check-in that this might happen and I still don't know why the pending charges were much more than the total cost of my stay.  I'm sure they probably have some policy about using debit cards, but it was not explained to me when I checked in, even when I clarified that I was using a debit card and stressed that I could not have the room charged to that card.  Will not stay there again.Great place! right in the heart of the city. Clean, cozy and has everything you need!If you're looking for a great place to stay that is reasonably price, I think this Holiday inn is it. The hotel a block away from oriole stadium, and a 5 minute drive to the harbor. This is probably one of the best holiday inn's I been too. I really like the pool, because the water is warm and it's right next to the gym. The food in their market is kinda expensive, but that didn't really surprise me. The room was also pretty nice, and our's comfortably fit 4 people.I chose this place due to it's close proximity to the Convention Center.  I did get a halfway decent rate of 174, then 127 and 127/night.  However it still did not seem worth it.First of all I had to run the shower for a good 10 minutes before I got hot water.  Then it became so hot is nearly scalded me.  On Saturday morning at about 8:30 a.m., I was awakened by men out on my balcany doing construction work.  Who the hell does this?The bed was almost comfortable, but the pillows were horribly overstuffed cheap foam pillows.  Therefore I got pretty poor sleep every night.  There was no in-room safe.The room was clean and in good condition and there was free wireless internet.  But was it worth over $500 for 3 nights stay?  I don't think so.  At least they are doing some updating on the outside of the building, but to do it on a weekend early morning is just plain inconsiderate.If it hadn't been a block from the convention center I would not have stayed.  Their rack rate was $246 a night for a double.  The pool needs serious rehab and painting - also concrete work because it is crumbling.  The fitness room needs to be cleaned - the equipment is a breeding ground of germs (which I believe is why I am sick currently) and they could use some updated cardio pieces.  Not a family friendly place - lots of drunk businessmen and it truly seemed like a few call girls in the elevator.  The housekeeping staff was very efficient though.Got a room on Priceline for a reasonable price.  Great location if you'll be at the Inner Harbor/Camden Yards...about a 5 block walk.  You can definitely book a room closer, but not for this price.  Room was clean and recently redone.  Bathroom was small, but the vanity was outside the door and very nice.  The only noticeable thing in the redone room was that the bathroom door was still a yucky old brown color.  We were on the firehouse side and weren't too bothered by it.  There's a great little convenience shop in the lobby to get a quick bite (bagels, yogurt, fruit, breakfast sandwiches, packaged snacks, and great coffee!)  I was pretty pleased with our stay.  Be advised, parking is not included in the room rate.  You can park int he adjacent lot for about $15 until midday the day after you check in.The most disgusting hotel that I have ever been to.  I came here for a conference with 10 other people, and we spent one of the worst weekends of our lives here.  After flying for over 7 hours to get to this place, the front desk informed us that they had only SMOKING rooms available for us despite our reservation for NON-SMOKING rooms.  The receptionist seemed bored and annoyed with us and did not offer any sort of compensation except a pathetic attempt to use an air purifier in the rooms for several hours and a promise of NON SMOKING rooms for the remainder of our stay.  So we waited for them to "purify" the air for about 4 hours.  We called the front desk again to ask for an air freshener but were greeted by an idiotic receptionist who clearly knew nothing about customer service or hospitality.  The air purifier and the lack of air fresheners failed in all ways and all of us suffered through a first terrifying stinky night.Called the manager first thing in the morning and arranged for the room switch.  The manager was very helpful and offered complimentary breakfast.  Still did not fully compensate for the suffering of the previous night but much better than the losers we dealt with the previous night.One of the girls woke up next night with bed bugs.  Another room switch.  And we are going onto our last (thank the lord) night.  Let's see what goes wrong this time!Never coming here again, or any Holiday Inn.P.S.  This place wasn't even cheap.My friends and I decided to make it a weekend after attending a conference at the convention center.  After the conference, we checked in and lounged around the room for awhile.  One friend climbed into the bed and found a dirty sock under the sheets!  She screamed and we immediately called the front desk.  They didn't seem very sympathetic, but after having to explain how disgusting that was they offered a room change.  We declined and stated we wanted to watch the sheets being changed (obviously they hadn't been changed the first time).  The housekeeping manager came up and was incredibly bubbly and apologetic.  She offered us free breakfast the next morning  - the buffet wasn't so great but the menu wasn't bad.  The rest of the stay was fine, with the exception of the fact that they charge for $1.50 for local calls.free breakfast for gold and platinum members, close to the convention center and good restaurants.Too expensive for what you get. The best part about the hotel is that it has a great location (close to the convention center, baseball field, etc). I'd give this one star if it wasn't for the location. Found a used condom in my room on the 1st night. Had to call the front desk each day to get the room cleaned. Hotel restaurant serves expensive horrible food. At least a hotel should serve good breakfast. Eggs were too dry, bacon had no taste, coffee tasted old and burnt, sausage was also very dry, waffles had no taste. Even a motel 6 gives you more for a much cheaper price.

review_content: The Hubs and I had a beautiful view of Baltimore from our 12th floor room. We were a short walk to our favorite spots in Fell's Point. So, location is good. The front desk staff couldn't have been friendlier. Rooms were clean and mostly comfy, except for the bed. The Hubs hated the bed.Self-parking is $20+ with no in & out privileges. The beautiful large Starbucks located in the lobby is a big bonus for me.The HIlton Garden is located in the upscale, gentrified section of Baltimore, surrounded by hoity-toity shops and overpriced restaurants. And this hotel maintains the standards of the surrounding area. It is lovely, everyone is very friendly but a bit formal. There are warm cookies for the guests in the lobby at tea time. The rooms are clean but very generic, and the hallways can be loud... you can hear every door slam as you are trying to fall asleep. What I really liked about this place was the location... it is a easy walk to Fells Point and the Little Italy section of Baltimore, and it is very accessible to the Green Line City Bus. Who knew that the bus system was FREE! Awesome!Hilton Garden Inn is located in the heart of the Inner Harbor and about 15 minutes away from the Greyhound bus terminal if using public transportation. The cab ride is roughly $14 with tips depending on traffic.Just a lovely and clean hotel with friendly staff and convenient to pretty much everything within the Inner Harbor. We had a beautiful view from our room and totally love their beds....super comfy...There is a bar/restaurant on the second floor in the hotel in case you want to grab a bite.However, keep in mind there are lots of restaurants walking distance, a movie theater and Starbuck next door as well. Highly recommended if planning to stay within the Inner Harbor.The service here is top notch. Everyone from the receptionist to the manager to the bel hop to the housekeepers were wonderfully friendly and accommodating! Rooms were great, amenities were awesome (don't sleep on the pool and gym!), and the food was great, too! A great location and a kid-friendly option, we would definitely stay here again!If this was just based on the staff and the location, it would be 5 stars. The staff were helpful and always very sweet yet professional. The 2 star loss is due entirely to 2 things. 1) The beds are awful. And not just for me. My husband and I have different tastes in beds but we both hated the bed. I kept needing to flip sleeping positions every 15 minutes because staying in the same position caused my back to seize up. This one is a first for us.2) We had free WiFi, which was great but while I have low standards for free WiFi, this network managed to lower my expectations even further. I figured it would be slow and spotty but the network would disappear every 5-7 minutes. Poof, gone, into the ether. We liked our time at the Hilton Garden inn, mainly due to the staff but would we stay at this one again? No, probably not.This hotel is in a great location in the Inner Harbor area. There are stores and restaurants even a movie theater right next door. It is about 1 block from the harbor. So for me this hotel was just okay. The front desk staff was pretty nice but when i arrived to check in there was no defined line so I saw a lady jump another just because there was no line or rope to create one. The same thing happened to me when I was checking out some lady just came from the side and jumped me and they continued to work with her instead of making her wait in line. So I love to swim and the pool is normally my main area but here is where I got annoyed. The pool is located where the gym is and because it is huge awesome gym it looks like a baby LA Fitness there are staff everywhere telling you what to do and what not to do. This is my vacation guys if I wanted rules and constraints I would go to work. The lady at the front desk of the gym was like you must sign in to swim because you have to go through the gym and that is a liability. I stay at tons of hotels I have never heard of signing a liability waiver to walk through a gym. They have to buzz you in and there is absolutely no sight seeing. One of the guys at the gyms front desk was like yelling at us "where are you going! the pool is that way" and I am like Your point would be. A lady told my father who was eith me to come to the conference room to get a cookie and he was trying to that but they act like they are at fort KnoxOnce we got to the pool area the guy managing that .area was like "hi are you coming to swim" we were like "yes" then he rattles off all these does and odn'ts. about the temperatures of the pool, how long we have to swim, how we should be dressed to come to the pool, who can swim where, he got an attitude when we asked for clarification on the temperatures and got smart with my father because he was surprised about the temp of the hot tub talking about "thats why its called a hot tub" his tone was very wrong and I was offended. Would I recommend this hotel? Probably not the people are too up tights and they don't know how to talk to customers.I've stayed at a handful of hotels in the Baltimore area, and the Hilton Garden Inn has been my favorite so far. I travel for business frequently, so the free WiFi to keep my mobile office running is so very necessary and helpful. The room was clean, the bed comfy and the staff friendly. I was even greeted by a delicious granola bar cookie situation upon arrival. Yum!The location of this hotel is superb too - in the heart of Baltimore's charming Inner Harbor, near the freeway and in walking distance to solid dinner options. Did I mention there is a Haagen-Dazs and Starbucks in the same building? Perfection, I tell you. Perfection.Just a tip: The attached parking garage is not associated with the hotel, so you can't charge parking to your room. But the price to park isn't terrible - $14 for overnight.Awesome! Great location, service, hospitality and room was ready for check in. Highly recommend to anyone looking to enjoy the inner harbor.The hotel is fabulous. It has a nice view of the water and centrally located in Harbor East within walking distance of a lot of shops and dining options, not to mention only a 10 minute walk from the Inner Harbor itself. Room was clean, sleek, and very well kept. 12 stories with a view from every angle. We stayed on the 7th floor in 2 doubles bedroom. This hotel doesn't offer the HGI bed adjustment system in the beds like some HGIs do. Regardless the beds are comfy as is. They're not too firm and not too soft with a nice middle ground. IT comes with a small fridge and microwave next to the desk. The bathroom has french doors to it. I know see the practicality to that, but I guess it could offer a cute fix to the room. All in all a great stay. I would come here for sure.Stayed here for four days and three nights. The bed was super comfy, and room was very clean. A little smaller than I'm used to. I stayed on the top floor, 12th level and wish I would've had a better view. But I did have a view overlooking the garden terrace and city. The terrace is on the 8th floor with benches and a huge fountain. Condos are attached to the hotel, and share the terrace. The hotel staff made my checking in and out as painless as possible. Was disappointed that the hotel didn't have a spa thoughGreat location at a good price. Very clean. Staff was nice. Loves being able to walk to the restaurants or bars in the area. Great view from the hotel room. Would definetly recommend it.I stayed at the Hilton Garden Inn - Inner Harbor for one night in July 2013. The hotel is in a perfect location and within walking distance of all of the Inner Harbor attractions and Fell's Point. The rooms are very modern, clean, and well-maintained. There are many shops, restaurants, bars, and even a movie theater within walking distance too. I would definitely stay here again if I find myself in the Baltimore area. Tip: Ask for a room on a higher floor with views of the harbor!I recently stayed at this awesome hotel for a baseball weekend with my brother and we had a fantastic time.First off, my bro was the one who booked the room. When we went to check in, I simply asked if they would honor the government rate while showing them my military ID. I made sure to tell them I was not on official business so there would be no ethical infractions. Even knowing this, the receptionist agreed to honor the government rate with a smile on her face. That alone saved us over $200, which meant we had more beer money. Hilton rocks, Baby!The location of this hotel is superb. It is less than two miles from Camden Yards, which is an easy walk when you are bar hopping your way there. Also, there is a movie theater right next door which gave us a good place to kill time before the Saturday afternoon game.The room was also spacious and spotlessly clean. We were up on the 12th floor which provided an amazing view of the harbor. I have no complaints about any aspect of our stay. It was fantastic.This Hilton Garden Inn will always be my first choice for future Baltimore visits.If we go back to the Inner Harbor, I would definitely stay here again. It was a short cab ride from Penn Station and a great location for the harbor. We don't mind walking a lot because we're New Yorkers, so to me this was in walking distance of everything. It's located about a lock off the water-we walked along the water to Fells Point, the water taxi and pier 5. The front desk staff was helpful, friendly and efficient. As were the housekeeping staff. They are apparently attached to a sports club with a pool and Jacuzzi but we did not check that out. The hotel was clean and quiet, the room was sufficient on the 12th floor and had a nice view of the roundabout, water and four seasons. It's on the same block as a CVS, movie theater, whole foods, shops and next store is a starbucks. It was an overall great experience. I enjoy a place where I don't need anything and can rely on a comfortable nights sleep. The Hilton does it again!Amazing location!Staff was friendly, accommodating, and informative. Room was clean and comfy, and couldn't hear any hallway noise except occasionally the room next to us slamming the door to their room. We were on the 11th floor above the Katyn Memorial Circle thing, but couldn't hear any street noise.Self parking can be a little tricky because it is a shared lot. We had a free breakfast from our HHonors benefits, but I would take the points next time instead. Cold items weren't great looking, tiny pastry collection, hot items seemed good but had been sitting out for a while. They do make fresh omelettes and such, but I didn't try.Overall it was a great room for the price and we had a wonderful staycation!Will definitely stay here again & recommend to friends!DO NOT USE VALET WITHOUT TAKING PICTURES OF YOUR VEHICLE: I stayed here last weekend and the room was great. But the valet was another story. I dropped my car off the night I checked in and had them bring it around the next morning and they hit my side bumper on something. I noticed it as soon as they pulled my car around. The valet had me fill out a claim form and said they would take care of everything and that the reason they have insurance is for incidents like this. Yesterday I got an email saying they were denying my claim because there was no proof that they were at fault for any damages. I got an estimate and the damages are around $700 with a rental included. Why would I pay $230 to stay at their hotel to only make a false claim for $700? It's sad that employees won't admit to wrongdoing, but I'm sure they would get fired if they did damage a vehicle. I am never staying at this hotel again and I will be taking them to small claims court. I know it's only $700, I could pay out of pocket or go through my insurance company but it's just morally wrong, they will pay me for the damages they did. And it will end up costing them for than $700 in the end!!!Forget what Expose said years ago*, what you don't know CAN hurt you.The point being, if you didn't know about this great hotel, you could be staying in the wrong place in Baltimore. This Hilton Garden Inn has it all...it's clean, quiet and has a great staff. The location is great! It's a bit of a walk (maybe 20 minutes) to the ballpark but Harbor Place and Aquarium are very close and you can also easily walk to Fells Point and Little Italy.The best thing is that you get use of the Maryland Athletic Club if you stay here and that's a really nice facility. During my recent stay, I visited frequently to keep my awesome physique in top notch form!Big fan of this place.__________________________________________*Awesome video youtu.be/O4ViqQkpcqEExcellent experience. The front desk staff were cheerful, efficient and remembered us in the morning (enough to wish us well on the next leg of our journey). The room was attractive, modern and well appointed. The air conditioning was not working properly but as we were too tired to request assistance, I'm not sure if they would have been able to fix it for us. We were on the top floor and our room was very, very quiet.Breakfast was wonderful--fresh and delicious with a lot of choices. We took an after breakfast walk around the harbor and it was nice to be so close to the water.For a "discount" hotel in Baltimore, ran me over $200 weekend, with taxes, so I can't give 5 stars. Also, valet parking is pricey at $35 a night. But the place has new car smell and everything works great. Staff was very accomodating from the moment I checked in until I left. The breakfast buffet had a lot of choices and ran only $13 with tip. The best part though, is that you gain free access to a huge gym that is connected to the hotel - you dont need to step outside. The gym opens at 5 AM and has everything you would ever need. Awesome! Coming back again in January 14 and can't wait...The suite was very clean and contained an incredibly comfortable king size bed that didn't shake, jiggle and wake up the other person every time someone moved. In addition, the sheets were crisp and fresh. The room was in good shape, no worn rugs, wall scuffs and peeling wallpaper. We were located on the eighth floor next to a large courtyard that is quite attractive. Initially we were worried about having so much window area next to a courtyard would not be advantageous, but, no one was peering in and, of course there are sheers and blackout curtains. The hotel noise level was relatively quiet especially considering that we stayed on New Years Eve. (The hotel did make people sign a pledge to no partying and maybe that worked. Or maybe our room was isolated enough to avoid the cacophony of slamming doors and loud voices.)The hotel is in a great location with a many points of interest within walking distance. The lobby is nice looking but the seating is a bit worn and stained, (though in working order). Finally, all staff that we encountered were very friendly and courteous.
review_content_20: I stayed here on my recent business trip to Baltimore and it was the best hotel I've stayed at in recent months. Great location, walking distance to the few cool spots in town, and the room was just what I needed. yelp.com/biz_photos/J9AR...TV - Finally an HDTV with HD programmingBed - Above averagePillows - Various levels of fluffiness were provided, not sure it that was intentional Bathroom - Served its purposeView - Another hotelInternet - Not needed as Baltimore has great 4g that I tethered with my phone (15MB down)On Site Food - Not testedyelp.com/biz_photos/J9AR...If you can get over the heat, humidity, crime, tourists, tiny blue crabs, and all the rest of Baltimore's failings, it's a great city to visit!My home away from home! First off Baltimore is the best kept secret in it's waterfront property,little neighborhoods like Fell's Point, Little Italy and Inner Harbor make for a romantic feel the grittyness of the city.I've stayed at this location on several occassions and loved it everytime.Convienience of nearby restaurants like Roy's, just a hop away from the Baltimore Aquarium and PowerPlant LIVE for the party animals.The Baltimore Charm Orange line bus line runs ouside the door.You can get a FREE ride to adjacent lines (also FREE)along with nearby bars and hot spots.Also, directly next door is a Starbucks and Movie Theater.Looking for a place to work out? You get a FREE pass to the upscale MAC gym.There is two sides to this hotel.Garden Inn, and the more spacious Homewood Suites.The Garden Inn is the sister to big brother Homewood Suites but in a good way.Each view I have had has been amazing! Front desk staff are professional and check-in is speedy.Downside is paying for parking UGH!!!,but at least parking is in a lot that has ample parking and is monitored.As far as ameneties go, it's up to date decor that is calm and relaxing.The bed is awesome (wink wink), Sheets are crisp and pillow are perfect.HDTV (not that you will need it) ,showerhead has three setting with great pressure.Room size is small compared to the Homewood Suites, but there is so much to do here you won't notice.Best part overall is the breakfast! The Great American Grill, takes up the whole second floor,overlooking the front of President's Street with a beautiful view.Made to order breakfast is the best.My typical egg white omlette and a variety of fruits,cereal and meat makes me want to stay another night.Price is great for location, even better with my Military discount.Just make sure you book ahead some weekends I have had to stay elsewhere.Also, make sure you check-in at exactly 3, or you risk being downgraded from your queen sized bed.I stay here everytime I am in town for work, mainly because my office is in the same building, and I get to wake up, get ready, and walk through a parking garage and voila, I am at the office. Convenient or not, this hotel is superb for many reasons, which I will share with you:1. Location - awesome. Harbor East is a booming new area in downtown, and there are a lot of new shops and restaurants with in seconds of the hotel. Little Italy is also right down the street...go to Amici's...you will thank me. Whole Foods is also around the corner, which is great if you are in town for awhile and want some food in your room. There is also a wine shop next to WF, and they sell beer and wine. Fells Point is also in walking distance, and they have great bars. Overall, if you are looking for fancy, casual, expensive, midlevel, cheap....all of the above in restaurants and bars are in walking distance.2. The warm cookies at check in. 3. The beds. High quality mattresses, pillows, and linens that will ensure a great night sleep.4. Fridge and microwave in room. 5. Room Service - very good food.6. Gym - you have access to the MAC, which is a huge full service gym. I cannot comment on price, as the bill is on my company everytime I stay, but I think it is comparable to all other hotels in the area, and the quality here is above most, especially for the great location.Location is great. Right on Presidents street on waterfront and a walk away from most everything else. Bed was very comfortable. Temperature needed initial adjustment, them remained comfortable my next 4 days there. There is a small fridge and microwave. There is a Whole Foods Market and wine stop 1 block away. There is a Starbucks and cinema right next door and an irish pub across the street.Flat screen TV was fine, but to find a channel and watch a show you have to go through a cumbersome 4-5 step menu every time you turn on the TV. Small business center with printers and other office supplies available and free of charge.The hotel is connected to a MAC gym. Blows any other gym i've been to out of the water. Next time i go to Baltimore, will definitely go here for my stay.An extra star, or two, lost to poor service. My significant otter phoned the desk to request foam pillows (side rant: feather pillows are completely useless! why must all hotels, inns, etc. default to these?! they may as well not provide pillows 'cause the feather kind are equivalent to sleeping without.) at 5 pm as we left our room. He informed them we would be out and the pillows could be left in our room. Upon return, around 11 pm, we discover one of our original pillows was missing. WTH went wrong? How do you get to the guest room, presumably carrying two foam pillows, forget to leave pillows and instead remove a pillow from the room? The otter, tired and not amused, called the desk only to have the phone ring, and ring, and ring. He finally gets an automated voice system and waits and waits. He eventually speaks w/someone and informs them of the situation and they say they'll correct the situation immediately. At least 10 minutes later (granted it was a long walk from the elevator to our room - the hall reminded us both of The Shining), someone arrives with two feather pillows. The otter was angry but tired and for the time defeated by feathers. Several minutes later there's a knock on our door. The otter goes to answer it and I remind him he's not wearing pants. Pants wearing otter opens the door to discover the same staff person with two foam pillows. As the staff member begins to ask for the return of the incorrect pillows, the otter shuts the door. I've never seen the otter get that upset. It's the little things that really do matter.Not sure why Anna chose a Hilton Garden Inn for a romantic weekend... This place is nice and new and clean. All things I love in a hotel I frequent.The front desk staff is friendly, but a little slow to greet. But I'll let it slide. I didn't have to wait long...The rooms are comfortable. Bed is great. Pillows are not those stiff hotel pillows. Desk is good for working and eating.The neighborhood is nice. Not like it used to be... Great to have a Whole Foods around the corner, along with some convenient restaurants to walk to. And just a short walk to Inner Harbor and the ball field.You get access to the gym in the building- like a regular gym, not a hotel gym. It's nice. A little crowded after work, considering they have poenty of open space they could put more equipment into. But it's good. It is only open until 6 on Sunday, which was a bummer. I had nothing to do when I got there, and would have worked out...Room service menu was pretty limited, and unappealing, so I decided not to order any. Breakfast buffet is standard, and does the job. I'll come back here...Great location in swanky Harbor East, an easy walk to the Inner Harbor in one direction and Fells Point in the other, and super close to all the great food in Little Italy. One star was knocked off for the weird bathroom double-doors with the big gap in the middle, and because I wish it had a free breakfast.Right off the bat, I was inforned that the king bed room I booked was not available, and offered two breakfast vouchers for a room with two double beds. Not quite ideal for the romantic weekend trip my husband and I were planning.When we got to our room, it was sweltering! The room temperature was 79!! The coldest the thermostat goes is 65, with no air conditioning function. After returning to our room, the temp was bumped up to 81. Not exactly the most comfortable for a 45 degree day. I was shocked the room service, and restaurant closed at 9pm. Not exactly convenient, as the "vending" machines on each floor are only equipped with an ice machine.The beds were pretty comfy, and I appreciate Neutrogena toiletries, so it wasn't a total bust, but I believe I'll be looking elsewhere to stay next time in Baltimore.As a traveler, I'm a fan of HGI in general; Hilton seems to do a much better job with both the property and the service than their head to head competition, like Courtyard Marriott.This is also a favorite of mine due to the location right on the Harbor and one of my favorite restaurants (Roy's) right across the street. Also, the property did a good job for us with a small meeting and lunches, etc.**4.5** My bed fetish has always been true to The Westin's "Sweet Sleeper" but must admit that the beds here were almost comparable which is what bumped them up from 4 to 4.5 stars. Located in a newly renovated (or so it seems) area of Baltimore, I felt safe walking near the hotel. Around the corner you'll find a Whole Foods and a variety of upscale shopping and restaurants (including my favorite, Roy's). The whole area was just beautiful! The food featured all of the upscale necessities one would need while staying at a hotel. We had trouble with our AC and the tech came up within five minutes and had it fixed in a jiffy. Even the small view of the harbor was beautiful. And of course my favorite... Black out curtains. Some other points were the convenient store which boasted a few odds and ends. Moderately priced so you didn't feel ripped off. Parking was also fairly inexpensive although it was a pain in the ass to get in and out of the garage because our card would ALWAYS get demagnetized. The staff was friendly although they could brush up on their knowledge of good places to dine. They were quite ignorant. Overall a great stay. It's so well located and in such a quiet location I can't wait to go back!!Great location, very nice rooms and close to everything. You can walk to the harbor, little Italy, and many great restaurants and bars. James Joyce is a great Irish bar/restaurant and it's right across the street. You will not be disappointed!This was only the second HGI that I've stayed in and it was head and shoulders above the quality and service I experienced at the other HGI location (Washington DC). The staff were friendly, competent, and attentive; and on par with the kind of service I've received at hotels with more stars and higher rates. The room I was in was relatively new, felt modern, clean, and quiet. The location is close to the waterfront, Little Italy, a CVS, and a Whole Foods -- very convenient. A Starbucks and movie theater are right next door. Also, since I was on a business trip I greatly appreciated the free hotel wifi which provided excellent and consistent connection. The only glitch I encountered was trying to print docs remotely to the hotel's business center, which didn't seem to work (wouldn't release my docs). I didn't eat at the hotel and didn't use the connected Maryland Athletic Center gym, but heard from other guests that it had a lot of equipment. Highly recommend this HGI location as it provided good value for the room rate.Ohmigod! The beds here were WONDERFUL! Loved my bed! Loved the duvet! Loved the pillows! Soooooo comfy! I may have slept better there than at home.The room is nice - modern and sleek. Flat screen TV on the wall. Mini-fridge and microwave. Decent size bathroom. Decent towels. Neutrogena bath products.Had a conference at the Marriott Waterfront - it sold out before we could get a room there. I thought it might be a pain staying here, but it was actually maybe even better. Super close. Very close to the Inner Harbor, Little Italy and Fell's Point. I thought the price was a little steep (~$180 + tax) so I was happy I wasn't paying. Maybe that's going rate around the area, but it's more than I'd usually pay, even for a place like this.Great location! Great price! Beautiful rooms with views and amazing amenities! There's a really good theater attached to hotel and surrounded by restaurants only problem we had with was this yellow pipe attached to a sewer grate that stunk up the entire block we stayed there Feb. 12-14 but besides the great place.Overall I was very pleased with the hotel. The beds, were very comfortable. I stayed five nights and slept very well. The hotel doesn't have its own gym facilities, but they give you a guest pass for the MAC club attached - there is a dedicated entrance from the second floor of the hotel. The fitness facilities alone will make me come back here whenever I need to come to Baltimore.Breakfast is very good; better than most other 3 star hotels. Watch out though, it costs $11.The main complaints I have were:*Price - I paid between $189-219 per night which seemed highish.*Lack of comedy central on TV (but they do have new flatscreen HDs with local HD channels*Towels smelled like maple syrup or molasses... weird.The hotel was immaculate. The room was new and modern. Tried to grab a late lunch at resturant and they would have tried to accomodate us but we went across street to Irish pub (great btw). The gym is awesome!! Indoor pool that my kids loved! Note gym closed early on Sat nite like 6??!! But seriouly the gym facility is really great. Passed by a pretty intense spin class in progressOur second night here. When arrived yesterday, were told we couldn't get our room at Homewood Suites as reserved. Instead got 2 double beds in a Hilton Garden room. Small room and bathroom. Screen on window is so dirty it might as well be a wall. Kleenex box was wet like it had been dipped in a sink of water. Left the room at 10:30am and got back at 8:00pm. The room hadn't been serviced. This is the worst experience we've had as Hilton Honors members.really wonderful location! if you are here to visit the inner harbor and the tourist spots in baltimore this is the best central location. short walks to all of the neighborhoods. the hotel is clean and the staff are very nice. there are multiple stores, shops and restaurants near by. next door to starbucks, ice cream and a movie theater! what more can you ask for.

hotel_name: Admiral Fell Inn, an Ascend Hotel Collection Member
review_content: We stayed here over Labor Day Weekend. We loved our stay and would definitely book here again. All of the staff were great, and dog friendly! Staff even greeted my dog. We did the rooftop "tour" and the guide was very informative, pointed out historical sites and gave us dinner recommendations. No problems bringing the dog at all! Room was big, cutely decorated, and had large windows. The hotel is centrally located and is walking distance to shops, restaurants, and the waterfront.The hotel was very clean, and nicely decorated. The staff was very helpful and friendly. The reason it get 2 stars is the extremely uncomfortable bed, the noise from outside and the drains were all clogged. If you want to sleep bring ear pluggs, which the staff was nice enugh to bring me. This area is very active way into the night, and all noise gets into the room.1* for the hotel bar "Tavern at Admiral Fells Inn" beneath the building (Broadway side entrance) and open W-Sa (Su ?)Walk inn to Tavern and a wave of 6hr old fish flaps into your nose. Pinch it off and waltz up to the abnormally well-lit bar that's decorated like it's still Christmas 1978. Asked the bartender for the cocktail list and.."Eh, what do you want?" A diamondback. "What's that?" Uh.. rye, chartreuse.. "I don't have chartreuse." Ok, how about a brown derby?"What's that?" Uh.. It has grapefruit. One moment.."I have grapefruit"I fumble for my phone, already planning my exit as I look up a brown derby recipe for him. My eyes float past mixology.com as it loads and down to the chartreuse green rugs. Why don't they have the liquor?Fuck this. "Hey man, gonna go somewhere else instead" and I walked out. Tavern recommendations came from a few local bartenders, so my visit must've been a wrong-time thing. I'll be back on a non-Thursday night.This review is strictly for the hotel bar, the Tavern at the Admiral... since they don't have their own yelp page I need to get this off my chest here.Nowhere in the entire city of Baltimore is it ok to charge anyone, locals or tourists, $7 for a bottle of Natty Boh... I could have gone to literally ANY other bar in the city and got a Boh for $2... $3 max! This is the cheap "local" beer that is known for being CHEAP and this place is taking advantage of tourists not knowing any better (and locals like me who never thought this was possible). So... TOURISTS BEWARE! Try a Boh elsewhere... maybe avoid this bar all together, I can't imagine how much a GOOD local craft brew is priced here... Also, the only reason I ordered a Boh is because I did't want to spend $10 on a cocktail... if I only knew then what I know now. And the bartender was not friendly or understanding about it either, we confronted him about it because we thought there had been a mistake... but no no, that was the price! Very unfortunate. I felt robbed, I will not be back.I booked this room through groupon for $99 a king bed, reservation was a breeze you are able to upgrade for an additonal fee. When we arrived at the hotel I was greeted by Emily at the front desk who was extremly nice,upgrading at the desk was breeze, the room was clean, balcony very enjoyable especially with the nice weather on that day, hotel staff attended to every need in a timely matter. Paking Valet is $30.00 a day, their are nearby parking garages with paking $23.00 a day after 5pm $9.00It's too bad you have to give a star to write a review because this hotel does not deserve a star at all. Actually, that's not true, the only reason they deserve a star is that they cater to patients and families that are receiving care at Johns Hopkins which is admirable. The stay started with a hotel room that was painted so pink it looked like pepto bismal. We also only had two hangers as well as only two open plugs for 5 electronic devices. After the first day we came back to find that our towels had been exchanged but they were exchanged for dirty towels, gross!! Thankfully housekeeping quickly brought us new towels. As I was placing the towels on the towel rack I looked up and realized there was hair all over two walls in the bathroom above eye level. There is also mold in the bathroom tiles. The hotel staff are nice enough but come the third day of our stay in the middle of what felt like a monsoon, we had to call for a shuttle to pick us up from Johns Hopkins 6 times and had to wait 1 hour and 20 minutes to be picked up. Every time we called they said 10 more min. It wasn't until the 6th time when we were completely fed up that the lady at the front desk said we could take a cab and they would reimburse us, would have been nice to know earlier!We are here with a group from work and there are three rooms of us. Each one of us has had to deal with the incredibly loud outside noise, whether it's people cl screaming and fighting on the streets after the bars let out or the loud talking that you can hear from the halls. One of the nights two men knocked on our co-workers door, if that doesn't make you feel unsafe, I don't know what would. Two of their rooms had holes for what looked like a fridge but there was no fridge, not sure if it was stolen or in the shop for repair! I was here on business and I travel a decent amount for work and pleasure and I would never recommend this hotel to anyone.We just had our wedding at the Admiral Fell on May 30, 2015.
