All I can say is that the entire event was such a massive success and all employees/staff of this hotel did a fantastic job. Mario, the General Manager is without quest, the best in the business. Not only did he treat us with the utmost respect, but did the same with every guest at that hotel. Any request was met without confrontation, any question was answered immediately, and any concern was addressed instantly.He also has a staff member, Donna, who was equally amazing. Every time we turned around, she had a drink ready for us, was there to lend a helping hand however she saw fit, and was just an absolute gem. She was there to help my wife with her dress and walking to and from the pier (where the ceremony took place,) to the cake cutting, drink preparation, and literally anything in between.If I could have given this place more than 5 stars, it would have gotten them. Highly recommend, and hats off to Mario, Donna, and the rest of the Admiral Fell staff. Cheers for making our big day a day that we will never forget.So I was a little nervous when I realized how old this hotel is. I like when my expectations are exceeded. Hotel staff is great. Location is great. My room was huge. The bed was an older king sized bed,but was comfortable. If you wanted to nit pick details you could. I understand the theme of the hotel and accepted things not to be 100%. There was free WiFi, free coffee in the lobby, and the decor was awesome. Being in Fed hill everything is right there. We plan on staying again maybe in the spring so we can check out the rest of the area. Overall, I was satisfied with everything.I have been on two separate occasions, as a plus one to a friend's work party. I liked it. The rooms are cute - large bed, comfy pillows although I only got ready in the room, didn't stay the night - each room has a famous name attached to the door, the "Poe" room for example. Nice size rooms. Clean. Very nice overall.Haven't gone down to the tavern, so I cannot speak on that, but I know its expensive and quite frankly I'm not sure why... maybe just because its Fells??I have gone up to the 5th floor, where parties and gatherings are held and it was nice up there. Nice view of the water. Open bar was nice, but I'm sure not always the case, and i hear it can be expensive, around $150 per plate when there are banquets, but not completely sure about that. Bartenders and staff were great, food was ok...nothing to write home about in my opinion. Although they did have these wonderful crab puffs that I adored... about 5 times over. Delicious!The staff at the greeting desk are very nice. The room was clean no problems there. Bed was king size and comfy. The room was small and good for 1 or 2 people only. The room was a little musty, bring some febreze. The air conditioner worked perfectly. We had rm 233, was great,especcially, if can sleep through loud noise. I was up like a zombie. But we were there for the 4th, I don't know if it's noisy in that area all the time. If you're a drunk, this place is excellent for you. Bars were north, south, East and west. The hotel and the whole fell's area is dog friendly. All in all the hotel was cool and the room was clean, it is located in a great spot for bar lovers. We ate and drank on the haborside, we took the water taxi $14 for the whole day. We didn't go to their bar or $15 buffet in the basement.. They had a greeting card in the room with a complimentary bottle of wine, lol the greeting card had the wrong name on it, but thanks for the free wine!We had a wedding at the Admiral Fell Inn and everything was very good. The Hotel GM, Mario, was amazing. He did everything possible to make things happen--from overseeing the rehearsal at the Bond Street Pier and the reception at the inn, to making drinks and helping to deliver dinners along with his staff . He is one of the best and 'hands on' GMs I have come across. The wedding venue is perfect for 120 people or less, with a nice balcony and harbor views for pre-dinner cocktails. The Bridal Suite is charming. Thank you, Mario and your professional staff, for making the day so special. I would definitely recommend the inn for a wedding.GREAT PLACE! GREAT LOCATION! WONDERFUL STAFF!PostedJuly 21, 2015Stayed there for art scape weekend. 5 min drive to any where in downtown area. Love that it sits in fells point district next to all the fun spots. Was able to party at local bars and fall right in to our wonderful room with a view at the Admril Fell Inn. No cab needed.Very clean and extremely friendly staff was very helpful in making our stay even better.Mario was great. Will defiantly be back.Just stayed in this hotel last night. It is a beautiful old historical bldg conveniently located at the shore, near all kinds of shops, restaurants and bars. All within walking distance. If you want to do a pub crawl with some friends, and don't want to drive, definitely stay here. Otherwise than that, I really felt that I did not get a great value for my money. I paid $129 for my room (2 double beds), and with the taxes I as looking at $158. And then I had to pay $24 to park my car overnight! They do not have their own private lot! And no free breakfast! Continental breakfast was offered for $9.95. Believe me they could have sprung for a muffin or two! Geez....My room was opposite the elevator, so I heard it ring every once in a while. Not a big deal, but another visitor next door created a racket starting at like 4:30 AM. How rude! Beds were comfy, room was clean. Kind of a strange furniture setup. Had a floral wingback in a corner, and a black recliner that was butted up against the bed. The chairs didn't match and they did not make sense for TV viewing with the flat screen housed in a TV armoire across the room. The cabinet that should have housed the fridge and the microwave had a big empty spot since there was no microwave, and the front of the mini fridge was scratched and dented. We pushed the desk chair to the side, and that was beat too. Arms were frayed. Coffee machine in room, but only enough condiments for 1 cup. And only 1 bottle of water left for a 2-4 person room. A second one would have been nice because the tap water did not taste good at all. A bottle of water costs about 19 cents. Shower was nice and hot but no water pressure and the tub dripped all night. Bathroom setup was junkyard. Open, rough hewn plywood shelves very roughly painted, and a old curtain covering an ironing board. Weird! There was magic marker on the sheets on one of the beds. All in all, too much money for what we received.The staff is courteous, knowledgeable, and they care. We are lifelong fans of this establishment, and Mario is the man!I - and the rest of my party - came away pretty disappointed with the Admiral Fell Inn. Here's what we experienced:* Parking is a nightmare. While that was obviously not the fault of the hotel, it was incredibly frustrating not to have an easy to see spot to pull up to use the valet parking. The person who looks like they're the valet parking for the hotel ended up being one for the restaurant next door. In order to get the valet for the hotel, you had to park and then go inside - which is highly problematic if there are no spots in front of it. Having someone outside the hotel would have made it much less stressful.* With seven of us coming into Baltimore for a bachelorette party, the maid of honor had booked two rooms with two beds in each so we could easily accommodate everyone. When we got to the rooms, we were shocked to find that both of them had one bed each - how on earth were we supposed to sleep all of us? We immediately trekked back downstairs and the concierge realized that the person who took the reservations over the phone made a huge mistake. With the hotel completely booked, he offered to have us potentially move to a sister hotel - that was out of the question as we had an hour to get ready for dinner reservations.We asked about cots and he agreed to give us two cots, one for each room, and when we asked if it would be free of charge - considering it was the hotel's fault we needed them - he immediately said yes.Fast forward to the next morning at check-out. Not only was there vast confusion with the concierge about cards to charge for the valet parking (more on that in a bit), it turned out they were trying to charge us for the cots! Upon seeing this, we immediately had an issue with it and it took at least 20 minutes before they finally relented. It was outrageous - they were trying to say that they had "upgraded" us to the rooms with the larger, one bed; without, of course, our permission. They finally, grudgingly, credited us for the cots.* Housekeeping was knocking on all the doors at 9 a.m. sharp - we had the do not disturb sign up.* Regarding the valet parking: we had three cars parked through the valet parking. On Saturday, as we checked in, we had given several different credit cards (we didn't want the cars to all go to the person who made the reservation) and were told it was no issue. It took the guy behind the counter nearly 20 minutes of explaining and going back and forth that, no, it was NOT going to be charged to the card on file; that we had given the guy the previous day instructions and cards; and yes, this needed to be done correctly so as not to force one person to pay over $80 in parking fees.* The walls are apparently made out of rice paper - I could plainly hear things coming from the rooms around, below and above us.The hotel itself is pretty nice. You can't beat how walkable it is to all the bars, restaurants and the rest of Fells Point and the bar staff downstairs was fantastic but, honestly, there's got to be better hotels in the area. It's not worth the parking stress or the inability of the staff to get it together. It was the one sour note to an amazing weekend.What a shame... had high expectations for this old historic hotel however keys have not worked since we've gotten here staff is friendly but light. We only had a two night stay and there is really nothing to boast about I would've much rather stayed at the Pier 5 or anywhere else.Fell's Point is like Bourbon Street all grown up and clean! And the Admiral Fell Inn is the place where the grown ups stay in that Harbor area.If you must stay where the tourists are packed in and kids run crazy please stay over on the other side of the Harbor. If you want a quaint, boutique hotel with fantastic service and the best crab cakes & most interesting bars within walking distance, stay here. Our airline got our luggage on the wrong flight and the car service at the airport was late and we were ready to just get checked in and figure out how to salvage our vacation if we never saw our luggage again. When we told Hakeem at the desk of our adventures so far he put us in what everyone tells us is the coolest room in the place - room 487. Ask for it if you can. You have windows on 3 sides, LOTS of room to relax and privacy since the room is on the end of the hall. We liked the place from there on out. If you think the rooms are gonna be small because it's an old hotel, they are not. Katherine has the largest suitcase in the history of suitcases and we have had to walk over it at some other historical hotels on our travels. We had plenty of room for her to open it up on the floor here.They made reservations for us at local restaurants, got car and shuttle services to them and other places the water taxi didn't go and stored our luggage after a noon check out so we could continue to enjoy the area. No one on the staff was less than fantastic! The water taxi is directly across the street and will take you to about anywhere in the Harbor. Don't bother with the free ghost tour of the hotel unless you just want the free drink afterward. There's not much information and few ghost stories involved in it really. You just kinda walk around the hotel.Yes it's even close enough to enjoy Camden Yards or the Ravens' games if you don't mind a short cab ride.Why 4 and not 5 stars? I asked twice for regular coffee for the in room coffee maker and was told they were out. In 5 days they couldn't get regular coffee for the rooms? Really? They do have coffee and muffins in the lobby in the mornings. But if you just want to roll out and stay in your jammies and have a cup...well, you'd be out of luck unless you drink decaf.While we were in Baltimore the weather changed from 90 degrees to 50 (even chillier at night). We walked into a very cold room the afternoon the front came through. We were told they were having the heat "changed over" from AC and it would be fixed in a while. So we went to eat and have a few beers. A few beers and Monday Nigh Football later we came back to a colder room. They did move us to another room - the honeymoon suite - with a gas fireplace. But it took forever to get that to a temp where we could sleep comfortably. A local woman we ran into told us the Inn has a reputation of not having decent heat.Look, I know those are picky things but heat in a hotel is kinda important and regular coffee doesn't seem like a special order.We'll stay here everytime and would tell friends it's the only place to stay in the Baltimore area. You'll find your best deals for rooms on Hotels.com or Expedia.com. It'll save you enough to enjoy the fantastic crab cakes a few times at Duda's down the street.This place is great. Especially the bar - Steve and christian took great care of us. Amazong drinks and awesome service. This is my second time staying at the AFI. The only downfall was that I could not watch the ball game when Baltimore was doing so well!I have mixed feelings about this hotel. The location is perfect for a weekend getaway in Fells Point. The staff was very friendly and helpful. The rooms were clean. And the price was reasonable. But the rooms leave a bit to be desired. Bathrooms could use an upgrade. The unique beds in each room certainly weren't traditional. Our room had beds that were nearly bunk height. I had to ask for towels each day bc we only got one in the room. I'd stay here again especially because of the location, but I'd balance expectations.Great historical hotel!!! Staff were super friendly and very helpful!! Amazing that its really pet friendly - our daughters cat was very comfy for the three days we were there. Its right in the thick of all the action so it is a bit noisy sometimes - but it was built in the 1700's and is really authentic, which means no double paned windows:-) I thought the breakfast was a bit basic for the $10 they charge, but there are other great options close by. They provide valet parking that is also a bit pricey, but no more expensive than most of the other hotels close by. I look forward to staying here again at the earliest possibility!!
review_content_20: I stayed here for one night. It's in a great location relative to dining and drinking, is a quick cab ride or a twenty/twenty-five minute walk to downtown. Another review here talked negatively about a Pepto-Bismol pink room - I stayed in one with a very pink bathroom and very pink bedroom accents and loved that it had such a vibrant color. It was clean, the beds were comfortable, and the staff were helpful and friendly. I think it's a bit expensive for what you get, but I did have a very short stay.Nice historic hotel. Clean rooms although there's no grab bars or anything if someone would need assistance. LOVE the stairs to get up into the bed! The bartender was awesome but his manager left a lot to be desired. I ordered a dink and was told by the manager that it was a shot so I ordered something else. My friend ordered the the drink from the bartender and it was not a shot, but the drink I had expected originally. We're still excited to continue our stay, more shopping, Irish music for breakfast, and more celebrating to come.We stayed at the Admiral Fell Inn with a group of friends this weekend.My fiance and I were pleased to learn that this is a dog-friendly hotel, so we brought ours along. Upon check in they gave us a gift bag for our pup (treats and a toy) which was very thoughtful. Although we are 'dog people' we didn't want to stay in a hotel that felt like dogs were there - we are happy to report that our room (and the hotel) was very clean and odor free - you'd never know if any pets had stayed there.They also gave us a bottle of wine upon check in and vouchers for breakfast, which was really nice; omelet station, pastries, fresh fruit, coffee, etc.The staff at breakfast were also very courteous and polite, I was impressed that they took our name when we ordered our omelet and brought it to our table.The hotel is in the perfect location, a quick walk to all of the restaurants, bars and shops that we wanted to check out. Though it is a little loud at night, that's a trade off when you are staying in the 'heart' of the activity, and in my opinion completely worth it.All of the staff were extremely polite and helpful. Definitely check out the bar downstairs, the bartender that was working on Saturday night was a really nice guy and told us some of the ghost stories and history of the hotel.We are planning on taking another trip to Fells Point when the weather is warmer and plan on returning to the Admiral Fell Inn.Quite possibly the WORST night I've ever had in a hotel! Room 219 just above nightclub..impossible to sleep! Room vibrated from the music..cars honking all night & loudstreet noise just below my window. Tried to change rooms completely sold out. Sunday early am street cleaners going up &down!Superb location in a historic hotel if you are a single traveller or couple without kids. This part of Fells Point is right across from the Water Taxi port and a short walk from Pitango Gelato. I was here in late October for a conference and stayed in Room 118 (first floor). The check-in process and valet parking ($24 per night) at 9pm were fast and professional. It's worth requesting the free MAC fitness center pass when you check-in to save time. The gym is about a 15 minute walk away in the Harbor East neighborhood (located in the same building as the Homewood Suites, about a block from the Whole Foods). PROS: The high ceilings, splash of pink, and Federalist-style furniture were nice. The free Wi-FI was also a big plus. The location and convenience of valet parking were also great (if you don't mind the $24 charge, otherwise there's a DIY lot for $14). The conference meeting space on the 5th floor with its view of downtown Baltimore was spectacular and convenient for guests staying at the hotel. CONS: Room 118 had a faint mechanical noise (elevator?) that ran in the evening, but stopped by midnight. Having a closet in the bathroom was a bit strange. Walking 15 minutes to get to an indoor gym (MAC) or the CVS/Whole Foods in Harbor East was inconvenient. Check-out was slow because Hakeem had disappeared for 10 minutes "to pickup lunch at his home". Leaving the front desk on a Saturday without requesting backup is unprofessional. BOTTOM LINE: If you have kids, I would strongly recommend the Homewood Suites at Harbor East instead - which is closer to the Aquarium. If you prefer historic inns, the Admiral Fell Inn is your place.If you want a clean, comfortable hotel or a good night of sleep, don't stay here. Many of the other reviewers complained of the noise from the street outside, but we were on the back side of the hotel and did not experience that. However, the walls of the hotel are paper thin and we could hear everything going on in the hallway and the nearby rooms clearly. We are very heavy sleepers and can sleep through nearly everything, but noisy people in the halls talking and shouting loudly and slamming doors woke us up many times in the night. When we complained, they apologized and were very nice but did nothing. To make matters worse, the room was dingy and had seen better days. It was also freezing cold with a draft from outside so strong that it moved the curtains, but if we turned on the heat the room got suffocatingly hot. There was no ability to heat the room to a normal temperature, nor was there a comforter on the bed -- just sort of a thin decorative coverlet or maybe it was an empty duvet cover. The shower had mold in the grout and there were hairs stuck to the bathroom walls. Disgusting. The only redeeming quality is that the location is good, but we will not be staying here again.Two-night stay: rehearsal dinner and wedding night. The staff are very friendly, the inn has great character and the location is just unbeatable, but I feel that this B&B is very overpriced -- just not a good value.Our stay added up to almost $700 for two nights with parking for only one night (despite originally being told when making the reservation that parking was included and that our stay would only be $500), and our room was just not nearly as nice as you would expect for paying that much money. It was a bi-level suite with only four chairs downstairs, no couch. Many of the doors and cabinets were either extremely creaky or broken. There was no body wash provided, only facial/hand soap and shampoo/conditioner. The TV was bizarrely slow to respond to the remote control. The toilet was incredibly slow to flush and you had to hold down the handle for upward of 10 seconds to get it moving. The breakfast was just pastries and cereal, no hot food. There was a stain on the sheets and the staff did not turn over our room after the first night. Obviously none of these things on their own are a big deal, it's just that for the amount of money we paid we expected a much nicer stay with more attention to detail. For two nights total at $700 we could have stayed at Celie's or Henderson's and had an overall much nicer experience.We just left the Admiral Fell and Thank God! It is 95 degrees and no air-conditioning! Yes, that's right, no air. My husband and I were up all night. The air was so thick you couldn't breath. We called down to the desk and they informed us that they were working on it. We asked if they had a room fan and they said the did not. I was livid. The next morning I called the manager and he agreed to knock off 50 dollars from our room. Big deal, our room was $275. We thought we would spring for a more expensive room to make the stay more special and it turned out to be a nightmare. The room itself was ok. Two wing chairs in the sitting room which were very uncomfortable. Should be a sofa in there. Also stains on the carpeting to the second floor and cheap laminate flooring in the bedroom. I would expect a little more luxurious setting for the price I paid.If I could give zero stars, I would. We booked a room here on Booking.com. I always use that website & have never had a problem through them. I travel frequently for work & have stayed in hotels all over the country. I had always wanted to stay here as well. First, they charged me a $30 incidental fee, which they informed me would be credited back after my stay. They explained it well & I had no problem with it. However, it definitely made me wonder what kind of place I was staying in that I was basically paying a security deposit...My booking online was supposed to be for $149 for the night, which was including the taxes & hotel fees. They told me it was to be $182 for the night with the taxes & fees. This was aggravating, but I agreed to it. Five minutes later I get to my room & something told me to check my bank account & low & behold...a charge of $212 & separately the $30 fee were charged. I called down & they tried to give me some BS about the incidental fee. I went down to the lobby & none of them knew what to do. They were not helpful & just tried to talk in circles to get rid of me. Finally, the manager came over & offered us $30 off of the room & was honestly unsure of what had happened. I was just fed up & no longer wanted to stay there. He said he would credit my money back & I left. About 20 minutes later, I felt the need to look at my account again & again they had taken out $30 & $212! I called them, got put through to the manager's VM, then called back & was informed there was no MOD & I would have to call back tomorrow! So now I have paid $484 for a room that I am not even staying in & I still have to find another room! Unbelievable! If this place wants to be on the same level as even a Motel 6, they really need to work on their customer service & management. I will NEVER recommend anyone to stay here. Such a major disappointment. And I really hope for their sake that they return my money promptly.This is a charming hotel. We really enjoyed our stay here! The location couldn't be better. It's right in the middle of Fell's Point, within walking distance to tons of shops and restaurants. The exterior is beautiful and the interior is cozy and comfortable. The staff at the concierge desk were friendly and helpful, as were the valets. The room was really nice. It was very well-decorated - no cheesy artwork or ugly, heavy drapes. It was very clean and the bed was really comfy. There are three restaurants attached to the hotel. One of them, Meli, was closed for renovations when we were there. There is also a tapas restaurant called Adela, as well as a more casual restaurant where you can get breakfast if you don't want to eat the free continental breakfast they serve in the lobby. We didn't eat at any of them this time, but the menus looked decent, and I like the convenience factor of having so many dining options available right in the hotel. There are three things keeping me from giving the hotel 5 stars: the continental breakfast, the parking price, and the nightly noise. They serve complimentary fruit, "homemade" muffins, and coffee for breakfast in the lobby each morning. The muffins were cold and tasted like they were just made from a boxed mix. And there was barely any fruit - just a couple of oranges. The coffee was good, though. The valet parking offered by the hotel is a rip-off. Don't bother with it. There's a public parking lot a block and a half away, where you can park all day/night for a reasonable price. As for the noise - I know it's hard to drown out the noise of people on the street, but I think the hotel could make a bigger effort to do so. Our room was on the corner of two streets with lots of bars and restaurants on them and there were tons of people outside making lots of noise both nights we were there. I have no problem with the people being loud outside. It's the hotel's responsibility to ensure the comfort of their guests by doing something to soundproof the rooms a bit better.All-in-all, the experience was very nice and I would return to this hotel!How I love this hotel! Or, should I say WE love it? My daughter and I took a long weekend trip to Baltimore. Our destination? Fells Point. Why? Because we love the shops and restaurants and bars there and have such an amazingly fun time every time we hit that city AND Fells Point. For the last couple years of this annual trip, every time we passed by the Admiral Fell Inn, we'd say, "Next time we're staying there." And now that we finally did, we wouldn't stay anywhere else!Why? From the few steps up into the lobby, the staff is extraordinarily friendly and accommodating - actually, even before we got there we were contacted by the hotel staff to see what more they could do to make our stay more comfortable, more interesting and more convenient. I like that!The room was gorgeous! Two beautiful mahogany, four poster canopy beds dripping with cotton lace awaited as we entered the room. Everything about the room suited the quirky, historic twists, turns and narrow hallways of the history contained within the hotel. Every room even has a name! Ours was Forbes. Did I mention it's haunted?! Even better!We did have a little noise outside of the windows around 3:00 a.m. on Friday night, but I rolled right over and went back to sleep. After all, if you want to stay in the midst of where it's happening in Baltimore, what else do you expect? I'd rather have that than have to take a cab back to someplace quiet and boring. And Saturday night was quiet as could be...or else I just slept through it.We can't wait to go back and repeat our experience all over again! Oh, and don't you love the name?! (And, yes, there really was an Admiral Fell...they didn't just invent the name for the pun.)Location: greatParking situation: a little confusing (street parking was marked in a confusing way, and the garage that is closer to the hotel is closed during what would seem like peak hours - try the one just a little farther away to bypass this issue)Room: surprisingly large, clean, lots of character.Service: decentHubs and I booked through hotwire so we didn't really know what to expect, based on the reviews here and other places online. We were in town for the Baltimore Marathon and were pleased with its relative proximity to the Inner Harbor touristy area.We arrived kind of late (9ish) after a long drive from Charlottesville and we had to wait a pretty long time to check in (there was only one attendant and he was assisting guests with valet parking charges or something) - but once we finally did, finding our room was quick (just one floor up) and I was glad that we had the room next to the ice dispenser (for post-marathon icing)!It was definitely a lively area to stay in - people were outside til late in the evening/early in the AM having a good ol' time, but hubs and I were so sleepy it didn't phase us.Definitely a disappointment. I love historic hotels but Admiral Fell Inn is just plain shabby. Offered $25 meal voucher but breakfast consisted of cold cereal and yogurt. No in room hospitality features. TV was on the wall to the side of the bed, so you had to lay sideways in the bed to watch. Uncomfortable mattress and pillows. Bathroom floor was damp and toilet was stained. Hotel staff were talking loudly outside my window, apparently on a break, at 11:38 PM. Very overpriced. Uncomfortable. Unpleasant. One redeeming feature was that front desk staff were polite.Second time I've stayed here. Nice historic hotel. Right in the heart of Fells Point. Excellent location for partying in Fells. This is a very well kept, professional, and elegant hotel. That said, it is very old so the floors creek, walls are thin, beds noisy but very comfy. The tv's are up to date flat screens. Staff is super friendly &very helpful. Very clean. DOWN SIDE - A bar opened up down stairs directly under the second floor rooms. They play Loud techno music till 1:30 am. Fortunately I travel with ear plugs, but it was really bad &the whole room was shaking. The hotel never mentioned that was an ongoing problem when I booked, nor when I checked in. They apologized saying they weren't affiliated & were in the process of trying to sound proof the ceilings of the bar & 2nd floor floors. Tip: 1) bring water & ear plugs, problem solved. 2) the valet service is nice, convenient but $24. They park it a few yards away in the public parking garage. Save the money & park it there yourself for only $3/day. 3) the buffet under the hotel is $15, not worth it. Not a big deal because there are plenty of restaurants around. 4) do the hotel's ghost tour, it's pretty quick, free, and full of some really cool history stuff. I'll definitely keep coming back.I spent a weekend here with two friends and was really surprised at how great this hotel is. I was concerned that the room would be small based on the photos online but to my surprise, our room was huge. Plenty of space for the three of us and 2 king beds. The room was super clean, had free wifi and the standard amenities: coffee maker, tv, hair dryer, iron, etc. We parked at the lot 2 blocks away for $14/night. You can't beat the location of this place. You're within walking distance to a ton of bars/restaurants. Inner Harbor is about 2 miles away making it a nice walk as well plus there's lots to see/do on the way. Staff were friendly and helpful. This place was less than $100/night and I would definitely stay here again.We had our wedding here in November 2013, using the top floor ballroom for the ceremony, cocktail hour, and reception. The wedding packages are very customizable, inclusive (linens, cake, centerpieces, musicians, transportation, etc) and we had a great experience. The best part is that at no additional cost you're provided with a coordinator - in our case Kristina Yepes- who did an absolutely amazing job. We really couldn't have asked for a better venue. Kristina made it so easy for us!! Our guests loved staying there as well - the only complaint was that the front desk staff was not extremely helpful when they called for reservations. In person the front desk staff was friendly and helpful, but I never talked to them on the phone.There is also some street noise - you're in the heart of Fells Point, to be expected, but totally worth it for the photos on the cobblestone streets and dock and tons of bar and restaurant choices for guests - a great part of Baltimore to introduce guests to!My wife and I booked a room at the Admiral Fell Inn for the first weekend in May to celebrate our wedding anniversary. The hotel is centrally located on the corner of Thames and Broadway in Fells Point. The lobby is nicely appointed, and our room was gorgeously laid out with hardwood floors and a large jacuzzi tub/shower. Our room had a shared balcony that overlooks Thames Street (sort of- to look down requires standing on a chair.) The small hotel bar had a local Heavy Seas beer on a cask pour system and made for a lovely space to watch the Kentucky Derby. Fells Point is a popular bar district, but we did not notice any noise from the street, in large part due to the large amount of noise from the wedding reception in the ballroom directly overhead. It got noisy when the dance floor was full, but we knew what we were getting into and the noise did not go obnoxiously long into the night. There were the little things, though, that made me raise my eyebrows. We paid for a Harbor Magic package, which included a few extra perks, such as a bottle of wine in the room. It was there upon arrival, but I found it odd we were never asked a preference, not even of red or white. When we were checking out, I asked if the Harbor Magic package came with anything else, and was presented with a $25 gift card off a future stay, as well as a $25 dining certificate for one of several local restaurants. The latter sure would have come in handy the night before when we went out to dinner, especially with the (hand-written) expiration date of that night. Fortunately we were locals and not rushing for a plane so we did make a point to use it. Our room was very clean, but there was litter on the balcony for the duration of our stay. The staff might be due some exra training perhaps, such as on not having conversations across the desk while guests are standing right there. There were many welcoming and friendly members of staff, although the man who checked us in was particularly quiet and reserved (he certainly didn't ask or check if we had, say, booked a Harbor magic package.) Overall, it's a lovely hotel and we look forward to staying there again."Admiral Fell Inn"Say it aloud. "Admiral Fell Inn"I swear I laugh every time I say it aloud or hear someone else say the name. I feel compelled to say, "Where?" and I have said it. The front desk stare at me and say, "Excuse me?" Enough of my touristy bantering, though. This is a historical hotel located in Fells Point within Baltimore. You have a great street that you can walk on with a plaza to the the left as you look out the front entrance. I only wish there were more people in the area. As close as Fells Point is to Downtown, it is still quite far due to the larger thoroughfares that are present. You can try to walk, but it is not recommended.The interior has been redone and looks rather tasteful in the rooms as well as in the common areas. Where the design falls short is in the mediation between the rooms and the lobby. One must traverse a dark and winding passage way that goes left, right, left, up and down to get to your room. I think this may have something to do with the fact that several older buildings have been combined under one use.All-in-all, I enjoyed my stay and will try this Inn again. I hope that the stone streets become more lively.Great, hidden tavern downstairs with amazingly crafted cocktails and knowledgeable mixologists on staff.Ok, before you book you must remember you are staying at an old historic hotel. Its not the hilton. Of course the walls are thin. You are staying in Fells Point which has the greatest concentration of bars in probably all Amuurrrka. With that said, if you are looking for quiet, fluff, pampering, free big continental breakfast, spa, then go somewhere else, this is not the place for you.But. If you are looking to experience something old and special. A bit of history. Closeness to some great night life (and in my opinion, even better and more mature than temple bar Ireland), great food, great drinks, and lots of great cool people, then this is for you. I really enjoyed my stay. Honestly, the customer service was great to me. If you are lucky enough to meet Hakeem, send my regards. He is fantastic and if I was a business owner I'd steal him away.
review_content_40: Fabulous hotel in the most perfect location.  The bedding is cozy and the rooms are clean. The hotel staff were all very friendly and helpful.  We will absolutely be return guests !!  Thank you admiral fell inn for an amazing weekend !!I was planning a quick romantic get-away and needed a hotel. I did have reservations somewhere else and I was feeling ok about them. But then, the Groupon Gods smiled on me and offered this beauty of a hotel for all of $62 a night. Score! So I bought the Groupon and cancelled my other reservations. Looking on Yelp, I was a bit apprehensive. But I also know that some people just don't Yelp nicely because they're jerks. My good experience with this place started even BEFORE we got there. Kimber, my Experience Specialist, was very knowledgeable and helpful when it came to planning my trip. She recommended restaurants, told us about parking and was very prompt in getting back to me when I had questions about anything. We arrived at the hotel. Its in the heart of Fell's Point, near the bars, but not close enough to where you'd hear any riff raff. We don't like riff raff. We were greeted by Dorian, a very professional front desk person. He took care of us, ensuring that the feather pillows I wanted were in the room when I arrived. We got to the room and it was so nice! This hotel has so much charm and character. Each of the rooms has a name and a story behind it. It was a spacious room with a very comfy bed. The bathroom had its requisite soaps and shampoos and such and they were actually good products. Kimber had sold me on a gift certificate to go to one of their restaurants. $40 for $50 worth of food. Not a bad deal. So I did it. We went to Pizzazz. Bad deal. Experience was so terrible that we only got $29 worth of food, making the certificate pointless. I called back to the hotel and told them about that so they could take the certificate off my bill. They were all so nice! Dorian handled the situation like a pro! Wait, it gets better. Because of my situation with the restaurant (see my Pizzazz review next), Dorian and Hakeem gave me a $50 certificate to the hotel for the next time I wanted to come back.I was impressed with the professionalism of the staff and the overall look and feel of the hotel. Because we enjoyed our stay so much, we're now looking for reasons to go to Baltimore for an overnight stay. Thank you, Admiral Fell Inn staff, for making my experience so good!This is a nice old hotel in the pretty and historic neighborhood of Fells Point.   Everything was great except for the booming noise coming from the nightclub downstairs late at night.  It appears to be a new club that is not good news for this hotel.   Calling reception at midnight, I was given the option of changing rooms, which would have been a big hassle, but was then told the loud music would soon finish, which jt did.  However, I was told that it would be open until 2am the following night, which would have been a big problem had I been staying longer.  I strongly suggest you get a room much higher than the second floor and not on the side street where the club is located.   It's a pity.I read all of the other Yelp reviews before I booked our weekend getaway using their Wonderful Winter Weekend package.  The package, as listed on their website, is supposed to include: 1.  First night, full price, second night for 50% Off  2. Free Valet Parking 3.  Two half bottles of wine 4.  $25 Harbor Magic Gift Card to use on your next visit5.  $25 Dining and Spa VoucherWe arrived after they stopped offering valet for the night (around 10) so we had to find parking, on a Friday night, in the heart of Fells Point, a place where every other business is a bar.  We found a spot as someone was pulling out, about a block and a half from the hotel.  A block and a half is pretty far when you're hauling luggage.  Upon check in we were given the $25 Harbor Magic gift card.  The wine was waiting in our room.  We never received the $25 dining card and it was never mentioned.  When we woke up on Sunday morning, the slip under the door indicated they were going to charge us $29 for valet parking and I brought it to the attention of the front desk and the charge was removed.  I don't know if they're shady or just disorganized. Our room was pretty nice.  It was clean with a little wear around the edged.  We had the Vane Room on the 4th floor, one of the King rooms with a jacuzzi tub and balcony access.  I think we were told when we called that we had our own balcony, but it was shared between our room and the room next door to us.  The jacuzzi tub was great and it was clean but I felt like I needed a stepladder to climb in and out of it.  Also, the soap that was in the room was rather bizarre.  It was a full-sized bar but with a big hole in the middle.  The box said something about removing the often wasted middle part of the soap.  I don't think I've ever used the edges only and thrown away the middle.  If they're concerned about waste, just provide a smaller bar. Based on appearance and features, I don't really feel like it was worth $300 a night to sleep here.  I guess you pay for the location, which was incredible.  It's right in the middle of everything in Fells Point.It is very, very small.  The pictures of the lobby area is pretty accurate but still not as big as the pictures look.  The room, I'm sure if we shelled out a lot more money we could have had a bigger room but the one we stayed in way way, way too small.  The only reason I didn't give it a one star is because it was very clean, staff was very helpful, and it is within walking distance of pretty much everything: entertainment, food, shops, etc..Great service, paper thin walls so sound isn't great if you have loud neighbors.  If you are a light sleeper, request the back side of the hotel not facing the street so you don't get all of the street noise from the bars closing. The staff was great the entire time, and accommodated several of our requests. We had extremely  loud neighbors who carried on with their door wide open . They had friends down the hall who yelled through the hallway when they wanted to communicate at 1am and it was so loud that it felt like they were inside our room. We called the front desk and they solved the problem for us which was great. The location was awesome, as it's right in the middle of everything in Fells Point. One thing that was also annoying was that the TV didn't have clear channels, it was fuzzy channels - about 60% visibility which  was strange because it was just basic cable. All in all it's not fancy but has a quaint charm and great staff.I spent two nights here with my husband and our yorkie, Stewie.  We really enjoyed our time there!About a week before our arrival, a representative from Harbor Magic Hotels emailed me, which was really impressive.  He was able to have our National Aquarium tickets ready for us when we checked in - if you are staying at this hotel, this is a great option.  The tickets are the same price as they would be at the Aquarium itself, but you can skip the line when you get there, and it also allows you entry at any time (as opposed to the timed tickets that the aquarium offers).  I don't know if I would have given the hotel 4 stars if it wasn't pet friendly; there were a few stains on the carpet in our room, but I was more lenient in looking the other way given that we could bring our dog, and there was no additional fee.  If you are expecting a Hilton or Marriott level of hotel, this may not be the place for you.  Each room is different, and the style is a bit old fashioned.  For me, this added to the charm.  The location is great - right by tons of bars, restaurants, and unique little shops.  The price for the room is also very reasonable.The Admiral Fell Inn has a unique charm. When I walked through the doors I remember thinking that I wished the walls could talk. The Inn reminds me  of some of the historical homes I have toured.  The staff was gracious and attentive. The bar downstairs is well stocked and drinks are poured generously. You can't beat the location. You are a short walk to dozens of excellent places for food, drink, or sightseeing. Why only 3 stars?  The rooms are very small and uncomfortable.  My room was no bigger than a walk-in closet in your average McMansion.  I was with a group of people, they all had the same complaint.We are local but were looking for someplace special to stay for a weekend and celebrate our birthdays together, that wouldn't require a long trip as we travel a lot for our jobs .  We chose the Admiral Fell Inn because we like historic places to stay.  While I'd say our experience  came out overall positive, it was definitely mixed.  The Admiral Fell is a nice place with friendly staff but it needs to get its act together and live up to its "no surprises" guarantee. First, the good things:  The location of this Inn is wonderful, especially if you're looking to stay in a historic setting near good restaurants and interesting bars.  Shopping in Fells Point is meh, but you can hop on a Water Taxi just steps from the hotel's door and jet over to Baltimore's Inner Harbor for more shops, or just ride the Water Taxi around the harbor for a nice view of the night lights.  (We did this - very romantic for nine dollars a person.) The Inn staff are friendly, nice and polite.  Our bed was comfortable and had a "romantic" canopy, and the room/furniture was in OK repair for a historic hotel (except for the bathroom sink - more on that later).   The elevator and public rooms are well kept and elegant.  Since we know parking in Fells Point is a hassle, we opted for the valet parking at 29 dollars a day.  Our weekend package included one night accommodations, chocolates (yummy), free breakfast in the morning, and some other stuff like coupon books and a CD which we did not really use. The room price we were quoted on the booking website was slightly underquoted as it did not include various taxes and fees, particularly a $9.95 "convenience fee" that was supposed to cover a bunch of stuff like long distance but in our case just covered bottled water and Internet - we didn't even get a Sunday paper.  Still, the room price was OK for the area and season.  So far, so good.  Now, the not-so-great stuff...We booked online and were contacted the next day by a "Harbor Magic specialist" who asked if there was anything more she could do for us to help with our stay.  I had been meaning to make a dinner reservation, but I thought I'd let her do it as I wasn't super familiar with good Fells Point restaurants.  I asked her if "the hotel had any restaurants" and she replied there were two, Fin's and Meli's, and that she would be glad to make us a reservation.  I asked which restaurant was nicer and she said they were both very nice but Fin's was more "traditional" and served steak.  As we were going for the traditional/ historic I asked her to please make the reservation there for 6:30 pm.  When we checked in, I confirmed with the desk clerk that the reservation at Fin's for 6:30 had been made.  I was told all was in order.We were not offered the "king upgrade subject to availability" we had been promised and were put in a room with two double beds.  The bathroom, while huge, had a big crack in the sink and a tub that wasn't particularly deep or nice - so much for a "romantic" bath.  We decided not to complain about the room because it had a decent view of Thames Street and the harbor and there was a wedding in the hotel that we figured probably took a lot of rooms. When we went down for our 6:30 dinner at Fin, we discovered that neither the dowdy hostess or the very snooty manager there had any knowledge of the reservation that the hotel supposedly made.  They were very rude to us, told us that the restaurant was separate from the hotel (different story than what we got from the hotel), claimed they were fully booked and offered to seat us in a backroom near the kitchen with nothing comped.  Because they were so nasty, plus their decor was not very "traditional", we declined.  We were later told that Fin and the hotel had been having strained relations as the hotel was working more with Meli's and apparently Fin took out their frustrations on us.  Phooey on them, as I said we are local and will never eat there now and will warn others away also.The hotel clerk apologized to us, booked us into Kalis' Court up the street and gave us a 50 dollar voucher,  so they did fix things, but would have been better if it didn't happen at all. At about 1:30 am we were awakened by a large crowd of people screaming in the street under our window for about 15 minutes- the hazards of staying in a bar area.  When we went to have our free breakfast at Meli's (our letter in our reservation specifically stated "Melis") we were told by the (nice) manager there that they weren' t offering the hotel breakfast until tomorrow.  Back to the desk clerk who directed us to another part of the hotel where breakfast was being served - yet another "surprise".  Finally, we had a late checkout of 2 pm with our package, but no one told housekeeping, who came beating down our door at 12:15 pm when we weren't dressed AND had a do not disturb sign up. By that time I was relieved to get out of there before anything else happened.My favorite place to stay in Baltimore.  I love it because:-  Neat, historic, great old photos of Baltimore history on walls, no two rooms alike, farthest thing from the chains you can get, totally functional, no ridiculous contrivances.-  Location is awesome, feel safe walking alone at night, close to everything (including my office)-  Has the things I need:  comfortable bed, good bathroom, no bad smells, safe, friendly.Things to know that may mean it's not good for you:-  A little noisy.  I don't ever have a problem, but I could see how some folks might.  The cobbled streets make the cars rumble as they go by, and the nightlife can include some enthusiastic outside discussions that are audible from some rooms.  Never kept me awake, though.- Rooms are sometimes pretty small, and many have an unusual shape (like a triangle, for instance).  I travel alone mostly, so that is totally fine with me.  -  Really not the typical hotel; if you're more comfortable with the standard Hilton/Marriot/whatever experience, and it bugs you when things aren't consistent in the way commercial hotels are (which is totally understandable!), this might not be a good spot for you.-  Steep steps in the entry,  several sets of steps that punctuate the halls to the rooms, and other odd angles make this a potential challenge for people with little kids or mobility trouble.Well, booked the hotel for a quick night away from Washington, looking to spend the evening in Fell's Point. The location of this hotel is perfect, right on the wharf, in the heart of this historic part of Baltimore.Entered the hotel shortly after 4, the posted check in time, and was told, "Oh, I am sorry, I have some bad news. We had some guests from Johns Hopkins stay beyond their reservation and so we do not have a room for you. We can give you a room in one of our sister hotels. It is only a ten minute drive away." I asked why I had not been called about this and he just looked at me. I asked for the manager, demanded a room, and within ten minutes had the key in my hand. It seemed oddly like something they had done many many times. Do they just overbook all the time, or are they that poorly managed?Despite the problem, the room was large and comfy. The hotel is charming in a sort of rundown historic hotel way. There were some stains on one of the chairs and some cracks in the plaster in the room. The hotel could use a pretty big overhaul. BUT, if you are looking to spend a few days in Fell's Point (which I do recommend), this place would do, just make sure to keep your expectations low, very low.The Admiral Fell is ok.  I stayed here each of the last two years after my Company's Christmas party, which was held downstairs.   I believe there was a $20 discount as a result.Anyways,Pros:1) Location.  You could not be more downtown in Fells Point.   If you walk out of your room you are near everything.2) Each room is named after a famous Baltimore man or woman.  For example this year I stayed in the Babe Ruth suite.  While it did not come with beers and hot dogs, its cool to read a little back story about a famous Baltimoreon.(?).  3)  Valet parking.   While not free, still a nice service to offer in Fells Point.Cons:1) Both this year and last The Admiral Fell has mischarged me.   Last year they did not give me the discount I was quoted over the phone.   This year they charged my girlfriend's card (who booked the room), even though upon check-in, gave my card and asked any and all charges to go to me.  They also tried to charge without discount again.  I was told my other co-workers similar things happened to them.   Poor business practice here really.2)  If I was being a nit, I'd complain about the size of the rooms, but that is the case anywhere in this historic built region.  Deal with it.3) The "ghost".  A guy who I suppose is an employee of the hotel came into our party and told the story of how he "haunted the building for over 200 years" etc etc.   While at least he dressed the part, he was awkward, unfunny and long-winded.   I think the long winded part was him waiting for a tip (which mercifully one of the bosses gave him and he finally left).  Hey ghost, your act blows.   Take it out to the streets of Fells Points and entertain the drunks or something.   You were a proverbial turd in the punchbowl at our office party.The Fell is ok on the whole.   Double check your bill, and tell the ghost to beat it.Loved this hotel and the super friendly staff!  They were awesome.  The rooms are a bit worn down, but enjoy the history and a fun, eclectic environment.  The hotel and area Is very dog friendly and the pubs were great.  Enjoy!I've stayed here and their sister hotel(Pier 5). Location is key, and The Admiral Fell in is in a great location.  You have access to tons of bars, boutiques and restaurants, $5 cab ride to the inner harbor, $7 to Johns Hopkins, and an option for the water taxi across the street($9, and is good for use from 9am-11pm)The staff tries really hard, and is helpful, although sometimes they seemed confused.  The shuttle service is mediocre, I often found myself taking one of the cabs waiting across the street instead of waiting for the shuttle(The shuttle drives for both Pier 5, and the Admiral Fell Inn, and is often a 10-20 minute wait).  I should mention that if the shuttle is unavailable, the hotel will reimburse cab fare, in the form of a deduction from your room bill.I was there for about 10 days, and had 3 different rooms.  Each of those rooms was noisy in some form or fashion, loud ventilation, street noise, etc.  The noise is in no way a deal breaker, but if you are sensitive to that sort of thing, or are planning on bringing an infant, you may want to take that in to consideration. (The street noise is BAD on the weekends after the bars close.)The rooms are sort of expensive, but you're better off forking out the $$$ than staying in other less expensive hotels in the area, you might find yourself being robbed, sold crack, or in the middle of a gunfight elsewhere in Baltimore.I would recommend this location for a weekend getaway during the summer for people in the NY/NJ area.  I would also recommend staying here if you're a patient/visiting Johns Hopkins hospital.  After research, this is in my opinion, the closest, and more importantly, safest place to stay that is in the vicinity of the hospital.If you're staying there, I'd recommend "Mezze"(2 minute walk) for dinner, and "Liquid Earth"(5 minute walk, vegetarian) for lunch.  The free breakfast in the hotel is pretty good, and the people that prepare/serve the breakfast are really on their game.1.5 stars for admiral fell inn, but i'll be generous and round up since the location is great.  (right in the middle of fell's point and just a short taxi ride - water or auto - to the inner harbor.)  i had high hopes for this hotel, but they fell pretty short.  (no pun intended.) i heard about admiral fell first from my boss, then from a couple of friends.  when a friend was in town for a conference and wound up staying @ this property, i decided i'd give it a try based on seeing her room.  it was lovely with big, fluffy canopy beds and gorgeous decor.  the bathroom was on the small side but very cute w/ a claw foot tub.  everyone (staff) seemed very nice and i really liked the vibe of the place w/ all its old/historic charm.  up it went to the top of my list for places to stay in baltimore.  FF to my weekend there.  ugh.  the room was TINY and horribly laid out.  i mean, HORRIBLY.  less than 2 feet from the door when you walk in is a queen-sized sleigh bed right in the middle of everything.  cute bed, but very out of place and cumbersome in that small room. (you know a room is small if a queen-sized bed takes up, well, almost the whole room.)  the curving head and footboards were just not a good look b/c they cut into the very little walking space there was.  the armoire - another piece of furniture too big for the room - housed the TV and had empty drawers below.  good thing, too, b/c there was NO CLOSET in the room.  (WTH?!  where are you supposed to hang your clothes/coats?)  behind the bed was a small side chair and they somehow managed to also wedge a desk and chair, too.  very small.  the window next to the desk looked out to a brick wall with some suspicious looking liquid oozing down its side.  gross.  after taking in this tightly packed room i was prepared for a broom closet of a bathroom.  surprisingly, it wasn't that tight.  yes, the bathroom was sort of small, but i actually felt more comfortable in there than in the room.  there were nice glass shelves under the mirrors and i really liked the tile job.  plus, the window in the bathroom had a partial view of the harbor instead of that icky wall.  points for that and the super fluffy towels.  i was all ready to fall in love with the bathroom when i drew back the curtain for the tub/shower - major FAIL.  the tub was one of those large jacuzzi tubs w/ the jets and everything.  nice, right?  no.  NO.you ever, as a kid, build some great lego scene and there's just this one part you want just so, but the lego piece won't fit?  like, the little pegs don't line up, but you jam it in somehow anyway?  that's how this tub was in the bathroom.  it was so awkwardly placed and horribly installed that it looked like something that could be on one of those contractor horror stories you sometimes see on the news w/ the guy who's "on your side" and humiliates the contractor into paying up to the wronged homeowner.  tiles that didn't line up and/or needed to be recaulked (including some mismatched ones that had been replaced), a big, gross lime stain where the faucet leaked continuously, the actual tub basin part that was probably white at some point was completely yellowing and had a few cracks, and so on.  i don't even know if the jets worked b/c no way in hell was i taking a BATH in that thing.  and taking a shower was challenge.  i wish i could explain the angle at which this tub was placed, but all i can really say is that it was so awkwardly placed that getting in and out was an exercise in balance and flexibility.  really, the only redeeming quality was that the shower had the removable head w/ multiple spray/flow settings.  it was like they were going to get a jacuzzi tub into that bathroom no matter what, just so they could advertise having one.  it was really bad, and i felt really misled/pissed off.  the rest of the hotel was still cute, i guess, but my opinion and experience was jaded by our room.  the best thing about staying there was when we stepped outside, b/c it is literally in the middle of fell's point w/ all it's restaurants, shopping, adorable cobblestone streets, diverse people and harbor.  IDK that there are any other properties to stay in, right in fell's point.  however, AFI sucked enough that i wouldn't stay there again just to have a fell's point experience.  i'd stay just a little ways up the road by the inner harbor, or just suck it up and make the drive back to DC at the end of the night.    i realize it's likely hit or miss based on my friend's room and experience, but the miss was so far off that i'm not willing to try for a hit.  admiral fell inn has fallen OFF my list.I traveled to the Admiral Fell Inn for a business meeting with about 80 business colleagues from all across the country. The views I am expressing are my own, but I heard many similar comments from my colleagues, so I know it isn't just me. I made my reservation at the Admiral Fell at least a month in advance. I asked for a large room with a king bed, in a quiet location, on an upper floor. After all, the Admiral Fell's website shows large, elegant, ornate rooms with huge beds. What they put me in was anything but. I asked to be relocated to another room but was told they were fully booked. My tiny, oddly shaped room was barely big enough for one double bed and two night stands (not king, not queen, but double). The windows looked out over the air conditioning system in the light well. The room was inconvenient in every possible way, from a very narrow entry corridor, to no place to put a suitcase, to an absurd "desk" (little more than a shelf hanging on the wall), to an air conditioning system that was impossible to regulate - it either ran way too cold or too warm, to a bathroom where the toilet was crammed into a corner that made it difficult to use. But it gets worse. The "closet" was an odd "armoire" style cabinet, but it appeared to be homemade of plywood. It had a real cheap quality. The drawers didn't open properly and the door had to be tied open with the phone cord in order to watch television. All of these things were inconvenient signs of a lower-end hotel. But what I found intolerable was how dirty the place was. Truthfully, I cringed when I had to walk barefoot on the carpet in my room. It was so dirty, with big grease and oil stains and dark smudges. I asked the housekeeping staff to shampoo the carpet. What did they do? Brought in a squirt bottle of some sort of carpet cleaning liquid and wet down the dirty spots. No scrubbing, no steaming, no vacuuming. It was no better when they finished than when they started. I found garbage from prior tenants under the night stands and strange hairs in the bathroom. Shudder. Then there's the internet. They offered free wifi. For the first couple of days, it worked okay, but then it suddenly went on the fritz, and the hotel staff couldn't seem to get it working again. Inconvenient.We held our group meeting in the large conference rooms on the fifth floor. Those were nice rooms, if you don't mind an occasional rat running around. The hotel provided a "continental breakfast" for our group, which consisted of inedible, rancid pastries and supermarket-quality bagels. The Admiral Fell does get my vote for courteous service. The front desk staff was nice, helpful and really tried to make things work out. But they're facing a tidal wave of deferred maintenance and repairs, and the place needs a thorough cleaning, stem to stern. And oh yes, they should wall off the miserable little room they gave me. It's unfit for habitation.Admiral Fell would be proud of his native city, Baltimore, and all ithas to offer (crab cakes, health care, gonorrhea, etc...). However, hemight not be quite as proud of the service provided in the hotel thatbears his name.I was in Baltimore for a meeting at Hopkins. I got the room throughPriceline, and had high expectations because apparently this is whereHopkins puts their prospective students and faculty candidates up whileinterviewing in Baltimore. My expectations were met, but only sort of.The room: 3.5 starsI was very pleased by the overall room quality. Usually when I get aroom through Priceline, they give you the worst room in the hotel, e.g.the room next to the elevator, a room on the second floor, or thejanitor's closet. However, they provided me a nice room on the 4thfloor away from the elevator with a nice view of Fells Point (which, bythe way, is actually kind of pretty [for Baltimore]).  The bathroom was accessible by a strange long hallway, but once inside, was clean, although definitely well-worn.  There were a few loose floorboards in the bedroom, but I'll chalk that up to the "charm" of an old inn like the Fell.  The service: 2 starsAfter a whirlwind day of meetings and running around Baltimore, I just wanted to check in, call my wife, and go to sleep.  I arrived around 9 and there was one agent working the desk.  I had to wait to check in while she took not one, but two phone calls, each of which lasting several minutes.  Okay, so I had to wait maybe ten minutes.  Not a big deal.  She was perfectly polite.  I signed some papers, gave her my credit card, and she gave me the key to the room.  While I was in the room, I noticed in the fine print that there would be a daily fee of $9.95 assessed in addition to the rate.  I didn't think much of it, given that, supposedly, all the fees are paid for when I booked the room through Priceline.(Their policy: " Depending on the property you stay at you may also be charged (i) certain mandatory hotel specific service fees, for example, resort fees (which typically apply to resort type destinations and, if applicable, may range from $10 to $40 per day), energy surcharges, newspaper delivery fees, in-room safe fees, tourism fees, or housekeeping fees and/or (ii) certain optional incidental fees, for example, parking charges, minibar charges, phone calls, room service and movie rentals, etc..")The next morning, I got a bill for the $9.95 at the door.  I went down to the lobby to check out and inquire, quite politely, might I add, about the fee.  I told them quite honestly and courteously, that if I had signed something saying that I paid the fee, I'd be happy to pay it, but otherwise, I would have liked for them to remove it.  The first clerk I encountered was very nice and he said that they would gladly take the charge off, given the person who checked me in failed to explain the fee.  He asked the other clerk at the desk to check me out and remove the fee.  That's when the niceness ended.  The second clerk became extremely rude to me, told me that the next time I stay here, I'd have to pay the fee.  Her gestures and body language also suggested that she was not happy about deducting the fee.  She bluntly and curtly said, "you're done."  I (politely) proceeded to ask her whether I could get another copy of the bill, but before I could get the words out, she again stated, "You're done!"  Being somewhat taken aback by her rudeness, I then handed over the keys, which she snatched from my hand.  Totally uncalled for.  I was extremely polite and her reaction was just ridiculous.  I'd probably stay here again, despite the little encounter with Miss Sunshine at check-out, but I would suggest that they hire slightly less rude agents to handle customers.  As for this review, as the agent would say, "I'm done."My husband and I were flying to Baltimore to meet family for a cruise that left from the Port. We wanted to stay in the area to see the Inner Harbor as my husband had never been there. I made reservations online after seeing multiple reviews. We were to arrive by 7:00 pm at the airport and were going to supper and cruise around the area for the evening. The Inn helped with transportation to the hotel from the airport . Needless to say our plane broke down and we did not get off the ground until 10:30 at night. We contacted the hotel and they were fantastic, as was our transportation service. When we arrived at the airport our transportation was waiting, took us to the hotel. The staff were extremely courteous and helpfull. Our room was perfect and even though we didn't get to see too much while we were there, we enjoyed it immensely.  The transportation service took us to the port, picked us up after our cruise and brought us back to the airport. The Admiral Fells Inn was a great place and hopefully we get to enjoy the area more the next timeI enjoyed my stay at the Admiral Fell Inn and, while there were a handful of (very) minor things to quibble over, the headline is that we are high maintenance hotel guests (we have a 15 month old daughter) and the staff really met our expectations and helped us out. To begin with, I wanted to arrange for a babysitter in the hotel. The concierge (nitpick #1: the title "experience specialist" must be a difficult burden for this young woman to bear; can we please just call it what it is? Also, the word "magic" is far too heavily used!) went back and forth numerous times. She put in a fair amount of effort trying to arrange for a hotel staff member to take the job. We ended up going with an outside agency, but I really appreciated her help.As another commenter has mentioned, the rooms aren't huge, and there's some cracked tiles and a patch of blackish mildew on the caulking in the shower. The crib was initially set up wrong (when brought to the desk's attention, it was fixed immediately). And there was a minor snafu with the bill. But if those facts are going to make your hair stand on end, then you probably aren't looking to stay in an old hotel in a historic district in the first place. The point here is that it's a cool old place perfectly located on the central square in the Fells Point area. If that's what you're looking for, then you've found it with this one.Next time you visit Charm City, stay here! It's a great hotel at the corner of Thames and South Broadway in Fell's Point. The hotel is comprised of eight adjoining buildings, some dating back to 1760. Each of the 80 rooms is different in size, shape and decor and each is named after a seafaring Baltimorean from the past. Cozy, warm, bright and haunted (or so they say) though we didn't see any ghosts and we were roaming the halls until 4am last night. Prices range depending on the season (obvs) and start anywhere from $159 a night (Saturday, 11/24/07) for a two double bed room to $229 for a king bed room and $289 for  a corner king suite with jacuzzi tub. Well worth the price, we stayed in a king bed room on the second floor that overlooked Thames (that's pronounced Thayms not Temz) Street and it was perfectly peaceful and quiet (and ghostless) at night, in the morning you hear the zen sound of cars driving over the cobblestones. The hotel also offers a Ghost Tour of the hotel, if your into that sort of thing. The room might be chilly when you first check-in but turn that heat on and you'll be toasty warm in no time. I'll be back here to hunt for ghosts for sure.
review_content_60: I came to Baltimore for an interview, and this is the hotel where I was "put up".  It is in an area of Fells Point central to just about everything, right across from the water.  The staff was friendly and helpful.  The rooms are small, but comfy.  The room also had a whirlpool tub, a definite plus in my book.  The breakfast was average fare (oatmeal, scrambled eggs, fruit, etc.).  Nice place to stay overall.

review_content: Stayed for a night in 2014, and the room we had was spectacular.Hotel amenities Include: 06:00 - 10:00 am Complimentary Breakfast 24-hour Fitness Center Complimentary Wi-Fi (password given upon check-in)Parking by Towne Park ($32 for overnight parking) Pool (closes at 09:00 pm)The hotel was great. Very friendly staff (house keepers, desk, valet) and were all very helpful. They had complimentary coffee/tea all day and night long as well as a very nice continental breakfast each morning. Within walking distance to the waterfront (two blocks or so) and many other attractions and bars to go to. The upgraded room was worth the additional $15/20 or so as the standard room was a bit of a squeeze but they were nice and clean. The beds were super comfortable as well.The only downside we experienced was the lack of free parking. It was $32 to valet park overnight because there just isn't enough legal available parking around. So if you are lucky enough to get one of the few spots that's legal after 5pm fantastic... If not, prepare to pay another premium.I would definitely stay here again and probably will this winter.I had another guest enter my room, rob me.   Hotel reports I'm at fault for opening the door.  Unexplained why hotel security never contacted police after being told my belongs were gone through. I have filled a police report with Baltimore police; report # 1-15099139I have yet to even receive an apology from the hotel.Mediocre at best. Didn't sleep well due to other guests talking throughout the night as well as opening and closing doors practically all night. Elevator had a mind of its own. When we asked for late check out we were given a whole half hour. Pipes in the room rattled though out the night as well.Clean but my two main issues are 1 - no free parking.  $32 for valet parking 2- poor HVAC maintenance.  The lobby's AC was out all weekend - eating breakfast in 87 degree heat stinks, and it got worse as the day went on.  Our room never got below 77 degrees, as the AC could not keep up on a hot ( but not u usually hot) day if 92 degrees.  We slept poorly - do not recommend coming In the summerPros: Good location, great breakfast and coffee, comfortable beds, suites with sink, microwave, fridge and room for six people, secure - key card for everything including elevatorCons: This hotel handed me a bill for $787 but up-charged an extra $120 on my bank card for the "potential" of incidentals such as valet and movies which we did not use. I expect my bill upon check out to reflect what is charged to my card. My only explanation for these "anticipated" extra charges is that we were there for Maryland Deathfest and they expected the room to be trashed, which it was not. I am also a member of their Hilton Honors program, which makes me even more confused as to why I would be treated this way. Guess I will just find another hotel chain to give my money to. Not staying with them again if they will not explain upfront that there is a "deposit" on a room. This has never happened to me at a hotel before.It's a beautiful little hotel, very close to all the local attractions, really at a walking distance from everything.  Being its location the amenities in the surroundings are great.  Valet parking.  Rooms are spacious and service is great and staff is friendly.  Kids enjoyed it, loved my stay.A very welcome staff, valet parking only ($32 but you do get in/out privileges).   The room we got was huge with frig and micro.  It has the usual HI breakfast.  The hotel is a block plus from the Inner Harbor.  Lots of places to eat, harbor cruises galore. Great people watching as well. Huge lobby with lots of places to just sit and read.Great little hotel. This hotel was squeezed into an old historical  building and I thought this gave the hotel a lot of charm.A little on the pricey side, we had reward points to use luckily.The room was comfy and clean.Easy walk to the inner harbor as we walked everywhere during out visit.Highly suggest this hotel if you need one in the area! Free hot breakfast in the morning and it was all yummy foods! Unlike some other hotels that just have cereal and muffins.This hotel was a block from the inner harbor and easy to get to from the interstate. Valet  service also superb we arrived at 11 pm they got us in expeditiously .  The hotel staff was friendly and attentive during our stay. Also the breakfast was a pleasant surprise.  We will be back again.Great hotel! Clean, nice pool, awesome complimentary breakfast. Christian at the front desk was very very helpful. Only complaint was that we had to wait 45 minutes for our car from valet.Internet down right now and a little far from Camden yardsHotel staff was very friendly and room was clean.  If you are looking for a hotel a few blocks away from the inner harbor but close enough to walk then it is a good place to stay.Free breakfast was a nice touch and tastyI wasn't impressed with the check in but the room was WOW! Very spacious and clean. We had 2 queen suite so it had a bathroom area along with a sink, a kitchen area with microwave, refridge , counter space and sink. Our couch also turned into a bed and we also had a work station. We had a family of 4 and still had plenty of room. The things they should work on is having more kids channels. It says they have Nickelodeon but it's a direct TV movie channel. PBS was too baby & Cartoon Network is too old for my kids. We requested a non smoking room and it is but all of the rooms around us are smoking so my hall smelled like cigarette smoke really bad!!!Great location, hotel was converted from an old historical building and had a lot of personality. Lobby is beautiful, staff was pleasant, breakfast was good (especially since it was FREE.) The gym was small and the shower didn't have the best water pressure, but the rooms were large, well taken care of and have great views. Walking distance to shopping, harbor, convention center, aquarium and really REALLY good restaurants. Will be staying here again!This hotel and service was absolutely perfect. Everyone was very friendly and very helpful. The hotel desk receptionist Dondrea, WAS ABSOLUTELY amazing for me and my family. Very friendly and very helpful. The valet service, I absolutely recommend, it is 32.oo a night but it is worth it. You can get your car as many times as you like.  The continental breakfast in the morning was delicious. The inner harbor is beautiful and I would highly recommend staying at this hotel.Stayed here for 2 nights.  We had asked for adjoining rooms, they just kept telling us "it's not guaranteed".  And indeed, when we arrived we didn't get adjoining rooms, but to try and satisfy our request, we had two rooms in a private end-of-hall area that basically served a similar purpose.
