So that was good.Positives include quiet, dark rooms; good toiletries provided; the breakfast was satisfying with a lot of choice (although I didn't understand why the plates/cups/bowls were all Styrofoam and then they provided a microwave -- you can't microwave Styrofoam, so it was basically useless); check-out time is noon; Wifi was included in the price and was always easy to connect to and a strong connection at that.My room key never worked; I had to change it 6 times.  And although the front desk guy suggested it was my fault (keeping it close to something magnetic), one time he gave me the key, I went upstairs and it didn't work, so it was obviously the door.  I did appreciate he suggested I use the reception phone by the elevators so I didn't have to keep going up and down every time it happened.  Good customer service.Good area, valet parking expensive though.  I'd recommend it.This is my second Hampton Inn stay recently and the room seemed cleaner than the last location. My room was huge and it had a King bed. As for the location, my window looks out to a "coming soon" hotel which is a little eerie but it had the opaque layer for privacy. The other window where the sink and entrance to bathroom is facing the Marriott across the street. Eerie again. Did I mention it only had a see through curtain?The microwave and fridge was a nice addition. The mesh chair for the desk is another favorite. The clean personal couch was nice also. The fluffy 4 pillows on the bed? Another plus! Outlets and wifi, Yes!Service was quick as far as check in and front desk calls. When there was an issue the maintenance staff came immediately. There was the snack shop and business center (with a mean monster fax/copier/printer) available. You are about 3 blocks from the Inner Harbor so you can always catch dinner there before retiring for the night.I can't say enough about this hotel.  We were staying there on a business trip and everything from check-in to check-out was perfect!  Staff was great, rooms were very nice and the breakfast that was offered was far above the norm for a continental breakfast!They have my business on my next scheduled visit to the area!!!!Decent hotel. I travel a lot, so the bar is already pretty high. Stayed there one night for a football game. Walls are pretty thin, kept hearing other people talking and doors slamming all night. Breakfast was great, if only for the waffles. :). Would stay again for one night, not more than that.With a budget, this place is as good as it gets! Clean rooms, hot breakfast in the morning, free wifi, minutes to the inner harbor and not unreasonable to Camden Yards (15-20 minute walk). Yes! Stay here!
review_content_20: I stayed here while in town for the Rebel Race. It's valet parking only and they're pretty efficient getting your car in and out. Just moments away from the inner harbor is a plus. One you leave your car with the valets, there is really no reason to pull it out again, unless you've got to leave the city limits. There are tons of cabs and busses to get you to where you need to go. The surrounding area can feel a little shady but you'll get past that. There are quite a bit of places to eat right around the corner if you don't feel like heading to the harbor. The customer service was very good. The front desk people were cheerful and extremely helpful. If you're hungry for a snack and don't feel like leaving the hotel, theres a food/snack pantry at the front desk. You'll find some microwavable meals like burritos and hot pockets, assorted drinks, ice cream, chips, candy and some fruit.Our room was comfortable. It had a gigantic mirror, refrigerator, microwave oven, desk, flat screen TV, and an extra chair. The bathroom had the usual toiletries. Oh, and don't let me forget about the free breakfast. Make sure you get up early. They have assorted dry cereals, oatmeal, scrambled eggs, bacon or sausage, bagels, muffins and assorted fruits and juices. Very convenient and very free. This hotel also seems to have a little bit more tables and seats than most.So great price, friendly service, and good location from the inner harbor. I would definitely stay here again.Everything was perfect. Good for families and couples.Stayed twice at the Hampton Inn and Suites Inner Harbor.  Location is great.  We were attending events at the Convention Center which is less than a 5 minute walk from the hotel.  It is less than 10 minutes to walk to Inner Harbor or Camden Yards from this hotel.  In addition there is a small divey bar around the corner (Peter's) for any late night drink.Our last visit in August 2012, the hotel let me check in at 9:30 in the morning!  Valet was exceptional (at 32.00 per day) with in/out privileges.  Room was VERY clean.  Rooms are different sizes as the room we had in 2010 was larger (same type-studio suite).  Our room had a fridge and microwave.  Everyone was VERY nice and accommodating!Breakfast-its free.  One day was eggs and sausage.  Second day was sausage and french toast sticks.   There is a Dunkin Donuts a short walk if you aren't feeling the free breakfast.  We didn't visit the pool so no comment there, and the wi-fi is ok (also free).Overall, I would stay here (as I am a repeat customer).  Location is great and staff was very friendly!Great hotel for its class.  I have stayed here three times while attending an annual conference at the Convention Center.  It's within walking distance of the Convention Center and the Inner Harbor. The room is very clean and comfortable, with all the conveniences.  The hot breakfast is varied every day, although I only stayed two days each time so I don't know how soon they repeat the offerings, which include combinations of things like: different types of sausages, omelet, French toast, scrambled eggs, home fries, etc., with make-it-yourself waffles always available. Free Ethernet and WiFi are available in the room.  The last time I stayed, they have added one more convenience: USB chargers and outlet breakouts in the room.  I didn't even have to use the one I packed with me.I got everything I expected from the hotel for the week I was there. The staff was very friendly and accommodating and as for the breakfast, it was exactly what I've had at other Hamptons in the past. To those that complain about it, I would simply say: IT'S FREE! They don't have to offer it, plenty of mid grade hotels I've been at offer breakfast but charge an arm and a leg, but make the cost confusing.  My boyfriend enjoyed everything they had, ate plenty every morning, and if I couldn't decide on something I made a fresh waffle, a favorite feature at any Hampton.The reason that I am not giving this hotel five stars is for the one hiccup we experienced. I booked a nonsmoking room with a preference for a king bed and got a nonsmoking with a queen. Normally not a big deal, but my room was on a smoking floor. At night the smell wasn't an issue, but if I happened to go up to my room after housekeeping started opening the other doors in the corridors, the smell was a bit overwhelming for nonsmokers like us.We stayed on the second floor, so if you book nonsmoking and they place you on the second, ask if they can move you if you think the smell will bother you.The Hampton Inn and Suites on Redwood in the Inner Harbor is a great place to stay while in Baltimore.  The hotel itself occupies a mid-nineteenth Century multi-story building which is very appealing. The valet service greets you right away and voila, your vehicle Is tucked away in a secure garage.  Downside: valet services will cost you $32.00 per day. The check-in staff is very friendly and helpful.  The lobby makes a good first impression.  The rooms are surprisingly large.  The 12 foot ceilings help in this regard.  The room  we had was very well appointed.  The Queen beds were quite comfortable.  The countertops were all marble, spacious and functional.  A neat tidbit: there are soap, shampoo and conditioner dispensers on the shower wall..yes, I was impressed! There was a surprisingly nice complimentary.  breakfast buffet, complete with lots of fresh fruit, cereals, muffins, with make your own toast, waffles and pancakes.  Nice. All things considered, a great place to stay in Baltimore's Inner Harbor.We stayed at this hotel for 2 night while visiting the inner harbor.  The room was very nice and clean, the bed was incredibly comfortable and the staff was very helpful and friendly especially the valet parking attendants.  It was a very short walk to the the harbor and mall and the breakfast is free and awesome! We are going back again in September. Did I forget to mention that the have great coffee and tea 24/7. Can't wait to go back.Wonderful hotel.  Rooms were big, comfortable, and no smoke smell. Easy walk to the inner harbor and all the sights.OK rooms, terrible breakfast, but as we have found lately on our Hilton Hotel stays, GREAT PEOPLE and service!  I would stay here over the Marriott I last stayed at anyday - I can always walk somewhere for breakfast or grab one of their handy bags.  Service is great, which is one of the things I rate hotels on - cleanliness and service are first in my book (no bed bugs please!).  Everything else is just frosting on the cake.I was in town for a little eye surgery at Johns Hopkins. I was in the hospital at 0630am and out the door at 1030am. So my dilemma was getting an early check in. After parking right out front the Valet told my wife to go in and see if they can check us in.  Sure enough the nicest woman said sure no problem and checked us in! The room was nice, king bed with a couch ( I assume pullout). Average bathroom, very clean with microwave and small refrigerator.  Oh if the manager reads these and I believe you do the compressor in the frig in room 330 is dying! It groaned all night. It didn't bother me, I was zonked on pain pills but someone else may complain.  Breakfast was great, plentiful with lots of choices.  The hotel is a couple blocks from the harbor so it would be a short walk if we were vacationing.  On a whole, great experience, great hotel, nice people.  I would stay here again.I traveled to Baltimore for a conference and was slow in booking my room.  I found the best deal at Hampton Inn on Redwood.  The cost was $134/night without taxes for two nights if I paid in advance.  The room total was $330.As I arrived at the hotel I was pleasantly surprised by the public amenities, the staff's graciousness, and the fantastic condition of the bedroom.My king room was enormous.  Hampton Inn did a retrofit of an older building and the appointments could not be nicer for this level of hotel.  All of my questions and requests were answered quickly and courteously.  The gym, while smaller, was used only by me--loved it.  I didn't bring a swimsuit and regretted it.  The pool was never in use while I was around.The breakfast was what I expected.  The dining area had a very high ceiling so sound drifted away and made the dining experience very nice.  I really liked the all-day coffee and teas service.A very nice stay at Hampton Inn.  I am staying here whenever business or pleasure take me back to Baltimore.Loved staying in room 722. I believe you have to speak with the hotel staff on-site to reserve it. I second another reviewers take on the beds - super comfy. Walked to the the Rusty Scupper and the ballgame at Camden Yards and liked it very much. $32.00 for parking.I will say the location of this hotel was spot on for getting to the inner harbor and taking a quick cab to Fells Point.  The concierge/doorman guys were awesome.  They were very helpful and quick to help us with our car and baggage.   The hotel room was nice and clean, although a bit small, and had free WiFi.  The unfortunate downside to our hotel stay was the room.  I believe that since we received a "deal" through their website promotion, we were stuck in a back corner room, facing a run down building, and the walls made crazy loud noises starting shortly after arriving.  We didn't complain as it was just for the night, but it was disappointing since I had searched dilligently on Yelp and found this place to have pretty good reviews.I stayed at the end of last week. The Hampton seems to be a historical property with solid service and the mini gym that's a solid effort. However for a business traveler, the lame internet speed was a bit annoying (worse than dial-up). It was free, but there was no reliable premium option. Definitely a good low priced alternative if you need to roll down to Baltimore for a ball gameWe enjoyed this hotel during our recent family vacation to DC and Baltimore.  It's hard to find affordable accommodations for a family with 4 children, and the Hampton Inn was one of few close to the Harbor that allowed us to stay in one room/suite.  Just a few blocks off the Inner Harbor, our room had 2 beds and a pull-out couch.  The beds were comfy, and our suite had a wet bar and refrigerator.  This hotel has a decent breakfast selection in the morning: eggs, sausage, assorted breads and cereals, and a waffle station allowed our kids to fuel up with a variety of options before we went out sightseeing.  The staff was incredibly friendly and accommodating at this hotel.  We enjoyed our stay here.The facilities and staff are pleasant and helpful but I can't say the same for the streets of Baltimore just a few feet from the sliding door.  I would also not say that the location of the hotel is in a family friendly part of town although one would think so considering its proximity to the harbor.  Just be prepared to be harangued by panhandlers at every corner and witness people screaming profanities at each other in the streets while cops do nothing.  Some situations reminded me of scenes from John Carpenters, "Escape From New York."We stayed at this hotel for 1 night while visiting the inner harbor.  The room was very nice and clean, the bed was incredibly comfortable and the staff was very helpful especially the valet parking attendants.  It was a very short walk to the aquarium and mall and the breakfast was awesome! We would definately stay here again if we are ever visit the inner harbor again.3 blocks away from Inner Harbor. Our room was very spacious, especially the bathroom. The only downside was our view, as our window was facing an empty, rundown building.  Seems like a pretty safe area, as long as you don't go to Baltimore Street (a block away) at night. There was a homeless guy pulling out Hustler magazines underneath his one-legged baggy jeans, and shady people yelling obscenities at one another.I had a pleasant experience in the one night I stayed here. The staff were very nice and because of my status and HHonors, I got upgraded to what was "the nicest room" in the entire hotel - room 722 - ask for it. According to the reviews that I read under mine, the building used to be offices and the decor in the rooms definitely reflected it - wood floors and wood panel walls - all beautifully done. There was a big whirpool tub in the bathroom as well as a big screen tv and several options for seating apart from the computer chair.The location is pretty good - it was a 5 dollar taxi ride to anywhere basically - parking is 29 a night so that is a bit of a chapper and for being a Hampton Inn - its kind of expensive - I paid 189 a night. The valets were nice and Hampton Inn breakfast didn't let me down.Great location in the Inner Harbour area.  This hotel is an old bank and Hilton has actually kept much of the architechtural integrity of the building.  The seventh floor was the executive floor of the bank.  The executive lobby is intact with it's stone pillars and terrazo floors.  The door jambs are actually the originals with the transem windows above the doors.  These rooms were originally executive offices.  Pretty cool.The staff was super nice and helpful.  The room was expensive at $259, but it was very last minute for a huge convention that was in town.I'll stay here again.
review_content_40: The hotel was very nice! Perfect if you're looking for something more upscale than a Best Western but cannot afford to stay at the Hilton. We stayed on the historic 7th floor. The rooms were not the typical square shaped room you find with most Hampton Inns. Service was great, the front desk people helped us out with directions and what there was to do.The valet parking was $30.00 a day but totally worth if you would rather your car be in a safe place rather than on the side of the road.The one thing we looked forward to from the hotel was the hot breakfast we were promised each morning. We went down at 9:30am to find NOTHING left. This was the only down fall of the hotel, they did not take in consideration that some people like to sleep in on vacation, and did not provide enough food for all their guests. Literally there were 4 bagels, but no cream cheese, an english muffin and my boyfriend was LUCKY to scrape up the last bit of has browns. They did provide coffee around the clock. But we were still hungry =[That was the only downfall of the hotel, all in all it was a relaxing stay. Even though we were let down with the breakfast deal, we would stay there again. Just remember to wake up early to get the grub!!!!!The hampton inn isn't normally my choice of accommodations, but due to other circumstances I found myself here for about 4 days.  When I arrived, the building was charming, and the desk clerk was overly friendly. Boasting he was from California too we talked about some common cali locals, and then he put me up in my room. He mentioned that at 5-8pm they have a happy hour. There are beers and wine for free in the lobby. It being right in that time, I walked over to find cans of keystone and bud in a big tin. classy. haha. The room was about $200, way to overpriced, but relative to the area. It was big and spacious, had a couch and the bed was super comfy. The internet was decent, and the room had a fridge and a microwave---always a plus. However, when I opened the window, there was left over towels and trash on the window sill. yes. I rate this place three stars.. for the service of the staff, and  the location. It was only a few blocks from the inner harbor and the room was big.

hotel_name: Baltimore Marriott Inner Harbor at Camden Yards
review_content: My boyfriend and I attended the Baltimore v Pittsburgh game and chose this hotel due to it being in walking distance of the stadium. Pros: friendly staff, nice spacious rooms, the beds are the softest I've ever slept in for a hotel, and the room was clean. Cons: parking is horrid (we used the hotel's) and hotel parking is pricy too ($28 for a day (I figured for the price we were paying parking would be free)) my only problem with the staff is when my boyfriend and I ordered food she called up to our room and was very rude about it. "Did you order food?" "Yes ma'am" "well it's here and they are NOT allowed to come up" then when I got down there she gave me a rude look and eye roll. (Besides that all my other staff encounters were great)Not what I've come to expect from a Marriott. This hotel is cheaply furnished complete with all polyester bedding and the rooms smell like they've been soaked in cheap artificial headache inducing air freshener to cover up the smell of mold.The staff seemed like they hate their jobs, and yelled at me and each other more like at a McDonald's than a hotel. The bar food was simply gross. Overall more akin to a red roof inn than a Marriott.Stayed here Saturday night ..What a disaster ..The bathroom shower almost flooded & never did drain ..Room was very basic ..I won't be backI love the Marriott and wouldn't want to stay anywhere else in downtown Baltimore.I stay here during the week when I travel for work and it's a close walk to my office. My project has negotiated a lower rate and I get the perks of free Wi-Fi and access to the concierge lounge. There's great breakfast options (eggs, pastries, oatmeal, cereal, fruits, snacks). They also serve a dinnertime "snack" and dessert service, but it's a great dinner option (steak, salmon, dumplings, salads, cheesecake). The attendants at the concierge lounge are amazing! Shoutout to Rochelle who is so sweet and absolutely accommodating. She knows that members on my team often stay late and gave us her extension number for us to call ahead to ask for a saved plate of food. It can't get better than that!The gym is sub-par, but as long as they have a treadmill and a TV, I get what I need out of it. The rooms are so comfortable, spacious and include fridges. Service is great and I always come back to a room that is spick and span. Sometimes, when I leave in a hurry and my clothes are thrown on the floor, the cleaning attendants will even fold and lay out my clothes :OThe Marriott Inner Harbor hotel in Baltimore is the best in town!Very nice hotel in a not very nice area.  Really wouldn't walk around after dark outside.Convenient to Camden Yards and UMMC, but not much else.Very nice room, great beds and amenities, the executive lounge is fantastic, open all day but not Saturdays for some reason.Room service is friendly and the crab soup is great!Overall a great place to stay if you need to be in that area.This hotel is not good. And not just for the price. But extra concerning with the price because it's not cheap. It's seriously outdated. The customer service is bad for the most part - I could give a few examples but I'll leave it at that. I would never plan a conference here or stay here. The conference food was not good, the hotel staff could be heard in the back during sessions, the audio was horrible... My friend had to switch rooms be caused it reaked of smoke. New room had a broken toilet and a Murphy bed. Not a good one. My beds had hair in them. The toiletries were used. My other colleague's room had a giant wet spot on the carpet. Everything just seemed old and dirty. There was no at the concierge when needed. There was cockroaches in the gym. I did report it to the manager and I could tell he heard me and was concerned. I hope the Marriott chain puts some love into this location. Haven't had a bad experience to this degree in a while.From the initial greeting I was not impressed.  The outside decor looks beaten, dated, and weathered.  There is a very odd display of the Orioles gear placed inside of the revolving door, which I  originally mistook for janitorial equipment. The staff seemed very disconnected and gave us half-ass greetings. We go to check in and of course what should have been a room fully paid for by my company was again charged to my credit card, which was over $1000.00!  I told the lady behind the counter that my hotel was previously paid for on our company card and she basically looked at me like I was speaking a foreign language.  She did not make an attempt to rectify the situation or even apologize for the mix up or provide a  solution.  She kept repeating, "the room is not paid for". I go ahead and have her charge my card and will deal with the balance with my employer because it was obvious i was getting no where fast with this chic.I go to the restaurant and order dinner which was pretty decent.  Once done im standing at the bell desk to get my bags and theres no one anywhere to be found.  The one person helping at the front desk kept looking in our direction, but did nothing to assist. After several minutes a security guard (who wasnt manning his station ) comes out of nowhere asking if we want our bags. DUH! I politely tucked my tip back in my purse and went to my room, only to find more dated, worn down carpet, furniture,  just about everything. Im a stickler about cleanliness, especially carpet.  I dont want to stay in a hotel where I feel like I cant take my shoes off. NO BUENO. This place needs immediate renovations,  especially to carry the Marriott brand.Naturally I'm always inclined to seek out the Marriott brand because of many amazing past experiences. I was not familiar with this particular location, but decided of the two local Marriott hotels, this would be the better choice, based on my expected plans. Parking: $28 per day....no biggie, but if I'm paying that amount each day I'd think they'd invest in a valet system. For $28 I want to drive up, hand over my valet key and simply walk in. Check-In: Seamless. We were checked-in and given generic hotel information in under 5 minutes. Also taken into consideration was the fact that we were also the only customers in line. They also deserve kudos for allowing us a really early 12pm vs. 4pm standard check-in. Room Location: Totally sucked. On the 6th floor, alllll the way at the end of the hall. I get it, alot of the better rooms were being cleaned so this was definitely the bottom of the barrel at such an early timeframe. Room Amenities: The room was pretty accommodating, albeit much smaller than previous Marriott locations I've frequented. The television was a 40" flat screen, a hidden refrigerator was located in the the dresser and they provided a microwave upon request. But the bed deserved the standing ovation.....it was freaking AMAZING. I have traveled this great world a few times over and luxuriated in many a fine beds, but this one has been placed in my top 5. I was floating on a cloud of fluffiness, wrapped in marshmallows on an air of Goose-down feathers. Devine....but au contraire my fellow Yelpers.....let us continue. Water Temperature: I usually conduct a function and cleanliness inspection upon arriving. All was well until I checked the water pressure and temperature of the hot water. The pressure was decent but the water temperature was lukewarm at best. I immediately phoned this in to the front desk. She said she'd send a technician up promptly. I had other matters to attend to so I wasn't present when the said technician arrived. Hours later I arrive back in my room, tired, weary and ready for "that" shower. Uggggg the water temperature was actually worst! I quickly took the fastest shower of my life and called the front desk again. She wanted to send another technician to my room but it was very late and I was drained....and upset. I was told that a manager would be emailed and would notify me the next morning. That sufficed for the time being. The next day after speaking with management, the hotel comped the daily parking charge for our inconvenience. Overall, decent hotel, convenient location and modern amenities. I'd recommend.The 3 stars is for the over use of security.  It was Baltimore after the riots, but come. on.  All the outer doors were locked and required your key to enter, unless you wanted to go around to the rotating doors around the drop off, where I was almost tagged by a cab.  The hotel itself is nice enough; it's a Marriott.  Nothing spectacular, but certainly nice.  Check in was a little slow and they had messed up our reservation (we were part of a group seminar); later they had charged incorrectly and also charged the group!  I likely wouldn't stay in this area again.  It's a little far from the places I wanted to walk to, but great if you are going to an Orioles game.My King Junior Suite was awesome.  This place is very nice.  The bar / restaurant is lively and has good drinks and food - something most hotels can't say.The staff is friendly and welcoming.  The temperature control was somewhat frustrating as it decided whether it was heat or A/c not yourself. Also a fridge would have been nice.  The parking is expensive, the rooms are expensive, and the internet is expensive.  But it's a Marriott.The hotel was nice but $28 a day for parking is a little absurd.  Parking in the hotel parking garage is the same as parking anywhere else in the city. The beds were nice and there was a mini fridge... Or I think the better term is mini freezer we had put lemons and limes in the fridge and they ended up being completely frozen when we came back from the baseball game.  The staff was super friendly and my only real complaint is the parking price I feel as if I am paying all the money to stay in the hotel I should get a discounted price on the parking.Sorry, Marriott that I didn't review this more timely and closer to the time I stayed. I really love this place. Great location, staff and amenities. Unfortunately I visited during wartime (Baltimore riots).  The staff was very friendly and willing to always help, but at the same time keep their guests protected and safe (it's wartime, remember?). They have this cool concept of serve your own craft brews in the lobby. Great concierge staff with excellent snacks, drinks and full breakfast for those who can access. The gym was very good with all the usual Marriott/ LifeFitness equipment. Very open lobby. Hotel has a protected parking garage. Very close to Camden Yards or the Convention Center.Stayed at the Baltimore Marriott Inner Harbor at Camden Yards over this past weekend (1 night); our check in was quick,  easy, and we were off to room 705. Nice room, view was of the top of the roof and some of downtown, but we weren't in the Caribbean so the view wasn't a major factor to me. The room was kept, the beds ridiculously comfortable and the shower was good! Later on that night our tv wasn't working so we called the front desk and within moments 2 technicians were there to fix it - unfortunately they could not get the tv to work, and offered us another room. We didn't feel like moving so  we simply hooked up our laptop and PS4 and watched tv that way. it really was no big deal for us,  we were about to head back out for a late dinner anyways. Upon our return (around midnight) we had a card slipped under the door  for complementary breakfast for us all to apologize for the inconvenience which I thought was a great touch. In the morning we were in need of  a microwave for leftovers, and literally within 5 minutes one was at our door - another plus! The $28 parking fee is a bummer, but its actually one of the cheaper rates I've paid when having to pay for parking so it was what it was-although those other times it was valet, so yeah $28 is a bit steep for self-parking. Oh and also, they had cucumber and fruit infused water in the lobby - yes its the little things that excite me. My only real concern is that after leaving my card was  charged an additional $17, but quickly refunded, and now my card has a $60.00 hold on it - which should be $50. Since the amounts are not crazy I will give it a few days to see what the final charge is before I panic.First off--the beds in this hotel are awesome!  Really comfortable and welcoming.  That's the best thing about the hotel as far as I'm concerned!Second best...location, if you are going to a Os game or if you want to walk over to Federal Hill.The service is somewhat impersonal, and the check in / out process feels longer than it should as the people behind the counters seem to constantly be called away or distracted by conversations.  One just odd thing; in the room, there is an envelop for gratuities for the people who clean the room.  Now, I know sometimes people leave money as tips for the cleaning staff, but it seems odd to me that the hotel would print and leave an envelop for that purpose.  Isn't that kind of an admission that they don't think they are paying their staff enough?  Even at a hotel that is charging $400+ per night, are they really saying that they are not giving enough of that rate to the cleaning people so they are asking the customers to dig out another $10 so that their staff is making a decent wage?Is it just me or do you agree this is a weird thing to ask?Why is parking $28 a day here? That's just overpriced. Rather half-hearted greetings from the staff, but a clean and spacious hotel room. The decor seemed dated and in need of remodeling. Little details take a star off or two: the deteriorating tile grout in the bathroom, the literal 7 minute walk from the elevator to my room (this hotel needs more elevator shafts). The bar in the lobby had some interesting beer choices ("Sweet Baby Jesus" did NOT disappoint) and good food. If it hadn't been for a conference that was held in this hotel I would have checked out. This hotel is overpriced for what it offers in a very seemingly depressed area.If you are visiting Baltimore or just want a fabulous hotel to  stay in for an Orioles or Ravens game do not hesitate to book here.  I can't begin to express the amazing customer service this hotel gives to guests.  Every time I walk into the hotel I am greeted by the staff who genuinely are happy to help.  Also, the hotel has a cool beer wall with areas to to drink on the lobby floor and get out of your room, if needed.Never again. If I could give no star I would.One word: mice.I was staying at the Marriott for a month with a large group on business. Rooms are on the smaller side for such a long stay but typical of a standard hotel room. About 2 weeks into our stay people began complaining of seeing mice in their rooms and in the restaurant area. My third week in I saw a mouse .... YES A MOUSE .... run across my floor in my room and under 1 of the beds. After a few minutes of me completely freaking out it ran from under the bed and out of the room under the room door. NEVER in all of the hotels I have stayed in across the country have I ever had to deal with this. Sidebar: I keep my hotel rooms very tidy .... I'm the person who straightens up before room service comes. So the mouse was not attracted to anything left thrown around my room!When I contacted to front desk all they offered was to move me to another room ..lol ummm thanks but that's not really any help.1. I have a months worth of stuff with me to move so it's not really convenient 2. If there are mice in the restaurant and the 3rd floor they are more than likely running around the whole establishment! I told the woman at the front desk I was not the first person to have a complaint about mice and suggested they do something to set traps or poison around but they said they can't do that in occupied rooms. The woman at the front desk said she would "let maintenance know."As far as the staff outside of this incident everyone has been very friendly. Wifi is slow, tv channel options are slim to none, no free continental breakfast. The location is not so great ... Go a few blocks opposite of the harbor and you end up in a not so nice area. Can't comment on price as my stay was covered by my employer.We decided to spend the New Year downtown at the Baltimore Harbor. Although we only live about 25 minutes from Baltimore city we didn't want the hassle of driving home and staying at the harbor gave us a night out, so why not!  Arriving at the Camden Yards Marriott was pretty easy. We payed $27 for guest parking for the night. Arriving in the lobby we were greeted by a super festive atmosphere!  They provided complimentary glasses of champagne, Sangria and another beverage. The hotel staff was very friendly and warm. We were checked in very quickly and the attendant that helped us was great, we even got complimentary New Years party favors!  Quick stop at the bar provided great service and a free shot! The place was also decorated to the hilt for the Holidays. Our room had a great view of the city and was very clean with soft bedding. We ordered room service. Room service is always expensive so I won't knock them on the prices because that's always expected. We ordered eggs Benedict and a breakfast sandwich and both were good.  I think my only complaints would be that the walls are extremely thin and the room temperature is a bit hard to regulate. We heard EVERYTHING that was going on in the room next to us all hours of the night... no further details on that.  So needless to say my sleep was less than enjoyable.  All and all I would more than likely stay there again, but hope for quiet neighbors.Concierge was fantastic. Shower is awesome. Love the water pressure. The bed is ohh so fluffy. I wish there'd be more pillows! Smoking area is very comfortable and i love it coz i feel safe there. Well lit and the hotel has provided really nice furnitures there. Thumbs up for that. However, i am just not happy with the wifi. It's 2015. Wifi should be free! We paid for the high speed internet (12.95$ per day) is not worth it. Too slow. And oh, the hotel rooms are not really good with sound proofing. Walking down the quiet hall and hearing laughter from one of the rooms was spooky!What you expect from a Marriott and close to everything.A very nice hotel. Clean on the outside. Staff super friendly and courteous. Room was spacious and clean.  Sufficiently sized desk, TV, bathroom. AC worked excellently. Bathroom amenities plentiful, towels soft and huge, there's a bath robe in the closet. Water pressure more than adequate, temperature easily controlled. Fitness room includes elliptical machines, treadmills, stationary bikes for cardio and dumb-bells and a cable machine for weight training. Pool looked clean but I did not use it. There is a bar within and our bartender, Mike, treated us very well. There is a city-owned parking garage attached. It should be noted, there's a fire station across the street so you'll hear sirens during your stay. That being said, I did not hear a single siren at night, not saying the FD didn't respond, but they probably used the siren less than they would during the day. You won't be sorry staying here
review_content_20: nice place, clean and staff was very nice, great bloody Mary'sWe reserved a room in November of last year as part of a group. Over half a year later, and 8 days before an event, they cancelled our reservation, saying they had overbooked, and moved us several blocks away to a different hotel. Don't reserve a room here unless you don't wish to actually stay at this hotel.Hotel location is great for the convention center, games, and inner harbor area. The rooms are good and the beds are super comfortable although I wish there was an intermediate blanket. It was only sheet and comforter so I was either freezing or roasting depending on the room ac being on or off. Room was very clean and the maid service was very good.No free wi-fi except in the lobby. It's 2014 right? It was also pricey. I wouldn't be opposed to saying at this Marriott again but I also wouldn't seek it out either.I came up to this hotel during the weekend of BronyCon 2014 and was, at first, disappointed to not be staying at the hotel directly connected to the convention center, but of course, my mind was changed. Not only were the rooms clean and fresh, but the service was fantastic. The hotel staff went out of their way to make BronyCon attendees feel welcome. Not only did they open their Chesapeake room for bronies to sit in and relax, but they also donned pony merchandise, gave discounts to those with con badges, and looped pony episodes all day on an internal channel, at no cost. I will definitely be making an effort to get back at this hotel come next year! For those who can't stand the cold, you'll have to fiddle with your room thermostat. It seemed constantly cold in my room.This is my go-to hotel when going to my annual summer Orioles weekend. Love the location, love the Marriott beds, and the breakfast is spot-on. Parking garage can be a tad confusing, but aren't they all?Completely DISGUSTED with my entire experience at this property. From the rude reservationist at the front desk to the lack of professionalism when dealing with hotel staff. The deal breaker was when finally getting ready to retire for the night, we find our room (room 234) had a MOUSE running around in the room with us.  I repeat - a MOUSE!! Never in all my years of traveling have I had mice in a hotel room. I will never, ever stay at this hotel again and I will be sharing my experience over Yelp, Twitter and with all my friends and colleagues. Get your act together, Marriott. Unacceptable.I was happy enough with this Marriott!  Like several other Yelpers who wrote reviews, I had access to the Concierge Lounge on the tenth floor.  This lounge serves a pretty decent buffet breakfast, as well as evening "snacks" and dessert.  The room has a big screen TV that's usually blaring traffic, weather and crime reports.  Otherwise, the only other negative worth mentioning is the automatic "espresso machine," which looks like a chemistry set when it's opened for restocking.  (I might be the Van Houtte "Single-Cup".)  My advice is to avoid it in favor of the normal drip coffee, which is A-OK.Speaking of coffee: The in-room coffee maker is an old-style drip.  Pod machines make better coffees these days.Here is some more information: I checked in at 1AM and got a warm and courteous reception from the night guy.  My room was comfortable and mostly quiet; there was occasional noise (especially TV noise) from the room next door, which was separated from my room by a double door (for use by families who need adjoining rooms).  The heater was not noisy, and the thermostat worked well.I liked the WiFi instructions ("Wired-for-Business") in the room.  "Step 1: Ensure that your device is WIFI ready."  You can imagine the calls to tech support: "How come my device won't connect to the network?"  Answer: "It's not ready."  The network, by the way, was pretty fast -- download 10.5 Mbps, upload 9.25 Mbps. Also, it was a bit unstable.The shower was fine, though it was counterintuitive to have to turn the knob clockwise for hotter water and counter-clockwise for colder water.The workout room was OK when it wasn't full.  I went down one morning at 5:30AM and found that the two stationary bikes were both taken!The rooms were clean and comfortable. The cleaning staff were kind. I am not one to give bad feedback but the fact that as a guest paying over 300 a night you are charged 30 a day parking is outrageous. There were some abrupt desk staff and miserable Starbucks employees. Next time I will stay at the days inn.I recently stayed at the Baltimore Marriott Inner Harbor at Camden Yards and when I checked in the attendant made a mistake and charge my credit card twice. I went back to the front desk later that evening and spoke with a manager who was not nice. I went back the next day and spoke with the Assistant Rooms Operation Manager, Dedre Blackmore who went over and beyond and got the problem corrected sending a  letter (fax) to the bank and made sure that the double charges were taken off the card that day. That is great customer service and I would recommend this Marriott property to anyone staying in Baltimore. The rooms were great the service was awesome!Thank you V. Robinson***This Marriott is very close to Oriole Park at Camden Yards, which makes it a decent option if you are just catching a ballgame; the hotel could use an update though to make it more enjoyable for a longer stay and more worth their high room rates***Baltimore Marriott Inner Harbor at Camden Yards has a great location if watching an Oriole game is your primary reason for visiting Baltimore.  This hotel is about one-to-two blocks away from the stadium's entrance.  It is very convenient.  It is also near the popular Inner Harbor waterfront area, which features great views and lots of touristy stuff (the stuff you would find at Santa Monica Pier or Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco...it seems touristy waterfront areas, regardless of the city, must feature a Bubba Gump Shrimp).The hotel itself is just okay.  This Marriott could probably use an update.  The rooms are pleasant enough, but they feel outdated.  Beds are comfortable though.  The same goes for the shower and the room temperature.Noise is kind of an issue.  The A/C unit is quite loud and this Marriott is located very close to a police station and a fire house and I heard quite a few sirens at night on my visit.The amenities are consistent with other Marriott hotels.  The fitness center is 24 hours and Wi-Fi Internet access requires an additional fee (complimentary for Marriott Gold and Platinum members).Marriott Gold and Platinum members also have access to the Concierge Lounge (on the 10th floor) and it is a decent one.  In terms of the layout, the biggest plus is the variety of seating options.  There are counter chairs and tables like most Marriott Concierge Lounges, but there are also couches for more relaxing near the flat screen television.The food at night features a good variety of items.  On my visit, there was crudite  (raw vegetables like celery, carrots and cherry tomatoes) and dip.  There was also packaged potato chips, crackers, and cheese.  The cheese was better than quite a few Marriott Concierge Lounges--brie was even available here.In terms of hot options, there was enough to make a meal.  There were chicken quesadilla cones, which were average at best (the bottle of hot sauce was really needed since the quesadillas lacked flavor).  There was also macaroni and cheese with ham and a crispy breadcrumb topping.  The macaroni and cheese was pretty decent--cheesy and creamy.Desserts included some decent gingerbread and two not-so-great desserts--a very dense chocolate chip bar and a kind of dry coffee cake.  This Concierge Lounge also had its own espresso / latte / hot chocolate machine, but the hot chocolate was lacking in chocolate flavor and was very watery.  It was nowhere near as good as the hot chocolate machine at JW Marriott LA LIVE's Executive / Concierge Lounge.Breakfast in the Concierge Lounge was decent.  There was good scrambled eggs and mediocre sausage (probably the breakfast would be better when they serve bacon).  Oatmeal, cheese and fresh fruit were available.  There was also a decent variety of breakfast pastries, breads, muffins, bagels, and breads.  I tried the croissant and it was okay, but it lacked the flakiness and light crispiness of the croissant in the Philadelphia Marriott Downtown's Concierge Lounge.Service was good and friendly.Room rates can be high here (weekdays and weekends) because of its prime location.Baltimore Marriott Inner Harbor at Camden Yards is an okay choice if you are catching a baseball game and are staying over for just one night.  It is expensive though.  I think the Fairfield Inn (a little farther away but still within walking distance) is a better choice.  That LEED-certified Fairfield Inn features much more modern decor as well as a more reasonable room rate than this Marriott.Parking is available via a pay parking structure that is attached to the hotel; it is a quick walk to get to your car from the hotel lobby (not always the case with hotel parking).  Parking is $26 per day.I have been staying here for 2 weeks, while some things work out okay, I dislike the fact that my AC squeaks and roar in the middle of the night, and that I can never get enough towels in the bathroom. I will not be staying here on my next trip.Pretty good hotel. My room was clean, my bed was comfy, but my pillows were almost too comfortable. Staff here is very friendly and easily approachable. My only gripe is the lack of a pool, and the gym is lackluster. May I suggest getting free weights less than 10lbs?I stayed here due to the snow storm.  The room was very clean, smelled wonderful.  Beds were comfortable.  The only thing I wasn't happy about was they charged me a day and a half fee instead of a day fee. I work nights and didn't check in until the morning and asked for a 6 pm checkout. So I had to pay the full fee and a four hour fee. I doubt the rooms were filled up and thought there should be a better understanding. Overall good experience. Would stay there again.OMG!!! Beautiful hotel and close to everything!!! We had a King size room and it was very spacious...Customer service could have been better...Great place love my king size bed. Top notch cleaning crew and attendance. Great place to stay.We had a wonderful experience at the Marriott Inner Harbor last weekend when we stayed for the Baltimore Marathon. The hotel is in the best area, easy walking distance to the start and finish areas, right by Camden Yards and Ravens stadium and the Expo.They provided welcome bags at check in with water, bananas, gu, and info and had a  runners' relaxation room off the lobby (cool towels, water, bananas). They even provided a large map in the lobby of the race and we encountered a staff person one time giving advice on the course - amazing!I also want to mention the biggest perk of all, the ability to have a 2pm check out and extended parking garage hours. This allowed the runners to return and shower before check out. This was awesome and such a wonderful advantage.We walked through some other big hotels in the same area and there was nothing like the Marriott provided.Lousy service and attitude.  Put my room service order for breakfast on the door before the printed deadline, but no breakfast the next morning.  I called and they simply said they often collect orders earlier in the evening and must have missed it as if this were my fault.  How am I supposed to know this when the menu states "before midnight"?  Then I asked about the "it's on time or it's on us" printed guarantee.  Their response was "that's only if an order is more than an hour late" - note that they have 15 minute windows for delivery printed on the menu.  I'm here for business - if it says that it will be delivered between 7:15-7:30 am but arrives at 8:30 am, that's too late as I'll be at my meeting.We went here for a wedding and unfortunately for us there was a playoff game going on. Needless to say the staff was unprofessional and overwhelmed. The receptionist was rude and had little information. Worst of all out room stank like smoke and we had to be moved. Overall I would have rather spent the night at a different hotel.We will not be back!Stayed recently for a conference and couldn't be more pleased.  Hotel staff was always friendly and ready to help.  We arrived early and our room was ready.  High praise to the housekeeping staff as our room was always neat and clean!One of the best views in the city.  Perfect if you are staying in town for a game.  Fantastic lobby, very upscale.  Rooms are clean and outstanding.
review_content_40: Stayed here many times.   This is my first Yelp review for this specific Marriott.  Nice rooms.  Actually pretty quiet for being downtown/inner harbor area.  Gets busy in the summer with the Orioles are winning.  Last time here I stayed in the suites on the second floor.  Larger rooms but right above the loading docks so at 5:30 am you going to hear them loading and unloading.  Rest of the rooms are great.   Concierge not open on weekends but they'll give you points or a continental breakfast to make up for it.  Bar and restaurant are small and get crowded very quickly.  Not a fan of the restaurant layout but the food is good.  Bottom line....it's my place to stay in Baltimore.Cons: room was small and had that sort-of-dirty-like-a-motel appearance and smell; tried to call the front desk 3 times, and the phone rang without ever being picked up -- I had to go down to the front desk to get any servicePro: good continental breakfast in the concierge loungeDepends on how you look at it: across the street from a strip clubConclusion: not what I expect from a MarriottWorst experience in a hotel. It is a old hotel with a dated heating system. First my room was too cold, then oven hot. The service person who came to look at it said he would check back with me and never did. I was going to let my stay slide but then after midnight when I was in bed, a man tried to get in my room. As a female traveling alone, it was unsettling to say the least. I told him someone was in the room. I tried to let it go but 15 minutes later he came back and tried to get in again. Through the door I told him again someone was in the room and he said he had been given that room. I called the front desk and they asked if I wanted to talk to Loss Prevention. At nearly 1 am I said no, send security to make sure this man gets to his room. In the morning I went down to share my stressful experience and was offered a free breakfast, not to talk to a manager. Nothing. Oh yes my co-worker had to get her key card fixed three times as she couldn't get in her room. So I don't recommend this place to anyone.We had a wonderful experience staying at this Marriott! Everyone on the staff was super nice and helpful upon our arrival, and the rooms were clean and offered all of the amenities you'd expect from such a nice hotel in the city. Since we were going to the O's game, the location couldn't have been much better, either. The beds were seriously comfortable enough that my wife and I walked away wanting to replace our own mattress with one of theirs. Haha.We also were lucky to land great prices on Priceline that only magnified the pleasant experience. $90/night for two weekend nights...during baseball season? Yeah...we'll be staying there again, for sure!I like the Marriott chain. You always know what you're going to get with one of their hotels -- nicely decorated and modern room with a comfortable bed, good service, and a relatively clean hotel. This isn't a five star place, but for the average traveler this has most of the amenities you could want (except a pool). They've got wireless internet in their rooms for about $12 a day. Parking is expensive at $24 a day, but that's to be expected since the location is two blocks north of Camden Yards. It's close to the convention center, football and baseball stadiums, and the Inner Harbor so it's ideal for tourists and business travelers. On the negative side, my room while nicely decorated, looked a little worn with pealing wallpaper, broken baseboards, and beat up furniture. The water in the shower didn't get very hot. Even after turning it up all the way it was lukewarm, at best. Still, I'd recommend this place to anyone staying in Baltimore.So, I've been travelling to Baltimore every week for work since beginning of May, and this has been my home for the entire time so far.I love the beds. Seriously. SOO COMFY!!Staff is always friendly especially the doormen.If you have elite access, you have access to the concierge lounge on the 10th floor, which means free breakfast.What else? Oh yea you gotta pay for WiFi. BUT, it's pretty awesome that there are free oranges and earphones downstairs at the gym for after your workout.Enjoy!Stayed here for a wedding in Baltimore last year.The hotel itself is pretty nice.  Limited bar, but solid placement right across the street from Camden Yards.  Room was accomodating and spacious.  Bathroom was clean and large.Only gripes are parking, which is a royal pain in get into.  Not to mention EXPENSIVE.  I'm already getting ripped off to stay at the hotel, and now I'm getting bled even more just for the priviledge to park at the same hotel.  If you pull up to the front of the hotel, you have to cut across traffic and make about 4 left hand turns, then search for the parking garage.Nice hotel, conveniently located near the Inner Harbor, walking distance the stadium, close to Johns Hopkins Hospital. Restaurant on site. Clean and well maintained rooms. Semi-attached garage...Customer service was superb ;)Other than that parking was $24/night with in and out privileges, no free breakfast, business center was like 50 cents minute which doesn't include the cost of printing, wifi in your room was an additional cost...I will not be backI'm such a Marriott girl. I love their hotels for their excellent service and comfortable rooms, and this Marriott in Baltimore is no exception. The staff here is incredibly kind. The employees in the lobby, from the security guards to the concierge, were all nice, accommodating, and friendly! The cleaning staff always greeted me whenever I passed by, and always offered extra amenities (towels, shampoo, etc.) without my asking.The employees at the bar were friendly and thoughtful when they kept refilling my coffee cup after I froze my pinstriped behind off at Camden Yards that evening.Oh, and speaking of, I love that it's right across the street from Camden Yards! Talk about convenient! The Inner Harbor is only a few blocks away ... but I came to see some baseball, and this was the perfect hotel for doing just that.I think that the Concierge Lounge fell short as compared to some of the other ones I've been to. Traditionally, the breakfast hours are usually spent quietly in the lounge, with a few businessmen reading WSJ or watching the news and eating a plate of eggs & sausage. On every day of our stay, there were large, loud groups of families in the lounge, and the food couldn't be replenished quickly enough. My poor boyfriend wanted nothing more than a bowl of oatmeal, and every day of our 3-night stay they ran out (and yes, we got there with an hour to spare). Same goes for sausage, cereal, and coffee (!!). I can safely say that the state of the Concierge Lounge was the most disappointing part of our stay.But I mean, the room was great (very clean!) & comfortable; the staff was excellent; the wifi, while not free, was strong & reliable. I would love to stay here again the next time I come to Baltimore.What a pleasant experience... we knew we were coming to Baltimore awhile ago to see an Orioles game. so we just decided to see what Priceline would yield us near the Inner Harbour.   We couldn't have gotten luckier... For $90 a night, plus $26 for parking we got to stay at the Marriott Inner Harbor at Camden Yards.  So close to the stadium!  Nice, clean hotel, nice and updated.  Friendly staff too.  Convenient to a lot of things too. We were really surprised as I travel a decent amount for work and have paid over 200.00 and 300.00 a night for a crappier experience in a not updated hotel with bad service.  Rooms were really clean too (see my review of the Cincinnatti Marriott on Mason Montgomery Rd).  A+++++++I have stayed a bunch of hotels over the years and have stayed at plenty Marriott's.  I was there for a wedding over the weekend and I wasn't pleased how the hotel operated.  Rooms were fine, wedding was wonderful but some of the staff seemed grumpy and didn't want to help.  Comparing this Marriott to other Marriott's, it wasn't a good experience.    Don't get me wrong, there were some nice people but what you get for your money, this wouldn't be my first pick.The staff is so friendly, the rooms are comfortable and safe. The food is really good, in a convenient part of town. You should stay here when in Baltimore.This review is for the conference facilities only. I'm sure the rooms are nice. I know the doorman is super pleasant.The room was plenty big for the number of people that attended the conference (about 300+) since it was just seating in rows to listed to lecture style presenters with their PowerPoint. However, the audio visual part was abysmal. Even though the screen in front was very large it was still hard to see anything except the largest print.  Maybe I should have sat closer to the front but I'm thinking you should be able to see and hear from anywhere in the room.The sound was kind of muted, too. Yeah.  I could hear the presenter if I really listened hard and didn't get distracted by other people but if the volume had been a little louder (not much, just a little louder) it would have been perfect.The cookies and ice cream provided as part of the conference before the presentation and during the break were great. I know at things like this it is the hotel that provides everything from soup to nuts, so I was kinda surprised the audio-visual aspects weren't up to standards. Oh well.In short: this is a very mediocre Marriott property. I stayed here for about 3 months during an extended project in Baltimore and was continuously unimpressed. I generally stay about 100+ nights / year in Marriott hotels and was the least satisfied with my stay at the Baltimore Marriott Inner Harbor. Overall it felt unpolished - the room service took forever, the rooms were musty and outdated, and the experience at the front desk was mixed. The location: incredible if you're heading to a game at Camden Yards. Otherwise, forget about it. None of the good restaurants are within walking distance and cabs in Baltimore are an experience reminiscent of visiting the dentist. Whether you're headed to Baltimore for vacation or business, I suggest one of the other hotels closer to the Harbor, namely the Renaissance or any of the newer hotels east of the Harbor.2/19/14 - I stayed here recently for 3 nights and found this to be a decent place.   It's over priced if you pay over $100 but I suppose it would depend on the season and the demand.  I was here when it snowed and the local area seemed shut down without too many good restaurants in the immediate area as someone has already pointed out.  But, the light rail, Camden Yards for Orioles fans, University of Maryland -Baltimore, Inner Harbor, Convention Center are all within walking distance.The Front desk was hospitable but I did feel slighted when another guest was telling me how he was treated.   Not sure why they "mistreated" me but it kept them from getting another star for the uneven treatment that ended costing me money.   The lobby was not very comfortable but felt cramped and just functional.  No points for the lobby, Marriott!  You must have bought this place on a fire sale years back because it evidently isn't one of your own designs.The gym was acceptable with perhaps 30 or more types of equipment -- all with television and earphones available and free oranges, small towels.The meeting rooms were acceptable but smaller than what we normally use but not as compact as I've been in a previous location.  We could hear through the moving partitions during our meetings however and it got to be a distraction. As our meetings don't end in the morning, I usually ask for a complimentary extension and they usually give me an hour.   THIS WAS THE FIRST TIME THAT THE FRONT DESK CLERK SAID: "HOW ABOUT 30 MINUTES!?"   My first reaction is that he is either kidding or just plain stingy with a resource that really doesn't cost Marriott anything but gives goodwill.   Evidently, they don't need much goodwill except that it provides me with a unique story for time immemorial -- do you get it now, Marriott?!  :)    But, I graciously accepted the 30 minutes without complaint.    Evidently our group is not spending enough here.  So, the bed was nice -- but too many damn pillows.   The walk to the room was down a long hall and so it was a tiring, long haul -- but I probably need the exercise.Our group will be back and I'll end up loving it for hotel management's minimalist attitude.    Oh, yes, the parking is $26 but that seems to be standard in Baltimore.  For the amount of time we spend outside our meetings, and the lack of interesting restaurants in the neighborhood, we should be going to a place that has free parking in the 'burbs or airport.    I'll see if i can make this happen.   :)I have stayed at this Marriott several times over the past few years and I have to admit it wasn't my first choice. Other properties seemed to provide better service. However on this trip, we booked a room for five nights and we have been very happy. The front desk staff was extremely helpful when we arrived and our room was very nice (10th floor Concierge Level). The redecorated lobby is very nice and the new restaurant decor is very pleasing. Food is not bed either. The Concierge lounge is nice. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The food selection is above average. The fact that they close the place for cleaning from 10am until ?? is a bit annoying since I am used to being able to pop in to use the computer or get a beverage during the morning, especially if I sleep in past breakfast. Overall we had a great stay and this hotel moved up a couple notches. The location is a must if you are going to Camden Yards or the Convention Center.Wow! What an awesome hotel. I didn't realize what I had booked until the taxi cab driver dropped me off at the front door! Beautiful entrance and lobby and very nice rooms. Interestingly, I didn't think the main entrance was on the side you would expect it to be on. In fact, it faces one of the less busy streets which I guess is a good thing. The best part is that there is free wifi and that it is a 5 min WALK to the University of Maryland hospital. Two blocks down and 1 block over!Probably the worst Marriott I've ever stayed in. I've just spent 25 nights at this particular location, and I must say that my level of disappointment is extremely high. When I hear the name "Marriott" I think of terms like "up scale", "modern", and "homey". This hotel made me feel none of these things. The most appalling revelation of this hotels short comings were the rats in the hotel. On more than one occasion I had to personally chase a rat out of my room, only to watch it scurry into the room directly across the hall from my own. I would expect more cleanliness from a Motel 6, much less a Marriott. Apparently I'm not the only quest who experienced these furry little creatures in my room if you continue to read further reviews. Furthermore, the amenities of the hotel are lacking in more areas than just having a healthy rodent population. The TVs in the rooms have a grand total of roughly 12-15 channels to choose from, so if you're like me and prefer to relax by watching your favorite cable television shows, this is not the hotel for you. Thank goodness I was forward thinking enough to bring along my laptop so that at the very least I had Neflix, HBO Go, ect.. or I truly would have been in hell. The food in the hotels' bar/lounge/restaurant is mediocre to good at best. Certainly, it's way over priced for what it is. With the abundance of other hotels in close proximity to Camden Yards and M&T Bank Stadium (home of the Ravens) you can certainly find something much more suitable to even the most modest of taste in terms of accommodations. The only reason I'm not demanding more from the hotel during my stay, is because my stay here is being paid for by the company for whom I work. I would not pay a dime to stay at this hotel when Baltimore has so much more to offer. I highly recommend the Hyatt Regency if you're looking for a place worthy of your money..I actually enjoyed my stay here.  It's a solid 3-3.5 start hotel done well.  Clean, courteous, super comfy beds.  I'd definitely stay here again.We had a great weekend staying at this Marriott. I wasn't sure what to expect, but we were immediately greeted by the friendly staff in the lobby -- they even offered us s'mores!  The staff was always super friendly, and the beautiful lobby always had fruit-flavored water for guests.  We got placed in a room on the 10th floor, which had a very nice view of the city. Room was immaculately clean and smelled fresh. Bed was amazingly comfortable. They let us check our luggage for free after we checked out so we could wander the city without heavy bags. Really great experience, and we were sad to leave! Would definitely stay again.
review_content_60: A bit pRicy but totttttally worth it !!! Beautiful, clean room ! Ridiculously comfortable bed- newly renovated lobby and some of the friendliest staff in the world ! Couldn't afford to do it every weekend but sometimes it's worth it to treat ureself rather than cheat ureself !!!Disclaimer: This review will only cover the conference facilities. I attended a three-day multi-room conference at the end of April, and did not stay in the hotel (too expensive!).For a large corporate hotel, this Marriott was NOT well-equipped for a conference. Yes, it has many rooms, with fancy-sounding names such as "Ballroom" and "Stadium", but fancy they are not. The audiovisual equipment is RUBBISH (although, the audiovisual guys are LOVELY and very capable and sweetly apologetic about the hotel facilities). The rooms are dismally lit (apparently there is no way to put the lights down up front near the projector screen without dimming the entire room), the microphone podiums are awkward (if you are using a laptop, you won't have room for anything else... not even your elbow), and sound clatters through the front and back doorways in EVERY room, with some rooms transmitting far too much sound from neighbouring rooms too.If you're going to offer up your hotel for a conference, you better make damn sure you realize how to accommodate professional presentations. In several of the rooms, the microphones were so placed that each time a speaker cleared their throat, there was enough feedback to deafen an entire pod of dolphins. In one room, despite the efforts of our AV assistants, we experienced feedback whenever a NEIGHBOURING room applauded.Efforts to move rooms or replace the AV equipment were shut down by upper management-types.Catering the event was a shit-show, too. Food ran out at every break. Requests to refill the water fountains (giving presentations is thirsty work!) were ignored. Spills and crumbs were vacuumed and cleaned loudly only during the conference sessions, much to the dismay of presenters already combatting the ill-equipped AV systems.Seriously, Marriott -- wtf?Of course, the location, the grandeur, the fact that the hotel was big enough to accommodate our 300+ strong crowd were all benefits, and the only reason this Marriott gets two stars instead of one.3.5 Stars!Pros: -Great location, easy to walk to the inner harbor, museums, aquarium and Lexington market.-SUPER comfortable beds, I got an extra 90mins of sleep because of the sheer comfort of the mattress.-Nice size gym with updated equipment (Not that I used it but I went to check it out so I could let you knowCons:-No safes in the room-You have to pay for wi-fi-Lacked Luster; and by this I mean that it was nice, clean, and functional but it wasn't anything to really experience within the hotel itself. There was not much of a bar scene or chic feeling in the lobby.Walkable and convenient to Hilton and BCC (Baltimore Convention Center)Wifi is $13/day in the room.Comfortable room.I stayed here for a business trip. I understand that the hotel is in the middle of a renovation, but I'm not sure that's even the reason I was so displeased. The hotel is extremely dated. I couldn't find vending machines or ice machines. Signage says they are on every other floor (why not every floor?), but the staff pointed me to the lobby. The bar area didn't sell bottled water - I had to go to the front desk for that. So in the middle of the night if you're thirsty, you have to go to the front desk? Bizarre. One evening I had no hot water in my shower. It returned in the morning luckily. Since my company was paying for the hotel I didn't bother mentioning it to the staff.I was snowed in here all weekend due to a work conference. One awesome thing is that a crazy friend of mine drove up from southern Md. to be snowed in with me.Overall, 2.5-ish stars.This is one of the business-flavored Marriotts, but man they suck you dry. The business center nearly made me slit my wrists. You had to swipe your credit card to do anything, and on top of that I think it's ludicrous they don't offer free wifi throughout the hotel, but just in the lobby.The rooms were clean and we all know the Marriott bed is the next best thing to sleeping at the Westin. They know it too; you can even purchase the bed online at shopmarriott.com/categor...The food here was the definition of mediocre, and when you're snowed in eating every meal here, it starts to feel like you're at an all-inclusive in Mexico or something--everything tastes the same and nothing's delicious. The staff were on point, and they went the extra mile this weekend to appease all the snowed in customers: bingo and a DJ dance party on Friday night, Wii bowling on Saturday night. I would return for sure--it's a decent stay--but would dine elsewhere in the city. Unfortunately we didn't have that option this weekend.Free wifi, a mini fridge in the room, a fan in the bathroom (for when drunk people sneak cigs) and two more creamers at the in-room coffee station would earn this establishment four stars.Great hotel if you're a baseball fan. It's walking distance to the Oriole Stadium and the Babe Ruth Museum. Parking is a whopping $26 per night. Thank goodness for Priceline the room was only $65 per night. The staff here is friendly and helpful! The rooms were clean and up to par with the star rating.First let me state that I did not stay in one of the rooms at the hotel, I just met my friend for drinks here. Now that we have moved past this let's get into the review!I must say that the decor inside the lobby of this hotel is completely spectacular and very modern. There are purple couches with gold pillows, leather white swivel chairs and fish tanks. Oh and let's not forget that wonderful staircase. As I waited for my friend to arrive I must say that I was immediately relaxed in the cozy atmosphere.The bar area was quite nice although our waiter was a little strange. He spoke so fast you could barely understand him. But who needs a rundown of the menu when you came to drink? LolOverall, I would definetely like to go back for another cocktail :)The Marriott Inner Harbor is a nice hotel for a fairly good value (comparatively to the other downtown Baltimore hotels). The interior is modern and clean and the hotel is actually scheduled for a renovation soon. Everything else is better than average, but not 5-star. The hospitality staff are friendly and try, but it's just not quite there yet. The concierge lounge is nice, with a good variety for breakfast (although no hot eggs/bacon), and happy hour/desserts. Location is walking distance to the Inner Harbor area and across the street from the Orioles stadium, Camden Yard, but as a lone female traveler, I wouldn't want to be walking around the area much after dark.would NEVER stay here again. Came in from out of town to go to a baseball game and got their best room. it was awful...old, terrible view. But I can deal w/ that. What I can't deal w/ is how cheap they were. Not enough toiletries given. had to call up for EVERYTHING and they made us wait an hour to hour and a half every time. I can't say 1 good thing about our stay there.The Baltimore Marriott Inner Harbor is short walk from Camden Station and a slightly longer walk to the Inner Harbor. Check-in is usually speedy except when you're stuck behind a large group.The concierge lounge has cold cuts, sliced cheese, scrambled eggs, assorted pastries, cut fruit, cereal, bread, yogurt, and assorted drinks for breakfast. In the evening, they have two hot hors d'oeuvres, a cheese plate, and desserts.At the end of one stay, I'd forgotten a pair of tennis shoes in the closet. The following week, I called and within two hours, someone dropped by with my shoes in a Marriott plastic bag.TV reception wasn't the same quality in all the rooms. Sometimes, the TV would be fine, and other times, the TV would be snowy. While I was there, they were doing maintenance on the elevators so there were only two working elevators. During peak times, you could look forward to a packed elevator, long wait or both.The gym has three elliptical machines, five or so treadmills, and a weight machine. There's a water dispenser, cups, and hand towels but you might want to bring your own water bottle. My friend preferred the gym at one of the Sheratons.Always enjoy staying at Marriott brands but this one has a place in my heart for a few reasons. It's close to Camden Yards, and being a baseball fan, the access is very convenient. Don't be fooled though - the "Inner Harbor" brand is misleading. It's easily a 10 minute walk to the shops and water taxi, things that make the inner harbor tick. But the Camden Yards part isn't, that's for sure! You can see the lights on game nights! It's a typical Marriott with top-notch customer service and accommodations. However, I would be remiss if I did not bring up one of the largest selling points and that is their BREAKFAST BUFFET!!! Design your own omelet stations, make your own waffles, biscuits and gravy, sausage and bacon and pastries...oh my! Considering I am from NY, their prices for a buffet are very reasonable (though if I lived in MD, truthfully, I have no idea if they think that way). If I stay in a different hotel, I always make it a point to hit the buffet, that's the truth! I rarely drive to B-more anymore, but when I did I remember parking was over $20/day. They screw you in the drive thru, that's for sure, but that's in most cities where you opt to park in a garage. I haven't stayed here in a while, but I always make it a point to visit when I am there!Marriott standard. That's what you expect, that's what you pay for. Clean rooms and bathrooms. Good air-conditioning in rooms. ONE complaint: The nice, new LG flat screen was hooked up to an ANALOG signal. Pony up the extra $$$ Marriott, come on.Soft bed, and expected Marriott service, I did want to express my shock with the poor concierge service... The rest of the staff was very nice and helpful, and the chef left his post to offer samples of his bacon-almond brittle, which I may add, was pretty darn good. But that concierge... short of making fun of me, was not interested (and seemingly bothered) in assisting me in finding a local Zumba class. From the ZUMBA? WHAT IS THAT? To, well sir, is there a Gold Gym nearby? "NO, It closed, sorry I can't help you" with a snort and a snicker, click. Jerk. I guess he was at the end of his shift. Or maybe at the end of his career. Or maybe unamused with the environment. Whatever it was, this poor man should probably do something else. I hope that at a minimum someone told him what Zumba is and how to find it... Or maybe to find something else to do than to be so... uninterested, and it showed...This is a great hotel, very clean. Little bit of construction around it but that should be finished soon. Good Staff, free internet in the lobby and easy to get around the city from here. Be careful on game nights you might have some trouble with traffic.Great location, nice room. Room service was pretty good. Wish I had a better view and free wi fi. 3.5 starGreat and accommodating service in the lobby. Room service is very quick and has a decent selection, even late at night. unlike other marriotts, this one charges for use of the computers/printers in the business center.Yard lobby restaurant is not a "typical" hotel restaurant/bar...that's a good thing.I really wanted to give this place NO stars when I first got there this past weekend. We arrived in the ridiculous heat around 2:30pm, and just wanted to lay down for a while before the baseball game, and they said our room wouldn't be available for an hour to 1 1/2. wtf? Annoying. Ended up being okay, room service food was actually really good, and pretty fast. The room was clean, bright, and good sized. They need more elevators, we had to wait every time. VERY convenient to Camden Yards which was excellent since we were not about to rent a car. A few restaurants near the hotel, but you have to walk at least 3-4 blocks or so to find shops and most eating options. Not a long walk normally, but in the 100 degree heat, it was pretty unpleasant.Stayed here during Otakon. The room was clean and the hotel was nice. Only things I didn't like was lack of free wi-fi in your room.The hotel was very comfortable, even in the midst of renovation. Construction noise could be heard in the middle of the day, but ended well before evening. The cafe and bar are fine. The Starbucks/convenience store makes a sugary mocha. The concierge lounge breakfast is decent. The only major negative is that there is no free Wi-Fi, anywhere in the building. Hint: there's free Wi-Fi at the Holiday Inn across the street. I was in Baltimore for a convention and the hotel is just a short walk away.
