If I were in Baltimore for other reasons, I'd stay elsewhere as the immediate area doesn't have much to offer after nightfall and the neighborhood gets a little dodgy just a few blocks away in most directions.
review_content_80: This is a very nice hotel. The rooms are modern and beds are comfortable, not to many restaurants in the area but is convenient to the convention center. Concierge service was a plus. Also recommend if you are going to Camden Yards. Overall I would say they live up to the Marriott experience plus a little more.Went for International Microwave Symposium 2011 in June.  With so many engineers booked at the hotel, the WiFi network and DSL box can't handle the load.  My network connection kept dropping off.  Forget about working remotely.  You might as well go out to a bar and go drinking.  Mind you, you can only go to ones close to the hotel.  Go just 1 or 2 blocks away and you'll end up in the dodgy part of town.

review_content: If you're a tourist - this is going to be the first place you hear about on google about Baltimore. It's one of the nicest areas in Baltimore and there's always lively events going around here. From the magicians and singers performing in one corner to the Aquarium, Top of the World, Federal Hill there's all sorts of events to come and see. If you're too tired to walk all the way around - you can take the water taxi all around as well :) Here's a list of all the things in the area: - National Aquarium (A must visit) - Camden Yards - Watch the orioles play a baseball game!- Federal Hill - one of the best views of the city- Top of The World - View the city from a really tall building and see a piece of the 9/11 wreck outside. .- Historic Ships- Paddle Boating - Maryland Science Center- Visionary Art Museum - Quirky art museum - Little Italy - Fells Points - lots of food options here if you want to get away from all the touristy parts.I'm a Ravens fan, which is probably the only reason I've ended up at the Inner Harbor on multiple occasions. Overall, it's not really all that impressive. Almost every place to eat in the Harbor is a chain restaurant (Hooters, Hard Rock Cafe, Bubba Gump Shrimp). The only somewhat good place, if you ask me, is Phillips Seafood, but even that's a chain.There's a Ripley's Museum, which is a real eye sore and can't be any less of a tourist trap than the one in Time's Square.I can't speak for the aquarium, but I've heard it's good.One of the reasons I'm stuck at 2 stars is because the Harbor was completely dead on an early Sunday night ... after a Ravens home game. WTF?Its magical, its expensive, its got an allure that wants you to come back, its impossible to find a place to leave the car.Leave it to here. Baltimore Inner Harbor is all that, and more. I've been to the Inner Harbor several times, especially in the last 2 years. Whether its a walk around the harbor, visiting some of the exhibits on it, or eating at Bubba Gump Shrimp Company, it's always a fun memory. Seeing an Orioles game (Camden Yards is really close by), only tops off a memorable visit here. It's also not bad public transportation wise (the real way to get here), either you can take the Metro to the last stop, or take the Light Rail to Camden Yards from Penn Station. Either way, its a treat. You never want to take a place like this for granted. Its like Coney Island. There's a magical feel that comes over you while being on it, and you feel like you're 12 again, with the sights and sounds that overtake the northeast corner of your eye when you've heard cannon fire, or when you finally realize, you're at one of the major cornerstones of American history, the place where Francis Scott Key wrote the "Star Spangled Banner" and major industry was established. Its hard to not get romantic about the Inner Harbor. And its why you should go visit.Always a good time to be had here.  It does not matter if you are taking in some history, enjoying an event, or sampling one of the many restaurants that surround the harbor.  There are some that are hesitant about coming to the downtown area because of news reports or just second hand information from others.  There is plenty to see and enjoy so if this is keeping you from coming here then you are missing out on of the many jewels of Baltimore.I've been here a few times now and I enjoy my visit each time I am here. There is so much going on around the harbor. Whether it be the WW2 submarine or the ship where you can go on them for a small fee; dining at one of the many restaurants around the harbor; listening to live music or simply taking a relaxing stroll -- it offers a little bit of everything for everyone.  I am giving it 4 stars because I do feel some of the areas could be better maintained as far as trash overflow and what not. If that gets in the harbor that could affect a lot more than just the humans on shore, but also the life in the harbor itself.Other than that -- I make it a point to visit when ever I'm in town.My fiance and I visited Baltimore's Inner Harbor for New Year's Day yesterday and had a great time.  We visited primarily to explore the National Aquarium, which is my favorite aquarium of all time.  We also explored the waterfront area and got a seafood lunch at Phillips.  The inner harbor is a really fun place to spend a day. My only complaint is that there aren't that many great seafood restaurants around.  Phillips was our best choice and we were hoping for other choices.  Note that there is also parking near the Inner Harbor - Lockwood parking lot was great and only half a block away!I was last here in 2000, and 2010. It was 5 stars then, but I see it as 4 stars today.It is still beautiful with very scenic views of boats and ships big and small, street musicians to entertain you, shopping, restaurants, the cool water taxi fleet, and all sorts of attractions in close proximity. I noticed a distinct increase in things that cost the Inner Harbor that fifth star. A lot more vagrants, panhandlers, and poor souls who walk around muttering or talking to themselves. I understand this is a city, but here's a question. If the Inner Harbor is Baltimore's Crown Jewel of tourism, where is the effort to control things? I walked around here for 4 1/2 days and didn't see a cop once. That was disturbing to me.I guess I don't see the appeal. It's nice for walking around and looking at water. But the restaurants and shops are obviously chain and touristy. It has a little bit of a smell, as most places around water tend to do.I don't know. It's nice, but there's nothing really here.If I were visiting Baltimore, I'd come down to the inner harbor, but I wouldn't stay around for very long.If I lived in Baltimore, I'd use it on my running route. That's about it.Tourist trap or not, it is beautiful here!.    Historic big ships, WWII submarines, docked in the water, and you can check them out!!   So many shops, and places to check out, and the food choices are endless!!   We stopped and listened to a great trumpet player just hanging out by the water, and we met some nice people as we walked around.     So much more to see......My opinion only, not right or wrong... Areas that are made specially for tourist are just plain awful. The main goal is to offer travelers the comforts they may have back home in the form of terrible chain restaurants and over priced "attractions" that could be and are most likely available back home. Don't eat at the restaurants here, no Dicks, no Phillips, no Cheese Cake, and defiantly no Hard Rock Cafe! If you're reading this Yelp review I have the confidence that you will chose wisely and avoid the restaurants and weak over priced tourist attractions at the Inner Harbor. Simply walk past as you enjoy looking at the waterfront and use Yelp to find yourself an "only in Baltimore" eating establishment that excites your palate and opens your mind.   For fun you ask? Baltimore is the most acetic major city in the great U.S. of A... Throw on your adventurous pants and set off to take an urban hike through this historic and quirky gem that we call Charm City.Inner Harbor is one of the more beautiful and happening spots in Baltimore. It's a beautiful harbor and very scenic, but not a huge area. You can probably walk around and explore the area in about 1 hour unless you decide to go to the aquarium, hop aboard the USS Constellation or take part in some of the water activities. There are also plenty of gift/souvenir shops in the area. If you're looking for a bite, there's a Phillips Seafood, but for those real foodies out there, they'll love that there's a Shake Shack and Chick-Fil-A across the street --- and right next to each other! Also, if you're looking to get around, there's the Charm City Circulator where you can get a free bus ride on 4 different colored routes. Just look for the bus stop signs with a color on it and you'll see where it goes.I first came here for work-related training in June of 2009 (again in 2013 and 2014). On our first day of training our bus drove a few blocks off the Inner Harbor and we were stuck in traffic because three people were shot at four in the afternoon. Just let that settle in, because the harbor is in one of the nicer parts of Baltimore.The harbor is essentially a small strip of shops, a Barnes and Nobles, half a dozen restaurants, a small Aquarium and boats. That is all great, however, on hot summer nights there are a hell of a lot of rowdy teenagers and nowhere near enough cops around to babysit them. Going here during the day is fine, hanging out at night is not necessarily a good idea.Whether you're vacationing or in town for work this is a place to check out.  This place has really good restaurants and a couple of shopping malls and the scenery is awesome.In Baltimore for a weekend conference, I was prepared for this to be a seedy, tourist trap of an area, with overpriced restaurants and aggressive panhandlers. But I was pleasantly surprised by how safe and enjoyable the Inner Harbor actually was, with a variety of family-friendly restaurants and attractions. I didn't have time to visit the Aquarium, but the Historic Ships were terrific, and I'm looking forward to coming back in a couple of years with our kids. There are a number of first-rate hotels, and the delights of Little Italy and Fells Point are just a short walk away. One of America's greatest urban redevelopments, Baltimore's Inner Harbor is well worth a visit.An excellent area for family fun, date night or sight seeing. Plenty of options to entertain you and your guests while several amenities are within walking distance. The Harbor is host to paddle boats, The USS Constellation and water taxis as well as the National Aquarium.Make sure you stop by the Charm City Carousel to relive the kid in you. This could be an area where you can plan a staycation with one of the local hotels and take in all that Baltimore has to offer. Again, all within walking distance if the weather is amicable or just hop in a cab.I have been here a few times and upon each visit I discover something else I want to check out on my next visit to the area. There are indoor shops, restaurants that support sidewalk dining and of course plenty of watering holes to do a couple of 12oz arm curls and enjoy pub food.I recommend making a list of places and make a day of it. It's good for exercise, tourism and your bucket list. The only detractor I experienced was some homeless guy milking himself in public. Other than that keep a positive outlook and experience all the harbor holds.Came here again with the now 9 year old for food, fun and the Aquarium.Dragon Boats, street performers, touristy stuff.Like NY's South Street Seaport but even better!It's ok for half a day to see the waterfront on a beautiful day with a breeze coming from the water. Walking around in the sun is fun, as you can saunter along with friends and family having casual and lighthearted conversation while watching people from all around the area and the world touring about as well.For fun, take a ride in a dragon shaped boat, pirate ship, speed boat or cruise boat. The harbor is filled with buskers and performers at various times of the day at various locations with skills of the musical and juggling and circus tricks variety. The kids love it, and adults can find fun with the acts, too!There are plenty of commercial sins to tempt you from big names in clothing and food for your pleasure or displeasure. Nearby, you may partake in the science museum or aquarium, but beware the aquarium lines are ridiculously long!!  There's also a music venue right in the harbor, too near pier 5.Overall, if you can find parking just north of the area at a 'meter,' your wallet will be happiest. Then, just be ready I have a nice walk and enjoy that sightseeing of people watching!  If you get bored, walk east and north to Little Italy and Fells Point.Wow. Baltimore Inner Harbor, huh?  Maybe I'm missing something crucial, but I don't see what the big appeal is.  I've heard a lot of the complaints about New York's Times Square being "Disneyfied," cleaned up and erased of anything identifiably New York-y, but I don't agree with that at all. Sure Times Square is an advertising wonderland, but it is unique in the world and still EXTREMELY idiosyncratic.  Say what you will about the Naked Cowboy and creepy Sesame Street knock-off characters, they were invented in Times Square's chaotic fabric.  If any nutcase wants to do anything and get noticed, Times Square is where they do it.  But those complaints about Times Square I believe in whole-heartedly about Baltimore's Inner Harbor.You can tell they spent a lot of money revitalizing the harbor, and unfortunately, it shows.  It's overdone.  It looks like it was all built at once so that everything is shiny, new and boring.  I get the feeling that the power plant is supposed to be a centerpiece, and I'm sure the building is pretty cool, but mostly it's now serving as a billboard for Barnes a& Noble and the Hard Rock Cafe  I know, right?  Barnes & Noble and Hard Rock Cafe!  Aren't they both bankrupt yet?  There's a Ripley's Believe It Or Not, a Bubba Gump Shrimp... basically every store that exists in every other tourist trap is here.  I even visited a McCormick's "House of Flavor," a very Times Square-y McCormick's store which stocked every flavor of spice that you can already buy in every grocery store, and little else.There is very little about the Inner Harbor that screamed "Baltimore" to me.  Except for the ships.  But to learn anything about the ships, you need to pay and go into a museum.  There is nary an informational plaque to be found outdoors.  In fact, very little enjoyment can be had for free here. I came on a Sunday.  I've visited other similarly sized cities on Sundays and parking is always free. In Baltimore it was $27.  That's highway robbery, and I'm not kidding.  If you want to encourage people to spend money at your attractions, you don't charge them like that right off the top.  This is basic city planning.I did stroll around Little Italy and Fell's Point and those neighborhoods were nice and historic, so I suppose if the Inner Harbor drives more money into neighborhoods like that, it's a good thing.***Baltimore's Inner Harbor is incredibly touristy like other big city waterfront areas like Pier 39 in San Francisco and Santa Monica Pier, but I actually enjoyed Baltimore's Inner Harbor much more; it was much cleaner than those two spots; it was more spacious and there was an abundance of greenery, nice housing and attractive buildings***When it comes to retail and dining options, Baltimore's Inner Harbor is definitely very similar to other big city waterfront areas like San Francisco's Pier 39 and Santa Monica Pier.  This waterfront area features touristy chain restaurants like Dick's Last Resort, Hard Rock Cafe and Bubba Gump Shrimp (are waterfront areas required to have one of these?).  Shopping choices are mostly touristy options including several souvenir stores as well as a large candy store (IT'SUGAR).  One of the more interesting shops, which also felt touristy, was the McCormick spice shop.  It, of course, featured a wide variety of McCormick spices like you would find at your neighborhood grocery store, but many other things were available including a good selection of gourmet candy bars.One nice non-retail and dining attraction is this area's very good visitor center.  It includes an incredible variety of brochures for Baltimore as well as the surrounding cities and states.  The visitor center covers everything from hotels and city dining options to historical attractions, wineries and nature trips.While dining or shopping at Baltimore's Inner Harbor definitely feels like you could be at Pier 39 or Santa Monica Pier, this waterfront area had several advantages over those two touristy spots.  It felt much more spacious so it was easy walking around; it could just be that Baltimore does not draw the crowds that San Francisco and Los Angeles do.It was a great and picturesque walk too.  There was a lot of greenery as well as many nice looking buildings.  If you walk long enough along the water, you not only see great looking ships and great views of the city, but you also see a very nice and upscale residential area that is right on the water.Because of the history and picturesque views, Baltimore's Inner Harbor is a must visit.  And while you can probably skip the shopping and food, you can enjoy a nice, relaxing walk along the very clean brick-paved path that is right up next to the water (a lot closer than a lot of waterfront areas, which gives Baltimore's Inner Harbor a special feel).Parking around Baltimore's Inner Harbor is expensive.  You might be able to find metered street parking if you are willing to walk.The Inner Harbor is absolutely beautiful. It reminded me of my hometown San Francisco with the historic boats, the beautiful waterfront and shops. The guy playing music and singing along for tips, kids running around and touristy like shops. We were lucky enough to stay close to the Inner Harbor, it's an easy way to get around the city. Everything was within walking distance to the Inner Harbor area. Although I only heard about the Water Taxi on the last day, it's the best way to get around the Harbor and visit all the neighborhoods. It's also a great place to picnic with your sweetheart. Just pick up a few surprises for lunch and head down to watch the views, boats and people go by.
review_content_20: I'll just start by saying that to rate the Inner Harbor as five stars is completely whacked simply because while there are certainly a lot of interesting (touristy to the extreme) elements at play here but underneath it all is a complete lack of substance which is why I rate the area as one of my favorite places to visit for a day or two but then after that I'm good for another few years.What's to like:  Well, the Orioles and Ravens being close by is alright, the B&O Railroad Museum is good if you can stomach the area that it's in, the historic ships are good, Federal Hill is a classic, Fort McHenry is legendary although not really in the Inner Harbor itself, Little Italy is a nice diversion and after that I'm stumped as to what else there really is that's worth while.What's not to like:  Chain shopping galore, absolute god-awful overpriced crap food at places like Hooters, Cheesecake Factory, The Hard Rock & Phillips for starters.  The transportation situation is a dumpster fire with certain parking decks and lots now approaching $30 for a day, the CCC is also wretched because even though it's free the buses run on a "loose schedule" that is completely unreliable to get you somewhere in a timely manner and the water taxi is huge ripoff in terms of price.I mean if you've never done it then by all means give it a once over but after that, meh, it's kind of a been there, done that type of thing.  There are only so many broken displays at the Science Center that you can stomach just like there are only so many unruly kids at The Aquarium that can be tolerated all while paying premium pricing for everything.I know that other Yelpers talk about this being a city of vital neighborhoods and that you should go out and see them to experience Baltimore fully but within the context of this Yelp listing that's irrelevant because this is solely about the Inner Harbor and to me if you're one of those Happy Idiots that Jackson Browne is talking about in his classic song "The Pretender" then I'm sure this area and all that is has to offer will do it for you but if you've got an IQ larger than a ping pong ball and you like things with more depth to them than a shallow puddle you'll see really quick that once is enough or that once every few years is more than enough to get your fill of the Times Squaresque tourist trap crap hole that is the Inner Harbor.Baltimore Inner Harbor Offers Much to Visitors!!!The Inner Harbor has a special Maryland charm to offer the visitors. It is important to note that there is so much to do with many different types of activities that it can keep a family or couple very busy with everyone content for more than a day. We flew in for a wedding and did not need a rental car. If we had known for sure that we would not be going outside the immediate area, a cab would have worked fine. There is minimal parking and what there is, is expensive. We just left the car in the hotel and walked everywhere. We had been there two days before we were made aware of the water taxis that take you from one location in the harbor to the other. Oh well, after eating the great foods and caloric crabs, we needed the walking. The entertainment in the plaza square was a treat. From magicians, to jugglers, etc., every time we walked by, there was some other group. Beside the Visitors Welcome Center there is a water splash park for the kids and the grass area, they offer various activities in the morning for anyone FREE. We actually got up and did Yoga from our hotel room at the Royal Sonesta Hotel. That was Pretty cool! The Inner Harbor is a TREAT for all ages.1. A variety of shops2. Great for boat lovers3. A place to visit for anyone new to BaltimoreThis is my first time visiting Baltimore and I have to say that I really didn't expect much from the city. I almost didn't even visit this harbor, but I'm certainly glad that my friend took me here! It's a nice place to visit for sure! Probably even better if it was a nice summer day. Then again, a nice summer day makes almost anywhere nice. Yes, but Baltimore's Inner Harbor has a variety of shops along the water. There are many food options. The ships make for nice photograph backgrounds. There's an aquarium that looked like it would also be fun to visit.There were serpent/dragon boats for expensive rides. There's also a mini lighthouse with a mini museum for your leisure browsing. The area is generally much larger than I expected, so you can easily spend an afternoon exploring. I heard the water is poisonous though, so don't touch it. (heavy chemical pollution).Very pretty area with lots of shops and eateries.It's nice how everything is in convenient walking distance and you can pretty much walk all around the harbor. This is definitely a major tourist zone. I was there is January so it was quite a bit quieter than I imagine compared to warmer months. All the boats were docked and the dragon boat operators were closed. No street performers. Most of the people who were visiting the inner harbor were families and some couples.There are plenty of things to do to keep you occupied for a weekend but be warned that only parking lot or garage parking is available so be prepared to pay some $$$.I did not like that this area is so over-run by chain stores and restaurants. Based on all the other reviews on yelp, those chain restaurants are all pretty bad. We ate at Paneras, Uno's and Five Guys during the 2 days I was there, totally because of convenience, and every meal tasted incredibly greasy and too salty. Unfortunate there aren't any good food options in this district.I'm not really sure that I can write a review for anything in Baltimore without revealing the fact that most of my experience with the actual city of Baltimore comes from watching copious episodes of The Wire, and thus my opinion in its entirety may be slightly tainted by way of television. However, as long as you're willing not to hold that against me, I will happily talk about the wonders of Inner Harbor at length!Inner Harbor really is a beautiful slice of the city to roam. I've been here many times, for many different reasons -- celebrating a friend's birthday at Fogo de Chau, shooting a wedding at the Renaissance Inner Harbor, and, most recently, taking another trip to the Baltimore Aquarium. It's always nice to walk around a bit, take in the sights, play on the super fun xylophone art installations, and marvel at the giant Hard Rock sign on the old power plant. There is lots of variety in businesses here, though you'll probably find the majority of them to be chains.Minus one star because parking here is pretty much a nightmare, with every single garage in the area (or at least the ones that are readily apparent to us non-locals) charging an arm and a leg and being the super awkward, billion-story high, curving kind with broken elevators. Also, driving around Inner Harbor can be confusing with its labyrinth of one-way streets and double-turn lanes. And don't even get me started on that one time I got stuck in my car trying to leave Inner Harbor for 2 hours because my dinner happened to end at the same time that an Orioles game got out. Reeeeeegardless, if you're a DC or NoVA native and you haven't yet taken a trip up to Balmer to explore Inner Habor, I do recommend scheduling a day to do so!I saved the Inner Harbor for my 700th review. I think the charm of the small city is evident here because this is what most people know when they think of Baltimore. Either that or its the scary Wire show scenes (just stay away from those areas). Before I highlight my favorite parts of the harbor, I have to say, you must venture out from it. The Inner Harbor is the touristy part of the city. Everyone that lives in the city doesn't really hang out at the Inner Harbor and there is a reason. Don't go to the chain restaurants. Try a local place. Try another neighborhood. Once you start to experience the culture you'll see that Baltimore has so much more to offer.So here is what I love.- Running around by Opera's condo (heard she has one in the Ponta's Villas but not sure :-)- Climbing Federal Hill to the flag and canons to see the view of when they protected the Inner Harbor back in the day- The skyline of the buildings- Watching the ducks sunbathe by the dock- Trying to speak and hear the sound bounce back from your friend over by the Science Museum- Watching the volleyball games during the summer- Shopping at Urban Outfitters- Having a drink or watching a Raven's game & being on TV as fans in Tir Na Nog- Going to the Aquarium- Watching the Christmas light show synchronized to music on the side of the Power Plant/Hard Rock Cafe bldg- Walking across the hanging bridge and feeling a little freaky cause it moves- Climbing the historic red light house- Looking at the iconic neon Domino Sugar lights across the water- Running towards Fell's Point and smelling the baking bread early in the morning- New Year's Eve fireworks - my favorite fireworks showAre you really going to give this mega-tourist attracting area a low rating?Of course not! Mainly because it's awesome. Also because it helps support our city.Between the independent street performers, the H&M, Urban Outfitters, the odds and ends of touristy shops, the ginormous (and beautifully designed) Barnes & Noble, the multitudes of generic (yet satisfying enough) restaurants, museums, the aquarium, and the boats, boats, boats, you've got yourself one successful location!Those who live in or around Baltimore really should take advantage of such a gem. Although there's so much more to the city than this, it's a great start for a weekend visit or a wonderful place to show off to visiting friends and family.Even though I'm a transplant that now considers herself a 'local', I still enjoy taking a stroll here. I'm also guilty of loving people-watching (a little too much). If you like either of those 2 things, then I'd suggest spending some time in one of Charm City's most popular destinations.Although the sights are pretty and there is a public restroom in the "mall", it is really a large tourist trap.  Please, vacationers, explore the real Baltimore outside of the Inner Harbor, it's not that bad. Really.  The restaurants are expensive and the food isn't that great (even the few non-chains).  I recommend taking a trek over to Federal Hill or even, if you have to stick in yuppy-ville, Fell's Point.  At least there is better offerings there.  I do admit, however, that Inner Harbor does at time offer some good people watching and the aquarium and science center are quite good.  It's just not a good representative of what the city is really like and yes, I think that is a bad thing.  I love Baltimore and have heard one too many people state that they wouldn't explore the city outside of the inner Harbor or Fell's Point which I think is rediculous.  So yes, visit the Inner Harbor.  It really is a must do when in Baltimore, but please don't let that be your main destination.if u ask the locals through inner Harbor is over priced and a tourist tap,  but I love it.  It is expensive so learn to use the water taxi and city bus to get around.Many decades ago, this was a blue collar harbor filled with crime. Then the clean up came.  Renovated harbor with lots of shops and restaurants, convention center, sport  stadiums for the Ravens and Orioles.  Sure changed the area.  It's now a safe clean place to visit.  It couldn't happen until the Inner Harbor changed first.  Glad it did  When I have friends visiting me, I always take them to Washington DC first, Annapolis next and Inner Harbor 3rd.  They like all the places.Nuts and bolts: I went once as a kid and now once as an adult. My how things have changed. I was so excited to show this off to boyfriend. After talking it up so much, it was rather disappointing when we got there. He said it was like a mini-mall. I remember all the local shops. And there was nice little food court. I remember my folks getting fresh seafood and one counter and my brother and I getting Chinese food. Man, memories.Verdict: Not what it used to be. Cool to have the ships around that you can take a tour of. Great architecture near by. Can sit and feed the birds. Or look into the water. As a kid, I remember staring at sting rays in the water. Loved it. Convenient mall across the street. I just don't want to spend as much time there as I expected to.Not sure what the big fuss is about here.  Maybe people have some low standards but here goes:The Inner Harbor is a great tourist spot, a good bit to see.  The main attraction is really because of its history and location on the water.  Also some retired ships are here that draws in all the tourists.  There are tons of restuarants and shops to visit. Pretty much everything is over priced due to tourism.  Inner Harbor is usually filled with screaming kids, out of towners who have no idea where anything is and stand in the middle of the intersection, rude cabbies that are looking to rip off tourists, the photo geek trying to get "that pic" at any cost, including standing in the middle of the road.  Also you'll find the occassional crab billy here - while living in the entire state his/her whole life; has never been to the Inner Harbor.  Parking is also a nightmare.  It averages out to around $7 for the first hour, then can go up to $16+  My TIP:  Park in little Italy and walk over.  It's not far.  Cut through the Pier 6 & 5 areas by going through the Columbus Square on President St.  From there it will place you directly in the middle of Inner Harbor.Also do not take the Water Taxi unless you plan on going to all the stops and visting the areas.  A one way ticket is $7 a person while an all day pass is $12.  It's mainly there as a tourist trap.  You'll never see any locals on it. The Aquarium is expensive, small, and old.  The Science Center usually has more current exhibits and attractions.  As of right now it's some sort of Mummy exhibit.I really enjoyed Baltimore's Inner Harbor. The atmosphere on a nice sunny day was priceless (Labor Day weekend). The Grand Prix of Baltimore was going on while I was visiting the harbor. The cars were racing through the street which was cool but loud. There are some tourist attractions, restaurants, shops, and fun thing to do at the harbor. If your plan on doing multiple tourist attractions, consider getting the harbor pass. The parking is a hassle around the harbor especially on a Saturday (some decks are expensive).  Baltimore's Inner Harbor is a great place to relax on a warm day.Great layout, plenty of entertainment options, clean public restrooms, and excellent water-oriented attractions. Downside is that the food selections are mostly chains.So a fun day out! Lots to do and a great selection of food to tryAbsolutely gorgeous & something for everyone! The views of the water & all the boating activity is really nice. Plenty of shopping and places to eat. Yes, there's the aquarium, which as others mentioned, it's pretty pricey.Parking in & around the Harbor can be pretty tricky & pricey, so keep that in mind when visiting.While there's plenty of places to get your money, it's also a good place just to walk (or run) around.I love Baltimore--and I really love the Inner Harbor.  Since my first visit here in the early 90s the area just gets better and better.  Yeah, I know...My love of the area is limited mostly to the area around the Inner Harbor and Fells Point, so no, I'm not a native and maybe I'm a bit of a tourist, but I still love coming here with the family..Like I said, I've always loved the Inner Harbor, but sadly my last visit was a bit disconcerting.  We walked through the shopping galleria today and it was so different than just over a year ago. No more Vaccaro's, no more Phillips, no more of a lot of places. Looked like they've either priced out the little guys or the little guys just gave up (not Phillip's, they moved over to the old ESPN Zone by the Power Plant). Very sad...especially the loss of Vaccarro's...they make the best cannoli-seriously, I've travelled to Baltimore on a day trip so we could have lunch and have a Vaccarro's cannoli.  The Inner Harbor lost a star simply because they lost or drove Vaccarro's away...very sad.  Thankfully they are still located over in Little Italy.The bars and restaurants in the Inner Harbor can be touristy, but who cares.  The food is good, the bars are great, the people are cool, and it isn't as expensive as some other east coast cities. Camden Yards, M&T Bank Stadium, the Baltimore Aquarium, great hotels and restaurants, and a great tourist await you around the Inner Harbor. Baltimore isn't everyone's first choice for a tourist visit on the east coast, but there is a TON to do here and it's been one of my favorite places to visit for a long time.  If you've never been to Baltimore...give it a shot.It is always fun to visit Inner Harbor in Baltimore, especially on good weather day. There is plenty to do - shop, eat, and enjoy the arts. They generally have a good band playing or other good performance going on at the harbor.The boat rentals are good too - to get my thigh muscles some workout :)The Aquarium is one of my favorite aquariums but be prepared to shell out some $$$The restaurants at the old Power Plant have a good party like atmosphere going all summer long!Parking can be a pain - too few street spots and parking garages are expensive!Nice place to spend a good day with family and friends!We were only in Batimore for a day, and after the disappointment of Poe's house, a cop directed us to come here, and boy are we glad to have come here. I definitely enjoy the obvious fact that this place is SAFE. haha. However, I have visited some areas and this place is nothing THAT impressive. I mean, the stores and restaurants they have around here is so generic and nothing too exciting. All in all, not bad.The Inner Harbor is really the only area I like to hangout n Baltimore, MD.  Plenty of restaurants and attractions to spend the day.  Must visit the National Aquarium and ride the ferry before leaving the Inner Harbor.
review_content_40: Great place for food drinks and fun.  There is a lot of energy and excitement there but still room to roam.  Take a walk around the whole harbor.  The brick sidewalk will give you amazing views of the downtown area and some space to relax away from the crowds.  It is a bit of a tourist trap but the prices for most things are surprisingly reasonable and comparable to any big city.Been coming here since I was little. The Harbor was always beautiful, but has drastically developed ! So many restaurants to choose from, places to shop ! I can't complain.Use to live in Baltimore for 3 years. I've been to the Inner Harbor countless times each being it's own unique experience. There's just so many things to do like visiting one of the 10+ museums, famous ships, dine at any dozens of restaurants, shop at any dozens of stores, or check out the many attractions in this major U.S. seaport. It can be quite romantic to walk around the harbor with your companion, catch a street performer at night entertain you and dozens of other onlookers while also being a fun place to take the family. Kids love going to the IH since there's big ships and subs to explore, exotic animals to see in one of the best aquariums in the country, spend an afternoon on the water with their dads in a dragon paddle boat, or walk a short distance to a professional baseball or football game.Getting from one place to another is easy whether you're walking, paying a small fee to catch a water taxi, or hopping a free ride on the Charm City Circulator (bus). Many hotels that are within walking distance. There is something to do for every age group.Lots to do here, for adults and kids. Port Discovery, Power Plant, Science Center, tons of restaurants, Aquarium...the list goes on and on. Some places are a bit pricey, but fun. Great comedy shows and the comedy factory in the power plant. Great food at Phillips. And the scenery can't be beat. Parking is plentiful, but pricey. My tip would be to see if any of the places you are visiting validate parking for a cheaper price. For example, if you are going to the science center or on a harbor cruise, park at Arrow garage on East Lee St. The science due center or harbor cruise will give you a voucher for a $9 flat rate at arrow. Saved us $9, because the amount of time we parked, we would have paid $18. Note: arrow garage takes cash only!Before going to this Harbor area, I was expecting this area to be crowded with people with and be disorganized, and with the temperatures in the area reaching near 100 degrees Farenheit, I was expecting humid conditions.  However, what I didn't factor into the equation, was the factor of cooler air coming off the Harbor water.  I absolutely loved looking back at the city from the edges of the cooler area nearby.  It just seemed so serene by the time I got away from here, that I wanted to go back and try again.  But the more I tried to go, the more worried I'd would have become addicted to this Harbor area.  It is so beautiful.However, most of the area around the Harbor, is shopping malls and buildings.  Not many non-shopping areas exist on the Inner Harbor area's landscape. Between all the lively people and events who meet here and all the lovely buildings, makes for one enjoyable afternoon.  A big retreat for me, if I ever find myself going back to the area.First off, I have lived around here my entire life. The inner harbor is alright of course i have been to all the attractions. The bums that stroll around asking people for money are rude and annoying, especially when you refuse. The aquarium has always been good, but the prices for attractions and parking keep me away today, not to mention the ambiance of the people who usually make up the majority. The food establishments are junk and over priced. The surveillance and police presents though necessary for the out of control youths is a bit much for a relaxed atmosphere. Today it more resembles a third world nation, not exactly what i would call fun...Populated with chain stores and restaruants by the water front; lots of things to do and option to eat. Happy place to relax, enjoy the weekends. So why drugged yourself to go to DC when Baltimoreans have its own.My favorite spot in America that tourists also like to visit. So indicative of Baltimore, though I think all of the city is amazing. There to be seen is the National Aquarium, Maryland Science Center, various-aged ships you can tour, the huge Hard Rock Cafe sign, World Trade Center, paddleboats in the harbor, the shops & eateries in Harborplace, restaurants like Phillip's, Bubba Gump, Tir Na Nog Irish, M&S Grill, Ruth's Chris & Edo Sushi, Federal Hill, the Water Taxi & plenty more. It always perks me up to go there.Baltimore's Inner Harbor is very picturesque and gorgeous area to go running; I've been working up to 3 miles, mostly downhill from Mount Vernon. On some days I'll get distracted by the Harbor Gallery Mall; Coach, Francesca's, and Aldos call out, and I'm very drawn to Urban Outfitters and H&M as well (H&M sports European sizes which works great for me). I'll cruise by the Inner Harbor on the way to Harbor East and Fell's Point; The USS Constellation, USCGC Taney, and USS Torsk have become familiar friends; the street performers are always fun as well :)Always have a nice time in the Inner Harbor shops. I do miss the Phillips buffet but the McCormick spice shop is a welcome addition.Tourist trap, yes.Beautiful scenery, yes.Lots of restaurants and shops, yes.Easy to maneuver with access to taxis, main thoroughfares and public transportation, yes!While I only visited Baltimore for a short while, this was a beautiful area to walk around. Able to see the harbor, World Trade Center of Baltimore, lots of shops and restaurants to choose and browse from.I feel like this is a convenient tourist/visitor location because it is convenient to shopping, Camden Yards, museums, restaurants and hotels. Lots of great spots like the Capital Grille and Phillip's are nearby...in addition to staples like Panera, Chipotle, etc...There seems to be something for everyone...and what a spectacular view!The inner harbor is pretty boring. I wasn't impressed. I took a trip to Baltimore when I visited DC. My friend was like "why are you going there? It is ghetto." Yea, I now agree after I went.Admiral Ackbar: "It's a trap! A tourist trap!"It might be a tourist trap, but it is a pretty cool place to go during the Spring and Summer while you are in Baltimore.There are a slew of restaurants all around the Inner Harbor, my favorites being Lenny's and the Rusty Scupper, but even if you don't go down for the food there are a ton of things to do to keep yourself occupied.Here are some of the highlights, which everyone should check out on any given trip to the Inner Harbor:Aquarium - pricey, but hours of exploringScience Center - not as pricey, hours of funTorsk Tour - cheap; for history buffsFederal Hill - free exercisePaddle/Electric Boats - go with the electric if lazy (like me!)People Watching - free and hours of entertainment (watch out for the Mennonites trying to get you to give up all of your money)Things to watch out for:Expensive parkingLONG lines at Cheesecake FactoryBaltimore thuggery & thieveryYou can spend an entire day at the Inner Harbor, if you have enough money, that is.  Many of the major to dos are located here - the only pay attraction we took part in was the aquarium (see separate review).  But there's plenty of other things to take your money - touring the submarine or the USS Constellation, the chinese drag paddle boats, the big fancy speed boats or cruises, plenty of shops & restaurants, etc.  We enjoyed just walking around, looking at the boats & people watching.  Yes, it is crowded and I'm sure the stores & restaurants are overpriced, but hey, it is tourist land.  You can easily catch transportation from here to see the rest of town (via the CCC, public buses, taxis, water taxi, etc).Even if you don't go to any of the museums or restaurants scattered around the Inner Harbor, it's a nice place to just walk about and take in the sights.  It was overcast and a cold day so the Inner Harbor looked so dreary but I'm sure during the summer it comes alive with the paddle boats and more additional tourists.We didn't take advantage of any of the museums for the simple reason of cost and that Saturdays are usually crowds of people with their kids.  My patience and the patience of my husband probably would have been severely challenged.Early morning's the best time to enjoy Baltimore's Inner Harbor. Preferably a clear day at sunrise. Well before 10am when Harborplace and the Gallery open for business and generate the hubbub. I enjoy the peace when hardly anyone's home. Just a couple joggers infiltrating from Federal Hill bouncing about the promenade, old folks hand in hand on morning constitutionals, gulls finding treasure in trash bins overflowed by last night's restaurant goers and shopaholics at Light St Pavilion. But it's still just me on a bench by Baltimore Visitor's Center eyeing fancy yachts tied to docks bobbing on the same serene waters as the historically significant USS Constellation, and sunlight separated by the 30 story World Trade Center and it's Top of the World observation area as I recall the region's largest New Years Eve fireworks extravaganza exploded from barges. An event drawing an insanely huge crowd. A lesser midday every day crowd gets entertained by street musicians strumming for their supper at Harborplace Amphitheater as a parade of school buses bring children to nearby National Aquarium's dolphin show and indoor Amazon rainforest. But early morning's still the best time to enjoy Baltimore's Inner Harbor. After 10am area hotels spit out guests for their daily tourists' takeover of the promenade and manic explorations of Harborplace's brasseries & boutiques. Much intimacy's lost. Sure I could shop 'til I drop like the rest. Been there, done that. Baltimore's Inner Harbor's backdrop of Harborplace and the Gallery's built to beckon. But I'd rather enjoy the early morning's soothing sights and sounds. They're necessary and they're free.Like others have said it is a tourist trap but it's such a nice place to hangout during the summer. From all the little shops in Harbor Place were you can grab some Baltimore souvenirs. (I collect shot glasses from everywhere I've been.) Tons of restaurants like The Cheesecake Factory, Five Guy's, Phillips Seafood, M & S Grill and the famous Vaccaro's Italian Pastries.With a volley ball court with sand, the National Aquarium, Science Center, Power Plant Live and Port Discovery in the area there are plenty of attractions. Go up to the park in Federal Hill for great shots of the harbor. Be sure to rent one of the little boats and ride around the harbor. Don't get the paddle boat like we did. Pay the extra money and get the powered boat. I got a horrible cramp in my calves! I haven't worked those muscles since before my daughter was born!A favorite place in the summer. Lots of great shops and restaurants. Sitting on the crab deck at Phillips enjoying steamed blue crabs. I recommend taking a water taxi around the harbor to Fell's Point!On a nice sunny day this a great place to be which frankly didn't used to be true at all.  This was the last place anyone would want to go.  However, those days have passed into a faded memory and has become the tourist hot spot it is today.  There are an assortment of shops, restaurants and activities available if you want to do more than catch the view.  There are paddle boats and actual boats to keep people of any age entertained should they feel so inclined to get on the water.  I like that there are so many things to do in one area and that a couple of my favorite stores are there as well.  It tends to lean on the pricier side, especially if you are considering dining.  Don't be afraid to walk a couple of blocks away to find some of Baltimore's dining gems.I am in no way a harbor / port groupie, but the Inner Harbor is much better than the Seaport in New York City, Penn's Landing in Philadelphia, Old Port in Montreal, etc.  There is plenty of things to do and the area is full of museums, an aquarium, chain restaurants (The Cheesecake Factory, ESPNZone, Hard Rock, Hooters, PF Chang's), historical ships, amazing views from Federal Hill Park, and 2 nearby sporting venues: Camden Yards (Orioles) and M&T Bank Stadium (Ravens).  In the words of Denzel, "King Kong ain't got nothing on them!"
review_content_60: Definitely a unique, one-of-a-kind area. I love visiting here on my way through Balitmore. This past Labor Day weekend it was packed full of people and the weather was absolutely beautiful. Lots of things to do and places to eat.If you are staying overnight at a hotel nearby, try priceline. It's a gamble but it paid off well for us. We landed really cheap rooms at the Renaissance, and although we could have paid an extra $40 or so for harbor view rooms we decided to save the money for food.We hung out at the harbor for the 4th weekend. We had a great time. There are a lot of things to do. We hit the dragon boat in the middle of the harbor. We wanted to catch the taxi boat but never made it to it. We walked everywhere as you definitely need to bring your tennis shoes. Everything is in good walking distance from the hotels near the harbor. The fireworks were great. The ones at the harbor need some work. They only went halfway in the air... yea!! They had two going at the same time. The other firework show was out in the actual harbor away from the shops. This one was the best. The only thing was they had 2 displays going on at the same time. I thought I was watching a tennis match. We stood near McCormick and Schmidt restaurant. We were able to watch both of them and had a great view. We visited the Ripley's believe it or not, the national aquarium, the galleria mall and checked out many of the restaurants in the area. We had a great time. The harbor needs to step it up on the shops. There are more eateries then shops which takes away from being there for the tourist. We had a great time all in all. The weather was the bomb.... yes. The breeze was flowing every day we were there. The sun was definitely out but we had the breeze blowing therefore, it made it much better. The area itself was family friendly and safe. Now on our way out we drove through some other areas of b-more. OMG... stay close to the harbor. If you go over too many blocks you definitely see a different look. :-)Really a beautiful area in downtown Baltimore. However, it is in no way representative of the tough city that Baltimore is. Drive down Fayette, Vine, or Fremont streets and you will recognize very quickly that the IH is an over-touristy place that is totally disconnected from Real Baltimore life.Lots of chain food places, hotels, a science center, an aquarium, a few museums, a convention center, and two sports stadiumd. But what do you really expect? It is the tourist spot in Baltimore. That being said, it really is a nice little area, very pretty, and fun to walk around when the weather is nice. Yes, it can be a little sketchy, but compared to other parts of Baltimore you shouldn't really complain. Also, this place is a pain in the butt to drive through, no matter what time of the day it is.There's a lot do do here and everyone should be able to find something they like. For starters you have the big tourist attractions like the National Aquarium, Port Discovery, the USS Constellation and many others. They are open year around and are all kid friendly. There's plenty of shopping if that's your thing. The most obvious is The Gallery. (It's a 4 story mall) and there are all kinds of places scattered about to pick up souvenirs to.Want to party? You'll probably want to head over to the Power Plant Live. Restaurant Row...etc... It can get crazy... You've been warned. :) There's also an ESPN Zone, Hard Rock Cafe, etc. Stay in one of the hotels around the waterfront or just come into town and make a day of it. The options are endless and the experience is whatever you decide to make of it.Visiting the Baltimore Harbor isn't that great.  First of all parking is very expensive in the area and the parking lot pricing system is often very hard to see while driving by.  The range and parking fees varies but seems to average around $15-$19 in the blocks around the harbor although if you get your car Valet parked at a hotel expect to pay at least $30.  The attractions around the harbor are mainly tourist trap type stores.  There are some museums to visit and of course the aquarium.  One thing that made me not give it one star was that they are trying to create a little area of marshland for birds.  That showed some innovation but overall the area was pretty touristy.  Outside the aquarium they are also doing a few other things like having a little bit of wooded area and a little waterfall where birds take baths.  The one thing that bothered me about the inner Harbor where the amount of shady looking individuals hanging around some of which look like they were up to no good.  I definitely recommend watching your purse or bag because I'm sure that there is some amount of theft going on.  As far as I can see it is worth a visit but probably not a repeat visit.  Baltimore really Needs to fix up it's downtown area.  It's interesting how the streets near the harbor and downtown are pretty vacant and when you get to the harbor  there are lots of tourists.If you're just breezing through B-more and want a one-stop tourist haven, the Inner Harbor is it.  Let's see... Aquarium.Maritime museum with a submarine, Coast Guard ship, and frigate.Enclosed mega-mall replete with cookie-cutter shops and eateries.Hands-on museum with IMAX theater.Paddle-boats.Harbor taxi.Tourist fly-paper extraordinaire!Go for: the National Aquarium, the Baltimore Maritime Museum, the Maryland Science Center, and the lovely views as your stroll around the harbor.  All well worth a stop at the Inner Harbor.  Despite its trappishness, this *is* a place you should check out at some point.Otherwise, it's a pretty sterile Baltimore experience.  This is a vital city of neighborhoods, and truly to experience all it has to offer means getting out and exploring them.A great place to step outside and walk around. They've really cleaned this area up, although at night, be careful. Very much more expensive than the area should be, but plenty of parking on the edges, boats to watch and paddle on the water with, food and restaurants in the area, and plenty of expensive hotels.At least there are plenty of police in unmarked cars sitting all around, and there are the couples walking around, the Water Taxis in the day, and the tourists, too.The Aquarium, USS Constellation, Sugar Factory and more lie along its edge, plus the visitor's center and Science Center.4.5 stars...Yes it's touristy, a little bit more expensive then it probably should be, and has more chain stores then would be ideal, but the Inner Harbor is great. It's clean, safe, beautiful, with plenty to do, see, and eat. They've got lots of little shops, the National Aquarium, the USS Constellation, the USS Torsk submarine, the Seven Foot Knoll Lighthouse and the Inner Harbor is an easy walk to Camden Yards (where the Oriole and Raven's stadiums are) and Federal Hill. It's also a decent walk to Fells Point. Its centralized location alone makes Inner Harbor great. If you've never been to Baltimore start by exploring the Inner Harbor first and go out from there.super cool place to chill on a spring or summer day.  so much to see and do during the day time.  tourist place? id say so.  but im a tourist so woohoo! restaurants like cheesecake factory, uno grill, dicks last resort, hard rock cafe.  paddle boat rides for $11 for up to 4 people.  umm AQUARIUM! second biggest in the country. barnes and noble.  a few shops like h&m and urban outfitters.  then the gallery is right across the street.  street performers doing their thang (juggling on unsteady things). this place is a lot safer than downtown baltimore.  id say that for sure.  maybe the safest area of the whole city? this is where you bring you family on a nice weekend. just take the orange circular!Do yourself a favor and spend a weekend in the Inner Harbor. I highly recommend booking a hotel in the area, so that you can walk everywhere and see all the amazing things Bmore has to offer!As a Baltimore native I can say that the Inner Harbor has changed quite a bit... and for the better (in my opinion). I'm not sure why my fellow Yelpers would be upset that it has become too commercialized because the new developments helped clean everything up. When I was a child my grandparents used to take me down here very often. I attended one of the very first games ever played at Camden Yards and I saw one of the first even IMAX films at the Maryland Science Center. It was always a little dirty and now most of that has changed. I like the Inner Harbor and the hotels are reflective of how desired the neighborhood has become. My grandmother tells stories of when she used to come down and see drunken bums fall into the water. review_content_80: I used to leave work early, if I was having a stressful day and take the MARC to sit by the water and watch the activity.I love the harbor, I can't stress that enough.  It's dated, but that really adds to the charm.I have a routine.  I get a chicken dinner from the Chicken Shack, and sit outside and people watch.  Heaven.  It's the main reason I'm relocating to Baltimore.  So that I can visit anytime I want...Described by the Urban Land Institute in 2009 as "the model for post-industrial waterfront redevelopment around the World.",the Inner Harbor is the gem in the crown of Baltimore tourism. But like any other crown only the king gets to wear it.  Paid for by tax payers and profited by private groups, the Inner Harbor was Baltimore's all out gamble in the 70's and 80's to bring tourists back to the city.  It worked...for the tourists and those who turn a profit from the Inner Harbor.  Whenever I have out of town guests visit I take them to the Inner Harbor on day 1 to show them the clean post card part of Baltimore, the side of our town that the city council wants tourists to see.  The rest of their stay is spent back in the neighborhood because that's where Baltimore lives and plays, eats and drinks.  In this way the Inner Harbor works for me much like Power Plant Live works for me: by penning all the tourists up in one central location and ensuring that I can still get a bar stool at my favorite corner bar in the hood.What's not to like here? You have a great view a chill place to relax and just 'be' as well as some store to shop and you're foot steps away from anywhere you'd want to be in downtown Baltimore.Nice area - very pretty and calm at night. Everything's pretty expensive (we're talking close to NY prices) but there are lots of places where you can rent paddle boats and go on short cruises and such. The surrounding buildings are all malls, shopping places, food places, aquariums, hotels, etc. Just be careful late at night because it's still a city and some of the surrounding sidewalks are under construction so it can look a tad shady.Not a huge fan of the Inner Harbor.  I really feel like that if I lived in Baltimore/the area, I would absolutely hate this place.  It's nothing more than a small harbor with a ton of different chain restaurants/cheesy stores.  Don't get me wrong, I do like some of the chain restaurants that are there, but I kind of wish this place was more a representation of the city of Baltimore and not just one big tourist trap.  If I lived in Baltimore, I couldn't see how I would ever come down and check this place out.  I guess I would only come here if I had guests visiting and they wanted to visit it.  As for the restaurants - like I said earlier, lots of chains (Hooters, Uno, Cheesecake Factory and a bunch of others).  I don't think every restaurant here is a chain but definitely a good portion.  There are also a number of stores - I remember an H&M and a bunch of total tourist trap type places.  There used to be an ESPN zone here but now that's gone.  It's still a fine place to go down and walk around on a nice day, but I certainly wouldn't make this the main destination of any trip.  On the plus side, there are plenty of places to go for a drink - most of them get pretty packed, though.  Most of the restaurants do have a pretty good view of the harbor.The Inner Harbor is really what is Spearheading (that's a fancy government term that leads to more promotion credit) the transformation in Baltimore.  Yes, it can be a tourist trap, and I don't believe us locals actually eat there, but it is a great environment with lots to do.  Countless restaurants for people to pig out at (the American past time), but they are a little pricier than in the neighborhoods of Baltimore.  Lots of activities you can accomplish (Science Museum, Paddle Boats, Water Taxi, Aquarium, etc...), and even some sporting events with the Volleyball courts, and probably the best area around for jogging (or is it pronounced yogging?  Might be a soft J).  I am a huge fan of the Inner Harbor, and it is what is connecting the city, and leading the way for Baltimore to be a safe and friendly city.  If all you have heard about Baltimore is from the Wire, it's time to change your opinion and spend some safe quality time at the Harbor!Yes, this is a tourist trap - but its a great place to go and do some local shopping and eat at the water front restaurants.  The harbor area is very clean, safe and extremely friendly.  Every person I interacted with from wait staff, to employees at the stores to the police on the street were so friendly and helpful.  Where else do you have a police officer actualy stop you and ask if you are enjoying yourself?  Certainly not where I come from.. So enjoy this beautiful part of Charm City.. they have truly earned their name from the friendly experience I had.We went to Inner Harbor on a Thursday afternoon when it was very hot and humid.   Due to construction it was very hard to find a parking.  We parked by Rusty Scupper and walked all the way around.   The area was very clean.   The place was very quiet and empty.   It was an okay place to visit but nothing special.Nice. Lots to do lots to see.Maybe this was great before the 'boom, but any local flavor has been sucked away by the walls of hotels surrounding the harbor and the chain food restaurants within.  Even the rare relic (U.S. Constellation) is so faked out & commercialized (c'mon, plastic cannons in front?!) that my two boys didn't want to go in!!The aquarium is pretty nice, although the dolphin show kinda sucked and it was wicked expensive.There are cool things in Baltimore.  You'll just have to look for them.My bike got stolen at the Inner Harbor  today around 4pm. I left it attached with a cable lock to the bike rack outside Barnes & Noble, in a matter of 45 minutes, the time I spent in the bookstore, my bike was stolen. Such a disgrace I will never trust leaving a bike anywhere in the city. Beware of the thieves!!!Touristy, sure - but unlike many other areas in Baltimore it felt safe to walk around.  The aquarium is great, the stores nice, and the greenspace plentiful.  Parking prices are a bit excessive in the area, but I guess that is to be expected.The Inner Harbor is my favorite part of Baltimore City.  Sure, there are a lot of places in Baltimore that are very cool, but they're sprinkled randomly throughout the city and there are scary people between these interesting points.  And if you're scared of crackheads and other crazies, like I am, then you'll do best to stick to the three to four block radius of the Inner Harbor, lest you be snatched up and taken into a secret world of crackeries.  The aquarium is very expensive, I can't say it's worth it, either.  Maybe if you're bringing kids, they'll somehow enjoy it more than you will.  The Science center is very cool.  My favorite is the ESPN zone, because I'm a big kid at heart.  It's just a great place to walk around, maybe do a little shopping, paddle boating, etc.  Again, though, if you wander too far from the Inner Harbor and the sun is setting, you better get back home soon!  I mean it!Always a good time!My husband brought me here when I first moved to Maryland. It's actually just about the only part of the city that he's familiar with. We just went back with an out-of-town guest and she commented how clean the Inner Harbor area is, which is actually a reminder to myself San Francisco is really trashy. Inner Harbor is very tourist-oriented but it's good for a day trip for guests. On the other hand, I'd really like to explore more of the city based on my positive experience in the Inner Harbor.

hotel_name: Days Inn Baltimore Inner Harbor Hotel
review_content: When I first saw the price of this hotel, I was skeptical at best, but I went for it as I just needed a bed for a few nights. I'm happy to say that this Days Inn far exceeded all of my expectations. The front desk staff were nothing short of a joy to work with. They answered all my questions and finished my check in process as fast as possible, which was very much appreciated. I was absolutely shocked at how nice the room was. My travel partner and I booked a single (king size) bed room, and the room was big enough for probably four or five people comfortably. The bed was absolutely huge, not to mention very comfy. The room also was equipped with a couch, coffee table, microwave, fridge, desk, chair, large flat screen TV, and spacious bathroom.The hotel is only blocks away from Camden Yards and the Inner Harbor, which I absolutely loved. Another plus of the hotel is the attached restaurant. I'm usually skeptical of attached restaurants. I ate breakfast one morning there and it was hot, delicious,  and very affordable. The breakfast was buffet style and run by hotel employees. I can't speak more highly of the restaurant staff. Everyone, our waiter included, was exceptionally nice. If they didn't have something on the buffet that you wanted, they would happily make it for you at no extra charge, if possible. (I especially enjoyed the french toast sticks, which were some of the best I've never had.) The only negative aspect to the hotel, is parking. Parking is a little pricey, but the hotel does not own the parking garage. All things considered, however, I suppose expensive parking is to be expected in the city.I had a pleasant stay here during a busy conference weekend. The staff is friendly and the rooms are clean, homey, and comfy.I flew in from a red eye and was hoping for a very early checkin, and I got it! The only room available was one on the first floor next to the employee rooms and business center (so at times, it got quite noisy outside), but it wasn't too bothersome. I'm just grateful to get a quick nap before the day started.The staff was really helpful in showing me around the area (on a map of course) and also helping me retrieve my bags from the hold room multiple times.Wifi is free and hassle free! It's right next to the convention center and super close to Camden Yards and public transportation. It's also a few blocks walk from Edgar Allan Poe's grave and Lexington Market. It's about a $10 cab ride to Fell's Point, although I hear public transportation is a better option.I was in town for some interviews recently and picked this hotel because of its proximity to one of my interviews. I love walking and this hotel is situated perfectly in a great location downtown - it is a mere couple of blocks from UMMC and about a mile or so from Johns Hopkins Metro. The staff at the front desk were very kind and helpful. The only thing that made me raise an eyebrow was an immediate charge of $60 (was there three nights) for "incidentals." Hmmmm...I just got there - how could I already have incidentals? No worries, though - it was never charged to my card, as it was just a fund hold. No problem with that.The room was spotless. Great view of the parking structure (again, no worries). A little loud at night, as I flew out very, very early on Saturday morning. Nice amenities - very clean room and very little noise given that I was on the 2nd floor. I would definitely stay here again or recommend it to someone coming into town.We have been here twice now. How to rate a hotel? Well, the staff is extremely friendly. One man at the front desk (wish I had got his name) will brighten your stay with his cheerful attitude.There is also public parking connected to the hotel, very nice. It's $28 a day though. Perhaps most importantly, is the location. Mickey Mouse always told me of the importance of location, location, location, amd this hotel is literally a 5 minute walk to Camden Yards, and 10 minutes to Inner Harbor. Can't beat that. The rooms are large, comfortable, and clean, with a  great king sized bed, and hallelujah free wifi. Reasonably priced, too, so even with the parking, it's a good deal.Great hotel.  Great location.  Greeted by Gerald whom I swear may be the nicest most helpful employee of any company I've ever met.     Recommend this hotel to anyone staying in Baltimore.  Especially if you need quick access to convention center or Camden yards area.The Days Inn is a coveted hotel for veteran Otakon attendees. This is due to their great rates, amenities, location and polite/helpful staff. We've stayed here twice, once in 2010 and again this past July. Overall our stay was very nice. Office staff are very welcoming of convention attendees and are quick to address any issues we may have. We had an issue with the card the room was booked on but the staff did their best to fix the issue. (the wrong card was charged) After a few phone calls and a bit of a wait everything went through fine. Had another issue with some shady characters lurking around the garage and pool area but the staff quickly called security and they were escorted away. Nothing more than scam artists but the staff's professionalism when dealing with them was greatly appreciated.Rooms are pretty basic but come with a mini fridge, free wifi and microwave which are nice to have and the pool is a decent size for relaxing. Hotel is a short 5 min walk to the BCC which is wonderful when you're in full cosplay attire. Parking is attached in the garage next door and rates are around $30 a day. Overall a nice place to stay if you're on a budget.Stayed here while attending a conference. Room service wasn't great, they didn't clean thoroughly. But also, on 11/7, a Saturday there was construction at the roof which started at 5 am, and woke me up. I called the front desk about this, they were aware, but the construction and extreme noise continued. It was ridiculous. I can't imagine of something that couldn't wait an hour or two to be repaired.I have booked 2 rooms for me and my friends and used only one room for couple hours. Had emergency and had to leave early. Haven't touch anything in second room. I asked staff and management if they can get at least partial refund for unused room, and answer was no. Also they gave wrong pricing for room and parking over the phone. So I've spent more then $400 within hour and half, and couldn't get anything back.Thank you Days Inn, you will never see me or my friends in your hotels anymore.Stayed here one night for Baltimore Comic Con. Great rate, great location. Parking garage is attached to the hotel which is very convenient. Hotel lobby was very clean and welcoming. The front desk staff are friendly and efficient. Check-in was very fast and they had my room ready at 9:30AM. I stayed in a standard 2 double bed room. Room was immaculate. Linens were clean and fresh. The room also has a microwave and a mini fridge and freezer. The sink is outside of the bathroom, which is great when more than one person needs to get ready in the morning. I ordered a pizza for dinner and the front desk called to confirm that I ordered it before they let the guy come up. I felt like this was very nice thing to do, especially as a female travelling without a male companion. The location is extremely convenient for both the convention center and the Inner Harbor. I would stay here again in a heartbeat.Had a bit of a rocky check in due to a glitch with Expedia however the hotel staff fixed it immediately.  The staff were all very nice and stopped to ask how your day was.We ate in the bar on site.  It is small but nice and quiet.  Perfect for a late evening cocktail.Great location if you have to be at the Baltimore Conference Center.  Perfectly adequate rooms and service, EXCEPT when sewage water started spewing out my sink the night shift concierge told me "Maintenance isn't in yet." When I told him it was something he should not disregard he told me he would leave them a note. When I returned and told him the situation was urgent, as the sink was overflowing and soaking the floor, he begrudgingly put down his cell phone a brought me a garbage pail. While attending to my room both he, and later, the maintenance guy complained about how gross it was and no one apologized or offered to relocate me.  Rude!When I heard the price of the room I was prepared for the worst, but I was so wrong. Everything is clean, the room is big with a working fridge and microwave, and its just across the street from all the action. Love it! (Security people are little sketchy which is why I took a star off)I've stayed at Days Inns since I was knee high to a grasshopper...well a long time. They were always roadside stops on long trips. Basic room and bed . I recently had a business trip to Baltimore and wanted cheap. I found it at The Days Inn Inner Harbor. For what I paid I wasn't expecting much! Well was I ever disappointed in my expectations. This place was gorgeously opulent. I'd give it A 5 Star rating, Immaculate, modern and a short walk from all the attractions of the Inner Harbor! Staff was top notch. went back the next week to stay again. This place is a great budget extender for a quick weekend away with the wife, kids if you must and they even take pets! WHAT A JOY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Pretty decent hotel. Very convenient location to everything around the Inner Harbor. The rooms are pretty simple and the bed was ok at best.This was the least expensive hotel I could find in the Inner Harbor. Once I booked the room, my card was charged and it was non-refundable so be careful! Everyone at the concierge desk was really friendly and helpful. They took our phone number to call us when the casino shuttle was coming, which goes to and from the Horseshoe casino every half hour. We forgot some toiletries and Gerald was kind enough to give us a whole bag of all sorts of stuff. Our room had a funny smell to it, but I think it was just the air conditioning.Exceptionally friendly staff (especially Gerald) at the front desk.  Clean and great location.  Would stay again.Charged my CC full amount after previously paying in full. Took over a week to get corrected.  But the real issue was the elevators. Holy god, slower that watching molasses drip from the 80th floor of the Sears tower. If you are unable to walk up the stairs, I don't suggest staying here. Otherwise, when you check in, hit the ^ up button on elevator, go grab dinner somewhere in the inner harbor, and by the time you finish and get back, the door may be opening.The place I was supposed to stay at while I was in Baltimore for a few days fell through the last minute (literally about 15 mins before arriving there) so I had to make a last minute reservation at a hotel that was going to be close enough to the Baltimore Convention Center that fit within my budget and had a parking garage. Thanks goodness for Days Inn!I made the reservation 10 mins before checking in and was able to find the room for fairly cheap at $62/night + taxes and it was 4 mins walking distance from the convention center. Parking all day was $25/day which is more than the other hotels but when figuring out the total cost, it was still much cheaper to stay here than the Hilton (across the street) and the other hotels in the 2 block radius.The hotel itself seemed to be going under renovations so it was a little messy but it wasn't that bad. The hotel itself, in comparison to the other hotels in the area, is tiny. It almost has that middle of nowhere (not that Baltimore is anywhere... ZING!) feel to it. The room was spacious enough and the bed comfy. I got 4 pillows all to myself and it was awesome. The toilet and shower looked clean and updated. I had the view of the parking lot but I didn't get the room for the view. I was able to see my car parked in the garage on the second floor.I always forget my toothbrush when I'm traveling so when I went down to ask for one from the front desk, I was really surprised at the quality of the toothbrush I got. Made my bleeding gums happy.Even though there were a few things that bothered me, this has got to be one of the first hotels I've stayed in America in a very long time that I went away satisfied with it.A few things that were a bit bothersome to me.- I didn't bother turning the air on because that machine is one loud mother (I'm a light sleeper)- The fridge, also made a little noise but it wasn't that badIf I ever have to stay in a hotel in Baltimore again (and that's a huge "if"), I'd stay here in a heart beat.Parking: $25/dayI was looking for a place to stay after an Orioles game during the week and this hotel was exactly what I needed for the night. It was not your typical Days Inn, it was a step up from the typical motel-like places they usually are.After researching online the possible places that were within walking distance to the game, the Days Inn was the best deal. It was around $120 for the night for two beds and was about one block away from the center field gates at Camden Yards. We came into town on the light rail from Penn Station and the Camden Yards stop is across the street from the hotel. In fact we flew out very early the following day and we hopped on the light rail again that brought us to the airport. After check in we walked down to the the inner harbor area to check out the city itself, which was about a ten minute walk.I highly recommend staying here if you are looking to spend the night after a game in a clean and comfortable hotel. BTW The air conditioner in our room worked great! Really important for June/July in Baltimore.Check in was easy. A lot of people were checking in, and they had 2 people at the front desk. They have a parking deck, and it is $28 per night, paid at the hotel. We received a ticket, so we could come and go. We were on the 7th floor, but the elevators were really slow. The hotel was sold out, which I don't think would have been a problem, but many of the rooms in our hotel had many many people staying in them. When we were checking out, we heard someone say they had 8 people in their room!?! This made the hallways, and the common areas miserable to negotiate.
