Someone kept trying to put his card in our door, which was scary and annoying. The room was good size, and the bed was comfortable. It was the on the edge of the inner harbor. It was a few more blocks then what I expected, but within walking distance. Search for a good rate. and enjoy!
review_content_20: I must say, I was surprisingly impressed. This past summer, at the last minute, I moved my daughter & me from D.C. to the Inner Harbor & this was the most reasonably priced place that wasn't booked for that weekend. When we arrived, the staff was jovial and welcoming. We were allowed an earlier check-in & our room was expertly decorated & comfortable. The ambiance of the hotel was satisfactory & the overall structure of the hotel was visually appealing. We were within a minutes' walk to all the activities and establishments the Harbor had to offer. A great location and perfect price if you're looking to stay in this locale.This hotel is newly renovated and very nice, good staff and didn't have any problems with it. I would stay here again and definitely would recommend it to people who need a hotel to stay for a few days, that is right in the middle of the Inner Harbor. It is conveniently located within walking distance to the Aquarium, Convention Center, Camden Yards, etc. On the down side, the tub in the room leaked a little but it wasn't serious. The hotel took care of this matter. Also, when parking at the hotel you are directed to use an adjacent lot, which cost $25 per day since there are no parking spaces directly on premises. You can seek cheaper nearby alternatives if you don't mind walking a few blocks. Overall it was a satisfying experience.Don't let the name fool you!! I have stayed in Days Inns all over the place and it's normally just acceptable. Something very different about this place. The room his huge more like a small suite. Very clean the staff was very nice and helpful. I was impressed by the ihome alarm clock and the cool showers. It's the little details that count. Great job will come back next time I'm in B~TownOnly short one star because if under construction.I planned to write this review about the comfortable beds, great location and better than expected room, that was until it took over 20 minutes to find someone at the front desk. Calls (20+ rings) and 15 minutes waiting in the lobby. When staff member finally showed up, she did not care at all that we had been waiting. She honestly looked annoyed to be asked to do her job. All proving that a good review can easily be ruined by one uncaring employee.I was surprisingly impressed with my stay here! It is the best value hotel near the Harbor and across the street from the Convention Center. The lobby is gorgeous and newly renovated. Only one elevator worked during my stay, and considering I was on the ninth floor during a conference, we stopped on every floor for every trip. There is no ADA ramp at the front entrance, just a few stairs. My queen double bed room was outstanding. Bathroom was small, but the sink/mirror space is outside of the bathroom. Our AC unit was also broken, but it wasn't a big issue considering it was freezing outside during our time in Baltimore. Housekeeping and guest services were very courteous and supportive of our requests.  Definitely the best value near the Harbor (short walk), and especially for the Convention Center.The staff at the front desk is VERY rude and arrogant...the front desk supervisor... I think her name was Marion; not sure but I know her initials were M.M.  Was extremely snotty and inconsiderate considering they were the ones who messed up our reservation in the first place. Instead of working with us to rectify the situation she decided to blow us off and give us a horrible attitude. The dirty looks and rude body language she was giving us while talking to her made me EXREAMLY upset. When you are spending $200 a night on a room (even though our reservation was SUPPOSED to be $99 a night) at the very least I would expect alittle respect and kindness. We travel a lot for our business and we will never stay at a days inn again.I'm a bit of a hotel snob and I would normally never stay in a Days Inn. However, this was all that was available for a quick work trip and it's surprisingly nice (for a Days Inn). The 4 stars is for comparison with similarly priced hotels, not Hilton, etc. Very clean. Super friendly front desk staff, and convenient location and parking. A little surprised there was no free breakfast option, and the hotel is a tiny bit dated and has an "older hotel smell".Rooms are clean, staff is helpful & friendly, beds are comfy, but walls are very thin.  The traffic outside is loud. At 4:10am I can hear a baby crying, a TV & the elevators.  Security finally got the neighbors to stop arguing. Not a good hotel for the light sleeper.Great rates and clean!  Linens were clean and it was really very quiet.  I actually slept (which is something that I have a difficult time with in hotels).  What else can you really ask for from an inexpensive hotel in the Inner Harbor area of Baltimore?I was really not looking forward to staying here. I'm normally a Hampton inn guy, and thought days inn wouldn't be as nice. However, the location was perfect and my room was clean and well appointed. Parking was ridiculous ($27 a day) but I've heard that is normal for baltimore.Excellent location.  Easy walk to convention center and waterfront . Rooms are average.Staff is helpful and friendly but not enough of them - waitVery nice front desk and rooms are good. I don't like when bathrooms have the sink outside but it's ok. Elevators are kinda slow and rooms are small but well furnished. I wish the bathroom was a bit cleaner. Excellent location though, especially for the convention center. Parking is expensive but there are plenty of garages around.I stayed at a Days Inn, once, for one night only, after a 12 hour drive from Salem, MA to Dumfries, VA.  I vowed never to return to one.  So when I heard I had to stay in one for work, I was not happy.  Until I found out it was the Days Inn Inner Harbor, which was recently renovated and has the friendliest staff ever.  Seriously, the staff was fabulous - I was surprised.It is still a Days Inn, but this one is a bit nicer due to the renovations.  I am super picky about hotels, and would stay here again.   Dated decor, TV's are bad, lighting is poor, phones are old, elevators are slow, gym equipment is basic - you get the picture.  Parking is steep - $22 for 24 hours, but you are downtown.   However, everything was clean and comfortable, and if you only need a place to sleep and shower, this is absolutely fine.I stayed at the Days Inn in the Inner Harbor Baltimore for 1 night 12/31/2013. It was the most horrible hotel experience.Pros* Fast check-in* Free Wifi* Good locationCons* Long elevator wait, which was dirty and small and limited to 1. Stairways were dark and dirty; later in the evening the landings were littered with beer cans and liquid that I hoped was beer* The 3rd floor smelled of marijuana (through the whole stay; I am asthmatic)* Room was freezing! Turned the very loud and very outdated heater on high for 2 hours and still cold. Turned out there was a severe draft under the heating system* Tall lamp not functioning* Roundy guests in the lobby, men fighting (on the phone, with other guests, with staff), girls with exposed body parts (due to their level of intoxication); again, long elevator wait* Front desk, housekeeping/room service, and wake-up call buttons not working on phone (were busy for hours). Had to call the hotel's main number from my cell phone for service. Was told that the buttons sometimes don't work... after this I tested the button and it worked. I assumed that they left the phone off the hook* Paper thin walls; could hear neighbors laughing, yelling, throwing up, coughing until 5:30am. Called security and there was no sign of them* Bed and pillows too plush (may be a personal preference, but it kept us awake); weird small* Room faced parking lot and a car alarm was going off at all hours of the night* Awake until 5:30am! We contemplated packing up the car and leaving around 5:00am, but we didn't want to drive while exhausted* Checkout was fine (because we got there at 10:45; 11am the lobby was a mad house)* Complained to the manager about our stay. Because we booked through Kayak and paid for our parking, nothing could be discounted at that time. Promised a call back and it has been a week and I have not gotten a callI visit the Inner Harbor often and we usually stay at the Renaissance or Hilton. To save money, we tried the Days Inn and wish we never had! This was the worse hotel stay we have ever experienced! My fiance and I considered going back during a less busy evening (not New Years Eve), but the lack of follow-up from management has convinced me otherwise. I would never recommend this hotel to anyone I know.  Loud guests, thin walls, lack of sleep, no security in lobby, lack of attention from some staff, dirty/cramped/limited elevators, faulty AC/heat, etc. I just can't spend my hard earned money on service like that.This is a great place to stay in the middle of inner harbor. Everything is within walking distance. It's approximately 15 minutes away from the BWI airport by car / taxi. This will cost you approximately $42 with tip.The light rail to/from the airport to the Convention Center (this is the name of the stop right outside the hotel) is approximately a 40-minute ride for $1.60 per person one way.It's right down the street from the Baltimore Convention Center. The Washington Monument is approximately a 20-minute walk north of the hotel. You'll also pass by the Basilica of the Assumption too. We walked 2 miles south to the hotel on St. Charles street, past the gay bars, etc. at 2am!! It was pretty safe for two (little?) Chinese girls. The harbor is approximately a 10-minute walk south of the hotel. We were able to walk to the American Visionary Arts Museum, Federal Hill, The Harborplace and Gallery, etc.Enough about the awesome location in Inner Harbor. Let's talk about the room.We had a single room with two double beds. Our room faces a parking lot. Not much of a view, but that's okay. We came to Baltimore to spend time outside the hotel room. The beds were comfortable. They had more than enough available electrical outlets for our phones.The lights were a little weird though. Right when we came in through the door, we couldn't figure out what one of the switches turn on. The other two were for the fan and light in the bathroom. Speaking of the bathroom, this is a little funky too. The sink is OUTSIDE the bathroom. Interesting... The drain in the bathtub also doesn't work as well as we'd like. It'd take another 5 minutes for it to completely drain away after our showers. The staff at the Inn were really friendly and nice. We lost our luggage stub and they let us look for our luggages in the closet. That was really nice of them. I'd definitely stay here again, if I were to come back to Baltimore.The best choice for value oriented travelers. Two thirds the price of the nearby convention hotel. Great service. Friendly staff. A bit of street noise in my room. Also an annoying $1 per day "safe fee" that they quickly remove when asked. My room had a broken alarm clock which was finally replaced. And the floor lamp had no light bulb. Very convenient location. Near the light rail which is $1.60 to BWI. Be sure and check out the Charles Street area (Mt Vernon neighborhood). You can work out at the nearby Better Bodies gym and shop at the grocery store just beyond it (Fresh Fields?). This is the best Days Inn save for the one in Chicago's Lincoln Park neighborhood.(Oh and I forgot to mention 3 free computers in the business center and guest laundry.)PS This is not the Ritz nor are you paying such room rates.You can do better.  Mediocre hotel with unhelpful staff (except for the wait staff in the restaurant who were friendly and helpful, regrettably the food was not great).  On the plus side my room had a small, but not very comfortable couch, and there were lots of power outlets.  Also the gym was decent.  On the down side, the parking fees are OUTRAGEOUS ($27/day and anything more than about 3 hours results in a $27 charge so an overnight stay can result in $54 in parking fees).  The elevator is also painfully slow.A great place to say right in the heart of it all. Very close to the harbor. Very clean and safe. I also like the fact that the parking garage can only be entered after you swipe your room key to lift the gate so you can pull in so your car will have a safe night as well.Had to go to Baltimore for a conference at the Baltimore Convention Center.  Being a resident, i booked the cheapest yet decently reviewed hotel that was close to the convention center.Pros:- GREATTTTTTTTTTTTTTT location! seriously less than 1 minute walk to the convention center. It was So nice especially since it was raining.- The service: the front desk along with the security guards were so accommodating and welcoming. I was in a suit for a presentation and it was raining. I had NO umbrella. While I stood out in front of the hotel just staring at the rain.. the security guard gave me an extra poncho that he had! He was SOOO nice. THANK YOU!!!!!-Forgot to bring a toothbrush so I asked the front desk for one. The quality of the toothbrush is probably the best toothbrush that any hotel has ever given me -- even compared to high end hotels in Vegas.-The hotel room has everything  you need --- coffee pot, refrigerator, iron, blowdryer-FREEEE WIFI!- The shuttle to the airport stops by the hotel every 45 of the hour. :)- Very friendly location for visitors allowing us to not rent a car but to walk to everything!Cons:- The bedding is SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO itchy! Just really low thread count sheets.- The refrigerator kept buzzing off and on throughout the night. I'm a very very heavy sleeper.. but I kept waking up throughout the night.- it has a funny smellFor the price.... I got everything I needed. I just gave it 3 stars because of the itchy itchy sheetsThe quality of the accommodation was about what you'd expect from a hotel at the Days Inn price point; adequate-but-not-wonderful beds, simple rooms with entry-level appliances (including my personal dread of having to choose in midsummer heat between being awake because of the heat or because of the noise from the cheap AC). That's their business model and you know what you're getting. That said, this place goes above and beyond in just about every other way. The facilities (business center, restaurant and coffee shop, pool, etc.) were more than I was expecting, but the most pleasant surprise was the staff. They have some of the smartest, most pleasant, most accommodating staff I've ever seen at a budget-friendly hotels (well, actually, they were smarter and nicer than I've gotten at plenty of nicer hotels), from the desk clerks and concierge right down to the security guards.You need something? You have a problem? They find a solution - a normal, people-with-common sense solution right there on the spot and with a smile. No "let me get a manager," no "we don't do that," no "I don't know, sorry." It's so simple and yet it was such a pleasant surprise and made such a positive impression that I really came away with a good feeling here. Also - especially considering that downtown Baltimore is horrible to drive in - the excellent, convenient, walkable location was really a plus.
review_content_40: A great value for the price. Free Wifi, my room was immaculate, the room looked recently renovated as does much of the hotel. The staff is incredibly nice and helpful, from the front desk to the restaurant and everywhere in between. My only complaint is that 1 elevator was out of service which meant long waits.Ahhh the many ups and downs, mostly downs, but we can pretend....Ups: The location literally could not be better if you are staying at this hotel to attend an event at the convention center. You can see the convention center from the hotel and it is literally one block away! Also, a great location for walking around the buzzing area around the Aquarium with all the bars, restaurants, and shopping. The staff members were extremely friendly and upbeat. Downs: Only 2 elevators within the building. The hotel is 9 floors and we were on the 8th. This seems to be a very busy hotel, so waiting for the elevators could sometimes take nearly 10 minutes when the line was out the door each night. Why not just take the stairs you ask? They closed the stairway around 9 p.m. each night, I guess because people would smoke in there? Still, it really caused a jam. The beds and pillows were the worst I've ever attempted to sleep in. I'm a bit spoiled by my bed and pillows at home, but this was just out right bad. I woke up over 10 times a night and just could not find a comfy spot! I typically fall asleep within minutes, so this was not pleasant. The bathroom was teeny tiny! Also, the elevators and hallways reaked of weed! Everyone was talking about it. Where the party was, I couldn't tell ya, but it appeared to be everywhere!For the price and location, I didn't mind it, but I will either bring my own pillows or choose another hotel next visit!My group has been reserving two rooms at the Days Inn for over 10 years now for the Otakon convention. We absolutely love it there, and would be so disappointed to go anywhere else. This year at check-in on Thursday, the staff had a table set up with free cookies and iced tea. After spending several hours on trains to get there from DC when our flights got diverted, I couldn't have appreciated those more!When we got to our rooms, our toilet wasn't working right. I called the front desk and a maintenance guy was there within 5 minutes. We came to know this guy well (Hi Larry!). He was amazing and every time we passed him the halls, he was so excited to see us. XD I absolutely love the staff at the Days Inn, every year they go above and beyond to welcome us. They even had a banner hanging to welcome con-goers, and they offer specials in their restaurant since they tend to know everyone's on a budget.One other good plus is that they don't mind peeps using the stairwells, in fact they encourage it. This helps a ton in alleviating the elevator congestion. We were on the 5th floor this year, and had no problem getting to our rooms at all.Free wifi, fridges, microwave, hair dryer, super comfy beds and HD TVs with open jacks to hook up our game systems to make this our go to hotel every single year for Otakon.Absolutely awesome hotel. Relatively small rooms European style (it is an old brick building). Simplicity is key, but all was very well thought out. Rooms have a big flatscreen TV and free wi-fi. Excellent service, by all staff. Closest hotel to the conference center. Will definitely stay here again.The hotel the conference was located in offered a special rate of $189 a night. Being a starving graduate student, I hit Hotels.com. At under $100, the Days Inn sounded good to me (and it was only about a mile away).OK... that's a mile of territory that can't be walked, safely. So I relied on a lot of cabs, at $5-$10 a ride. It still ended up cheaper than if I'd stayed at the conference hotel.Free wifi, a reasonably comfortable (if really, really small and cramped) room, a pool, and Seattle's Best coffee in the lobby. Important pluses, in my book.Hotels.com doesn't warn you that parking is $20 extra a night. Parking ANYWHERE in the Inner Harbor, apparently, is that expensive. But how does one manage to plan and build a hotel -- a hotel, for godssake -- without offering guests any parking?The air conditioning was broken. So was the bathroom fan, so the room acquired a swamplike feel. The sink was clogged. I was irritated. I mentioned the issues, as I left for a day of lectures. They were fixed when I returned. Ah, better!One of the better chains.Comfy and charming value right near everything! Clean, good hotel with a spiffy little outdoor pool. Staffed by polite and helpful people. I was in a smallish but good room with two double beds. The hair dryer worked good, the TV was alittle outdated, but the room had a large mini fridge. Parking was not cheap but the location can't be beat. Tip for those doing their own driving in Baltimore as a newbie...make sure your car has GPS or plop down $12 a day to include one with a rental car. Charm city was way more charming with my GPS. I visited once before without one, and I spent as much time getting unlost as I did getting lost.Great location. Reasonably priced. The room was clean and smoke free. There are only two elevators and sometimes that can result in long waits, given the size of the place. Overall I am very happy with my stay at the Days Inn.Compared to many of the hotels in the area: prices were great.$119 a night wasn't bad at all. Staff @ the Front Desk were not the friendliest people in the world; but then I remembered that I was in Baltimore & that must have been the A-Winning personality that I heard so much about.Room was nice; apparently, recently renovated.HD TVs in the room, but nothing in HD; all Standard Definition programming (that's always a little annoying).Parking was $20 a day. Hotel Restaurant prices were real good too.We booked a room here based on price & proximity to the Inner Harbor; we got a wheelchair-accessible room with a roll-in shower for about $150/night. The room was nicely appointed with all sorts of free goodies (granola bars, water, popcorn). The furniture was typical hotel, but we didn't care so long as it was clean (it was). What interactions we had with the staff were positive - they even held our bags when we arrived early so we could explore in the meantime.I see that someone wasn't thrilled with the elevator wait; I can understand that, but we didn't encounter problems.There is a restaurant on premises, but we decided to eat elsewhere to get a feel for the neighborhood.Quibbles:1. The bathroom sink didn't allow for us to rest toiletries there; the edges were too narrow & what surfaces there were were sloped into said sink. Annoying.2. It's wonderful & helpful that they have a room with a roll-in shower & attached, flip-up seat, but said seat is hard as a rock - no padding whatever. It's a bit hard (no pun intended) on the behind.Overall, I'd go back.Great place to stay. Easy walk to most downtown attractions. Friendly staff. Great price for it's location. I will stay here again. Ohh. Ya. It was CLEAN.Staying here for the Baltimore tattoo convention. Second day in a row with no hot water. A hotel shouldn't run out of hot water every morning if they are hosting a convention. They should have enough hot water for multiple guests to shower at once. Extremely disappointed with this place.HAHAHA! OMG! I think I had this exact same room with the blood stain on the ceiling! Was it room 511 (I think that's was our room number...)? The rat must have changed residence in the three weeks between our stays and I had no problems with the Internet connection. The close proximity to the ballpark was enough for me and the price was more reasonable than most. I found it to be in a fairly safe spot in Baltimore... so that was a bonus... but we only stayed a night...and we were drinking... so Lei probably knows better than I do!!!I live about an hour away, but my wife and I got a room here to avoid any drinking and driving after attending the Chelsea vs AC Milan game at M&T Field on Friday night with out breaking the bank. For that purpose, the hotel was perfect. The location could not have been much better to get to the stadium and entertainment on Pratt Street. Also when leaving town, there is not an easier place in the city to get going south bound on 95 (or 295 or 97). Finally the cost of $150 beat most of the other hotels in the Inner Harbor by half. That is where any convenience ends. Our overnight plans fell through late Thursday so we scrambled Thursday night to find a room. I did a basic Inner Harbor search by cost and came up with the Days Inn as one of the top options. I called the Days Inn and was told they they were booked before I could get my question out. I called all the other hotels in the area up to $200 and was told more politely they all were booked. I went to sleep to contemplate my options. When I woke my wife wanted to give it a try so took my list and was going to call them all again. The first one she called was Days Inn, and we got a room. Checking in was fine but we found out parking was not included and would cost $20 a night. This wasn't shocking, but it would have been nice to be told when you book. The whole building feels old. Carpet, wallpaper, furniture... all just gave me the feeling that the place probably has mold issues. Also, they have two elevators for 10 or so floors that had us waiting and waiting and waiting. Also, we got rejected when we called down at 10:30am to see if we could extend check-out to noon. Overall, the place was a place where we could sleep from 4am to 11pm. Besides that, the staff was not friendly, the place made me want to sleep with an extra layer of clothes, and wouldn't want to stay here again.Everything was fine until we noticed strange things in our room.There seem to be what looked like a splat of blood on the ceiling. Our heating unit would randomly make loud screeching sounds that woke us up in the middle of the night. The best part of our stay was the huge rat that lived under our beds. They moved us to another room that had a toilet that wouldn't flush and the front desk guy brought us a plunger and handed to my friend to fix the problem. In their computer room, the internet connection sucked because any page you tried to look up was blocked. Also, an employee on break was on a computer and didn't get up to let a hotel guest use it. WTF??The restaurant staff was pretty cool...although I couldn't stop thinking about the rat in our room...what about their kitchen??Staff is friendly and everything was in working order. The fridge and microwave is a plus. Best water pressure I've ever felt in a hotel shower! Was amazed by that! Great location for the convention center and the harbor.Eh. The location is great but the rest is just ok. They charge guests $20 bucks a day for parking I hate that. The rooms are ok a little cramped. It was clean though. The sink is outside of the bathroom which is weird when you have four people sharing on space. Also the air conditioner was so loud you could not hear each other talk. The elevator is another HUGE issue. There are only two and 8 floors of guests. Do the math it doesnt work. Sunday am when checking out the elevator stopped at every floor before finally getting to the bottom. There is also no force close button. They really should be a little more efficient. Use the money we are paying for parking to upgrade it! Thanks!My car broke down outside of this Days Inn. I went inside to ask for some help and the front desk help was amazingly kind and helpful. While I was waiting for the hotel's engineer to meet me in the lobby, the front desk staff told me (and my friend) to make ourselves comfortable in the lobby and use the restroom, etc. as needed. I heard them answer a phone call and they kindly explained to the person on the other end that they have a lost and found and could send the person their missing item (I've never ever heard of a hotel doing this for anyone). The engineer, Greg, helped me fix my car and I was on my way. I have never stayed at this hotel because I live nearby but based on this experience I would highly recommend it based on the courteousness of the staff. The lobby was also clean and bright and this hotel is right on the light rail line to BWI airport. I highly recommend Days Inn at Hopkins Place.We stayed at this hotel during the 2nd leg of your trip to Maryland.We were very pleased that we were able to get a hotel right in Inner Harbor for the price we booked through a travel vendor.This hotel was one of the highest rated within the price point I had searched.I had read that the rooms were small, but clean and comfortable.We weren't concerned with having alot of space as were were not going to spend alot of time in the room.We did want a pool,fitness room and a place to eat on premises if we needed too.We also wanted clean and comfortable rooms.The Days Inn Inner Harbor provided that.My only complaint is that the they charge $20 per day for parking.To be more competitive with area garages AND as a consideration for PAYING GUESTS they should offer a much lower price.With that being said,I will try to book there again.The staff we interacted with,The Doorman,the desk clerks,coffee barista and lifeguard were very pleasant and helpful.Got a room at a very decent rate prior to the marathon. Room decor was a little dated but room was spacious and had fridge/microwave. For this price and location on a busy weekend, I was very happy with the hotel. Front desk people were almost too nice.

review_content: I spent one night at the Hilton while in town to see Garth Brooks at Royal Farms Arena.  I was traveling with my 6 year old son.  We had room 2003 on the 20th floor (top floor).Pros:Located in nice, redeveloped area - Whereas most of the area between Penn Station and the waterfront has come upon hard times, the hotel is in a nice area.  While it is a little further from the waterfront activities, it is connected to the convention center via skywalk and right next door to Camden Yards.   Royal Farms Arena is 3 blocks away.View - Our room had an awesome view of Camden Yards and M&T Bank Stadium.  The room - Standard 4 star Hilton room.  No over the top touches you would expect at a higher end property (Waldrop, St. Regis, etc.) but very solid for its class.  Although this hotel has been open a few years, everything in our room was still in good shape.   Water pressure in shower was good.   We were a good distance from the elevator and found the room to be very quiet.Food and beverage - We didn't try to the onsite restaurant (Diamond Tavern) but found the onsite Jimmy John's and Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf locations to be very economical (normal prices) and convenient. Early check in - we were able to get into our room at 12:45pm.Business center in Lobby - Business center in lobby worked well to print a document.Cons:Layout of hotel - The hotel is located on both sides of S. Eutaw St.; the front desk could have done a better job explaining the sky walks.  It took some trial and error for us to find our way around.Room darkening curtains - The direct sun in morning really heated up our room and curtains were badly overmatched.  The windows probably need some type of glazing to supplement the curtains.BIG convention hotel - Expect heavy elevator traffic and long walks - probably 10 minutes to get from our room to Jimmy John's for lunch on Sunday morning.Lounge was unremarkable - I will admit that we did not make breakfast on Sunday morning, but the offerings during the day on Saturday afternoon were very average.  The selection of soft drinks was good but the only food offering was some cheap snack mix that set out in the open all day.  Having just left a very good lounge at the Grand Hyatt in Washington DC, this was a definite letdown.General:We felt extremely safe at the hotel and in the harbor area, however the rest of the area between Penn Station and the hotel was pretty run down.  There was a significant amount of loitering on the North Side of Royal Farms Arena.  After walking from the hotel to the other side of the harbor, we used the metro from the Shot Tower station and felt the same.  Uber was reliable but seemed to be perpetually on surge.Overall:I would definitely stay here again when returning to Baltimore.  We felt safe in and around the hotel and the room was the typical quality you expect from Hilton.Clean room.  Friendly staff.However, not worth the $400+ a night they charged me.  Not staying here again for this price!  Crazy.Very impressed with the staff located at all stations throughout the hotel, cleanliness of the room, and the hotel itself.  I wish the refrigerators were included with the room (instead of for a $25 fee).  I didn't see one speck of mold in the shower, which I feel is sometimes rare for hotels.Will stay again!I did not stay overnight here, but visited my in-laws' room, as well as had some drinks in the bar downstairs. It's your typical Hilton hotel, probably a little larger than other locations and it's attached to the Convention Center. The room itself was pretty standard, but my mother in law said it was really dusty. The drinks at the bar were fine...I'm not a huge Hilton fan, but it's definitely a convenient location to shopping and dining, and obviously the convention center, and can be accessed by the Light Rail easily as well.I'm an HHonors Diamond member so this is my go-to place to stay in Baltimore whenever I have to go there on business. Let's just say that if I didn't have business in Baltimore, I would really never have a reason to go there. The location of this place in the Inner Harbor area is a little deceiving since it is on the Orioles Stadium side, not the true Inner Harbor so don't expect to see any water from your room. Do expect to see the inside of the stadium if you stay in an odd numbered room from about 1-35 on floors higher than about 10. Pretty cool on game days. This hotel is modern, lots of glass and marble in the lobby, skyway connected to the convention center. Self parking is $30/day(!) and oddly enough, you have to go to a different area than check in to arrange this. Also beware that on game days, the garage fills to capacity immediately so if you take your car out, don't expect to get back in until the game is over. The staff is friendly, the exec lounge is what you would expect with a highlight being a nice view into the stadium. A couple shortfalls are that the rooms are not very soundproofed so on game days, you hear the cheers, the music, the fireworks, etc. Also, most of the touristy Inner Harbor things are a 10-15 min walk to the other end and if you walk the wrong way, you will quickly realize the true grittiness of urban Baltimore so beware. Overall, a perfectly serviceable hotel, offers everything you would expect from a Hilton property at a convention center.Meh...  Honestly if there was a shade under 3, I'd have used it.  It was good as a business facility, descent meeting rooms and the catering was top notch,  that was what saved this from a 2-star review.  As a place to stay it really needs some help.  For such a prime location right next to both Major League stadiums, and right by Inner Harbor, in my mind they need to really pay attention to staying up to date.  The furniture in my room was severely worn.  The bindings on the chair arms was cracked and peeling, the fabric was really faded and had some seriously ground in staining.  The desk, bedside table and TV stand were all dinged and chipped, showing age and in theory abuse.  The most offensive part was what I found in the bathroom. There was mold, or at least a seriously thick black line under the sink rim, directly under the faucet as well as cracked and dirty/moldy grout in the shower.  I think they need to have a real chat with the maintenance folks especially the cleaning group.  My company picked this place, I have no control,but if I ever do have an option, my vote will be fore somewhere else.My co-workers and I stayed here for a meeting a few weeks ago.  Great service and hotel except for the roaming homeless people all over town giving you each their sad stories about why they need money.  I had about 5 homeless people (including inside the hotel) ask me for money.  As much as I'd love to help each out, I'd be poor if I helped each one.  Tonya at the bar was a character, except we were a bit offended when she was talking to a group of people for about 5 minutes before she acknowledged us.  When we said, "Excuse me, can we order?"  She mentioned she'll be there in a few....she was catching up with her sister.  Overall it was a good experience but I would hate to see Tonya REALLY annoyed :)Good, simple, clean hotel. I'm a huge fan of hotels that have duvets with *white cotton covers so that you know they wash them for every new guest and this place does that. About a 10 minute walk to the inner harbor and connected to the convention center.I came here for a conference and was impressed with the space throughout the 2nd floor.I can't say I agree with any of the naysayer reviews posted. Yes, parking is extra, but that is typical for a downtown hotel. I got free wifi, but I guess that could have been thanks to my silver (lowest) status with Hilton. I did need to wait a few minutes to check in, but they had my room ready for me and were very polite!I didn't get a fancy view, but the room was a fair size. The king bed was comfortable to watch tv on, but didn't seem to translate perfectly to a good nights sleep. Still more pros than cons with this Hilton and its location.This is the first year our group stayed here while attending Otakon. Our previous Otakon hotel, the Baltimore Harbor Hotel, really let us down at checkout in 2014 and our whole experience was less than acceptable, causing this move. The Hilton Baltimore is more expensive than many other Otakon hotels, but its location next to the Baltimore Convention Center makes it very attractive. Main entrance was not large but we got unloaded quickly. Valet parking was $42 per night, though expensive was worth it. Check in was smooth with no issues. Six elevators serve the main hotel floors. After arriving to our room we found a major issue, the reserved double was only a single. They had no more doubles but were able to get us a rollaway. Room was very basic with no mini-refrigerator or microwave. I noticed some minor wear and tear including scratches on the TV and some marks on the bedding, but nothing serious. Soundproofing was surprisingly good and we could not hear other rooms. The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf, located in the lobby, is a nice but not cheap place to grab a pastry. The Hilton's convention space and sky bridge to the Baltimore Convention Center is a major advantage to staying here. Convention space in the Hilton is nice and spread across two different buildings. The sky bridge to the Baltimore Convention Center has one major flaw. Directly before the convention center there is a choke point due to a narrow staircase and handicap elevator.Overall, even with some issues, our stay was good and we will be returning due to the Hilton's convenience.I  stayed for 2 nights, it was about 2 blocks from the National Harbor so there was plenty to do. I gave it 3 stars simply because I had to call 4 times for someone to give me fresh towels/wash cloths and the chair and bedding on the bottom looks as if a pets scratched on it for dear life!!! Ugggh the parking was expensive ( valet $42 a day) on top of their nightly rates. Ehh I may stay again in the near future maybe at another locationWe came here from DC on our way to NYC for a baseball game.  The hotel was average, clean and comfy.  It was about a 10 minute walk into the harbor where most of the shopping and restaurants were.  The room service food was nothing to write home about either... No bell hop to help with luggage and you had to pay for parking at a separate window, it wasn't included in your hotel fees.  The hotel seemed to lack service in the lobby area altogether.The best part of this hotel is the view of Camden Yards!I enjoyed my stay here and did not have any complaints. The rooms were clean and the staff is friendly. Nothing jumped out at me as truly exceptional, but then again I did not make use of the amenities they offered.As far as parking goes, it is all underground. I appreciated having the option to pay for a valet or self-park, so that was nice. The Cleveland Browns also happened to be staying there, not that they changed anything but it was still cool. All in all, I would be happy to stay here again.My union had our national convention at this hotel. Of all the hotels we've had conventions at that I've attended this one was the best. The reason is simple-- the staff. Friendly and helpful as hell from front desk to bellmen to bartenders/waitstaff/baristas to housekeeping. They gave us a very warm welcome and wore our union's (UE) buttons in solidarity with us. Other UE brothers and sisters attending the convention also raved about how great and friendly the staff is. Really blew us all away how genuinely friendly everyone who worked at this hotel were. Members of UNITE-HERE Local 7, they are presently in negotiations with the Hilton for a new contract so wish them luck as they certainly deserve everything they're asking for which isn't much.Also big plus are the beds, very comfy, nice duvets and sheets, as well as the room views, many of which have clear views of Camden Yards so you can essentially watch a live ball game for free.Only downside: insufficient outlets in the rooms-- they really need to get with the times on this. Also parking is pricey.But overall great experience at a great hotel with great staff.The Hilton is always a favorite among my group of friends as we attend 2 conventions in the attached BCC each year. Never had a problem with checking in early and the front desk staff are quick to address any questions we had. Love the location to the BCC as I wear several large costumes to both Otakon and Bronycon and the skywalk is a blessing in those instances.Only real issue we've had with the Hilton  was with their parking staff. If you're parking valet park on the right side of their drop off zone. If you're unloading luggage, park on the left side. We were unaware of this one year and dealt with a very rude parking attendant. The left side was parked up so we parked on the right to quickly unload our car (maybe took 10 minutes) and the attendant insisted if we were parked there we needed a bellhop to help us unload the car and use their valet service. After reassuring him several times we were just being dropped off and unpacking our own luggage he eased off as more guests arrived. I think he was looking to make a few bucks but the entire exchange was unpleasant.While attending a Hazardous Materials Conference in Baltimore, we stayed at the Hilton Inner Harbor in downtown Baltimore, conveniently located next to the Baltimore Orioles baseball stadium and near the convention center. The hotel was comfortable, clean and quiet, with a coffee shop on the lobby level. If we ranked the hotel on this alone, we'd give it a 5 stars, but they have some serious recordkeeping issues. Before arriving, we'd adjusted our check-out date by phone, but the update was never entered, requiring a second phone call. Then after arrival, our room wasn't cleaned until late afternoon when a supervisor came to inspect, surprised because their records showed our room was vacant. Upon check-out, our bill was correct except our room number. Oh, and don't expect to check in before 4 PM.Due to the few issues mentioned above, we would rate this hotel 4 stars out of 5. If they improved these recordkeeping issues, they would definitely rate 5 stars.Ernie & Dora Hiers, Fiction Faith & Foodies BlogGreat hotel that's right in the Inner Harbor if you're into that sort of thing and also a block from Camden Yards, I always did not like this hotel because it blocks the clocktower from being seen when you are in Camden Yards which is something that I grew up with, but the rooms here are very nice and the amenities are also very nice. I would stay here again, although it seems like everytime I do its because I get it on HotWire.Came here for a conference. Had an average stay. Would probably not willingly stay here again and here's why:- My boss was nice enough to book a king bed for me. We get there and they tell us they ran out. - The room itself was nice and clean, but for their rates it's kind of ridiculous. I stayed at a holiday inn that looked exactly like this room. - Charging guests for Wi-Fi is absolutely absurd! - I hate hotels that don't have late night eats. I'll settle for a vending machine. Everything in here closes way too early.But all of it wasn't bad:- I had a great view of Camden Yards.- The bartender Hashim was a peach.- It's a great location. Was able to get to much public transportation from here.Gigantic Bust.I come to Baltimore every year for a conference and I usually stay at the Marriott. I decided to stay here since I was a HHonors member. I was sorely disappointed from the day I arrived. I filled out a form asking me if I wanted anything to be in my room when I arrived. I ordered a few things and none of them were there upon arrival and I ended up waiting several hours for them.Room service took FOREVER. I understood there were two major conventions going on at once, but 3 hours for barely lukewarm food at almost $100 for three people was ridiculous. I got better food across the street at the bars than I did here. Housekeeping SUCKED. The first night they said the 'Do Not Disturb' sign was up. I found that to be hilarious since I didn't even have a sign and requested one. When they finally came, all they did was make the beds with dirty sheets, didn't replace the towels, or remove the food service trays that had sat outside the room for over 18 hours.You also pay through the nose for everything. $40/day for Valet, $28/day to park yourself, $12/day for very shitty WiFi, $12-40/glass for wines you can pick up for $15/bottle, $8 for a 12 Oz domestic beer and $6/can for pop. I was surprised I wasn't charged per trip up and down the elevator. I had booked in their Executive Suites, so I expected a little more than I got. When I complained to the front desk manager, she rolled her eyes and walked away from me.It would take an act of God to get me back in this hotel and I'll tell everyone how bad it was.The room and view are very nice. But what's the point of reserving a room with a king sized bed when it's not "guaranteed?" My husband and I checked in and the gentleman at the front desk reiterated that it was for a king sized bed... We got up to the room and found out we got stuck in a room with two full sized beds. Called the front desk and the woman just kept saying they "sold out of king sized rooms." No mention of that when checking in though?!? Not the best way you want to celebrate your first wedding anniversary....
review_content_20: I stayed here in April 2015 for the Food Safety Summit.What I liked:- Great view from the 14th floor. I was able to see Camden Yards (unfortunately the scheduled games were cancelled due to the Freddie Gray rioting and looting in the area)- Nice, updated decor throughout the hotel. Upscale feel.- Very polite, helpful staffWhat I didn't like:- When I first got to my room, I thought I heard a vacuum cleaner either next door or upstairs. The problem? The sound literally NEVER stopped. Obviously it wasn't a vacuum. Maybe I was near a laundry room? Or it could have been the HVAC system? Whatever it was, the non-stop humming noise was beyond annoying.- The coffee pot in my room was DIRTY AND DISGUSTING! See pics.- Very few outlets in the room, and they're all spread out in random parts of the room. I don't understand why hotels--especially a big one like the Hilton--don't cater to our need for ample outlets to charge all of our gadgets. First world problems, I know. But still.- Getting around this hotel is confusing and exhausting, particularly if you are attending an event at the Baltimore Convention Center (it's connected to the hotel). It's literally a 15-20 minute walk down random hallways, stairwells and bridges.- On my last morning, I was welcomed by an ant crawling from underneath my pillow.Tip: Don't wanna pay for wifi in your room? The events taking place at the hotel/convention center might have a free network password. You can ask for it at the desk, but they may require proof that you are there for an event.The staff here have been great. Everyone has been so friendly. Nice place with plenty to do nearby. Highly recommended.I'll make this quick. The location is great. The room I had was clean. No complaints there. But the king bed wasn't a king. I have a king at home. This was a queen at best. I've been in hotels where you get a real king size bed. Don't tell me it's a king and give me a queen. Plus, if your sleeping partner moves an inch the whole bed shakes. Let's just say it wasn't a great night's sleep. This hotel nickel and dimes you too much in other areas to shortchange you on the bed size on top of it. It's no better than three stars because of that.Came here on a business trip.....Offerings in the concierge lounge is sparse.  Continental breakfast and 2 hot dishes during the evening.  Cookies for dessert.Wifi was decent.  i was able to stream movies without problemsParking is sketchy.  I left my car in the deck and just walked to work everyday.Shuttle bus from outside the side entrance of the hotel 30 minutes past the hour every hour to the casino.Self parking was pretty easy, there are elevators to the lobby. We only stayed a night so can't comment much. One of the nicer Hiltons, rooms look new and the lobby is quite nice. Lobby was booming on a Wednesday night.Location is nice. Only thing I complain about is an odd smell but my fiance said its normal room smell. Reminds me of old sheets?We ordered bagels and they said it could take at least 40 minutes, ok that's fine.We have a pretty nice view of the city.They do charge for everything but so does every other hotel at this star level. Recently we learned that Marriott would block personal hot spots and force you to use their internet.I have to say that half of the fun of my vacation in Baltimore was the location of our hotel. The Hilton Baltimore is right next to Camden Yards, which I could see from our 11th floor room. We arrived at night and there was a game on. I could see the lights and the score and felt like I was in my own VIP suite with a King Bed. The room was nice and we ordered up a fridge for the week to make ourselves at home. The next day, I went to the gym and was blown away. Not only is it twice as big as regular gyms with a full lap pool, jacuzzi and hot sauna - it has a deck with chairs where you can watch the game for free. You can hear it, see the home plate and all bases. Like sitting in the Extra Outfield. Every neighborhood or place I wanted to go to was within 1.5 miles of the hotel, so I walked almost everywhere. Otherwise there is the Circular which is a free bus shuttle that goes all through the different neighborhoods or the Water Taxi, which is nearby in the Inner Harbor and by far the best way to travel. Housekeeping staff was very friendly and kept our room clean and stocked. I like to swim everyday, so I shower a lot and need extra shampoo/conditioner and towels. The beds are firm yet very comfortable, I slept great which means a lot away from home. I would recommend this hotel to any fan of baseball. Being that close to Camden Yards and actually getting to see the game from your room is an AWESOME experience.Convenient to the convention centre. Rooms were fine.Service was okay. Didn't have our rooms made up one day because we had left items on the bed? I've never heard that before.Glad the conference rate included wifi - I would have been pissed to pay $13 a day for that.Expensive for what it is - glad work was paying.I stayed here with my wife and two kids for one night recently, and found it to be a pretty good hotel. The lobby is spacious and stylish, and there was plenty of room for my kids to run around and annoy people.Check-in was easy and quick, though I was disappointed to find that a room on the Camden Yards side would cost an extra $30. We declined and instead enjoyed a pretty decent northward view of the city. As a baseball fan, though, I would spring for the other side if I planned to be staying there while baseball was being played.Our room itself was nice and typically Hilton-y. Slick and white. No fridge in the room, and Wifi was not free. Checkout was purely by email notification, which is always nice.We stayed here in part so our kids would have the opportunity to swim in the hotel pool. It's a weird pool -- very long and narrow. When we visited, it was somewhat crowded, so there was a fair bit of jostling with strangers. There was also a deejay playing very loud salsa music, and many people dancing in and out of the water. I think the hotel was hosting some kind of salsa dancing event. The resulting pool scene was kind of charming, but kind of annoying too. A larger pool would have been appreciated.Bar opens at 5 says the concierge. Waiting at the bar while 3 employees bounce around and guests stand there waiting. Only served when I asked when they opened. Bartender replied oh I didn't notice no one had a drink. Haa that's your job dude. Absolutely terrible. Beautiful hotel. Skip the bar. They're not into working for tips.Fabulous hotel in Baltimore's Inner Harbor with pretty great views. I was attending a conference in the nearby Baltimore Convention center so it couldn't have been more convenient. I was on the 15th floor and had an incredible view of Camden Yards. I didn't dine at the hotel but used the store inside which was a little pricey but otherwise I enjoyed my stay.First Hilton Baltimore is expensive, but in a great location. My room is big but worn and not the cleanest. What pisses me really off:* I arrived a little early (12:15 PM) and my room wasn't available. The unfriendly receptionist offer me a $40 room upgrade for immediate availability. No thanks. --- In similar situations both Sheraton and Marriott offer me a free room upgrade or at least a free drink while I wait. * Generously the rude receptionist offers to call me once my room becomes available. 3:15 PM and still no call so I trot back to the hotel to ask. A more friendly receptionist now has a room available. * Earlier, while I was waiting for a little while in the lobby and noticed that the lobby bar is not open. (That's hospitality)* In the room now and they want $12+ for internet access. NFW. If you like expensive mediocrity: Stay at Hilton! Otherwise choose a guest friendly hotel.After traveling lots and staying at plenty of places this place is the worse. Attempting to check in was so slow they apologized and have some vouchers to the bar. That appeared to be fair then later we went to the bar to use the vouchers...wow waited for 30 minutes no service...finally after trying to flag some one down we get service with attitude. Will NEVER stay here or stop here for a drink. Just horrible!Other than the convenience of being close to the stadiums, there is no reason to stay at this hotel. I travel frequently, and have stayed in many Hilton hotels. This was by far the worst experience I've had at a Hilton or any hotel for that matter.The customer service was terrible on all ends. Before booking my reservation I wanted to make sure that I would be able to do an early check-in. They said that I could, so I went ahead and made the reservation. They failed to inform me that there was a $25 fee for an early check in which is unnecessary and a complete rip off. I've never been charged for an early check in at any other hotel I've stayed in. It should be done as a courtesy if available.After after agreeing to pay the fee, we arrived at our room which was supposed to have harbor view, of course no view! Why would I specifically pay extra for a view only to open my curtains and see nothing.What really encouraged me to write this review was when I called the front and asked if I could get extra silverware sent up to my room. The woman told me to walk down and pick it up from the front desk!The next morning, I was woken up by housekeeping knocking on my door two different times after I had the "do not disturb" sign on my door.Finally, when I called to see if I could do a late check out, the desk said there would be an extra charge. Big surprise. When I asked to speak with the manager the front desk said they were going to transfer me and hung up instead. My boyfriend and I decided to stay at a different hotel the rest of our visit. It just wasn't worth it. 1 Star for the location... The hotel itself was mediocre and the service was unsatisfactory.Not very clean.  Dusty throughout the entire room.  They are going to upgrade the lobby area with new stores, but it will be later in the year.  One advantage, it's right next door to Baltimore Convention Center.  I will never stay here again.Horrendous! This is why we don't stay at places like this... Check in was terrible. We waited so long (there was only one person being helped at the counter and we were next in line) that they gave us 4 drink coupons... Then we waited at the bar for 15 - 20 min at least to get waited on. The bar tender had an attitude. The table stayed filthy with glasses from the prior patron that never got removed! For $300 a night you'd expect a little more. Should have stayed at our local favorite the Renaissance ... Never againI am writing this review as I sit in the lobby now. The hotel is beautiful and the rooms are just ok. There are not any convenient places to eat within (gift shop seems to stay closed). I suggest you bring snacks. It is winter and snowing so we have been snowed in and literally starving~ the hotel only has a Coffee Bean shop that closes at 2pm & never has anything in stock to make whatever you order anyway. The hotel also has a tavern that oh course is for full course meals but you would get bored going there. No Panera bread, Starbucks, etc,. I'm surprised the Hilton wouldn't offer more accommodations/options for its quest. It offers a nice view of Orioles Park & 2 highly expensive vending machines. It also has a bar...This is not a gluten free friendly establishment. Their room service closes at 11pm and there are literally no other food options. For being the Hilton and trying to promote their brand outside of business travel this is a terrible terrible lack of accommodation. We have stayed at the Hilton twice in two diff cities and they have proved to disappoint both times. We will no longer be booking any stays with the Hilton.I wish the Lobby Bar had its own listing here on Yelp, because I had a much better experience there than the hotel itself. But it doesn't so I averaged the two for ratings purposes.The hotel was rather pricey and didn't give you much in the way of room amenities. No free wi-fi unless you are a Gold or Platinum member. If you want it, it $13 a day. No refrigerator in the room, if you want one, you'd have to pay extra.Now, this isn't much different than other hotels, and I would have not minded it if the service was better. We got a pull away bed for our daughter (who is four) and asked to put it away from the window and the vent for the AC. The guy who brought up said "No, I'll put it here (Near the window and the AC vent) so she can watch TV in bed. My wife and I had to move it after the guy left.One of our days, we left our room about 9am. The maid's cart was a few doors down. We come back a little before 5pm and our room wasn't even touched. I don't know if they were just understaffed or skipped our room or what, but that was unexpected.There are good things about the hotel as well. It is right next to Camden Yards and there is a patio next to the gym where you can sit and watch the game. It has a walkway that connects it to the convention center, and it is only about 4 blocks away from Inner Harbor.But the best thing about the hotel was the bar, and that was due to the two bartenders working there when I went, Ana and Mike. I'm not a hotel bar kind of guy but I was there two nights (one to hang out with a friend and his wife and the other to watch a football game).The first night the bar was practically empty. Ana and Mike were great with conversation, filling up our drinks and answering our questions about what they offered. The next night, the bar was packed with businessmen who were there for a convention. I marveled at the way Ana and Mike worked. No one had to wait more than a second for their drink order and even though my tab was a pittance compared to hundreds of dollars the business people were spending, I always had a drink waiting when I finished my previous one. They made me feel welcome. Just great, great service from great, great people. The hotel should sit the rest of their staff down with Ana and Mike so they can give them some pointers on good service.Great lobby for meetings and breakfast. Hotel is close to landmarks and the glass keeps the room open. This can get packed during conventions as it's across the street and when there are ball games.The room appeared cleanly.   I had no problems with elevator speediness despite being there for a HUGE conference, easy access to the gym mid-day (at least 6 treadmills), and no trouble getting cabs from the hotel.   Also the cleaning person was liberal about replacing my soap/shampoo/conditioner daily which is HUGE.  And the location can't be beat right next to the ball park and inner harbor.  The gym treadmills actually face the ballpark so if you were there during a game you'd be able to watch the whole thing.However, on the con side, the coffee they provided in room was horrible and there was no close by option except for one starbucks in the convention center that was swamped given the size of conference I attended.  It looks like they are putting in a Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf but that's the kind of coffee they had in the rooms so does not seem like it will address the issue.  Also - one of my colleagues found bed bugs in her room.  Another colleague who stayed at Sheraton for same conference ALSO found bed bugs so clearly not something the Hilton has a monopoly on in Baltimore.  The electronic check out option on the TV did not work because of some technical glitch either. Finally, the air quality in the hotel seemed really bad - like there was not enough circulation.  I could barely run on the treadmill at the gym because of it.
review_content_40: If you're coming to an O's game from out of town, this hotel is very convenient. The side entrance puts you less than a block from the Eutaw Street gate of the park. With the rain yesterday, it was pretty nice to be able to wait at the hotel until things settled down. Additionally if you happen to be in town and there's a game happening, there's a terrace on the 4th floor the looks right into the stadium. There are rooms with balconies that also have the same view, but the terrace is accessible to all hotel guests. The hotel is less than a mile from Inner Harbor and in a very walkable area. Even with my dad's wheelchair we didn't have too many problems going around the area, minus the crowds there for the Star Spangled Banner celebration. The handicap accessible room was weirdly designed. There's a slight hallway before you turn into the area where the beds are. I'm sure they designed it that way so it would be easier to get a wheelchair in the room, but if you're dependent on your wheelchair to get around the entire room, it's not going to work. The rest of the room is designed like your average room, so there's limited space between the beds and dresser. The other problem I found was that the bedding retains heat really well, arguably too well. The bed itself was very comfortable, but the inferno that built up while you were laying there made it very difficult to stay comfortable throughout the night. We even lowered the temperature in the room to nearly 60 degrees and it was still never comfortable. This is probably more of a personal issue than universal, but still something worth noting in my opinion. Also they severely overcharge you for guest valet parking. Maybe it's the area, but $40/night seems rather high to me. Overall there are a lot of pros to staying at this hotel that would make it worth coming back, so I'd give it another shot & recommend it to others.This Hilton gets no complaints from me! Perfect location if you're hitting either stadium for a baseball or football game or the convention center. Room was clean and spacious. Hotel staff were helpful and courteous. And if you can get a room facing Camden Yards, all the better. Overall great experience.Great location, but the colors used to decorate were obnoxious. I constantly felt overwhelmed , even in my room. The 70s called and they want their hotel back! The beds were comfortable and the workout room was great. Did you see the view? Please update this awesome location!I'm actually surprised by the number of negative reviews for this hotel.  We stayed here to attend a game at M&T Stadium and were very pleased.  The hotel looks new, is in a great location, and was very reasonably priced.  The bed was great, the room was clean, and the bath products were Peter Thomas Roth (my fav). Housekeeping and the front desk were both very accommodating to our special requests.  The only negative was the hallways were at times quite noisy with what I'm assuming were over served guests.  And I do wish they did not allow dogs in this hotel.  We did hear a lot of yippy yapping through the walls.  Luckily, I can go back to sleep easily.  When we return, we would definitely stay here again.The good:Room was clean and reasonably spacious. Beds were comfortable. Not much else to say. Not bad, but with a few issues...The bad:Room was a little worn down. Outlets were coming off the wall. Tub was impossibly small. Not enough towels (even when we asked for me). I also think they deflated the pillows before we got there. Way too flat.The ugly:No. Toilet. Paper.We ran out of TP (a valuable resource) given there wasn't much in the room to start, and they did not restock it when asked (or even after cleaning the room). One can NOT survive modern society without TP. It's magical. I can deal with a lot of things, but a distinct lack of TP is not one of them.The service here is horrendous.  Upon check in the manager continuously tried to get me to give up my reservation and share a room with my colleague because they overbooked, I had to tell her "no" 4 times before she finally stopped asking, she was overly pushy. Then she checked me into a handicap room without asking me that had no closet, I had to go back down to get another room.   My toilet broke and they had to come two separate times because they did not check their work the first time.  Don't expect any service as I tried calling guest services and no one answered the phone on 3 occasions during my stay, lastly the maid decided to not clean my bathroom one of the days.   If you want a drink or are hungry expect to wait and get bad service, I was shocked to see the rudeness roll over to serving staff at the bar, the lady had a attitude, I was shocked. The only reason they get 2 stars is that the location is good.  Avoid this place if you can get a room at the Sheraton on the other side of the convention center.  Usually I have great experiences with he Hilton but this one needs a whole new staff.If this was a Marriott Courtyard or similar type hotel,it would get 5 stars. But it is a Hilton,and that is the major problem. When you stay at a Hilton you expect the extra mile. Mini bar, fridge,micro way,$8.00 bottle of water available, etc.This hotel was clean and spacious, service average, lobby and restaurant freezing for temperature. The restaurant was available in the building across the street. The restaurant food was very good, and there was an indoor crosswalk available, it still FELT inconvenient and unwelcoming for the hotel. The restaurant was called a tavern,but the hotel lacked that hotel bar availability. All and all a clean and spacious place,but not a warm and cozy place.Great location, however, the staff is horrible. In 2 short days I was approached by people demanding cash from me in the hotel and outside the hotel to a cook coming out changing our TV to NBA from baseball which we were watching? The staff of the hotel could care less if we were even there. Our company made the trip worth while with the always great effort they put in to it. I hope the Hilton Baltimore got a few tips on customer service!This is a very nice hotel. Parking, check-in, front desk service all very easy. Location is great for going to Orioles game. It is a very large, spacious building. Even with the O's in town, several conference functions, the lobby and hallways never felt crowded. Ballpark view is an amenity I will never tire of, so do take advantage, if you are a fan.Brief introduction... I'm an HHonors member and I try to stay at Hilton Hotels as often as I can, however, I've found that I usually favor the Garden Inn and DoubleTree lines as the flagship Hilton Hotels are usually outrageously priced and do not offer anything more than what the less-expensive Hilton lines do. That brings me to the Hilton Baltimore, room came at a discounted price, so no real complaints there, but when you factor in the cost for parking ($28 per night/$40 for valet), and the charge for Internet ($10-13 per day), the cost of your stay really starts to add up. I actually called and requested a code for the Internet as this was my first stay at this particular Hilton and I was denied the code (even for just a 24 hour period) and was told I could use the free WiFi available in the lobby. Never in my life have I been forced to pay for Internet at any hotel (including Hilton).  I ordered room service twice, first from their late night menu (food was quite good) and then again from their breakfast menu (I could have gone to IHOP and paid less for a better meal). If I'm going to pay a premium for "good" food delivered to my room, then that food better be worth the cost. Now, I cannot vouch for everything the hotel has to offer as I only stayed for one evening and did not take advantage of things like the gym, pool, etc., but I honestly cannot believe that anything this hotel has to offer other than its proximity to the downtown Baltimore area makes it anywhere near the cost. Pros:Updated, comfortable, quiet rooms. Shades pull tight and the room stays dark.Prompt, courteous service in all regards. Convenient to downtown and major highways. Cons:Outrageously expensive. Pay for parking. Pay for Internet. Food is not worth the price. More or less pay for anything extra.No microwave or mini-fridge. Needless to say, I will not be staying here again, and unless you really have money to burn, I'd suggest staying elsewhere.Hilton honors member who stays at hIlton properties frequently for business travel.  For a true Hilton Brand hotel, decidedly unimpressive.  Stayed for two nights, management was conspicuously absent, and 50% of the time when we called to get our car from valet or called concierge, phones were not answered.  The "hotel" restaurant is across the street from the hotel.  Otherwise, hotel was clean and modern.  We've received much better service at some of the Hilton brand's less expensive properties.I gave it one star because of its location and the fact that it's physically connected to the Baltimore Convention Center (so I didn't have to walk in the rain).However, if those are the best reasons to stay here... the Hyatt and Marriott also have the same great location and the Hyatt is also connected to the Baltimore Convention Center.To begin, they messed up my reservation. Somehow (which I'm still unsure of), they had me down to leave a day earlier than I reserved. ...which was only noted when I received a reminder email. When I called to get it fixed, they told me the hotel was completely booked and, basically, I was out of luck. After arguing for a LONG time and being transferred around, they FINALLY found a mysterious room to put me in. I have no idea how a hotel can go from no rooms whatsoever so they can't fix THEIR MISTAKE to finding one, but as I needed a place to stay the night, I didn't ask questions.So, I arrive. The rooms are the same quality as a standard lower-end chain. It's not bad, but it's DEFINITELY NOT worth the money. You also have to pay for the Internet by the day.One of my co-workers was staying in the Marriott, another in the Hyatt, and I STRONGLY urge you to try those places before trying this hotel. They're both within a block or two from the Hilton (and the Hyatt is right by the Inner Harbor). Not only that, but the lobbies are nicer (the Marriott has a self-serve bar wall), the gym hours are more convenient, the Internet is FREE, the rooms are significantly better quality, and the staff is waaaay better. Don't waste your time or money at the Baltimore Hilton.We stayed at this location for three days during the last big snowstorm during the World Series of Poker circuit event. We stay in lots of hotels all over the country and assumed that the Hilton would be a safe bet. We guessed so, so wrong. We were nickeled and dimed throughout our stay and left really disappointed that we didn't choose one of the other numerous hotels in the area.Parking:$40/day for valet.$28/day self in a lot that is partially public...meaning limited security at best. You have to buy a new ticket every 24 hours and they rip and wear down and stop working pretty quickly. Wi-Fi:NO FREE WIFI.Hilton advertised this as 'free in lobby' meaning free in the overpriced "Lobby Bar," and non-functional on the days that I was there. I listened to several of my fellow guests struggle with access while waiting for my order. You can only get the password by requesting it from the bartender, and, I'm assuming, some medium social pressure to buy something.  Otherwise you can pay $13-15 in the rooms or use the computers in the pitiful 'business center' attached to the UPS store for $6/hr.Food Options: Expensive room service, mediocre food at the attached Diamond Tavern. Vending machines are $3 for 16 oz. sodas, and on the guest floors the vending machines only take credit cards. This location also boasts a Jimmy Johns and a Starbucks in the attached East Building, both with limited hours. There is also a Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf in the lobby that we literally never saw open the entire length of our three-day stay. They close at 2PM.  No bottled water in the rooms, complimentary coffee/tea is cheap instant. No complimentary breakfast offerings like the sister chains and not even as much as free water in the lobby.The bar in the lobby closed early (1:30 AM) on Friday night, the night we decided to head back early and catch a nightcap...so we sat there hoping for the bartender to come back from a break for a good ten minutes. Several staff members were at the front desk chatting, but no one came over to serve us or tell us that the bar had closed up early. Other nights we were there, the bar was packed and open until 2AM, so we have no idea what happened.NO FRIDGES OR MICROWAVES included in the room rate. This seems crazy to me. You can allegedly request a fridge brought to your room, but this is an extra charge. No experience on whether this is a daily charge or a one-time charge, but based on everything else, I'm sure it's daily.Most importantly we stayed on the 15th floor and our ice machine was RIDDLED WITH BLACK MOLD. At first I thought I was seeing things, then I thought it may have been the provided ice bucket. Finally, when I got home I stated unpacking my travel cooler and found even blacker mold-all over everything that I'd poured the ice from the machine on. Seriously gross and a health hazard. Not impressed.Cleanliness: Room itself was very clean. NO bedbugs in mine (believe me, I checked).However, there were shopping bags of other people's trash in the parking deck, in the elevator lobby to the parking garages, in the rooms with the vending machines....I saw them everywhere and was pretty grossed out. Maybe they need to provide bigger trash cans for guests in public areas, but I saw the same leaky brown paper bag of garbage sitting in the corner every time I went in and out of the vending machine area for three days.Service: All of the individual employees I spoke with face to face were incredibly polite, cordial, and helpful. I'd like to give specific shout outs to the housekeeping ladies working on my floor on 3/8/2015...I ran out of my room looking for towels and they handed me over a big stack, no questions asked. The employees working the parking gate were great too-I had issues with my ticket repeatedly and they were very patient with me. Echoing the earlier reviews, I did have two unsatisfactory interactions with the Guest Services line that I dialed from within the room. On day one I noticed that we had a burned out bulb and requested a replacement.....which never came. For two more days. On Check-out day, I requested that a bellman come help us with our bags....only to never hear from them again after giving them my room number. Finally, when my boyfriend checked out he was not even offered a receipt for our stay. You know how at fast food chains they advertise "If our cashier doesn't offer X, we'll give you an entree free?" Yeah. When Taco Bell has more efficient customer service procedures in effect than a major hotel chain, you know you're in trouble.I have been on hold on and off for almost 30 minutes to try to verify a rate for reservations. I am looking to currently book a room for this impending snow storm since I am a nurse at University of Maryland.  I called the number on the website and was put on hold for 20 MINUTES to then be told I need to call the location for the exact rates and to see if I can get an extended check out time since I work night shift and its crazy to be told I need to check out at 3PM! So I called the direct number given to me and have been on  even make s reservation for 15 MINUTES!!!  I have yet to speak with anyone!  I am done with this hotel and I will be telling all my coworkers who are looking for a room to go else where!!!The hotel is in an excellent location. I didn't think to ask for a room facing the field. (I recommend it!) I stayed on the 14th floor, where the halls had a peculiar odor--I couldn't identify it. My room didn't smell very fresh either, but after a long walk down odor hall, I noticed it less. I noted the rooms are a little worn, but my bed was comfy and I'll always favor the PTR soaps. The gentleman at the front desk was concerned about anything I had to say in regards to my room or my stay. I don't think it's worth as much as they charge, but I guess they base it on location. For a HILTON tho, I would think they'd upgrade some of their amenities.Overall, had a pretty nice stay for two nights during an Orioles' home stand and two large meetings occurring at the hotel, as well as a religious convention at the convention center. The hotel is large enough so you don't feel crowded. The value of the stay itself is not worth the price but you are paying for convenience, location and view above all.For previous reviews: stairs are not locked. My kids and I used the end stairs several times (they thought it would be fun to go from floor 4 to 14. Ha). The elevators may get crowded but there was never a wait for a second car. Cons: not too many. We had a stadium view room so it was pricier, and the room lacked a refrigerator. The TV was HD on only the local channels. Some outlets were very loose and there were very few to plug in devices. Wireless internet will cost a premium rate. The patio overlooking the stadium is very small but it wasn't too crowded. The patio also closes at 10pm every night and they are strict about this (games both nights went past 10).
