Pool is nice but it's a lap pool (narrow and shallow) but my kids didn't seem to mind at all. Room service forgot some items. Parking is premium and the rates ($28 self, $40 Valet) is per night, not per stay nor in/out. The load/unload area is very small for the hotel's large footprint so be ready to wait as someone likes to stop in the middle of the driveway to unload (why they don't just put this zone on Eutaw St??) Lobby bar service, especially after games, is non existent. Check in at 4pm is serious, if you arrive before you may not have a room ready. If you are in the "south wing" facing west, use the curtains as the ballpark view side can look directly into your rooms. Pros: For all the people and the street noise (Hi Pickles and Sliders!), rooms are insanely quiet and the black out curtains work very well. Staff were all kind and eager to help. Fitness center is large, great view of the ballpark and no wait to use machines. Lobby is very large and has lots of seats/sofas to stretch out on. Card access to patio, pool and fitness center keeps out the non-guests. Beds are very comfy. Lobby, rooms, and auxiliary areas are very clean. Bell staff always available. Location, location, location. Can't beat the views and access to downtown spots. Front desk always staffed at right times so wait times are minimal. There is a fee for late checkout but they give a grace period.Walking Distance to Ball Park & Inner Harbor Restaurants and Sights.  Very nice hotel, Good Staff, Very nice Concierge Lounge that offers Breakfast, Lunch, and (Snacks & Drinks 24/7). Not a Fancy, but a Clean Room with Nice Views.  Would Stay here again.  I strongly suggest the Concierge Upgrade if available.  I also suggest walking a couple blocks to M & S grill for their Happy Hour Specials.Enjoy, Chef Gary CurryWhen you're somebody's mistress, you expect to be treated like a queen.  At least that's what I've seen on t.v. and read in chick-lit books.  As I am not officially someone's mistress,  a friend was kind enough to put me up here  to hang out while he was doing some learning.  Like some have said, the view of Camden is great, and the lobby is beautiful.The Diamond Tavern patio on a Friday afternoon is not too shabby, particularly when you knock over your drink and they give you a complimentary new one.  Granted, later than night when you're drunk off your ass, that doesn't seem so great.What's not great is when you're hungover and HOUSEKEEPING comes banging on your door at 9 a.m. on a Saturday morning.  Who. The. Feck. Does. That.In reality, of the Baltimore hotels I've stayed at in the past two months, this wasn't too bad.  But really, wait until checkout time before you come a'knockin, because I may be a'barfin.For me, the Hilton Baltimore will forever represent overly expensive, inattentive housekeeping and awful customer service. Choose another hotel. A) Their housekeeping staff is inattentive. Morning one, I discover no hair dryer in my room. Day two, the made up my room and failed to leave towels. Day three, failed to refresh the stash of in-room coffee. B) The hotel staff didn't care that housekeeping made so many mistakes!  When I spoke to front desk staff about my issues, there was no apology, no "oh my gosh, I can't believe that. How can I make it right?" In fact, on the morning I was coffeeless, they wouldn't even give me a free cup of joe. C) My room was $289/night. For those prices, I expect stellar and I received mediocre.  If you're in Baltimore for a convention, find yourself a different hotel.Don't be fooled this place is ghetto. Upon arrival it looks swank and hip but it is GHETTO.The lobby area is very nice and the check-in staff are really nice. The folks at the bell desk are also great as well. If you're an Orioles fan, this Hilton also has an enviable location right next to the ball park.(Otherwise there's not much around to do at night. But you can cab it up to Mount Vernon which is not too far away if you're looking for a bar or two)  If you're on the right side of the hotel and are on a higher floor you can watch the game from your room. The Hilton Hhonors Gold lounge also serves good cookies and coffee. These are the nice things about the hotel.Here are the not so nice things:-key cards for rooms do not work well. You have to insert key, leave it in for   about a second then slowly pull out. If you do it too fast you can't get into your  room.-no 24 Hour room service....they stop at 11:00pm-WTF??????-When we did order room service it took two hours....FOR WINGS!!! I will note  that there was a convention so there were probably a lot of room service orders  but that's what planning ahead is for.-I am supposed to have free wi-fi but I couldn't get a decent signal all weekend  and  their home page had trouble identifying me.-It was bad enough that I did not have my Double-A to iron my shirt for me,  forcing me to do it myself. The iron leaked water out of the holes on the  bottom so that instead of  pressing my shirt, my shirt was soaked.-I paid $11 for a Stoli and soda but they were out of limes so I had to have lime  juice in my $11 cocktail. If that doesn't go into Webster's dictionary as an  example of the word "Ghetto" I don't know what does.Very disappointing experience. If you HAVE to stay here because of a convention (or a baseball game) come expecting to be underwhelmed.
review_content_60: What is wrong with this hotel? I came here to stay for one night for Otakon 2014. One night for 4 adults costed $250 - with no free breakfast and no free wifi. We came here early to check in and they charged us $25 extra! My friends and I wanted everyones names on the receipt (so we could get reimbursement from Otakon for volunteering), so we paid an extra $20. It seems like this hotel charges for everything. However, we later realized that after we paid the $20, the hotel didn't even put our names on the receipt! We asked them to print out a receipt with all our names - especially since we PAID for it - but they refused.In our hotel room, we called housekeeping and asked for extra towels and shampoo since the room did not have enough for all four of us, but they did not bring any up. Room did not have a fridge or a microwave. The tap water tasted horrible, even after we boiled it. Bed sheets felt slick and disgusting. Would NEVER stay here again, especially since we were charged almost $300 for one night. We changed hotels for Baltimore Harbor Hotel, which costed $300 for two nights with free breakfast, free wifi, great housekeeping, and friendly service. Don't come to Hilton guys, ever.I was there for a week for a conference a couple of weeks ago (July 2013).  My 13-year-old son accompanied me.PROS* GREAT location across the street from Camden Yards if you're an Orioles fan (I am). The gym looks out right into the field, so on the night I didn't attend a game, I was able to watch it while working out and sitting on the terrace.* Very close to the Inner Harbor, the Aquarium, and other sites.* Nice room, comfortable beds.* Had room service one morning, and it was excellent. I requested a 7:30-8:00am time frame, and there was a knock on the door at exactly 7:30! Food was hot and delicious.* The Sunday brunch staff at the Diamond Tavern was awesome! MIDDLE OF THE ROAD* Front desk staff and concierge were polite and helpful, but just answered my questions. Didn't offer any additional info or assistance above and beyond what I was asking.  (Example: To concierge, "Do you have a weekend schedule for the MARC trains?" Answer: "The MARC trains don't run on weekends."  End of conversation. Had to keep asking questions regarding options to get to DC on the weekends.)* I asked front desk for a room on a higher floor, and we were put on the 4th floor.* Clock in room was two and a half hours off, and in-room safe didn't work.CONS* No mini fridge in room.* Several homeless people right outside the hotel leaning against the walls. I have no problem helping someone, getting them some food, etc., but many of these people were very aggressive (high/drunk). One three occasions, I was walking past someone and they called out to me. I continued to walk and they started screaming at me, demanding that I "get back here."  It was starting to scare my son. One of these times, about a block from the hotel, two people were walking towards us, one of them pushing a shopping cart. As they passed us, the one with the shopping cart quickly pushed it toward us, like he was "joking" and about to slam it into us.* My beefs were mostly with housekeeping. One time, I had to retrieve something from my room for a meeting that was about to begin. The housekeeping cart was right in front of my door, blocking it. Also, the door was closed. You ALWAYS clean rooms with the door wide open, and never lock yourself inside. I had to push the cart away and open the door.  At that point, the housekeeper got annoyed that I was entering the room (just what was she doing??) and said she was cleaning it now. I apologized, but said I needed something important.* Another time, I came back and found that the housekeeper just basically made the beds and changed the towels.  Did not restock any of the shampoos, lotion, or coffee packets and cups. Also left a plate of dirty dishes with crumbs all over the table.  I called downstairs and explained the situation.  I had to get to a meeting, but when I got back, whoever came just brought a bunch of shampoos and lotion and tossed them on the bathroom counter (instead of placing them on the tray). Didn't restock the coffee and still left the dirty dishes.* Yet another day, the housekeeper didn't even START cleaning the room until 5:30PM!  I've never had a room cleaned that late. I understand that maybe they were short-staffed that day or something, but both my son and I had to shower and change for an evening event. We both also needed to use the bathroom to answer an urgent call.  The housekeeper just replied, "I'll be done in about 15 minutes or so." We had to use the bathroom in the men's locker room at the gym, and then stand there and wait so we could shower and change to go out. (It was longer than 15 minutes.)Summary:  This shook my faith in Hilton hospitality.I have a lot of experience at Hilton Hotels as traveling consultant, have stayed in many of their hotels in many countries.  Loved them all.  Then this experience shook my faith in Hilton hospitality.  I was looking at the site as a potential wedding base:  big block of rooms, bridal suite, and brunch for 120 guests - aka BIG money, and was treated poorly by the Director of Catering (no confirmation of visit, 30+ minute wait, constant checking of her blackberry during appointment, no follow-up on questions asked).  I  DO NOT RECOMMEND this spot for anyone planning a large event.Whole Story (likely only to interest brides and other event planners):My fiancee and I were considering using the Hilton Baltimore, Inner Harbor as our wedding party hotel block, bridal suite (overlooking Camden Yards), and brunch location.  We had tried to make an appointment to view the suite and brunch venues and were directed by Sales Manager to make an appointment with the Director of Catering, Manager on Duty, let's call her M.M did not respond to our requests for an appointment via email the few days prior to our planned visit to Baltimore and as we were in the area visiting other wedding vendors, we dropped in at the Hilton anyways and spoke to concierge.  They informed us that M had been notified we were there and would be down shortly.  We waited over 30 minutes - during which time the concierge disappeared and we had no updates.  When a different person came to the un-manned concierge desk, we explained our situation and he called M who was down in 5 minutes.M claimed not to have been notified of our arrival and did not recall being asked to have an appointment prior to our visit.  Nor did she stop checking her Blackberry the entire 15 minutes we spent with her.  She did not provide us with any pricing or catering details (we asked to see sample brunch options) nor did she offer to follow up with us on our questions.  It has been 4 days since our visit and I don't think we will hear from her.  Needless to say, this is not thesort of treatment I would expect from someone in hospitality, particularly when the customer is a HHonors Gold member looking to spend a few thousand dollars.All my experiences at Hiltons around the world have been top notch and this really disappoints.Five hour wait to get roomHospitality is non existent. Go anywhere elseThis place was simple amazing...But for some strange reason they do not have water after several request we went to buy it from another store.Competative rate, excellent location, fanastic front desk staff and always a warm welcome from the bell hop. I have stayed at the Holiday Inn and Marriott at Camden Yard and this Hilton tops them all without a shadow of a doubt. Certainly not the most outstanding Hilton I have stayed at but definately far from the worst. The Camden Yard area has a lot of traffic so the rooms are a little run-down (scratches on the walls, outlets not working, etc) but certainly not something they can't overcome easily at Hilton. Room service and maid service is on point....I will be back for sure.I stayed at this hotel during the weekend of Otakon 2014.  From check-in to check-out, I experienced nothing but helpful and courteous assistance from staff.  Whether it be ensuring I got internet service in my room, or bringing up extra toilet, paper, my needs were addressed in a timely and friendly manner.  The only real downside to the location is the cost of parking on-site, which the Hilton has no control over (garage owned by the city).  Even on move-out Sunday, where EVERYONE is trying to escape the grasp of the long elevator waits, the Hilton staff came to the rescue.  Knowing that upper floor dwellers were getting the stiff end because of people riding up to go down, one of the cleaning staff ensured we got down much more quickly via the staff elevators.  My time at the hotel has made the Hilton #1 on my preferred lodging franchises.I stayed here for 3 nights and paid $140 a night during a recent conference held in the hotel. As such, my cost-to-value ratio should be taken into account considering how much more some other reviews paid for their stay, and how much higher expectations would be at those rates.The lobby is modern and airy, and the conference spaces/ballrooms are as well. The hotel in general seems to have been built fairly recently. The front desk was quick and the bell station was kind enough to loan me an umbrella on rainy days while I was there. The concierge was polite but both times I asked for food recommendations they quickly pointed me to the Diamond Tavern- the hotel restaurant. The area around the hotel seems tourist friendly- several restaurants and bars within a few blocks from the conference center.My double queen bed room was clean and modern, with a large window, a desk and a good size flat screen tv. The dresser drawers kept popping open though, and I almost tripped over it one night. The bathroom was also clean and modern, which was important to me. The walls seemed sufficiently thick too. I avoided the housekeeping drama mentioned by other reviewers by leaving the do-not-disturb sign on the door until I left the room.Overall I had a pleasant stay, and it was a convenient walk to the inner harbor area after the conference. My biggest complaint about the hotel though is not necessarily their fault- it was the lack of breakfast places close by. Lunch and dinner places abound, but not so much breakfast. There is a Starbucks about 4 blocks away but that was about it, unless you're willing to spend $15-20 for an just an average breakfast at the Diamond Tavern.My parents and I stayed here for 1 night and it's a very nice hotel!  We stayed on the Executive floor so they provided a complimentary breakfast (fruit, pastries, toast, hard boiled eggs, coffee, etc) and also had a happy hour (cheese and crackers, fruit, nuts & snack mixes, etc) but you had to pay for the drinks :(They also have a very nice gym and a lap pool!  But me and my parents went for a run in the morning along the Inner Harbor, which is just down the street from the hotel!  It's about a 10 minute walk to hit the heart of the harbor.I appreciated that although the rooms did not come with refrigerators (and they said that there was a fee to get one in your room), they did offer to store my allergy vials for free in their fridge downstairs.I stayed at this hotel for a convention in August 2013. With convention block pricing, the nightly rates are pretty acceptable. The hotel is very clean, and a nice social center during downtime at conventions, and the covered walkway to the Baltimore Convention Center was very convenient. As far as cleanliness goes, the hotel was pretty clean, leaving me with no complaint. It looks very modern, well kept, and the rooms and public areas had an overall pleasing appearance. However, the hotel's size also was a disadvantage. They only have six elevators that run the entire span of the hotel, which lead to huge crowds of people and long wait times in order to get on an elevator. This was compounded by the fact that they normally keep their staircases locked except in emergencies, so the only options to get to your room is either wait for an elevator, or wait for someone to unlock the stairs.What got me though was that the hotel lacks a few basic amenities that you would normally expect in a hotel - there was no mini-fridge or microwave in the rooms, and the WiFi was kinda expensive, especially since the rate was per device, per day. Because of these, I'm planning on staying at a different hotel next year instead.Not set up to handle the amount of guests it accommodates. Nice staff, but overworked. New facility without effective technology - slowest elevators ever. Avoid this hotel - there are better in Baltimore.Nice looking Hilton but inconsistent on several levels.Pros: 1.  Beautiful lobby - Spacious and glass enclosed2.  Lobby bar - Friendly bartenders and attentive service3.  Diamond restaurant - Great lunch entree in the crab cake salad with roasted fennel  I could eat that for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  But pretty pricey even by hotel standards.  The breakfast buffet is good but overpriced at $18.  The omelet bar was a nice touch and service was impeccable for breakfast and lunch; the staff is super friendly too.4.  Pet friendly - for a $50 plus tax fee.  But because I did have my dog in the hotel, the staff didn't clean the room and I had to hunt down towels and toiletries.5.  Some of my coworkers had views of the Oriole Stadium.  In fact, location is probably one of the best features of this Hilton, especially if you are a baseball fan.  Lots of bars and restaurants within walking distance.Cons:1.  Diamond bar service is pretty bad at prime happy hour.  Coworker kept trying to get a drink at the bar and was kept waiting forever.  A server was supposed to be sent to us at the outside table but no one ever came.2.  They charge for wi-fi. 3.  Minor wear and tear issues:  Towels were a little worn with little holes and some stains.  Room had damp smell because carpet was recently shampooed and still quite damp.4.  No mini fridge.Overall, a nice hotel that needs a few improvements.  Depending on the room rate, I would come back for a visit.It's a pretty swanky looking place but my stay here came with a few minor inconveniences. 1.Ya gotta pay for wifi. Don't stay here if you're going to need frequent access to the good ol' interwebs and you hate the thought of shelling out 14 bucks a day for it. 2. THERE IS NO MINIFRIDGE! This was a sad, sad realization for me. I stayed here for 4 days and I couldn't keep any of my leftovers, so I had to eat every bit of what I ordered out because I didn't want to waste it. I blame the Hilton for the 15 pounds I likely gained as a result. What was even more torturous.. was that there was a perfect little nook for which a mini fridge could be housed; I would look at it and think "My leftovers would look wonderful inside of a minifridge placed right there in that corner."3. Their staff is painfully clueless... about everything. It's like they went to the middle of nowhere Utah, picked up a bunch of people, dressed them in hotel staff garb and dropped them off at the Baltimore Hilton. If you want to know something about anything Baltimore or hotel related... ask anyone else. If someone told me I had to stay here again I wouldn't be too upset about it. It was a clean place and I'm not that fussy but I would probably attempt to bring my own freakin' minifridge.I stayed at the Hilton Baltimore for a conference in March 2012.  The staff was very friendly and the lobby/hotel had a funky modern decor.  The conference took place in the event rooms that were connected to the hotel, so staying there was very convenient.As other reviewers mentioned, the parking was a bit much ($28 a night).  I think they should comp at least one night for guests.  Our room was on the 11th floor in the corner.  The room was very small, but the bed was pretty comfortable.Horribly rude staff at front desk, operator, and housekeeping. I was in town for a meeting and the convention staff were great. Sheets were dirty and had hair that was not mine on it. Did not clean the room well, items left behind from another guest Rude whenever I would call down for anything. Rooms are in need of an upgrade and remodel. I asked where the gym was at check in and I got a 'last time I checked it was on the 4th fl' WHAT?!?! Rude!!!I stayed here on business last week and it was a nice hotel. Centrally located, clean, new, and seemingly well run. My only complaint, aside from the poor lighting in the bathrooms in the guesi rooms, came on the morning of my departure... I was walking down the hall from my room to the elevator with my suitcase and the housekeeper popped out of a room and asked me which room I had just left, which I found to be slightly unprofessional.Let me be clear--the 2 stars is relative to cost, expectations, and the Hilton brand. The hotel is huge, clean, and beautiful. If I had paid, say, $200 a night, I would give it 5 stars. Easily. The problem is I paid around $500 a night for a hotel directly overlooking Camden Yards in Baltimore's most tourist-friendly area. That's not a cheap room (although it's not a penthouse suite rate, either), and Baltimore is definitely not New York City.First off, the Internet was down for two days of my stay. Okay, so I'll read a book instead of browsing the Internet. That's just an inconvenience, albeit a quite large one nowadays. But it made doing any work completely impossible. They did offer the alternatives of sitting either in their noisy front lobby or in their cramped mailroom, both of which had working Internet. Not their fault, of course, but quite a damper on what I was hoping to be a simplified, relaxed work environment.Second, the rooms were small with very little in them. No mini-fridge, mini-bar, or microwave, and there was a dirty, difficult, unsynchronized alarm clock with awful speakers for your iPod. The shower had a curtain that was too high and only a thin rail that separated it from the rest of the bathroom. Every shower ended with water spilling everywhere. If I were paying a more modest rate, these are trivial problems not even worth mentioning. But given the cost, these were frustrating.Lastly, the maids knocked incessantly if I accidentally forgot to put up the 'Do Not Disturb' door hanger. It started around 9:00 and involved two mornings where maids walked in while I was wearing less than I would have hoped. (Even my cries of 'I'm here!' and 'Don't come in!' were to no avail.)I thought I was splurging to have a comfortable, stress-free stay at a hotel that takes pride in their hospitality. Instead, I felt like a guest at a quaint 2- or 3-star hotel who was practically being robbed blind.I only stayed here one night. Overall experience was good. The front desk people were pleasant. The bar service was a little slow.  It's in walking distance to a lot of things and about 30 minutes from the BWI airport. If you are planning to park a car at valet it's $40 per night. You have to pay separate from your hotel bill unless you prearrange it before hand. At least that's what the valet guy said!I belabored in my decision about how many stars.  They would totally get 4 if they had honored the preferences I shared when I booked, but the customer service they provided prevented them from getting two. THE BAD: When I booked the room, I requested a king bed with a view of Camden Yards and was told that one was available and that we'd get one.  A king bed is a simple pleasure that really makes us feel like we're on vacation.  All that space is a luxury.  When I checked in, the receptionist said she was sorry, but there were no king beds available.  The only ballpark-view rooms available were ones with two double beds.  No way jose!  I'm not downgrading from our queen at home while on vacation.  I expressed my sadness and said that a king bed was really important to us.  Nothing could be done, but we got loaded up with perks:  a voucher for 4 alcoholic drinks at their bar, a voucher for two breakfast meals at their restaurant, and an upgrade to the VIP lounge.  Despite my disappointment at the bed situation, I appreciated the receptionist's sympathetic nature and the manner in which she tried to compensate us for our disappointment and inconvenience.  We ended up pushing the beds together and it wasn't entirely terrible. THE GOOD: We had a view of Camden Yards, an absolute must for my O's-loving husband's birthday weekend.  We spent a weekend in B-more for his 26th, and a view of the ballpark was one of the best parts.  We were on the 18th floor... it was awesome!  The room was clean, with updated decor.  The beds were super comfortable.  Heavenly comforter and pillows.  The housekeeper was timely and efficient. Overall, I would try this place again.  The stay was enjoyable for both me and my husband.  If my preferences would be disregarded a second time, then I'd boycott.As the biggest hotel in Baltimore, it's impressive. However, don't let the size and modernized ways fool you. They have MAJOR issues.I stayed for a client's week long conference, and had presidential floor access...Cons:1. They never clean up. Order room service and watch the plates in your room and hallway pile up. I've had a plate of dried lasagna sit in front of my door for 3 days. Housekeeping doesn't take it with them (I guess it isn't their job) and room service never comes back to pick up the plates. EVERY floor you walk on will have the smell of food in the hallways. Guaranteed. Even after several calls and complaints, having presidential status didn't matter much.2.Roof leaks. Randomly at 4am, I thought I was dreaming that my toilet was overflowing, but the light bulb in the shower was pouring out water! I called down to let them know and no one ever came. EVER. However, I guess they went upstairs to check the room above me. To this day, I don't know if it was a problem in my room or upstairs.3.Elevator has one set of buttons, on the farthest side at that. Not saying you need to have more, but it saves a walk, seeing as though the hotel is already oddly shaped with extremely long hallways.4. Location - Because it's beside the stadiums, and a main street right off the interstate, traffic can be horrible and the parking prices are insane.Pros:1. Room had coffee and tea! I left a note for housekeeping to stock me up extra time and they kept at it the entire week. Happy to have had them.2. Housekeeping is on point, they work very hard, almost all day long I see them (it's a huge hotel!) and they are always friendly.3.There was construction done on the hotel for a day, and the next day we received a apology note with a candy bar shaped like a hammer :) It's the little things...4. Food - there's multiple places to eat, happy hour, and the food isn't bad at all.5. View - I could see the oriole stadium from my window6. Location - see #5, it's right next door to each other, a few blocks away from the harbor and cabs run right by the front door. You can't ask for a better location of downtown baltimore.Overall, I enjoyed my stay, and definitly miss the bed. Now THAT is what I wish I could've taken with me...
review_content_80: No shortage of great views at Hilton - gym, concierge lounge, room - everywhere I went, I had a great view of Camden. Location and views are impressive. Here's the rundown on the rest from a business stay point of view:Internet - good effort, but a FAIL: Two options for internet 1536K down or 768K - chose 1536, but only got .67Mb/s down on speedtest.net speedtest.net/result/961... for wireless - wired was slightly better, but not much - .97Mb/s down speedtest.net/result/961...Room - comfortable, clean - what you'd expect at a Hilton.Concierge lounge pretty good, but nothing exceptional.Gym - very solid Hilton gym - probably one of the best Hotel gym options in Baltimore. Pool is not your average BS pool for the kids - if you're a swimmer you'll appreciate it - there's a sauna to boot.Pros- Beautiful hotel with a great view of Camden Stadium- Very nice facilities for conferencesCons (Staff)- Fast-Food-like staff- Anything off the menu/script like resolving an incorrect charge lead to "deer in headlight" stares- Have little to no authority to resolve anything- Staff could easily be replaced by a kiosk- To their credit, they were courteous but not really empowered to provide above and beyond serviceWith its nice modern and well appointed rooms to its view of Camden Yards, where you can watch the Orioles play for free on the 4th floor terrace next to the gym, this is a great place to stay and get a real nice taste of Baltimore. The location is really good, next to the light rail ( easy access the airport); proximity to the convention center; the aforementioned closeness to Camden Yards; and a free Charm Bus stop located right outside of the hotel (allowing you easy access to the tourist areas), there is no need for a car and pay the $35 a day it will cost you to park a car here. Gym, although as mentioned in another review, the gym's hours are only from 6 am to 10 pm. However, it is well equipped with nice Precor machines, free weights and is roomy enough for stretching, yoga etc. Concierge level for Gold+ HHonors members allows you access to unlimited access to non-alcoholic drinks and snacks, as well as continental breakfast in the morning and light appetizers in the evening.Got to stay here for a convention. Nicest hotel I've stayed in this year. Everything is so new and so fresh and clean! The rooms are modern enough to be fresh, but still warm in a traditional way.The fitness center is top of the line. Each treadmill and elliptical and bike has it's own tv. They've also got weights and weight machines, and a good-sized pool.The best part is the view of Camden Yards! Any of the odd numbered rooms have an awesome view of the ball field. And if you end up in an even numbered room, you still have a great view of the park from the end of the hallway and the fitness center. As is typical of these hotels, relatively nothing is included - you have to pay for the internet, the breakfast, and the business center. But if you're there for business and it's not your bill, it's a great set up.Big city Hiltons generally don't disappoint, and this one is no exception. I stayed three nights, non-consecutive, and have no complaints. Yeah, the parking is too expensive (as are all downtown hotels), and room service was too expensive (ditto), so is the wifi (ditto) but if you're looking for cheap you don't stay at a Hilton...The room service itself was very good. The wifi was fast. The staff was friendly, the room was comfortable and reasonably quiet. The lobby is quite big and inviting, rare for a downtown hotel. The location is fantastic if you're doing something at the Convention Center or Camden Yards, and very good if you're headed to the inner Harbor.Why only four stars, instead of five? Because the damn building blocks the view of the Baltimore skyline from Camden Yards! That view was one of the reasons they built the stadium there, and left centerfield open. For that, I can never forgive the Hiltons...The staff is very friendly and the location is great, outside of that, I found this Hilton product incredibly overpriced for what you get. The room was worn and had an odd (and unpleasant) smell. The tub filled with water while we were showering and took 30+ minutes to drain. The sink drained slowly, too. The room corridors were freezing, yet we couldn't get the room itself to cool enough to be comfortable. We won't be returning unless we find a deal that provides a substantial savings on the rooms, because what we experienced certainly wasn't worth $300+ a night.I recently stayed at this property for business and experienced superior levels of service from Jason in food and Beverage and Josh Porter in sales! What an unforgettable experience from check in, to check out. This has quickly become my number one place to stay while in Baltimore.I travel at least 2-3 days month. I have stayed at Hilton hotels (and every other chain) many times all over the world, and this was by far the absolute worst experience I have ever had. I am an HHonors member (I even have the credit card) and am now thinking about canceling my membership and credit card.When we pulled into the self-park garage to park upon our arrival (we are from DC), we accidently got confused and parked in a "Hilton Reserved" spot thinking it was reserved for guests. Turns out it is reserved for valet, which isn't mentioned anywhere. We load up our bags, our dog (this is a dog friendly hotel) and start shuffling towards the entrance. Then we hear someone yelling at us from a parked car. They are yelling at us about how we are in a valet spot. Of course we appreciated someone telling us, but they were incredibly rude towards us and didn't even both to get out of the car to come give us a heads up, instead just shouted meanly at us. So low class! We were clearly paying guests and they treated us like trash. We asked her name, and turns out her name is "Kia" and she works at the concierge. Worst personality EVER! We would have of course moved the car right away, but she could have nicely given us a heads up without heckling us as we have our hands full with bags, etc. My fiance was LIVID, but we put it behind us, move the car to a new spot, and went to check in.Upon check in, I'm told our room isn't ready. It is just a few minutes before 4pm by this point. We are asked if it is OK for us to wait while it is cleaned, which we reluctantly say is fine. I wouldn't normally care, but we're in the middle of a busy lobby with our dog... not ideal for us or other hotel guests. We also have a 5pm dinner reservation for my fiance's birthday. About 20 minutes go by and we are called back in for a room that is now open. Oops, turns out someone else in the time that the lady came to get us in the waiting area to when she swipes my card has taken our room. Would we mind taking a Harbor View instead of a ballpark view? I say no, only because it is my fiance's birthday and we have tickets to the O's game at 7pm, and we're making a whole baseball theme of the weekend (why we specifically booked at this Hilton). We are asked to wait for another room to be "rush" cleaned. Another 30 minutes go by, and finally we're checked in to a Ballpark View room. They offer us two breakfast vouchers, and a couple free drink tickets. My biggest complaint -- a manager never once came over to apologize to us, ask if we'd like a drink, or offer a cart to help us with our bags. Totally useless management as far as I'm concerned... I saw them at the desk approving our vouchers and looking our way but nobody ever came over to say a word to us. That's a first. Not a big deal that there were mistakes and our room wasn't ready, but come on, just have a manager come over and at least pretend this hotel cares about its guests. Nada.An hour later, we're finally heading up to the top floor to check into our room. At this point, we had missed our 5pm reservation at a nearby seafood restaurant, and we were both hungry and ready to leave our stuff and head over to the stadium to find something to eat. We arrive on the 20th floor, and start walking towards our room. There are a handful of dirty trays outside of quite a few rooms, I'm guessing because room service is cleaning and leaving them there. It was gross to see people's half eaten food in the hallway... ick.The positive -- the room was nice. Clean and had a nice view. It was everything I had expected. We get back from the game that night and have a chilled bottle of white wine and cheese platter waiting for us. This is really nice, but since there was no note or anything, we were a bit confused. None the less, we appreciated what we figured was a nice gesture from the management for our troubles (it was also my fiance's birthday which we mentioned on the reservation, so that might have been it). Cherry on top -- I later learned that my mother called the hotel from overseas and ordered surprise a bottle of champagne and a birthday note for my fiance, and neither were ever delivered to our room (or mentioned once). Her credit card hasn't been charged yet, so hopefully we won't have to deal with yet another fiasco with this hotel.All and all, we had a pretty crappy stay at this hotel. I read the reviews before staying here, and while I noticed other themes from reviews, I am usually a big fan of Hilton and decided to give it the benefit of the doubt. Big mistake on my part!If you need the bare bones, stay here. If you want a fun, relaxing weekend with great customer service, run away. We stayed at the Four Seasons in Harbor East last December, and were treated fabulously and didn't have any issues at all.Two thumbs down from a once loyal Hilton guest. :(I stayed here during Otakon 2009 (which seems silly since I live in Baltimore), and while the convention sucked (let's be honest, sometimes Otakon can suck), this hotel did not. The room was very comfortable, especially since it was just my boyfriend and I. The bed, oh my god, the bed was so comfortable, and the bathroom was beautiful!The view from the room was also really nice. The staff at the hotel was surprisingly friendly to us. I've been too enough cons and checked in at enough hotels to know the staff usually gives con goers attitude. Maybe because he saw that both my boyfriend and I were from Baltimore? Or maybe because I had a scowl on my face, I don't know. But the staff was friendly.If I had a reason to stay there again, I would.The hotel itself is beautiful...great open lobby, perfect Inner Harbor location, lovely rooms. But the service has been questionable and I can't believe internet in the room is $13 a day! And to park in the garage is $26 a day. Took four hours for my father in law to get more pillows last night. I guess the Hilton family isn't taking care of B'More very well. Still enjoying a great weekend for a fantastic event though!Can't really complain. For $100 on Hotwire, it's a good deal. So close to Camden Yards that if you had a good arm, you could sub in as pitcher. We are HHonors Gold Status which afforded us a very meager continental breakfast in the concierge level lounge which was staffed by folks who could have literally cared less about the whole affair. However, for $100 I was totally satisfied by our experience.I stayed here for only one night. I love the hotel. The lobby is modern and lovely. The staff I talked to was very friendly. The room is spacious and clean with a nice view. The bed is comfortable. The most important of all is the location! I can walk to harbour and had a quick exploration of the downtown during the short stay. I will definitely recommend it!Location, location, location. Hotel could use some updates but the location could not be beat. We could see the stadium from our room and walk to it almost as quickly. Easy to get to the harbor or the convention center.Now that it's been open for a year and has the initial running bugs worked out, it's a great place.Staff in the front of the house were friendly, although one was less helpful when I tried to get them to contact someone in the sales department (I work for Otakon and there was an issue I needed to discuss).Found out they reserved our room as a double when we asked for king, they switched it without issue. The elevators run well, even with the loads of people from Otakon there. The meeting space is well kept and professional looking. The public bathrooms were clean all the time as well.The hotel rooms themselves are of the brand standard. My remote was on the fritz but I never had time to call, so it really didn't matter. The room was well cleaned daily, with the sheets changed per my request.Great hotel, convenient to the convention center, and overall a very pleasant place to stay.High Points: Bell Hops are awesome! Very modern looking Hotel from the inside, great views of Baltimore.Low points: Messed up our reservation, the restaurant associated with them screwed up 2 meals, non existent customer service, unable to get anything right.My wife and I got married at Camden Yards... so it made sense to stay at the Hilton right across the street (right?).... never again. I'm done with Hilton.We are very low maintenance, we didn't ask for anything special, no arrangements, nada. We first thought the Hilton hooked us up! We were staying in a suite looking over the ballpark with a balcony. We had 2 bedrooms and a parlor (enough room for my wife and her party to get ready). We were thrilled!!!! The Hilton also asked for a photo of us so they would know who we were when we got there. OK! Thanks for making us feel like celebrities!But then we showed up..... They had no clue who we were, our rooms weren't ready at 2pm (which they said would not be a problem the day before and that morning), they gave my wife a hard time at check in saying I had to be there. It gets worse.... our suite wasn't as advertised. Turns out the parlor is considered a 2nd bedroom (hint... no bed...), that was a new one to me. When my wife called to correct the problem the front desk manager did take $100 a night off for the trouble. We supposedly got the mid level suite... I'd hate to see the entry level suite. Our room was not dusted, had a leaky sink in the parlor room and no frig anywhere in the suite.All in all our stay at the Hilton was lacking. We don't expect special treatment, but when you tell us "you're special" and then don't deliver.... bad on you.Also throughout the weekend the front desk was not staffed very well - long lines of customers and only 1 person at the front. They were not very friendly and kinda cold.... Never Again.Oh! If you've never stayed in downtown Baltimore before... after city and state tax - add $100 a night in taxes (ouch!).$169/night. Newly built hotel. It's central to Camden Yards and walkable to Inner Harbor. It is very close to University of Maryland (about 3 blocks).See photos.Stayed here for a recent company event. The location is spectacular, especially if you are heading to an Orioles game. The stadium is literally across the street, and may of the suites have an uninhibited view of the playing field, which is great for hosting events.3.5 StarsI stayed here for a business trip and if I was as big of a baseball fan as some, I imagine I'd be pretty stoked about its location. Though it did have easy access to the harbor and the touristy spots including the aquarium. The staff were generally helpful; especially the concierge who recommended a great restaurant for us on our first night. There was an issue though when my boss and I were using the business room/computer lab. We asked (I assume the manager on duty) for help but were told that in order to resolve it we would have to call the number of an external company they use for their computers and other tech equipment, as opposed to just the staff at the hotel, which was inconvenient.The room I stayed in (standard) was very spacious, with sleek bathrooms, but the water pressure wasn't as good as most.Although I didn't eat at the restaurant, we did hit up the bar before we left and it was decent. Nothing extraordinary.Overall it was a nice stay.I am staying here right now and I am extremely disappointed in the level of service. The staff appears to be uncaring and pretty stupid. I brought a jacket down to the front desk last night to be dry cleaned. There was no specific dry cleaning bag in my room, so I asked for one at the front desk. They asked me why I didn't have one. I replied there was no bag in the room. They asked me why not. I replied that I could not explain why their staff had not put their bag in the room, but could they please take this jacket anyway. They put it in a clear plastic bag. They assured me it would be done the next day. They assured me it wouldn't be lost. When it hadn't arrived back by the appointed time the next day, I started calling looking for it. The front desk staff, the housekeeping staff, and everyone I could get on the phone in the span of an hour just said they didn't know anything about it, it was nowhere and I would have to call back in three hours, at 10 pm when the night staff came back on. Waiting until 10 pm to start looking for a lost jacket you need for a meeting the next morning at 7:30 am isn't going to work. A hotel staff should solve problems, not tell you to talk to someone else when they come on the night shift at 10 pm. I called back three more times until I found a manager who located the jacket rumpled up in a plastic bag somewhere. It has never gone out to be cleaned and had spent the night and the day crumpled in the plastic bag. He brought it to my room. But frankly, after having been reassured that my jacket would be dry cleaned in the next 24 hours, and having to spend an hour trying to find it, to discover it was more winkled and dirty than before, is truly terrible service. The manager called later to apologize, but his staff should never have started down this cascade of events.When I called yesterday at noon asking for a sewing kit, I was told someone would bring one up. No one did. I had to call two more times. And to be charged $28 a day to park in their hotel is an insult on top of this. I am extremely disappointed in the staff of this hotel. The manager seems eager to solve my problems, but it's frustrating to spend so much time wading through incompetent staff to get to him.Very disappointed, front desk treated me like if I was asking for a free room. I was a presenter in a conference, everything suppose to be charge in a master account, but, no, they charge me. It has been a week and I still waiting to talk with someone that can say at least " I'm sorry for the mistake" Never going back.

hotel_name: Hotel Monaco Baltimore, a Kimpton Hotel
review_content: When I was shipped off to Baltimore for a work meeting, I must admit, I wasn't too excited. Mainly because all I know about Baltimore comes from Serial and The Wire. Then I saw there was an affordable Kimpton property close to where my meeting was, and alas the tides turned!From the moment I got out of my Uber, to the moment I got back in the Uber to head to the airport, every member of the hotel staff was super friendly and helpful. The bellhop was quick to great me and direct me to the lobby area, which is on the second floor. Check in was a breeze, and the man pouring wine at the happy hour in the lobby was very welcoming.Location was awesome! Even though it was a bit cold for this desert dweller, I walked everywhere and felt safe walking at night.I scheduled breakfast room-service delivery for 7-7:30, and it was right on time. You can also have them print your boarding pass for you with breakfast delivery.When I checked out, I had about an hour to kill before I had to head to the airport and planned to go explore. I got to the front door before I realized I needed to stash my luggage. The bellhop said he would watch my stuff so I didn't have to haul it up back to the front desk.And of course the room was super comfy. Awesome bathroom and shower. If I hadn't been so nervous for my meeting in the morning, I also would have slept amazingly well in the giant king bed.Even though my company picked up the tab, the room rate was super reasonable.Whether you're in Baltimore for business or pleasure, definitely check out Hotel Monaco!My wife and I stayed here a few weekend ago. The hotel is just beautiful and has so much history to learn about since it was once the B and O railroad headquarters. The staff was very friendly. You have to valet your car and I think that cost 30 plus dollars a day.  We stayed in the spa suite with a soaking tub.  The room was big and beautiful and we had plenty of room to relax. There was some dust on the vents that I noticed for being such a nice hotel I thought they would have catch that.       We eat breakfast in the hotel's restaurant both mornings overall good food. The hotel has a wine hour starting at 5pm, so we grab a glass of wine before heading out for dinner.  The hotel is in walking distance of the inner harbor.  After we had dinner we come back and grabbed some drinks from the bar.         We were on the seventh room and overnight my wife and I were woken up several times by trucks driving by.   Overall our stay was great. We would totally stay here again.Really great experience here and overall with Kimpton hotels. Staff was very friendly and answered my questions smoothly, the building itself is beautiful and great that they kept a lot of the historical parks as best they could. Room size was what you'd expect. But bigger than most hotels I've been to. A really solid hotel to stay at if you're in the Baltimore area.This was my first time staying at a Kimpton hotel and I was not disappointed!The hotel is beautiful. It used to be an old train station and the marble decor is absolutely stunning. The rooms themselves were spacious and clean and the bathrooms were also pretty big.I loved that the heat was blasting as soon as you walked into the lobby (it was in the 50s when we visited Baltimore and we are from California). I also loved the fireplace on the left side of the concierge desk, and free happy hour every day at 5!My only real complaint is that we ordered coffee and tea to the room, and it ended up being almost 30 bucks with a 5 dollar delivery charge and tip included (we didn't see the tip was included until after and also tipped room service on top of this). That's a little ridiculous for two beverages! Sidenote - the restaurant attached the the hotel had the worst service ever!My husband and I stayed at the Hotel Monaco, along with several of our friends, for a wedding weekend in Baltimore. We got a decent room block rate on a lovely room, and had a very pleasant stay.I made our reservation over the phone and found the Kimpton crew friendly and easy to talk to throughout the process. We missed the room block rate for our first night before the couple opened up more rooms, and were able to get the cheaper rate applied without any problem when we called again. I also mentioned that we were celebrating our anniversary that weekend (mostly true--it was the Monday), and the hotel sent us a bottle of champagne and a full-on dessert of rich, tasty chocolate peanut butter cakes.The hotel was attractive, definitely renovated but done up in a classically opulent style. I guess the hotel is in the old B & O Railroad building--I must not be the only person who thinks of Monopoly when I hear this, because there were at least a couple Monopoly-related flourishes in the hotel ("Monopolizing My Doom--Do Not Disturb"). It had a historically salient feel that I enjoyed.Our room was comfortable, pretty, and clean, with a nice bed and a decent view--not that we got much use out of that, as we were in for a dim, rainy weekend. The Hotel Monaco was a great place to be stuck, though, when there weren't wedding events going on. We made two visits to the B & O restaurant, and I liked that place a lot, both for food and drink. There was wine in the lobby at happy hour, which we took advantage of at check-in. If the weather were better, the location would've been convenient, but that didn't end up mattering, unfortunately.Staff was pleasant and everything went smoothly overall. I guess cheaper parking would've been nice (something like $37 for overnight), but no real complaints. I'd recommend Hotel Monaco if you're looking for a place to stay in Baltimore. I'll keep it in mind next time we make this trip.This hotel is by far one of my our favorite. High ceiling, room was clean. Complementary humidifier, tooth brush, etc. best of all you can request a pet goldfish for your stay. Also the wine hour with appetizer!!I can't believe for all the times I have stayed at this gorgeous hotel I've yet to do a review.  This one is long overdue and since I stayed here again last week I figured now is the time.This hotel is stunning and at one time was the headquarters for B&O Railroad.  I have stayed at quite a few Kimpton properties (to include numerous Monaco's) and the entrance to the Baltimore Monaco may be the most beautiful.The staff...everything you would expect from a Kimpton Property....Valet, Check-In, Housekeeping, etc...all go above and beyond to ensure that you are satisfied and enjoy the Kimpton experience.  This is what truly sets Kimpton's apart from all others.  Caitlin was awesome and it was so nice of her to send along my welcoming gift too.The rooms are beautiful and very spacious too...the beds are extremely comfortable...the bathrooms huge and very modern.  They also have a decent exercise room that does the trick....One of the most beautiful hotels I have ever visited. Beautiful lobby, great history, friendly staff, comfortable and luxurious rooms. Where else can you grab a handful of Goetze's Caramel Cream upon check-in??Great downtown location. Walking distance to the Inner Harbor and Camden Yards.I am a Hotel Monaco and Kimpton fan for sure!Can I move in?!Oh so fancy...Nice big room.It's clean.High ceilings.A bathroom big enough where you can break dance.Ric Flair robes in the closet. (And a subsequent Instagram video).Comfortable beds.Valet parking.Close to many shops being in the Downtown area of Baltimore.Did I mention the Ric Flair robes in the closet.BTW, Baltimore is much prettier than Hampton Roads. They win.Me likes Monaco. Me wants to go back.The Hotel Monaco team was so helpful throughout our entire visit over Labor Day weekend. We brought our English Bulldog along with us (yay pet-friendly hotels!) and they allowed an early check in to make sure we could get him situated and comfortable. We were easily walking distance to the inner harbor (half a mile?) - it was pretty warm out, so make sure you walk on the shady side of the streets if you venture out in summer!The immediate blocks around the hotel werent the best - lots of homeless people and a few cops on corners at night time.... but my guy and I stuck together whenever we went out in the evenings and we were fine. We also are at the restaurant in the hotel - my guy had a burger and I had the brussel sprouts with some cocktails - if you've OD'ed on local crab... definitely eating at the downstairs restaurant will be a delicious detour.Hotel Monaco offers a wine hour from 5-6pm... we indulged one night and made new friends in the lobby over a glass of sangria - it was lovely!Staff was incredibly friendly (as was everyone in Baltimore!) and the hotel was immaculately clean, even with all the furry friends running around!We are staying in Hotel Monaco for our wedding in Portland, Oregon next year - and after this visit to the Baltimore location, we're thrilled with our choice in supporting such a fantastic place!My wife and i stayed here back in September ... we loved it we had the Mediterranean spa suite and it was unbelievable. ... we were in Baltimore for only one night but we loved the room so much and the price  that we wished we could stay for a week! ... we will definitely be back as soon as we can ... definitely the best hotel in B'more and a true hidden gem we love the Hotel MonacoThe building is gorgeous. Really it is. The majority of the staff we encountered were friendly and accommodating. Room was clean and updated. One gripe- I was told they swipe your card for $75/night for incidentals (which is reversed) and is the norm at may hotels I visit. We stayed 3 nights- and it was swiped for $765. A slip of the finger maybe? When I brought it to the desk's attention, she told me not to worry as it is reversed if nothing was damaged...... which I understood but I didn't get an explanation or reversal for the original swipe (which should have been more like $225) at that moment. The location was ok, it required a car at night as it wasn't right in the heart of the action.I really, really wanted to like this hotel more than I did.  The exterior is gorgeous as is the lobby and common areas.  However my room itself was a let-down; clean but ragged and worn, in desperate need of a makeover.  The hotel staff was great, very friendly yet efficient.  Service at the restaurant was slow even though it was not crowded at all but we enjoyed the food and signature cocktails we ordered.  Did not bring a pet, but impressed that it is a pet-friendly property.  Enjoyed seeing other furry critters, as I always miss mine when traveling.  What was most disappointing is that I inquired ahead of time about booking a spa service, my travel indulgence to myself whenever I'm away.  I was told that for the time period of my stay (mid-week) I did not have to make a reservation ahead, I could call the morning of service to choose a time.  That is not the way I normally handle these things but figured the 'expert' had just assured me of the process so I did as instructed.  Bad move; there was nothing available for any of the days of my stay!  Sorry Hotel Monaco, you lost me there.Kimpton hotels are the best hotels! I've been to a few and I've never been disappointed. Definitely sign up for karma rewards! You'll get free breakfast and wifi. As a side note, it's very vibrant and hip.The hotel is a beautifully restored office building. The rooms are enormous and lovely. I thought the staff were also very attentive and did a great job getting me a room right away. I valeted the car and it was quick and easy. I had a meeting in town and the fast service made it a lot less stressful to get in the room and out to attend to business. The only thing I thought they could improve on were the pillows. They were a bit lumpy, other than that I would say this is a great place to stay in this town.I recently stayed in this this hotel for two nights, it is beautiful with rich history. However the service was terrible. My boyfriend and I checked in and were given keys to our suite. Upon arriving in the room, we quickly discovered that this was not the room I paid for. He placed us in a standard room, when we booked a spa premier room, in which was significantly more. I chose this room because of its beautiful Fuji tub, so was disappointed. Went back to the desk, to be served by the same fellow who assisted us earlier. He was not sympathetic, did not apologize. Just took the keys from me and handed me two comp "continental breakfasts... Without saying anything. (The hotel offers $1 continental breakfasts )He said "let me see if we have one available" I thought, "if you have one?" This is what I was booked for, now I assume that he placed us in the wrong room on purpose, hoping we wouldn't notice.A few minutes later he located one, called who I assume was house keeping , to ask if the room was ready. It was, or so we thought. Upon arriving in the new room... Which was beautiful but not clean. The tub I was so looking forward too still had water in it, the water had hair in it, as well as hair was around the tub itself. We went back down, as we planned on attending the free wine and appetizer hour, in which there were no appetizers and no where to sit. The man serving the wine watched me walk around looking for one, and did not greet me or offer me a glass. While doing this my boyfriend spoke to front desk, same fellow again. He said he would send someone up, again wasn't very sympathetic. We headed back up to the room as we missed out on the wine hour. Waited for someone to arrive to fix the tub, about 20 minutes later a young man arrived with a towel and spray bottle in hand... Mumbled something and just walked in the bathroom, fumbled around there for a bit. Walked back out and went for the door, without saying anything. My boyfriend had to ask "everything good to go"? He said "yeah" and walked out... Not exactly professional by any stretch. To make matters worse because of this we were late for our dinner reservation at a restaurant. A few other things that should be mentioned. The elevators were also very touchy, they wouldn't register the floor when the button was pushed sometimes and other guests were having issues with that as well. Some high points... *The building itself is worth the stay! Beautiful and historic. Gorgeous original staircases, detailed ceilings, gold accents. Lobby is warm and inviting, with lovely decor and fireplace. Building is also leed certified and pet friendly :)*Valet service was good, the attendants were friendly and accommodating. Timing wasn't the best. *The night/early am shift front desk person upon our check out was pleasant and helpful. Overall, not a great first experience at this hotel, I had high expectations due to its star rating and Kimpton's reputation, but came up short. Not sure if I will be staying with Kimpton in the future.Stunning. I have no idea how the Kimpton chain has the ability to take historical buildings and turn them into Hotel Monacos, but they done did it again. I believe this was the National Rail HQ from the mid 1880s, and the Monaco has preserved all of the gilded glory of its former digs. The rooms are appointed in rich tones and leather, with subtle modern flair -the art is all post modern surrealism or bright abstracts juxtaposed against leather quilted bedframes, antique chairs and trunk end tables.Huge marble showers, chevron print carpet and as with all Kimpton's- impeccable service. The only place I'm likely to stay in B'more.My wife and went back 1 year after our wedding here. The staff was very friendly and went the extra mile to take care of us. Thanks to the staff, and especially Vernon, the front office manager, for making the visit special.We visited recently with high hopes and expectations.  Our room was very nice.  Huge and well kept.In the middle of the night our AC went out.  It was a sweltering 79 to 80 degrees from about 2 am on.  We could have called maintenance or asked for a new room but for our daughter who was managing to sleep through it and had two interviews the next morning.We reported the issue first thing in the morning and suggested they address it before reletting the room.  When we checked out the desk clerk was most apologetic and offered up that the manager would be calling us about our experience.  Never ever got a call.  What horrific customer service from a chain with such a good reputation.  We'll not visit this property again.As much as I wanted to like this hotel unfortunately there were too many problems for me to give them higher than two stars.The woman who checked us in on Tuesday night was quite cordial. My friend and I requested a high floor and to my delight she put us in a room on the top floor. Unfortunately while high up, the room appeared fairly standard which translates to adequate, nothing special. The big problem that night was that the room was freezing cold. Even though we set the thermostat to 80 degrees, the room never truly warmed up. I called down and asked for slippers since the floor in the bathroom was particularly cold, the same young woman who checked us in informed me that the hotel did not provide slippers but would bring up an extra bathmat to cover the floor, which she did promptly. The temperature outside that night was particularly cold so I gave the hotel a pass for the cold room and maybe I'm old fashioned to expect slippers in a hotel room these days. I held out hope that our stay would improve.Fortunately the weather warmed up substantially the following day so heat was no longer an issue. But that morning I observed that the bottom sheet on the bed was torn but was confident the housekeeper would notice and change the sheet. That night while turning down the bed I was quite surprised to see the same torn sheet. Once again I rationalized that maybe housekeeping assumed that since the tear was at the edge of the bottom sheet they could get away with it. So again I looked forward to our continued stay.On the following day, Thanksgiving, we returned to the hotel around 11:30 PM. My friend and I pulled up to the valet parking area which appeared to be deserted. After lingering some time with no one in sight I finally went inside to find an attendant while my friend waited outside by the car. Ultimately I located two attendants on the second floor by the check-in desk. It was Thanksgiving night so who could be upset with the parking attendants celebrating a bit.Friday night we returned to the hotel around the same time, 11:30 PM and once again no parking attendants. This time I went straight to the desk to complain. Before I even finished explaining the problem the manager deducted the unreasonably high valet charge ($38 for overnight, clearly he acknowledged the major error in service. The final insult came that night when we returned to our room to discover that housekeeping had never stepped foot into the room. The response when we called down to complain was an offer to send someone to do a "light refreshing in the room" which we declined as we were tired and just wanted to go to sleep.While the exterior and lobby of the hotel are very pretty, even grand, and the restaurant quite pleasant it doesn't come close to making up for a mediocre room and seriously sub-standard service.
review_content_20: The Hotel Monaco is a beautiful historic place with all the grandeur of it's  4-5 star neighbors. The staff are super friendly and get an A+ for customer service. The BEST part is that they are 100 percent DOG FRIENDLY!  It was so nice to see so many dogs coming and going during our stay. If your a dog owner, I highly recommend.  Fyi, the check in desk is on second floor, one elevator floor up.I really like how all hotel monacos are in historical buildings. This one is so beautiful. The hotel overall was ok. I asked for a room with a roll in shower for my husband and ended up with an accessible room with a normal bathroom that was really no different from a regular bathroom outside of grab bars. Oh well. The room also offered a doorbell and some lower items for someone who would need that feature. Overall a clean room and mid day they surprised us with some fresh fruit that was ok. I forgot my flatiron and they lent me one from housekeeping. Worked out well! All employees were kind except for one valet guy that couldn't understand why we wouldn't want to walk a few blocks to the ballgame. (Duh-its called handicap$. Kind of thought that was ignorant. Do your job-get us a taxi.What is up with the no locks on the bathroom door? Although I was only with my wife and son, I felt like I had no privacy. My son would constantly come over and slide the door wide open. He had a blast with it, but I sure didn't. Sitting on the toilet while he runs over and slides it open and runs away laughing was not a hit in my books. But, I have to say, it was rather cute seeing him do it, but it was also very embarassing and got annoying after awhile. Wife also had a really good laugh too, but I still would like locks on my bathroom door.What I did like was the fact that they have a wine hour at this hotel. I believe it was at 5?? It's in the main lobby of the hotel. You come down, get a glass of wine or cocktail, grab some snacks (flatbreads, goldfish, fruit, etc), and just chill on the sofas. The guy serving the wine was very nice. He even went and got my son a popsicle from the hotel freezer. Also, another plus was the decor. It was a very clean and upkept hotel. The valet guys were also great! They were very nice and fast at getting the vehicle when needed.I did have one little misshap that got me pretty upset for a good portion of the night. Wife and I wanted oysters and asked the guy up front if he could make us reservations at a specific restaurant. The person said that Sunday nights aren't busy and we wouldn't need it. We got to the restaurant and there was an hour wait before we could even be sat. UGH. I wish he would have just made the reservations for us. We would have avoiding the whole fiasco of trying to find other restaurants that would seat us right away.Oh, and wife booked the aquarium package which included a fish in the room. It was cool at first, but not even a full night past and the fish died! It just sat there on the counter and when we got back to our hotel for the night, we just saw it floating on its back. It's not like my son played with the water or anything. He didn't even get a chance to play with the fish. It's a good thing he's very young because that could be pretty dramatic for a child that was old enough to remember and comprehend their surroundings.I know Kimpton hotels are supposed to be Amazing. I've heard and read great reviews, but this one just didn't cut it for me. Maybe another kimpton elsewhere would??Overall: I would probably be back if they put locks on the bathroom door, but until then, I will have to check out other Baltimore Hotels.Very Nice hotel !  It was beautiful on arrival .. The valet guys were awesome gave great info . The security guy , Craig was nice as well and funny. The parking was too expensive , front desk was ok not very friendly though .  On the first night I was getting out of shower and stepped on glass. Security came to my room and did an incident report . However no manager ever called or came check on me .  I complained the next day. And was given 100.00 credit to restaurant there and free mini bar .. Ended up not eating at restaurant there due to us not liking anything on dinner menu .  Upon check out they offered me a free 1 night to come back and stay in suite .  They said they would email the offer to me per Vernon the manager .  It's been 1 wk later and Nothing in my email . Not to mention corporate has not called to check on my foot .  Hotel was wonderful but I can't believe a hotel this nice does  not have top notch customer service.. Also no pool .  You pay 300.00 per night and no pool ... Major ding with meThis place is 3 blocks away from Inner Harbor Baltimore, so it was a good location to stay for New Year's Eve. We didn't have to walk far to see the fireworks. We did valet parking since we were staying for the night, the valet parking was $38 (if you do the parking yourself is $30/night). Even on a cold night, someone was there to hold the doors for us and gave us direction to the check in lobby, since the lobby located on the second floor instead of first. The place has the historical design, the stairs to the second floor was long but it wasn't just straight up but it was in a circle style. I was in love with the lights design and even the signs to show the directions. The check in staffs greeted us nicely and helped us through the process smoothly and quickly, I was very satisfied with the service. Our room was on the 10th floor but sadly it wasn't the room that face the front street, instead it was just the back. I am okay with that since the room design was already amazing.Kimpton is my favorite hotel chain but as other people have noted, this one is far cry from the standard expected from this group.  While the building is beautiful, room service is awful (unapologetically so), the rooms are very much the worse for wear and need updating/reconditioning, parking is ridiculously expensive, no cable TV (really!), no swimming pool or spa on site (limited services are available in guest rooms).All in all, I would rather have spent my money at a Holiday Inn for half the price.  At least I wouldn't have been as disappointed with the lack of services and amenities because my expectations would have been much lower.This is the second time we here.  It is near the inner harbor (walking distant) and it is a great hotel overall.  The place is beautiful.  Front desk (on 2nd floor) is friendly.  Amazing coffee and tea by the lobby.  The room are clean and roomy.  I only wish the wi-fi were free.Firstly...the staff was very very very nice. The building itself is cool, HOWEVER...The room looked like someone had lived there for a while. Wasn't clean - M&M's behind the couch scattered on the floor elsewhere and a crunched water bottle was just sitting there in the middle of the floor. Huh? The finishes and decor are a hodgepodge of an unbelievable level, and I could overlook it if I wasn't paying 300.00 a night! Like whaaa-at? ONE LESS RANDOM PATTERN WOULD BE NICE.  What about the wires sticking out unceremoniously from behind ill-mounted or busted electronics? Oh lord, the bathroom...faux leather shit colored wallpaper that is peeling up and window shades so sheer that require you to keep the light off at night lest you be seen by any and everyone...   The bed, the sofa bed AND the roll-away were the most uncomfortable beds I have ever sat and/or slept on. I don't know what kind of hotel doesn't have an extra blanket somewhere? Why have that ridiculously huge thrift shop looking dresser in the room if not to provide the guests with extra linens like a normal hotel? When we asked for an extra blanket, the one we got looked like it had been wrapped around a water heater!! And please do not order room service. Like the hotel itself, you most definitely do not get what you pay for...Fucking wretched. I don't know what hotel the other reviewers stayed at, this is the first time I have been misled by fellow yelpers because this hotel is low brow and waaaaaaaaaaaaaaay overpriced. Definitely a blemish on the Kimpton portfolio. And they must know it.We stayed here after seeing a special on trip advisor.Staff is great. Happy hour was a plus. Lounge with fireplace really nice.Only drawbacks are the rooms are small and sliding door on bathroom lacks privacy. The charm and history abound however and I would come again.Easy walk to the harbor but don't stray too far from that direction at night!Kimpton's just never seem to fail me! This property has to be one of my favorites! It's gorgeous! It was a converted train station, and I can tell you they did it right! The lobby is on the second floor, and you are always greeted with a smile. The staff just makes every Kimpton visit a little nicer. They are so quick to accommodate any needs. I truly appreciate that! The rooms were a nice size with all the amenities! It was tastefully decorated, bright and clean, comfortable beds and pillows. The bathroom rocked with a cool open shower and a huge jacuzzi tub! The Monaco has 24 hour room service, and a decent menu to order from. Love the location, we were able to walk down to the ballpark. When I'm back in Bmore this will be my go to hotel!This Hotel is beautiful, no doubt. The costumer service is great too, but there are some details that left us thinking we would try another hotel if we return to the city.  We paid extra for the spa suite, but it was a little strange.  I've been to three other Kimptons where the tubs are more than worth the money.  This one left me comparing it to a weird Jacuzzi at the YMCA.  I've said this before with other Kimpton's, but as eclectic as the robes are, they're freaking uncomfortable... crunchy...and small.We stayed in the hotel for the first nights dinner and drinks the following night.  I understand this is a Hotel that accommodates many different parties and people alike, but we felt like we could not escape the Sh*t show of a wedding (I think) that was going on.  The restaurant didn't seem to keep any of it separate from the costumers that were there for a relaxing weekend.  Sorry, but I left college years ago and I don't wish to attend an Ivy league frat party.Sorry, Kimpton. Thumbs down on this one.I was very impressed by this hotel, not only is it gorgeous but the staff are friendly as well. My room was beautiful and I felt that I got a lot for what I paid. The suite was big, nice tall ceilings and a gorgeous marble bathroom. They were so nice to my dog (which was the reason I booked with them in the first place, it's hard to find a good hotel that allows pets) and even gave her a goody bag. The location was great too, I could walk to the inner harbor and I felt safe as well, my dog approves of this place (as she peacefully passed out beside me on the bed),which is the only thing that matters to me.Stayed here at Monaco Baltimore 2 weekend ago for a wedding. There was no safe in the room, so I left some things in the dresser to lighten my backpack. Left a few magazines, iPad and a book and forgot the items on my way out. I called the hotel the next day asked for Housekeeping. They said that they did have my things, but that there was no iPad left in the drawer. I insisted that there was an iPad in the drawer, and was told that the staff member who cleaned the room returned everything that was left in the drawer. She was kind enough to offer to send my items for free. Nice gesture, considering someone made off with a nice iPad. Don't trust the Housekeeping staff. You've been warned.This is a nice hotel with good, personalized service. Rooms are sizable, bedding comfy, and bathroom amenities are nice. I was staying for a conference and service seemed okay. Banquet food service, at least what they served me, was frankly subpar. But you don't go to hotels to eat. This is a good enough place to sleep.We love the quirkiness of the Kimpton line, and Monaco didn't disappoint!  Our room had bunk beds for the kids with a huge puppy-portrait mural on their wall--adorable!  In-room gaming system made the kids' waiting time a lot more fun.  The building is gorgeous and really retains the old historical feel of the B&O railroad headquarters it used to be!  Marble staircase, stained glass, train-inspired details everywhere...it's lovely!As with all Kimpton hotels, the morning/evening snacks & drinks are so appreciated and just give that extra touch of making you feel comfortable and welcome.  Same with the staff--so friendly!  Love it!'The bf and I stayed here just one night for a Valentine's weekend getaway.  We arrived a bit early before check in time but were able to check in and head to our King room.  The front desk staff were super friendly, advising how they are a secure hotel- you have to insert your key in the elevator to get to your floor.The hotel is HUGE, spacious and very swanky.  I love all the details- the marble and chandeliers are so nice. The room is very big with very high ceilings, the mini bar (pricey!!) has all kinds of neat stuff.  Snacks, drinks, champagne, beer, and even Patron- of course, all for a price in a nice little price sheet on the table.  You can even have a new pair of fuzzy socks!
