If you have some kind of skin irritation, you might want to leave ASAP.While we were at the Sheraton we spoke with 3 members of the staff, I can't even tell who was the worse, the 2 ladies in the front or the supervisor ! All of them so rude . We asked for a king , they gave us 2 queens , they wanted to charge $80 for parking , yes $80 just because we had a truck (we were moving from one state to another) and the parking lot we left the truck was completely empty, once we told them we were leaving , the supervisor said we had 5 minutes to drop off the keys in the reception ! Really rushed us out, the room was old , we just decided to go somewhere else , element. Such a. Better hotelWe stayed at the Sheraton Inner Harbor to attend a convention. The hotel is next to the convention center and is attached with a bridge connecting the two establishments. During our stay, there were several Baltimore Orioles game and I noticed that a lot of the fans stayed in this hotel too. The Orioles Camden Yard stadium is just 2 blocks from the hotel. There is a Light Rail Station next to Camden Yard and this will take you to and from Baltimore Airport. Also in Camden Yard is the MARC train station that you can use to go to Washington DC. The hotel is a 5 minute walk to inner harbor. As far as the physical state of the hotel, the rooms are dated but clean. You can tell that this hotel need to be upgraded. I recommend this hotel if you need to stay near the convention center and will stay here again if needed.$189.00 per night. Dirty room, portions of the carpeted room look like it hadn't been vacuumed in years. I actually moved some furniture, hoping the staff would clean it, no such luck. AC unit was also covered with dust- oink!What a remarkable property.  It's not just for the blithe, casual dismissiveness of the front desk that makes this a hostile hotel tour de force.No.  It was that my toilet didn't work nor did the television.  Not that I used them at the same time of course.  Wifi in the room?  Random connect and disconnect.   That's for both the toilet and the wifi.The gift shop?  What gift shop.  It carries 4 kinds of snacks and bottled water. I saw more exciting and dynamic offerings in post-soviet era Prague.Picture the worst hotel experience you've ever had, and multiply it by two. That would describe my experience at the Sheraton Inner Harbor Hotel.This delightful stay began innocently enough. I was able to check in in the morning, which was nice, since I had arrived on a red eye and would be in a business meeting all day, and needed to freshen up. But when I got back to my room that afternoon, there were screaming college students running down the hallway, blasting music in the room next door, lugging beer kegs, etc. I immediately called down to the front desk, and asked that they move my room. I was told I had to come downstairs to accomplish this. When I got to the front desk, there was a line out the door - almost literally - of more college students. I learned that this was like a multi-campus fraternity and sorority party, and the whole hotel was infested with busloads of these kids. (Got a sense of the quality of this establishment yet?)I eventually made it to the front desk and asked for another room, indicating that I wanted to be nowhere near this noise. I was given a new room key, and assumed that was that. When I got to the elevator bank to go to my new floor - the eighth floor - the elevator simply wasn't coming. Ten minutes went by. Finally, the elevator came - but when I got up to my new room, I saw that it hadn't been made up. The sheets were all over the place, the ironing board was out, etc. So now, I had to trudge back downstairs to get yet another new room. This time, I learned that half of the elevators had simply stopped working. WIth hundreds of college kids swarming the place, you can imagine how long it would take to catch an elevator.So yep - I had to climb down eight flights of stairs, reeking of stale cigarette smoke - to get back to the lobby. I barged into the interminable line of college students waiting to check in, and angrily demanded a new room - this time, a clean one.  The only apology I received from the harried, prepubescent desk clerk was free admission to the "courtesy suite" in the morning, which would allow me free continental breakfast. Whoopie. I then had to climb UP eight flights of stairs. With my luggage. When I got up to my THIRD room in one hour, I realized that there was no place safe from the hordes of screaming college kids. The hotel ignored them and didn't care. They were paying customers, after all (apparently something the hotel lacked?) So I had to endure people running down the hallway at all hours, loud music, and a teen couple having a loud and inane lover's spat in front of my door at 1 am. DId it not occur to these kids that this was a hotel, not a dorm?? You might argue that this wasn't the Sheraton's fault. They're not the parents of these kids. But it WAS their responsibility to ensure that their other guests were not disturbed, and on that count, they totally failed. So yep - that was my utterly fantastic experience. Never again.My husband and I love staying at this particular Sheraton.  We have never had any of the problems that some other reviewers have had and we've stayed here 3 times.  It's a great location and they allow our dog to come and stay at no charge.  Some other hotels charge as much as $100 a night for a pet, not Sheratons.  The beds are so comfortable and the rooms are spacious.  Yes, it's true they don't have a fridge or a microwave in the room but they do have a coffee maker with Starbucks coffee for you to make.  So the person that complained about not getting a free coffee and having to pay $6 was just wrong.  We even asked housekeeping and the front desk for more coffee and they were very accommodating.We've never eaten at the restaurant in house because we always venture into the Inner Harbor.  Of course the prices are going to be high. It's a famous steak house at a hotel!  Some people are just so...... ugh!  Once our room was next to the ice machine which we heard and we asked to change rooms.  It was no problem at all.  Everyone we've ever had contact with there was very polite.  We'll definitely be back.This is a perfectly fine hotel. I was attending a conference literally a block away, so location-wise, the Sheraton was a no-brainer. Now, considering how much my employer paid for me to stay here ($199 + tax), it probably wasn't a great value, but that aside, I had no trouble with my stay.The room was clean and spacious. Bed was comfortable. Shower had good pressure. Check-in was fast, and staff was pleasant. There was a nice looking flat-screen TV, but I never turned it on. I didn't come to Baltimore to watch TV, after all. If I could get a decent deal, I'd stay here again. It's not the Ritz, but it gets the job done.Our stay here was so horrible, we are ending our relationship with the Starwood Gold  member program. We were given a horrible room overlooking a parking lot, although the hotel was not close to full, no upgrade whatsoever, dirty bathroom(some bizarre ooze on the door) not cleaned even after we complained. A floor full of prom goers-why were they even aloud to be in the hotel?-minors, drunk and fighting in the halls. Required FOUR PHONE CALLS before they were removed. No compensation offered for our awful stay even after contacting the manager and the Starwood program. Never again, Starwood. We love the W and Aloft hotels, but this is the last time we stay at one of your subpar brands such as Sheraton.Horrible horrible horrible.The rooms are clean, the staff was helpful and you can't beat the location if you're in town for a game. They have a Morton's in the lobby and an on site pub. It's a Sheraton so don't expect the service or amenities you'd get at a pricier hotel.Its a Sheraton.  Nice bed. Nothing fancy.Shout out to the super nice staff.I stayed here this week and was unimpressed with the old Marriott vibe (decor in rooms, etc...), slow internet, aberration of a fitness room and uncomfortable beds. Great service (especially in the club lounge) and a Morton's onsite although pros, didn't save this property. I can understand other people's visceral reaction - I'm glad I only stayed one night.Excellent customer service! Very clean rooms, pool, & gym. We had a room with a nice view facing the harbor. Dislike that we had to pay for wifi, charged for parking, and no complimentary breakfast.Good location, good price.  Great staff.  Room ok.The room was large, the bed comfortable, and the a/c managed to keep up with the 98 degree heat.  Location is onvenient for both the Inner Harbor and Camden Yards.Here's what stood out:  Reina, the concierge, who seems to have invented Baltimore and knows everything about everything..  The front desk staff was super helpful.  The valet parking women were efficient and pleasant.Here's where the Sheraton needs some help:  the TV didn't work.  The clock radio's alarm appeared to be on (from someone else) and the only way we could figure to turn it off was to unplug it.  The bed only had a table and lamp on one side, not on the other. The only phone was by the bed, not on the desk.  Did I mention that the 27 inch flat screen TV didn't work?The Sheraton was perfectly fine.  Just about  every hotel chain is represented with 1/2 mile of the Inner Harbor.    Get the best price you can find and go for it.Old hotel.was going through some remodeling at the time.Interior and decor is a little dated.restaraunt is not very good, not my favorite place. breakfast buffett was horrible.I would say this is not a good value but they do try hard!! So staff was very friendly but again Rooms were clean and decent. Bed was nice and firmOverall hotel was disappointing but the location is pretty decent but please eat elsewhere.
review_content_40: Hmmm: The swimming pool was disturbingly filled with particulate matter, despite noting that the Pool Care Log noted 'Clear' for the last 5 entries. Keep young children, the elderly, and immuno-comprimised persons away. We washed the bathing suits 3 times now and the mildew smell still lingers. No ice or vending machines on the floors.Comforting, Great Location.My stay at this faclity was great! The staff was accommodating and the location was a few blocks from city center. Loved it!sheraton inner harbor in baltimore.. front desk..rude!staff NOT helpful!BAD EXPERIENCE!messed up my reservation for a king bed room, got double beds. Fortunately a friend of mine also got shafted in the opposite way so we ended up trading rooms, being right down the hall from eachother.The hotel itself is nice, but the beds weren't doing it for me. I woke up with extremely tense shoulders each morning of my stay.Only convenience is it's location and connection to the convention center. Otherwise I'd definitely stay at the hyatt or the bran new hilton next time.Old tub, sheets crinkly and loose, I could hear my next door neighbor pretty obviously early in the AM.Smoky room (I felt like it was masked by heavy perfume).Although only $70/night I did not enjoy my stay.Free computer usage and water in the lobby area. Walkable to the GALLERY MALL SHOP but stores are lame.Standard room with double bead was nice. Mattress was comfortable. Nothing spectacular. Of note, parking fees are atrocious. I was charged $27 to park for what amounted to 12 hours. Try to find other parking accommodations nearby if possible.There are a lot of things to love about this place. The view from where we were was spectacular as we got to see the harbor simply by opening the curtains. The outside area on the second floor breezeway to the convention center (yes, it's pretty much connected to the convention center) is set up nicely with comfy lounge chairs and tables. The front desk staff was ALWAYS friendly and incredibly helpful. We were able to get an early check-in at no additional cost (which is available only if the room they assigned you to was cleaned out and ready for you), 12pm check out is great, they have a rental car station, garage (expensive but necessary for us at the time so I'm not taking stars away from them for that but $27, ouch), The doormen were really polite and ready to lend a helping hand at the drop of a hat, and our room was great. Beds are comfy, bathroom is nice with a long counter top which was necessary for 2 women to share lol, great coffee, within walking distance (a block) from the harbor, lot's of spaces for lounging throughout the hotel, 2 restaurants inside. I mean it was hard not to love this place. There wasn't a fridge in our room which is a bummer but not a deal breaker. People would prob deduct stars for the lack of fridge and how expensive parking is I know usually I would but they have so much going on to make up for those things that it really shouldn't. Great Customer service, respect, and politeness no matter what the situation is is hard to come by but not here.One of the bad things about traveling from the West Coast to the East, is arriving late at hotels and getting a bad room.  Since I'm Gold Preferred Guest at Starwood, and also had called ahead about my room, I wasn't too worried.  I should have been.Arrived after midnight, and first impression:  no one outside to help with car or luggage.  Once inside, second impression: small lobby and boring!  Nothing got better at the front desk.  When I inquired about possibly getting a better view, I was told that it would be $15 extra for a view of the Inner Harbor.  Come on - as I said, I'm Starwood Gold, and have been Platinum for years - I have NEVER been asked to pay extra for a view.  In Hawaii, Sheraton upgraded me to Ocean Front, no charge and in Seattle, Westin gave me a connecting second room for a friend for 3 nights of my stay for FREE!  So maybe I'm spoiled, but it seems pretty ridicuolus to pay $15 more a night to get a view of the Inner Harbor - it's just Baltimore guys!  And the woman behind the counter is so sticky sweet fake nice, that I want to throw up as she tells me this.  So I get up to my non-view room and it's an "accessible" room.  So it's great that hotels have these rooms for people that need them, but they are also the rooms that when they are not needed are passed off on the unsuspecting victims.  The bathrooms are funky - weird toilets and showers and all that.  So not only do I not get a room with a view, but I get the lowest room on the totem pole of rooms.  I go back downstairs, I almost cry, I spill a diet coke - and suddenly a room with a view magically appears, no extra fee.  Why couldn't we have skipped the drama and went straight to this room?  So at least I have my room with the view now, but this hotel still needs help.  The staff all seems like they are just going through the motions.  The room looks like it has some new furnishings, but it's not super clean - there was even dust on the blow dryer.  And the bed is supposed to be "Sweet Sleeper" but they don't compare to the Marriott beds that make you sleep in and never want to wake up.  And where are all the amenities for frequent travelers?  Marriott has: bonus points at check-in, upgrades (hint hint) and a concierge level.  What is Sheraton bringing to the table?  Come on guys. pony up!Good location, that's the only thing that is good. My room smelled like cigarrettes and it was small and dark. The bed was awful, the GYM is the worst I have seen in a hotel (old machines and it is the size of a room). The swimming pool has space for 5 people, they should call it a tub, not a pool. On the top of all this, the service was awful. They did not do my room one day and when I asked why, they said it happens. No apology... juts an offer to make my room at 11 PM that I came back from work eager to sleep. Really, by far the worst experience I have ever had in a hotel. Oh, and I am a gold member of starwood so I guess if you are not, you will get an even worse experience.I stayed at this hotel because I thought it was the closest one to the Convention Center.  But it wasn't.  The Hilton is directly connected to the Convention Center.  If I had known that, I would have stayed there.I had several gripes with my stay:-There are no electrical outlets near the bed.  That means that the alarm clock is located on the table across the room from the bed.  That's not a fun way to wake up although, it means that you're less likely to snooze.  It also means that you have to plug in your phone across the room from your bed.  -I was put in a handicapped room and I wasn't even asked or notified prior to arriving in my room.  The handicapped room was OK except for the bathroom which had barely any counter space and felt very hospital like. -They try to encourage green practices like rewarding you with a $5 voucher for every day that you decline housekeeping services.  However, they don't tell you that you can only use their voucher in their restaurant or room service and NOT in their gift shop.  So, who can get away with only spending $5 at a hotel restaurant?.-Their gift shop closes really early.  It was closed by 8pm on Sunday.-The sink gurgled all night.  It was so loud that it would wake me up!  Other people who stayed there also said they had the same experience.  -The walls are really thin.  I could hear full conversations from the people in the room next door and they didn't seem to be talking particularly loud.  I could hear the words they were saying so it wasn't muffled sounds.  The hotel is close to the Inner Harbor area and the Convention Center and the doormen are very friendly.  However I won't be choosing to stay here again in the future.Before we go on, I have to say that Priceline rocks and the whole "name your price" thing is great.  This is only the 2nd time I've used it, but I will probably use it from now on.With that said, the Sheraton Inner harbor is a pretty good hotel with good service.  The rooms were clean and we had a pretty decent view.  Its location was excellent for all the tourist trap stuff.  Right before we checked out some guy was having trouble with his keycard.  He asked us if we could help... he had the card oriented the wrong way... but even after getting that right, he couldn't get it to open.  "Be more assertive" was the next thing that blabbed out of my mouth.  I had no idea what I meant, either, but after hesitating for a moment, he inserted the card like a man and the door opened.Yeah... that's why they pay me the big bucks.Plain and simple: Satisfied with my stay. My room was nice, the bed was comfy, the concierge was very helpful (thanks again Rena!) and the rest of the staff accommodated where they could. If in Baltimore, and on someone else's tab, I would stay here again... very easy to get to, within walking distance of plenty of restaurants and things to do and the neighborhood seemed pretty safe.I was staying here for a short business trip.  It was a particular comfortable stay at this hotel.  On the day of arrival, I called to confirm my room (I have too many bad experience that they give away your room for late arrival).  I told them I probably would be arriving late, front desk said that's fine, my room would be available when I arrived.  Of course, when I got there...they ran out of the room that I reserved, the only room left was a room with a queen size Murphy bed.  I was so tired, didn't want to fight, I just took what they gave me.  The room itself it's a large suite (it's a dining room which was an extension from the next suite).  It had a dining table, two couches, big screen TV, small kitchenette, bathroom and the Murphy bed.Since it was a extension room from next door, there was a connection door, which did not blocked sound that well and I could hear the family next door.  I laid down on the Murphy bed and watched the Celtics final game on the big screen TV, and I started to notice this humming noise from the vent/AC in my room.  I knocked on the vent couple times, and the humming noise sorted stopped.  I didn't notice it as much once I fell asleep that night, but I woke up couple time the next night cuz it was bugging me. I finally called front desk at 5am, and they sent maintenance immediately to check it out.  Maintenance opened the whole vent, changed the filter, and just left the cover off in order to avoid the humming noise. When I checked out, I told front desk about my complaint of my stay.  She said "okay", not sorries or anything.  I called back later to talk to supervisor, she apologized about the inconvenience and gave me some extra award points.Crappy.  Crappy.  Crappy. Crappy rooms, crappy service, crappy location.  Ugh.  I just felt dirty staying here!  Have decided to break out of my Starwood points-hoarding next time I have to be in Baltimore.Stayed three nights for a conference. The room was small and had a strange floor plan, but was a corner room overlooking Camden Yards.  Food at the Sports bar was very good! Try the salads - the chef makes great efforts to prepare them.Starbucks coffee in the rooms. Housekeeping didn't clean the coffee pot every day.The TV worked. Well, at least it turned on. The channels were fuzzy, like it was on an old tv antenna rather than HD cable.  As with nearly all hotel remote controls this one had to be cleaned before use, and the keys still stuck sometimes. (what do people do with the remotes? maybe we don't want to know!)The first night was pretty noisy as there were people in the adjoining room. Afterwards, it was pretty quiet.For Jazzy, at $70 you got a deal when compared to our conference price.~Stayed here at a discount for the Yankees/Orioles game on 9/7/12. Great location and very helpful and friendly staff. You can walk to Camden Yards and the Inner Harbor in a few minutes. I will stay here again the next time I come down to Baltimore to see my Yankees kick Oriole butt!!!I stayed here as part of a Starwood Free Weekend Reward Bonus.  Its located right near the Inner Harbor (which was the whole purpose of my trip).  The room wasn't spectacular, but the king bed was comfy and they did have a flat screen (I just wished the room had a refrigerator to preserve my leftover crabs).  Overnight parking was $24 (unlimited in and outs).Expensive parking @ $28.  SLOW internet and extra fee. Terrible tv reception. No channel guide or hotel/pool/club/restaurant info in the room or on tv.  Room temp programmed for 60F and it took 3 calls to the front desk and a 45 min wait till midnight to get it reprogrammed.  Room smelled like cigarettes. Bartender @ Oriole bar could not find the wine I ordered from menu and offered "spumanti" which he tried to assure me "was the same thing."  Yeah, well, they both had bubbles.  I tried to order a beer instead but he couldn't tear his eyes off the TV sports news (not even a live game).  Restaurant food just okay, and expensive - take the circulator or walk to Little Italy instead.  Room large clean and comfortable. Convenient location.This was the worst hotel experience ever.  First, the heating unit in the room was broken.  It took three hours on the second day of our stay for this to be fixed (a new unit had to be installed).  One afternoon I came back to the room and put the latch on the door.  As I was going to the bathroom, a housekeeping person came into the room (so much for the security offered by the latch).  We extended our stay by one night due to storm weather.  My (now ex-) wife went downstairs and arranged for the extra night's stay.  The next day I returned to the room and the room key would not work.  I went to the front desk and informed them of the problem.  The employee, Winston (who also turned out to be the manager) seemed to view me as a problem from the moment I approached the desk.  He also seemed to take some strange delight in my misfortune.  He asked for ID and the room details.  The manager said my name was not on the room so he could not let me in for "security reasons".  A few hours after my wife returned from her conference.  We went to the front desk again.  It turns out that we should have been issued new keys the day before when the stay was extended.  And, my name was on the room booking (but when they had extended the booking for an extra night, they only put my wife's name on the booking for that night).  Unbelievable.  I will never stay in a Sheraton again after this experience.Spent two nights at the Sheraton Inner Harbor. Location is great. Very near the Inner Harbor (3-5 minute easy walk). Room was fine.Bed was great. I booked a room that viewed the Harbor. Had a great view. Bedroom was perhaps a little small for he price paid. Wi-Fi is not free - which is should be. The Morton Steak House has a great deal on appetizers before 6:30 and after 9:30 pm. Concierge (Rena) was very helpful. Make sure you ask for her to get suggestions for what to do and restaurants.
review_content_60: In my lifetime, I've stayed at a good number of hotels and I've had some fantastic and some disappointing experiences.  This Sheraton would be on my top three of disappointing experiences.   Lets begin with the bell hops, I pull up to the hotel entrance and instead of greeting us, he comes  to me and asks me "do you need any help?"  Lets see, I have a toddler, my wife, two pieces of luggage and a few other smaller bags.  I would say a little help would have been nice.  I say yes and then he proceeds to load our luggage.  Actually I load it myself and he just watched.  He proceeds to wheel the dolly to the lobby and instead of keeping an eye on it he just puts it next to a wall and walks away.  If my wife didn't keep an eye on it, it would have been easy for someone to take a few of our items.  Now for the best part of the hotel.  The front desk.  I have never met such a misinformed, incompetent and full of attitude front desk attendant in my life.  We approach the desk at 5pm to check in, and we reserved three rooms.  Please keep in mind that check in is 3pm.  The front desk attendant that was helping us (or should I say not really helping us) tells us that our rooms are not ready yet.  I asked her what time check in is, she proceeds to tell me that its 3pm.  I tell her its 5pm, then she proceeds to tell me that the 3pm check in is upon availability.  I think to myself, is she serious and then I proceed to ask her if she was kidding.  She says that she's serious.  I asked her where in the documentation it states that it is "upon availability" she looks at the reservation papers and doesn't know so she asks her colleague where it is.  They proceed to point to a little footnote looking for anything that can be related to the nonsense that she uttered and she proceeds to point out something that has nothing to do with reservations.  I proceed to tell her that, the statement that she pointed out has nothing to do with our conversation.  She says there is nothing she can do.  In these situations, the front desk attendant would be apologizing for the inconvenience and would ask if we would like to grab some drinks at the bar while we wait for our rooms to be ready.  But here, all I get it is attitude and a person who insists that the 3pm check in is only really a guideline and if your room isn't ready by the time you arrive after check in time your are SOL but you still have to pay the full room rate.  While the conversation is still happening, miraculously the three rooms we reserved are ready.  This place really is a shit show.  This could have all been avoided but I guess they wanted to test me on whether I would bitch or not about the rooms not being ready two hours after check in.  The room:  Crap, crap and crap.  For the rate we were paying for the less than 350 sq ft. rooms totally not worth it, it was old and somewhat stinky.  Bath room smelled of mold and the ceiling had some water damage.  You definitely want to keep your shoes on in the room.  If you're walking around barefoot you'll most likely contract some type of foot fungus.  Not much more I can say about the room, but not worth it.  There was one incident that stuck out in my mind that really annoyed me more than the front desk attendant.  A young boy was walking to the revolving door but I guess he was caught between the door and the wall of the doorway and he seemed to be in pain, crying, tears, yelling the whole bit.  The parents were helping him up and consoling him.  There were two porters/bell men about five feet from this incident and all they did was stand there and watched.  Instead of going over and helping and asking if they need assistance.  They just didn't care and looked over as though its not worth their time or effort.  Unfortunately this place suffers from ill-trained, lazy employees.  Of course this is a blanket statement and there are exceptions.  But from the the people that I've dealt with and experienced this is my take on the hotel.  The porter that helped us down with our luggage was pleasant and informative, as he asked us how our stay was and we talked about local restaurants.  He helped us to our car and the lobby attendant helped load our car.  I was thinking to myself just as I was leaving the service got better, unfortunately it had to start off so poorly.  I usually don't write this much as I have better things to do, but I wanted my experience here was spectacularly underwhelming.  Spend your hard earned dollars somewhere else where they appreciate you.

review_content: This was my second time staying in this particular building, my first time being back in 2006 when this building was still the Intercontinental. The good:It's located in the Inner Harbor within walking distance of the southern end of the Inner Harbor and the Baltimore convention center.The Federal Hill area is also within walking distance.Friendly staffClean, comfortable roomsFree basic wifi, but the connection is a bit spottyDecent gym and indoor poolThe bad:Most of my favorite restaurants in Baltimore are in Fells Point, which is on the northern end of the Inner Harbor. Around this hotel, you're stuck with mostly tourist trap restaurants like Bubba Gump.While my car was ok this time around, my car did get broken into in the hotel's parking garage during my previous stay. Overall:Certainly a reasonable lodging option if either the price is right, or if your primary destination is the convention center. Otherwise, I might recommend the Marriott or the Four Seasons on the other side of the harbor. Really a 3.5 star review, but will round up to 4 stars.Location!! I booked this hotel on Hotwire and got a great deal. I really preferred to stay in Harbor East, but couldn't find a deal in that area. Well this ended up being perfect. Inner Harbor directly across the street, Harbor East & Little Italy are a 10 minute walk in one direction and Federal Hill is a 10 minute walk in the other direction. Loved it! We walked everywhere. Our room was a lot better than I expected. There was a large foyer when you walked in with a mini fridge, keurig, full length mirror and closet. The bathroom was spacious with a large tub. Then a nice big king bed, chair, and desk area. No complaints on the furniture or layout of the room. The only problem was air flow! I had the AC on high on the lowest temperature and it was still very stuffy. There was only one ceiling vent in each room and you couldn't even feel the air flow. That was disappointing. I was dying for one of those under the window units that blasts air! The other weird thing was parking. We couldn't figure out how to walk from the garage directly to the hotel, even though it appeared that they were connected. Maybe it was just us. Parking was $26 overnight, which is pretty standard in the city. I would definitely recommend this hotel based primarily on location, but the room was also very nice.Terrible view with dirty window and a wonderful view of construction. Picked the hotel because it was so close to the harbor and was loved by so many other hotel guest.My boyfriend and I came to have a romantic getaway. When we first arrived to the Sonesta, we were treated like royalty. The staff greeted us as if they had been preparing for our visit. After check-in, we went to our room and was amazed of the layout. Then to top that off, the view of the harbor was immaculate. We really enjoyed our night in a clean spacious room were we heard what we needed,...quietness. The bed was so comfortable with soft sheets. Even though we stayed one night, I wish we stayed more. I would definitely stay there again. Thank you Sonesta Royal for having the team you do that assisted with the excellent stay my boyfriend and I had.Check in was at 4pm we arrived at 420pm  room was not available.  The couple checking in next to us were offered 2 free drink vouchers to the bar....we were not offered anything until we said something about it to the clerk..  And we reserved  a large suite not just a regular room so you would think that they wojld be the first rooms to have ready since they are the most expensive.... then we walk into the coffee shop on lobby floor and were looking at the menu board for a few minutes and i asked for two coffees and they told me they were closed....Why wouldnt you say that when we walked in the ???The lobby and bar area are nice but thats all weve seen since our room isnt read uh still... not to mention we planned on showering and getting ready for dinner reservations at Roys Hawaiian  Bistro in harbor east at 7pm...so now we will have to cancel since we wont have time to get ready.....1 hr 15 min after check in time was supposed to be...i will not stay here again nor do i reccomend it to anyone elseWe stayed at Royal Sonesta in the King room with harbor view for Valentine's Day. The room was very nice and the view was amazing. There were, unfortunately, several issues that slightly soured our overall experience. When we initially arrived at the hotel, we pulled in to the valet area and immediately experienced disorganization. There were cars everywhere and a permanent structure in the middle of the driveway that made it very difficult to maneuver the cars. One of the valet drivers actually backed a car into a Mercedes while we were waiting. For the price, $40, we would have expected a higher level of professionalism. When I booked the room I got the Valentine's Day special that included a bottle of champagne and chocolate covered strawberries. When we returned to the room after dinner at 7:30, they had not yet been delivered. After several calls to the front desk, we received our champagne and strawberries three hours later. The next morning we went to the Explorers restaurant for breakfast at 9 AM. When we got there, there was a line of people waiting to be seated. It appeared that they were extremely shortstaffed and very unorganized. There were only two waitstaff and a manager trying to seat and serve dozens of people. We waited over 30 minutes to be seated and the buffet breakfast that was offered left a lot to be desired. All that was offered was a few hot dishes and stale pastries for $20 per person. There's no free wifi offered either in the $300+/ night stay. For the price, next time I will choose a different hotel.The hotel is beautiful and conveniently located near the inner harbor. Walkable to Royal Farms Arena, The Convention Center and Camden Yards.Great restaurants and bars are also walkable from this hotel.We were checked in quite efficiently at 4 p.m. on a Monday. Our room, which was large by any standard, overlooked the courtyard. Very clean and comfy. The parking garage is next door. $26 for the overnight.We will return!Booked the hotel through Expedia.  We had stayed there before when it was under different ownership and it was great.  This experience was not stellar at all, this time around.The room key did not work and we were forced to have security let us into the room FIVE times, before they decided to change out the lock.  We left a review on Expedia, and Steve, who obviously tries to tend to their social media and online reputation, actually lied and said that after the room key not working, they upgraded us to another suite,  Funny, I don't remember that!  I do remember the hotel being booked solid because we were there for the Yankee game, and we were told that the hotel was completely booked. The hotel room was never cleaned, for the 2 nights and three days that we were there.  The reason was, they had so many guests and not enough staff.  That was straight from the front desk!The best part of the staff were the valets, who were actually awesome, which is the only reason I would give this place 1 star.Bad enough to have a horrible experience, but then for the staff to LIE about what accommodations (on Expedia) they supposedly gave and did not is just down right HORRIFIC.They charged double the normal room rate because the Yankees were in town and told us it was not because of the game, it was a supply and demand "thing".  Well, the demand was because of the game, so we got gauged and had a bad experience.You would think the hotel would actually reach out to the customer rather than lying about what accommodations and upgrades they got.  This review never would have been written if they didn't treat their customer bad and then lie about it.Very nice hotel. Room wasn't ready on check in so they upgraded us to a suite. Lovely view of harbor. Staff were very friendly. The room was clean and plenty of towels.I didn't have any parking/valet issues, just parked on the street. We'll probably stay there again sometime. Oh oh oh oh and check out the gym and racquetball - bananas.Very pleased w/ our stay. Staff is kind & courteous.  We are on our 3rd night & our room is very nice.  We have a harbor view king size.  I read that housekeeping has been spotty for some guests so i have taken the time to stop at the front desk on our way out each day & request that housekeeping make up our room while weare out.  I have each time been met w/ a courteous smile & upon our return, we have found our room tidied to perfection. Oh-and I must note, the hallways in the hotel smell exceptionally fresh-I am particularly critical.  The inner Harbor is truly within walking distance.  The Aquarium, Hard Rock, Rusty Scupper, Harbor Boats, Phillips Seafood, the Ripleys Museum-all easily walked to. You can take a water taxi from the Rusty Scupper to Fells Point & then Uber back late night for about $6.We will be back-we booked through groupon and our Saturday night through Expedia-great value.Great hotel with a boutique feel. The salt water indoor pool and hot tub were very nice. Love the gardens and super awesome they keep bees! Happy hour at the bar on the second floor has great specials. Be sure to try the honey glazed wings since they use the honey from their own bees. Just a warning--$36/night for valet parking plus tax makes it almost $45/night. Might be worth looking for another garage nearby for half the price.I would recommend checking about any planned maintenance during your stay, including any crews outside windows.From the time we arrived, until we the time we left, the staff was wonderful.  When we arrived we offered an upgrade by Carmen to harbor view. OMG so glad we did it... Worth it!  In addition, when she found out it was our 37th anniversary we had champagne and strawberries delivered to our room. What a nice surprise!  At check out we had our parking FREE.  It was a beautiful hotel and beautiful view of harbor.  We did not need the rental car because we could have gotten a cab from the airport.  Not knowing the area, we opted for the rental.  For a weekend, there is sooooo much around the harbor to see and do.  We had drinks one evening in the bar with light snack.  View of course was harbor.  Several mornings we ate in breakfast the Explorers Lounge.  One morning we ordered off menu and next we had buffet.  Both were good.Best of the bunch in the Inner Harbor.  Quiet, Quiet, Quiet.  Sound deadening was obviously employed in the rooms.  Clean, with all the amenities you could ever want.  But the staff really shines.  Attentive, professional, courteous.One star for gorgeous views, one star for location. This hotel has them all licked on that. Problem is, they know it. I could have given this hotel four stars. I wanted to. The concept is just stunning - beautiful place. But the service, maintenance and the labyrinth-like maze leave ALOT to be desired. Another hotel billed as a four star and didn't quite cut the mustard. After coming east for a funeral, I decided I would spend my last night here to sort of clear my head and adjust the vibes after a very sad weekend. Check in is a nightmare. You pull in to what literally looks like a large closet, with room for about six cars if you're all very careful. At that point, the valet is there to help (if you want to pay $36.00 per night plus tips - I don't know about you, but I hand my valets five to ten for each pick up/drop off). If you don't want the valet, there is a parking garage that should be connected to the hotel. It isn't. You must navigate a maze of corridors and elevators to get back in. This means no luggage cart, no nada. Very difficult if your bag is heavy. Finally got to the room. Looks nice and clean til you look. Open the cabinet - filthy. The triple toiletry dispenser on the wall had leaked "coco mango" conditioner all on the tub floor (dangerous). But the sheets were great and the beds were clean. I was promised a harbor view that I did not get. I got a nice view of a brick wall. All that for the bargain price of $180.00.It gets worse. I know my hotels and I always choose one with an onsite restaurant and bar. This experience is what ensured I won't return to Royal Sonesta, ever. My brother and I needed a nice cocktail to unwind. We walked into the restaurant to find no host. We seated ourselves at a table for two a bit away from the bar which was crowded with loud, obnoxious drunks. Then, the 300 lb waiter came over with menus. My brother said "no thanks, we'll just be having a beverage" to which the waiter replied (at 9:30 at night with only one other occupied table in the place) "Oh, well then you'll have to move over there" gesturing at the bar. All that remained for seating was a very uncomfortable looking banquette. "This is set up for dinner" he explained. Ridiculous. You certainly did not have a full restaurant - and I quickly found out why. When ordering, I wasn't 100 percent sure what I wanted. I was tired and wanted something refreshing. The waiter suggested a mojito. Rum is not my thing. I told him so and said "Oh, a mint julep would be great!" He looked at me funny and said they didn't have the ingredients for a mint julep. If you have a good strong whiskey and the stuff for a mojito, you most certainly have the makings of a mint julep. I then had to educate the waiter and explain that a mint julep is simply a strong bourbon whiskey served in a glass which has muddled mint, simple syrup and crushed ice. That's it. That freaking simple. He took it to the bartender, who failed miserably. He's clearly not a bartender, but a beer tender. I ordered an appetizer as I was slightly hungry and it was late. I ordered the brie/spinach "dip". This was simply awful. Near frozen brie, with a few spinach leaves mixed in with some microwaved brie on top, unedible toast rounds out of a box and the only good thing: artichoke chips. The waiter's attitude was just ridiculous. He got the standard 20% tip just to shove it in his face. I think because I looked so tired he may have "wallet profiled" me. Anyone who frequents high end establishments knows what wallet profiling is. Problem is, your server got it wrong this time. Another downer: playing terrible 80's R&B in the lobby after 9p.m.. Clearly this was not the hotel owners/managements choice but the girl behind the front desk. No one with the kind of money it costs to stay in this dive has listened to SWV since they were 12. Unbelievable. On second thought, thinking about that crappy waiter, it's one star for this low rent "trying to be high end on price alone" dive.Clean rooms, helpful and polite staff in this hotel.  Room service food was amazing. Only 3 stars because I felt the room should have been bigger for the price/view (stayed in a king with stated  harbor view but a wall half obstructed the view)I was very pleased. The staff were very friendly and helpful from the front desk to everyone else:-) very clean room and comfortable.This place was very good.BEAUTIFUL hotel! Everything about it was clean, elegant and convenient.  The room was spacious, the carpet was soft and clean and the bathroom was awesome!  (there was a TV in there! and the water pressure--oh  my oh my!)I booked a harbor-front view, which was WELL WORTH the price.  The view at night is so romantic; my fiance and I just sat there, looking at the passersby and the lights of the city for hours.  The parking situation is convenient but very expensive.  $26 for self-parking and $36 for valet.  I believe this is per day, but I am not sure.  The only bad thing about this hotel is the price for room service and the taxes.  I have never in my life paid $60 for breakfast.  I ordered a waffle, french toast and two sides of sausage.  Yes, that was $52---then I of course tipped the staff who brought it up.  WHOA.  If I could change anything about the trip, it would be to get out of my lazy state and go get breakfast somewhere else--the food was not worth it (I don't think any waffle is worth it haha).  The food was the same quality you would get at a local Denny's, so don't let the advertising on the menu fool you (it fooled me.  I expected a giant plate of chef-style food and was delivered a regular waffle with overcooked sausage).The hotel is walking distance from the main tourist attractions such as the aquarium (which is a must see!), the restaurants and bars.  The city is really clean and I absolutely loved just walking around.  Be aware of the hotel tax and surcharges.  I reserved my room for a rate of $159.  After taxes and charges, the room cost came up to $283.  Yes.  I am telling you the truth.  The taxes and fees were almost the same cost as the room.  No, this is not even the "incidentals" fee---this is just the tax.  So... With that said... Make sure you ask before you book! If you can, get a room that includes breakfast and possibly is on a higher floor.  A lot of people say they can hear the noise from the street, but we didn't and we were on the fourth floor.  So-- in a nutshell:1- BEAUTIFUL hotel2- Convenient3- Room Service is too expensive and not worth the cost4- Taxes are really high5- Parking is expensiveThe Royal Sonesta was my first choice in a hotel to stay in the Baltimore area. The hotel lobby is was more impressive then the actual room. My room wasn't that great. The bed was amazing, but that was about it. The bathroom had an outdated tv on the wall. That was pretty cool. I did not have the harbor view, but I can only imagine what it looked like. I ordered breakfast in the morning, I have to say it wasn't that great. For $60 dollars I could've had a 5 course dinner for one at a nice restaurant. I don't think I'll stay here again, I would like to explore what Baltimore has to offer.
review_content_20: Pros- Location overlooking the Inner Harbor- TV in the bathroomCons - A rapist friendly parking lot (I had to go through 3 doors / corridors to get to the lobby and the garage's carpeted urine smelling elevator was a nice touch)- Staticy Direct TV channels- Peeling wall paper and outdated carpeting and furniture- A toiletry dispenser in the shower for Coco Mango shampoo, conditioner, and shower gel- An empty refrigerator....all I wanted was water after my Belgian beer heavy dinnerOvernight parking: $26What an awful experience. The room was booked far in advance, then we tried to check in far in advance only to find out that we were subject to long lines, poor service and additional wait times far beyond the guaranteed 4pm check in time. All in all a very disappointing experience and certainly makes me never want to visit this hotel again... Ever.  The location is great but all of the other negatives completely negate the location.From the moment I walked in the staff were extremely friendly & helpful. They had my room ready earlier than expected, which was a very pleasant surprise. The room was big, clean & comfortable. I didn't watch much TV but when I did put it on the reception was a bit fuzzy. Great location, walking distance to everything. reasonable parking rates although I think the hotel prices in that area are a bit expensive & Sonesta was no exception. I would probably stay there again.I would not recommend the Royal Sonesta for a group.  We pre-paid for our rooms and they were not available at check-in.We were in Balitmore to celebrate Carnival and had to miss a half day of festivities due to check-in issues.  Many guests were not able to check in until after 6 p.m.  Simply terrible.This was hands down the worst stay I've ever had at a hotel, and I travel year round for work.  I checked in on Sunday and upon getting to my room turned on the air conditioner.  After about 30 minutes I realized it was not working.  I contacted the front desk and they sent a maintenance employee up.  After checking some things he left and said he was going to look into something in another area of the hotel to try to fix it.  It didn't get fixed that night and I never heard another word from any hotel employee asking if the issue had been resolved. I kept the air set on 66, but the room temperature never fell below 76. In the morning when I took a shower there was absolutely no water pressure.  The refrigerator in the room was also not cold, and the cabinet it was in was dry rotted.  It was disgusting.  I went to work and when I came back to the hotel on Monday it was again incredibly hot. I again called the front deal and they told me they would send someone up immediately and if it couldn't be fixed they would try to find me another room.  After waiting for 2 hours for my "immediate " help I left to go get something to eat.  In my way out I stopped by the front desk to find out why no one had come to my room.  The woman working couldn't have cared less about what I was asking her.  She told me someone would be up.  I was gone for about 20 minutes and returned to a still very hot room.  The temperature was at 78 by this time.  I never had anyone come to my room to check the problem, I never even got a call from anyone to see if I still needed someone, I never got an offer to be moved to another room.  When I woke up after a terrible nights sleep because it was so hot I had a note under my door for a free $25 breakfast.  It was infuriating and insulting.  I'm so glad I made the trip out here ahead of the rest of our team.  The other 7 members who are traveling from April 20-May 5 will absolutely be staying somewhere else.  I'm going to ensure that I share this experience with any and everyone that will listen.  I've never been treated so poorly!Was here for a conference.  I originally had a reservation set up for 5 days.  I asked if I could change my reservation to 4 days and if they could hold my bags on the 5th day as I tend to work stuff.  They were really helpful over the phone in changing my reservation.The taxi brought me here and I checked in.  When you enter, it's like entering an old palace with gold and chandaliers everywhere.  Checking in was a breeze.  Complimentary Wi-Fi!  Woo!When I got to my room, it looked a bit dated.  I understand the whole "royal" theme to it, but it's more like 1600's in the room.  Yes, the old furniture gives it a royal or old look, but it's a bit too old.  How?The corner of the bed was super dusty.  The lamps are rusty and hard to turn on/off.  In the bathroom, it was a nice touch to have the old feel to it, but too old.  The tiles made it cheapy.  So did the toilet.Taking off some stars as well because the tub/shower combo had hair all over.  Yuck!  Not like long pieces of hair either.  I'm talking short leg hair or private hairs on the sides and edges of the tub.  The showerhead looked rusty too.  I was scared to shower.I just can't justify the high price for a room because it's "royal" in whatever way.  I get the decor and color scheme makes it royal, but it's just old.Stayed here for one night and was apart of a large group that purchased 19 rooms. Our Exec team booked these rooms over 4 months in advance and yet when we arrived our rooms were not ready! We arrived around 4pm and I myself did not get into my room until after 6. I find that completely unacceptable.The front desk attendant had a bellman tag our bags and place them in storage but when trying to retrieve them when our rooms were finally ready she did not seem willing to assist as that was most likely not in her job description. I would hope that after guests were inconvenienced this much the staff would do their best to make their stay a positive one.The assistant manager also proceeded to give us the option to go to the hotel bar, ,pool and etc while we waited for our rooms to be ready. I found this ridiculous as these amenities would already be included if our rooms were ready when they were suppose to be.  I don't understand how you would think to recommend your inconvenienced guests to then patronage your hotel bar with no discount etc. I will never stay here again and will be sure to tell my colleagues, friends and family the same.A friend of mine booked a room for his girlfriend's birthday party on a Saturday night. He even informed the staff that that was the occasion. We were unprofessionally threatened by security several times because we were being loud at 10 PM. We checked outside of the room to see if we were indeed loud, but that wasn't the case. We knocked on the two doors on either side of our room to see if anyone would answer. No one did, so we were surprised that there were "complaints". I honestly feel like security had nothing to do that night and just kept rounding and stalking our rooms.As for potential housing patrons, the suites are pretty sizable. There's a large jacuzzi and a mini TV in the bathroom. The living quarters are spacious and the big is king-sized. The room doesn't wow you, but again, this isn't a 5-star hotel.Stayed here for 3 nights for business. Overall, cute hotel with very nice staff, but there is definitely room for improvement, and I believe they are already planning renovations. My two cents:Pros:- Not sure if everyone gets free web access, but the free level (basic) was plenty fast- Again, very nice and accommodating staff- I dig the vegetable based soap in the bathrooms- Nice to have a fridge for dinner leftovers- Super comfy beds, though I think the pillow tops need to be replaced (a bit misshapen)- Beautiful staircase and fresh flowers in the lobby- TV in the bathroom. Super cool!Suggested improvements:- Ditch the in shower shampoo, shower gel and conditioner dispensers. They just get in the way and who wants to use mystery toiletries??- Put a coffee maker in each room by default, not upon request- Linens throughout the property are just plain tacky (I believe this is part of their renovation plans)- Creepy paintings throughout the property need to go. Sure, there is a historical element, but at times, I felt like I was in the Haunted Mansion at Disneyland. (After a few drinks, I think one would feel the eyes in the paintings are following them)**TIP #1: If having the bellperson call a taxi for you, be sure to confirm ahead of time (if you need this) that they accept your credit card. (e.g., if traveling for biz and you have to put on your company credit card).**TIP #2: Use a car service instead of taxi to get to the airport. About the same cost, more comfy of a ride, clean, they have A/C and won't claim their credit card machine is down as most cabbies do.3-1/2 stars, leaning forward because of extremely friendly staff. Every single person I dealt with was professional and very helpful.This hotel is in a fantastic location, the inner harbor in Baltimore. You are right across the street from the harbor and plenty of shopping/eating choices.The hotel itself is fine, but nothing makes it truly outstanding or memorable. Rooms are pretty standard, pretty clean and well-enough appointed, but again, nothing special. One odd note, the bathrooms have installed dispensers for shampoo/conditioner/body wash in the shower. I personally don't care for that, give me my un-opened, fresh little bottles, please! BUT, this is just a personal preference.I think the location is the real draw of this hotel; convenient to all downtown Baltimore has to offer.First, the positives: the recently renovated rooms were comfortable and the hotel is in an ideal location in Baltimore's Inner Harbor...convenient to shops, restaurants, and attractions.Now, the one major negative that has prompted the decision for me to never stay at this hotel again:The check-in process was atrocious, the worst check-in I've ever experienced at a hotel before. I reserved a room with 2 double beds approximately two months in advance of our stay. We were expecting crowds because of the warm weather, Orioles opening weekend, and admitted students events at local colleges. I was willing to pay for early check-in, but the hotel noted that their policy did not allow for that and there was no room. We arrived early, around 11:30 AM, and knew that were most likely too early for our room to be ready. Note that the check-out time was 12 PM and check-in time was 4 PM. The front desk offered to store our luggage while we explored the Inner Harbor, and we returned at about 3:40 PM. The woman at the front-desk noted that our room would not be ready until 4 PM, so we patiently took a seat in the lobby while we waited. We were not upset yet, because I cannot fault a hotel for not having a room available before the posted check-in time. As we were waiting, I noticed multiple parties lining up to check in, and the line was so long that it was almost to the exit door at the front of the lobby. Noticing the time, I decided to get in the line. I have never seen a check-in line this long before, it was insane. As I was in the line, the time passed 4 PM and parties were still getting turned away at the front desk and told to return because rooms were not ready yet. Eventually, the front desk began to say that parties had to wait until 5 PM and should call then to see if their room was available. At 4:15 PM, there were still 5-6 people ahead of me in line. The hotel seemed to completely disregard the fact that some of us had places to be. I even talked to a father whose son was getting married nearby and he had to leave the hotel within the hour, but his room was not available for him to get ready in at the posted 4 PM time. Some families were even having their kids go stand in the back of the line so they would have a back-up option should they be denied a room the first time (my sister did this for us). When I finally made it to the front of line, at about 4:40 PM and after about 50 minutes of standing in line, the only reason I was able to get our room keys was because I told the woman this was my third time to the check-in desk and pretty much demanded we have a room (we had dinner reservations to get to and we had not even begun to get ready yet without a hotel room). Luckily, she gave us room keys, much to the dismay of the 10-12 parties before me who were denied a room. I obviously felt bad for them too! This was by far the most dysfunctional check-in experience I have ever been a part of, and I am not happy that we gave the hotel our money this weekend.I am disappointed because the renovations were so on par and location is so ideal. I will not be staying here again.I'm only reviewing the bar area, as I met some friends for a drink. I got the Berry Martini and it was delicious. The service was great and if you're looking for a chill place with a great view---this is a nice option if you're in the area or having friends staying there.Stayed hear for a week, overall I liked this hotel. The rooftop Basketball court was a nice feature, loved the pool and the racquetball. Room overlooks inner harbor right near inner harbor and Camden yards.Pros: Service, cleanliness of the suite, location, had valet parking, amenities Cons: Bad maintenance of the plumbing,  a malfunctioning Keurig machine, pricey breakfast in bedI am extremely OCD about dust and germs, but this room was super clean, which was definitely a win for me.  The bed felt fantastic, and I loved how they supplied various beverages in the minibar.  As some reviews have already stated, the lobby is much more grand than the actual room itself.  Kind of seemed 'empty' when we first walked through the doors to our suite.  I also paid for the breakfast in the morning, but for the price and the way they presented it, I immediately regretted my choice.  The price was ridiculous! I could've taken us to an amazing restaurant right in front of the hotel with that.  Overall, it was a nice experience.  I paid $181 for one night, and my lady and I did enjoy ourselves at Inner Harbor, but for a 4-star hotel, we expected the drains to be working perfectly.  Just washing out hands almost flooded the sink.  The same thing happened while we were taking a shower.  Probably will go to the Four Seasons next time we visit Inner Harbor.This boutique style hotel might be a hidden gem on the harbor. The European decor really sets it a part from your average hotel. The doormen were friendly and very helpful with taking my luggage to the room. I was able to check in early and even snagged free wifi. I didn't utilize the restaurant or coffee shop, but I'm sure it compliments the hotel.Ideal location with nothing to back it up.  Needs refurbishing (upholstery is dismal) immediately.  At 1 am, the door opened for a guest that was just checking in!The hotel has a prime location near the waterfront and convention center. While it was a little pricey compared to others I've stayed at in the area, the room was pretty big, as was the bathroom, which had a television overlooking the sink. The lobby decorum was nice, especially the big makeshift stairs and library. While I didn't spend much time at the hotel and have little else to say, I will mention that my one disappointment with the place was that a continental breakfast was not included with the room. There was one available, but it was rather pricey.Unfortunately it is just not the harbor court hotel it used to be.  Went to the beautiful bar that used to have wonderful adorned animal prints and furnishings.  They have replaced with typical hotel furnishings and cold lighting.  On top if that the wait staff is below professional that they used to be. Asked us to check our before we even had our second sip of our drink.  No class left here, we will not be back.What a disappointment!!! I booked here over 4th of July weekend and was very disappointed with my "city-view room" on the 5th floor looking at a wall across the street (honest. see the pictures). I have stayed at a lot of hotels, for business and for pleasure, and I have to say this hotel is a wanna-be modern hotel riding on the coat tails of some kind of apparent formerly grand reputation. It's not like a motel or low-class hotel, but for a "superior" hotel the style and decor were very dated with 'gramma's living room"-style upholstery. The rug in my room was stained in 2 places with something that made the antique roses appear to be consumed by giant black blobs. It was quiet, and the beds were mushy and comfortable is the best thing I can say. Oh, and free WiFi was nice. My friend told me the Renaissance Inn was great, and I very much wished I had stayed there or in Harbor East or Fells Point maybe even. I even booked via them rather than through a third party hoping I would get better treatment as a guest--to no avail. Front desk staff is snooty to boot. Onsite cafe staff and others very friendly though. The rate the hotel was offering that weekend was deeply discounted, which makes me think they had a ton of availability, so why not throw guests a bone with an upgrade to the same class room on a higher floor? If I had paid $400 for that room, I would have been absolutely ill, all over the blob-consumed roses.Nice hotel on the western part of the Inner Harbor, where you want to be in a B'more visit.  Our room was large and well appointed and nicely decorated.  Valet parking is available, though i highly recommend finding a room rate package where this is included in your stay.  The front staff and the valet were friendly and professional.  When we checked in we were well greeted and handed a small package of Berger cookies, which i thought was a nice touch.  You can tell the hotels pays attention to these details, especially when they ask about it in a survey you receive after your stay.  Almost scary how detailed-oriented they are, but it's nice that they pay that close attention to quality of service, which is much appreciated.Overall a nice Inner Harbor stay.  Definitely an option if you're looking for a nice room.
review_content_40: Quite possibly the best hotel experience I've ever had. We got there way before check in and were immediately accommodated by the wonderful Brittany at the front desk. We got a room and mentioned that we live in the area and were here for our anniversary. When we got to our room we noticed we had gotten a room with 2 full beds, not the most romantic but we were fine with it. Not 2 minutes later Brittany called the room and said she realized she had given us a two bed room, would we like a king? We said sure and the bellman came up to bring us our new key. The bellman was awesome and so nice and lead us to our new room which was an amazing harbor view suite. We were speechless. We could barely afford the little garden view room we had initially booked so getting the upgrade was such a treat. Then, to top off what was already above and beyond what we ever could have hoped for, we came home from dinner to a bottle of champagne, chocolate covered strawberries and a card wishing us a happy anniversary! The room was fantastic. It was huge with a chandelier, jacuzzi tub that could have fit 5 people, a TV in the bathroom as well as the bedroom area. The bed was one of the most comfortable I've slept in and had the benefit of being a king size sleigh bed. The best part of the whole room though was the view. I've lived in Baltimore my whole life and this view gave me a new perspective on the city. It was incredible. Before booking I read some reviews saying that the hotel was decor was dated and dirty. I was able to see a standard room and a suite and found both to be very clean and, I thought, adorable. It's not the typical decor you find in an airport Hilton or one of the thousands of other hotels you can stay at but it's nice. Our bathroom had an incredible rain forest mural all over the walls, the hotel bar is jungle themed with a taxidermy panther and gong. It's different and fun and a little quirky. We loved it.There is so much to say about this hotel.  My husband and I just got married in Baltimore (3/29/2014) and we really loved staying here with all our out of town guests. I happened upon this hotel by doing an inquiry with the Baltimore Chamber of Commerce.  This enabled us to accept e-mail bids FROM prospective wedding hotels vs. the typical wedding where the bride or groom sends multiple e-mails out.  Basically, we had every big hotel in downtown Baltimore competing for our business, since they knew we had contacted the BCofC. This provided us about 30 hotels competing for our wedding contract.  We choose the RSHC because of their online reviews for excellent customer service (TRUE), their heated indoor pool, their beautiful furnishings and decor (I'm an artist and my husband is very artistic, so aesthetics are important to our enjoyment of most experiences), and finally because they offered a better price than the other high-end hotels downtown (who had pools).  The RSHC treated all our guests consistently with gentleness, respect, and friendliness.  Many of our guests are elderly and/or infirmed, so this was very important to our enjoyment - knowing their needs were met and they were well cared for. Whenever anyone needed anything, NOBODY EVER give off a vibe of 'that's not my job.' Rare in today's world.I would like to particularly commend: Tonya, Don, James and the others in their bellhop/valet division who really were outstandingly friendly and efficient, Jonathan the concierge who helped us with our welcome bags and further helped with suggestions about where to eat or shop, Carmen, also from the front desk, who helped my mom with printing and coordinating some travel reservations, and most of all Liz, in their group sales dept., who answered all my various questions over a period of more than a year - both promptly and with high spirits. Liz arranged for an AMAZING upgrade for my fiance/husband to a huge, glorious, sexy, romantic, splendid, plush, elegant suite.  She also arranged for a generous upgrade for my sister and her husband, as a gift from my husband and I to thank them for hosting us at Thanksgiving and to treat them in the midst of hard financial time they've been  having....maybe an unorthodox 'comp' but she made it happen!Beautiful view, but a lot of the room amenities didn't work!  My husband surprised me with a suite here for our 2 year anniversary back in February.  Check in was easy and the view from the room was spectacular, however, the phone didn't work and the light over our GIGANTIC tub in the bathroom was burnt out.  I knew my husband dropped a LOT of dough on this room and I felt  it was unacceptable for such a high priced room t be lacking the most basic amenities.  We addressed them with the staff on our way out for the evening, and when we returned to our room, the phone and light were fixed.  Thanks, maintenance man!!! One thing that really impressed me about the hotel was the bar/restaurant.  Before we hit Fogo de Chao for dinner, we stopped at the bar/restaurant for a drink and an appetizer.  We had the spicy/sweet calamari and I am 100% honest when I tell you that it was the best calamari I have ever had.  It absolutely melted in your mouth.  I also had a really delicious drink there (I don't remember the name but it had Chambord in it and the rim was dipped in honey). Delicious!  I gave the hotel 3 stars because the rooms are very dated (carpets worn, wallpaper peeling off in the bathroom, and the lack of basic room amenities being functional).  It's not a terrible hotel, but when you're paying $550 for one night in a suite, it betta be decent!There are two very separate reviews for this place. The hotel itself and the service & convenience.Let's start with the good. The hotel service was truly excellent. From the second I got there they were on the ball with getting me checked in quickly and accommodated my request for a room on a higher floor. Each time I needed a car from the hotel to meetings downtown, I was able to call downstairs and have a car waiting within 5 minutes. It was very convenient to walk to parts of the harbor as well where meetings were being held or to just grab a drink or some food. The hotel is located right across the street from the water and is probably especially nice in the summertime. It is a little bit of a walk from the center of the inner harbor, but in the summer it wouldn't matter. Overall service and convenience were both excellent in my opinion.Now to the bad. And by bad, I mean the god awful decor of this hotel. What the......  When I walked into my room I literally felt like I stepped into a time machine that took me back to the 1950's. The carpet was maroon red with unbelievably ugly designs in it. In addition to this, the seemingly 50 year old carpet gave the room a musky smell. It was obviously the smell of 50 years of guests staying there. The room was huge, but the lighting was terrible. There were 3 lights and it barely lit up half the room. In this huge room, I'm not sure who thought it would be a good idea to put a 20 inch screen TV on the dresser in a part of the room that makes the TV impossible to see unless you're wearing Harry Carrey's glasses... it was truly weird. The strangest thing of all was the bathroom and how it was completely the opposite of the entire room. The bathroom was brand spanking new and clean to the T. They obviously re-did the bathroom and said F the rest of the hotel room. This hotel is doing itself a huge disservice by not upgrading the rooms. You're better of closing for a short period of time and getting the whole place redone, rather than charging guest to stay in poorly configured, oversized and anciently decorated rooms. Great hotel for convenience and service, but the visual effects kill any hope it has.Decor and bar staff great, front desk staff rude, inattentive and forgetful. We stayed here as part of a wedding party, so after a nearly three hour drive we would have expected a smile and a welcoming greeting. Instead, the front desk was on the phone and we had to wait to be checked in (while our friends were waiting at the ball game for us). Second, there was a $100 per night "incidentals deposit fee" charged to our card that the front desk couldn't explain. (We found out at the wedding that NO other guests were charged this fee). Third, we found out that the wedding hosts put together a wonderful gift bag that we did not receive, even though our account clearly showed we were booked as part of the group. No coffee makers in the rooms. Hot water from the bathroom sink a trickle. Slow Internet access limited to three devices only. Room service prices are high but on par with 5 star hotels, however the Sonesta is far from 5 star. On the positive side, Steven at the bar was exceptional. He made great conversation, great drinks and even attended to my girlfriend when her knee was bleeding from tripping on the old streetcar tracks. The decor is nice, very roomy and comfortable lounge with lots of sofas, quiet and quaint. Room was large and LCD in bathroom. Bed was very comfortable. I recommend this hotel have Steven train the front desk staff on customer service and basic manners. Since the front desk makes the first impression, we will likely not stay here again.This Hotel use to be one of the best if not the best in Baltimore at the Inner Harbor, it was and still is awarded the highest rating and they should be stripped! The carpert was horrific the rooms decor was ugly at best the best was great but the rest of the furniture dated and in need of restoration- The need to go floor by floor and totally redo this property I was so disappointed.The front desk was not the best for the start rating either but The valet and bell staff we top notch professionals! I would not stay here for more than 99 a night and I only say that much because of it supreme location to the harbor and ball park(s). I was there for a Ravens game, I was able to walk to the stadium which saved a lot that where the goodness of luxury convenience stopped.Was in town with a group to celebrate Carnival. Upon arrival at the hotel at around 3:45 and the rooms were not ready. I find that very unacceptable. Some in our group did not get their rooms until after 6:00 PM.I've stayed at a number of hotels in the Baltimore area and by far this was the worst.This place should be given 5 stars! The staff was so very nice and sent me a complimentary piece of cake for my bday and a personalized note! Awesome staff and clean hotel with great city view. Everyone was so friendly and nice. I had a great experience and it made my bday extra specialFast, easy, professional check in.  5th floor facing harbor has great view (the bed actually faces the window instead of the TV!) Pricey restaurant and drinks.  Pool, hot tub and gym on the 7th floor.  Note:  don't forget to bring toothpaste; we needed some and they provided a 5g "tube"- pretty funny!First, I want to say that Tony, our porter, was wonderful. If it wasn't for him, we probably would have left soon after we checked in. We live in Baltimore and reserved a room for two nights to celebrate our anniversary - couldn't get away, so thought this would be the next best thing. We booked a king size bed and arrived to find we had been "upgraded" to a queen. There were no kings available, and they kept saying it was an upgrade even though it wasn't. That was really annoying. Then we noticed a memo at the front desk about brown water in the rooms due to construction. That didn't bode well, but we decided to check in anyway. Tony graciously took us to our room and made sure we were settled in - he even filled our ice bucket for us. He was very pleasant and kind, explaining that all the dust and plastic covering the floors in the hallways was due to renovations. He apologized, but we were shocked they had us in a room in a construction zone.  After being in the room a short time we noticed the trash hadn't been emptied and the fridge had someone's leftover drinks in it. Then we realized the toilet was broken and was running continuously. It was close to midnight, so we turned the water off to the toilet so it wouldn't keep us up and called the front desk to let them know what was going on. They emptied the trash and fixed the toilet the next day while we were out. We came back in the evening after a day spent downtown, thinking it would be nice to take a swim. We were informed the pool was open, but that the water was "colder than usual" because of the construction so we opted to skip it. Upon checking out the next morning, we discovered a room service charge for breakfast was on our bill. We told them we never ordered breakfast and the reply was "oh, sometimes they bill it to the wrong room". Good thing we didn't just pay for it, huh? We explained our disappointment with how things had gone, and Sarah H., at the front desk did offer us a partial credit which was very much appreciated. Our weekend was by no means ruined,  my husband and I can have a good time in almost any situation, but we were really surprised by our experience at this hotel - we hoped for (and expected) so much more. The location is great, we walked all over downtown and really enjoyed being tourists in our hometown, but the hotel didn't provide the respite we had hoped for. I would advise anyone thinking of booking a room at RSHC to triple check and make sure the renovations are completed before making a reservation. Frankly, they shouldn't be open if they can't provide better service. I would hate to see someone visiting Baltimore from out of town have an experience like ours.Friendly and pleasant staff, sometimes in short supply; the rooms are large but a throwback to some distant past, dim lights and stained carpeting complement a horrible decor, with the exception of the bathroom, which was new, but the gold plated everything was garish. NO basic room amenities such as a coffee maker or microwave - just an old empty fridge, and to get coffee in the morning you must buy it at their small espresso kiosk by the lobby (long lines and only one person serving, with prices that will make Starbucks blush with envy...), or at the dining room on the second floor, both very pricey!...Two eggs were $17.00 !!! Hence the reason for the absent coffee maker, I guess.The pool is on the roof, surrounded by neglected outdoor garden, and some view of the area, if you tiptoe up over the wall...They will charge you for parking each night ($36.00).
