That whole area by the waterfront is very expensive and meant for tourists, much like New York's South street Seaport. The rest of what we saw of the city could use some serious renovations along with this hotel.This hotel is absolutely terrific. I came here with my wife for a mini-moon the weekend after our wedding, and we were very impressed. The bellhop that greeted us was prompt and courteous, the concierge service hit on everything that they recommended for us to go and do (i.e. restaurants and activities). They even upgraded our room to a harbor view suite when they heard that we were on our honeymoon. The one minor hiccup came when we had to remind them that we ordered a champagne and chocolate strawberry package with our reservation that was not ready for our arrival. This is definitely a four star hotel, and probably one of the best bets in terms of service and overall style available near or in the inner harbor.First off, The decor is horrid.The lobby is kind of nice but the room really was ugly.  The carpet is ugly and reminds me of the 1930s and our room had ugly pink wallpaper. The service started off bad. Check in is at 3pm. We arrived at around 6 and our room wasnt ready. I didnt mind too bad because we had a friend staying there and we met up at the bar and waite the extra 20 minutes it took for our room to be readied. The bar was small and the bartender was sort of corny. We got the room on special so the price was decent but I would never pay full price for this place. It just didnt wow me.NOT GOOD.  My Meetup group had organized a trip to Baltimore, for CARINVAL.  There were 36 of us in double occupancy rooms. After the first activities, we went to check in @ 4pm at the Royal Sonesta.  1. We had to stand in the lobby because the hotel wanted us to only use the manager to check in.  So other guests were able to check in before us. Even when there were no other guest we were only limited to the 1 customer service person. 2. One Asian customer service rep gave us the stank eye the whole time.  We were not loud or rowdy.  We hadn't spoken to her she hadn't spoken to us.  She just stared at us.3. At 4pm 3-4 rooms were given out.  15 minutes later there was an announcement that they weren't any clean rooms left.  Come back later, no time frame given.  Since we protested that we wanted a shower, they told us to use the shower by the pool.  They would hold our bags and food and beverage was available for purchase. No complementary anything for the inconvenience or late check out. (side note you need a room key to go into the pool area)4. After returning two hours later, I was asked how well I knew my roommate.  Confused I answered somewhat.  The manager, was trying to give us a king bed.  After she saw the anger on my face she found a double bed room. What I paid for.5. There was no bell man to retrieve our bags, so security had to. He had an attitude because this was not his job and tried to give me the keys to GET IT MYSELF.  I told him that if I got those keys I would go shopping in there for all the inconvenience the hotel put me through.  He quickly retrieved my bags. (I'm not a theft but it scared him lol)6.  The rooms and pool was nice but, our group was scared throughout the hotel.  It would have been nice to be on the same floor.7. On Saturday night we asked the hotel to call a taxi for us.  We were told it be faster for us to just hail 1 outside.  Yeah great have 30 + ladies hail cabs in club outfits. Thanks Royal Sonesta.  When we returned in 1 piece & in multiple cabs we were cheering.  Then a security man came & yelled at us like school children in the most aggressive manner to quiet down.  He later apologized stating another security manner got him upset and he took it out on us... 8. Check out was at 11am, however the maid was knocking on our down reminding us of check out @ 10:30 am.  Hmm they couldn't do that the day before huh. 9. Still needed a credit card for our pre paid room.  Received no receipt for my check out because it was already paid.  I had to ask questions to receive information.  I was told that my charge for the room would automatically be dropped however it took a few business days.The location was good. The next day a new batch of bellmen came in that were very courteous. Those bellmen even help out a stranded member of our group.  I believe one man was named Ernest. However this hotel was a big fail. Royal my behind.Wonderful staff and facility.My husband and I just stayed here this past weekend. Beautiful! We had a harbor view room and the view was great! The room as very spacious and bed was very comfy! Walking distance to everything. The only bad thing I can say if I were looking for one is that you can not check in until 4:00. But they will hold your bags for you! Went to eat at Bubba Gumps before check in and went to Power Plant Live that evening. Perfect weekend in Baltimore!I recently stayed for a long weekend at this hotel and I had nothing but a great experience with the staff & stay. The room furniture is a little outdated, yes, but the  most important things I would say is it's clean, comfy, has a great view plus convenience of the harbor and some very good food. The pool is indoor and is a bit small but the hot tub/sauna was nice and if it's bad weather outside, this is good entertainment for the family. Valet parking is a bit expensive yes, but all Sonesta's in the big cities seem to be this way. You can opt for self parking to save a few $$. The bathroom lighting was a bit dim, not sure if it was the bulbs used or intended to be this way. If you want to see the Orioles play you can walk to the stadium. TV's in both bathroom and bedroom, nice and quiet, just the way I like it. Right accross the street is the Science Center and the stores/restaurants on the Inner Harbor.I stayed at this Hotel recently and was very much pleased.  The service was excellent.  The bellhop was on point with dining recommendations, he was courteous and very attentive.  We checked in quickly and were very pleased with our accomodations.My friend and I stayed here for the night to rest up for our drive to NYC.  It is located across the street from the Harbor so if you're lucky enough to get a room that over looks it like we had then you're really in for a treat.  The view is just amazing and only gets better as everything starts to light up in the evening over the harbor waters.  We had a bay window so it was a great view all around.  The woman at the service desk was very friendly and courteous when we checked in.  I noticed the staircase in the lobby area that spiraled up to the second floor.  It looked very nice and clean.  Unfortunately the pool hours ended at 8pm so we couldn't get in as it was already a bit late.  Our room was very roomy and I am not quite use to having a tv and a phone in the bathroom however it was nice to have in case.  The beds were very comfortable and I enjoyed the break from driving all day to lay on something so soft.  We grabbed a couple drinks from the Explorer's Lounge on the second floor.  It was nice, with couches and tables you can choose to relax wherever you like.  We hung around for a bit and then took our drinks with us back to our room.  I would highly recommend that you grab a bite to eat in their hotel restaurant Brightons.  We were in a hurry to leave early but luckily the restaurant opens at 6:30am and we ordered food to go.  The Chesapeake Crab Cakes Benedict is phenomenal.  It comes with a side of breakfast cut potato's and probably made my morning that much more enjoyable.  A great choice to stay for a night.NOT good for group travel! My Meetup group had organized a trip to Baltimore, and reserved at the Royal Sonesta for our overnight stay. I'd seen the mixed reviews on Yelp before we'd left, but I was still looking forward to our stay at this hotel. So our private coach drops our group of 36 ladies off on the sidewalk (there's no hotel parking lot or garage). We arrived just after 4pm for check-in only to find that not everyone's room was available. So of the 18 hotel rooms we'd PRE-PAID for, only 4 were ready for check-in. Now I'm a fairly flexible person, having worked in the service industry, but that's a bit ridiculous when you already have a check-in that's later than most other hotels! We've just spent the last 3 hours in the July sun and all anyone could talk about was getting a shower! They'd offered to put our bags away in the Regency Hotel NEXT DOOR until our rooms were ready. After squaring away my own bag in a friend's room, we'd decided to go grab some food. Around 6pm we'd returned to the hotel and I was finally able to check in. This completely threw off our group's schedule, so no one was able to return to the city's Caribbean Carnival celebration...the whole purpose of our trip!! The rooms were very nice and the beds uber comfy. I was glad to be given a room with 2 queen beds, unlike 4 of our group members, who were forced to share king beds...a bit awkward since these 4 ladies had never met before this trip!! The location was good, and the staff was courteous and tried to be very helpful in light of the circumstances, but they'd failed where it truly counted.
review_content_60: The hotel and the location of the hotel (physical appearance and location) is great!  The staff is at the total opposite end of the spectrum.  This hotel would improve greatly if they greatly improved the customer service.  My room was not available at check-in and when I checked out I heard other people complaining there room was not ready and it was well after checkout.  Also, housekeeping took my bathing suit and lost it in the sheets and towels.

review_content: First off, if I was going to stay in Baltimore again on "my own dime" rather than on an expense account, I'd likely stay at this hotel again. However this hotel is really hard to review because it's hard to describe it accurately without seeming negative. My best analysis is that it's the McDonald's of chic hotels. At first glance the furniture seems high end, the art trendy (Frank Zappa pic in the bathroom) and the vibe kind of boutique. But then you realize it's more TJ Maxx than Macy's BUT the room was about $100 per night and exactly 1 block from the center of the Inner Harbor area. In fact it's across the street from the back of the Rennaissance, one of the nicest hotels in Baltimore. From hotel to Inner Harbor walking is about 100 yards or less and there's a parking garage, not owned by them, next door ($21 for each 24 hour period). For that $100 I got 2 free bottles of water, free wifi and a suite with a separate living room with desk, couch, microwave and refrigerator and a bed room and full bath. I also got free breakfast in lounge on the top floor with a great Harbor view. Breakfast is standard free stuff but includes make your own waffles, eggs, bacon, cereal, etc. Occasionally there will be scuff, rust spot or less than perfect item, but I often stay at the Hyatt at $250 per night so it's a fair trade given the price and location.We stayed for one visit to Baltimore And Booked through a third party.Front desk and maintenance staff were very accommodating, that is the reason we are giving them 3 stars. Seems to be an older building with some issues, we were lacking heat in our room, hotel was completely booked so we were not offered another room, repairs were attempted with no fix, we were offered quite a few things that made this a acceptable stay. Location is great. Breakfast was adequate. Come stay here to enjoy the inner harbor,Room was pretty, but a few flaws as well. First room, the heat wasn't working so the front desk quickly change our room. 2nd room bathroom was much more dirty. I guess I can't have it all :(Close to everything in the inner harbor. Definitely a plus. The free purple and green circulator bus ran right out front.Breakfast was pretty good, but needed to be warmed up. Had things like, scrambled eggs, sausages, cereal, bagels, mc muffins, bread, yogurt, waffle machine, oatmeal, fruit, juices and tea and coffee. It was on the top level which made eating breakfast a beautiful view. Gym was right there, just in case you had to shed a few pounds from the breakfast.Modern, clean and convenient location!! Super friendly staff. Hot continental breakfast, clean 24 hour gym and bar on site. All decorations are simple, relaxing and artsy. Comfortable beds and couches, large, flatscreen TVs. Friendly and professional housekeeping service who are willing to work around you. Don't be thrown off by the lower than surrounding hotel prices: This place is a gem!!We stayed at Brookshire for a recent weekend getaway.  It was a great set-up for our family.  We were within close walking distance to all of the Inner Harbor attractions.  Definitely not a five star hotel, but also quite adequate for the price.  My husband, two year old, and myself got the one bedroom suite with the king bed. They had the crib (sturdy, comfortable crib - not a flimsy playpen - yay!) ready in the room. The living room and bedroom were separate with a TV in both rooms and a pull-out sofa bed in the living room.  The kitchen area (fridge, sink, microwave, cabinets, small counter, coffee maker) were in the living area.  The bathroom (modest - regular bath, average size) was in the bedroom.  There were closets in both areas. A small desk, rolling chair, and club chair were in the living room.There was an obvious attempt to make the decorations feel modern and trendy. Some of the fixtures seemed older and in need of repair - i.e. rust in the sink drain, rust on the shelving in the bathroom.  We parking in a parking garage across the street.  It was $21/24 hours.  Our two days (~37 hours) cost $42.  The view in the breakfast area is great.  It's on the top floor, with big windows that look across the harbor.  The breakfast food reminded me almost exactly of what Hampton Inn serves - waffle maker, dry eggs, meat, fruit, breads, toaster, yogurt, cereal, etc.   We had limited interactions with staff since we had no issues, but the staff seemed nice.This hotel met most of our hopes - price, location, and suite-style rooms.  Wouldn't go here expecting luxury or brand new facilities, but IMO it's completely decent.This is a great place for a one or two night stay.  I prefer hotels with a full service restaurant but for my one-night stay in Baltimore Brookshire was perfect.  It's walking distance to shopping, restaurants and entertainment.  The continental breakfast was sufficient to get the day started with my favorite being the Belgian waffle maker.  Front desk staff were very polite and my room was clean and neat with no problems at all.  I'll definitely stay here again.My husband and I stayed here for our anniversary weekend a couple of weeks ago so we could spend most of our time at the inner harbor. The hotel was soooo my style. It had modern decor and cool pictures on the walls throughout. The room was what I expected, but just a bit smaller. It had a nice sized tv, a mircowave, mini fridge, and kitchenette sink. The only thing my husband found issue with was the same thing stated in plenty of other reviews - the picture over the toilet. I used a groupon, so even though the room was really only big enough to sleep in, it still felt like a steal. The complimentary breakfast left something to be desired in terms of hot bar items (eggs, sausage, and oatmeal only), but they also had a waffle maker, cereal, toast, bagels, pastries, English muffins, yogurt, coffee/tea and juice bar. As long as you're not expecting a 5* buffet, you'll have a filling, enjoyable, breakfast. Service was great and they were responsive.Honestly, the only thing that ruined the experience for me was the lack of dedicated parking garage. I understand that it's the city, but the prices were ridiculous and the staff was unpleasant at the garage we parked in. Now, there is valet parking dedicated to the hotel but those prices were even more steep. I would definitely stay again, but probably look into parking a bit further away to save some money and an unnecessary headache."Great Night's Stay before our Cruise out of Baltimore Harbor"My husband and I stayed at Brookshire Suites the night before we left on a Royal Caribbean Cruise from the Baltimore Port.  The front desk was courteous and professional, the location is a short walk from the Harbor, and the room was large and well appointed, and included a fridge, sink and microwave, nicely decorated and the bed slept like a dream!  Breakfast was on the top floor, it was delicious, with an "eggs to order bar" and the view was refreshing.  We wished we had a little more time to spend at the Brookshire, we will definitely return!Stayed her for a quick over night stay to check out the Inner Harbor and general area.. Upon check in the front desk Kelly was very nice and offered me a free upgrade to the One Bedroom suite from my Queen bed room which was apparently a lot smaller..which was a win on my end why not let's go free upgrades rock! lol..The rooms are very nice to begin for the price.. nice large living room with your typical sofa, microwave, large fridge by hotel standard's what looks to be a first for me is two free water's included... Anyone that stay's in a good chunk of hotel's over the years know's the struggle of places charging for a water or giving you one of these small 8 oz water's at best! That actual bed room was nice, comfortable and super clean. The bathroom was a little on the smaller side and a tad dated looking but there is only so far you can go in a refresh of a hotel before it moves into a whole new ball park of price ranges.. don't get me wrong it was clean and stocked which always is a first hit or miss thing some places lack.Upon leaving the maid was nice enough to ask if I needed any water's or how my stay was making sure the room was clean... another industry first in my time of staying in hotel's as most maid's give you the hello or quick nod.. It made me feel welcome and she did a great job upon arrival to the room it was spotless. Parking wise I used the parking garage across the street on the hotel side which was a breeze to use but they do offer Valet. Remember this hotel is only a block away from main Inner Harbor a major plus if your visiting for that reason.I gotta say for a smaller hotel and a first of my stay I was impressed and couldn't ding this place if I tried it was a well rounded, friendly, clean hotel with a great staff for the price.. Give them a shot they deserve in an industry dominated by other big chain hotels.Stayed here for Otakon weekend. The staff were very friendly and greeted us everytime we came in. Which we were skeptical about because we probably had 6 or 7 people in our room lol. But the place is very cute and updated and free wifi!Walking distance to the convention center and the inner harbor. There is also a parking garage close by but not associated with the hotel. Parking was about $20 per day. We also had a handicap person with us so they are handicapp friendly!My husband and I spent two nights in Baltimore, not knowing the area at all we booked a hotel in walking distance to the aquarium seeing as that was the reason for our trip.Upon check in we where welcomed by the wonderful front desk staff, we thought this was going to be a great stay.That night I jumped in the shower, when I got out the bathroom floor was flooded. I'm talking inches on water. I immediately call the front desk and they send housekeeping and maintenance up. They commented on how insane it was that it flooded and on how much condensation was on the walls because there is no fan. I was SHOCKED that the front desk staff didn't offer us a room. The next night I was woken up by my neighbors. I felt like I was in my college dorm again. I could hear them talking, flushing to toilets and banging around. And then at 7:30 was woken again from the banging on my ceiling. Also, the wall paper was peeling off in the room and our bathroom vanity was falling apart.Parking was another frustrating part of the trip. we parked across the street in the garage not knowing how expensive it is because the signage is not accurate. I wish the hotel could  have recommend a garage that was a little more inexpensive.The only reason I am giving this hotel two stars is because of the front desk staff that greeted us and the front desk girl Monday night. Other then that save your time and book somewhere else.I stayed here for two nights with my boyfriend, we were here for the Ravens game. I booked this room two months in advance through Expedia. When I booked through Expedia, I got a rate that said it included all of my fees etc. When we got there, I was told there was a $9.95 PER DAY mandatory destination fee which was for the wi-fi, access to the gym and breakfast. There was also a $50 deposit but you're supposed to get that back after check out. I also thought it was closer to the harbor than it actually was but that wasn't a big deal because the harbor and restaurant were only about a 7-10 minute walk. There are two parking garages across the street, $21/day but that does not include in and out. So we spent $57 on parking in two days not including when we left to park on the harbor. For the price, I was hoping for more amenities. Being from out of town, I didn't realize that this was more of a business hotel. When we book, we always book hotels with indoor pools or hot tubs. The staff was really nice, our room was super hot when we got there. The girl at the front desk told us they turned the heat up thinking it would be colder than it really was so they gave us a fan for the duration of our stay. Overall, we had a good experience especially with being from out of town.I've been here 3 times every year because I go to the dragon boat festival that happens at Fells Point at the Under Armour headquarters. So this year, is the first year our team has come after renovations. It's a nice look. Very modern and a little higher class. I still like coming here because of having a fridge and a microwave and breakfast! (But now they charge you like a mandatory fee of $10 for destination fee? and I don't understand why that's just not included in your total cost if it's mandatory) Anyway, the rooms are all pretty different but have the same components. The room was clean and smelled fresh. Unfortunately, one of the mattress' was sinking on one side. If you're gonna do a reno, why not get new mattresses. Everything else was good. The staff was very friendly. Always said, welcome back when you came into the lobby. Check-in and check-out was quick and smooth. There are trolley things you can use yourself to carry your luggage to your room. I don't think there is a bellhop service.Up to the top floor where they have breakfast and the gym.Before reno, they had a lot more tables and a tv up there. But now, it has less tables and they got rid of the tv so there's even more room, but still less tables. So I don't understand why there is so much space but not a lot of tables/seats. Seems weird to me. Unfortunately, the breakfasts are getting less. There was only eggs and biscuits as hot food. I mean there was oatmeal that didn't look to appetizing. And of course, cereal, bagels, danishes, coffee, juice, waffles, etc. It seems very basic and slightly disappointing. Though it is better than complimentary breakfasts you get at chain hotels.Also the location of this hotel is great. Two blocks from inner harbor and from power plant live (a string of bars). Tip: don't get valet parking, it is super expensive. There's a parking garage right next door that is much cheaper.So I will look forward in coming back here!This is the third time I've been here, as my team always stays here for the dragonboat festival held by the Baltimore DragonBoat Club. The location of the hotel is great, it's two blocks away from the inner harbor and you have easy access to all the shops, bars, and major tourist destinations.The hotel had recently been renovated, and the lobby looks more welcoming, modern, and relaxing. They added a bar in the lobby, which is a nice touch, as it really draws everything together. The staff was extremely courteous and friendly, always welcoming us back whenever we came back from doing whatever we were doing.I don't know if they actually renovated the rooms though, because I don't really pay much attention to that. In general, I think all of the rooms were pretty decent, the bed was comfortable and it served the purpose of housing me over night. I've definitely been in hotels that were a lot worse.They also renovated the sky room (I think that's what it's called), so that there is more space to sit and view the city. They also added a fridge for their complementary breakfast - no more reaching into cold tubs of ice for your yogurt!Overall, I always have a good experience here. The only thing is that I wish they would include bacon or sausage with the complementary breakfast, but hey, I'll take what I can get.This place is a decent price for the location.  It's basically a 5 minute walk to the aquarium and surrounding area.  As of this review, the hotel is dated and the owners know it.  There's signs regarding a multimillion dollar renovation coming in the fall.  The lobby area is nice, but the hallways and living room area and kitchen (suites) is old.  The TVs are flat panel and beds are very comfortable.  The bathrooms are also a bit updated, which is nice.  Having a corner suite is the best because you have so many windows which make the room feel enormous.  I'd stay here again if I need to be in the area overnight again.I stayed at this hotel for a little getaway weekend downtown with a friend. I'm not big on chain hotels, so this seemed like the perfect fit for us. The rate was one of the best in the area, especially in that particular location. The staff was extremely nice and helpful and the rooms were very clean and well maintained. We were very conveniently located next to everything we wanted to visit including Mount Vernon, Federal Hill, and Inner Harbor. We were able to walk to many locations including the aquarium and many restaurants and great pubs. We loved Tir Na Nog (good food and drinks!) and all of the little shops in HarborPlace. I definitely recommend this hotel to anyone planning a visit to Baltimore.I stayed at the Brookshire Suites for two nights recently while on business. I thought the price was reasonable and the room size was generous (I'm thinking that the room was likely a one-bedroom apartment at some point). The location can't be beat for access to the Inner Harbour and Camden Yards. And I can't remember ever meeting more helpful and friendly staff. If ever I'm back in Baltimore, I'll be staying here.We had a conference group stay at Brookshire Suites and had such a wonderful experience! Great location and amenities, and the staff we worked with were absolutely great and very accommodating! Christine helped organize our group room block and was very attentive and flexible to our needs. She was fantastic, and we will be using Brookshire Suites again in the future!**Update** After I finished me whole stay I can say the only real problem is the parking.  Every time I pulled in I had a 5-10 minute wait in the cold until someone came out.  When I called down to bring the car around it was a 50/50 shot if someone would even pick up.  If you offer valet, especially a valet service the same price as the 5 star hotels around you, you should have an attendant stationed waiting to take cars at all times.  If you don't want to do that then offer self-park or discounted valet.  To charge the same price for parking as Monaco does is absurd.  They're all but rushing up to the door before you even stop to usher you inside. **End Update**I'll start by saying this hotel is worth the double digit price I paid for a one bedroom suite.  The room is really huge.  Aside from how large the room is and how cheap it is, I can confidently say the staff is really nice and the hotel seems to be incredibly clean.  In addition it is awesome that they take large-breed dogs so we can stay here with our Lab/Hound mix.Now to the downsides: the valet parking is really confusing and around the back of the building.  Its the same price as the parking at the nicer hotels in the same neighborhood that are right in front of the door.  Its really just drop off, and walk around the building to go check in.  You pull into the garage yourself.  There should be a bit of a discount on parking.The facility itself is really, really dated.  They say they're in the middle of updating, so we'll see how it looks when they're done.  If the furniture and decoration were the same quality, but more modern, I would have given them 4 stars.  Not because they're a 4 star hotel, but because they would have been a nice 3 star hotel.  As it stands they are a solid 3 star hotel in location, service, and amenities.  The quality of the furniture and decorations is more of a 2 star hotel.Other plusses: free breakfast and free internet.Once their renovation is complete I'll come back and see if it qualifies them for another star.My husband and I really enjoyed our stay here. We called to reserve a room and informed them that we could get a better price on a third party website, so they gave us the manager special. The room was discounted, we received free valet($29) and a $25 gift receipt to use at six locations near by of our choice. This location is pet friendly and doesn't charge a fee, so our little pup was happy to travel with us! Not much of a view of the inner harbor but the staff was very nice and attentive. Overall very satisfied.
review_content_20: Really disappointed. Small, noisy rooms and breakfast that often runs out (eggs and milk were out during our stay and when we just bought our own breakfast at Dunkin Donuts we ran up to grab a knife and there were no utensils out).Best hotel I've ever stayed at. Love the building and the staff! Modern style with a price that can't be beat. When I'm visiting Baltimore I'm not staying anywhere else.the bf and i stayed here for a last minute trip to Baltimore. i guess nobody plans for a funeral but this really has nothing to do with my review, i think...with little time to thoroughly research other places to stay, i was lured by the hotel website's pretty pictures and reasonable prices. needless to stay, if you bothered to pay attention to my 5-star rating, we were not disappointed...we booked a queen suite with a view for the price of almost 100 bucks a night and it was super spacious and stylishly furnished. the bed was cozy comfy. at my boyfriend's suggestion we grabbed a quick bite at the complimentary breakfast the hotel. it was decent and i was able to make myself a faux Sausage McMuffin and grab some juice and coffee. not that i care but the staff were super friendly and attentive enough to make me feel comfortable but not so attentive to make me feel uncomfortable. what can i say, i prefer an unassuming hotel staff.as for the parking, i was surprised about the strict downtown Baltimore street parking that is enforced 24/7. one night we found parking for 9 bucks like 1/4 mile away but that was after midnight and we had to be out of there early AND we had to walk to the hotel in like 20 degree weather. needless to say, we paid to park at the hotel the second night. there wasn't a parking attendant but it was in no way difficult to just park in the drive-up and notify someone at the front desk to park our car. the next morning the car was retrieved right away. easy-breezy...My boyfriend and I stayed here for one Saturday night. We had a work gathering/ party for his company to attend in the city, and with an open bar, we opted to crash at a local hotel instead of attempting the drive home. Especially with this arctic weather going on at the moment. Drunk driving= not cool! drunk driving in blizzard conditions= not cool and really dumb.Anywho, I chose the Brookshire Suites because the modern artsy look seemed like a nice change of pace and the reviews weren't half bad. Plus for the price, it couldn't be beat for the area. We picked a studio Queen room, with the Baltimore lovers package. This included cookies in the room upon arrival, free valet and a free suite upgrade if it was available. The cookies were delicious, free valet was definitely a plus since it's normally $36 a night. Which, is a smidge pricey. We did get a suite upgrade, which is fine, but that came with issues of its own.The lobby of the hotel is really nice, has a unique modern take to it. Check-in was painless, and the staff was very friendly and accommodating. After we checked in, we had enough time to go up and check out the room before heading to the party. Room was easy enough to find, on the eighth floor. However, those elevators feel, sound and look like a death trap, and they're exceptionally slow. It's apparent in the renovations of the hotel, the elevators were not included. The room was nice, spacious, clean and had plenty of windows. The view left something to be desired, but hey, Baltimore isn't exactly a pretty city anyways. The downside to the suite was discovered much, much, later in the night after we returned from our party. Apparently, the suites have dual heat zones. However, the one in the bedroom was completely turned off, and despite fiddling with it we could not get it to turn on. For all intents and purposes it appeared to be non-functioning. Thus, the bedroom was ice cold all night. Thanks to the gigantic windows in the room, I'd hazard a guess that it was very close to the temperatures outside. I cranked the living room one up way high, and kept the door between the two rooms open in an attempt to get some heat in there but my efforts were futile.After a very, very, chilly night, we awoke and went about getting ready to check out. When we went to turn out the bedroom lights, we discovered a clear plastic (against white walls) light switch hidden behind one of the bedside lamps. I flipped it assuming it would turn the lamp off, but lo and behold it turned the damned thermostat on. Never in our lives, have we seen nonsense like that, especially since the one in the living room was not set up the same way. Once it flipped on, the screen went berserk for a few minutes, and finally settled on a temperature. As the heat kicked on, the sounds and rattling noises it made were monstrous. Had we figured out how to turn it on in the middle of the night, there's no doubt that neither us, nor any of our neighbors would have been able to sleep over the racket. We left it on, in the hopes that the poor suckers who occupied the room after us wouldn't have to spend a night in the ice cold like we did.Moving on, part of the $9.95 mandatory "destination fee" they tack on is free wireless, gym/pool access and free breakfast.The gym was tiny, dated and worn in. Never saw the pool. Breakfast was horrendous, super meager selection, just very cold eggs, stale biscuits and gravy and make them yourself waffles. Plus the standard, cereal and toast bar. No bacon, no sausage, nothing of any value to actually fill you up. Plastic silverware and plates and throw away cups. For a hotel that claims to be modern, and Eco-friendly, the breakfast area is anything but. The tables were all filthy, trash and food bits everywhere. All in all, breakfast was miserable and I'm surprised we didn't end up sick. Our room only cost $118 with the Baltimore Lovers package, plus another $9.95 "destination fee" and some more in taxes. Total cost was $146 for the night. Since it was only one night, and it was cheaper than other area hotels, I'd say it wasn't a complete waste of money. However, had we been staying longer than one night, we'd have probably moved to a different hotel, even if it meant a slight increase in price,I stayed here because I wanted to enjoy a concert nearby and didn't want to drive back late at night. It's hard for me to find a hotel which is near the inner harbor, is nice, and is dog-friendly. This hotel fits it all, nice staff and the room was much larger than I expected, almost like a studio apartment. My view wasn't super nice (view of the adjacent roof top and alley), but what do you expect with a city view? The day I checked-in the internet was down due to a storm the previous night. I got back to the hotel late night, about 5 minutes before midnight which was just when the downstairs bar was closing but the bartender was nice enough to stay open for myself and another hotel guest. We all chatted and I enjoyed a beer, then went to sleep. I had a comfy sleep and was happy to have my pampered pooch by my side. Word of advice, the streets around the hotel can be a bit sketchy at night, and being a young female by myself I didn't feel very safe walking the 1.5 blocks from the concert venue to the hotel. I'd recommend walking back with a friend or asking the hotel for a taxi or escort. Overall had a good experience here.The brookshire suites suites was fine for the two nights I was in Baltimore, but was a bit odd. Most of the reason I'm writing is their seemingly bullshit fee structure. We chose the hotel because it was a bit less expensive than hotels in the same area, but once they've nickeled and dimed you the deal is 100% gone.  Their rates include a "destination fee" of $9.95 a night. I see people on yelp attributing that to a bunch of things (pool use, breakfast, etc.) and have no idea what the truth is. When we stayed, a sign at the front desk said something about it covering phone calls and bottled water.  Well, it's the age of the cell phone, and you only get 2 bottles of water with no additional bottles even though they charge the fee again the second night. So those bottles end up at about $9.95 a piece in our case. Yikes.  Bottom line: either charge for stuff specifically or raise your prices a little, Brookshire - people know when they're being had and they don't feel good about it.As other people mentioned, the couch cushions were weirdly slippery and There were what seemed like 2 million pictures of the singer from the counting crows.Lastly, our view was of the abandoned building next door. milk crates holding up a satellite dish, a smashed AC unit and broken-into windows.  Lovely...  I know the hotel can't control their neighbors but that detail just capped off the feeling that the hotel was a bit off.I stayed at Brookshire Suites in Baltimore this past June.  I was in town for the world premiere of my film at the B'More QFest, and Brookshire graciously hosted me (and the film's director) during our stay. The location of the hotel was terrific, and it's got a cool, fun vibe.  I was treated to a corner suite on the top floor, so the living area had a nice view (I could see my complimentary yacht parked in the harbor from the living area...just kidding, it wasn't complimentary, or my yacht).  We were able to walk to the harbor and had I worn better shoes, there were lots of nicer little shops around, as well. Prior to my stay, I contacted the manager about vegan options, and unfortunately, their complimentary breakfast was not vegan-friendly.  However, he sent me an extensive list of accommodating local eats, which was fantastic.  When I arrived and walked into the suite, I was so pleasantly surprised.  I've never been in a suite before, and this one was well appointed, clean and simple, yet contemporary and cool. And, bonus, there was a picture of Mama Cass watching over me above the toilet--my own private restroom angel (Adam Duritz' picture was above the couch, swoon).  And bless their hearts, there was a vase of fresh purple daisies (at least, I think they were daisies...I know movies, but don't know flowers), as well as a big, full bag of the most delicious vegan-friendly locally made granola I have ever tasted, compliments of the hotel, as well as a print out of the list of restaurants I had been sent earlier.  I felt so special.  There was more than enough space for me, and the bed was like a big hug and extremely comfortable after some very long flights and days.  The couch, although cool-looking isn't really the kind you'd jump onto to get cozy, or take a nap on because of the size and material (I slid off once...or twice, but I'm not that coordinated anyway), the bathroom was on the small side, and the water pressure could be a skosh better, BUT, HUGE bonus points because this hotel uses cruelty-free shower products!!  I love the thoughtfulness this hotel put into my stay, and how kind and accommodating the staff was.  It's not a pretentious or ultra-luxe hotel; it's a hotel that deserves thoughtful recommendation and one I'd stay at again.  It was lovely that they were a sponsor of the B'More QFest, and I was just happy to be treated as a special guest.Shocked this place only has 3 stars. I'm local but not local (not from Bmore but a little over a hour away) and I will DEFINITELY stay here again. This hotel has class and swag (so what if you hate that word). The staff was exceptional, honestly. Nate or Nathaniel at the front desk was 5 star the night I checked in. The deal I got from Expedia was great. (used current available promo code for installing their mobile app and got 10 percent off an already reasonable rate). The room was f*cking amazing. The staff was excellent. My only issue was out of the hotel's hand and it involved parking. Pretty much everything in the vicinity is garage parking at $16 daily on weekends.The location is so close to inner harbor that I could see water from out 4th floor window.  The front desk and staff were great and their hot breakfast was a welcomed treat the next morning, I'm talking waffle iron to yogurt and eggs.  The breakfast made the extra fee per night worth it.  My only complaint would be the weird pictures everywhere, I know they want a modern look and all the the guy from the counting crows doesn't have to be watching me in the bathroom.The pictures posted on this business are way outdated. They have refurbished this hotel in a tasteful but hip manner. My room was upgraded to executive queen when my 1 bedroom king was not available. The staff are young and serious about providing great service. For my  visit it was a special occasion and the staff here did not hesitate in helping me piece everything together for me. From opening a wine bottle to actually selling me the wine and providing me with wine glasses. My room is very comfortable with a view of the harbor from my window. The bed is nice. They do provide a breakfast every morning which has a little something for everybody. It is not a IHOP restaurant but it does serve the purpose. So far my stay here has been delightful and I will return again and again.We won't stay there never again. I have to say the location is good because is close to the harbor and the staff is very attentive. But they really really need to do something about this place. First our view from the window was a brick wall(im not kidding) and the a/c was not working well so we had a really bad night didnt rest at all. Also they need new windows and remodel the bathrooms. The tvs are nice, new and good size but the room was not that great ugly pictures on the walls. BAD EXPERIENCE!!The one star goes to their decent breakfast service. Aside from that, I was disappointed with my stay based on the reasons as follows:The walls are extremely thin in this place especially when your room is in the corner (which is where they usually put those who booked the hotel with a special rate, I suppose). I got so annoyed with the sound of the door banging shut from my next door neighbor that I decided to change my room around 11PM. Even then, voila, they put me in same room in the corner on a different floor. Thank goodness my new neighbor was somewhat quieter, otherwise I might've tried something interesting.Other cons for this hotel: 1) For whatever reason, they disconnect the phone on the desk so you have to really check the connection and fix it yourself before you can make a call. This happened in both of my rooms. Weird...2) The Hotel staff isn't always present at the front desk. I had to call 2-3 times before someone finally answered my call.3) The biggest reason of all--there is a HUGE lack of professionalism and integrity at this hotel. Why? I booked this hotel as an out-of-towner for a business reason, and I specifically needed a transportation to get to my location. I checked with them at least 4 times to make sure it's comp'd by the hotel and they confirmed that with me each time. When the day came, I had to pay out of my own pocket. I called the hotel, got transferred to the manager who wasn't present, left a voicemail demanding the be refunded for my cab fare only to never receive a call back from them. Wtf? All in all, this hotel is similar to my experience with the ghetto-hole-in-the-wall-from-hell-Baymont Suites and Inn in Cedar Rapids in that, despite the nicely decorated facade, it really is just another motel with a crappy service. Needless to say, I won't ever stay there again.I stayed here for two nights, in a one bedroom king room. Plus points:Great location nearest to harborFriendly staff all aroundGood value on the larger roomsClean, good air conditioningVery soundproofBreakfast "included" - see belowValet parkingMinus:A little datedSmall rooms other than the full suitesForced to pay extra ($10!!) for the included breakfast which is total shit qualityLocation is good but difficult to negotiate in a vehicleSuper tight squeeze when parking for valet or loading/unloadingSelf-parking sucksHomeless people passed out in side alleyAnd the big minus: It's BALTIMORE. Don't go out wandering at night even around the hotel. This city is not what I expected. You can't go anywhere without piles of sketchy people peering at you.They know you aren't from around there. Anywhere outside of the immediate inner harbor, stay out of. Don't drive with a visible GPS. This hotel will be undergoing a huge reno over the next year or so... if I ever go back to Bmore, which will probably be never, hah, I would stay here again.Of course, this is *not* a four-star hotel. But it earns the four stars because it does what it is supposed to do very well.First off: location and price. It's an easy walk to the Inner Harbor, aquarium and convention center and Camden Yards is also walk-able if you're up for it. It is diagonal from the Renaissance Harborplace, which is probably the best property in the area. Yet booking a weeknight room the night before only ran me $120, not including $30 to valet. The Harborplace was going for $330 that same night.For such a disparity in price I surely expected letdowns or things that struck me as sketchy. Not at all. The staff was cordial and helpful. The room was clean, the wi-fi kicked ass and the complimentary breakfast - on the top floor, with an amazing view of the city - was passable. If they had a nice oatmeal option, it would've been right on par with what you'd expect at a Residence or Fairfield Inn, or on the concierge level of a Marriott. While this was a leisure trip, I would have been more than comfortable working in the room. Sure, there were funky elements to the place, and I would definitely request a room on a higher floor, as another site recommended, due to street traffic.But Baltimore is a tough hotel town; not a lot of inventory, which drives the prices up, and the surroundings in some spots can be sketchy. With all that in mind, the Brookshire seems like a real find and I'd definitely come back.Hotel was clean (except for a small stain in the comforter, but it was the only imperfection I found so I can let it slide).  The hotel itself seemed clean and the staff was friendly.  The front desk always greeted us with a good morning whenever we were leaving or coming in.  The shampoo and lotion are from bath and body works so that's nice.  Shower pressure was great.  Only negative was that there wasn't enough places to hang towels, so hand towels were just kind of laid on the counter.  Bed was too firm for me and just a little uncomfortable.  Our nice and quiet room was fine.  Free wifi is always a plus too.Breakfast:  Breakfast wasn't amazing, but it has a great variety that you're bound to find something you can eat.  Eggs, sausage, make-it-yourself waffles, bagels, toast, cereal, yogurt, coffee, and juice.  Parking:if you plan to use their parking, it is $29 per day which is horrible.  that's where the minus 1 star comes from.  but the valets themselves are quite efficient and will get your car for you in advance if you call ahead. Pet: we also did bring our dog and the staff was very warm and welcoming to our dog.  however, there weren't any nice additives that we've found in other pet-friendly hotels.  no dog bed or bowls, and only one person at the front desk even mentioned that they had dog treats.I liked this place.  It wasn't a shiny new high rise and didn't have many fancy bells & whistles, but for $109 for a two bedroom suite, it was most acceptable.What really made a difference was service.  It was warm, friendly, down to earth, and extremely accommodating from the valet, front desk folk to the bartender in the cloud level lounge and the breakfast staff.Yes the valet was pricey but we are used to paying much higher prices in Chicago and NY so we took that in stride.  Besides, included in our suite price, was complimentary happy hour which included beer and wine with appetizers (2 drinks p/p), and a full, hot/cold breakfast buffet.The rooms definitely were a bit dated and the ceilings were low, but it was quiet and the bed was super comfortable.  If I was expecting the Ritz than of course I would have been disappointed, but we knew we were booking an older hotel with less amenities than a higher priced chain property.The top level lounge, surrounded by windows, even afforded you a peek of the waterfront.   It was open 24 hours, so guests could read, play cards, or partake in happy hour and/or breakfast.As others said, the location was perfect.  We were going to the Bob Seger concert, so even though this was a stone's throw to the Inner Harbor, it was also a quick walk to the 1st Mariner Arena.  It's amazing how a great hotel staff can transform an experience.  It did for us.Awesome room updated and extremely clean.  Just one stupid destation fee so you pay 9.95 for bottled water and breakfast.Stayed here for the night when Hurricaine Sandy was in town.  My job was putting people up in hotel rooms so that we would be able to get into work =P  Although some of the hotel looks aged, it was a nice hotel overall!  Rooms were very spacious - I had a double, which also had a sofa, coffee table, desk, chair, microwave, and mini fridge.  The bed was comfortable and the sheets clean.  The best part is probably the free HOT breakfast.  There is no restaurant in the hotel, but there were some frozen and non-perishable items in their lobby.This hotel was recently purchased out of foreclosure. The hotel will be completing a multi million dollar renovation this winter. The team is amazing and so will the hotel be once renovated. It's good clean large rooms now, just a bit dated, but clean.We loved the decor. very modern and spacious. The only complaint is that the windows do not block out the loud city outside.
review_content_40: Pros: The location is outstanding, one block from the Inner Harbor. The staff is very friendly. The rooms are clean and comfortable. The wifi signal was strong in our room. Good bang for your buck.Cons: Their "Baltimore rock n roll" theme runs thin ... I don't need a photo of the guy from Counting Crows in the bathroom. The breakfast was kinda weak. We got a suite, and the leather couch was annoying (the leather was so slick that the back cushions kept sliding off the couch). We needed to jiggle the handle on our toilet. If this was just a normal hotel with normal decor and furniture, it'd easily be four stars.I read a lot of hotel reviews before settling on the Brookshire, so I knew what to expect when I walked in. I'm still chuckling over the reviewers who were upset about having to lay eyes upon the less fortunate nearby; if you're afraid of homeless people, maybe you should never visit a major city and definitely don't ever visit San Francisco. I for one thought it was a nice change that the area didn't smell like pee. Seriously, the location was great. Safe area, cheap parking and lots of fun stuff to do nearby. A stone's throw from the Inner Harbor, walking distance to great restaurants and shops, as well as the famed Baltimore Aquarium. A short walk to a nearby liquor store got us a reasonable amount of delicious Yuengling (if you're from the area, you know, and if you don't, I suggest you familiarize yourself with this delicious lager). I felt very safe in the area and had no problems.The hotel itself, as has been said, is in dire need of upgrades. The lobby was really pretty and fairly modern, but once I got to our floor I was glad I'd prepared myself by looking at the photos, because the decor is extremely dated. It's clean and looks nice for what it is, but it's reminiscent of a bygone era when taste was in short supply. Even though I hadn't asked for it, we got a suite, which was nice but we didn't really use the living area (except to store the aforementioned Yuengling). Still, it was nice to have a fridge, microwave, coffee maker, and lots of storage space. The bed was comfortable and the water pressure was great and heated up quickly. We had a small problem with the tub clogging, but it was minor.The wallpaper had scuff marks and the carpet was faded, but they're about to start upgrading all the rooms, so I'm sure they'll look fabulous once they're done. I was a little disappointed with the view, but a hotel right on the water was prohibitively expensive. Being close enough to walk there was nice, though. They offer valet parking for $35, which is worth it if you're afraid of city driving or don't know where to park, but all they do is park it in a nearby garage which is $19 a night. It's near the hotel on Lombard (Arrow Parking) and it's about as secure as you're going to get. Leave the car empty and remove your stereo faceplate and you should be fine.I give the staff five stars. Everyone I spoke to was extremely friendly and accommodating, and I never wanted for anything. They have a 24-hour convenience store and complimentary breakfast and in-room wi-fi, but we didn't use any of those so I can't speak to how good they are. When I come back to Baltimore I'll definitely consider Brookshire again.Large rooms, plenty of hot water, and decent enough beds.  We could have used more towels and the place could definitely have been cleaner.  This is an older hotel and it really could use some attention.  The breakfast is fine, but they really good put some more effort into it.  The location is great and they are pet friendly.Room was spacious, nice centrally placed TV, great view to see the harbour. In addition, the staff are very friendly and helpful.The hotel is in walking distance to the harbor but, that's the only positive. We only stayed one night and the bed was clean but everything else looked warn and dingy in the room. Our bathtub had water sitting in it when we arrived. Yuck.Staff great! Rooms are older but they plan to remodel. That is when I will come backThe fabulous:(1) Location, location, location. 2 minute walk to the Harbor, and 0.4 miles from Power Plant Live (where Ram's Head is for you music fans like me). (2) The view from the room(3) The view from the Cloud Club(4) One free beer or wine every night between 5:30pm to 7:00pm(5) The price, at $76.00 per night base and $100.00 per night total(6) Free DSL in the room with no annoying log-in pageThe good:(1) There is valet available(2) Very friendly staff(3) Laid back atmosphere(4) Breakfast provided in the mornings (did not actually eat it)The pppppppptttttbbbbbbbbbb:(1) The valet costs $29.00 per day. Yikes!(2) Lumpy pillows and too-soft mattress*(3) Outdated decor in a tiny room*(4) Occasional sewage-like mystery smells in the elevator* I'll qualify this by saying that I made my reservation for 2 nights through Expedia for the weekend after Thanksgiving about 1.5 hours before I arrived, and Expedia said there were only 4 rooms left. I am guessing I got a bottom-of-the-barrel room.If I had another weekend adventure in Baltimore, I would definitely stay again. You just cannot beat the convenience for the price here.Be ready to be GOUGED. I had a 2 night stay at this hotel and made a reservation through their own website. I chose this place because they did accept pets and the location and the final quoted price was $225.50, which seemed like a good deal. Somehow on this price they left out the pet fee of $35, daily destination fee of $10 (pays for that complimentary breakfast, wifi, and treadmill), daily cleaning fee of $10, and daily valet fee of $36.  This takes nickel and diming to a whole new level and somehow their reservation software included none of it. My final bill ended at $354 for 2 nights and had to be emailed to me since "their printer wasn't working."I stayed at the Brookshire while attending a conference held at the (much more expensive) Marriott in the Inner Harbor.  I'm giving it three stars only because it was by FAR the best deal in the area, at least at the time I booked it.  Otherwise, it was basically a two-star kind of experience -- maybe two and a half, tops.On the positive side, the people at the front desk were friendly and helpful.  The shower was great -- plenty of hot water, excellent water pressure, etc.  And there's a free breakfast in the mornings, although I can't say how good it was, since I had breakfast at the conference each morning.That said, the building feels very old and run down.  The rooms need paint and carpet cleaning.  The air conditioning didn't work very well, and even worse, the walls were SO thin.  I mean, most hotels are kind of loud, but this place was amazingly loud -- I could clearly hear conversations in other rooms, TVs in other rooms, etc.  I was also woken up again and again by police sirens and by people walking around outside the hotel. I'd stay here again, honestly, if I had to be in the neighborhood -- but only for the deal.Just dark,dirty and kinda gross (broken chairs,broken coffee maker,stained rug,phone doesn't work). I was traveling for a trade show and had to stay here because I was traveling with a group.The lock didn't work on my room door so I had to put a huge chair in front of the door. My room was located right next to the stairs facing Lombard Street so between the loud sirens and being a nervous wreck I would be murdered, not a pleasant stay. I personally didn't see any "bugs" but someone in our group did. The staff was nice and the only reason for the one star.Warm welcome, staff was friendly and available. Bed was comfy. Breakfast was good.  2 blocks from Inner Harbor.  Only issue was there was no fold out bed in sofa as expected when the kids went to go to bed.  They gave us a fold up bed we put on the floor for 1 and thankfully we had an air mattress for the other.  They did give us a refund for their oversight.I stayed at this hotel a few weeks ago and was impressed by the very friendly staff here.I flew in from LAX and my plane landed at 6 am. I got to the hotel at 7 am and they were able to get me into a room with early check in at no cost (which is great since it was 4 am my time and I was dead tired)The have wine tasting every night and a full breakfast every morning for free. Also - Free WiFi and bottles of water. I cannot remember the last time I have stayed in a hotel that did not charge you $4 for the bottle of water they leave in your room.Great prices - nice staff. I will stay here again.Great huge suite I got with a groupon coupon. Large bedroom and living room. Breakfast is included.We had a great experience at this hotel recently. We got a one bedroom suite with kitchen. It was in the back and very private. We appreciated that at night, as it was nice and quiet. My 3 year old enjoyed the coin game. She managed to collect 20 coins over 4 days, resulting in 4 toys from the treasure chest. Our room was clean and the staff was incredibly nice and very gracious. We had a free drink of choice in the Cloud Club every night between 5:30 and 7 PM. There's a nice view from there out floor to ceiling windows. Overall, my eval is as follows:PROS -- Great value overall, inexpensive, great location, super friendly and accommodating staff, flat screen TV's, family friendly (kids and pets alike)CONS -- remote controls were awful, low ceilingsBottom line is that you get a lot of bang for your buck at this hotel. We got a package with discounted tickets for the aquarium, port discovery museum and science center. They have shuttle service on-demand for popular destinations and between the harbor magic hotels. We even got our 3rd night free. So, we ended paying about $200 a night TOTAL (attraction tickets included.) We would have paid $400 EASY for a one-bedroom suite at one of the other Inner Harbor hotels. If you don't need somewhere extravagant and are realistic in your expectations, this hotel is a good value for the money.The price was fantastic but that's pretty much where the "magic" stopped... The proximity to the harbour, the aquarium and the various ships was pretty good, as the hotel is only a couple of blocks away from all of those.The front desk staff were friendly and helpful but the hotel itself is very run down. The carpets in the room had a dirty, musty smell to them. The bathroom floor was sticky. (I kept my shoes on the whole time I was there...)There were a couple of burned out bulbs and everything looked old and uncleaned. The bed and the pillows were the most uncomfortable I've ever slept on, and that includes camping and hostels. I ended up taking one of my clothes bags and stuffing that with some clothes to be my pillow.The breakfast was disgusting. The eggs were mushy and tasted like they'd been reheated from previous days.The hotel itself used to be a parkade, which probably explains why it has such a cramped feeling, but it also means the walls are paper thin - including the outside walls. I was on the fifth floor, but the noise from the traffic and people outside was so clear I may as well have been sleeping on the street.This is probably one of those "you get what you pay for" situations which, in most cases, is acceptable. Unfortunately, for what you get the low low price doesn't quite make up for it.Stay as far away from this hotel as you can, the worst hotel I have ever stayed in. You basically have to ask ten times if u want something the second night of my stay they turned the air off in the bedroom, with 90 degree heat outside. Watch out for the hidden costs on your bill my room was $99 a night two nights hidden costs the bill was $318 for the two nights avoid this place.I loved the hotel but there is one thing to remember.   Never stay on the side of the hotel with the subway on the street. At 0230 in the morning the bars let out and the subway is 24 hours.  Drunk people + food= no sleep for youI recently purchased a Groupon deal for a one night stay. Me and a friend checked in on Friday night. The Groupon included free valet and a $25 gift card to a local restaurant. Upon arriving at the hotel two cars were parked in the valet location, making it hard for us to squeeze our car in so that we wouldn't hang out on the busy street.  The hotel was beautifully decorated. The decor was purple and the couches were unique. The tree was very nicely decorated and festive. The front desk clerk got us checked in and explained the drink tickets and breakfast to us and we were on our way to our room. The elevators were slow. So slow we considered taking the stairs. The room was smaller than I thought. The decor was a little dated. I was pleased to see that they used Eco friendly products for the toiletries.  Later that night we decided to order a movie. We had to call the front desk to get the restriction for ordering movies lifted. Once we did that we ordered the movie. Being that it was late we fell asleep on it. The next morning I tried to rewind, but that button didn't work on the remote and it shut the TV off. After numerous tries I gave up. I ended up wasting $15.00 on a movie I could have seen on my netflix when I returned home. Around 10:00 the maid started hounding us to come clean the room. We informed her that we were in there and would be checking out at 12:00. Unfortunately she didn't  wasn't satisfied with that. She returned FOUR times even when we put the "Shh I'm sleeping" sign out. I really can't comprehend why she would disturb us when checkout is at 12:00. This was a major problem for me. Upon checking out the front desk held our bags while we shopped at the gallery.Over all the trip was great. However the movie and maid situation has me considering other hotels when I visit Baltimore.  The locations is amazing. It is in close proximity to the necessities of Baltimore.Just returned from a Sunday-Monday trip to Baltimore with the family to checkout the Inner Harbor.  Got the Groupon deal and was very happy with this place.We arrived at noonish and were told no rooms were ready, which was non unexpected and understandable.  However, the Manager was there and immediately said to put us in a one bedroom suite on the 11th floor.Like other have said, it's not the Ritz but the room was nice. Very comfy queen bed and a "not-so-comfy" pull-out-couch (good for the kids).The shower water was HOT and good pressure and the entire room was quite clean with plenty of towels.My ONLY issue that people need to know is the street noise is very noticable (to say the least).  I am not a light sleeper but I was awakened several times by the horns/sirens and our room was on the top floor facing Lombard St (front of the hotel). The windows were old and the ones that opened were unable to be completely closed due to broken handles and age.  If you are a light sleeper, insist on a "non-front" room.The breakfast was like going to a Hampton Inn, which is decent for the price.  The Club Room on the 12th floor is really nice.  Would like to come back for a M-F happy hour.The service was great, from the front-desk to the Valet, to the food staff.Highly recommend this place.The location and price were fantastic, with the Brookshire being way cheaper than other Inner Harbor hotels.  We could see the Inner Harbor from our room, and the top of the warehouse at Camden Yards.  Inner Harbor was a very quick walk from the front door.There is a $10 fee called "Entertainment fee" which pays for the breakfast, bottles of water in the room, the shuttle to the other 2 hotels (Pier 5 and Admiral Fell) which runs all day until 10pm, and you can go to anything going on at the other 2 hotels.  We took the shuttle to Pier 5 more than once and had a walk around Little Italy, and also attended their Chocolate Fountain hour, which was on a Saturday afternoon.  The shuttle also brought us to Admiral Fell, which is right in the middle of Fell's Point, so it was a great place to walk around and for nightlife.The breakfast was alright, the eggs were a bit bland and probably powdered, the orange juice was gross, but there were 4 juices to choose from so cranberry saved me.  All three mornings, breakfast was the same exact thing - eggs, french toast, bacon and sausage, as well as cereals, bread and some nice fruit.Our floor's hallway reeked of smoke despite no smoking signs everywhere as well.Overall, I would say it was decent, I would stay here again, the location is perfect and the shuttle is great to get to other areas worth visiting.
review_content_60: I got a great deal on a room here and decided to try it out. The staff were exceptionally helpful. When the television in my room didn't work at 6AM, they promptly offered to move me to a larger suite at no cost. The breakfasts and snackable dinners, along with free drink tickets, make the place even sweeter. The location is ideal for a walking traveler.Let me start by saying i have lived in tents in Iraq without running water and would rather take my family there.  I came to Baltimore because my daughter needed surgery. I picked this hotel because it was close to the hospital. I could not sign in on the first day because of some medical stuff. I called in and explained my situation and they told me I already paid for the hotel so checking in didn't really matter. Ok two days later I show up to take a shower and check the place out. $30 to park are you kidding me? The lady at the front desk lectures me about smoking in my room, while she and the lobby smell like a bar. I go to the elevator and it smells like bad eggs, both elevators. I get to my floor and everything is purple. Yuck! I get to my room haven't showered in three days and get in the shower and feel grosser getting out then when I went in. Remote didn't work and room was to small so I leave and get back to my family. Me and my wife decide it was more comfortable to sleep in a folding chair in the hospital then in our hotel. Find out that the surgery is not going to get fully done now so have to leave the room early. The manager after hearing why tells me not my problem and makes me pay for the full time. Sleep in the street before this hotel. Motel 6 better.I've stayed at this hotel now on two different occasions, it's a great location relative to the harbor and the convention center and it is not nearly as harmful on your pocketbook as most of the other hotels in the area.  It's not uber-luxurious but it is a nice, solid, safe hotel with very professional and courteous staff. They have valet parking but no front-entrance driveway, which can be a little dicey when loading/unloading from your car, as it means you just have to pull over to the curb.  Definitely be careful there.I stayed here with three friends...hmmm...had to be three years ago this coming October.  We were most impressed , I think, with the pleasant, accomodating staff.   We'd arrived from NYC earlier than check-in, but just as breakfast was being cleared; the staff not only hung onto our stuff, but arranged for the remains of the breakfast to be held (We were starving!).  Our wheelchair-accessible rooms were well-appointed, complete with mini-bars.  The hotel's conveniently located within walking distance of most sights; we had no problems except for the rain one night.  The neighborhood seems pleasant enough.All in all, it was a pleasant enough experience that I'm strongly considering staying there again when I return to Charm City this summer.DO NOT STAY HERE!  If you must, bring a Costco-size amount of hand sanitizer.  This was the only hotel I could find that accepts pets, and I wanted to bring my dog to a week-long meeting in Baltimore (now I wish I'd chosen the Hilton further away).  When I arrived, I had no trouble checking in.  I was told I'd receive a dog travel kit (advertised on their website and repeated when I called), so I didn't bother bringing food bowls.  When I arrived, I was told they had none.As soon as I got on the elevator, I knew there'd be a problem.  It looks like it was installed the year elevators were invented and hasn't been updated since (that's also the way I'd describe its performance).  I was staying in a suite on the 5th floor, which had the same feel as the elevator.  It was dank and disgusting.  I was hesitant to put my bags down and I didn't remove the plastic bag from my suits. I ordered room service, which comes from Mo's.  When I picked up the phone and pressed the room service button, it didn't work.  One phone didn't work at all, and it took 5 times on the second to register all the numbers.  The TV was fuzzy.  The remote barely worked, and the channel selection was poor (oh Bravo how I missed you).  I should've picked something up because it took 1.5 hours to arrive and was cold.  The crab cake was filled with shell.  I couldn't eat it.  I went to bed hungry in sheets that had holes in them.  I couldn't stop coughing in the musty air.I told the staff that my dog would be in daycare from 7-7, so the room could be cleaned during that  time.  They told me to put a sign on my door telling staff I had a dog, but didn't provide it (nor did they give me a privacy sign).  I checked in on Monday, and no one cleaned my room on Tuesday.  The shower dripped, and it didn't drain so I stood in a pool on Tuesday morning.  I informed the front desk, but it was never fixed.  The towels were rough.  I'd asked for a robe through their pre-stay especialist service, (although given the accommodations I'm not sure I would've used it) but it never arrived.  Why send me two especialist emails, if neither of the two things I asked for were going to materialize (the dog travel kit and the bathrobe)?  I even called to confirm when I was forced to book an additional day.  By the way, they couldn't modify my reservation, I was forced to make a second reservation for the additional day and they couldn't guarantee I'd get the same room.On Wednesday my room was cleaned, but it smelled like sewage when I arrived after midnight.  I thought I must've forgotten to take out the trash, but I was never able to determine the source of the smell.  It finally dissipated after I turned off the air conditioning.  Obviously in late June, this was a less than ideal option.  When my room was cleaned, my bath mat disappeared never to return again.On Thursday, maid service dropped by at 5:30 p.m. to clean the room.  No, thank you.  Why bother at 5:30?  It took a few times to communicate that I was declining cleaning service.  On Friday, I couldn't get away fast enough!  At a former job, I was sent to an Econolodge, and when I entered my room, I rolled over a cockroach.  That was the worst hotel I've ever stayed in, but this was a very close second.  There was no free parking, but there's a garage across the street.  The location is good (especially for the price), but it's still not worth it.  I didn't attend any events, try any food, or take the shuttle.My boyfriend & I came to Baltimore to celebrate our Anniversary. Staff got us upgraded to a nice King size bed suite! Staff was very friendly and helpful. The air condition was broke when we arrived but thankfully, they had it up and running within a few hours. This is a block away from the Inner Harbor and a great location! Parking is on the expensive side...Not surprised by that. The continental breakfast was awesome! They had a make your own waffle station which was SO good! Only problem- you could hear the traffic right outside the window. Other then that- great deal!Parking update. F the valet, its now $34 because they added a 16% parking tax. Your best bet is to park in the garage on Lombard just before you get to the hotel. Their 24 hr max rate is $18.We booked this hotel the day before we wanted to stay there ... we got some last-minute Orioles tickets and wanted to stay at a hotel in the Inner Harbor area. Pros:* With a one-night stay in a king bed room, it came out to about $130 after tax, which was not too bad for a tourist area. * You're a stone's throw away from the shops and restaurants in the Inner Harbor, and about a 10-minute walk from Camden Yards, so it's quite convenient. Cons:* They don't validate parking or provide a lot, so you need to find your own. We parked in a lot across the street ("The Gallery" for Renaissance Hotels, I think) and wound up paying over $40 for less than 24 hours of parking. They have valet which is about $27, I think (not sure if that includes a lot fee on top of that). * Once we checked in, we were immediately charged an additional $10. I think that only included Internet in the room - which wasn't wireless, you needed to plug into an Ethernet cable - and two bottles of Poland Spring water. * The room was quite small. We were also facing the street that looks out on the Inner Harbor, and there was construction going on for most of the night. That, paired with the regular traffic, made the room quite noisy for the duration of our stay. * The air conditioner barely worked, which wasn't too pleasant on a muggy August night. Not very comfortable. * The television was hard to operate and many channels were fuzzy. * The breakfast the next day wasn't very good. The scrambled eggs tasted like the fake ones you get from McDonald's (maybe made from powdered eggs). * The checkout line the next morning was long, because there was only one clerk at the front desk. Luckily someone else asked if we wanted to do "express checkout," which consisted of us just handing them the printout we'd gotten at check-in. They asked if there was a problem with the bill, we said no, and that was that. Good thing we didn't wait on that whole line for a five-second process. I don't think we'd go back if we can help it. If you're in need of a quick hotel room near the Inner Harbor, and you're not picky, this place will probably do. It wouldn't be my first choice, though.I stayed here this weekend with my boyfriend and booked through living social/groupon. I bought this as a valentines day get away thinking that it would be a nice romantic little getaway. I should have known from the minute I walked into that old run down elevator things would only get worse from there!Upon getting to the hotel I thought how nice the lobby looked, and the use of colors were pretty cool... However, by the time we both arrived to our floor I started to notice things weren't right. The ceiling was so low that my boyfriend almost had to duck down, I thought that I had entered a land for short people, as I am only 5'3" and I couldn't help but chuckle at first. When we opened the door I found to my horror that the "Suite" I had upgraded to for an extra fee (which wasn't a huge deal to begin with) was run down, dark and depressing with little light, and down right disgusting and unclean. The walls were beat up, the carpets smelled funny and had stains, and I kid you not... had water damage EVERYWHERE. The bathroom was even worse, as they had cut one of the vents in half to fit in the bathroom, put a hole in the wall to fit the shower head, and just small and stuffy!  I was horrified and a bit embarrassed that I had taken my boyfriend to this dump! I've stayed in motel 6's nicer than this place! To top it off, the service of this place was just as horrible, it took us 3 hours to get our bags from the valet, and the lady at the front desk seemed drunk in the morning. Please save yourselves from this horrible place!

review_content: This is a beautiful hotel. I've had two stays now and it's definitely top class. I had a standard room on the first visit and a really nice suite on the second. Kind of crazy that my hotel room had more bathrooms than my apartment! The views are beautiful, the staff is friendly and helpful, the food at Wit and Wisdom is really good, and everything is sparkling new and clean. There's kind of a strange smell in the lobby (kinda like a BBQ smokehouse), but I can overlook that for all the positives that the Four Seasons has to offer.Pro tip: Stay on someone else's dime!The four seasons Baltimore is the highest end hotel in Fells Point. Thus you are surrounded by a certain level of clientele, resulting in decent but somewhat pretentious service. The grounds and rooms are stunning. This location is new and the design is flawless. The spa is gorgeous and my favorite in Baltimore with experience showers, lounging jacuzzis, and heated seats. My actual service (massage) was not too impressive.
